title: TIGHTER CASH RULE ON THRIFT UNITS SET
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today it was tightening up on the amount of cash and nearcash which Federally insured savings and loan associations must keep on hand.

title: Dale Next Berra To Bear Watching
description: Everywhere else, he may be known as the former New York Yankee catching great and now the manager of the New York Mets. But in Montclair, he's simply the father of those Berra boys. boys.

title: WellStacked Liners on Wane at Port Here
description: The days of wellstacked liners in the port are numbered.

title: FORD MOTOR LISTS 10.6MILLION LOSS
description: DETROIT, April 30The Ford Motor Company reported today a loss of $10.6million for the first quarter of 1975, compared with net income of $123.6million, or $1.31 a share, in the same period a year ago.

title: Ford Delays Oil Fee Rise, But Will End Price Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, April 30In another prod to Congress to enact comprehensive energy legislation, the White House announced today that President Ford was again deferring an increase in the special fee on imported crude oil but that he was starting an administrative process that could end all price controls on domestic crude oil in two years.

title: Brandeis Students Defy Order From Judge to Vacate Building
description: WALTHAM, Mass., April 30 (AP)Despite a court order requiring them to leave, a small band of Brandeis University students continued tonight to occupy a campus building in protest to planned cuts in the university budget.

title: Advertising
description: Remember Weekend Kick off, which was going to be a weekly, 10millioncirculation magazine distributed as a newspaper supplement during the football season? That's right, the one that suspended publication last November because of a lack of advertiser support.

title: Derby Week: Festival of Juleps, Boom Prices and In Crowd
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30At the preDerby cocktail parties, the millionaire horse owners try hard not to let their vanity show.

title: LawyerPianist Is Persuasive in Recital
description: Robert Miller, the extraordinary pianist who spends most of his days working as an attorney in Wall Street, ended his series of three Alice Tully Hall recitals on Tuesday night with a program consisting of Aaron Copland's Variations (1930). Elliott Carter's Piano Sonata (194546), Roger Sessions' Second Sonata (1946) and the premiere of Milton Babitt's Reflections (197475).

title: Chess:
SAIGON REDS LOOK TO NONALIGNMENT
description: PARIS, April 30The war in Vietnam is over, the Provisional Revolutionary Government said here today in a statement hailing a victory of historic significance for the South Vietnamese Population.

title: HEALTH LEGISLATION PUSHED BY LEADERS
description: Governor Carey, Mayor Beame, many of the state's top health officials and some of the country's top labor leaders gathered at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night to spearhead a campaign to make full, free. medical care a fundamental right of American citizenry.

title: Unconventional Tactics Paid Off for the North
description: North Vietnam's victory in the South was achieved by conventional forces using unorthodox tactics against forces theoretically superior in numbers, air power and advanced weapons. The last and most decisive campaign of a war that has sparked and sputtered in Indochina since the Vietminh rose against the French in 1945 went to an army able to deploy forces superior in numbers and drive in every critical engagement, from Ban Me Thuot to Bien Hoa.

title: Mets Fall As String Ends at 7
description: CHICAGO, April 330The Cubs beat the Mets today, 74, before a sparse assembly of 4,820 paying observers in 59yearold Wrigley Field and thus ended the Mets' winning streak at seven games. In reflection Yogi Berra, the Mets' manager, said that after all he didn't expect to win them all.

title: Chase Manhattan REIT Gives Banks New Credit Plan
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, the nation's largest real estate investment trust, said yesterday that a comprehensive plan had been presented to its creditor banks for restructuring the trust's credit agreements under which it currently has borrowed $761million. Reuters reports.

title: SENATORS RETAIN BUDGET GUIDELINE
description: WASHINGTON, April 30A centrist coalition in the Senate decisively defeated today attempts by both liberals and conservatives to amend the budget guidelines that have been set by the Senate Budget Committee.

title: HOUSE UNIT REJECTS VOTING RIGHTS SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)The House Judiciary Committee yesterday narrowly defeated on a tie vote an amendment to all six Southern states and a number of counties in other areas to withdraw from coverage under the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: Derby Week: Horses, Juleps, Boom Prices and In Crowd
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30At the preDerby cocktail parties, the millionaire horse owners try hard not to let their vanity show.

title: Mandatory Death Penalty
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 30 (UPI)A Superior Court jury convicted Robert Cline, a prison inmate, of first degree murder today under a mandatory death penalty law. He cold be the first person in Rhode Island to be put to death in more than 100 years. Mr. Cline, 23 years old, was accused of killing Frank A. Pirri, a Bristol fish peddler, in the parking lot of Providence housing project on April 11, 1974, while he was an escapee.

title: High South Korean Discounts Impact of Vietnam's Collapse
description: SEOUL, South Korea, April 30Foreign Minister Kim Dong Jo said today that his Government was unconcerned by the fall of Vietnam to the Communists and was confident that the United States would honor its commitment to defend South Korea.

title: Profiles of 4 Marines Lost as Vietnam War Ends
description: The youngest of three children, Lance Cpl. Darwin L. Judge, 19 years old, of Marshalltown, Iowa, joined the Marines after graduating from high school last June and was put in an honor detachment. He was proud to be a Marine and had volunteered to serve in Vietnam.

title: Books of The Times
description: In 1972, the linguistics specialist J. L. Dillard published an important and provocative book called Black English: Its History and Usage in the United States. In it he argued persuasively that what appears to the speaker of Standard English to be bad English spawned by ignorance and cultural deprivation is actually a language with its own coherent grammatical structure, capable of generating a range of expressions just as complex and sophisticated as any other tongue, including Standard English. Now, in AllAmerican English: A History of the English Language in America, Professor Dillard attempts to broaden the gauge of his analysis. He argues, in the spirit of H. L. Mencken, that American English is a language distinct from British English  a language that had already undergone a sea change by the time the Mayflower colonists reached these shores, and a language that has continued to be transformed throughout American history by contact with tongues that British English never encountered in its native setting. But unhappily, Professor Dillard's new thesis doesn't quite support a book of the length of AllAmerican English (which is onethird notes and bibliography in any case). It looks a little like Son of Black English, with details and anecdotes to pad it out. And a somewhat sickly offspring at that.

title: Thai Border Town Awaiting Phnom Penh's Evacuees
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, April 30The first of over 600 foreigners that the Cambodian Communists are releasing from Phnom Penh could cross the ThaiCambodian border as early as dawn tomorrow, officials here said today.

title: A Surge Pushes Dow to Its Highest Point in Last 10 Months
description: The stock market, spurred by a late rally, made a sharp advance yesterday in somewhat heavier trading, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed at its highest level in 10 months.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday., April 30, 1975

title: Front Page 2  No Title

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 17yearold boy who was paralyzed from the neck down when he was injured during a high school varsity baseball game was awarded $1.8million in a damage suit against the Board of Education. The youth, Roy Passantino of 6355 83d Street, Middle Village, Queens, was a star player on the Newtown High School team. According to testimony during a sixday trial before a Supreme Court jury and Justice Frederic E. Hammer, a school coach had directed the boy to execute a socalled suicide play to score a run.

title: Wagner Looks Back to the Good Old Bad Times
description: In a relaxed and reminiscent talk to about 100 builders and landlords yesterday former Mayor Robert F. Wagner said that while the citys housing problems had grown since he left office 10 years ago, their nature was basically the same.

title: BIG FLOW OF CAPITAL SEEN UNLIKELY IN '75
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (Reuters)The Federal Reserve Board says that last year's huge capital flows through United States banks are unlikely to be repeated in 1975.

title: Times and News Reporters Win Columbia's Mike Berger Prizes
description: De??rdre Carmody, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times, and Peter Coutros of The New York Daily News were declared yesterday the cowinners of Columbia University's 1975 Mike Berger Award.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Byrne Names Panel To Act as Stimulus For State Economy
description: TRENTON, April 30 (UPI)Governor Byrne named a group of executives, lawyers, economists and labor leaders today to develop a comprehensive plan for stimulating the state's stagnating economy.

description: TRENTON, April 30Environmental Commissioner David J. Bardin warned today that he would not delay the planned Aug. 1 start of more stringent mandatory autoemissions standards, even if it meant longer waiting lines at state inspection stations this summer.

title: At the Front and Back Home
description: More than 56,000 Americans died and more than 300,000 were wounded during the U.S. role. G.I.'s knew pain, anguish, fear: the anguish reflected in the face of a medic helping a wounded comrade; the fear in the eyes of a marine under fire at Con Thien. But those who returned knew the joy of reunion with their families, a joy tempered by the memory of their sacrifice.

The company has said net proceeds will be used to fund advances and capital contributions to operating subsidiaries of the utility holding company.

title: Any Stalls for Buddy Jacobson ... Nova?
description: When the buzzer sounded in his apartment, Buddy Jacobson walked over and picked up the telephone.

description: The City Planning Commission yesterday proposed the establishment of a special zoning district for Staten Island's South Richmond areathe city's last frontier for extensive developmentto preserve parkland and open space while allowing for growth and development in the area to a limit of 300,000 persons.

description: A Justice Department inquiry into the possible abuse of Attica inmates after the 1971 rebellion at the prison was thwarted because the presumed victims would not cooperate with Federal Bureau of Investigation, agents, in the view of the official who directed the inquiry.

title: A 19Point Air Safety Program Is Announced by Federal Panel
description: WASHINGTON, April 30A Federal panel announced today a 19point airsafety program providing, among other things, for trying out a nopenalty system for spotchecking pilot and aircraft performance through use of automatic flight recorders:

description: HANOI, North Vietnam, April 30 (Agence FrancePresse)  Hanoi exploded with joy today.

Nixon that promised the Saigon Government in 1972 and 1973 that the United States would take swift and severe retaliatory action and would respond with full force if North Vietnam violated the Paris ceasefire accords.

description: FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., April 30The first planeload of an estimated 20,000 Vietnamese refugees scheduled for temporary resettlement at this reservist training base will arrive early Friday, United States Army authorities announced today.

AMEX PRICES RISE AS VOLUME SLIPS
description: Rebounding from its slump of the day before, prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday as volume dipped slightly from the previous day's trading. Prices and volume rose in the overthecounter market.

description: Tom Butler pitched a sevenhitter and Andy Muhlstock followed with a twohit shutout yesterday as Penn clinched a tie for the Eastern League baseball championship her defeating Columbia in a doubleheader, 61, 40, at Andy Coakley Field.

title: U.S. Spent $141Billion In Vietnam in 14 Years
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) From 1961 until the surrender of the Saigon Government, the United States spent more than $141billion in South Vietnam, or more than $7,000 for each of South Vietnam's 120 million people.

title: MAY DAY CLASHES FEARED IN PORTUGAL
description: LISBON, April 30Political tension between the Communists and moderate groups rose markedly here today on the eve of the big May Day labor celebration.

description: The city's Health Department yesterday released the names of 16 more food establishments that allegedly violated the Health Code and failed to correct firstinspection violations at the time of a second inspection. Dispositions in three other cases were also cited. The results were as follows:

description: SUGARMANProf. Robert Reuben. A footnote to the memory of the late Prof. Robert Reuben Sugarman will be unveiled at New Mount Carmel Cemetery, Cypress Hill St., and Cooper Ave., Glendale, at 1 P.M., Sunday, May 4, 1975. No rain date.

title: Personal Finance
description: The First National City Bank and the Bank of America have announced that they will sell their travelers checks at a reduced price this monthan indication that the vacation season it getting under way. The action also points up the importance of travelers checks as a safety measure for vacationers in and out of the United States.

title: 4 Governors Back Hathaway; Ecologists Oppose Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 Four Governors, two Republican and two Democratic, strongly endorsed Stnaley K. Hathaway for Secretary of the Interior today, while two national environmental organizations just as strongly opposed the nomination.

title: Film: Antonioni's First:'Story of Love Affair' in Comeback at 25
description: The years haven't been kind to "Story of a Love Affair" ("Crnanca Di Un Amore"), Michelangelo Antonioni's first feature, made in 1950, but they have at least given it historical importance in view of the highly personal, hugely better films he made afterward, from "L'Avventura" to "The Passenger."With hindsight one can see here, the beginning of a style that this idiosyncratic Italian Marxist would go on to develop into what became virtually a genre all its ownthe film about people disconnected from each other and the world around them. I doubt that if we saw "Story of a Love Affair" today, without the benefit of hindsight, we would do much more than snicker between extended yawns.The story and much of Mr. Antonioni's treatment of it recall the kind glossy soap-opera movie that was immensely popular in Europe a quarter of a century ago, before Europeans discovered the edifying joys of television drama. It's about the impossible love of a poor auto salesman (Massimo Girotti) and his former sweetheart (Lucia Bose), who has married a rich Milan textile manufacturer and moved bag and baggage into the upper classes, where she's lonely but very happy to be over-dressed.The pair, who had earlier parted full of guilt when they did nothing to prevent the accidental death of Mr. Girotti's fiance, are reunited, first in fear, then in love, when Miss Bose's husband starts looking into her past. The fact that the affair is renewed as a result of the husband's groundless suspicions is an irony that is not to be taken lightly in a film that is completely without intentional humor."Story of a Love Affair," which opened yesterday at the Cinema Studio, has a number of easily identifiable Antonioni moments, some quite fine, such as the scene in which the lovers are reunited after seven years, and another, photographed in the stairwell of an office building, when the pair ascend from one floor to the next only to reach an absolute impasse in their relationship. The trouble with the film is not that their problems are mini. To paraphrase Claude Chabrol, there are no small problems, only small films. In a better movie we might be able to take seriously Miss Bose's inability to cast aside her life of luxury, and Mr. Girotti's inability to see her for the bore she is. But "Story of a Love Affair" is tacky. It seems to share Miss Bose's fascination for high society, which, as shown in the movie, means playing bridge all afternoon and throwing fur coats on floors.The Cast

title: FARMERS' PRICES UP 4%, IMPLYING RETAIL RISE SOON
description: WASHINGTON, April 30Prices of farm commodities rose 4 per cent in the month ended April 15, the Agriculture Department reported today. A top departmental economist noted that the increase was focused largely in areas where it would be most quickly reflected at the retail counter.

title: PUBLISHERS TOLD OF COPYRIGHT ILLS
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 30When the outgoing chairman of the Association of American Publishers, Simon Michael Bessie, president of Atheneum Publishers, gave his opening address to the group's annual meeting here, he told his colleagues to lask themselves:

title: Sun and Moon Trick Satellites and Shut Them Off
description: An overactive sun and an overbright moon have been fooling control instruments in space, causing brief shutdowns of communications satellites that transmit television between continents and carry more than half the world's transoceanic telephone traffic. The problem indicates that maintenance of the 10yearold network of the 89nation International Telecommunications Satellite Organization (Intelsat) is far from routine.

title: Legislature Votes U.D.C. $228Million
description: ALBANY, April 30The Legislature voted tonight to give the Urban Development Corporation $88million and to lend it $140million as the state's part of a delicate agreement with the major commercial banks to make it possible for the insolvent agency to repay its debts and finish its building programs.

title: CALIFORNIA SEAT IS WON BY WIDOW
description: LOS ANGELES, April 30Shirley N. Pettis was elected yesterday by San Bernardino and Riverside County voters to fill the 37th Congressional District seat left vacant by the death of her husband, Jerry L. Pettis. He died in a plane crash Feb. 14. Mrs. Pettis, 50 years old, a Republican like her husband, received 60.5 per cent of the total vote, thus avoiding a runoff.

title: Mansfield Bids Americans Draw New Perceptions
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (Reuters)The Senate Majority leader, Mike Mansfield, said today that the end of the war in Vietnam should lead to a reassessment of American foreign policy, but he agreed with President Ford that there should be no recriminations about the American role in the war.

title: Veto of Death Penalty Set Back in Bay State
description: BOSTON, April 30 (AP)The Massachusetts House overrode today Gov. Michael S. Dukakis' veto of a bill to restore the state's death penalty.

title: Allon Tells of Clearing the Air in Talks With French
description: PARIS, April 30  Foreign Minister Yigal Allon, winding up the first official trip to France by an Israeli minister, said today that the atmosphere has changed for the better in relations between the two countries.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Vietnam

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
MRS. GANDHI HAILS VICTORY IN SAIGON
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 30 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India extended greetings today to the Provisional Revolutionary Government of Vietnam in what was said to be an invitation to join the movement of nonaligned countries.

title: JOBLESS BENEFITS SLASHED BY 153,200
description: WASHINGTON. April 30 (UPI)The Labor department said today that 133,200 persons dropped off unemployment insurance benefits rolls in the second week in April.

title: 13 to 15 Expected
description: LOUISVILLE, April 30The heavy rains this morning failed to disturb the optimism of the hardcore owners and trainers of horses who will run in the Kentucky Derby. At least, not yet. Since the start of the week the prediction has persisted that the field for the 101st running of the race on Saturday will be between 13 and 15 horses. And today's rundown did not discourage those figures.

title: Market Place
description: Longsuffering shareholders of the Commonwealth United Corporation who bought stock during a oneyear period of market manipulation are finally being paid off.

title: SCHOOL VOTE STIRS CANARSIE BATTLE
description: The rallying cry of Canarsie schools for Canarsie children has again entered the school board contest in Brooklyn's District 18, where a struggle over integration plans rages between the heavily white Canarsie area and the racially and ethnically mixed East Flatbush.

title: Guam Refugees Mourn for Saigon, Then Face Future
description: TAMUNING, Guam, Thursday, May 1The collapse of South Vietnam, and especially the fall of Saigon, brought tears to the eyes of many refugees here last night.

title: Vietcong, After Long Struggle, Attain a Vanguard Role in the South
description: The Vietcong, the cutting edge of the Communist revolution in South Vietnam, have been many things to many men.

title: United Fund Opens Drive
description: The United Fund of Greater New York today opens its seventh annual appeal to help support 425 affiliated voluntary hospital, health and social service agencies. Among the nearly four million people who are being helped each year are those in need of the services of such organizations as The Salvation Army. the Red Cross, clinics, emergency treatment centers, workshops for the handicapped, neighborhood houses, family counseling and child guidance agencies, visiting nurse services and many more.

title: U.S. Treasury Freezes South Vietnam Assets
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)The Treasury Department ordered all South Vietnamese assets in the United States frozen today.

title: Mayday Forebodes Some Uncertainty for Wall Street
description: Today is historic for Wall Street. After 183 years, it embarks on an era of negotiated, commission rates.

title: MARTIN CRITICIZES POLICY ON SAIGON
description: The following pooled dispatch was written from the United States ship Blue Ridge and transmitted by Agence FrancePress:

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SWEET HOME With warm weather opening up, so are more local home tours, an increasingly popular diversion for those who enjoy seeing where, not necessarily how, other people live.

title: War Tore At Fabric Of U.S. Life
description: Nothing divided Americans so much as the war. Veterans protested in Washington and youths burned their draft cards. Four died when Guardsmen fired on Kent State students protesting against the Cambodian incursion.

title: Barricaded Inmate Dies After Guards Throw In Tear Gas
description: An inmate at Green Haven Prison in Stormville, N. Y., died Tuesday after he had barricaded himself in a hospital area and security personnel used tear gas to remove him, state correctional officials said yesterday.

title: CORN CONTRACTS DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Corn prices closed a little lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, after price rally early in the session. There was early talk of rainy weather, with scattered showers over some of the planting areas.

title: Americans, Vietnamese: Mutual Misconceptions
description: The Vietnamese and the Americans never knew each other very well. By the time the United States troops withdrew, taking with them the epithet gook, profound gulfs of ignorance still remained. Even those who tried to see beyond the stereotypes often slipped into subtler misunderstandings.

title: Hussein Denies a Dispatch Times on Link to Syria
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (Reuters)  King Hussein of Jordan said here today that there was no substance to a report published last week saying his country and Syria had agreed to establish joint milltary commands for their land and air forces.

title: Hunter Students Occupy Dean's Office
description: Several hundred Hunter College students yesterday occupied the College Dean of Students office and demonstrated in halls to protest Mayor Beame's proposed budget cuts in City University programs next year.

title: DR. LEO LEHRMAN
description: Dr. Leo Lehrman, who retired in 1970 after more than 50 years as a chemistry professor at Ctiy College, died here Monday. He was 74 years old and lived at 430 East 86th Street.

title: U.S. DOLLAR IN PARIS SETS 20MONTH LOW
description: BRUSSELS, April 30 (UPI)The dollar hit a 20month low in Paris today, but had a mixed performance on other European money markets. The price of gold remained more or less static during a quiet trading day.

title: Welfare Council Expects a Rise In Case Loads as Budgets Drop
description: NEWARK, April 30  The New Jersey Welfare Council opened its 74th annual meeting today amid predictions that purveyors of social services would have to meet the human needs of a greater number of people during the coming year with fewer dollars.

title: Article 2  No Title
Beame Bids U.S. Operate All Projects to Aid Income
description: WASHINGTON, April 30Mayor Beame of New York called on the Federal Government today to take full responsibility for all income assistance programs.

title: A Reunion at Camp Pendleton  Vietnamese Restraint Gives Way
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., April 30Nate Allen is a big man with a sunburned nose and one lens missing from his eyeglasses, the only casualties pf his one  man, 20,000  mile odyssey to rescue his Vietnamese wife's family.

title: Campaign Aids St. Mark's InBowery
description: Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday opened an $800,000 campaign to rehabilitate historic St. Mark's Church IntheBowery and to insure its yearly maintenance.

title: Brown Takes Stand
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 30 Donald F. Hornig, the president of Brown University, said today in a letter to alumni and parents that the university would never again negotiate with students occupying a university building. Black and LatinAmerican students seized and occupied the main administration building for 38 hours beginning last Thursday, leaving only after they had negotiated a settlement to their enrollment and recruitment demands and received a guaranty of academic and legal amnesty.

title: H.U.D. REPORTS LAG IN LEASED HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) A new leasedhousing program for the poor has proved so tricky to carry out that only onefifth of the predicted units will be ready in the first year, Housing and Urban Development Secretary Carla A. Hills said today.

title: For 26,000 Refugees, U.S. Is a Little Closer
description: CLARK AIR BASE, Philippines, April 30A slight figure in dark pajamas moved solicitously among the 66 Vietnamese children in the improvised nursery on this United States Air Force base in the central Philippines.

title: John McKay, NASA Pilot, Dies; Flew RocketPowered Aircraft
description: LANCASTER, Calif., April 30 (UPO)John B. McKay, a research pilot who flew the X15 rocket plane at more than five times the speed of sound, died Sunday at the age of 52.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company has been awarded a $245.4million Navy contract for development and productin of a new warhead for the Trident submarinelaunched missile.

title: Meadowlands Commission Chief Gains a OneYear Job Extension
description: LYNDHURST, April 30The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission approved by a 3to1 vote today a resolution to give Executive Director William D. McDowell an oral agreement to stay in that post at the same salary until April of next year. The dissenting vote was cast by Patricia Q. Sheehan, the commission chairman.

title: Death Toll Rises to Six In Crash of Butane Truck
description: EAGLE PASS, Tex., April 30 (UPI)  Three more persons died today, bringing to six the death toll in the explosion of a butane truck that jackknifed and crashed into a trailer park last night.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MAY 1, 1975

title: Reliance Group Is Omitting Dividends on All Its Stock
description: Reliance Group. Inc., an insurance holding company said: yesterday that its board had voted to omit the quarterly dividend payments on the common stock and its Series B and Series C preferred stock. The common stock dividend is normally payable July 15 and the preferred dividends on June 1.

title: ZVI BENARY
description: Zvi Benary, who had been a leading theater operator in Palestine and then in Israel, died yesterday at his home in Tel Aviv. Mr. Benary, who was horn in Lithuania in 1905, later entered film distribution and operated several movie theaters.

title: City Consumer Affairs Unit Asks Franchising Disclosure
description: A regulation has been proposed by the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs that would require disclosure of the business relationship between a franchisor and franchisee. The proposed rule would make franchisors. franchiseesand, where applicable, subfranchiseesdisclose their legal names and addresses and state that they are separate entities.

title: Islanders May Go To Smith
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 30Question marks will be starting in goal for the New York Islanders and the Philadelphia Flyers tomorrow night, according to this afternoon's rosters.

title: CREDIT MARKETS HOLD FIRM TONE
description: A firm tone prevailed yesterday in the credit markets prior to the Treasury's announcement, expected late today, of plans to sell perhaps as much as $6billion in debt securities early in May. This package would consist of $3.8billion to refund, or refinance, maturing debt, as well as the raising of net new cash that may run around $2billion.

title: Wallace to Speak at School But He Will Not Get Medal
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, will speak at a local high school banquet May 9 as scheduled, but will not receive a promised medal for contributions to education, officals of the school said today.

title: New Hampshire Court Bars Plea Against Nuclear Plan
description: CONCORD, N. H., April 30 (AP)The New Hampshire Supreme Court ruled today against an environmental group that sought to delay approval of the Seabrook nuclear power plant on grounds that the state's right to know law had been violated.

title: South Vietnam's U.N. Mission Closes
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 30The office of South Vietnam's observer mission to the United Nations and Consulate General closed today.

title: CURB ON ABORTIONS FOR MINORS IS UPSET
description: BOSTON, April 30 (AP)A Massachusetts law that prohibits minors from getting abortions without parental consent has been overturned as unconstitutional by a threejudge Federal panel.

title: Johnson Sets Cutback
description: Johnson & Johnson stated yesterday that its Chicopee Manufacturing unit would curtail nonwoven fabric production at its Milltown, N. J., plant.

Nixon that promised the Saigon Government in 1972 and 1973 that the United States would take swift and severe retaliatory action and would respond with full force if North Vietnam violated the Paris ceasefire accords.

title: Yanks Beat Orioles, 64, On Bonds Homer in 9th
description: The first Baltimore Oriole of the year was spotted at Shea Stadium last night. Not quite the harbinger of spring, it was felled with one swift swing of Bobby Bonds' bat a threerun homer in the ninth inning that gave the Yankees a 64 comeback victory.

title: Barge Used in Salvage of Soviet Submarine Leaves Coast Port, Bound for Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES, April 30The 324  foot submergible barge that was used to recover part of a sunken Russian submarine from the Pacific Ocean last summer has left its Redwood City berth, the Coast Guard said today.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Thursday, May 1, 1975

title: Vietnam, Test of Presidents, Was Distant War and Battle at Home
description: WASHINGTON, April 30In Franz Kafica's The Trial, a priest sets out to explain the mysteries of life to a character called K. They discuss a parable of the law and disagree on its meaning.

title: A Warm Reading By Ailey Dancers In Carmina Burana
description: John Butler's lyric, dramatically accented Carmina Burana received a warm reading at City Center's 55th Street Theater on Tuesday evening. The Alvin Ailey company's Sara Yarborough was paired with Michihiko Oka while Clive Thompson partnered Judith Jamison, as the two major couples.

title: ROBBERY SLAYINGS LAID TO 5 YOUTHS
description: Five unemployed youths were arrested yesterday and charged with the separate murders Brooklyn last month of an 85yearold woman and a 62yearold man while their apartments were being burglarized. A lot of old people are frightened to death these days because of killings, said Lieut. Joseph Christian of the 13th Homicide Squad in announcing the arrests. We hope this will put some of them at ease.

title: Solti Leads Masterly Verdi Requiem
description: For the last few seasons the Chicago Symphony under Sir Georg Solti has been bringing a display piece to Carnegie Hall. Usually it has been an opera, or part of an opera. Last night it was the Verdi Requiem (there are those who will say no difference, considering the operatic qualities of this work).

title: Amtrak, at Age of 4, Still ProblemRidden
description: Amtrak executives and a Federal judge riding the Metroliner from Washington to New York recently for a hearing on rail passenger problems, including train delays, inadvertently became prime exhibits when they got stuck behind a slowmoving freight train and pulled in 35 minutes late the story. It's the idiots that operate them.

title: Bomb Kills 2 Children
description: FIRESTONE, Calif., April 30 (AP) Two children were burned to death and another was injured early today in a fire set by a Molotov cocktail thrown through the living room window of their apartment, the sheriff's department said. The authorities identified the dead children as Demetria Johnson, age 1, and her sister, Tammy, 4. Their brother, Michael, was injured.

title: Tomahawks Defeated in Home Debut
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 30As subtle as a karate chop, indoor lacrosse barreled into the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Long Road to the Paris Pacts Had Misleading Signs, Pitfalls and Dead Ends
description: PARIS, April 30Throughout the long Vietnam war there were probes and talkson scale probably unparalleled in military historyto find an alternative political settlement.

title: Cosmos Lose, 32, In Opener
description: The New York Cosmos started their North American Soccer League season by losing to the Miami Toros, 32, at Randalls Island Stadium last night before 9,238 paying fans.

title: Westinghouse Chief Scores Lack of Action on Energy
description: PITTSBURGH, April 30Robert E. Kirby, chairman of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the nation's leading manufacturer of nuclear power plants, warned today that the lack of action concerning the nation's energy problems threatened industrial shutdowns. by the end of the decade due to a shortage of electrical energy.

title: Liberation
description: The end, when it finally came, was sudden, sharp and definitive. No negotiations, no period of transition dampen the exhilaration of the Vietnamese Communists in Hanoi, victorious in their thirtyyear war for Indochina.

title: OneYear U.S. Bills Average 6.40% Yield
description: WASHINGTON, April 30the Treasury auctioned oneyear bills today at an average yield of 6.40 per cent.

title: February Steel Imports Show a Rise of 43.8%
description: Steel imports in February were 43.8 per cent ahead of the yearago level but trailed the January level by 33.8 per cent, according to data from the Department of Commerce. The total for February reached just under 1.2million tons, against 828,141 tons brought in last February and 609,354 tons in January. As a result, imports for the first two months totaled 2.99 million tons, 80.7 per cent ahead of the 1974 level.

title: End of a letter from former President Richard M. Nixon to President Nguyen Van Thieu. It was dated Jan. 5, 1973. It is not known who underlined certain portions or when.
description: WASHINGTON, April 30Following are the texts of letters made public here today by Nguyen Tien Hung, former Minister of Planning in Saigon, who said they were sent by President Richard M. Nixon to President Nguyen Van Thieu before the Paris ceasefire agreements.

title: ALFRED W. WEIGT
description: Alfred W. Weight, who had been a stockbroker for nearly half a century, died Tuesday evening of cancer in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 2923 148th Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: Saigon's Surrender Texts
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 30 (Agence FrancePresse)Following are the texts, in unofficial translation, of President Duong Van Minh'S address on the surrender of South Vietnam and of the General Staff's order to South Vietnamese forces:

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: 2 VERDICTS DIFFER ON ORVIS PARTNERS
description: Carl W. Anderson, a former partner in the defunct brokerage house of Orvis Brothers & Co., was convicted yesterday of conspiracy to file false financial statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: FARMERS' PRICES UP 4%, IMPLYING RETAIL RISE SOON
description: WASHINGTON, April 30Prices of farm commodities rose 4 per cent in the month ended April 15, the Agriculture Department reported today. A top departmental economist noted that the increase was focused largely in areas where it would be most quickly reflected at the retail counter.

title: 60 IN MOSCOW URGE HELP FOR DISSIDENT
description: MOSCOW, April 30 (Reuters) Sixty Soviet dissenters appealed to the world's people today to raise their voices in defense of an arrested dissident.

title: Power Agency Sees Gain In Deregulating Gas Price
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The Federal Power Commission issued a staff report today asserting that the nation would gain by ending price regulation on natural gas, even though the action would mean higher gas bills for consumers.

title: ScrippsHoward Names Stolberg to Editorial Post
description: The appointment of David F. Stolberg as assistant general editorial manager of ScrippsHoward Newspapers was announced yesterday by Jack R. Howard, president and general editorial manager of Scripps Howard.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Toward an Economy That Needs No Wars India's Lesson

title: Can You Imagine a Pot That's Tall as a Person?
description: Can you imagine a ceramic pot so tall and heavy that it takes two strong men to schlep it into a kiln? Well, you don't have to imagine it. A number of these pots are now on view at the American Craftsman gallery, where Ron Levy is having a oneman show.

title: Bridge:
description: The tournament program for May will include some events of unusual interest, both for players and kibitzers. Most notable are the following:

title: Trial Suspension of Fairness Rule Urged
description: Arthur R. Taylor, president of CBS Inc., yesterday proposed a oneyear trial suspension of the controversial fairness doctrinewhich requires broadcasters to present all sides of debatable public issuesif the Congress did not see fit at this time to abolish the rule entirely.

title: Gov. Grasso for Raffles But Not State Lotteries
description: HARTFORD, April 30 Gov. Ella T. Grasso today spiked an incipient plan for an instant lottery twice a year to finance a program to equalize public school financing in Connecticut.

title: Legislature Votes U.D.C. $228Million
description: ALBANY, April 30The Legslature voted tonight to give the Urban Development Corporation $88million and to lend it $140million as the state's part of a delicate agreement with the major commercial banks to make it possible for the insolvent agency to repay its debts and finish its building programs.

title: The Vietnamese Are Corning and the Town of Niceville, Fla., Doesn't Like It
description: NICEVILLE. Fla.. April 30 The Vietnamese are coming, but this little town doesn't want them.

title: Suit Links Woman's Cancer To Drug Taken by Mother
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP) E. R. Squibb & Son, the drug manufacturer, has been sued for $3million by a woman who says she developed cancer because her motherwhile pregnant in 1951took one of the concern's drugs.

title: Dance: Spring Season
description: The New York City Ballet opened its spring season quietly Tuesday night at the State Theater, saving its surprises for the Ravel Festival later this month. A bookend approach to the program had Jerome Robbins's The Dybbuk Variations framed by two ballets by George BalanchineDonizetti Variations and Cortege Hongrois.

title: Philip Brooks, RareBook Dealer And a Columnist, Is Dead at 76
description: Philip Brooks, a specialist on rare books, died Tuesday at North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L. I. He was 76 years old and lived in Great Neck. L. I.

title: Theater: Liberty Call
description: Upstairs in its intimate studio theater at the St. Marks Playhouse, the Negro Ensemble Company is having a spring seasonwithinaseason, a festival of new plays some of which have come out of the N.E.C.'s Playwrights Workshop.

title: SAIGON REDS LOOK TO NONALIGNMENT
description: PARIS, April 30The war in Vietnam is over, the Provisional Revolutionary Government said here today in a statement hailing a victory of historic significance for the South Vietnamese population.

title: Tugs Make Waves in Steamboat Race
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 The Belle of Louisville won the muchballyhooed 12th running of The Great Steamboat Race handily today against two other paddlewheelers in a contest that is certain to be debated up and down the Ohio River for the next year. Her margin in the 10mile race was 25 minutes.

title: NBCTV REVAMPS LINEUP FOR FALL
description: In the wake of the announcement Tuesday by CBSTV of its new fall schedule, NBCTV yesterday rearranged its own previously announced lineup for next season.

title: The Communist Takeover: How Breakthrough in South Vietnam Developed After Paris Truce Accord
PHELPS DODGE SETS COPPERPRICE RISE
description: The Phelps Dodge Copper Products Company raised yesterday the price for all hot, rolled copper rods by fivehundredths (.05) of a cent a pound. All bar and tinned round wires and cables and square rectangular wires were raised by a quarter of a cent a pound while copper and rolls and drawn copper were advanced by a half a cent a pound.

title: Byrne Challenges License Renewals In Bid to Get TV Station for Jersey
description: TRENTON, April 30Governor Byrne announced today, that he had filed a petition with the Federal Communications Commission challenging, the license renewals of all the television stations in New York City on the ground that they had largely ignored New Jersey.

title: Chelsea Case Is Lost By Postal Service Here
description: A Federal appeals court ruled here yesterday that the United States Postal Service must provide a comprehensive environmental impact statement before it could build a major construction project.

title: Amtrak, at Age of 4, Still ProblemRidden
description: Amtrak executives and a Federal judge riding the Metroliner from Washington to New York recently for a hearing on rail passenger problems, including train delays, inadvertently became prime exhibits when they got stuck behind a slowmoving freight train and pulled in 35 minutes late.

title: Ulster: One More Try
description: So many failed political experiments in Northern Ireland have been dubbed the last chance for stability and peace that there is a natural reluctance to apply that label to the election today of delegates to a convention to write a new Ulster Constitution. Yet it is as difficult to figure out a next step should the convention fail as is to be optimistic about its chances for success.

title: Chrysler Ties Rebates to Dealer Program
description: DETROIT, April 30  The Chrysler Corporation has tied its new rebates to a dealerincentive program that will put pressure on some dealers to sell many cars quickly to qualify or not be eligible to offer rebates.

title: 250 Youths Demonstrate For Jobs at City Hall Park
description: More than 250 teenagers from youth councils all over the city demonstrated in City Hall Park yesterday afternoon demanding that the city provide 50,000 summer jobs.

title: Old Enmity Wanes in the Saar As Its Links to France Tighten
description: SAARBRUCKEN, West Germany, April 24Although they are surrounded by reminders of 300 years of hatred and war between France and Germany, the 1.1 million Germans of the Saar have dropped all traces of enmity toward the French.

title: Undercover Detective Penetrates Gaming Ring and City Is Winner
description: Nineteen months ago, policemen raided a wire room in an apartment on the West Side and seized $20,000, part of the day's betting receipts. One of the gamblers, who managed to hide an additional $10,000, broke loose from the police and fled.

title: CORN CONTRACTS DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Corn prices closed a little lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, after price rally early in the session. There was early talk of rainy weather, with scattered showers over some of the planting areas.

title: ETHICS UNIT CURBS SCHOOL LAWYERS
description: The city's Board of Ethics issued a ruling yesterday prohibiting lawyers employed by community school boards from representing any school board member or an opponent in challenges to candidacy in elections to the community boards.

title: Bulgaria Is Striving to Improve U.S. Ties
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 26Bulgaria appears eager to improve her relations with the United States despite a harrier created for the country by the Soviet Union's rejection of a commitment to freer emigration in return for more favorable trading conditions.

title: Palestinian Guerrillas Improving Discipline
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 30The Palestinian guerrilla leadership is demonstrating a growing organizational discipline and diplomatic ability in its struggle to mobilize Arab support and international recognition of its cause.

title: WBAI WILL APPEAL REPRIMAND BY F.C.C.
description: The Pacifica Foundation, owner of Radio Station WBAIFM, will appeal in Federal District Court a reprimand from the Federal Communications Commission for broadcasting a program containing language considered indecent.

title: AN ANTIWAR FUND ENDING OPERATION
description: A foundation that quoted its Wall Street brokerfounder as having said the chief enemy of mankind was the injustice of governments and of the United States Government in particular is ending operation after spending nearly all the $6million the broker left it.

title: VICTOR F. LIEF, 70, PSYCHIATRIST, DIES
description: Dr. Victor F. Lief, senior staff psychiatrist at the Silver Hill Foundation, a psychiatric hospital in New Canaan, Conn., died Tuesday of a heart ailment in New York Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 11 Old Kingdom Road, Wilton, Conn.

title: Suit Seeks to Block Adoptions Of Many Vietnamese Children
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 (AP)A class action suit filed in Federal court is seeking to block adoption of Vietnamese children brought here during Operation Babylift.

title: Mark Set in Comely
description: Locust Hill Farm's sparkling Ruffian glittered again yesterday in winning the 26th running of the Comely at Aqueduct with the same ease that marked her previous six performances in an unbeaten career.

title: $104,000 Damages And Former Job Won By. College Teacher
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., April 30A judge ordered today that Brookdale Community College reinstate a journalism professor who had criticized the college president, and that the college president and six trustees each pay her $10,000 in punitive damages.

title: Thieu Silent on Events; Wife Is Said to Join Him
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 30 Nguyen Van Thieu will have no statement about the Communist takeover in Saigon, a spokesman for the South Vietnamese Embassy said today.

title: JAY BERNARD JOSEPH
description: Jay Bernard Joseph, a retired stockbroker, died yesterday at his home. He was 71 years old and lived at 876 Park Avenue.

title: A Rise in Wellhead Price Of Canadian Gas Opposed
description: OTTAWA, April 30 (UPI Energy Minister Donald MacDonald said today he would oppose an arbitration award in Alberta that ordered an increase in the wellhead price of natural gas to $1.15 per thousand cubic feet.

title: Reaction of U.S. Troops: Relief, Tears and Anger
description: FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., April 30American soldiers woke up this morning saddened, relieved, glad, embittered and frustrated over the news that the Vietnam war was over and that the side on which they had fought had lost. A few said that when they heard of Saigon's surrender late last night, they wept.

title: Saks Executive Fined $15,000 On PriceFixing Plea of Guilty
description: Barrie Sommerfield, vice president and merchandise manager of Saks Fifth Avenue, was fined $15,000 yesterday and was sentenced to one day of unsupervised probation for having conspired to fix prices of women's clothing in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: Kissinger Says U.S. May Shelter 70,000
description: WASHINGTON, April 30United States Navy ships continued today to pick up South Vietnamese refugees fleeing their country in small boats, the State and Defense Departments reported.

title: Inflated Farm Bill
description: The farm bill that Congress has laid on the President's desk, which provides for raising price supports on all major crops and extends income guarantees to farmers, could be so costly to consumers and taxpayers that we believe the President should veto the bill.

title: $104,000 Damages And Former Job Won By College Teacher
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., April 30A judge ordered today that Brookdale Community College reinstate a journalism professor who had criticized the college president, and that the college president and six trustees each pay her $10,000 in punitive damages.

title: Plots That Failed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 30Most of the citizens of the nation's largest state are enjoying the way their new young Governor appears to he setting the bureaucracy on its car.

title: Teamsters Here Urge Unions To Stop Backing Farmworkers
description: Teamster Union locals in the city are threatening to end their traditional support of A.F.L.C.I.O. unions in strike situations if these unions con tinue as sponsors and backers of the United Farm Workers.

title: DR. OTTO M. BERGEN
description: Dr. Otto M. Berger, a specialist in internal medicine, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 71 and lived at 200 East 62d Street.

title: Women's Rights Faces Snag in Albany
description: ALBANY, April 30The proposed Equal Rights Amendment to the State Constitution, which earlier this year was headed toward easy second passage by the Legislature and placement on the ballot for a November referendum, appeared to be in trouble today.

title: Article 1  No Title
Red Cross Asserts It Wants to Continue Activities in Vietnam
description: GENEVA, April 30The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that it hoped to continue without interruption the humanitarian activity it had been conducting in South Vietnam from Saigon.

title: Senate Unit Deadlocks on New Hampshire Race
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)The eightmember Senate Rules Committee deadlocked today on a key question in New Hampshire's disputed United States Senate contest, the closest in its history, and the issue will be put before the full Senate.

title: The Hathaway Record
description: The Senate Interior Committee has a responsibility to examine the record of President Ford's nominee for Secretary of the Interiorformer Gov. Stanley K. Hathaway of Wyomingmuch more carefully than it has yet done.

title: H.E.W. Official Says Refugees Are Healthy
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 A spokesman for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that the thousands of South Vietnamese refugees on their way to the United States were generally in good health and, as far as was known, carried no exotic diseases.

title: U.N. Unit Drops South Africa
description: GENEVA, April 30South Africa's membership in the World Meteorological Organization, a United Nations agency, was suspended today. The agency's congress voted to suspend South Africa until she renounced her apartheid policies.

title: U.S.O. READ VOICES HOPE ON FINANCES
description: The national chairman of the United Service Organizations, Inc., Dr. Elvis J. Stahr Jr., said yesterday that the U.S.O. was still in a very bad financial situation. But he said he was optimistic that the organization, which has provided recreation and relaxation since 1941 to men and women in the military services, would survive.

title: Adjusted Withholding Goes Into Effect Today
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)Beginning with paychecks dated tomorrow, workers will get a few dollars more in their takehome pay as part of a government effort to perk up the economy by adding $17.6billion to consumers' buying power.

title: The Ballet: More Than One Way to Dance Giselle
description: In the classics the Bolshoi Ballet has traditionally permitted its chief interpreters considerable leeway in individual characterizations. It is a principle, sometimes also followed in the West, that has a lot to commend it, for dancers instead of feeling themselves encased within the unbreakable confines of a production, are given a little, precious room to move, the chance to interpret a role themselves, rather than merely to execute someone else's interpretation.

title: F.T.C. Declines to Order Proof Of Ads Hailing Company Image
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission declined today to require companies to prove such advertising claims as Exxon wants you to know that they are doing their best to provide more gasoline for you.

title: An Overture Of $500,000 To Namath
description: The World Football League will deliver a certified check for $500,000 to Joe Namath in the next 24 hours as the first overture of its proposed $4million contract offer, Chris Hemmeter, the league president, disclosed last night.

title: Article 4  No Title
Notes on People
description: Ending speculation that arose from sharp competition over the appointment, President Ford chose Lieut Gen. Louis H. Wilson yesterday to be the new Commandant of the Marine Corps. General Wilson, now commander of the Fleet Marine Force in the Pacific, succeeds Gen. Robert E. Cushman, who will retire.

title: People and Business
description: We are cautiously optimistic, L William Seidman, Presidential economic adviser, said in an assessment yesterday of the economic picture for members of the National Economists Club in Washington. He warned, hoWever, that in the next few weeks the numbers will comprise a mixed bag of good and bad news.

title: Look on My Works...
description: WASHINGTON, April 30The war is over. Did we think we would ever say those words? They bring relief, pain, exhaustion, an aching desire to forget. But the rest cannot be silence not if America is to restore her integrity and her vision after these ravaging years.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALLYankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (RadioWIVICA, 7:55 P.M.)Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago. (RadioWRVR, 2:25 P.M.)HARNESS RACINGRoosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I., 8 P.M.Freehold (N. J.) Raceway, 1:30 P.M.Monticello (N. Y.) Raceway, 8 P.M.HOCKEYIslanders vs. Flyers, Stanley Cup semifinal playoff, at Philadelphia. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8 P.M.) (RadloWHN, 8 P.M.) THOROUGHBRED RACINGAqueduct (Queens) Race Track, 1:30 P.M.

title: Shift of Policy Expected To Bolster Role of NATO
description: BONN, April 30Saigon's surrender after 30 years of struggle in Vietnam was seen in Europe today as a chastening defeat for American policy, but there were hopes that it might prove salutary.

title: India Has Worst Malaria Outbreak Since '53, but the Toll Is Low
description: NEW DELHI, April 30The worst outbreak of malaria in nearly 20 years is surging through broad sections of India, according to government officials and the office here of the World Health Organization.

title: Assembly Votes Doctor Insurance Bill With Fewer Curbs Than the Senate's
description: ALBANY, April 30  The State Assembly today approved a medical malpractice insurance bill that includes additional concessions by Governor Carey on the move to curtail malpractice litigation.

title: Pennsy Loss Almost Double '74 Deficit
Judd K. Polk, Economist, Dies; President's Descendant Was 62
description: Judd Knox Polk, an economist and author, died yesterday at his home, 4 Washington Square Village. He was 62 years old.

title: N.B.A. Owners Look For Political Ladder
description: Larry O'Brien did what was expected yesterday. He formally accepted the job as commissioner of the National Basketball Association.

title: C.A.B. BACKS UNITED ON DISCOUNT FARES
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 The Civil Aeronautics Board today granted United Air Lines permission to offer a Bicentennial discount fare of up to 25 per cent off under selected conditions on flights between Chicago and seven East Coast cities.

title: COMMUNISTS TAKE OVER SAIGON; U. S. RESCUE FLEET IS PICKING UP VIETNAMESE WHO FLED IN BOATS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 30Communist troops of North Vietnam and the Provisional Revolutionary Government of South Vietnam poured into Saigon today as a century of Western influence came to an end.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday opened an $800,000 campaign to rehabilitate historic St. Mark's ChurchlntheBowery and to insure its yearly maintenance.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: The dean of the Seton Hall University School of Law called yesterday for a state constitutional convention to reshape all three branches of government in New Jersey. In a Law Day message, Dean John F. X. Irving said the recent trial of Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel pointed up the need for reform.

title: Political Infighting in Kenya Continues Over Critic's Death
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 30The political infighting in this East African country has intensified as Parliament has acted strongly to show its independence of the Government of President Jomo Kenyatta.

title: For FrontLine Soldiers, War Had Bitter Flavor
description: They were not understood or appreciated by many Americans and Vietnamese. They were always a small minority in America's Indochina establishment. The combat soldiers, the young Americans who for nearly a decade carried rifles, walked the jungles and slept in the mud, were closest to, the Vietnam war, knew its terrors most intimately and paid its dearest price.

title: Charges Against 26 Policemen Follow Picnic Featuring Sex
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 30The Nassau County Police Commissioner announced today that 26 police officers were being charged with a total of 93 departmental violations, most relating to allegations of attending a barbecue while on duty and engaging in sexual activities with a barmaid.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, April 30A SenateHouse conference committee failed to reach agreement today on securities industry reform legislation and fixed the date of its next meeting as May 13.

title: Bicentennial Barge to Ply State's Waters Next Year
description: ALBANY, April 30A Bicentennial barge will ply the state's waters next year, flying blueandorange banners and carrying displays showing what New York was like during the Revolution.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia. April 30 (AP)Muhammad Ali, the world heavyweight boxing champion, and Joe Bugner, the European and British champion, have signed for a title fight at Merdeka Stadium here on June 30, according to a Malaysian official. The scheduled 15round bout, for which Ali would receive $2.5million, and Bugner $500,000, was announced today by Harun Idris, Chief Minister of Selanger State and president of the youth wing the ruling United Malays National Organization.

title: Ordination of 11 Women Called Valid
description: WASHINGTON, April 30The Right Rev. John E. Hines, former Presiding Bishop of they Episcopal Church, testified at a landmark ecclesiastical trial here today that he viewed the ordination of 11 women to the priesthood in Philadelphia last July as valid, though irregular, and that the House of Bishops' statement calling them invalid had no legislative or judicial weight.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: G.M. Executive Forecasts HigherPriced'76 Models
description: DETROIT, April 30  The vice chairman of the General Motors Corporation today predicted another round of price increases when the 1976 models go on sale this fall.

title: LAOTIANS IN CLASH AT ROAD JUNCTION
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 30 (UPI)New fighting flared today in Laos when Communist troops shelled Government troops trying to retake a highway junction.

title: Hijacking Suspect Arrested
description: CLEVELAND, April 30 (UPI) Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested Everett Lee White, 34 years old, formerly of Cleveland Heights, here today on charges of airline hijacking. Agents said lie had been arrested in connection with the Jan. 28, 1969, diversion of an Eastern Airlines jet to Cuba. They said he had been arrested shortly after returning from six years in Cuba.

title: THE LONG WAR IN VIETNAM: A HISTORY
description: War and rebellion have shaped the major chapters of Vietnam's history ever since the first mention of the Viet people in the writings of Chinese historians some 2,200 years ago.

title: PHELPS DODGE SETS COPPERPRICE RISE
description: The Phelps Dodge Copper Products Company raised yesterday the price for all hot rolled copper rods by fivehundredths (.05) of a cent a pound. All bar and tinned round wires and cables and square rectangular wires were raised by a quarter of a cent a pound while copper and rolls and drawn copper were advanced by a half a cent a pound.

title: Looters Rush the Abandoned U.S. Embassy in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 30The sixstory United States Embassy in Saigon withstood a determined Communist commando attack in 1968. Five Americans died in its defense.

title: REIT's Credit Plan
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust has given its creditor banks a plan for restructuring the trust's $761million of borrowings. Page 62.

title: Abercrombie & Fitch to Give Customer Refunds of $33,000
description: Abercrombie & Fitch, specialty store at Madison Avenue and 45th Street, known for its sporting goods and outdoor apparel and equipment, has agreed to refund to consumers $33.000 in unclaimed credit balances and to revise its method of dealing with existing and future balances in customer accounts, State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday.

title: An Arbitration Award Goes to Merrill Client
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., must pay a former client, Richard T. Tench, $30,000 because it failed to warn him sufficiently of the risk of various securities transactions it effected for him in 1970, 1971 and 1972, a fiveman arbitration panel ruled yesterday.

title: Camden Aide Testifies Before State Jury
description: TRENTON, April 30John Nero, chairman of the Camden County Municipal Utilities Authority, testified for more than three hours today before a state grand jury that is investigating the award of a contract by a former law partner of Governor Byrne.

title: Washington Preparing for Inaugural
description: I'm not what you call an ancestor worshipper, although I respect my family background, said Richard B. Washington, Lieutenant Colonel, United States Army, retired, son of Thomas Campbell Washington, son of Bushrod Corbin Washington, son of Thomas Blackburn Washington, son of Bushrod Corbin Washington, son of Corbin Washington, son of John Augustine Washington, brother of George.

title: FACTORIES TRIM BIG INVENTORIES
description: WASHINGTON, April 30Manufacturers finally succeeded in cutting topheavy inventories in March, the first reduction since August, 1971, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Market Averages
description: THE NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE

title: DOMINION TEXTILE IS SCORED BY DHJ
description: Herbert Haskell, chairman of DHJ Industries, Inc., a textile company, accused Dominion Textile, Ltd., yesterday of failing to live up to an agreement in connection with Dominion's teder offer for D H J common stock. Mr. Haskell said that Dominion had agreed to modify substantially the strict conditions, contained in its original offer; that concerned arrangements with creditors, and to raise the offer from $5 to $5.50 a share.

title: Frank Corsaro Is Projecting a New Image for Opera
description: One of the prestigious novelties of the New York City Opera's recent season is Erich Wolfgang Korngold's 1920 opera Die Tote Stadt. It is a hallucinatory fable, set in the Belgian city of Bruges, about the fanatic devotion of a man to the memory and some of the memorabilia of his dead wife.

title: $8.5Million Given To Einstein College For Cancer Center
description: The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University has received an $8.5million Federal grant to build new cancer research center in the Bronx, Dr, Samuel Belkin, the university's president, announced yesterday.

title: Vietnamese Saw Turmoil and Death
description: At left, Buddhist monk commits suicide by fire ?? Saigon in 1963, dur?? the demonstrations against President Ngo Dinh Diem. At right, women cry over coffins of victims of the Vietcong massacre in Hue in 1968. Below, children flee from their village after South Vietnamese planes dropped napalm on it by mistake.

title: Washington Is Preparing for Inaugural
description: I'm not what you call an ancestor worshiper, although I respect my family background, said Richard B. Washington, Lieutenant Colonel, United States Mrmy, retired, son of Thomas Campbell Washington, son of Bushrod Corbin Washington, son of Thomas Blackburn Washington, son of Bushrod Corbin Washington, son of Corbin Washington, son of John Augustine Washington, brother of George.

title: U.S. and Thailand in Dispute Over 125 Planes From Saigon
description: BANGKOK Thailand, April 130  A dispute has developed here over the fate of the 125 South Vietnamese Air Force planes that arrived in Thailand before the Saigon Government surrendered to the Communists.

title: Text of Communists' Policy Statement
description: PARIS, April 30Following is the text of a statement made today on behalf of the Provisional Revolutionary Government of South Vietnam and issued in translation by its representative in Paris, Dinh Ba Thi.

title: Nuclear Tests in Nevada MERCURY, Nev., April 30
description: (APThe second underground nuclear test in less than a week was conducted deep beneath the Nevada desert today. A spokesman said the test had a yield of between 20,000 and 200,000 tons of TNT but was at the lower end of the scale.

title: Kissinger Is Given Vote of Confidence In a Gallup Survey
description: Secretary of State Kissinger, the target of increasing criticism in Washington, has received a vote of confidence from a majority of the American people, according to Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: Nine Hospitals May Balk Over Insurance
description: Nine of the largest voluntary hospitals in Brooklyn have decided to handle only emergency cases if a satisfactory medical malpractice insurance program is not available by July 1, when their current coverage expires.

title: S.E.C. to Allow Brokers to Charge for Services
description: WASHINGTON, April 30The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted today a temporary rule exempting brokerdealers from certain provisions of the Investment Advisers Act.

title: Mrs. Ford Describes Sadness on Vietnam
description: Betty Ford said yesterday that she and President Ford were deeply saddened by the fall of the South Vietnamese Government and called the surrender by President Duong Van Minh very. tragic.

title: 6 Agencies Rebuffed on Taxi Ads
description: Who are the last people you'd expect to find bearing witness against advertising? Why agency people, of course. Yet Fred Papert, a founder of PKL Advertising and a member of the board of the Municipal Arts Society, managed get six of the biggest names in the business to do lust that.

title: Brewers Triumph, Yount Goes to 393
description: Robin Yount, 19yearold shortstop, collected three hits, raising his batting average to a hefty 393, and Darrell Porter and George Scott supplied key hits as the Brewers beat the Detroit Tigers, 62, at Milwaukee last night.

title: NASSAU EMPLOYES FACE JOB LOSSES
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 30The Nassau County Board of Supervisors said today it would announce tomorrow the terms of a new contract for the county's 12,500 municipal employes that could result in the loss of jobs and curtailment of programs.

title: Waiver on Child Labor Law For Berry Picking Rejected
description: WASHINGTON April 30 (AP) The House Education and Labor Committee defeated today a bill that would have permitted children under 12 years !old to pick berries this summer in Northwestern states.

title: From Paris to New York, the Timelessness of Chanel
description: Betty Ford and some 750 other women, dressed to the nines, shared a rather unusual phenomenon yesterday at lunch at the Hotel Pierre: They watched time stand still.

title: Chief Judge Is Seeking Wider Powers
description: ALBANY, May 1  Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel of the Court of Appeals, charging that recent legislative action on court reform has been dangerous, undesirable and replete with obvious defects, said today that he would soon propose an entire new judiciary article for the State Constitution.

title: BERGERAC CHOSEN AS REVLON CHIEF
description: Michael C. Bergerac, the 43yearold president of Revlon, Inc., was elected its chief executive officer yesterday.

title: Advertising
description: For Bruce Crawford, newly elected president of BBDO International, much of the fun of the ad business comes from problem solving  discovering what lies behind given condition.

title: BRITISH RAPE RULING STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: LONDON, May 1 (Reuters)Britain's law lords have ruled that a man cannot be convicted of rape if he honestly believed the woman had consented to sexual intercourse  no matter how unreasonable his belief might have been.

title: Aaron Breaks Mark For Runs Batted In
description: Two talented players, one old and the other young, were prominent yesterday in Milwaukee's County Stadium as the Brewers routed Detroit, 173, to climb into a firstplace tie in the American League's Eastern Division with the Tigers.

title: Name Change for United
description: The United Aircraft Corporation said yesterday that it has changed its name, effective immediately, to the United Technologies Corporation.

title: Beame and Carey Back A Balanced City Budget
description: ALBANY, May 1A New York City budget that will be balanced without city borrowingthereby virtually guaranteeing that New Yorkers will face some tax increaseswas endorsed today by Mayor Beanie and Governor Carey.

title: G. & W. Raises Dividend
description: Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it was raising its regular quarterly dividend on common stock to 27 cents a share from 25 cents. The dividend is payable July 1 to shareholders of record May 30.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Article 1  No Title
Syria Walks Out of Talks With Iraq on River Issue
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May (Reuters)  Syria withdrew today from an Arab League meeting that has been trying to resolve a dispute between Syria and Iraq over sharing of water from the Euphrates River.

title: Parolee Is Linked To 12 Robberies Of Bronx Doctors
description: The police said last night that they arrested a 26yearold parolce who had been linked toat least 12 robberies of doctors and physicians in the last year in the Morrisania and High Bridge sections of the Bronx.

title: Ford Asks Aid to Consumer
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) President Ford told five new members of the National Consumer Advisory Council today that American consumers needed help in two critical areas price and quality.

title: RapidAmerican Registered a Loss In the Fiscal Year
description: The RapidAmerican Corpora tion last night reported a net loss of $43.5million for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, in contrast to a pearearlier profit of $29.5million, or $3.14 a share. Sales, meanwhile, grew to $2.56billion from $2.53billion.

title: May Day Gunmen Flee In Soviet Mission's Car
description: It was May Day yesterday for international working men and women, and it was pay day for four members of the criminal class.

title: Burns Aims at 5% to 7% Money Growth
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, disclosed to Congress for the first time today the Reserve's target for growth of the nation's money supply in the year ahead and defended the figure as sufficient to finance a vigorous economic recovery.

title: Tax Bill for Glomar Explorer Will Go to Hughes
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1The Los Angeles County Assessor plans to present Howard R. Hughes's Summa Corporation with a 1975 tax bill of at least $1.2million on the Glomar Explorer, the ship that recovered a portion of a sunken Russian submarine for the Central Intelligence Agency last year.

title: President Vetoes Farm Bill As Congress Acts on Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 1President Ford vetoed the farm bill today, saying he was acting to hold the line on the budget deficit, which he has vowed to limit to $60billion.

title: Asian Communists Cheer TakeOver in Saigon as Others Ponder the Implication
description: HONG KONG, May 1Peking and other Communist capitals in Asia made the liberation of Saigon a dominant theme of their traditional May Day celebration today, while the rest of the region warily pondered its implications.

title: Doctors Limit Care In Protest on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1Surgical care at most hospitals in northern California was severely curtailed today in a controversy over the soaring cost of malpractice insurance.

title: In SoHo, MiddleClass Virtues and Goals
description: On weekends, the tourists pour into SoHo and women with large handbags and men in flowered shirts play Look, there's an artist as diligently as birdwatchers spotting exotic plumage. An artist is, of course, a rare bird who feeds on marijuana and cheap wine and his mate is a touslehaired slattern who's covered with goose bumps from posing in the nude

title: Urban Americans Moving to Rural Maine
description: BLUE HILL, Me., April 30The men and women who follow the arcane science of demography became aware recently that a significant change had taken place in the State of Maine. It had begun to gain population after decades of losing people.

title: CONTRACTS RISE IN CONSTRUCTION
description: Contracts for new construction in March rose from the February level but were still 15 per cent under the volume of March, 1974, the F. W. Dodge division of McGrawHill Information Systems reported yesterday. The Dodge index of construction contracts, with 1967 as 100, rose to 153 in March from 135 in February but was 28 points below 181 registered in March, 1974.

title: I.T.T. Increases Net 2.4% in the Quarter
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, which has been having profit problems, reported yesterday that its firstquarter consolidated net income rose to $106.6million, a 2.4 per cent increase over the same period last year.

title: HighLiving Mob Figure Guilty on Taxes
description: An alleged Mafia chieftain who entertained a girlfriend at such places as 21, the Four Seasons and El Morocco and gave her a diamond broach when presumably he was not earning enough to have to file an incometax return, has been found guilty of incometax fraud.

title: Harvard Club Bar Dryly Puts Martini Back on Pedestal
description: Spirits have been restored at the main bar at the Harvard Club. The 8to1 martinis are back.

title: American Business Trims Plans For 1975 Outlays, Survey Finds
description: American business has lowered its sights this year in capital investment for new plants and equipment, the McGrawHill Publications Company said yesterday. A total of $118.6billion will be spent for modernization and expansion in 1975, or only 5 per cent more than actual expenditures in 1974, the company said.

title: CORCO LOSES BID TO BLOCK TENDER
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company (Corco) lost a legal move yesterday to stop the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation from completing its tender offer for 38 per cent of Corco's stock next Tuesday.

title: Canadiens 70 Victors
description: MONTREAL, May 1 (UPI) Guy Lafleur scored three goals and Ken Dryden earned. his second playoff career shutout as the Montreal Canadiens routed Buffalo, 70, tonight, narrowing the Sabres' lead to 21 in their Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: Official Assures Arkansas Over Impact of Refugees
description: FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., May 1 Though some local residents oppose housing even a small number of Vietnamese refugees on this Army post, a State Department official said today that the exiles with the toughest resettlement problems might be sent here.

title: Buffalo Budget Cuts Jobs
description: BUFFALO, May I (AP) Mayor Stanley Makowski tecommended to the Common Council today a 6249.6million budget for operating the city and schools during the 197576 fiscal year, $20million higher than in the current year. The plan would do away with 293 salaried lobs, many of which are currently vacant.

title: 400 of State's Politicians Penalized on Fund Reports
description: ALBANY, May 1The State Board of Elections, for the first time, has obtained court orders, many of them including fines, against nearly 400 candidates for the Legislature who failed to file one or more campaign finance reports since the state's new campaign finance law went into effect last June 1.

title: John Leonard Is Named Times Cultural Writer
description: John Leonard, who has been editor of The New York Times Book Review since 1970, will leave that post to become the newspaper's chief cultural corresnondent.

title: Mrs. Ford Gets CheckUp
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI)  President Ford's Wife, Betty, underwent a cancer checkup today, and doctors found everything completely normal, a White House spokesman said.
