Mrs. Ford underwent surgery in September for removal of her right breast. A spokesman for Mrs. Ford said that she had undergone her periodic postsurgery checkup at the Bethesda Naval Hospital.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday stated erroneously that Barrie Sommerfield, vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue, changed his plea in March from not guilty to guilty in connection with Federal charges that he had conspired to fix prices of women's clothing. Mr. Sommerfield changed his plea to nolo contendere (no contest).

title: Quakers Complain of City Bias On Their DrugCare Program
description: A Quaker committee operating a drugtreatment program whose budget was cut by 60 per cent by the Addiction Services Agency has charged the city with religious discrimination, citing an evaluation report by the agency that said Quaker manners are terribly foreign to the program's largely poor, black clients.

title: People in Sports
description: Somewhat against his will and with a tinge of bitterness, Sonny Jorgensen was forced into retirement from the Washington Redskins yesterday. Coach George Allen declared at a news conference  with Jurgensen present that the 40yearold quarterback and his No. 9 jersey had been retired.

title: Wide Hostility Found As First Exiles Arrive
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1The arrival in the last few days of the first thousands of South Vietnamese refugees to be resettled in this recessionhobbled country has set off a groundswell of controversy.

title: Camden County Utility Official Indicted on a Charge of Bribery
description: TRENTON, May 1A state grand jury investigating alleged corruption in Camden County today indicted James Joyce, the Democratic county chairman there and one of New Jersey's most powerful political leaders, on charges of bribery and misconduct in office.

title: Church Schools a Queens Election Issue
description: Vincent J. Dwyer, the president of Community School Board 26 in Queens, who has sometimes been criticized as unduly favoring parochialschool interests, likes to twit audiences with remarks: You know me, I'm the guy they say wants to change the name of Alexander Graham Bell School to St. Alexander.

title: Moscow Applauds Victors in Vietnam In Restrained Tone
description: MOSCOW, May 1The Soviet tradership congratulated the Vietnamese Communists today on the liberation of practically all the territory of South Vietnam including Saigon.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Babcock & Wilcox Company has received contract. awards totaling $60million from the Energy Research and Development Administration. The work will he performed at the company's Naval nuclear fuel division in Lynchburg, Va.

title: GOLD PRICES OFF IN SLOW TRADING
description: Gold prices drifted down in slow volume yesterday amid two political rumors. Some bearish talk centered on the tons of gold flown out of South. Vietnam and refused a home in Switzerland. This gold, if sold, could lead to a temporary price decline.

title: The Governor's No
description: Governor Carey's refusal to accept the recommenda tion of a factfinding panel for an acrosstheboard increase of 6 per cent to state employes reflects the painful realities of the fiscal squeeze confronting the state and city governments.

title: RAPE AND SEDUCING SPLIT IN ACQUITTAL
description: A judge yesterday drew disctinction between rape and seduction and found that man could be crafty, scheming, manipulative and deceitful and use any other method short of force, threat or violence to bed a woman, without being guilty of rape.

title: LEO M'GINITY DIES; EXTIMES REPORTER
description: Leo A. McGinity, who retired as a general assignment reporter for The New York Times in 1959 after 40 years with the newspaper, died Wednesday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L. I. He was 82 years old and lived at 41 Hilton Avenue, Garden City, L. I.

title: Ford Urged to Bare Any Vietnam Pledges
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The publication of two letters from President Richard M. Nixon to President Nguyen Van Thieu of Sou,th Vietnam in 1972 and 1973 spurred new demands in the Senate today for a full disclosure by the Ford Administration of all private documents relating to possible American commitments to Saigon.

title: BARBARA DANE SINGS POLITICS AND BLUES
description: Pete Seeger and Ario Guthrie still give their concerts, to be sure, but ever since Bob Dylan went electric, the political folk song has gone underground. It is thus most refreshing indeed that Barbara Dane has broken a yearslong, selfimposed absence from the club circuit and returned for a week (through Sunday) to Folk City, 130 Third Street.

title: Comment by Expelled Priest
description: TOKYO, May 1 (AP)The Rev. James Sinnott, a Maryknoll priest from Brooklyn who was expelled from South Korea yesterday after 14 years as a missionary, told a news conference here today that prisoners of the Seoul Government were made to squat for hours with a wooden board held behind their knees while interrogators stood on their legs or poked them with umbrellas. Forced sleeplessness, water torture and electric shocks also were used, he said.

title: Bridge:
description: A pair representing the University of Missouri captured the North American intercollegiate title at Chicago last weekend. Heading the 16 pairs of finalists, survivors of an original entry of almost 1600 pairs, were Thomas Allen of Columbia, Mo., and Lee Goodman of Kansas City, Mo.

title: JURY SPLITS VERDICT IN PUROLATOR THEFT
description: CHICAGO, May 1 (UPI)A Federal jury returned a split decision today on the two prime suspects in the $4.3million burglary of Purolator Inc., the largest cash theft in U.S. history.

title: BELLEVUE QUIETLY BEGINS ITS MOVE
description: One of the largest hospital moves in history began quietly this week as the Bellevue Hospital Center, the nation's oldest public hospital, began transferring from a sprawl of aging buildings into its new $140million steel and glass tower.

title: Dance: Return of Balanchine Ivesiana
description: It is apparently seven years since the New York City Balet last danced George Balanchine's Ivesiana in New York. On Wednesday night at We New York State Theater, We company revived this 1954 work, and I was absotutely amazed to discover how long it had been absent from the repertory. Although I have seen the ballet once during the years betweenin Amsterdam danced by the Dutch National Balletit still seems scarcely longer ago than yesterday since it was in New York. This, on reflection, seemed the most telling tribute to the ballet's strange power of practically impregnating the memory. Ivesiana is not an easy work to appreciate, overlook or forget.

title: Angolan Rivals in 3d Day Of Fighting in the Capitol
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 1, (Reuters)  Sporadic shooting broke out in Luanda for the third day today among rival liberation groups.

title: JOURNALISTS NAMED TO HALL OF FAME
description: Ten living journalists were named yesterday by the New York Chapter of Sigma Delta Chi to the professional society's Hall of Fame. The selection is part of the group's 50th anniversary, which the New York chapter will observe with a dinner on May 20.

title: Oropez Advances In Eastern Tennis
description: WOODBURY, L. I., May 1 Willie Oropez of New York, fifth seeded, defeated Tony Bardsley of Canada, 62, 62, in the quarterfinals of the Eastern hardcourt tennis championships today.

title: AsheOkker In Semifinals
description: MEXICO CITY, May 1 The fourthseeded pair of Arthur Ashe and Tom Okker ousted John Alexander and Phil Dent, 46, 63, 76, 63, today in the quarterfinals of the World Championship Tennis doubles tournament.

title: About New York
description: During the twoweek period that began on Monday about 100 makers of women's clothing here are showing their fall collections to buyers for stores around the country, to the press and to rich women who dress richly.

title: Election Panel Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, May 1John G. Murphy Jr., a professor at the Georgetown University Law Center, was appointed today as general counsel of the new Federal Elections Commission, which will administer the campaign regulations and subsidies that Congress enacted last year. Mr. Murphy, who is 37 years old, was a legal consultant to the Office of Economic Opportunity from 1965 to 1969 His new job pays $36,000 year.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: President Vetoes Farm Bill As Congress Acts on Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 1President Ford vetoed the farm bill today, saying he was acting to hold the line on the budget deficit, which he has vowed to limit to $60billion.

title: Army Engineers Creating Salt Marshes From Sediment
description: The Army Corp of Engineers, whose dirtyred barges annually dredge up millions of tons of bay and river muck to keep the nation's harbors and waterways clear, is often accused of destroying wetlands and shellfish beds when its barges spew out their snoin.

title: JACKSON DOUBTS HATHAWAY TALLY
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Henry M. Jackson, chairman of the Senate Interior Committee, will ask Gov. Calvin L. Rampton of Utah to clarify a statement made to the committee yesterday that 49 of the Governors in office in the last two years supported the nomination of Stanley K. Hathaway to be Secretary of the Interior.

title: PROTESTERS SEIZE OFFICES OF DEAN
description: PISCATAWAY, May 1 About 100 students at Livingston College here seized the offices of the dean shortly be fore noon today and announced they would remain until Rutgers University instituted changes in its meal and residence requirements.

title: Klein Emphasizes Suffolk's Austerity In Capital Program
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., May 1Responding to a deteriorating economic situation in this oncebooming area, John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, today presented a $700million capital program that proposed a moratorium on new projects for the county during the next three years.

title: Brownings' Lives, Love and Lyrics Illuminated in Public Library Show
description: How do we celebrate them? Let us count the ways.

title: Market Place
description: Investors are accustomed to seeing the opinion of certified public accountants on annual reports. And although some are skeptical when they read that the accountants believe the company has kept its books in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles, most regard those words from independent outside firms as assurance that things are what they seem to be.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University, who had suggested review of his five years in office, has been asked by the trustees to continue with what was described as a warm handshake of confidence from all.

title: Alleged Hijacker Arrested
description: CLEVELAND. May 1 (UPI)  Everett L. White, 34 years old. of Cadiz, Ohio, was arrested here yesterday, by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who charged him with air piracy in the hijacking of an Eastern Airlines passenger plane; to Cuba on Jan. 28, 1939. The F.B.I. said Mr. White returned to the United States recently from Cuba after six years and had been living with a brother in Cleveland Heights.

title: Brownings' Lives, Love and Lyrics Illuminated in Public Library Show
description: How do we celebrate them? Let us count the ways.

title: License to Restore WNCN Sought by Chicago Group
description: A new corporation, Concert Radio, Inc., yesterday filed with the Federal Communications Commission a competing application for the license to operate the rock station WQIVFM, with the proposal to return, it to its previous classical format under its original call letters of WNCNFM.

title: Hunter Blanks Orioles
description: The devisive boos Catfish Hunter heard not too long ago at Shea Stadium turned to cheers and chants of Catfish, Catfish, Catfish last night as the multimillionaire Yankee outpitched Jim Palmer, the talented Baltimore Oriole who preceded him as the American League's Cy Young Award winner.

title: Exchanges Close Abroad
description: Securities and commodities exchanges in several countries, including Argentina, Belgium. France, Italy, Switzerland and West Germany, were closed yesterday for the Mayday holiday.

title: Board to Decide Fate Of Coast Study Center
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1 The board of directors of the fiscally troubled Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions will meet in Santa Barbara on May 10 to resolve the fate of the California based study center.

title: Rises in British Sales Tax End Luxury Buying Spree
description: LONDON, May 1 A consumer stampede for kitchen appliances, phonographs, fur coats, television sets, cigarettes and wines and liquors ended today as sweeping tax increases aimed at balancing the Government's budget went into effect.

title: House and Senate Pass Budget Guides
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Thel House of Representatives, by a tiny majority, and the Senate, by a large one, approved today guidelines for next year's Federal spending that were somewhat, but not greatly, higher, than the totals proposed by the Ford Administration.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: They're 12 and 13 years old, and they seem so young to be already planning a lifetime away from home. But for the children who will be attending high school couple of years from now in some idyllic spot far from the city, the search for that school has begun.

title: 88% Rise Registered in Quarter Earnings
News Summary and Index
description: The House overwhelmingly rejected a bill yesterday that would have authorized $327million in aid for Vietnamese refugees as the Administration reported that the number of refugees had grown by 10,000 to 84,000. The vote was 246 to 162. President Ford later issued a statement saying he was saddened and disappointed. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: INTERFAITH TIES SEEN IMPROVED
description: Three prominent theologians of the major faiths agreed yesterday, that relations between Jews and Christians had improved in the last year but they expressed concern that a hard core of antiJewish sentiment still remained.

title: 400 of State's Politicians Penalized on Fund Reports
description: ALBANY, May 1The State Board of Elections, for the first time, has obtained court orders, many of them including fines, against nearly 400 candidates for the Legislature who failed to file one or more campaign finance reports since the state's new campaign finance law went into effect last June 1.

title: Burns Aims at 5% to 7% Money Growth
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, disclosed to Congress for the first time today the Reserve's target for growth of the nation's money supply in the year ahead and defended the figure as sufficient to finance a vigorous economic recovery.

title: ROCKEFELLER BACKS VIETNAM SILENCE
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Vice President Rockefeller told leaders of the National Urban Coalition today that he had declined to criticize American involvement in Vietnam in the nineteensixties because he feared he would harm New York State's chances of obtaining Federal aid.

title: VIETNAM MERGER NOT LIKELY SOON
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 1  Authoritative sources here said today that two different political, economic and social systems would probably prevail in Vietnam for some time, leading in steps to the reunification of the North and South.

title: Bill by Javits Seeks to Revive Flow Of Donations to Museums by Artists
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Senator Jacob K. Javits is trying to restore the flow of gifts by writers, composers and other creative artists of their own works to the Library of Congress, museums, universities and other institutions.

title: Cambodia Evacuees Overdue at Border
description: ARANY APRATHET, Thailand, May 1Camboaian Communist, French and Thai Government officials met repeatedly today across the bridge here that marks the ThaiCambodian border, but the discussions failed to produce any firm word on the whereabouts of foreigners who have been isolated in the French Embassy compound in Phnom Penh.

title: A Monetary Pragmatist
description: Paul Volcker is the best Monopoly player in the world, said Robert Kavesh, an economist, friend and former classmate of the man who will become the new President of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. He uner

title: School Campaign Intensifies in Manhattan
Music: The Guarneri
description: The Guarneri String Quarlet did some eloquent pleadMg for neglected music Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall. Rudolf Firkusny joined the group as piano soloist in Faurs Piano Quartet No. in G minor, one of those consistently skillful and intermittently lovely pieces that somehow miss having the individuality necessary to lodge themselves in the chambermusic public's consciousness. And, going even farther afield, the Guarneri dug out the Sibelius Quartet in D minor (Voces Intimae), a work that once had influential admirers but is now all but igriored.

title: Indian's Trial to Move
description: SHAWANO, Wis., May I (UPI)  Circuit Court Judge Henry Gergen granted a change of venue yesterday to five members of Menominee Warrior Society charged in connection with the armed takeover of Roman Catholic novitiate this winter. He ordered the trial moved to Juneau in Dodge County but refused a petition asking he be removed as the judge in the case because of bias.

title: Restaurant Reviews; A Simple Place, Seating Just 21 (or 25), With Turkish Food That Is Unbeatable
description: It couldn't happen to a nicer restaurant, and it's a shame to do it, but it is necessary to write about Istanbul Cuisine, which has been rocking along for eight years now at 315 Amsterdam Avenue (near 75th Street) unnoticed except by Turkish ambassadors, occasional selfeffacing movie stars, the staff of the nearby American Museum of Natural History, and some plain people who think that about$10orlessandbringyourownliquor is the most astounding bargain in town for the kind of food you get here, which is Turkish and unbeatable.

title: FORD AND SADAT TO MEET IN JUNE IN AUSTRIAN CITY
description: WASHINGTON, May 1President Ford will meet with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt in Salzburg, Austria, in the first days of June, and is considering a later meeting with Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel.

title: Toward Cleaner Air
description: The agreement by Mayor Beame and Governor Carey to reduce motor vehicle pollution here comes like breath of fresh airfiguratively and literallyto a city that has suffered too long from the injurious effects the internal combustion engine.

title: Holliger's AvantGarde Siebengesang Has Premiere
description: Heinz Holliger, considered by many the Heifetz of the oboe (though in his circles that might be considered an insult), put reed to mouth last night in Carnegie Hall. With the Contemporary Chamber Ensemble, conducted by Arthur Weisberg, the Swiss avantgardist played a work he had composed in 1967the Siebengesang, for oboe, orchestra, seven women's voices and loudspeakers. It was its United States premiere.

title: THE WORKER AS COMMODITY
description: BALTIMOREWorkers in American factories live under a sophisticated kind of dictatorship legitimated by socalled collectivebargaining agreements and policed by collaborationist unions. It is a dictatorship that subordinates workers and makes them vulnerable, in part by keeping them ignorant.

title: MISS KRUPSAK CUTS HER SALARY BY $3,750
description: ALBANY, May 1 (UPI)Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak said today she would trim her $60.000 annual salary by $3,750.

title: Doctors Limit Care In Protest on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1Surgical care at most hospitals in northern California was severely curtailed today in a controversy over the soaring cost of malpractice insurance.

title: The View From the Wheelchair
description: HARTFORD, May 1Two leading Connecticut political figures, along with 250 other healthy people around the state, spent most of the day today in wheelchairs to dramatize problems encountered by the handicapped.

title: Nessen Spars With Reporters Regarding Vietnam and Evacuation
description: WASHINGTON, May 1As President Ford urged the United States once again to look to the future and not back at Vietnam, his spokesman reacted testily today to lingering questions about the nation's past involvement there.

title: Harlem Troupe Dances After Corinth
description: Any visitor from Mars would have been greatly impressed by After Corinth, a new ballet by Walter Raines that was presented by the Dance Theater of Harlem on Wednesday night at the Uris Theater.

title: Stones Tour Is On and So Is Ticket Rush
description: With the shy diffidence for which they are famous, the Rolling Stones announced a threemonth tour of the Western Hemisphere at 12:30 yesterday afternoon by singing Brown Sugar from a flatbed truck on Fifth Avenue and then tossing handbills to a surprised growing crowd.

title: Sales in April Off Sharply At the Major Retail Chains
description: April sales of the nation's largest retail chains faltered sharply, reflecting the leanest results of the year so far compared with the corresponding 1974 month.

title: Dow Industrials Up 9.62 In Busy Trading Session
description: The stock market ended higher yesterday in accelerated trading as Wall Street began a new era of competition in brokerage rates. Yesterday was the first time in 183 years that the nation's brokerage houses operated without tixed commission rates.

title: Article 2  No Title
Mets Are Beaten by Cubs, 52
description: CHICAGO, May 1  The Chicago Cubs beat the Mets again today, by a score of 52. And it was an inopportune occasion for the New York club to lose. Some of the qualities generated from the team's recent sevengame winning streak were washed away and the possibility of making it into first place in the National League's East Division sometime soon dimmed considerably.

title: Charles J. Solomon Dies at 69; Won 7 National Bridge Titles
description: Charles J. Solomon, one of the leading figures in the world of contract bridge, died in Philadelphia yesterday morning after a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

title: But Says President Park's, Policies Are Still Best
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 1A senior member of South Korea's ruling party said today that President Park Chung Hee's restrictive political policies had failed to achieve the intended national unity but asserted that they still represented the best course.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 3.3 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 198.9 from 202.2 last week.

title: A 10YEAR EXTENSION OF VOTE ACT BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) The House Judiciary Committee approved today by a vote of 27 to 7 a 10year extension of the Voting Rights Act, defeating every Republican attempt to modify its provisions.

title: REFUGEES SWELL CALIFORNIA CAMP
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 1Processing of refugees at this Marine Corps base picked up tempo today as the number of displaced Vietnamese overtook the initial swell of Americans and their dependents returning from Vietnam.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: JAMES W. SCOTT

title: N.C.A.A. Puts Seton Hall On TwoYear Probation
description: KANSAS CITY, May 1 (AP) Seton Hall Univerity has been placed on probation for two years by the National Collegiate Athietic Association, which cited the school for questionable ethical conduct and improper recruiting and financial aid for basketball players.

title: Voluntary Nursing Homes Say Curbs Could Hurt Operations
description: ALBANY, May 1Representatives of voluntary, or nonprofit, hospitals and homes for the aged warned the Assembly subcommittee on health care today that attempts to abolish abuses in the nursing home industry, found primarily in profitmaking homes could severely hamper the operations of their institutions.

title: Election in Ulster Is Marked by Violence
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 1Northern Ireland voted today for a 78member convention that is intended to work out a new form of selfgovernment for Britain's troubled province.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it was introducing a variablerate certificate of deposit that would pay its holders a premium of 1 percentage points over the threemonth Treasury bill rate. The latter currently 5.6 per cent, so the rate on the new certificates would start at 6.55 per cent. The rate will be changed monthly, the bank said.

title: 2,500 Refugees Leaving Guam for U.S. Mainland
description: ANDERSEN AIR FORCE BASE, Guam, Friday, May 2The refugee airlift, which four days ago was hauling as many South Vietnamese as possible to this small Pacific island, is now carrying away more than 2,500 people a day toward new lives in the continental United States.

title: Byrne Agrees to Reduce Tax Plan by $100Million
description: TRENTON, May IGovernor Byrne agreed today to a substantial reduction of his proposed $750million tax program in a compromise designed to enlist the necessary legislative support. However, legislative leaders gave the proposal only a small chance of gaining legislative approval.

title: POOR ARE DENIED AID FOR DIVORCE
description: The State Court of Appeals, in a landmark opinion, ruled yesterday that a poor person seeking a divorce did not have the right to be represented by a lawyer paid from public funds.

title: CHRYSLER SHOWS LOSS FOR QUARTER
description: DETROIT, May 1  The Chrysler Corporation reported today a net loss of $94.1million for the first quarter of 1974, the company's largest loss for any quarter in its history.

title: Swiss Banker Linked to Israel Held in Fraud Case
description: GENEVA, May 1  Tibor Rosenbaum, the Hungarianborn Swiss banker who has been involved in controversy over funds raised to promote Israeli development, has been arrested here on suspicion of dishonest management and fraud.

title: Wide Hostility Found To Vietnamese Influx
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1The arrival in the last few days of the first thousands of South Vietnamese refugees to be resettled in this recessionhobbled country has set off a groundswell of controversy.

title: Treasury Says Tax Receipts Exceed Its Expectations
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Treasury disclosed today that its borrowing needs in the half year ending June 30 will be $5billion less than previously estimated because tax receipts are running higher than expected.

title: Deficit of 21Million Is First Since 1940
description: The Southern Pacific Company, the second largest revenue producer among the nation's railroads after the Penn Central reported yesterday a $21.6 million loss for the first quarter. It was the first time since thesecond quarter of 1940 that the Sotuhern Pacific had operated in the red.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Several hundred high school students demonstrated peacefully in front of Newark's City Hall and the Board of Education to protest the impending dismissal of the largest number of teachers in New Jersey history. The protesters, most of whom walked out of East Side High School after learning of the layoffs and planned cutbacks in nearly every major public school program, dispersed from the steps of City Hall after student delegations met with Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and school administrators. Stanley Taylor, Superintendent of Schools, said that 877 teachers, 50 administrators, and 685 others were to be dismissed on July 1 unless some way was found to replace $14million in funds cut from the city's school budget.

title: Islanders Beaten, 54, In Overtime; Trail, 20
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 1The New York Islanders lost, 5.4, to the Philadelphia Flyers tonight when Bobby Clarke scored off his skate at 2 minutes 56 seconds of overtime. But the young New Yorkers won some more converts with yet another dramatic comeback, rallying from a threegoal deficit and scoring twice within 14 seconds late in the final period to tie the score at 44 and send the game into suddendeath overtime.

title: POOR ARE DENIED AID FOR DIVORCE
description: The New York State Court of Appeals, in a landmark opinion, ruled yesterday that a poor person seeking a divorce did not have the right to be represented by a lawyer paid from public funds.

title: Art: Helen Frankenthaler at Corcoran
description: WASHINGTONWhen Ernest Flagg designed the upstairs rooms at the Corcoran Gallery here he did a terrific day's work. Opened in 1897, they are still some of the finest things of their kind in the country. They call out for painting that is ambitious in scale, deep and steady in its breathing and heartfelt in its commitment to the unexhausted potential of painting.

title: ...and Responsibility
description: Too many extraneous issues were involved in yesterday's defeat of the Vietnam humanitarian aid proposal in the House of Representatives to justify President Ford's denunciation of this vote as an indication of lack of Congressional concern. New legislation targeted directly to the resettlement problem in this country already in preparation and should be expedited. Congress has an inescapable responsibility to make speedy and adequate financing available.

title: Auto Output Down By 12.9% in April To a 14Year Low.
description: DETROIT, May 1American auto production totaled 590,463 units last month, off 12.9 per cent from the 677,748 cars built in April, 1974, and the lowest for any April in 14 years.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: About Wrens
description: There is, it turns out, a good reason for a wren being called a wren, a word that had its beginnings in the Old English word wraenna, meaning lascivious.

title: FORD AND SADAT TO MEET IN JUNE IN AUSTRIAN CITY
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 President Ford will meet with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt in Salzburg, Austria, in the first days of June, and is considering a later meeting with Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel.

title: A Time for Reflection
description: WASHINGTON, May 1After the fall of Saigon, renamed HoCity, you might think that Washington needs little time for quiet reflection, but that's not the way it is. The hunt is on for explanations, lessons and scapegoats, and our gabbiest politicians are popping off before they have anything sensible to say.

title: SUPPLY OF MONEY IN SHARP DECLINE
Rape and Guile Separated As a Suspect Is Acquitted
description: A judge yesterday drew a disctinction between rape and seduction and found that a man could be crafty, scheming, manipulative and deceitful and use any other method short of force, threat or violence to bed a woman, without being guilty of rape.

title: RICHARD RICK, 73, LED STORE CHAIN
description: Richard H. Rich, a member of the Atlanta family that founded Rich's Department Store in 1867, died yesterday in Houston He was 73 years old.

title: Chairman of Mobil Sees Energy Security Jeopardized
description: SAN DIEGO, May 1Praisel for President Ford's proposal to release the oil industry from the Government's only remaining price controls was coupled today at the Mobil Oil Corporation's annual meeting with a warning to Congress against further puntive actions.

title: Veto of Death Penalty Bill Is Upheld in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, May 1 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate sustained, today a veto of a bill providing the death penalty for nine kinds of murder, thus defeating the measure.

title: A Possible Resurgence of Ancient Asian Frictions
description: PARIS, May 1The sudden and sometimes apparently contradictory twists of the various Indochinese Communist parties have surprised knowledgeable French officials and scholars.

title: Veto of Death Penalty Bill Is Upheld in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, May 1 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate susta ned today a veto of a bill providing the death penalty for nine kinds of murder, thus defeating the measure.

title: SEA EVACUATION CONCLUDED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that United States Navy ships, which had been picking up refugees fleeing by small boats, had left the coast of South Vietnam.

title: Consultants on Tocks Accused of Bias
description: PORT JERVIS, N. Y., May 1Consultants reviewing the need for a Tocks Island dam were charged today with being biased in favor of the dam.

title: It Might Have Been
description: This is a time of reflection and reminiscence and wondering for everyone whose life and work and attitudes were altered by Vietnam. Secretary Kissinger, for example, recalling his negotiation of the Paris accords of 1973, said at his recent news conference:

title: Sadat Says Soviet Refused Plea for a Delay on Debts
description: CAIRO, May 1President Anwar elSadat said today that the Soviet leadership had rejected his demand for a rescheduling of payment on Egypt's large debts to the Soviet Union.

title: Flash! Aesop, on Coast, Comments on Vietnam
description: BERKELEY, CALIF. AN ostrich one day, aggrieved because of assaults on its character, chose to walk along a sunny beach, in hope that nature might unruffle its feathers. Doing so, it chanced upon a Congressman.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EAST LYNN To her sure fingers, Lynn Richards adds a cool, casual voice and a smiling mien at the piano of Jacques' Tik Tak, a restaurant at 210 East 58th Street (south side, near Third Avenue). This is a new place with Continental menu and a long bar (vodka is $2) where you can perch near the music up front. Miss Richards, who accedes to song requests, adds an earthy flavor to the rather stylish decor. Her casual way at the keys is deceptive; she obviously has a firm technique.

title: Foul Play Doubted By F.B.I. in Death Of Atomic Worker
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Justice Department said today that the death of a young woman who had raised serious safety questions about an Oklahoma plutonium factory did not appear to be murder.

title: Donovan Hit With Suit By Braves
description: The suit, filed in New York State Supreme Court, asked that Donovan be banned from working for the Knicks as general manager or for any other National Basketball Association team before July 29, 1977. That is the date on which a threeyear agreement Donovan was supposed to have reached with Snyder runs out.

title: HOUSE, 246 TO 162, BARS $327MILLION FOR REFUGEES' AID
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The House of Representatives overwhelmingly rejected today a bill that would have authorized $327million in aid for Vietnamese refugees as the Administration reported that the number of those refugees had swelled by 10,000 to 84,000.

title: Finn, Austrian Win At Games in Israel
description: TEL. AVIV, May 1 (AP)Finland and Austria won gold medals today in the opening events of the 10th Hapoel Games, organized by the Israeli trade union movement.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, MAY 2, 1975

title: Amex Employes Vote To Approve a Contract
description: A contract, which will give them an 18 per cent pay increase over the next two years, was approved last night by the unionized employes of the American Stock Exchange. The first year's increase will be 12 per cent; the second's, 6 per cent.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: JOHN M. HOUSTON

title: Where to Seek Information
description: It will probably be couple of years before the Parents League of New York holds another event bringing together boarding school admissions directors, parents and children.

title: Texas Eastern Bid Deferred For Increase in Gas Rate
description: The Federal Power Commission suspended yesterday for fine months a proposed $103.2million natural gas rate increase request made by the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, one of the nation's largest wholessale natural gas companies.

title: Harvard Club Bar Drily Puts Martini Back on Pedestal
description: Spirits have been restored at the main bar at the Harvard Club. The 8to1 martinis are back.

title: Egypt Leads in Cup Play
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 1 (AP)Ismail ElShafei and Ali EIDaoudi gave Egypt a 20 lead over Monaco today in Group A Davis Cup tennis play. EIShafei beat Louis Borfiga 75, 60, 61, and ElDaoudi defeated Emmanuel Vanderpol, 64, 62, 75.

title: Senate Opposes Ford Plan to Decontrol Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Acting with unusual speed, the Senate expressed opposition today to President Ford's intention to end all crude oil price controls within two years.

title: OTB Takes Derby Bets Today
description: Eddie Arcaro, who likes Prince Thou Art in tomorrow's running of the Kentucky Derby, showed up yesterday at the Times Square Offtrack Betting Corporation parlor to publicize OTB's separate parimutuel pools on the race and to leave his wager with Joe Burke, a bartender at Gough's Chop House on 43d Street.

title: Reds Report TakeOver Of Vietnam Is Complete
description: The new Communist rulers of South Vietnam announced yesterday that their forces had completed the takeover of all areas of resistance that had remained after the surrender of Saigon Wednesday.

title: California's Senate Votes Bill Repealing Sexual Prohibitions
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 1 UPI)  Lieut. Gov. Mervyn symally cast the tiebreaking vote in the California Senate tonight to pass a bill legalizing sex acts between consenting adults in private.

title: Britain Urges Commonwealth To Negotiate Commodities Pact
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 1 Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain urged the nations of the Commonwealth today to support his proposals for stabilizing the prices of food and raw materials through a general agreement on commodities, to which producer and consumer nations would adhere.

title: Canada Plans to Admit 3,000 South Vietnamese
description: OTTAWA, May 1 (Reuters) Canada will accept 3,000 South Vietnamese refugees, Immigration Minister Robert Andras said in the House of Commons today.

title: JOANNE LITTLE TRIAL IS MOVED TO RALEIGH
description: WASHINGTON, N.C., May 1 (AP)A state judge today ordered the murder trial of Joanne Little moved away from here to Raleigh, in Wake County.

title: 5 AUTHORS WINNERS OF BANCROFT PRIZES
description: The Bancroft Prizes, given annually by Columbia University, were awarded last night to Stanley L. Engerman and Robert W. Fogel, authors of Time on the Cross, the twovolume study or American slavery; Eugene D. Genovese, author of another slavery work, Roll, Jordan, Roll, and Alexander L. George and Richard Smoke, who wrote Deterrence in American Foreign Policy: Theory and Practice.

title: 142 duPont Layoffs End
description: SEAFORD, Del., May 1 (UPI) E.1. duPont de Nemours & Co., Inc., said 142 employes at a local nylon plant returned to work today in the first callback of workers laid off in recent months. A company official said the recall was made possible by an improved market for fibers produced at the facility.

title: SEA EVACUATION CONCLUDED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that United States Navy ships, which had been picking up refugees fleeing by small boats, had left the coast of South Vietnam.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday stated erroneously that Barrie Sommerfield, vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue, changed his plea in March from not guilty to guilty in connection with Federal charges that he had conspired to fix prices of women's clothing. Mr. Sommerfield changed his plea to nolo contendere (no contest).

title: The Stage
KENYATTA FAILS TO RALLY CROWD
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 1For the first time in the history of independent Kenya, President Jomo Kenyatta failed today to capture and carry with him a mass crowd, an event that seemed to confirm a shift in political sentiment here.

title: People and Business
description: The Secretary of Labor, John T. Dunlop, said yesterday that the jobless rate would not go much higher than the 8.7 per cent level reported for March before it peaked.

title: State's Conservatives Join Move to Stop Amenciment by Lobbying Campaign
description: ALBANY, May 1The move to stop the proposed women's rights amendment picked up momentum today as the state Conservative party announced its support of an alternative measure that would, in effect, keep the amendment off the referendum ballot next November.

title: West 96th St. Builder Agrees To Cut Plans by Three Floors
description: The builder of a proposed apartment house  department store complex at Broadway and Vest 96th Street has decided to reduce the building's height from 31 to 28 stories and to finance renovation of the intersection's subway station to ease community opposition to the luxury complex.

title: AWARDS ARE MADE BY URBAN LEAGUE
description: The New York Urban League neld its 10th annual Frederick' Douglass Awards Dinner last night, and in addition to giving, its usual awards in the field of civil rights it honored the 2,000 young people who have been served by its street academies.

title: An End to Apathy!
description: Next Tuesday, in the third citywide Community School Boards election, voters will pick the 288 citizens to be entrusted with stewardship over New York's 32 decentralized school districts. This is a decision of utmost importance to the quality of the schools, which in turn has much to do with the quality of the city.

title: BRIBERY CHARGED TO CAMDEN AIDE
description: TRENTON, May 1A state grand jury investigating alleged corruption in Camden County today indicted James Joyce, the Democratic county chair. man there and one of New Jersey's most powerful political leaders, on charges of bribery and misconduct in office.

title: HOUSE, 246 TO 162, BARS $327MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The House of Representatives overwhelmingly rejected today a bill that would have authorized $327million in aid for Vietnamese refugees as the Administration reported that the number of those refugees had swelled by 10,000 to 84,000.

title: Small Investors Stoic While Institutions Bargain Hard as Negotiated Rates Begin
description: Amid some confusion, a considerable amount of gentlemanly horse trading and occasional secrecy, Mayday came to Wall Street quietly yesterday. For the first time in almost 200 years, on the direct orders of the Securities and Exchange Commission, stockbrokers abandoned fixed commission rates.

title: CANADA TO RAISE LEGISLATORS' PAY
description: OTTAWA, May 1The House of Commons has approved a controversial bill to raise the salaries and allowances of members of both houses of Parliament by one third, putting the Federal lawmakers in a higher income bracket than all but a thin upper layer of Canadian wage earners.

title: Price of New York Post Will Rise to 25c Monday
description: The New York Post is increasing its newsstand price on Monday by 5 cents to 25 cents a copy.

title: Reds Report TakeOver Of Vietnam Is Complete
description: The new Communist rulers of South Vietnam announced yesterday that their forces had completed the takeover of all areas of resistance that had remained after the surrender of Saigon Wednesday.

title: Brandeis Officials Go to Court to End Student TakeOver
description: WALTHAM, Mass., May 1 Brandeis University officials went into court today in hopes of ousting students who have taken over the school's sociology building in a budget dispute. The move came after neotiations between students and the administration broke down this morning.

title: Faith and Credit
description: Although the moral obligation bonds of the Urban Development Corporation are not formally backed by the full faith and credit of the State of New York, the long and arduous salvage operation that has finally rescued this overextended public corporation from the brink of bankruptcy was an act of good faith that does credit to both Governor Carey and the Legislature.

title: Yonkers Bid Accepted
description: YONKERS, May 1The owners of Young Quinn, said 10 he the fastest harness horse of the Southern Hemisphere since Cardigan Bay, have accepted an invitation to Yonkers Raceway's first International Pace since 1971, Timothy Rooney, Yonkers president announced today. The 5yearold New Zealand pacer, undefeated in his last 11 starts, will leave Auckland May 13 to prepare for the $100,000 race on June 14.

title: Elide Webb Dawson, 79, Cotton Club Dancer, Dies
description: Elida Webb Dawson, a dancer and choreographer at the Cotton Club in Harlem from 1923 to 1934, died early yesterday morning at the Park West Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at 746 St. Nicholas Avenue.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Space, scientific and technical subcommittee10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Position Is Second Only to Burns's in Banking System
description: Paul A. Volcker, the outspoken pragmatist who managed the country's international monetary relations for five turbulent years from 1969 until 1974 as Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, was formally named yesterday to head the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. His job is the second most powerful position in the central banking system.

title: LAW DAY DRAWS MIXED COMMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 1They sat quietly in rows of chairs in a small converted church near the edge of the cityall of them black and 60 or older, most in their 70's, most on the lower income levelwaiting for the dean of the Howard University Law School to talk to them about the law.

title: No More Caribbean Junkets In the Name of Sex Equality
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 (UPI)No more African safaris, French cooking schools or Caribbean junkets to promote sex equality, the Bank of America has been told by a Federal District Court judge.

title: Newark Students Protest SchoolStaff Cut of 1,600
description: NEWARK, May 1Several, hundred highschool students, demonstrated today in front of City Hall and the Board of Education building here to protest the impending dismissal of more than 1,600 publicschool teachers, administrators and workers20 per cent of the school payrolland the curtailing of curricular and extracurricular programs.

title: Gains on Greek Bases
description: The Government of Greece has now indicated clearly that it will not permit resentment over United States behavior during the Cyprus tragedy of 1974 to destroy the links with this country that are vital for Greek security. Negotiations about the American military presence in Greece have not been concluded; but the communique issued after the latest talks suggests the likelihood of settlement reasonably satisfactory to both countries.

title: Youth Robs Teachers
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 1 (AP) An armed teenager invaded a high school faculty lounge yesterday, robbed the 12 teachers of $48 and threatened to shoot them but his pistol jammed, the police said. He then fled. It could not be determined if he was a pupil at the school.

title: L.I. Stars Defeated By Ukrainian Five
description: HEMPSTEAD, I., I., May 1  The Ukrainian junior basketball team from Kiev rallied from a 7point deficit to defeat the Long Island junior allstars, 8685, tonight at Hofstra University.

title: Justice Marshall Rejects Plans To Ease High Court's Caseload
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  As sociate Justice Thurgood Marshall said tonight that he op posed all the varying plans that would ease the Supreme Court's workload by creating a new national court of appeals to share the judicial burden.

title: Books of The Times
description: ARE WE THERE YET? By Diane Vreuls. 190 pages. Simon & Schuster. $6.95. I believe Are We There Yet? is the first authentic picaresque novel by a woman that I have read, and I guess this fact has its own peculiar significance. In a way, it seems even more startling than women's sexual freedom did when that first broke into print. In the light of the morning atter, it did not seem extraordi nary that women could write, and feel, about sex with as much detachment as men did. But for a woman to take to the road, not hitchhiking but pushing a cart all across Ohio, a female Don Quixote with a 4yearold daughter for her Sancho Panzathis is really a radical departure. Emma Benson, the heroine of Diane Vreuls's Are We There Yet?, is one of that tribe of women who have set up housekeeping squarely in the center of despair and somehow seem to thrive in it. She ought to get along fine with the heroines of Diane Johnson's The Shadow Knows and Joy Williams's State of Grace. They could sit on the ground and talk about the death of kings, as Shakespeare says somewhere.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: David J. Vervaet, who was convicted of manslaughter in the fatal shooting of Magistrate Joseph J. Crescente, of Wanaque was sentenced in Paterson to an indeterminate term at the Yardville Youth Correctional Facility. Mr. Vervaet, 19 years old, also of Wanaque, was described by Judge Thomas R. Rumana of Passaic County Court at the sentencing as a follower who participated in the Nov. 4 shooting out of foolishness rather than malice.

title: Where Derby Winners Come From
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., May 1This is Darby Dan Farm, these green and gentle meadows beside Old Frankfort Pike. Here in these whitefenced paddocks more than 30 colts destined to run in the Kentucky Derby wrestled and fought and romped as yearlings and, growing up, went off to the burly burly of Churchill Downs, which is 70 miles from here by road and a million light years away in spirit. When this was part of Colonel Edward R. Bradley's Idle Hour Farm it was home to Behave Yourself and Black Servant, who ran one, two in the Derby of 1921, and to Bubbling Over and Bagenbaggage, who did the same in 1926. This is where Burgoo King started, the chestnut colt that carried Bradley's green and white to victory in 1932, and also Brokers Tin, who brought the feisty old gambler his fourth Derby a year later. Now John W. Galbreath breeds his Derby winners hereChateaugay, who did the job in 1963; Proud Clarion, who scored in 1967, and Little Current, who should have won last year but didn't.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW MIXED TONE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange dosed mixed yesterday in steppedup trading while those in the overthecounter market rose in increased trading.

title: School Trip Exchange Gets an A
description: RIDGEWOOD, May 1Students from this affluent white suburb and a predominantly Spanishspeaking and black neighborhood of the Bronx completed an exchange of school visits today and decided that they had more in common than they had imagined.

title: U.S. Agrees to Big Cut In Its Forces in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand May 1 (AP)  The United States Government has agreed to substantial withdrawal of American forces from Thailand, Foreign Minister Chatichai Choonhavan said at a news conference today.

title: YOUTH CONVICTED IN SISTER'S DEATH
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1Eben Gossage, 20yearold son of the late Howard Luck Gossage, one of the nation's leading advertising executives, was found guilty of voluntary manslaughter here today in the slaying of his younger sister, Amelia.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $1.06billion, up 4 per cent from the yearearlier $1.01billion. Total retail store sales were about $11billion, up 8 per cent from $10.1billion.

title: Very Rev. Raphael Grande, Headed Atonement Friars
description: The Very Rev. Raphael Grande, superior general of the Atonement Friars from 1940 to 1949, died Tuesday of heart attack in the Peekskill (N.Y.) Community Hospital. He was 69 years old and had been living in retirement in Graymoor. N.Y., for the last year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: About Real Estate
description: One of the legacies of the drastic outflow of deposits from thrift institutions last year was renewed attention to variablerate home mortgages. The outflow has become an inflow, but the attention persists.

title: Trainer Accuses Jockeys
description: A trainer said under oath yesterday that the country's leading jockey, Angel Cordero Jr., was part of a jockey ring that fixed triple and exacta races and cashed winning tickets up to $250,000 a day.

title: VIETNAM MERGER NOT LIKELY SOON
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 1 Authoritative sources here said today that two different political, economic and social systems would probably prevail in Vietnam for some time, leading in steps to the reunification of the North and South.

title: WOMAN TESTIFIES AT PRIEST'S TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The term godly admonition came under renewed and sometimes humorous scrutiny today, as the landmark church trial of the Rev. William A. Wendt heard testimony by the woman he had let celebrate communion and by one of the Bishops who had participated in her ordination to the Episcopal priesthood.

title: Home Loan Bank to Pav Off $1.27Billion Debt
description: The credit markets held steady yesterday in quiet trading as the investment community awaited details of the Treasury's May refunding plans after the normal close of trading hours.

title: Byrne Ask Health Regions
description: TRENTON, May 1 (UPI) Government Byrne asked the Federal Government today to set up five regional health service areas in the state. Mr. BMyrne said all of New Jersey's 21 counties should be placed in regional districts within the state not absorbed in metropolitan districts with outofstate cities.

title: America's Opportunity...
description: Unlike the ordeals in Vietnam that Americans witnessed so helplessly in the years of war, the resettlement of Vietnamese refugees is a problem that ordinary people of the United States have the power to solve.

title: Cambodia Evacuees Overdue at Border
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, May 1Camboaian Communist, French and Thai Government officials met repeatedly today across the bridge here that marks the ThaiCambodian border, but the discussions failed to produce any firm word on the whereabouts of foreigners who have been isolated in the French Embassy compound in Phnom Penh.

title: Breakfast Rhythms And Chacona Mark Da Capo's Concert
description: The Da Capo Chamber Play, jers, who gave their final concert of the season at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night, might described as the repeaters of the New York modern music world. They specialize. not in first performances, which they may give on occasion, but in second, third, fourth or possibly 40th performances. In other words, they rummage around among previously played pieces and bring the ones they like out for fresh consideration.

title: Harried Professionals Migrating to Maine
description: BLUE HILL, Me., April 30The men and women who follow the arcane science of demography became aware recently that a significant change had taken place in the State of Maine. It had begun to gain population after decades of losing people.

title: U.S. SAID TO ABANDON VIETNAMESE AIDES
description: A broadcast news correspondent said yesterday that United States Embassy officials in Saigon had abandoned 450 Vietnamese employes that they had promised to evacuate from the city.

title: 5 or 6 Rated Capable of winning Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1Lou Rondinello does not bet, but the trainer of Prince Thou Art and Sylvan Place almost wishes he did.

title: Portuguese Socialists Invade a Communist Rally
description: LISBON, May 1Portuguese Communists sought today to prevent the Socialist party from participating in a huge May Day labor rally in a stadium here, but a crowd headed by Mario Soares, the Socialist leader, pushed Its way in.

title: SOUTH AFRICA EASES A CURB ON BLACKS
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 2The Government has restored to urban blacks the right to own their homes.

title: McEnroe, 16, Gains In Eastern Tennis
description: WOODBURY, L. I., May 2 John McEnroe Jr. of Dougiaston, Queens, a 16.yearold, reached the semifinals of the Eastern men's hardcourt tennis championships today. He beat Doug Barrow of Bay side, 63, 62.

title: Navy Trackmen Capture 4 Quantico Meet Events
description: QUANTICO, Va., May 2 (AP)Two members of the United States team headed for China later this month were winners in the 19th annual Marine Corps relays today and the Naval Academy cantured four events.

title: Frank A. Sedita, Buffalo Mayor Three Times, Dies at Age of 67
description: BUFFALO, May 2 (AP)Former Mayor Frank A. Sedita died here today at the age of 67.

title: Issues Tough, but Commonwealth Thrives
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 2Everyone fcels at home on this flowering island. There has been tea and cricket, Trooping the Color and the Queen.

title: FORD SEEKS A RISE IN REFUGEE ENTRY
description: WASHINGTON, May 2President Ford intends to authorize the admission of 30,000 more South Vietnamese refugees into the United States, bringing to 123,000 the number who will be allowed to settle in this country, the State Department said today.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, May 2. 1975

title: Weeden & Co. Plans New Firm as Means Of Joining Big Board
description: Weeden & Co., Inc., long an irritant to the New York Stock Exchange because it deals in Big Board stocks without Big Board membership, disclosed yesterday that it was forming the Dexter Securities Corporation to buy a seat on the New York exchange.

title: EXPOSE OF C.I.A. WINS THE HILLMAN AWARD
description: Seymour M. Hersh of the New York Times, who uncovered Central Intelligence Agency surveillance in the United States, was among six recipients of Sidney Hillman Foundation awards yesterday at the Commodore Hotel.

title: Canada Extending joint Defense Pact
description: OTTAWA, May 2The Canadian Government will renew its joint air defense agreement with the United States for five years, despite the arguments of nationalists here that the 17yearold pact infringes on Canada's sovereignty.

title: Columbia Pictures Offer
description: Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., is offering to exchange $550 principal amount of 1124 per cent nonconvertible subordinated debentures clue May 1, 1990, and 15 shares of its common stock in exchange for each $1,000 principal amount of its outstanding 534 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due Nov. 1, 1994, and for each $1,000 principal amount of 4 3/4 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due Aug. 1, 1987.

title: Slayer Jumps Bail of $50,000 Just Before Jurors Convict Him
description: District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx asked the Federal Bureau of Investigationi to assist in a nationwide hunt for a killer linked to organized crime who jumped bail of $50,000 just before a jury convicted him of manslaughter yesterday.

title: Screen: Anthropology
description: Anthropological Cinema couldn't be more scientific as a general title for the three documentaries thatlike graduate courses opened recently at the Whitney Museum of American Art. If these studies are not precisely entertainments, they cleave to the definition of anthropology as the science of man and illustrate professional findings that are tributes to the researchers and films as a teaching tool.

title: MALPRACTICE SNAG DEPLORED ON LI.
description: WEST ISLIP, L. I., May 2The NassauSuffolk Hospital Council warned today that the continued impasse in the State Legislature regarding malpracticeinsurance legislation for physicians and hospitals would seriously affect health care on Long Island.

title: Egypt Still Sees U.S. Role As Vital in Mideast Talks
description: CAIRO, May 2Egypt continues to look on the United States as the main power in arranging a Middle East peace settlement, despite setbacks to the United States by the failure of Secretary of State Kissinger's diplomacy here in March and the surrender of Saigon to the Vietnamese Communists.

title: 7 Transports Fly 490 Vietnamese to Arkansas Post
description: FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., May 2The first Vietnamese refugees to be flown to a processing point in the United States beyond the West Coast arrived here today, many of them English speaking, middle class professionals who probably will have relatively little trouble making new homes in America.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Employees at U.N. Protesting Pay and Benefit Inequities
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 2United Nations employees staged a five hour work stoppage today and crowded into the General Assembly hall to complain about inequities in salaries and fringe benefits.

title: Slumping Orioles Lose 5th Straight
description: If the Baltimore Orioles are going to become a factor in the American League's Eastern Division race, they'd better get cracking.

title: EIMICHMAN PLEA OPPOSED IN COURT
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The special Watergate prosecution asked the United States Court of Appeals here today to affirm the convictions last summer of John D. Ehrliclunan, once the chief domestic affairs adviser to Richard M. Nixon, and his three codefendants in the socalled plumbers case

title: Zsigrnoncl GyallayPap, 65, Radio Free Europe Editor
description: Zsigmond GyallayPap, chief of the Hungarian desk of Radio Free Europe here from 1957 to 1974, died Thursday in Englewood (N. J.) Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 73 Prospect Terrace, Tenafly, N. J.

title: Benjamin West Recalled in Art
description: The career of Benjamin West was the first great success story in the history of American art, and few subsequent successeseven by today's standard of international celebrity  have matched the Immensity of his.

title: Drive to Organize a Student Boycott Of Newark's Schools Appears to Fail
description: NEWARK, May 2Efforts to mount a citywide student boycott of Newark's public schools to protest layoffs and program cutbacks appeared to fail today. At the same time, a top school official reported that at least $25 million would be needed to avert the massive layoffs of schoolboard personnel announced earlier in the week.

title: The Dance: Firebird
description: George Balanchine is mortal just like other, more commonplace geniusesor, if not mortal, at least almost humanly fallible. However, it is comparatively rare to find a ballet of his that does not have some redeeming feature. Yet if ever there was a ballet in need of redemption it is the recension of Firebird that he and Jerome Robbins dreamed up during a bad patch of the Stravinsky Festival three years ago. It is quite perfectly pointless, and usually the kindest thing that can be said of it is that it comes last on the program. at least giving reasonable men and women the fair option of departure.

title: Operations Curtailed in Strike Of Northern California Doctors
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 2Northern California physicians entered the second day of their strike today to protest the high cost of malprictice insurance.

title: U.S. Has a Surplus On Mideast Trade
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 2 (AP)  The cost of United States imports from the Middle East more than tripled last year, hut increased United States exports to that area exceeded imports by $400 million, the American Embassy announced today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Special Phone Number For Voting Complaints
description: A special telephone number was established yesterday to receive any complaints of racial discrimination in the local school board elections next Tuesday.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER GAIN
description: Prices on the American stock Exchange and in the OvertheCounter market rose yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: Bonn Figures Show Decline in Jobless; Opposition Doubtful
description: BONN, May 2The number of people without jobs in West Germany went down in April for the second month in a, row, according to information that leaked out in Bonn today.

title: Dance: Harlem at Its Vibrant Best
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem was seen at its vibrant and welltrained best on Thursday night at the Uris Theater when it offered a company premiere of George Balanchine's Allegro Briltante in a program that was splendidly danced from beginning to end.

title: SmallHome Owners Press Chicago Banks
description: CHICAGO, May 2Clout is a word heard frequently in this pragmatic city as a convenient shorthand to describe an attribute of those who know the right person, those who can cut the red tape, and, most importantly, those with an in at City Hall.

title: Miss Astrologes Leads
description: Miss Astrologes Leads

title: Filigree Foods, Inc., Files Under the Bankruptcy Ac
description: Filigree Foods, Inc., filed yesterday bankruptcy proceedings under Chapter XI in the United States District Court in Totowa, N.J., as a result of action by ???

title: Episcopal Tribunal Cites Chief Bishop for Contempt
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church was cited for contempt of court today as the ecclesiastical trial of the Rev. William A. Wendt ended on its third day.

title: P.B.A. FAILS IN BID TO END PAY PARITY WITH THE FIREMEN
description: A threeman arbitration panel rejected yesterday the effort of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to break the pay parity of police officers with firemen and to increase further the existing 10 per cent differential above sanitationmen.

title: RETARDED PRESS FOR SPECIAL UNIT
description: In an effort to press Governor Carey to sign a bill that would: create a special office for the mentally retarded, almost 1,000 retarded persons and their supporters demonstrated in front of the Governor's New York office yesterday blowing whistles, carrying cardboard frisbees and chanting, Sign, the bill. We're blowing the whistle on the Governor, said Joseph T. Weingold, the executive director of the State Association for Retarded Children. He has a committment to these people.

title: AN EXTRAVAGANZA BY JOHN CAGE DUE
description: Just a few years back, avantgarde mixedmedia events were all the rage. Now we see less of such extravaganzas, which have fallen victim to both postsixties economic recession and a recession of the ebullient, anarchistic spirit of those times.

title: Paper Restoring: A Scary Business
description: When Margo Feiden Is scared, she shares her fears with her clients. As she talks, somehow things come together, and, as in the fairy tales, everything turns out happily in the end.

title: Ford Plans to Visit Spain And Italy to Bolster Ties
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The White House announced today that President Ford on his coming European trip would pot only meet in Austria with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt but would also visit Spain and Italy to bolster ties with those key Mediterranean countries.

title: People and Business
description: It's an absolute fact, Lynn Townsend, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said yesterday in Detroit, that the 1976 automobiles will cost more than the 1975 automobiles.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss FarmTrespass Charges
description: CLARKSBORO, May 2 (AP)A Municipal Court judge today refused to dismiss trespassing complaints against a state legislator, two newsmen and a social worker who attempted to inspect a migrantlabor farm near here last summer.

title: ROBERT J. MUNCE
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., May 2 (AP)Robert J. Munce, former president of Suffolk University in Boston, died here yesterday at the age of 80.

title: JAMES W. HUTCHISON
description: James W. Hutchison, vice president of the Home Insurance Company, died Thursday in St. Anthony's Hospital, Hays, Kan., after a long illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 1750 Cooper Road, Scotch Plains. N. J.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Concerto for Two Mandolins, Vivaldi; Symphony No. 48, Haydn; Violin Concerto in E, Bach.

title: 22 States Have Laws On Jobs For Disabled
description: In addition to the Federal Government and the District of Columbia, 22 states have passed laws granting equal job opportunities to the handicapped. They are the following:

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NIGHT AND DAY Possibly for the sake of variety, many club and restaurant showcases now have such a brisk turnover of circulating talent these evenings that some performers are quickly out of one place and into another before they can be cited.

title: 2 New Lisbon Nurses Dismissed
description: Two nurses have been dismissed following the death a New Lisbon State School patient who was found suffocated with styrofoam and tied in a straitjacket. A spokesman for the state Department of Institutions and Agencies identifed the nurses as Alfreda Kelber, 48 years old, Manahawkin and Myra Przychoda, 57, of Barnegat. The patient was Wilfred Johnson. 24.

title: DR. J. J. SEABROOK
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 2 (AP)Dr. J. J. Seabrook, president emeritus of HustonTillotson College, died yesterday while speaking before the City Council. He was 76 years old.

title: April German Jobless Rate Expected to Decline Slightly
description: BONN, May 2 (Reuters)West German unemployment figures for April, to be released next Tuesday, will show a further slight drop to 1.08 million from 1.11 million in March, informed sources said today.

title: Bridge:
description: The New York representatives are favored to win the threeteam Grand National zonal playoff beginning at 1 P.M. today at the Hilton Inn, Tarrytown. N. Y., and continuing tomorrow.

title: Nude Bathing Ban In Effect on May 19 At U.S. Cape Shore
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The National Park Service has officially banned nude sun and sea bathing on the Cape Cod National Seashore.

title: SUSPECT CLEARED IN BAXTER KILLING
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office yesterday dropped the murder charges against a 30yearold Bronx baker accused of strangling Karen Baxter, a 15yearold runaway and prostitute, in a Murray Hill hotel last February.

title: Toll in Angola Is Put at 250 as Clashes Go On
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 21 (UPI)Supporters of two rival black African nationalist movements attacked each other's offices with grenades and mortars today in the fourth day of fierce battles that have killed at least 250 persons in this West African country.

title: PHYSICIANS DETAIL CASE ON REGENTS,
description: Leaders of the Medical Society of the County of New York have presented a bill of particulars to state officials in support of the society's charges that the state has been lax in investigating and disciplining doctors.

title: Memorial Services
description: BROWN Dorothy, Junker Phoppy C.P.A ??? coral tribute on the anniversary of her death, at St. Peter's Church, 346 W. 20 St., on Sunday, May 4 at 10:30 A.M.

title: DONALD M. HYMAN
description: Donald M. Hyman, president of Donley Realty Corporation and of the SmugglerDurant Mining Corporation, died yesterday at his home, 340 East 64th Street. He was 66 years old

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, May 7, 1975 Petition filed by:

title: Burden of Care
description: The legislative package on nursing homes submitted to Governor Carey by Moreland Act Commission Chairman Morris B. Abram represents a respectable first step toward bringing the nursing home industry under controlbut no more than that.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL SETS LAYOFF OF 400
description: The Bethlehem Steel Company, one of the nation's major steel producers, announced yesterday that 400 workers would be laid off next week at its Sparrows Point plant near Baltimore. The company cited business conditions as the reason for the layoffs.

title: Feminism in the Wild WestSo Far It's Been Pretty Tame
description: DENVER, May 2Male chauvinism Is alive and kicking in the Rocky Mountain states. But the girls of the golden West are beginning to discover that they are women, too.

title: Luce Heads China Institute
description: The election of Henry Luce 3d as chairman of the board of trustees of the China Institute in America was announced yesterday. Mr. Luce, vice president for corporate planning of Time Inc. and president of the Henry Luce Foundation, succeeds James V. Pickering, a former board chairman of Esso Standard Eastern, Inc. The institute seeks to familiarize Americans with the history and culture of the Chinese people.

title: BONN AND BRAZIL IN URANIUM DEAL
description: BONN, May 2West Germany has approved a major accord with Brazil under which Bonn will receive longterm deliveries of natural uranium in return for its advanced nuclear technology, a Government spokesman said today.

title: JEWISH ROLE SEEN FOR BICENTENNIAL
description: The American Jewish Committee yesterday called on American Jews to bring to the Bicentennial celebration the story of Jewish contributions to the nation's growtha story that goes back to Asser Levy, who served in Peter Stuyvesant's militia.

title: Market Place
description: Recent tender offers have resulted in trading suspensions in the shares of target companies under circumstances that some seasoned observers regard as unusual.

title: TokenSale Machines Removed From Subway
description: The Transit Authority has removed its token vending machines from subway stations in a move that will save it $141,000 a year, an authority official said last night.

title: New Cambodia Regime Recognized by Britain
description: LONDON, May 2 (AP)Britain today formally recognized the new Government of Cambodia.

title: British Football
description: British Football

title: U.S. BID TO CANADA SEEN IN SPY CASE
description: OTTAWA, May 2A Chinese diplomat whose removal was ordered by the Canadian Government this week was ousted at the request of the United States after he was found picking up industrial and military information for his embassy on missions to Washington, according to Canadian newspaper and radio reports today.

title: 900 Cambodians Are Due at Pendleton as Processing Slows Down
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 2Nine hundred Cambodian refugees airlifted from Thailand were expected to arrive here this weekend as the machinery for processing thousands of the Vietnamese already in camp in this Marine base showed signs of slowing down.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI)The head of the major women's intercollegiate sports organization has accused the ruling hierarchy of the National Collegiate Athletic Association of trying a quiet power play to seize control over women's sports on the nation's campuses. Dr. Leotus Morrison, president of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women, also charged that the N.C.A.A. was ignoring the wishes of its allmale membership in mounting what she called a. unilateral takeover.

title: Carey Shifting Key Aide to Welfare Post
description: ALBANY, May2In a major cabinet shift, Governor Carey has moved his chief planning adviser, Stephen Berger, into post at the Department of Social Services, where he is in line to become the new Commissioner.

title: Notes on People
description: A 1973 ruling on overlooking by airlines ordering Allegheny Airlines to pay $50,000 for bumping Ralph Nader from a flight to Connecticut, was overturned yesterday. A Federal appeals court in Washington sent the case back to a lower court, which had ruled that the consumer advocate was victimized by wanton misconduct because the overbookingaccepting more reservations than there are seats for flightwas not mentioned in the airlines advertising.

title: EUROPEANS DOUBT QUICK GENEVA GAIN
description: GENEVA, May 2Senior diplomats from the Western, Eastem and neutral nations attending the European security con; ference here say that there is no sign of a breakthrough on several key issues, some of which appear trivial or procedural but are considered politically significant by East and West.

title: Business Briefs
description: A suit was filed yesterday in Manhattan Supreme Court by the U.S. Brewers Association charging that the New York State Liquor Authority was arbitrary and capricious compelling brewers to label their malt liquor as beer.

title: SAIGON WORKERS SEIZE UNION SITE
description: The Saigon headquarters of the South Vietnamese labor movement was reportedly seized yesterday by 3,000 workers as the revolutionary authorities continued their reorganization of all aspects of national life.

title: Art: Fine Sculptures by Caro
description: Anthony Caro is by any rational count the most remarkable sculptor to have appeared anywhere in the world during the last 25 years.

title: Parent Coming Back; Islanders Not Fazed
description: How can things he looking up for the New York Islanders when they are down, 2 games to 0, in their fourofsevengame Stanley Cup semifinal series with the Philadelphia Flyers? How can they sustain their positive outlook with the news that Bernie Parent, the Flyers allstar goalie, is ready to return to work in Game 3 Sunday after missing the first two games with a knee injury?

title: People in Sports
description: Warren Giles has some free advice for Lawrence O'Brien, the new commissioner of the National Basketball Association: Forget politics.

title: Jersey Urged to Penalize Deficient Nursing Homes
description: TRENTON, May 2The State Public Advocate recommended today that Federal Medicaid funds should be withheld from New Jersey nursing homes that fail to meet state standards.

title: Track Hall Bill Signed
description: CHARLESTON, West Va.. May 2 (UPI)  Gov. Arch Moore signed into law yesterday a bill appropriating $852,500 for land for the United States Track and Field Hall of Fame in Charleston.

title: In Memoriam
description: BERINSTEIN  Sue, May 3, 1971. Lovingly remembered, so sadly missed. BOB

title: Arab League Sending Aide To U.S. to Influence Opinion
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 2The Arab League is sending an Arab information expert to the United States to speak for the Arab cause while the Administration is reassessing its Middle East policy.

title: Wall Street Pretzel Fees Unfixed
description: The best buy on Wall Street these days are pretzels. What some analysts have been calling the Great Pretzel War has driven the 25cent pretzel down to 20 or even 15 cents.

title: 2 Brewer Homers Down Yankees, 42
description: MILWAUKEE, May 2Welcome, George Medich said, to the scene of the first annual Pfistercuffs.

title: Equal Opportunity Job Laws for Disabled Have Little Effect
description: The Federal Government and nearly half the states have passed laws granting equal job opportunities to millions of workingage Americans with physical, medical and mental disabilities. But in many cases the laws are not having the desired effect because of inadequate enforcement and difficulties in interpreting them.

title: Lindsay Still In Despite Being Out
description: One evening last fall, shortly after former Mayor John V. Lindsay had returned from his eightmonth vacation Europe and resumed the practice of law, he was walking home from his office when it began to rain. There were empty taxis around so he decided to keep going by foot.

title: DR. EMMA WARE DIES; SOCIOLOGY TEACHER
description: Dr. Emma Louise Ware, author and emeritus professor of sociology at Adelphi University, Garden City, L.L. died Thursday in Doctors Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at the Prince George Hotel.

title: Health Council Asks Ban on Hollander As the Operator of Any Nursing Home
description: Members of the State Public Health Council read in silence yesterday a report on Eugene Hollander's nursing homes, then unanimously recommended that he be put out of business
