title: NIGERIA SAID TO PLAN TIE TO 3 CAR MAKERS
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, May 2 (Reuters)Three European auto makersthe British Leyland Motor Corporation, Fiat S.p.A., and DaimlerBenz, A.G.have been chosen to build three commercial vehicle assembly plants in Nigeria, informed sources said today.

title: LAWYER SENTENCED FOR MARKETING ROLE
description: John G. Davies, a London lawyer, was sentenced here yesterday to six months in jail and put on probation for three years for his admitted part in 196369 plan that cost investors in the National Student Marketing Corporation an estimated $80 million.

title: Federalized Welfare
description: The United States Conference of Mayors has given a needed prod to the Ford Administration and Congress on the urgency of basic welfare reform. In light of the vast increase in human distress caused by the recession, the continued failure of the Federal Government to act in this field is inexcusable.

title: News Summary and Index
description: About 500 foreigners who had been stranded in the French Embassy in Phnom Penh arrived at the Thai border after a fourday journey in open trucks. The seven journalists, including Sydney H. Schanberg of The New York Times, were the first to cross. The French Military attachd in Thailand said that about 100 of the foreigners had been left behind temporarily aparently because of lack of transportation. [Page 1. Column 8.]

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday stated incorrectly that Assemblyman John J. Flanagan, Republican of Huntington, was one of a group of legislators who had been fined for failing to file campaignfinancing reports. Actually, it was John Flanagan Jr., a State Senate candidate in Brooklyn, who failed to file and was fined.

title: RABBI ARYEH LEV, CHAPLAIN, 62, DIES
description: Rabbi Aryeh Lev, director of the Commission on Jewish Chaplaincy of the National Jewish Welfare Board, died yesterday in University Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: The New Narcotics Prosecutor
description: When I look at my public school graduation picture, most of the faces I see didn't make it. They became drug addicts or ended up in jail. The reminiscence came yesterday from Sterling Johnson Jr., Man one member of the class of 1948 at Public School 93 in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn who did make it. The 40yearold, stocky former high school athlete, police officer, assistant United States attorney and Drug Enforcement Administration official was named by the city's five District Attorneys yesterday to be Special Narcotics Prosecutor for the city. Man in the News

title: Hearing for Most Wanted
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., May (AP)  Arraignment has been scheduled for May 28 in Larimer District Court for Cameron David Bishop, one of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 10 most wanted fugitives before his capture in March. Mr. Bishop, 32 years old, is being held in Denver on a Federal charge of sabotaging power transmission lines leading to a defense plant.

title: Labor Set Back as ToriesGain In British Provincial Elections
description: LONDON, May 2Conservatives had a net gain of 200 seats today at the expense of the Labor party in local elections in 36 provincial cities and towns.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: SAIGON WORKERS SEIZE UNION SITE
description: The Saigon headquarters of the South Vietnamese labor movement was reportedly seized yesterday by 3,000 workers as the revolutionary authorities continued their reorganization of all aspects of national life.

title: P.B.A FAILS IN BID TO END PAY PARITY WITH THE FIREMEN
description: A three man arbitration panel rejected yesterday the effort of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to break the pay parity of police officers with firemen and to increase further the existing 10 per cent differential above sanitationmen.

title: T.W.A. and Braniff Report Sharp Drop in April Traffic
description: Trans World Airlines and Braniff Airways both reported yesterday sharp drops in their April traffic. T.W.A.'s system traffic was off by 17.4 per cent from a year earlier, with its domestic traffic down 12.8 per cent and international off by 2.6.3 per cent.

title: Buckley Reports U.S. Assurance of Aid to Navy Yard
description: Senator James L. Buckley, surrounded by anxious ship workers and executives at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday, said he had received strong, strong assurance in Washington of a Federal loan guarantee that could restore 3,000 jobs at the depressed Seatrain shipyard.

title: Carey Aide Tells Arts Chief to Resign
description: Eric Larrabee, executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts, has been told to resign by Governor Carey's office. The resignation, as of June 1, was requested by Thomas Lynch, deputy appointments officer, after consultation with Joan K. Davidson, the Governor's new appointee as chairman of the state agency.

title: Buckley Reports U.S. Assurance of Aid to Navy Yard
description: Senator James L. Buckley, surrounded by anxious ship workers and executives at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday, said he had received strong, strong assurance in Washington of a Federal loan guarantee that could restore 3,000 jobs at the depressed Seatrain shipyard.

title: HUNTER, RONSON GIVE FELT FORUM CONCERT
description: If the criterion of a successful rock show is that it gets people up off their feet clapping and happy, then the Ian HunterMick Ronson concert Thursday night at the Felt Forum was a success.

title: William Lynch of Calumet, Mining Engineer, 81, Dies
description: NORWALK, Cornn., May 2William Walmsley Lynch, a mining engineer and vice president in charge of metal sales and procurement for the Calumet and Hecla Corporation until he retired in 1959, died yesterday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: Tomahawks Lose, 117, To Wings in Lacrosse
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., May 2Wayne Platt, Philadelphia's allNational Lacrosse League goalie last season, recorded 54 saves to help the Wings turn back the Long Island Tomahawks, 117, tonight before a crowd of 4,246 in he Nassau Coliseum.

title: Lefkowitz Opposes ElectricHome Bill
description: WHITE PLAINS. May 2Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz told a legislative hearing, here today that he opposed new state legislation that would eliminate preferential utility rates for electrically heated homes.

title: Entry Is Rated Close Behind for the Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2Foolish Pleasure faces the most serious undertaking of his 11race career tomorrow. John Greer's Florida bred colt will seek to justify his role as favorite to win the Kentucky Derby.

title: Red Smith
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2Ben A. Jones, the sage Parnell, Mo., had a rule for judging the quality of any year's crop of race horses. If anybody is unfamiliar with Ben's credentials in this field, well, he and his son Jimmy trained eight winners of the Kentucky Derby, and that may more than the president of Churchill Downs has ever seen. Ben used to say that in a year when all the top 3yearolds kept beating one another, this meant they were all champions or ordinary, and there never vet has been a year when they were all champions. Last year was like that. Coming up to the 100th Derby there were 20odd colts that had won stakes and not more than two or three that had won two. The year before that it was Secretariat first and the rest nowhere. The word for this year's crop is competitive. With 15 horses named to start in the 101st Derby tomorrow, six or eight are given some kind of chance at the winner's $209,600. Considered most likely to succeed: Sports of the Times

title: Alice A. Hoffman Wed to Lee Hanley
description: Mice Anne Hoffman of New York, daughter of fiance, Ohio, and the late Mrs. Charles Driscoll of DeRansom Peter Holman, was married here yesterday afternoon to William Lee Hanley Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hanley of Palm Beach. Fla., and Southampton, L. I.

title: Ford Crowns Daughter Apple Queen
description: WINCHESTER, Va., May 2President Ford, putting aside for a sunny afternoon the problems of Vietnam and rising unemployment, turned his attention to his 17yearold daughter Susan today as he crowned her Queen of the 4Sth Shenandoah Apple Blossom Festival.

title: Many Discouraged JobHunters Giving Up the Search
description: LOS ANGELES, May 2John Santos sat atop a weathered gray picnic table at the City Terrace Park in the MexicanAmerican barrio of East LosAngeles and spoke of his despair.

title: School Board Candidates on S.I.
description: from the list of District 3 candidates published yesterday in an article on the community school district elections. He is endorsed by the United Federation of Teachers.

title: HOGS AND CATTLE SHOW PRICE RISES
description: Live hogs, pork bellies and cattle rose in price yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Other commodity futures were mostly steady in slow trading.

title: American Center Picks Chief
description: The election of Roger D. Stone as president of the Center for InterAmerican Relations was announced yesterday by David Rockefeller, honorary ichairman, and Emilio G. Collaclo, chairman of the center's board. Mr. Stone was formerly vice president in charge of the communications division, international department, of the Chase Manhattan Bank. The center, a nonprofit organization is concerned with political, cultural social and economic activity n the Americas.

title: A NEW BUDDY'S PLACE HOUSES RICH'S BAND
description: Buddy Rich has reformed his 16piece band and moved into a new Buddy's Place at 133 West 33d Street (he left the first Buddy's Place, on Second Avenue, last December, and it closed in January). The new room appears to be an attempt to fill whatever void was left by the closing of the Copecabana.

title: ABCTV Lists Robin Hood Spoof, Live Variety Show;
description: Mel Brooks will produce situation comedy spoofing the nobin Hood story, and Howard Cosell will be host of a live weekly variety show in the new ABCTV fall schedule.

title: Concert
description: No doubt they were always In there, practicing away, but recently one has been struck by the number of superior brass ensembles that have been coming out of the band closet, so to speak, and into the larger world of chamber music. The Western Brass Quintet, which gave a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night, can be offered in testimony to this phenomenon.

title: Dow Up by 17.52 to 848.48; Volume Rises to 25.21 Million
description: The stock market posted an impressive gain yesterday in much heavier trading as the list was propelled by investors favorable reaction to the Treasury Department's financing plans announced late Thursday.

title: Antiques: British Devices
description: It may be a record for gout stools, Kirk A. Igler quipped the other morning, recalling the $600 that a centuryold, ratcheted contrivance fetched last month at Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: The Turks And Their Army
description: ANKARA, TurkeyThe Turks are an extraordinarily tough and military people and their army leaders have either directly or indirectly influenced political affairs for centuries. Long before Kemal Ataturk, a distinguished general, created a republic on the ashes of the Ottoman Empire, there was a tradition of interference by officers in civilian government.

title: Sarafan Scoffs at Trainer, Calls Fix Claims Gossipy
description: Bertram D. Sarafan, chairman of the State Racing and Wagering Board, said yesterday that he thought testimony about fixed triple and exacta races given Thursday by John Cotter, a New York based thoroughbred trainer, was an irresponsible act.

title: Toward a New Life
description: America's better instincts are on trial. There is simply no way to shed the responsibility, proclaimed throughout our country's history, for providing a haven to those fleeing from persecution and conquest.

title: Dividends
description: Dividends

title: S.E.C. Finds $4.2Million in Gulf Bribes
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) Documents of the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that the Gulf Oil Corporation paid $4.2million in bribes to foreign politicians to protect the company's oil assets.

title: Padmaja Naidu Dies at 75; ExWest Bengal Governor
description: NEW DELHI, India, May 2 (AP)Padmaja Naidu a noted social worker and former Governor of West Bengal, died toAny of a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 75 years old.

title: Patent Reform Bill to Be Revised
description: WASHINGTON, May 2A bill providing for reform of the patent system will be revised by the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Patents, Trademarks and Copyrights and sent to the full committee for action, a subcommittee aide has disclosed.

title: Jobless Rate Up to 8.9%; Total at Work Also Rose
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The nation's unemployment rate edged up twotenths of a point in April to 8.9 per cent even though the total number of persons with jobs rose for the first time since last September, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Yunich Marks Year at M.T.A. With Positive Note
description: David L. Yunich completed his first year as head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday and announced the completion of a $22.8 million program to install high level platforms that speed loading at 43 Penn Central commuter stations well ahead of schedule.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores
description: KANSAS CITY (A.)

title: Anueilings
description: FODOR Camilla. A monument to the memory of Camilla Fodor will be unveiled at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I., on Sunday May 4, at 11 A.M.

title: Vienna Panel Proposes Stricter Guarding of Nuclear Materials
description: VIENNA, May 2Stricter international procedures for protecting nuclear material have been proposed by a panel of experts from 11 countries convened here by the International Atomic Energy Agency.

title: In Postwar Da Nang and Hue, New Flags and a sigh of Relief
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, May 3For two famous cities of South Vietnam, Da Nang and Hue, a 30yearold war ended with loudspeakers on street corners sputtering the news. Crowds milled in the city markets intent on their shopping. At this historic moment there seemed to be no general overwhelming emotion except relief among the 200,000 residents of Hue and one million of Da Nang.

title: Governors Queried on Hathaway Stand
description: WASHINGTON, May 2Gov. Calvin L. Rampton of Utah, chairman of the National Governors Conference, sent telegrams today to 21 Governors and former Governors asking them to confirm or reject his authority to tell the Senate Interior. Committee that they supported the nomination of Stanley K. Hathaway to be Secretary of the Interior.

title: Divergent Interest Groups Join In Backing District 5 Candidates
description: Slates of candidates for the community school board contest in Central Harlem's District 5, where members of past boards have been accused of failing to work together, have solidified this week with an unusual number of endorsements of the same people by divergent interest groups. and Mr. Dickens, and the ministers association endorsed Mrs. Gumbs.

title: Silence
description: Vice President Rockefeller has broken his silence about Governor Rockefeller's silence during the decade of war in Vietnam. He told the National Urban Coalition that the reason he declined to criticize Washington was that it would have diminished the flow of Pederal aid to Albany. And he added that, by keeping quiet, he succeeded in increasing the amount of money returned to this state during his administration.

title: NET AT TRAVELERS TUMBLES 8Y 73,6%
description: The Travelers Corporation, the nation's second largest stockholder owned insurance organization after Aetna Life and Casualty, reported yesterday firstquarter net income of $13.1 million, or 29 cents a share, down 73.6 per cent from $49.6 million, or $1.11 a share a year earlier.

title: Pennsylvania Is Home to Some Commuting to Linden G.M. Jobs
description: LINDENFor more than 30 years, young men in northern and western Pennsylvania have been engaged in a quiet revolt against a preordained lifetime of work in coal mines and steel mills and have been looking elsewhere for work.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Food Poison Source
description: HOUMA, La., May 2 (AP)Improperly refrigerated shrimp caused the food poisoning that closed a Jehovah's Witnesses convention here March 29, the health authorities said today. Horace Thibodaux, chief sanitarian for the Terrebonne Parish Health Unit, said laboratory reports showed massive bacterial contamination in shrimp salad sandwiches eaten by about 200 of the convention's 2,000 delegates.

title: Saigon Copters Found a Haven at Sea
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. MOBILE, in the South China Sea, April 30 (Delayed)On this day of the surrender of Saigon, dozens of Vietnamese refugees sat clustered around a radio they had brought with them, listening to the first Communist broadcasts.

title: Thailand May Return Planes to the U.S.
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 2 (UPI)Faced with American protests, Thai Government officials appeared today to be backing down from previous statements that they would return to Saigon the 125 South Vietnamese planes flown here by fleeing pilots in the closing hours of the war.

title: Heart Transplant Patient Is Dead After 6 1/2 Years
description: TORONTO. May 2 (UPI)Perrin Johnson, 61 years old, who was the world's longest living heart transplant patient, died today six and a half years after receiving a new heart.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: 2 Sheriff's Men Held in Sale of Drugs
description: NEWARK, May 2  Two members of the Essex County sheriff's detective squad and a civilian were charged today with operating their own drugsale system, using confiscated narcotics and information gained in the course of their police work.

title: TEXACO INCREASING GASOLINE PRICE 2c
description: Texaco, Inc., announced yesterday that it was increasing the price of all grades of gasoline by 2 cents a gallon. The price of heating oils, diesel fuel and kerosene will be advanced by 1 cent a gallon.

title: New Man at Turtle Bay
description: If he becomes chief United States representative at the United Nations as expected, Daniel Patrick Moynihan will undoubtedly have a lot of furl, score debating points, generate publicityand perhaps say some things that need saying. With a twoyear hitch as Ambassador to India behind him, he is better qualified now than when former President Nixon offered him the U.N. job late in 1970.

title: CONGRESS DEFIED BY NAVY ON PLANE
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The Navy, in defiance of a Congressional injunction for interservice cooperation, has decided to build a fighter plane different from the Air Force's.

title: A. C. L. U. Charges Intelligence Inquiry By the House Lags
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The American Civil Liberties Union called today upon Representative Lucien N. Nedzi to affirm his intention to investigate the activities of American intelligence gathering organizations or to resign the chairmanship of a House select committee set up for that purpose.

title: Britain and Spain Lead in Cup Tennis
description: LONDON, May 2 (Reuters)  Britain, Spain, Hungary and West Germany all took 20 leads today in their Davis Cup zone series. Each of the teams won the two opening singles matches.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: NEW LOW IS HIT BY BRITISH POUND
description: LONDON, May 2The British pound came under heavy selling on foreign exchange markets throughout Europe today and closed at a record low against other major currencies.

title: Beneath the Baked Steppes, a Golden Hoard
description: The endless debate on detente with the Soviet Union I leave to historians and economists, but detente has accomplished at least one remarkable thing: It has brought the collections of Scythian gold from Leningrad and Kiev to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. And it has brought back to me my childhood, and the fascinating stories my grandfather used to tell me of his archeological adventures in Russia. My favorite anecdote was the story he called The Golden Combabout the very same comb that is now a showpiece of the Metropolitan exhibit.

title: South Brunswick Is Assured That Pigeon Swamp Will Be Preserved
description: SOUTH BRUNSWICK TOWNSHIP, May 2Local township officials here today were given assurances by David J. Bardin, the State Commissioner of Environmental Protection, that the 2,600 acre Pigeon Swamp tract, a natural preserve and water source here, will not be put to any other use than as a natural preserve for future generations.

title: Ford Plans to Visit Spain And Italy to Bolster Ties
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The White House announced today that President Ford on his coming European trip would not only meet in Austria with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt but would also visit Spain and Italy to bolster ties with those key Mediterranean countries.

title: Two Sheriff's Detectives Seized On DrugSale Charges in Jersey
description: NEWARK, May 2Two members of the ??? iff's detective squad and a civilian were charged today with operating their own drugsale system, ??? nonfiscated narcotic and information gained the course of their police work.

title: S. Sloan Colt of Port Authority And Bankers Trust Dead at 82
description: S. Sloan Colt, former president and chairman of the Bankers Trust Company and former commissioner and chairman of the Port Authority of New York anti New Jersey, died yesterday at his home in Westhampton Beach, L. I. He was 82 years old.

title: Abduction Suspects Seized With New Rochelle Victim
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 2 The predawn kidnapping of a New Rochelle child by four gunmen ransacking her parents' home ended today with the recovery of the child and the capture of two suspects

title: U.S. Boxer Wins
description: BRISBANE, Australia, May 2 (AP)James Marshall of Los Angeles knocked out Tony Mundine of Australia, the British Commonwealth champion, in the first round of a scheduled 10round bout tonight. Mundine was flattened by a right to the jaw in 2 minutes and 10 seconds.

title: CAMBODIAN DELAY ANGERING FRENCH
description: PARIS, May 2French anger and concern rose sharply today over the continued failure of the Communist Government in Cambodia to deliver to freedom the 610 Frenchmen and other foreigners who took refuge in the French Embassy in Phnom Penh when the city fell more than two weeks ago.

title: France Retains Saigon Economic Ties
description: PARIS, May 1France has made a determined effort to maintain her economic influence, investment, cultural ties and physical presence in South Vietnam, part of the Indochina colony that she lost more than two decades ago.

title: RAYMOND W. MITCHELL
description: Raymond W. Mitchell, a partner in the law firm of Wachtell, Manheim & Grouf and president of the Eastern Scanning Corporation, died of cancer yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived at 1088 Park Avenue.

title: Delta Air Lines Arranges $75 Million of New Credit
description: ATLANTA, May 2 (UPI)Delta Air Lines has arranged $75 million of additional financing in two new unsecured credit lines.

title: Oil Glut Causing Crisis For Greek Shipowners
description: PIRAEUS, Greece, May 2Tourism is down all over, but there is at least one place in Greece where a reservation is neededthe middle of Eieusis Bay.

title: Dr. Gloria Clare, Dr. Kurt Elias Wed
description: Dr. Gloria Clare, an assisttant clinical professor of psychiatry at the New York Medical College and widow of Dr. Jack Eliot Clare, a physician, was married at noon yesterday to Dr. Kurt Elias, an internist and oncologist at the Montefiore Medical Group in the Bronx.

title: Slight Drop Is Set In Weekly Layoffs By Car Companies
description: DETROIT, May 2The number of United States automobile workers on layoff will decline slightly next week to 178,013, but will still represent an unemployment rate of 25 per cent in the basic auto industry. The number idle this week was 179,370.

title: Women's Interclub Golf
description: Women's Interclub Golf

title: BOTTLE DEPOSITS ARGUED IN QUEENS
description: Strong opposition was heard at a hearing yesterday in Queens on a bill to make returnable cash deposits mandatory on all beer and carbonatedi beverage containers sold in the state.

title: Students Add to Demands After Arrests at Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, May 2The 46 students who were arrested last night while occupying the Livingston College dean's office presented a new list of demands today to the college and to the Rutgers University administration and and vowed further action if they were not met by Tuesday.

title: Teachers Union Opposes 5 on Staten Island Board
description: A major effort is being made by the United Federation of Teachers and the Council of Supervisors and Administrators to defeat five of the eight local school board members who are seeking reelection Tuesday in Staten Island's Community School District 31.

title: At 80, Dr. Mark Is Honored For Pioneering in Polymers
description: Dr. Herman Mark, the Brooklynbased scientist who laid much of the intellectual basis for developing the artificial polymers the world uses in clothes, automobile tires, toothbrushes and for wrapping just about everythingand then spent the last 40 years as the peripatetic chief missionary for this branch of scienceis 80 years old today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In an effort to press Governor Carey of New York to sign a bill that would create a special office for the mentally retarded, 1,000 retarded people and their supporters demonstrated in front of the Governor's New York City office, blowing whistles, carrying cardboard Frisbees and chanting, Sign the bill.

title: Lindsay Still In Despite Being Out
description: One evening last fall, shortly after former Mayor John V. Lindsay had returned from his eightmonth vacation Europe and resumed the practice of law, he was walking home from his office when it began to rain. There were no empty taxis around so he decided to keep going by toot.

title: Mrs. King Leads 3021 Sets Victory
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., May 2Thanks to Billie Jean King, making her debut with her new team, the New York Sets opened their world team tennis season tonight with a 3021 victory over the Phoenix Racquets, who won the league championship last year while based in Denver.

title: FORD SEEKS ENTRY FOR 30,000 MORE FLEEING VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON, May 2President Ford intends to authorize the admission of 30,000 more South Vietnamese refugees into the United States, bringing to 123,000 the number who will be allowed to settle in this country, the State Department said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: EUROPE'S INNER DEMONS: An Enquiry Inspired by the Great WitchHunt By Norman Cohn: 302 pages. Illustrated. Basic Books. $12.50.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: Thousands of Refugees Fleeing on Vietnamese Boats Appeal for Food and Water
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. BLUE RIDGE, in the South China Sea, May 2 (Agency France Press) As many as 50,000 to 80,000 Vietnamese refugees, many suffering from lack of food and water, were still at sea today, according to messages reaching this Seventh Fleet command and communications ship.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Local officials of South Brunswick Township in New Jersey were given assurances by David J. Bardin, the State Commissioner of Environmental Protection, that the 2,600acre. Pigeon Swamp tract, a natural preserve and water source here, will not be put to any other use than as natural preserve for future generations.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Betty Ford didn't turn up. In fact, she wasn't even expected. But everybody knows she wears Albert Capraro's clothes. So a mob turned up to see his fall designs for Jerry Guttenberg. If the First Lady wears them, they can't be all bad. Fashion is desperate for a leader.

title: NEW CURB URGED ON NURSING HOMES
description: TRENTON, May 2The State Public Advocate recommended today that Federal Medicaid funds should be withheld from New Jersey nursing homes that fail to meet state standards.

title: STATE ARTS CHIEF TOLD TO RESIGN
description: Eric Larrabee, executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts, has been told to resign by Governor Carey's office. The resignation. as of June 1, was requested by Thomas Lynch, deputy appointments officer, after consultation with Joan K. Davidson, the Governor's new appointee as chairman of the state agency.

title: DRUG AGENCY TARGET OF JUSTICE INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) The Justice Department acknowledged today that a special investigation into possible mismanagement or corruption within the Drug Enforcement Administration had been under way since March.

title: Philippines to Restrict Refugees Who Arrive at American Bases
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Saturday, May 3 Refugees from Vietnam arriving in the Philippines today and later aboard ships of the American evacuation fleet face restrictions imposed by the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Tori Frederickson Is Married on Coast
description: Victoria Olson Schmidlapp Frederickson was married yesterday afternoon to Harry Korshak, a producer for Paramount Pictures. The civil ceremony took place at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Korshak, parents of the brideroom in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Episcopal Tribunal Cites Chief Bishop for Contempt
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church was cited for contempt of court today as the ecclesiastical trial of the Rev. William A. Wendt ended on its third day.

title: 4 Electrical Contractors Indicted
description: A Federal grand jury in Camden indicted four North Jersey electricalcontracting companies and three of their officers on charges of price fixing and bid rigging. The indictment said the companies engaged in collusion between 1969 and 1971 to parcel out among themselves contracts awarded by the general contracting company of Joseph Muscarelle, Inc., of Maplewood. The indictment, received by Judge Mitchell H. Cohen of Federal District Court, was the first to be issued by a special grand jury that was empaneled here last July I.

title: BlackSatchel Mystery
description: It was after midnight when Henry Kissinger, carrying a small black satchel and accompanied by sources close to Kissinger, arrived at the White House Reassessment Chamber. He apologized for keeping everyone waiting several hours, but sources close to Kissinger said he had tarried deliberately, hoping the reassessors would get sleepy and go to bed.

title: STUDY FINDS DROP IN EAVESDROPPING
description: WASHINGTON, May 2The amount of wiretapping and bugging officially sanctioned by Federal and state courts; in the cause of law enforcement dropped 16 per cent last year from the record total set in; 1973.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday stated incorrectly that Assemblyman John J. Flanagan, Republican of Huntington, was one of a group of legislators who had been fined for failing to file campaignfinancing reports. Actually, it was John Flanagan Jr., a State Senate candidate in Brooklyn, who failed to file and was fined.

title: Apartheid And The Future
description: NATAL, South Africa  White Rhodesia unilaterally declared her independence from Britain nine years ago. It is led by some of the most obtuse white men in the world. I don't know whether they read, but they certainly can't read the writing on the wall. Their Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith, up till now has had only one political idea, and that is to keep political power in the hands of the 5 per cent white minority.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The emphasis in the inaugural show is on the showbiz style. Nipsey Russell is on for 50 minutes of patter and doggerel that floats along amiably for 30 minutes but grows tiresome. Carmen McRae does 35 minutes of her hardvoiced songs with an emphasis on slow, superficially dramatic pieces.

title: Martin Beats Star Field In 880 at Relays Here
description: It was cold and damp at Randalls Island yesterday for the opening of the 10th annual New York Relays but the athletes warmed up the spectators with some outstanding performances.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Today's Entries at Aqueduct

title: Sound Used by Camera System to See Through Solids
description: WASHINGTON, May 2Byron B. Brendan, who was honored as an Inventor of the Year for his achievements in acoustical holography, was awarded his basic patent in the field this week. The technique, which ernploys sound to see through solids, is expected to have increasing importance in medical diagnosis, nondestructive testing and tunneling through solid rock. Mr. Brenden applied for Patent 3,879,989 in 1966, but issuance was delayed by interference with another application. It is assigned to the Battelle Development Corporation and is licensed to Holosonics, Inc., Richland, Wash. Patents of the Week

title: Money
description: Money

title: Koosman Early Betting Favors Foolish Pleasure
description: Jerry Koosman said that after his start in Montreal last Sunday had yielded nine hits and six runs in five innings, I was awake in bed and thought a long time about it. I'd been so damn wild, I thought now I'd have to concentrate.

title: Trevino's 69135 Leads by 2 Shots
description: HOUSTON, May 2 (AP)Lee Trevino, still seeking his first pro victory in his native Texas, shot a threeunderpar 69 today and opened a twostroke lead with 135 in the second round of the $150,000 Houston golf tournament.

title: Joyce Pleads Not Guilty in Bribe Case
description: James Joyce, the Camden County Democratic chairman, was released without bond yesterday after he pleaded not guilty to state charges that he had solicited a bribe from an engineering concern. Mr. Joyce was arraigned before Superior Court Judge Hervey S. Moore. A trial date will be scheduled later in Gloucester County.

title: DIFALCO REPORTED WEIGHING SWITCH
description: Surrogate S. Samuel DiFalco has discussed with Manhattan Democratic and Republican leaders a switch to a State Supreme Court bench later this year, leaders of both parties said yesterday. The move would permit him to remain judge after the usual retirement age, and would give him a voice in the selection of his successor.

title: Dakota Police Rout Indians From Plant; Curfew Is Imposed
description: WAGNER, S.D., May 2 (AP) South Dakota highway patrolmen used tear gas to flush eight armed Indians from the Yankton Sioux Industries Pork Plant tonight.

title: Grant Pays Its ExChief $100,000 a Year
description: The W. T. Grant Company, the troubled retail chain that lost $177.3million in its last fiscal year, has arranged large compensation payments for the man who operated the company when it fell into its severe financial difficulties and also for the man who is expected to rectify them.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Ford intends to authorize the admission of 30,000 more South Vietnamese refugees into the United States, bringing to 123,000 the number that will be allowed to settle in this country, the State Department said yesterday. The 30,000 were discovered aboard 26 South Vietnamege naval ships and are being escorted to safety by United States ships in the South China Sea, State and Defense Department officials said. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Merger Agreement Reached By Dutch Banking Concern
description: Pierson, Heldring & Pierson, a 100yearold Dutch private bank active in international investment banking, has agreed to merge with the AmsterdamRotterdam Bank, a large bank in the Netherlands with approximately $14billion in assets.

title: Scofflaws Are Warned Of Liens on City Assets
description: The New York City Transportation Administrator warned New Jersey scofflaws yesterday that he would obtain liens against their bank accounts unless they paid for parking violations.

title: QUEENS JURY HEARS MALCOLM WILSON
description: Former Gov. Malcolm Wilson appeared for two hours yesterday morning before a special grand jury in State Supreme Court in Queens that is investigating allegations of corruption leveled at an unidentified public official.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Jobless Rate Up to 8.9%; Total at Work Also Rose
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 The nation's unemployment rate edged up two tenths of a point in April to 8.9 per cent even though the total number of persons with jobs rose for the first time since last September, the Labor Department reported today.

title: In Siberia, Ingenuity and Stamina Are the Keynotes to Survival and Development
description: YAKUTSK, U.S.S.R.The gravediggers went about their task in this manner: first, they poured kerosene over the frozen ground and set it afire.

title: Is There a Message in Media Feud?
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2Will John Campo speak to Jean Cruguet in the paddock tomorrow when he hoists his unwanted jockey aboard Media for the 101st Kentucky Derby?

title: Loblaw Discloses Tender Of National Tea Shares
description: Loblaw Companies, Ltd., of Toronto said yesterday that about 1.1 million shares of the National Tea Company of Chicago have been tendered as la result of its April 10 offer. ILoblaw said also that 625,000 shares of Lohlaw, Inc., of Buffalo, N. Y. had also been tendared.

title: CLASS ACTION SUIT FILED AGAINST CERRO
description: The Cerro Corporation, metals fabricator, said yesterday that a class action suit had been filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York by a Harold Barnett, who the company said claims to be a shareholder.

title: DR. JOHN H. DEAN
description: Dr. John H. Dean, assistant professor of geology and geography at Herbert H. Lehman College, the Bronx, died Thursday in Memorial Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 2421 Webb Avenue, the Bronx.

title: The Brain Bank of America
description: No myth deserves a more emphatic death than the idea that science is an inherently impartial and objective enterprise; objectivity has. after all, been batteredby everything from Thomas Kuhn to Watergate. Yet it continues to thrive among working scientists because it serves us so well. It works within our profession by. inspiring our students and sustaining us through inevitable periods of selfdoubt; more crucially, it is the hallmark of our effort in public relationsa selfserving statement that enhances the social prestige and political clout of scientists. It also provides the rationale for America's scientific priesthood: the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Nature and nurture and gender
description: Tiresias, blind prophet, one of the spookiest figures in ancient legend, was said to have disobeyed the gods and therefore to have been changed midway through life from a man to a woman. And then the gods used him for research purposes. Who, they wanted to know, gets the most sublime pleasure from sexmen or women? Tiresias told them women and the gods ceased their investigation, failingat least as far as the legend goesin using their handy hermaphrodite to further civilization's knowledge of sex.

title: But What Does It All Mean, Mr. Antonioni?
description: On a coffee table in the otherwise unadorned hotelsuite living room is a bowl of bloodred roses, which, like all roses, have about them an aura of something obscurely sinister and menacing. In liar corner of the staleaired room, a pair of whispering mento whom none of the others in the room either speaks or refers are on their knees trying to fix a broken airconditioner. They work somehow almost soundlessly, but without success, for the room, stiflingly overheated, remains so even when, after a time, they rise and quietly depart.

title: Foyt Top Contender for 200 M.P.H. Indy Lap
description: A. J. Foyt and Johnny Rutherford, the Texans who dominated the scene last year, are expected to be the central figures again when qualifying begins Saturday for the incuanapoils 500mile race. Foyt won the battle last year, but Rutherford won the war. About Motor Sports.

title: Australia to Airdrop Maggots In Drive Against Blowflies
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, May 4Australian biologists are planning to bomb an island with millions of maggots in a war on blowflies.

title: International Wood Crafts With a Japanese Accent
description: HUNTINGTONThe pungent odor of new wood, masses of potted marigolds, and a crisply modern Japanese setting greet the visitor to KuraBarn, a newly opened shop for wood crafts and furniture at 479 New York Avenue (Route 110). Inside is an eclectic sampling of the woodcrafter's art from a Vermont desk and a Shaker rocker kit to a $2 Russian doll and a $1,500 madetoorder Japanese game table.

title: Klein Sees Long Austerity
description: HAUPPAUGEin his subdued presentation last week of a $700million capital program in Which no new major projects were proposed, Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein was clearly passing the word that the current economic problems could affect this oncebooming county for at least the next three years, perhaps longer.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Culver Line Is Likely To Close In a Week
description: Termination of service on the Culver elevated shuttle in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn a week from today became all but inevitable after a public hearing last week.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange registered their fourth ccnsecutive weekly advance last week in continued active trading.

title: Rivals on Busing Issue Clash in Boston
description: BOSTON, May 3  Rockthrowing clashes broke out today as the leftist Progressive Labor party held a march on the edge of South Boston the neighborhood that is the heart of this city's antibusing sentiment.

title: Fareless Flyer Lures Nashville to Buses
description: Some citizens of Nashville were a bit startled last Tuesday when the city offered them a free ridea bus ride.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Among Great Moments in film history (the Odessa Steps sequence from Potemkin, the last scene of City Lights and the montage that describes the failing marriage in Citizen Kane, to identify just a few of the more obvious ones), there are at least half a dozen in a film that won no major Academy Awards and wasn't even listed on many TenBest lists for the year it came out (1952).

title: Power Tops Loughlin In Medley
description: Close finishes and a couple of hot disputes marked the close of the twoday program in the 10th annual New York Relays yesterday at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: Moscowo The time is the present. The stage shows a quiet, peaceful c;earing in the woods near Lake Legont in Karelia, the northern part of European Russia. To the accompaniment of a guitar, a quintet of young people enter and sing of a tragic incident that occurred on that, very spot. 30 years ago during World War II when four girls of the woman's division of an antiaircraft section were killed by a patrol of Germans. Suddenly, in a flashback, the four girls and their commanding officer appear to reenact, in highly romanticized terms, this grim episode from the past.

title: Financial Editor Is Elected President of Deadline Club,
description: The election of Myron Kandel, editor and publisher of the Review of the Financial Press and other newsletters, as president of the Deadline Club, the New York City chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists, Sigma Delta Chi, was announced yesterday.

title: Summer School Now Serious Business
description: Some of the best supporters of Cornell University's summer session are still in elementary school. They are the children of Cornell graduates who accompany their parents to the summer alumni program, which offers combination of intellectual stimulation and vacation fun.

title: Prison Escape Fails
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., May 3 (AP)The authorities say that two prisoners who took a jailer hostage and raided a deputies storage rack for guns were back in their cells today. Their bid for freedom collapsed yesterday when 50 officers rushed to the scene and forced their surrender. The prisoners were identified as Willie Adams, 37 years old, and Max Atterbury, 22.

title: Charter Unit Urges City to Consolidate 3 Agencies
description: The State Charter Revision Commission for New York City yesterday called for upgrading the generally uneven performance of the city's construction services by consolidating the work of three superagencies tato a single new department.

title: In Buttons, It's Buy American
description: American industry, often proclaimed a victim of foreign competition in its own home markets, appears to be winning its way back in one field  the takenforgranted button.

title: Recognition Is Goal Of Serious Bowlers
description: At one time bowling was a sport most women played with their families on weekends or in leagues with other women. Some women regarded their evenings spent at Dowling alleys as the counterpart of a husband's night out on the town. While many women still think of bowling in those social terms, there is a growing number of serious athletes among them, who are the first to boast of the accomplishments women have made in professional and amateur bowling. Women in Sports.

title: U.S. Will Lease Home Of Washington Family
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (Reuters)The lease to the British ancestral home of the first President of the United States, George Washington, will he formally presented on Monday to the United States Bicentennial Commission.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Attendance, 29,925. Track parimutuel handle, $1,083,504. OTB handle, $1,644,586.

title: Vietnam boosters
description: Unless you are into postVietnam flagellation or the smug enjoyment of saying I told you so, as if you really did, this is not a book for sustained reading. But it could be a kind of medicine cabinet for that lingering Asian sickness, especially now that the nation is again feverish over Vietnam; now that new factfinding missions are reporting to the President; now that the thin edge of potentially paralyzing recrimination seems to be setting in.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Convicted of killing eight student nurses in Chicago in 1966, in what one news account described as one of the most savage multiple murders in the history of crime, Richard F. Speck was first sentenced to death in the electric chair. His sentence was reduced to a minimum of 400 years in prison after the Supreme Court all but outlawed the death penalty.

title: Blood Pressures To Be Tested Free
description: WAYNEFree bloodpressure tests will be offered to the public Thursday at William Paterson College. The tests, which are being sponsored by the college's Irish Cultural Club, will be given in the new Student Center from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M.

title: Johnson Quotations Selected for Memorial Grove
description: WASHINGTON. May 3 (AP)Lady Bird Johnson has sclected four quotations by her late husband that will be used in the LBJ Memorial Grove on the Potomac River across from the capital.

title: Encounter: When Fantasy Becomes Fact
description: IT'S a fairly common fantasy, especially around income tax time: a stranger walks up to you on the street and hands you a plain brown envelope. No explanation, no questions. He disappears. You open the envelope and inside is a large amount of cash. Last year, in the lobby of a hotel in Washington, D. C., fantasy became fact.

title: Jersey Expands Vocational Programs
description: TRENTONNew Jersey's public school systems are putting additional emphasis on vocational and career programs a means of combating a high dropout rate and facilitating entry Into the Job market.

title: Some Weeds Are Delicious As Well As Nutritious
description: Plant as soon as the soil can be easily worked, advises the fine print on the back of the seed packet. By the time the soil can be easily worked, the canny gardener will find a fine crop of homegrown greens ready for picking: winter cress, chickweed and dandelions. Before the seeds have germinated lamb's quarters and ettles appear.

title: The Man Who Brought Us Greetings From the Vietcong
description: At the Academy Awards show a few weeks ago, producer Bert Schneider inflamed the conservative wing of the movie colony, as represented by Bob Hope and Frank Sinatra, when he read a message from the Provisional Revolutionary Government of Vietnam while accepting the Best Doctimentary award for Hearts and Minds, the powerful antiwar film directed by Peter Davis, The Vietcong message, which contained greetings of friendship to all the American people from Ambassador Dinh Ba Thi, chief of the PRG delegation to the Paris political talks, and Schneider's references to the current liberation of South Vietnam, stirred up a small firestorm which has not yet

title: The Rock Road Leads to The Bottom Line
description: Our audience is anywhere from 18 to early 40's, depending on the act. For Barry Manilow, they were what you'd call nice people, good spenders. For Miles Davis, they were mostly black and poor tippers. The bluegrass crowd will try to bring in their own wine. Blues, jazz, and Latin audiences don't come to the early shows but the late shows sell out. Eating patterns vary, too. For West Coast rock and roll, like Jerry Garcia, ordering will be heavy on pizza, french fries, and Heineken's. For Cashman and West, it's eggplant parmigiana and shrimp Creole. A blues auther.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: $11Million Project For Stony Brook Cut
description: STONY BROOK  Construction plans for a new $11milion Social and Behavior Sciences Building for the State University here have been indefinitely postponed.

title: One District, Three Systems
description: When the parents at Long Beach, L. I., could not agree what kind of schools the town should have, they decided on a compromiseoffer three different kinds.

title: Red Smith
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3To prepare a thoroughbred horse for a race like the Kentucky Derby, to time his development so he reaches his peak on the first Saturday in May and to recognize the signs when this has been attainedthese are the hallmarks of good trainer. Diet, proper shoeing, equipment changes, overcoming horse's bad habits, teaching good ones, working him enough for fitness but not enough to dull the fine edge are only few of the complexities involved. Nobody understands this better than the veteran horseman, Phil Bieber.

title: Insect Pests Survived Mild Winter
description: This past winter's weather conditions in the metropolitan area were not especially harsh to insect life. In fact, mild weather remained well into November and December in many areas. These conditions favored the survival of many insects, some of which are pests of shade trees, woody ornamentals, and flowers.

title: OutofStaters Face Rutgers Crackdown
description: NEW BRUNSWICKRutgers University has developed moreefficient methods of detecting outofstate students who wrongly declare themselves New Jersey residents and thus qualify for a lower tuition rate.

title: Senate Unit to Explore Interpol's Role in the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) The chairman of a Senate Appropriations Subcommittee said today that he would hold hearings next week on the International Police Organization's operations in the United States and the relationship of the organization, known as Interpol, with the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Marine and Pastor Save a Saigon Baby
description: SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, May 3 (AP)  As the Rev. Fritz Berhaus was scrambling on Wednesday to board a United States Marine evacuation helicopter in the American Embassy compound in Saigon, a marine in battle gear thrust a Vietnamese baby into los arms.

title: Young Dealer Shows His Prize Latin Crafts
description: GREAT NECKA crafts bazaar unlike any that one might see in the Latin American cities where tourists congregate opened Friday for a 10day run here at the North Shore Community Arts Center.

title: At Siding Time, Savvy Insulates Against Regret
description: Anthony Zito is having his 70yearold, twofamily house on Emmons Avenue in Brooklyn covered with aluminum siding. It will be redwood and fawn, rather than the customary white, and the siding will be insulated.

title: Mr. Ford Turns to The Mideast
description: The World

title: Art for the Very Young Taught in Cellar
description: PRINCETONRobin Liebmann ??? stood in the prodigiously cluttered basement of her home here and talked with a visitor about the unconventional art studio that she runs for children in that unlikely setting.

title: Whoppers
description: There are few things as beguiling as a really audacious lie, and the prospect of a collection of them seems almost too good to be true. The reader better be ready for large amounts of rustic exaggeration.

title: Miss McKinney To Marry May 3
description: Martha Sloan McKinney, student at the University of Louisville, and William Davis Morgan, a professor of architectural history at Louisville, nlan to be married May 31.

title: Susan Morris Is Bride of E. C. Cameron
description: In St. John's Episcopal Church in Franklin, N. C., yesterday afternoon, Susan Bradford Morris, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Bradford Morris of Birmingham, Ala., became the bride of Edward Christian Cameron. He is the son of Mrs. Thomas Robinson Thrasher of New York and Dr. John Mlinge Cameron of Montgomery, Ala.

title: Free Data Source for Business
description: Information, like most everything else, is getting expensive. Ad that has sent more and more businessmen, small investors and entrepreneurs to the Brooklyn Public Business Library and the handful of others like it around the country.

title: Celtics Win, 10190, Trail by 21
description: BOSTON, May 3  Pride and baseline to  baseline pressure basketball, which had earned 12 National Basketball Association championships for the Boston Celtics, brought them back into playoff competition with a 10190 victory over the Washington Bullets today.

title: Gather, Ye Witches And Warlocks
description: I knew I was a witch when was 11, or surely an emissary from some remote and richer realm, and if I had come into this one not exactly railing clouds of glory, at least I had the power to cloud men's minds Most of us share and subsequently elinquish this sense of our special participation in the extraordinary, so you might think it would be a (super) natural for writers with the juvenile trade in mind. Yes and no.

title: FUTURE WEIGHED BY FINCH COLLEGE
description: The president of Finch College, a 75yearold college for women on the East Side, told the student body last week that a decision on whether to shut down or to reopen in the fall would be made in three weeks.

title: West Ham Conquers Fulham, 20
description: WEMBLEY, England. May 3 For 15 years. Bobby Moore, was the star of the East London team of West Ham United. Today, in the Football Association's cup final, he took the field against his old teammates and found them just too much to contain.

title: The Quitting Deal
description: Trina Schart Hyman is my favorite children's book illustrator. Her people remind me of the ways we are and want to be. Her illustrations for The Quitting Deal are especially Fitting since the story is about very believable people. They are so real, in fact, that kept trying to remember which of my friends the book is about.

title: Liner's Summer Cruise Program Abruptly Halted
description: The summer cruise program aboard the Constitution, which was to have been started by Wall Street Cruises on June 20, was abruptly canceled last week. The vessel actually is the Holland America Cruises passenger ship Volendam, which, under an agreeentered into earlier this year, was to have been chartered by Wall Street Cruises for two years, with an option for another two years. The ship was to have been known as the Constitution for the Cruises.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Random House has sublet more than 36,000 square feet of office space at 825 Third Avenue to four tenants at an aggregate rent of more than 84million. The lease terms range from five to ten years.

title: Coal Rush Lures Hillbillies Home From Northern Jobs
description: YOLYN, W. Va., May 2Spring fell softly on the greening mountains towering above this settlement of about 100 people in Rum Creek Hollow, and the apple tree in the yard flashed its white blossoms.

title: Serena S. Rhinelander Bride of John Bruno Jr.
description: In St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church here yesterday afternoon, Serena Schley Rhinelander, a fashion model, was married to John C. Bruno Jr., owner of the Pen & Pencil restaurant. The Rey. Leo Daly performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Explorers Club, of which Mr. Bruno is a member.

title: Mediacracy
description: Kevin Phillips's latest book, Mediacracy, is an effort to look at what has happened to American politics in the last 10 years or so with an eye toward telling us where all the crosscurrents of our political life are taking us in the next decade. If nothing else you have to admire the man's courage. Lesser mortals might be content to point out that we are in a time of great chaos when it is difficult to distinguish between the transitory effects of individuals and deeprooted patterns forecasting permanent change. But not Mr. Phillips. He is certain there are great doings afoot and that they signify a substantive swing to the right in our politiell life.

title: Jipcho Takes Track Double
description: DURHAM, N. C., May 3 Ben Jipcho, who wanted to run three races, settled for 3 minute57.6second mile and 8:30.8 twomile today in another successful payday on the International Track Association pro tour.

title: LAG FOUND IN AID FOR HANDICAPPED
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 Speakers and individual delegates attending the 28th annual meeting of the President's Committee on Employment of the Handicapped here this week expressed confusion and misunderstanding about recent legislation mandating affirmative action programs for the country's disabled citizens.

title: Group Files Suit to Change Parole System in State
description: A suit seeking major changes In the state's system of paroling prisoners has been filed in Federal District Court here by the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: Small Lives
description: Approximately 85 per cent of all animals known to science are insects. Based upon criteria such as number of species and adaptations for surviving in different habitats, insects rank as one of the most successful groups of animals ever to have evolved. With approximately one million species described to date, any attempt at appreciating the significance of their diverse adaptations should begin with an understanding of the characteristics used by scientists to distinguish among the insect groups:

title: Roosevelt And Churchill
description: Herbert Hoover used to talk about the machinery of government, and someone remarked that he thought it really was machinery. But government is human beings, and its operations are in the realm of human relations. Especially at the highest level, the regularities of bureaucratic procedure often are overridden by the irregularities of personal relations.

title: Artists Colonies Dot More of Countryside
description: Three acres of farm land adjacent to the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N. H., sold recently for $13,000. Unimproved acreage adjoining the Yaddo colony at Saratoga Springs, N. Y., much of it heavily wooded or swampy, has doubled in value in the last five years. Mountainland near the Millay Colony in Austerlitz, N. Y., could be had for $200 an acre only a few years ago; now can't be touched for less than $1,500.

title: Births
description: GOODDr. & Mrs. Larry I. (Good nea Judy Chafetz joyfully announce the birth of their san Adam Eric. April 13, 1975. Proud grandparents are Mr. & Mrs. Benjamin Chatetz, Forest Hills, N.Y., and Mrs. & Mrs. Samuel Good, Merrick.

title: Janet Goldstein Is Fiancee of L. M. Bell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Goldstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Carol Goldstein, to Lawrence Martin Bell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Bell of Ardsley, N.Y. and Chilmark, Mass. An August wedding is planned.

title: San Francisco Is Ordered To Hire 60 Women Police
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May (UPI)  A Federal judge has ordered the City of San Francisco to hire 60 women police patrol officers within the next 32 weeks.

title: 45 Unwilling Exiles Petition to Go Back To South Vietnam
description: AGANA, Guam, May 3 (Reuters)Fortyfive South Vietnamese Air Force mechanics, unwillingly exiled from their country when their pilots flew to Thailand last Tuesday at the height of the shelling of Saigon's airport, petitioned President Ford today to let them return home.

title: The Tot in the Gray Flannel Suit
description: When William Kessen, a developmental psychologist at Yale, spent last year studying a class of firstgraders he foundas he and others suspectedthat there was a hidden curriculum, one that the school had never consciously put on the classroom schedule. But he also found something morethat the children evidently understood it very clearly.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor Marshall Berman (is] offensively vicious on the subject of Erikson's personal integrity and his Jewish identity (March 31). His red herring of evasion and denial on Erikson's part is exposed as deception on Berman's part by referring to Coles's Erik H. Erikson: The Growth of His Work. In the index under Jews and Erikson's Jewish background the answer is stated explicitly in response to Coles's direct question:

title: Word Processing Comes of Age
description: The evolution of the typewriter from a machine operated by hands and feet to ope that, without either, zooms along typing 350 words a minute makes automation in the office seem a flick of a switch away.

title: ART VIEW
description: Certain artists can be fully understood only on their own home ground. Between their art and the terrain that shapes their experience and sensibility there exists a relation so intimate and so profound that no final reckoning of what their art signifies is possible without taking into account the environment in which it was created. Artists of this sort are not easily exported. To know them in any serious way, we are obliged to journey to the world that formed them.

title: Rutgers Hails Deputing Dean
description: NEW BRUNSWICKTheir place in the hierarchy of Rutgers University's Cook College is different, but administrators, faculty and students alike all say they will sorely miss their departing dean.

title: Sometimes Guerrillas, Sometimes Regulars, Always Well Disciplined
description: The tanks and infantry of the North Vietnamese Army, streaming down Saigon's boulevards last week, signalled the end of an amazing military achievement. The army of an underdeveloped country had survived for years the onslaught of up to half a million. American troops and the world's most advanced air forces and then broken the military power of Americanarmed South Vietnam.

title: Queens College Arts Center Finds Business Is Booming
description: The Colden Center for the Performing Arts, at Queens College, has become an oasis of prosperity in the nation's landscape of recession.

title: G.O.P. Eying Governorship As Byrne's Problems Mount
description: TRENTONEncouraged by the recent policy problems and political scandals that have plagued the Democratic administration of Governor Byrne, New Jersey Republicans have begun to maneuver for their party's gubernatorial nomination in 1977.

title: John Francis Otto Jr. Marries Nell Wall, Research Assistant
description: Nell Duncan Wall daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Craig Wall of Conway, S.C., was married there early yesterday evening to John Francis Otto. Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto of Greenwich, Conn.

title: DEAL NEGOTIATED FOR COMMODORE
description: The Hyatt hotel chain and a realestate developer have reached agreement on a plan to purchase the Commodore Hotel from the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company and renovate the 26story structure into a luxury hotel.

title: Man Killed After Abduction
description: ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP)A janitor was shot to death by policeman early today after barricading himself in a downtown bank building and critically wounding a woman hostage, the authorities reported. The police said that Willie McGrath, 31 years old, was killed in the Farm and Home Savings and Nvorked. The police said that Mr. McGrath had shot Polly ?? Kirpatrick, 40, in the head when she tried to flee.

title: Summer Camps Tighten Belts
description: Summer camps, squeezed by a recession and the growth of family camping and recreation, are moving into the upcoming season with a combination of ingenuity, soulsearching, hopeand an average 10 per cent rise in fees.

title: LEGAL AID FOR POLICE IN ATTICA CASEURGED
description: State Senator John J. Marchi said yesterday that he would introduce a bill tomorrow that would require the state to pay legal fees for state policemen and other public employes subpoenaed in connection with the 1971 Attica prison rebellion.

title: A Clinic for Pregnant TeenAgers
description: Pregnant teenagers in Far Rockaway are receiving prenatal counseling and care at a clinic that has been designed to deal with their special needs and problems.

title: Dance: City Swan Lake
description: The New York City Ballet's Swan Lake by George Balanchine does not so much tell the story of Swan Lake as refer to it. It is a oneact version based on the Ivanov second act of the 1895 Petipalvanov fouract production of Tchaikovsky's Swan Lake. and one hopes everyone in the audience is aware of this.

title: 3 Classes of Offshore Races Seen Aid to Competition
description: It used to be easy to spot an ocean racer. It was the large, sleek yacht with a man in a blue blazer and white ducks at the helm and a crew dressed in whites. It is not so So simple today. The gentlemanly skirmishes have been swept astern by a generation using stripped racing machines, powered by computercut sails over courses determined by onboard minicomputers. News of Boating.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: Brooklyn Salute to the Bicentennial, a citywide outdoor exhibition sponsored by the Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association, weekends through May 18, 11 A.M. to P.M., Brooklyn Heights Esplanade, Remsen to Cranberry Streets.

title: Lon Nol Denies Reports Of Wealthin Switzerland
description: HONOLULU, May 2Marshal Lon Nol, who for five years headed a Cambodian Government that was accused of being inefficient and corrupt, has moved in five weeks from teetering pinnacle of power in Phnom Penh to apparent retirement on a quiet residential street here.

title: Headliners
description: There seems to be little doubt that it was his political past that won Lawrence O'Brien a job as the new Commissioner of the National Basketball Association. His previous experience in basketball consists of his attendance at several games this season. Owners of professional basketball teams are hopeful that Mr. O'Brien, the former Democratic National Chairman, has the necessary political contacts to obtain Congressional action permitting longsought merger with the rival American Basketball Association. The N.B.A. Players Association, which has opposed the merger, is not necessarily opposed to the O'Brien appointment. Bill Bradley the New York Knicks, an Association leader, said he feels Mr. O'Brien may pressure some owners into less intransigent views on issues such as the reserve clause, which binds players to one team. Mr. O'Brien said the merger had not been discussed prior to his appointment, but he conceded he might be discussing it in the future. There is always the art of the possible and the art of compromise, Mr.

title: At Princeton: Images of Madonna
description: PRINCETONThe Princeton University Art Museum has mounted an exhibition that is a tribute not only to some fine paintings, but also to art history and art education.

title: Song Of the Trees
description: First are the trees behind the house. Hickory, pine, beech, sturdy walnut, sweet alligator gum, they are the joy of young Cassie's lifetrunks to hug, leaves that sing, branches that protect. With such a forest, a girl can feel rich even though this is the Depression and monev is scarce, particularly in Mississippi for black people.

title: SAIGON SAYS HANOI BEGINS REBUILDING OF SOUTH VIETNAM
description: The Saigon radio announced yesterday that North Vietnam. had undertaken a vast reconstruction program in South Vietnam to provide jobs and to begin reversing the devastation of 30 years of war.

title: Broadway's Hottest Producer is a Cool Businesswoman
description: It is midmorning in an elegant East 72d Street townhouse. The phones are ringing madly. The doorbell is buzzing incessantly. And up in her booklined office, Adela Holzer, Broadway's hottest producer, is taking care of business.

title: Russian Rescued at Sea
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 3 (AP)A seriously injured Russian seaman has been rescued by a longdistance American airlift, I he Air Force said today. Officials at McClellan Air Force Base said Victor Sidorenko, 37 years old, was recovering at the Veterans Administration hospital in Sao Francisco from a compound skull fracture, a possible ??? fracture, a broken leg and a shifted windpipe. He was injured in a fall aboard t he Russian fishing trawler tangli, about 300 miles off the California coast, and was picked up off the vessel by an H3 helicopter.

title: Williams's 0:09.2 Sprint Wins in San Jose Meet
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 3 (AP)Steve Williams, former world recordholder in the 100yard dash, sped to a 9.2second victory in the event today at the San Jose National invitation track meet in which several other world class performers were hampered by cold, rainy weather.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The Bicentennial is upon us, and for the next two years or so the country is going to be inundated by things American (and also by things not American, a case in point being an opera commissioned from Penderecki of Poland to help celebrate the American beginnings). Broadcast Music, Inc., is contributing its share. Tucked away in its offices at 40 West 57th Street is an amazing collection named The Carl Haverlin/BMI Archivesa collection containing more than 6,000 items from the 16th century to the present; a collection rich in Americana as well as In European music. Not many are familiar with this material, and that situation will be remedied. Starting now, BMI is making part of the collection available for free in a series Bicentennial exhibits. Ask and ye shall receive.

title: Physicists Still Not Sure if New Particles Have Charm
description: After almost six months of hectic research in which the world's largest experimental devices have been used to probe some of the tiniest constituents of matter, the nature of the new class of particles discovered last November has become more perplexing than ever.

title: The Rockefeller Commission Has Been Forced to Add it to the Agenda
description: WASINGTONFour months ago, topic A in investigations of The Central Intelligence Agency was domestic surveillance. Now it is assassinations, foreign and/or domestic, plotted and/or committed. The subject has become a preoccupation of the Presidential commission headed by Vice President Rockefeller despite its primary mandate, an inquiry into allegations that the C.I.A. paid considerable attention, improperly and perhaps illegally, the activities of thousands of Americans.

title: No Energy Tax?
description: Economists can readily demonstrate that taxes, selectively imposed, would be a powerful incentive for achieving energy conservation. But taxes are never popular, and rare is the constituent who writes his Congressman urging that a tax be levied on anything he uses or buys.

title: Rowdies Defeat Cosmos by 10
description: TAMPA, Flu., May 3 (AP)Stewart Scullion, 3 substitute, scored on an unassisted 45yard shot late in a North American Soccer League game tonight to give the Tampa Rowdies a 10 victory over the New York Cosmos.

title: 10,000 Yugoslav Croats Given Papal Audience
description: ROME, May 3Pope Paul VI granted a special audience today for 10,000 Croats who had come from Yugoslavia for the Roman Catholic Church's current Holy Year. They were believed to be the largest pilgrimage ever to arrive in Rome from a Communist country.

title: DR. JOHN F. DASHIELL
description: Dr. John Frederick Dashiell, Kenan Professor Emeritus of Psychology at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, died yesterday in Alexandria, Va., where he lived. His age was $7.

title: CHESS
description: The positional sacrifice of the exchange is based on the principle that a powerfully functioning minor piece may often prove stronger than a rook whose mobility is curtailed.

title: Texas Construction Halted
description: FORT WORTH, May 3The North Texas Contractors Association yesterday ordered work halted on some $500million in new ceastruction, breaking oil negotiations with 27 building trades unions in the DallasFort Worth area and putting 27,000 workers out of work. The action came after pickets from some of the unions arpeared at random construction sites.

title: Foolish Pleasure Wins
description: Foolish Pleasure, ridden by Jacinto Vasquez, won the 101st running of the Kentucky Derby yesterday at Churchill Downs. The favorite covered the mile and a quarter in 2:02 and returned $5.80 for $2 to win. Avatar was second and Diabolo third. Details in Section 5.

title: TEXAS ROAD AGENCY MOVES TO END TOLLS
description: FORT WORTH, May 3Reacting to mounting public pressure, the Texas Turnpike Authority has moved to put itself largely out of business within three years and to open a 30mile strip of urban real estate for more than a billion dollars in new development.

title: Guam Refugee Health Excellent
description: OROTE POINT, Guam, Sunday, May 4Military doctors, refugee workers and public health officials expressed amazement here today at the superior health of the more than 41,000 South Vietnamese refugees who have passed through Guam in recent days.

title: FOOD STAMPS HIT 19.1MILLION MARK
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UFO) Enrollment in the Federal food stamp program rose to another record of 19.1 million persons in March, Agriculture Department figures showed this week.

title: Michigan's Jobless Rate Last Year Led the Nation
description: WASHINGTON. May 3 (UPI) A Labor Department survey has found that Michigan and the West Coast were among the hardest hit by unemployment in 1974, while most of the South escaped severe Impact from the recession.

title: Mortgage Rates Suddenly Tilt Up
description: LOS ANGELES  Interest rates on home mortgages, which have been tumbling for more than three months and had been expected to decline even more this spring as savings deposits grew at a record rate, are leveling off or climbing again.

title: Endpaper
description: This is a work of conceptual art by Hanna Darboven, a young German artist. It is a message to The New York Times about her visit to New York, to attend an exhibit of her work at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Ghost Story
description: There is nothing wrong with dialect. But it can be a chore to read, and there ought to be at least some reason for its useeither to reflect the accent of a first person narrator or at least a distinctive locale. There is no such justification here in a tale of ghosts too poor to buy permits allowing them to flow through walls. All we are told is that the action takes place in Boston, so the choice to render the entire story in a subliterate third person struck me as bewildering and labored  not cute, as I suspect it was meant to seem. A beginning reader would be even more burdened than I was plowing through such deliberate grammatical bungling as they all got along together real good or don't help none or could of. The search to do something a little out of the ordinary is admirable, but why brutalize further our already much abused tongue?

title: The Tattooed Potato
description: Ellen Raskin, designer of more than a thousand book jackets, authorartist of a dozen picture books, wrote her first novel in 1971. The Mysterious Disappearance of Leon (I Mean Noel) has a plot reminiscent of some Gilbert and Sullivan operettas. It's a convoluted story dependent on word play  anagrams, synonyms, acronyms, all manner of verbal trickeryto reach its conclusion. A puzzle as well as a mystery, all the missing words miraculously fall into place on the last page for those who haven't already filled them in.

title: Samuel Gonard Dies at 78; Led International Red Cross
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 3 (Reuters)Samuel A. Gonard, a former president of the International Committee of the Red Cross, died today at his home at CorseauxsurVevey near here. He was 78 years old.

title: After Vietnam
description: The American role in Vietnam ended as it had begun in a muddle of misconceptions. Initially, a handful of American advisers were expected to shape and sustain an independent South Vietnam; in the end, one more consignment of American arms was expected to save regime that never took root. In the intervening fifteen years, an anticolonial nationalism had evolved into an antiAmerican tide.

title: Proposals For Budgets Are Listed
description: Following are the school districts in Nassau and Suffolk Counties that will hold budget votes this week. In Nassau, all of the votes will be held on Wednesday, except for Hempstead, which will be on Tuesday. In Suffolk, all of the votes will be on Wednesday, except in Amagansett, Montauk, Remsenburg, Sayville and The Springs, which will be on Tuesday. Tax figures are based on $100 of assessed valuation:

title: The Fourth Law of Politics
description: WASHINGTON, May 3'What would you do about all these Vietnamese refugees?, someone asked Representative Morris Udall ju't after he'd finished a brief talk to the Prince Georges County (Md.) Democratic Women's Club.

title: Gertrude Stein and G. B. Shaw Inspire Menus at 2 Festivals
description: Gertrude Stein is being served up with some Alice B. Toklas specialties at C.W. Post College this week while a Bernard Shaw minifestival at Hofstra University will be celebrated with a V eg etarian dinner. One program is designed to involve the local community in the college, the other to take the classroom beyond the campus.

title: Miss Freear Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Faxon Freear of Pasadena, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Osceola Louise Freear, to Evan Welling Thomas 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Evan W. Thomas 2d, of New York and Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L. I.

title: Honorary Degree for Ford
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (UPI) President Ford will receive an honorary degree from the University of Pennsylvania following an address to the university's 219th commencement May 18. Commencement exercises will be held at Franklin Field.

title: Leading Indicators, Having Led Astray, Getting a BrushUp
