description: A major cause of the current recession was the Government's inability last year to see that the economy was actually heading down when it appearedbecause of rampaging inflationto be still moving up. Monetary policy, consequently, was far more restrictive than necessary, most analysts agree.

title: Brooklyn Ethical Culture Society Drops Its Sponsorship of School
description: Citing financial pressures and reordered priorities, the Brooklyn Ethical Culture Society has decided, after more than 50 years, to withdraw its sponsorship of the Brooklyn Ethical Culture School.

title: SchoolVote Drive Is Pushed in Queens
description: Two years ago, when the last school board elections were held in the city, only one of every nine eligible voters in Queens went to the polls.

description: To most persons who experienced it, the Great Electrical Blackout of 1965 was an event that they long will remember. But it was more than that for the Automatic Switch Company of Florham Park.

title: Speedy ExPoliceman No Flatfoot in N.A.S.L.
description: Before Steve David, the speedster of the Miami Toros, joined the North American Soccer League team last year, he was a policeman in Trinidad, specializing in fingerprinting. But he was more in demand when a prisoner escaped. They would call me and ask me to get after them, on foot, David said at RandalIs Island last Wednesday night after he had scored twice to lead the Toros to a 32 victory and spoil the Cosmos opening game. It's true that I used to run after the prisoners, David said. I was very fast, I guess. News of Soccer

title: A Correction
description: In an article in this section last week on children's art from Armenia, a reference was made to a painting by Vinny La Rosa of Brooklyn. This painting was from Salute to Brooklyn's Creative Youth, also on display in the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Yankees Defeated By Brewers, 4 to 3
description: MILWAUKEE, May 3Artistically, the game was about as pleasing to the eye as a canvas that would cross Rembrandt with Andy Warhol. In Milwaukee's 43 victory over the Yankees today, the professional baseball players walked 16 batters, committed six errors and left 20 runners on base.

title: Vietnam Did It Kill Off Economic Tranquility?
description: WASHINGTONHow much did Vietnam, which for all practical purposes ended financially with just a whisper last Tuesday, wreck the fairly tranquil prosperity of the American economy?

title: Harvard Crew Easy Victor In Cup Race on Schuylkill
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 3After the Adams Cup race on the lovely Schuylkill River today, there was an inclination to search the fiberglass shell of the Harvard varsity crew for a nuclear power plant. The Crimson boat went zoom in the first 20 strokes of the 2,000meter race against Pennsylvania and Navy, assuming an impregnable lead of one boat length, and proceeded to win the cup easily and impressively for the fourth year in a row. It was the fourth straight victory this year for the nation's No. 1

title: May
description: Early spring or late, May brings a sense of reassurance. There is a feeling of order and rightness about a world where grass grows green again after the weeks and months of winter, where buds open and flowers bloom, even the lesser flowers of elm and alder and hepatica on the stony hillsides. No matter what man is doing, making grim mischief or dreaming of a better tomorrow, the world is going about its fundamental business and the seasons are following patterns that have been etched among the stars a long, long time.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor I disagree with the view of John H. Lichtblau that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is more than a cartel, that it is also a political organization with the ideology of more equal distribution of wealth among the developed and underdeveloped countries (Uncle Sam Would Be a Weak Oil Bargainer, April 20).

description: WASHINGTON, May 4With most Americans already mystified about what is and what is not a national holiday, scores of lobbying groups are putting pressure on Congress to make more changes in the holiday calendar.

title: Recreational Vehicle Limit On Federal Land Ordered
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) The Bureau of Land Management violated both the law and a Presidential order when it opened 450 million acres of Federal land to unrestricted use by offtheroad recreational vehicles, United States District Judge William B. Jones ruled yesterday. He ordered the Interior Department agency to draw up regulations limiting the use of the vehicles, which include snowmobiles, dune buggies and motorcycles.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 17yearold New Jersey youth was accused of having tried to extort $30,000 from Helen Reddy, the pop singer. The suspect, Gerald E. Hall, of Asbury Park, was picked up on Friday night by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a telegraph office near his home, where he had allegedly been told the money would be waiting for him. The youth allegedly made threatening phone calls to New York Thursday and Friday to Jeff Wald, the husband and manager of the Australianborn singer, who was in New York for a concert. The calls had been made to Mr. Wald's Los Angeles office and had been rerouted to his hotel suite in New York, where they were monitored by the F.B.I. Young Hall is to be arraigned tomorrow in Federal Court.

description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Sihanouk Says April 17 Is the New National Day
description: PEKING, May 3(Agence FrancePresse)  Prince Norodom Sihanouk has said in a statement here that April 17 will be Cambodia's national holiday, replacing Nov. 9, which had marked Cambodian independence and the end of French Colonialism in 1953.

title: Los Angeles Debates CrimeFighting Priorities After Mass Arrests of Youths
description: LOS ANGELES. May 3The arrests of hundreds of young persons at a rock concert has put the city's tough, outspoken police chief. Edward M. Davis, at the center of a controversy; over law enforcement priorities.

description: Charlotte Kathryn Cassidy and Daniel Harry Ryan were married yesterday morning In St. Martha's Roman Catholic Church in Uniondale, L.I., by the Rev. John J. Tutone.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: LONDON Kennedy's Children, Robert Patrick's mordant lament for the sixties, is a phenomenon in two ways. It is the first play to leapfrog from a London pubtheater (the estimable King's Head in Islington) into a West End playhousetio mean feat in these days of economic restraint. And, more impressively, it is one of the first plays in living memory composed entirely of discontinuous monologues by five characters who, though they inhabit the same stagesetting and belong to the same imaginative world, er directly relate to each other. (The play is expected to be produced by the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C., next fall.)

description: WASHINGTON  The traditional reservoirs of power in Congressthe party leaders and the committee chairmenhave lost much of their ability control legislation.

description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne is said to be ready to recommend major changes in the state's controversial system of releasing inmates from prison.

Both families are of New Canaan, Conn., where the ceremony was performed in St. Mark's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. C. Lawson Willard. He was assisted by the Rev. Grant A. Morrill.

title: CAREY AND BEANIE HONOR EDUCATOR
description: Dr. Carl Fenichel. founder and director of the League School for seriously disturbed children was honored yesterday by Governor Carey and Mayor Beame both of whom in past years had served on the Brooklyn institution's board of directors.

title: A Little Demonstration Of Affection
description: In 1973 Elizabeth Winthrop published a novel in which she described the special summer relationship between a girl and her grandfather and the subtle and unhappy changes in that relationship resulting from the girl's bringing her best winter friend into the summer situation. It was a nearly perfectly constructed and sensitively detailed piece of work and one which promised even more ambitious projects in the future.

title: DyerBennet Now Helps Others Find Their Voices
description: STONY BROOKIn American folk music, Richard DyerBennet, a contemporary and colleague of the late Woody Guthrie, Josh White and Leadbelly, as well as Pete Seeger, is a living legend.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Had never supposed That musical comedy depended all that much on words, but perhaps it does. Musicals, lately, have obyiously been in deep trouble, reaching into the past to see what nostalgia might do for them, turning into concerts with virtually no spoken words at all and little in the way of intelligible lyrics, getting down on their knees and begging choreographers to come in and play tricks with scenery and lighting that may somehow or other save their souls. But almost no one ever writes a musical anymore, and when a joke or even a straight line is permitted to obtrude for a moment, It's apt to blow everything that the amplified singing and the shocktreatment dancing have accomplished to smithereens.

title: Concert: Suited to Solti
description: The adulation accorded Sir Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony hasn't been universal. Some of us find Sir Georg's interpretations curiously bland and impersonal, for all the blunt flash and for all the glories of the orchestra itself. But Friday evening's concert at Carnegie Hall was mightily successful, and it is tempting to suggest that a major reason was that Sir Georg had at last found a repertory suited to his ternt.

title: Coop City Residents Suit Raises FarReaching Issue of Whether a Share Is Like a Corporate Stock
description: Legal and housing experts believe that a case now before the United States Supreme Court may have farreaching significance for residents of tens of thousands of cooperative apartments across the country, and for housing developers too.

title: 2 Aussies Reach Eastern Net Final
description: WOODBURY, L.I. May 3John James and Tony Dawson scored victories today and set up an allAustralian final in the Eastern men's hardcourt tennis championships at the Woodbury Country Club. They play tomorrow at 1 P.M.

title: How to Keep A Vegetable Plot Productive
description: Homeowners who are growing vegetables for the first time may like to know some special knacks and practises that keep their gardens productive. Here are a few.

title: Good Old James
description: Tickled by a million falsecheery (as well as natural) stimuli, my kidsI often feelare delighted quite enough. So, maybe perversely, I'm happy (delighted) to see John Donovan's new book, Good Old James. It is spare, charming and, by its subject, undelightful. Donovan, who has previously dealt with crumbling families, odd relationships, death, here deals with those outnosts of alienation  old age, retirement, loneliness. The tone is understated, sophisticated and precisely reflected in James Stevenson's drawings.

title: Gas Truck Explodes On Bay State Turnpike
description: NEWTON, Mass., May 3 (UPI)  A gasoline tanker truck exploded on a Massachusetts Turnpike exit ramp this evening sending a river of burning gasoline more than a mile underground through the Newton sewer system into the Charles River.

title: PRESIDENT VOWS NATION WILL KEEP PLEDGES ABROAD
description: NORFOLK, Va., May 3Four days after the evacuation of the remaining Americans from South Vietnam, President Ford pledged today that the United States would keep its commitments abroad and would remain militarily strong.

description: DETROIT, May 3After half a decade of development and the spending of millions of dollars, the General Motors Corporation has informed a Government safety agency that it will not offer air bags as an option on its 1977 models.

title: OTB Derby Bets Set Mark
description: New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation, accepting bets on the Kentucky Derby for the fifth time, had a record handle of $3,630,794.

title: Woman Stabbed to Death Outside Home in Tuckahoe
description: A 23yearold waitress was stabbed late Friday night in front of her home at 46 North High Street, Tuckahoe, N. Y., and died early yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxvile. A man was seen leaving the scene in a darkcolored motorcycle after the stabbing.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Holmes redivivus. The knack for spotting a popular fancy before it blossoms into a trend is nowhere cultivated more avidly than among editors, especially those with paperback houses. Two years ago, his wits honed through an apprenticeship with Popular Library, young Juris Jurjevics joined the oldline hardcover house of Dutton and soon found on his desk a manuscript called The SevenPerCent Solution. Mr. Jurjevics liked Nicholas Meyer's recreation of Sherlock Holmes even better than the Conan Doyle originals. More to the point, he had a hunch that the world was ready for a Holmes revival. The hunch became conviction when he learned that sales of Doubleday's edition of The Complete Sherlock Holmes were leaping and bounding.

description: KINGS POINT, 11 May 3  Adelphi University produced eight winners  six individual and two relays to successfully defend the team title in the 23d annual Collegiate Track Conference championships today at Tomb Memorial Field.

description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, May 1 (AP)Dr. Thomas R. Hoskins, a 31yearold American Quaker pediatrician, recalls that he was working in the Da Nang hospital's emergency ward when the South Vietnamese Army gave up the city.

title: If a School Flunks, Must Student Pay?
description: When a new shirt turns out to be defective, no one has any hesitation about returning it and demanding refund. title: Soccer Violence? Not in the U.S.
description: In an article on this page on March 30, Frederick Baron called for a cessation of athletic violence, a principle with which I wholeheartedly concur. Webster defines violence as exertion of physical force so as to injure or abuse. There certainly is no place in sport, no matter what the game, to injure or abuseon the field or off.

title: HeartofSnowbird
description: Last year Carol Lee Lorenzo gave us Mama's Ghosts, a humorous, wistful first novel Now she follows with a longer, more ambitious book. This one is about Laurel Ivy Anderson, a young teenager from a poor Southern mountain town with bird Gap. Because Laurel is something of a loner, her world is small, including only her preoccupied groceryman father, her stepmother, her sister and her friend Judith. Into this tight sphere comes a darkskinned, exotic stranger on a Yamaha minibikean American Indian boy, Hank Bearfoot. Hank and his family are considered a threat by the allwhite, nonintegrated hamlet. Only Laurel expresses openminded curiosity and, finally, seeks the boy's friendship.

title: BirdBook Watching
description: Ornithologists figure it's a safe guess that there are some 8,660 species of birds. Another safe guess is that at least that many different books about birds must be flying around at any given moment. In the 1973 Bowker's Subject Guide to Books in Print, the listings under headings that begin with BIRD cover more than five and a half pages of smallish type from BIRD, ATTRACTING (see Birds, Attracting of) to BIRDS OF PREY (see also Eagles; Falcons; Hawks; Ospreys; Owls). Here are 10 more bird books. Cool.

title: Answers/Questions
description: AMORE ON TOMATO FERTILIZER (March 30) Mrs. L.P.C., Gloversville, N.Y., had heard that Epsom salts (hydrated magnesium sulfate crystals) placed in the bottom of the tomato planting hole hastens growth. She asked if it was true. On April 20, magnesium and sulfur were referred to as trace elements used in minute quantities by plants and the use of Epsom salts was not recommended. Dr. Norman J. Curtis, an agronomist caught our error and makes this correction. He writes, Magnesium and sulphur are major elements for both plants and animals. Magnesium is the only mineral found as the core of chlorophyll. Magnesium Is low in soils in some parts of New York State, including the area around Gloversville. Sulfur is necessary for the assimilation of nitrogen. The use of Epsom salts does hasten ripening and improved flavor If the soil is low in magnesium. Use up to one tablespoonful mixed into the god around a tomato plant Epsom salts can also be used under a faded blue spruce to increase chlorophyll content and blue foliage.

To make mom, the Mets sent Bob Gailagher, a rarely used outfielder, to Tidewater, their farm in the International League Glenn Jones will come from Florida today and may play with the Mets tomorrow in the annual game against Army at West Point.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Business, quite properly, has been taking it on the chin as socalled political slush funds are uncovered. It is altogether fitting, of course, that lawbreaking, regardless of the motives or position of the lawbreaker, be exposed and punished. Corporate contributions to Federal election campaigns are clearly illegal.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Athletes and Free Speech
description: To the Sports Editor As much as the gag rule of professional sports may be an unfair reStriction on a player's freedom of speech, its erasure should not entail the adoption of a players rating system for officials, as was suggested by Dave t Anderson in his March 30 column. Nor should repealing this rule license player to make, at no cost, as acrirnomous an insult as the one Kareem AbdulJabbar paid $300 for.

title: JUDGE WHO CURBED TRIALS FORCED OUT
description: SKIATOOK, Okla., May (UPI)  Municipal Judge Harvey Lee Wilson contended that if you can not produce a wit, ness and prove you're innocent, you're guilty. Yesterday he resigned, ending six years of guilty pleas and no trials in his courtroom. Mayor Bob Kehler said that Judge Wilson had been given choice of resigning or being dismissed.

title: Business Index Rises
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity rose to 365.2 from 364.5 a week earlier. A year ago it was 394.2.

title: Animal World
description: It was once believed by the writers of children's books that little people were not meant to be happy. As one scholar put it (Bettina Hurlimann in Three Centuries of Children's Books in Europe), Children were not born to live happy but to die holy, and true education lay in preparing the soul to meet its maker.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: AT the crisis point of the Great Depression, when the nation was suffering from a huge erosion It, wealth and savings, when the hosts of the unemployed faced the grim difficulty of survival, when production and trade had withered gravely, and when the nation's spirit was enduring a most rigorous test, President Franklin D. Roosevelt sought to rally the American public with an inspirational Inaugural address on March 4, 1933, in which he sought their understanding and support.

title: U.S.S. Nimitz. the Navy's Newest and Biggest Vessel
description: NORFOLK, Va., May 3The U.S.S. Nimitz, at 95,000 tons the largest aircraft carrier ever built, was commissioned into the Atlantic Fleet today with President Ford as godfather when she has taken aboard an air wing of approximately 100 tactical aircraft, the Nimitz will be not only the largest but also the most powerful surface warship in the world, according to Navy sources powered by two nuclear reactors, she is designed to operate for 13 years without refueling.

title: West Germans See Their Recession Ending
description: DORTMUND, West Germany There are signs that West German voters, despite economic anxieties over much of the last two years, are beginning to agree with what their neighbors and leaders have been saying for some time: that West Germans are better off than any other people in the world, recession or no recession.

title: GUEST VIEW
description: Despite its record of high achievement over the past decade, the New York City Opera, which has just concluded its 197475 season, is in a period of confusing transition. To tell the truth, the company has lost its identity. In  the old days on 55th Street the City Opera provided New Yorkers with a genuine alternative to the Met As the late Cecil Smith, editor of Musical America, said in 1951, the New York City Center Opera Companyto give it its original titlehas discovered a huge new audience of operagoers and has became the true Volksoper of New York. The Met had stars, money and social glamour; the City Opera had guts: Unlike the Met the yourtger company never chose its operas in order to flatter Its audience's limitations. Instead, it embarked on a Whole succession of unfamiliar works that did not stand a chance of being done at the house on 39th StreetProkofiev's Flaming Angel and Love for Three Oranges, Richard Strauss's Silent Wife and Capriccio, Ravel's L'Heure Espagnol, Rossini's Cenerentola. The company also gave world premieres of several American operas, among them William Grant Still's Troubled Island, Aaron Tender Land and Jack Beeson's Lizzie Borden. And it performed the standard repertory with disarming gusto, including certain grand operas which, given its limited resources, it really had no business even attempting, like Aida, Turandot and Meistersinger.

title: Cramp ton Shot Ahead At Houston
description: HOUSTON, May 3 (AP)Bruce Crampton of Australia rallied from three strokes off the pace with a 66 today, moved ahead of struggling Lee Trevino and took a oneshot lead in the third round of the $150,000 Houston open golf tournament.

title: Fort Ticonderoga: A Bicentennial Replay
description: T. THE date was May 10, 1775, barely three weeks since the battles at Lexington and Concord. At 3 A.M., a sroup of Green Mountain Boys rowed quietly across Lake Champlain from Vermont. Their leaders: Ethan Allen and Benedict Arnold. Their goal to captuie Fort Ticonaeroga, a strategic fortthen held by a handful of British redcoatsthat controlled the waterway between New York City and Canada. Caught by surprise, the British surtendered without firing a shot. The taking of Fort Ticonderoga marked the first American victory of the Revolution.

title: The Hundred Penny Box
description: When my grandfather was old, he had to be in a nursing home. He had Parkinson's disease, and at the same time, like they say, His mind began to go, the result of arteriosclerosis. This was especially distressing for his wife, my grandmother and his daughters, who saw the man they had known and loved dissolving slowly before their eyes. But I do not think it was altogether distressing for my grandfather, and for us, his grandchildren, there was wonder in the process as well as fear and sadness. The deeper layers of his mind, rich veins of forgotten experience and language (he spoke Yiddish again for the first time in years), were bared as the worldly surface was worn away by the soft rain of old age. The lawyer anxiously preoccupied with business, the prideful perfectionist whose digestion fluctuated with the stock market, was gone; in his place was a man who, in greeting, reached out a trembling hand to take mine looked up into my eyes and said with the difficulty and earnestness of someone trying to express exactly what he meant: Are and dancing?

They did not say why. But the news item reported, deadpan, that teams from Taiwan and Japan have captured seven of the past eight championships. The incident reflects a mood and raises a question about the capacity of Americans to adjust to a world which power is diffused, centers of decision are pluraland, even when our national game laved. Americans do not always win.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Total production of quarters, halfdollars and dollars bearing the 1974 date will almost certainly set records that should stand for generations to come. This became apparent with the release by the Mint of production totals for those three coins for the first two months of this year. During January and February more than 10 million Eisenhower dollars dated 1974 were struck; and in that same period over 37 million halfdollars dated 1974, and more than 216 million 1974dated quarters came off the production line. All of these coins, of course, not only carry last year's date but also the old obverse and reverse deThe story behind this date holdover centers on the Mint's determination to avoid low mintages that would be pounced on by speculators.

title: Fryman Hurls OneHitter,Expos Top Mets, 30

title: Chad Speculates on Possible French Role in Coup
description: NDJAMENA, Chad  French and Chadian sources have reported recently that a number of French soldiers and civilians here knew in advance that the coup d'etat of April 13 was coming but chose not to alert President Ngarta Tombalbaye or to help him oppose it.

title: The Notebooks of David Ignatow
description: The schematic for David Ignatow's progress as a poet can be found in any Horatio Alger novel. With Pluck and Persistence, though not without Pain, he wrenched himself from the industrial world he hated, endured the humiliation of trivial jobs to earn a living, and surmounting domestic afflictions of all sorts, reached that eminence that enables him to have three books published by three different publishers in a little more than a twelvemonth. But The Notebooks of David Ignatow, his working journal and a rude chart of the poet's course, is no song of triumph. It is, instead, one long litany of despair, a bitter jeremiad against the work he is compelled to do, the unrelenting cruelty of his father, the obligations of wife and family and the frustrations of trying to write in an unsympathetic environment. I write of failure, he says, always of failure. Pain is my favorite subject.

title: Garden Club Sale Slated in Teaneck
description: TEANECK  The Garden Club of Teaneck will hold its annual sale of plants and vegetables next weekend. The event, to be held in the parking lot of the Pathmark store, 647 Cedar Lane, features items grown in the club's greenhouse this past winter. Herbs also will be offered.

description: SHORT HILLSHighlighting a fiveday plants anti wares show and sale at Temple B'nai Jeshuruo will be the dedication, at 4:30 P.M, next Saturday, of a Biblical garden on the temple's arouneis.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Saigon radio announced yesterday that North Vietnam had undertaken a widespread reconstruction program in South Vietnam to provide jobs and begin reversing the devastation of 30 years of war. Customary communications channels with Saigon have been cut since Wednesday when the Communists took over the city. The broadcasts, monitored in Bangkok. Thailand, suggested that a wholesale reorganization of South Vietnam was under way. The new regime has begun organizing Revolutionary People's Committees, ostensibly to protect Government property. The radio said that 5,000 people had signed up for duty. All members of the defeated South Vietnamese military forces were ordered to register with th:.: new regime or face punishment. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: What's Doing in PROVENCE
description: SUN AND SMILESProvence is a vast region of south France bisected by the Rhone River as it flows toward the Mediterranean. It is as much a state of mind as a geographical area. There seem to be more sun and smilesin Provence than elsewhere in France. The weather is occasionally wet, but in spring and fall it is delightfully warm, in summer hot and dry, and in winter the climate is often the best that France has to offer. The legendary mistral wind from the north blows frequently, but the natives complain about it snore than visitors, who find the dry air pleasant. The region's poet laureate, whose name was Mistral, called Provence the empire of the sun. It was a Greek colony, then Rome's first province outside. Italy, hence its name. Provence is noted for its physical beauty, for there is little in the sixFrench departments that have been carved out of the region that is not a delight to the eye, apart from a few downtown districts, such as in Aix and Nimes, which the automobile owners of the world have conspired to aestroy.

title: A Slither Of Snakes
description: One way to shed light on the true nature of Class Reptilia is through good books on the subject. And lately they seem to be coming. As the number and variety of reptile books for kids grows, a fillet picture of snakes is starting to emerge. We're beginning to get the message that the way of a serpent on a rock may be unique, complex and worthy of something more than a casual yecch

description: NEW HAVEN, May 3Nathan Hale did not say what most people thought he said. Paul Revere never got to Concord. And George III was probably not crazy.

title: How TV's Feeling Good Went Bad
description: Feeling Good, the educational TV series designed to promote better health that premiered last November over some 200 PBS stations, was the most expensive, most thoroughly researched, and one of the most heavily publicized programs ever to reach noncommercial television. It took years to create but just weeks to be judged a failure and be withdrawn from the air. But that is not the end of the story. Instead of being scrappedthe usual fate of TV flopsFeeling Good was entirely revamped and can now be seen on Channel 13 Wednesdays at 8 P.M.with a repeat Sundays, at 6:30 P.M. If there is a lesson in how and why all this happened, it is that virtuous Intentions and plislunents do not a successful TV show make.

title: SpaceAge Subway: Under San Francisco at 80 M. P.
description: LIKE numbers on a digital clock, large squarecut green figures indicating miles per hour 76, 77, 78flash on an instrument panel that; I can see through the control cab door. When 79 appears, my ears pop. The other passengers seem to be feeling the same sensation; most exchange smiles and put fingers to ears.

title: Art Notes: The In Couple; And a Suspiciously Real Novel
description: A large contingent from Uptown sallied Downtown recently for one of the season's chicest openings  a bask it the Clocktower on Leonard Sreet for a show of works from the collection of Dorothy and Herbert Vogel. Dorothy and Herbert who? Well, not exat:tly plugged into the ScullHeller circuit, the Vogels (Herbert works for the postoffice, Dorothy's a librarian) have only recently surfaced, though they've been demon collectors since their marriage in 1962. They share a onebedroom apartment in the East Eighties with six pedigreed cats, 12 exotic turtles and about 500 works of very contemporary artwalltowall, floortoceiling, here, there.

title: Here Kitty, Kitty
description: People who like cats are constantly being given, or asked for, books about them suitable for children. My own reaction is to change the subject as fast as possible because most of the books are fey, coy, cuddly and sentimental. Of the four new ones I've just looked at, two are quite charming, but really only ostensibly about cats. The other two are relentlessly about cats and quite grim, although possibly in a socially constructive way.

title: For the Schools of 1985, More of the Same?
description: In contemplating what the future holds for our nation's schools, one is forced to make the following sober observation: Despite all the current hopes, slogans and trends, school wont De too much different in 10 years from what they are now. title: Working men and breeding women
description: Don't worry about the title. It would have been better if they had called this book something like Androgyny Requited or Eighty Years of Recapitulation (demonstrably, book titles are hard to invent) instead of choosing an inert lump like Him/HenSelf: Sex Roles in Modern America. But there it is, printed in shiny orange and green on white, wrapped around a really interesting and useful book that is infinitely more lucid and informative than its cover.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The Bolshoi Ballet is back at last. After about nine years absence from New York, it is now in. the middle of a full season at the Metropolitan Opera House. During the years since the company's last visit to America, we have had a large number of concertparty groups, some of them fairly large and most of them adding to their divertissement fare with simple productions of the second act of Swan Lake. the second act of Giselle and Fokine's Les Sylphides. They were fundamentally variety acts with a little ballet blanc thrown in. Sometimes, more daringly, we would be offered something like Alberto Alonso's Carmen Suite or a reconstruction of Fokine's Le Spectre de la Rose. But it was fundamentally Bolshoi dancing rather than the Bolshoi Ballet itself.

title: Vote Ruling May Be Vacated
description: ALBANY, May 3The State Board of Elections said today that it would move next week in State Supreme Court here to vacate a judgment and a $100 fine against Assemblyman Joseph Ferris of Brooklyn for failing to file a campaign financial report. Donald J. McCarthy, counsel to the board, said that Mr. Ferris had not been properly notified of the court proceeding and of his failure to file the campaign report.

title: Shardik
description: A forest at summer's end: Along the groundsoft, bare soil, twigs and fallen branches, decaying leaves black as ashesthere ran a continuous flow of sound scuttlings of rodents, snakes, lizards and now and then the padding of some larger animal on the move. Above, the green dusk of creepers and branches formed another realm, inhabited by monkeys and sloths, by hunting spiders and birds innumerable. Between the trees the air seemed scarcely to move. The heat had thickened it, so that the, winged insects sat torpid on the very leaves beneath which crouched the mantis and spider, too drowsy to strike. Along the foot of a tilted red rock a porcupine came nosing and grubbing.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Mets travel to West Point tomorrow to play the Cadets in an exhibition game and then spend the rest of the week in Shea Stadium. Pittsburgh will be here for games at 8:05 P.M. Tuesday and Wednesday and 2:05 P.M. Thursday, which is another Senior Citizens Day. Cincinnati will play here at 8:05 P.M. Friday and 2:05 P.M. Saturday and Sunday.

description: Beverly Hastings, 30 years old, divorced and the mother of three children, is working for her master's degree although she has no bachelor's degree. But then, some of her fellow master's degree candidates at the College for Human Services never graduated from high school.

Byrne of Greenwich, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Byrne's daughter, Mary Michelle Bergen, to Donnell Middleton Smith Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Stevenson, Md. Miss Bergen, known as Mimi, also is a daughter of John J. Bergen Jr. of St. Thomas, Virgin Islands.

description: There are comparatively few heroes in ballet. There are leading roles, of course, but not many heroesnot what Carlyle or Nietzsche would have called heroes.

description: A Queens Supreme Court jury early yesterday convicted Osborne (Sonny) Boalds of the holdup slaying of Police Officer Timothy M. Hurley outside a bar in Jamaica, Queens, in March. 1974.

description: MONTREAL, May 5Coach Scotty Bowman of the Montreal Canadiens can get excited now. With an 82 victory tonight for their second rout in a row of the Buffalo Sabres, the Canadiens evened their National Hockey League semifinal series at two games apiece and convinced Bowman.

title: TV VIEW
description: When Time Inc is considered the little guy on the block the rest of us can get a bit of perspective on the enormous size of the territory that is usually referred to as audiovisual communications. The field is dominated, of course, by broadcasting and production for television and radio. But it also includes video cassettes, film strips, educational materials and an array of multimedia parapherenalia. At Time Inc., the concerned parties are grouped in TimeLife Films, a wholly owned subsidiary.

title: Film School Opens Doors in Hollywood
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., May 3Seven years after the American Film Institute established its training school for young film makers here, the doors of the school were thrown open and Hollywood wits invited in to have a look around.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  The primary elections are just a month away and, although the end result will not be known until November, the likelihood of quite a few new faces in the 80member State Assembly looms strong. All told, seven incumbentssix Democrats and one Republicanare not seeking another term in the lower house.

title: Medicaid Abuse Is Laid to 3 Clinics Here
description: City Councilman Carter Burden charged yesterday that the director of a methadone center in East Harlem had been diverting patients to another physician for unnecessary and possibly dangerous medical tests so that he and the physician could reap the patient's Medicaid payments.

title: New for the Home
description: The new Flusher Fixer kit is designed to permanently solve the most frequent cause of leaky toiletsthat is, toilets that keep running or leaking due to a worn or defective rubber ball valve (or rubber flapper valve) at the bottom of the tank. Consisting of a flapper  type valve that is made of tough vinyl instead of rubber, this replacement unit also includes a stainless steel new seat which is installed right on top of the old one to correct another common problem  worn or eroded seats that continue to allow water to seep through even after a new rubber ball or flapper valve has been installed. The assembled flapper and metal seat can be easily installed without tools the new metal seat is put on right on top of the old one with a special adhesive that uses water as a catalyst for curing, thus eliminating the need for removing the old seat (which often requires removing the tank from the wall first). The Flusher Fixer kit, including lift chain and adhesive, is priced at $5.49 and is made by Fluidmaster, Inc., 1800 Via Burton, Anaheim, Calif. 92805.

title: Self Sustaining Role Is Urged for State White Elephant
description: PRINCETON  Drumthwacket, considered a masterpiece of 19thcentury architecture when the state purchased it in 1966 for use as a Governor's mansion, lies idle today.

title: Miss Leichtle, Vassar Alumna, To Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Adrian Leichtle of Watertown, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Adrienne d'Albe Leichtle. to John Courtlandt Maxwell Jr. of Richmond. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell of New York.

title: Ideas &Trends Education, Law, History
description: Periodically, claims are made for this Intrepid voyager or that as the first to reach the Americas. Columbus, most authorities on the exploration of the two continents agree, has already lost his title to the Norseman, Lief Erikson.

title: Below the Root
description: This rock is my house. You can have that one. Children don't just stare at nature the way adults do. They use it.

title: Shift Sought On CATV Franchising
description: NEWARKAt a hearing to be held here on Tuesday, officials of the cabletelevision industry will urge the state's Public Utilities Commission to shift from municipalities to the Office of Cable Television the responsibility for granting franchises. The office is a subsidiary agency of the P.U.C.

title: VOTE DIMS HOPE OF ULSTER PACT
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 3An overwhelming election victory for hardline Protestants today dashed hopes of an agreement with Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic minority on the political future of the province.

title: Some Are Real Dogs
description: Children love animals; they particularly love dogs. Recent experiments with young patients who were withdrawn and given dogs as pets showed that the children enjoyed a marked improvement soon after. A dog does not make demands or have unrealistic expectations of its owner. It exists as an affectionate, give and  take, warmblooded creature, it trusts those whom others have already given up as hopeless.

title: ExRep. Albert Vreeland Of New Jersey Dies at 73
description: Albert L. Vreeland, who served two terms in the House of Representatives from New Jersey's 11th Congressional District in the early nineteenforties, died yesterday in Orange (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 132 Norwood Avenue, Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: SERVICES SLASHED IN DOCTOR STRIKE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 Several private hospitals here closed their maternity wards today and others began to lay off 10 per cent of their employes as the strike by physicians to protest the rising cost of malpractice insurance continued with no resolution in sight.

title: PACE U. STUDIES PLAN FOR MERGER
description: Negotiations are under way to merge the College of White Plains, a small liberal arts institution, with Pace University, officials at both colleges said yesterday. The White Plains campus would serve as the site for Pace's new School of Law.

title: How to cook a shark
description: According to Harold W. McCormick and Tom Allen in Shadows in the Sea, their book on sharks, skates and rays, almost all kinds of sharks are good to eat, and the meat of young sharks is best, The authors do not 1 cup ground shark 2 cups potato or cornmeal mush 1/8 teaspoon pepper 1 tablespoon butter 1 egg.

title: Conviction Upheld on Coast For Income Tax Protester
description: LOS ANGELES, May 3A Federal district court judge refused this week to overturn a tax conviction for an income tax protester who alleged he was the victim of discriminatory prosecution.

title: Miss Caesar Sparks Black Gospel Fete; Seven Groups Sing
description: I don't like to sing in & theater, Shirley Caesar shouted yesterday afternoon. I don't like to sing in the dark.

title: Letters: The End in Vietnam
description: To the Editor An armed aggression permitted to succeed, imposing the aggressor's will on his prey, is at least an odious precedent for the future and at most a moral catastrophe. All rational human thought confirms this. Yet, many liberals, after their enormous contributions to the fall of Southeast Asia, are still speaking and writing of lessons to be learned from our Vietnam experience, obviously to instruct and shape America's future conduct when faced with the next Communist aggression.

title: Seton Hall Excels In Quantico Relays
description: QUANTICO, Va., May 3 (AP)Anthony Hall of the Bruce Track Club recorded the longest javelin throw of the year by an American and Seton Hall staged a near runaway in the relay events today on the final day of the 19th annual Marine Corps Relays.

title: Prep Schools Explore Ethics
description: One week last spring the discipline committee of an Eastern boarding school was confronted with two separate cases of student stealing.

title: JAMES W. HUTCH ISON
description: James W. Hutchison, vice president of the Home Insurance Company, died Thursday in St. Anthony's Hospital, Hays. Kan., after a long illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 1750 Cooper Road, Scotch Plains, N. J.

title: Home Clinic
description: In an effort to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions, most of the Home Improvement column this week is again being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of the letters published here pose questions similar to those asked by other readers whose actual letters may not appear, but who, nevertheless, will find their answers printed below. Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department. The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N. Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered here.

title: Talking About the Untalkable
description: Picture this scene: I am about 12 years old and I have just entered the shower in the little cabanatype arrangement we have outside our summer house. My mother is sitting on the bench in the dressing room. Carol, she says to me, I think perhaps it's time we had a little talk about um well, you know mean now you're a woman, and that is. I turn on the shower full blast. What? I say, I can't hear you.

title: U.S. Energy Agency Grants Hardship Relief to Company Operated by Carey's Brother
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Federal Energy Administration, granting an appeal for hardship relief, has authorized the New England Petroleum Company to participate in an industry costsharing program that is expected to give the company roughly SSmillion a month for four months.

title: Judith M. Bergson Has Nuptials
description: Judith M. Bergson, daughter of Abram Bergson, George F. Baker Professor of Economics at Harvard University, and Mrs. Bergson of Belmont, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Michael B. Rosen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Rosen of Riverdale the Bronx.

title: Fed Faces a Congress in the Mood for Reform
description: Events in the months ahead could lead quickly to the first significant changes in the decisionmaking process for monetary policy since the nineteenthirties. This would result from either of two extremesaborted recovery of an early return to skyhigh inflation, either of which might be blamed on the Federal Reserve System. In the first instance, monetary policy would be viewed as too tight; in the second, too easy.

title: Englewood Exhibit Lists 150 Artists
description: ENGLEWOODPictures at an Exhibition, an annual art show and sale sponsored by the National Council of Jewish Women, will be held next Sunday and Monday at the Englewood Jewish Center, 153 Tenafly Road. There will be a gala preview Saturday night for sponsors, patrons and participating artists.

title: Canton Gardens To Be Renovated
description: The City Planning Commission has approved a $10million plan to rehabilitate Carlton Gardens, a 500unit middleincome apartment project at Kissena Boulevard and 73d Avenue in the Kew Gardens Hills section of Queens.

title: POLICE CALLED IN BY ITALIAN CHURCH
description: LAVELLO, ItalyThe people of this farming town in Italy's poor south have been seeing a lot of policemen around lately, but not because of an upsurge in crime. The police were called in as part of an attempt to remove a local priest.

title: Nancy Drew and Friends
description: That attractive strawberry blonde has been driving her blue convertible from clue to clue in the vicinity of River Heights since 1930. River Heights is just down the fictional road from Bayport, where the Hardys live. The area is a sort of all American Shangrila. Fortyfive years have passed. The convertible is still the newest, bluest model, while the boys and the blonde have aged just two years. each. Otherwise Nancy Drew, heroine of 52 Nancy Drew Mystery stories and Frank and Joe of the 54 Hardy Boys Mystery books have hardly changed at all.

title: Maple Syrup on the Wane
description: The producer of Aunt Jemima pancake syrup hasn't bought a single drop of pure maple syrup this year because maple syrup costs $12 a gallon, and Americans have come to likeeven preferthe taste and consistency of imitation syrup.

title: Susan Post Gellatly Is Married To Joseph Gibson Robinson Jr.
description: Susan Post Gellady, daughter of Mrs. George Marshall Heiner and the late John Hansen Gellatly, was married yesterday to Joseph Gibson Robinson Jr., son of Mrs. Robinson and the late Mr. Robinson. Both families are of Pittsburgh, where the wedding took place.

title: Letters
description: In Russia during the nineteenthirties, posters depicted capitalists as Frankensteinian creatures with sallow faces capped with a top hat. I was reminded of this by Robert Wool's article about me (Capitalist squash, April 13).

title: Wrong Horse Called in Lead
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3Driving to victory aboard Foolish Pleasure near the finish of today's 101st Kentucky Derby, Jacinto Vasquez heard what everybody else at Churchill Downs and in a national television audience heard: That's Prince Thou Art taking the lead by a length.

title: 374 Refugees Are Flying On 747 to Florida Base
description: EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., May 3 (UPI)  Fleeing Vietnamese refugees aboard a jetliner headed today for a tent city in the Florida Panhandle.

title: Editors Choice
description: CRUCIAL CONVERSATIONS, by May Sarton. (Norton, $5.95.) At 50, Poppy Whitelaw packs it in with her marriage and successfully businessman husband in a flawed but morally probing and socially aware novel.

title: The Rival Enclave of Schwindelheim
description: MORE and more American tourists are discovering the Royal Enclave of Schwindelheim, a nation set like a solitaire in the diadem of the GermanAustrian Alps. And no wonder! In addition to the breathtaking scenery and Old World charm typical of many European countries. Schwindelheim boasts such unusual tourist attractions as Otto Furbalow, the tallest automobile mechanic in at least a 500mile radius; Wissennichts Valley, breeding ground of the Schwindelheim shoat; and the oldest chainlink fence in Europe.

title: One Gardener's Approach to Appealing Design
description: A garden needs to be planned for the family to use and enjoy and its shape and design should be what appeals, not just what the landscape plan dictates.

title: Strong Country Bill Sung at Felt Forum By Merle Haggard
description: Merle Haggard is as big a name as country music can boast, but when he first performed in Manhattan 13 months ago, he looked nervous. Something about his image as the poet of the common man and his authorship of Okie from Muskogee must have made him wonder how he'd be received in liberal New York.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: At the final press conference before his retirement as chairman and chief executive officer of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in 1965, Monroe Jackson Rathbone said that the major problem for the petroleum industry in the future would be its relationship with government.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran. May 3 (UPI) Gen. Mustafa Barzani, the former leader of Kurdish rebels, said in an interview published today that the Kurds battle for autonomy in northern Iraq is futile and will never be resumed.

description: PRINCETONThis town is about to be invaded by a Pilobolus again.

title: The Adirondack Train Schedule Will Be Speeded Up on June 29
description: Fifteen minutes more will be cut from the running time of The Adirondack, an Amtrak train, in the AlbanySaratogaChamplain corridor between New York and Montreal, effective June 29. Last week a 20minute cut went into effect.

title: Epilogue
description: Smokey the Bear, the nation's most vigilant forest fire fighter, has been retired. 25year career with the Forest Service came to an end last week during ceremonies at Washington's National Zoo marking the debut of the new Smokey, a 6yearold black bear, who has been understudying the job since 1971. Smokey the Bear has lived in the zoo since 1950 when lie was brought there as a badly burned, orphaned cub after being rescued in a forest fire. After his recovery, Smokey became the living symbol in the Forest Service's campaign against carelessness in forest areas. Crippled with arthritis, Smokey was considered too old and grouchy to continue in his job. Plans are being made to move Smokey and his shebear companion, Goldie, to a retirement home in New Mexico.

title: Mrs. King Gives Sets Big Punch in Her Debut
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., May 3For someone who has been talking about reducing her tennisplaying activity, Billie Jean King was one busy racauetwielder this weekend.

title: State Treasurer and 3 Bankers Are Indicted in West Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 3A Federal grand jury has returned eight indictments here charging the West Virginia State Treasurer, his former assistant and three Huntington bankers with extortion, fraud, bribery and misapplication of bank funds.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The image of the Philadelphia Flyers is more notorious than glorious. When they appear on the ice, it melts. They wear shoulder holsters instead of shoulder pads, brass knuckles instead of gloves. They carry axes instead of sticks. The blades of their skates are really switch blades. But among the Broad Street Bullies is a babyfaced.

title: End of the Manual Line
description: More portable typewriters than office machines are sold in the United States each year, but the prices are lower [from $60 to $300 compared with $300 to $1,000], the profits are smaller and the market is shrinking.

title: Governing is harder than conquering
description: TEL AVIV. Premier Yitzhak Rabin settled wearily into his chair and lit another cigarette from stub smoked down to his fingertips. He spoke sadly, slowly, in a low, grinding voice. A citrusscented breeze wandered into the booklined study of his Tel Aviv penthouse apartment, but in the brilliant light of the Mediterranean morning his eyes were squinty, tired, tense.

title: Tigers Bow To Red Sox In 122 Rout
description: BOSTON, May 3 (AP)The Boston Red Sox sent 11 batters to the plate in the first inning today, scored six runs on just four hits and defeated the Detroit Tigers, 122.

title: The Nation. In Summary
description: The latest unemployment figures can be read as bearing out the forecasts of the Ford Administration and other analysts that the recession is now nearing bottom. Though unemployment continues to increase and prices are still rising, they are doing so at considerably slower rates than before.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the announcement of the engagement of Carol Iskols to Richard A. Daynard in The New York Times last Sunday. Mr. Daynard's name was incorrectly given as Draynard.

title: Caso Scores Pact With County Union
description: MINEOLANassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso said last week that the county was faced with $20million deficit in 1975 and said that it was unbelievable that the Board of Supervisors had granted the county's 12,800 municipal employes salary raises as high as 6.5 per cent.

title: New Knowledge of Learning Poses New Problems
description: A cartoon that appeared recently in an educational journal shows a young boy standing before a school librarian and declaring, I'd better play it safe and take one of eachbright, normal and slow learner.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: Critics charge that the tests are racially and culturally biased The tests are culturally biased to the extent that reading ability is culturally linked.

title: Henry Kissinger's Reflections on His Dunkirk
description: WASHINGTON. May 3 Henry Kissinger looks these days like a man who just got off the boat from Dunkirk: a little beatup and defensive, but tough. He expected, and is getting, the backwash from the Indochina retreat, but he is not going to resign, and he believes his major problems are manageable.

title: Ithaca Wins 5 Races and O'Hare Cup
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 3Ithaca College swept the varsity, junior varsity and freshman eightoared events and then added victories in the varsity lightweight eight and heavyweight four in the 12th annual Metropolitan intercollegiate rowing championships on the Orchard Beach Lagoon today.

title: Goldwater Hospital Is Life KEEP IT ALIVE
description: Edith and Kevin are patient residents at Goldwater Memorial Hospital. They are cared for in the hospital's Respirator Unitthe only one of its kind between Boston and Baltimore.

title: Manhattan Runners Sparkle to No Avail
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 3Tony Colon won the halfmile and mile runs and two other Manhattan runners set meet sprint records today, but Army's depth in the field events helped the Cadets defeat the Jaspers, 96.67, at Shea Stadium.

title: NEIL SEDAKA SINGS UPDATED MESSAGES
description: Anyone expecting Neil Sedaka to turn his appearance at the Bottom Line on Friday into a parade of golden oldies (after all the man did write Stupid Cupid for Connie Francis back in rock's prehistory) was in for a surprise. True, Mr. Sedaka, on piano, Gat shysuited, with a cohesive backing group and enormous confidence still, did package his puberty rock hitsOh Carol, Happy Birthday, Sweet Sixteen, Calendar Girl, etcinto a brash medley, but the rest of his perfornance was very much Sedaka, 1975.

title: The Met's Big Islamic Plans
description: A striking example of local Interest in Middle Eastern art was turned up last week by a routine call to Thomas Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, to learn what, if anything, the Met was planning in this area. In the third week of September, Hoving told this amazed interviewer, we are opening 18 permanent galleries devoted to our Islamic collection. It's part of our master plan to have a museum of Islamic art within the Metropolitan. The galleries will be chronological, starting off with the very early archeological material  preIslamic, obviously but including those things from the countries of the Middle East that will eventually relate to the styles that are pertinent to Islam.

title: TV Notes: The Coming Battle of Video Disks
description: The idea of a phonograph record that reproduces audio and pictures through a television set may sound wildly futuristic, but the technology for the video disk is already here, and the item will be on the consumer market in the fall of 1976. Put a record on the video turntable, adjust the stylus or laser beam and out comes a movie, a musical performance or a tennis lesson, as you may choose. Without commercials.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Article 11  No Title

title: ON YOU AND YOUR LIFE:
description: Because you are not going to get out of this world alive; doesn't it make sense to learn how to live in it as long as you can?. Never forget Men's lives are chains of chances but as Euripides saw clearly so long ago: Chance fights ever on the side of the prudent. Your only insurance against tomorrow is what you do today! To put it bluntly, the mistakes you make in your younger years are drafts upon your older years, payable with Interest, some 30 years rater. The socalled diseases of old age are essentially the diseases of 50 to 70; the dangerous years. Medical research no'w indicates that men who survive these dangerous years without acquiring a chronic disease (such as heart trouble or cancer) are likely to live on another healthy quarter of century.

title: Carrier Enters Subic Bay With 2,000 From Vietnam
description: SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, Sunday, May 4The United States carrier Hancock sailed yesterday into the home port of the Seventh Fleet here carrying 2,000 American and Vietnamese evacuees out of Saigon.

title: The TeenAge Worker Is Hardest Hit
description: A decade after the ghetto ripts in America's major odes, a flood tide of teenago unemployment  predominantly among black youthis stirring apprehension about the prospect of another long, hot summer.

title: Food
description: Although duck  gastronomically is seldom thought of as America's national bird, it is without question one of the 10 or 12 most popular dishes on French menus in this country, and deservedly so. Duck is a winged creature of many virtues, not the least of which is the richness of its flesh. While duck a l'orange is by far the bestknown duck preparation in the French repertoire, there are scores moreincluding the two dishes outlined here. are cool enough to handle, carve them as follows: Carve away and separate the legs and thighs. Carve on eithet side of the breast bone, carving the breast halves in whole pieces and leaving the main wing bone attached Cut off and reserve the second joint and wing tip from the wing bone Trim off and discard any excess fat but leave the skin intact.

title: TEXAS IS REVISING ITS INSANITY LAWS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 3Texas lawmakers are moving to plug a hole in the state's criminal insanity laws that was created last year when a Federal court ruled against irate prosecutors and freed nearly 200 persons accused of crimes who were confined in mental hospitals.

title: CLAIR HALLIGAN, 72, DEW LINE ENGINEER,
description: Clair William Halligan, a retired electrical engineer, who helped develop the DEW (Disant Early Warning) Line and FAGE (SemiAutomatic Ground Environment), also a defense system, died Friday in Massahusetts General Hospital, Boston. He was 72 years old and lived in Wayland, Mass.

title: SYRIA AND IRAQ HALT RIVER DISPUTE TALKS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 3Talks between Iraq and Syria in a conflict on sharing of the waters of the Euphrates River, under way for the last three days at Jidda, Saudi Arabia, broke up today without an agreement.

title: Helicopter Tour: Up Above Manhattan at $1.60 a Minute
description: WE stood on the porch of the trailer and waited for our pilot. In front of us a little red helicopter sat alone on the long, narrow concrete pad beside the East River. Suddenly an unmistakable sound made us look up. Quite low over our narrow heads, what looked like a bit of red plastic came fluttering down, producing the most incredible amount of noise and wind. We stood buffeted and somewhat astonished as it eased itself onto the pad 100 feet to the left of its twin.

title: Reading: The Search For Individual Needs
description: Eddie Dorn, a 9yearold fourthgrader, had a good vocabulary and had demonstrated proficiency in various skills, such as reading compound words, but diagnostic testing showed that he was still having trouble drawing conclusions from what he read.

title: Jane Howard, Roger Cheever Plan to Marry
description: Jane Howard, a paralegal with the Boston law firm of Herrick, Smith, Donald, Farley & Ketchum, and Roger P. Cheever of Cambridge, Mass.. executive director of the Massachusetts Horticultural Society, plan to be married Aug. 30 in the Congregational Church in Little Compton, R. I.

title: Math: Integrating The New and the Old
description: The new math swept into American classrooms in the reformminded days of the New Frontier. Now, amid a wave of conservatism, academic critics of the new math charge that the sum of parts does not add up to the total of its earlier promise.

title: Trenton State College Turns to the Education of Its Employes
description: TRENTON  Interest in lifetime education has been growing rapidly. says Harry Van Houten, director of the Adult Education Resource Center at Trenton State College. Our center's primary role has been the training of adulteducation instructors, but we also have monitored and evaluated local adulteducation programs in Central Jersey and assessed the further needs of the communities.

title: Monserrat Assails Supervisors in Heated Exchange Over Leadership and Reform in the School System
description: DOWNINGTOWN, Pa., May 3 A member of the Board of Education excoriated New York City school supervisors at their convention today for failing to provide leadership and for impeding educational reforms.

title: Women's Legal Rights
description: Shana Alexander, looked to by many readers for sensible opinions sensitively expressed, has lent her name to a regrettable project. Women's Legal Rights is padded as outrageously as a Victorian stuffed chair: more than half its pages are devoted to repetitive, spacehungry, statebystate listings of legal information which for the most part are excess baggage.

title: The Truman Doctrine Fades
description: ANKARAI have been coming to Turkey for 36 years and never before found American governmental relations with this stubborn country at lower ebb. The Turks are a courteous people and officials and friends are always personally polite and hospitable. But the glow has worn off from the era of the Truman Doctrine, Turkish military participation in the Korean war, and Ankara's enthusiastic embrace of NATO.

title: 1,424 More Win Merit Scholarships
description: A total of 1,424 high school seniors from across the country were named winners of fouryear renewable scholarships under the Merit Scholarship program, the Merit Scholarship Corporation in Evanston, Ill., announced yesterday.

title: City Refining School Norms
description: Is it reasonable to expect that at virtually every youngstar. who completes secondgrade, regardless of his or her ability, should be able to read such words as baby, men and book, count to 100, and add 43 and 15?

title: The Wizard In the Tree
description: Lloyd Alexander is the magician of the children's book world. Winner of the Newbery Medal and a National Book Award, he has spun tales rich in adventure and fantasystories that might be ordinary save for the imagination he brings to them. His plotting is excellent, his characters interesting, his language vivid, and it is risky to criticize him for not being other than he is. Nevertheless, his latest book has rather palled on me.

title: MigrantCamp Ruling Praised
description: TRENTONAdvocates of reforms for the state's hundreds of migrant farm workers are hailing a new legal ruling that guarantees visitation rights at the camps inhabited by such itinerants.

title: The Soviets Will Be Careful in Capitalizing on U.S. Failures
description: MOSCOWDetente or not, you can't expect the Russians not to try to pick up the marbles, observed an American diplomat recently. He alluded to the diplomatic opportunities presented by Amen can setbacks from Indochina to the Middle East.

title: CAMBODIANS HOED 250 MORE ALIENS
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, May 3The more than 500 men, women and children who arrived at this town on the Cambodian border this morning refused to describe their trip or their experiences in the French Embassy compound in Phnom Penh, where they took refuge two weeks ago when the Communistled insurgents took over the city.

title: Army Women Now Serve In Many OnceMale Jobs
description: FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., May 2Women are joining the United States Army in record peacetime numbers, integrating hundreds of previously maleonly soldiering jobs from fixing tanks to flying helicopters, and moving closer to an assault on the Army's last bastion of male exclusivitythe combat arms.

title: Steel Steamboat Is Christened for Luxury Cruising on Inland Rivers
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3Amid the hoopla and carefully orchestrated anarchy here during Derby Week, the christening of the Mississippi Queen steamboat Wednesday was thoroughly overshadowed locally by the human celebrities an dthe various balloon, cycle, auto, steamboat and horse races.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: WESTBURY, L.I.

title: Loyalists Are Few in Number At 28th Loyalty Day Parade
description: With 10 marching bands on the ground and sunny skies above, veterans, scouts and military units paraded down Fifth Avenue yesterday in the 28th annual Loyalty Day Parade.

title: Easing of Buggy Fishing Is Urged
description: SEASIDE PARKIn a continuing battle over fishermen's access to Island Beach State Park, the New Jersey BeachBuggy Association has asked the state's Department of Environmental Protection to again allow holders of buggy permits to fish along the Atlantic beachfront between midnight and 4 A.M. during the summer.

title: U.S. Official Warns on Easing Hatch Act Curbs on Politics
description: Politicians, union leaders and Government employes joined here yesterday in a second day of hearings before a Congressional committee to support a bill that would ease the restrictions of Hatch Act, which limits the political activity of three million Federal employes.

title: Letters: A Modern Miracle in the Desert?
description: To the Editor In the regions adjoining the Suez Canal many miraculous events are purported to have taken place, but none can surpass the phenomenon of sighting Mount Ararat from that waterway as described in the Notes Column (Travel Section, April 20). Mount Ararat, which is in eastern Turkey, rises to 16,946 feet, but it is some 870 miles from the nearest point on the canal. A simple trigonometric exercise reveals that at that distance any surface feature less than about 500,000 feet high would lie below the horizon. The writer probably had in mind the impressive emergence of Mount Sinai in the Sinai peninsula as one approaches or departs from the canal through the Gulf of Suez. Perhaps the local legend that Mount Sinai, rather than Mount Ararat, was the true landing site of Noah's Ark contributed to the cofusion.

title: A Shannon River Log Undampened Gaiety
description: LAST summer, on my first visit to Ireland, the land of my fathers, spent seven days cruising on the River Shannon. It flows 210 miles (140 of them navigable), and for its entire ??? it runs through countryside ??? ??? by commercial traffic or pollution. In our rented cabin cruiser, my wife, Pat, and I and a writer friend James Farrell, traveled about 110 miles up and down the river. Together we shared a memorable week of majestic views and sound opinions.

description: TodayTrenton K.C. allbreed and obedience, Washington Crossing State Park, Bear Tavern Road, Route 579. Washington Crossing, N. J. 3,654 dogs; 8 A.M.

description: MADISON, Wis., May 3 (AP) Wisconsin prison inmates are making legal contracts with the state that can mean rehabilitation, training and an early release.

title: An Epochal Approach to Liberal Arts
description: At the end of a recent school week, 18yearold Deborah Andrews felt more like the Egyptian queen Nefertiti than like a college freshman.

title: Some Say He Has a Political Future
description: WASHINGTONJohn B. Connally is a survivor. The rifle shots fired from the Texas School Book Depository in Dallas killed President Kennedy, but left Governor Connally wounded. The antiwar movement forced President Johnson into premature retirement, but left his protg, John Connally, unscathed. The Watergate scandals exiled President Nixon, but a Federal court jury has acquitted Mr. Connally of bribery charges spawned by that scandal.

title: Tenant Role Is the Key, Says Group In Clinton
description: Gloria Walker Milliken and her eight colleagues are among the very few people involved in Clinton's housing who are convinced that the area's 19thcentury tenements can and should be saved.

title: Capitalizing on Poor Writing
description: George Washington has contributed much; in making of American History. A general in the army during American Revolution. He commened many victory; that lead the 13 colonies to a indepenent United States. His picture is shown on the one dollar Bill and twenty five cent picence (quart). Making his home in Virginia with his wife Martha.

title: Patrolman Is Set for a 65Mile Charity Run
description: NEWARKPeople who say that they never see a foot patrolman anymore should be on the lookout tomorrow for Harry Romeo.

title: ORAL ROBERTS U. TO TRAIN DOCTORS
description: TULSA, Okla. May 3 (UPI)Oral Roberts University, founded by the evangelist who got his start as a faith healer, announced plans this week to build a $60million medical school.

title: Susan Ruppert Sets December Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Farrell Ruppert of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ruppert, to Lieut. John Winthrop Sergeant, U.S.M.C., a graduate of the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md.

title: Redman, Racing's Antihero, Man to Beat at Pocono Today
description: LONG POND, Pa., May 3A few minutes before he was going to take his new racing car, Which he had never driven, over a course he'd never driven, Brian Redman said, I'm going to avoid heroics.

title: Suit Planned To End Split In Sessions In S. Amboy
description: SOUTH AMBOY  Residents of this Middlesex County town are awaiting a decision by the state's Commissioner of Education that could end nearly 14 years of split sessions in the public schools.

title: Search for a Song Ends in a Dirge
description: LOS ANGELES, May 3After a 10year search, Los Angeles his abandoned its quest for a city song to rival I Left My Heart in San Francisco.

title: PEKING REACTION IS WORRYING INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, May 3For the first time in years. India has denounced China and expressed worry that Peking is seeking to disturb the stability of Southern Asia.

title: Samuel Graff Weds Sarah K. Lane
description: Sarah Kerney Lane a copy editor With The Trenton Times Newspapers, and Samuel Saul Graff, an editor with the New Jersey edition of The Daily News, were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Stephen Lane of Harbourton, N. J. Judge Richard J. S. Barlow of the Mercer County Court performed the ceremony.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: There has been talk lately that business, in reacting to the economic crunch, may abandon or at least sidetrack programs dealing with important social issues. If this is true it could be the worst mistake American business has ever made.

title: Catherine Magruder to Wed in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hull Magruder of Fairfield, Conn.. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Godard Magruder. to Peter Hugh Armour, son of Mrs. Arthur Edward Larkin Jr. of Oak Brook, Ill., and Donald Cochran Armour of Santa Barbara, Calif. A wedding in July is planned.

title: L.I. Resisting Jobless Spiral But Is Still Losing Ground
description: At the start of spring, when unemployment should have been declining, close to 10,000 residents of Nassau and Suffolk Counties lost their jobs on Long Island and elsewhere in the New York metropolitan area, bringing the total number of unemployed Long Island residents to more than 77.000.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: One of the secrets of making a successful movie of a vacation trip is doing some research and planning ahead of time. Since few people make a complete documentary of their entire trip, the idea is to select for filming the scenes, objects or people that will most interest the photographer and future viewers of the film so that nothing important will be missed. By reading about the.

description: GAINESROTH. Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Roth announce the engagement of their daughter Sherry to Mr. Jay Gaines, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Gaines. A summer wedding Is planned.

description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 3 (Reuters)Communist guerrillas killed 10 Government officials and border patrol policemen in a clash near the Burmese border yesterday, military spokesman said today.

Children, I said, may God and the poets save you from common sense. Go and ask the librarian for X. J. Kennedy's One Winter Night in August, a lively collection of nonsense jingles. You will see at once he's a man to be trusted, a really firstrate liar:

title: Church Council Bids Taipei Return Confiscated Bibles
description: GENEVA, May 4 (Reuters)The World Council of Churches has appealed to the Nationalist Chinese Government on Taiwan to return more than 2,000 Bibles confiscated by the Army in Taipei in January.

title: Few Appear at Kent State As 2Day Memorial Begins
description: KENT, Ohio, May 3 (UPI)Antiwar speakers competed with the noise of tennis and baseball games at Kent State University today at the start of a twoday memorial observance of the fatal shooting five years ago of four student peace demonstrators by Ohio National Guardsmen.

title: Television This Week
description: 11:00 A.M. (2) CAMERA THREE. Zen and 1, SelfPortrait of the Great Turtle Priest. A day in the life of Tachibana Talk', a highranking Zen priest in Kyoto, Japan.

title: 3, Including ExInmate, Seized in Prison Theft
description: Three young men were arrested Friday after the safe at the Niantic, Conn., Correctional Institution's office was broken into and money belonging to inmates was stolen. A guard and a telephone operator were bound and gagged.

title: Jacob TwoTwo Meets The Hooded Fang
description: Mordecai Richler is a funny man, a good writer, and everyone should go out tomorrow morning and beat his local bookseller into submission if he hasn't got a nice plump display of books titled Jacob TwoTwo Meets the Hooded Fang. It is suitable reading for book reviewers in their late thirties and also young children and their grandmothers. I haven't the vaguest idea who it's written for and don't care. It is a tallish tale about a smallish boy and tells the truth about life's pecking order and how it feels to be right down there at the bottom, age 6.

title: Worst Speed Trap In Nation Disbands Police Department
description: FRUlTHURST, Ala., May 3This town of 250 on the AlabamaGeorgia line which the, state's Attorney General, William J. Baxley, called the worst speed trap in the nation has eliminated its police department.

title: The Last of the National Book Awards?
description: Parlous, that's the state of the National Book Awards, parlous. And it's all a matter of money. To recap: the National Book Committee, overseer of the N.B.A., was disbanded last year when the book publishers pulled out their backing. Man on white charger, Roger L. Stevens, thought the awards should continue and so organized a temporary Committee on Awards Policy, which kept the prizes and ceremony going for this year while he searched around for a permanent backer. At the beginning of N.B.A. week he indicated a couple of times that he would have an announcement to make at the culminating ceremony about said backer, but, alas, on the big night all he could say was that he couldn't say, because at that very moment a very prestigious organization was discussing the possibility of backing the N.B.A. with the publishers. Who could this be? Somebody said American Library Association. Somebody said no. Exxon? Uh, uh. Who else has money? Not the publishersnot money that they'll let loose, anyway. Jackie Kennedy? Doubtful. Huntington Hartford? Please, no! Whoever decides to back it will get a bargain for a mere $60,000, which is the outlay for administration, prizes, judges fees, transportation, etc. The $20 reception tickets for the reception.

title: Two Elderly People Found Slain in Apartments in Manhattan and in the Bronx
description: The 77yearold superintendent of a building on a seedy strip of Eighth Avenue was found dead in his apartment yesterday, tied up in bed, his head buried in his pillow.

title: BILL ON RETARDED IS FACING A VETO
description: ALBANY, May 3Governor Carey is expected next week to velo a bill, passed overwhelmingly by both houses of Legislature, that would set up a sepatate state office for the mentally retarded outside the Department of Mental Hygiene.

description: WASHINGTON, May 3 A broad spectrum of American scientists specializing in agriculture and nutrition have found ground for optimism on the world's capacity to meet its food needs until rapid population growth can be brought under control.

description: PROVIDENCE, R. L, May (AP)Raymond L.S. Patriarca, angered at being termed a reputed New England crime boss, has asked court action to stop Federal officers from making unsubstantiated allegations about his character.

description: The Federation Equestre Internationale has approved Bromont, Quebec, as the site of all equestrian eventswith the exception of team jumpingat the 1976 Olympic Games.

description: DENVER, May 3 (AP) George McGinnis tossed in 40 points, leading the Indiana Pacers to a 10496 victory over the Denver Nuggets tonight in the seventh and deciding game of their American Basketball Association Western Division playoff series.

title: Drew Botanists Find Pipelines Are a Boon to Wildlife
description: MADISON  A fiveyear experiment that Drew University botanists conducted for the Texas Eastern Transmission Company has found that pipeline and electricline construction offers an opportunity for nurturing more wildlife than did the original terrain.
