description: TodaySports Car Club of AmericaUnited States Auto Club races at Pocono International Raceway, Long Pond, Pa. Heats start at noon; TransAmerica race at 2 P.M.; Formula 5000 race at 3:30 P.M.

title: LATINS DENY REPORT OF PAYOFF BY GULF
description: Government officials in Ecuador and Venezuela have denied that the Gulf Oil Corporation was required to pay $4million to operate in their countries, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Rewards Are Few For a Prefontaine
description: To the Sports Editor Upon reading the letter of James E. Foley (Mailbox, April 13) regarding Steve Prefontaine, I can't help but come away with the impression that Mr. Foley has a severely impaired perception of amateur athletics, particularly longdistance running, and how amateur athletics in the United States contrasts with worldwide amateurism.

title: Some Critics Miss the Point About Open Education
description: Despite all the debate that has been set off in less than eight years by open education, critics and friends agree that its impact has been significant. But the battlefield on the most controversial approach to learning since the days of John Dewey and progressivism is strewn with misconceptions.

title: School Pioneer Is Retiring
description: MAPLE WOODA pioneer of adult education in New Jersey will retire on July 1.

title: Bank Rates On Loans Face New Senate Test
description: TRENTONState Senator Matthew Feldman will make another attempt this week to obtain the approval of a bill that would allow interest rates on bank loans to climb as high as 15 per cent.

title: All Kinds Attracted To Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3The Kentucky Derby turned into its second century today with 70,000 mint juleps and 113,324 persons at Churchill Downs. But there were still 50,304 fewer persons, eight fewer horses and one less royal Princess than were at the centennial running of America's most historic horse race. a year ago.

title: The North American Soccer League
description: Northern Division

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: It has been a stubbornly late spring, but suddenly the season of alfresco pleasure is upon us. And so is the urge to stroll, to find outdoor cafes, to reacquaint oneself with the street life of New York. It is time for the passaggiata, the cappuccino and a bit of dolce far niente. And the vernal expedition to Little Italy.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: American League attendance for the first month of the 1975 season is up 10 per cent over last year's, the league has announced. After 100 playing dates in 1975, American League games had drawn a paying attendance of 1,344,107, an increase of 117,577 over last year. Six teams showed increases of 20 per cent or more. Cleveland, with its playermanager, Frank Robinson, as a prime attraction, led the way with an increase of 266 per cent. The New York Yankees were up 54 per cent.

title: Seawall Built to Cut Raritan Bay Erosion
description: MATAWAN TOWNSHIPA $3million project to prevent further erosion of the 50foothigh cliffs overlooking Raritan Bay and to preserve one of the finest fossiled clay preserves in the United States is under way in the Cliffwood Beach section of Matawan Township.

title: Nancy Wilson Sets Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Galt Piper of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Piper's daughter, Nancy Wilson, to George Pomeroy Bassett 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bassett 3d of New Berlin, N. Y. A wedding in July is planned.

title: New & Novel
description: The nicest thing you can say about the Rev. John Lenox is that he is a secret horseplayer. When the mood seizes him, which is often, the young clergyman swaps his clerical collar for a purple turtleneck, and slouches into a Boylston Street cafeteria to place his bets. So much for nice qualities. For the rest of it, Lenox is as nasty a job of work as you'lltind in any crime novel. With very little hesitation, the cleric bludgeons three victims, one to further his aspirations, and two to conceal them. A suicide, a triple murder by one of the hero's parishioners and one final corpse bring the mortality rate to the epiclemic level.

title: Derby Learns ABC's In TV Networks Shift
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3In the covered countryfair paddock at old Churchill Downs, the two California candidates waited serenely, apparently unaware that Howard Cosell was about to replace Stephen Collins Foster as the Muse of My Old Kentucky Home.

title: Of Things To Come
description: For many years science fiction, like science, was pretty much a man's game. Once in a while a woman would be accepted as an equal, or at least nearequal, on the basis of sheer talent. Just as science had its occasional Madame Curies, science fiction had its Leigh Bracketts and C. L Mooresand its Mary Shelley, whose Frankenstein has been called the first real novel of science fiction. But the great mass of S.F. has been written by males and for males; and the role of women in most S.F. stories has been limited to decoration, breeding and a dash of what oldtime pulp editors referred to as human interest.

title: THE COLLEGE BOARDS
description: (A) Still cause fear and trembling among highschool students. (B) Cannot accurately test innate ability. (C) Reliably predict college performance for the most part. (D) All of the above.

title: Kristey Gunnell Wed to Lee Peck
description: Kristey Ann Gunnell and Lee Wallace Peck were married yesterday afternoon in the home of the bridegroom's father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Knowlton Peck of Cedarhurst. L. I.

title: The Crows Of War
description: The Roman invasion of Britain in 43 A.D. is the background of Steven Rayson's The Crows of War. And in a busy narrative filled with skirmishes, ambuscades and a bloody fullscale battle at the Ircn Age hill fort of Maidun (Maiden Castle in Dorset), we are shown the Romans and their army in action and also the life and customs of the ??? of the West Country in peace and war, especially those of the Somerset lake villages around Meare and Glastonbury.

title: A Tender and Heroic Spartacus
description: When people think of the Bolshoi Ballet, they think of leaping male athleticism. And when they think of those prodigal jumps, they think of the ballet called Spartacus. And when they think of Spartacus, whether they know it or not, they are probably thinking of Vladimir Vasiliev.

title: Companies Press for Rte. 178
description: PARSIPPANY  Representatives of seven large corporations in Morris County have organized to let the state's Department of Transportation know that they think the county is being mistreated when it comes to highway funds.

title: Emmet F. Gordon Is Dead at 62; Headed a Unit of Phelps Dodge
description: Emmet F. Gordon, president of the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Company, one of seven operating units of Phelps Dodge Industries, Inc., died IThursday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 400 East 56th Street and in Plandome, L.I.

title: Judith Stone Is Betrothed
description: Judith Stone, whose engagement to Aaron Appelstein has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Stone of Teaneck, N.J., plans to be married May 18. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mr. Henry Appelstein of Laurelton, Queens.

title: A Drag Revisits The Point
description: I USED to weekend at West Point as the drag of a cadet. I meandered on Flirtation Walk, sang Brave Old Army Team at football games, watched parades and danced at hops in Cuilum Hall. Hops were always formal thenreceiving line, long gowns, white gloves, ballroom dancing. Cadets wore swallowtailed coats with three rows of large round brass buttons down the front. After the hop ended With the traditional strains of Army Blue, fnany a drag fell into bed at the Hotel Thayer feeling buttonbattered. The only article of clothing a cadet is now, and was then, allowed to lend civilian is his long gray raincoat with hiplength cape. For a long time I proudly traipsed about New York in a cadet raincoat, never dreaming that years later, girls wearing military handmedowns would wander the city by the hundredsand would be called hippies.

description: Those who rely on old sayings are often puzzled by the fact that they seem to come in pairs with diametrically opposite meanings. Such a pair with applications for bridge is: Look before you leap and He who hesitates is lost.

description: MINEOLAThe Board of Supervisors was asked last week to show cause in State Supreme Court on Wednesday why it should not be required to make up a legislative district composed of five contiguous areas of the county that have substantial black and Spanishspeaking populations.

description: Participation in school elections is often cited as one way that citizens can influence the quality of their children's education. By this standard, New York City residents differ considerably from their suburban neighbors.

title: Contest At Cowlick
description: Hogbone and his gang rode into the little town of Cowlick one dusty afternoon when the sheriff and his men had gone fishing. Not bad for openers Sets the tone and sets the tale. Cowlick could be in for trouble. For sure the bank is in for trouble. Hogbone means to rob it. You're already smiling at the prospect because you've seen the swirling illustration across the title page. It is a threecolor cloud of dust churning up 16 hardriding desperadoes, Hogbone out in front. And you know that no desperado with a mug like that could possibly rob a bankeven an undefended one  without messing things up.

title: Urban Analyst to Replace Clark at Research Center
description: Dr. Charles V. Hamilton, a leading analyst of urban politics, has been appointed to succeed Dr. Kenneth B. Clark as president of the Metropolitan Applied Research Center.

title: LightSaving Bonus
description: The State Public Service Commission has made a small but consequential start toward rationalizing Consolidated Edison's rate structure. If the commission carries the thrust of its initial order through the whole massive complex, the utility which supplies New York City and Westchester County with electric power will for the first time have a schedule of rates that encourages customers to save current, not waste it.

title: Roaches Said to Intensify Cases of Bronchial Asthma
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May (UPI) Researchers from Chicago's Mount Sinai Hospital Medical Center say cockroaches can intensify bronchial asthma Two researchers from the center's Department of Medicine told a symposium of the American Federation of Clinical Research here yesterday that 12 of 16 asthmatic subjects showed positive reaction when cockroach antigen mixed with common inhalant antigen was administered.

title: Books of The Times
description: I guess I should have known better. was expecting to be only modestly entertained by Fast Company, a profile of six successful gamblers by an English journalist named Jon Bradshaw. I was expecting to be amused by a steady stream of anecdotes Iike the one with which Mr. Bradshaw begins his first chaptes, about the poker player Pug Pearson hustling his golfing partners during a black tournament in Nashville (The percentages are all right as fat as they go, drawls Pug, trying to talk the author into placing a bet on him: But I don't think you're takin into account your. human element. Heil, I know them old boys. I know em real well. And I know their (And, sure enough, he does.) But I was sure that a sense of repetition would soon set In. After all, how much variety can you lend to an introduction and six profiles on, men who are all in the same line of work? And how many different ways can you describe the process of winning or losing a lot of money?

title: Thousands of Greeks Here Mark Easter
description: The goldenrobed priest intoned Christos anesti (Christ is risen) from the altar at midnight yesterday, marking the climax of the Greek Orthodox drama of Holy Weeka combination of religious, fervor, family love and the renewal of ties of Greek community life.

title: Rev. Edward Doherty, 84, Dead; Star Front Page Era Reporter
description: The Rev. Edward J. Dohertyremembered here as Eddie Doherty, the star reporter straight out of the raffish, fasttalking Front Page set that thrived on scandaldied yesterday in Renfrew, Ontario. His age was 84. He had been ordained at 79, after ??? as a newsman and author and while still married to this third wife, a former Russian baroness, who is among his survivors.

title: $325Million Cost Overrun For B1 Bomber Reported
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI)  Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that Congressional auditors had turned up a $225million cost overrun by Rockwell International on research for the BI bomber.

title: Gains for Bonn
description: Parties of the governing West German coalition headed by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt halted a recent losing trend and made clear gains in state elections yesterday in North RhineWestphalia and the Saar. Details are on Page 9.

title: Caldwell Strikes Sparks With Cellini
description: BOSTON, May 4Anybody attending an Opera Company of Boston performance learns to wait for the big sock momentthe Caldwell Climax. In the Berlioz Trojans, a few years back, Sarah Caldwell (the woman who runs the company, stages many of Its performanes, conducts and probably collects tickets when she has a loose moment), worked up a sensation that came with the arrival of the Trojan Horse, a colossus nearly 30 feet high, holding half the Greek army. Last night, at the premiere of Benvenuto Cellini by Berlioz, the Caldwell Climax came just about at the end of the opera.

title: Lepers Children Are in Limbo
description: SEOUL, Korea, May 4It was nearly a year ago that a South Korean couple announced that they would give up their two small daughters for adoption in the United States.

title: Alla Romeo Triumphs
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, May 4 (AP)Henri Pescarolo of France and Derek Bell of Britain, driving an Alfa Romeo 33T3, won the 1,000 Kilometers of Spa for sports cars today. The race was shortened to 750 kilometers because of bad weather.

title: Wall St. Mayday Cheers Big Investoii
description: Large investors found a weak spot among stockbrokers last week and worked on it steadilyto push commission fees down to unnrecedented levels.

title: Why Greek Orthodox Differ on Easter Date
description: The annual date that the Greek Orthodox Church celebrates Easter differs from that of Western Christendom for two reasons:

title: TrabertMrs. King Win By LEONARD KOPPETT
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., May 4A pair of professional television broadcasters, whose names happen to be Billie Jean King and Tony Trabert, defeated two of Australia's most honored tennis names, Frank Sedgman and Margaret Court, in two sets today in the first Mixed Doubles Classic at the John Gardiner Tennis Ranch.

title: Baker First in 500, Outdueling Pearson
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., May 4 (UPI)Buddy Baker beat the threetime defending champion, David Pearson, in a finallap chase today and. won the Winston 500 NASCAR race. The race was marred by the death of Richard Petty's brotherinlaw and five accidents involving nine drivers.

title: BONN'S COALITION GAINS IN REGIONS
description: BONN. May4Nearly a third of W'st Germany's voters gavel Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's coalition parties clear gains in two key state elections today, ending the losing trend of the last 15 months.

title: Truth in Governing
description: Although Congressional oversight and criminal sanctions provide some brakes on Federal malfeasance and ineptitude, one of the most effective checks on misuse of power has proved to be public disclosure of embarrassing or incriminating facts by honest civil servants. Scandals ranging from enormous cost overruns on aircraft construction contracts to unhealthy conditions at a hospital on an Indian reservation have been uncovered in this manner.

title: Allez France Defeats Dahlia Again
description: PARIS, May 4Allez France opened today a clear lead over Dahlia in their race to become the world's richest thoroughbred as she beat her rival for the seventh straight time. Allez France, making her first start of the season, scored by four lengths, with Carl King second, Comiesse de Loir third and Dahlia last in the field of six in the $100,000 Prix Ganay at Longchamp.

title: Harlem Church Finds Home in a Former Synagogue
description: Walker Memorial Baptist Church, organized In 1891 as the first black church in Harlem, has found a new home in a former synagogue at 120 East 169th Street, just off Grand Concourse in the Bronx.

title: About New York
description: Shirley Moses who works for Columbia Tours here, called the other day to relay a story she had heard. it concerned a New jersey woman who had driven her new red Volkswagen to Madison Square Garden a week or so previously to buy tickets for the circus.

title: U.S. Company Payoffs Way of Life Overseas
description: American companies doing business abroad are spending hundreds of millions of dollars each year for agents fees, commissions and outright payoffs to foreign officials.

title: Top Chinese, Losing Inhibitions, Venture Abroad
description: HONG KONG, May 4 Drawing on an enlarged cast of Government leaders, China is starting to repay the dozens of unreciprocated state visits that foreign leaders have made to Peking in the years since the Cultural Revolution. Until January, when the number of Deputy Premiers in Peking was increased from 2 to 12 as part g a general overhaul of the leadership, highlevel contacts between the Chinese and other governments were virtually confined to the Chinese capital. Notes on China.

title: The Stage: Miss Janie
description: Just about five years ago Ed Bullins wrote a play called The Pig Pen, which was all about a mixed party in 1965, that took place the night Malcolm X was assassinated the night of the big divide between black and white. Now Mr. Bullins has produced The Taking of Miss Janie, which arrived last night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival. It is described by the author as a sequel, and once again it is about the nineteensixties, pot and wine parties, blacks and whites not so much together, and the face of America's violence. But there is a difference of tone.

title: Americans Reported Paid To Help Refugees Flee
description: NORFOLK, Va., May 4 (AP) A retired Air Force colonel said today that many South Vietnamese evacuated in the hours before the fall of Saigon had been sold affidavit signatures by Americans for as much as $3.000.

title: Deyan Urges Peace Bid
description: TEL AVIV, May 4Former Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that Israel should submit new Middle East peace proposals to the United States before President Ford meets President Anwar elSadat of Egypt in Salzburg, Austria, next month.

title: Consumer Agency Accused In Delay on Aerosol Sprays
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) An environmental group said today that it would take the Consumer Product Safety Cornmission to court for failure to act on the question of whether aerosol sprays were destroying 'the earth's protective ozone layer.

title: Deaths
Port Authority Bridge and Tunnel Tolls Increase at Midnight
description: The tarpaulin covers came off the new toll signs at midnight last night at all six Hudson River bridges and tunnels operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, reflecting the 50 per cent increase that took effect this morning.

title: STRAUSS FORESEES DEADLOCK IN PARTY
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The chairman of the Democratic party, Robert Strauss, said today that there was a very good chance that the 1978 Democratic convention would deadlock over the choice of a Presidential nominee, leaving men like Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama to act as brokers.

title: Triumphant Jockey At Derby is Loser
description: BOSTON, May 4 (AP)Westgate Mall, ridden by Temistocles Santos, beat the Kentucky Derby winner, Jacinto Vasquez, and Onion in the stretch today for a head victory in the $28,350 Bay State Handicap before a crowd of 12,296 at Suffolk Downs.

title: Doctors Aims Questioned At 2 Hospitals They Own
description: For the last year and a half, a partnership that now numbers seven doctors had been enjoying increasing support from community and legislative leaders for the way it seemingly had been improving two private Manhattan hospitals that had been under fire by the state Health Department.

title: ARAB OIL NATIONS WILL AID OTHERS
description: KUWAIT, May 4Arab oil ministers agreed today to provide $80million as compensation to poorer Arab countries for higher oil prices this year.

title: Port Authority Bridge and Tunnel Tolls Are Up 50%
description: The tarpaulin covers came off the new toll signs at midnight last night at all six Hudson River bridges and tunnels operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, reflecting the 50 per cent increase that took effect this morning.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Six Days In the Evacuation From Saigon
description: ABOARD U.S.S. BLUE RIDGE in the South China Sea, May 4The last day began precisely at 4 A.M. On April 29, Saigon awoke to the heaviest rocket attack of the war. First six rockets, then 22, then dozens more slammed into Tan Son Nhut airport.

title: Purchasing Group Sees the Economy Set for Recovery
description: The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday in its monthly report that the economy was set for a recovery.

title: Dodgers Box Score
description: SAN DIEGO (N.)

title: Bridge:
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., May 4 New York battled in the stretch with a WestchesterHudson Valley combination in the Grand National team spring championship here tonight with New England trailing.

title: To Ukrainian Family Easter is the Big Day
description: Hurry up, it's ready, sit down, called out Natalia Zamiaty, reaching for a colored Easter egg. For Natalia, who is 12 years old, it had been a long night. The Thor Zamiatys had left their home In Richmond Hill, Queens, at 10 o'clock Saturday night to drive to St. Vladimir's Ukrainian Orthodox Church on West 82d Street in Manhattan for Easter services.

title: Major League Baseball
description: American League

title: ExGurney Aide Says Mitchell Stopped F.B.I. Inquiry Into Shakedowns
description: TAMPA, Fla., May 3A key witness in the extortion and conspiracy trial of former Senator Edward J. Gurney of Florida has testified that the Federal Bureau of Investigation began investigating his shakedown of home builders in Florida within two or three months after it began in 1971.

title: Exxon Disnlaces G.M. as No. 1 in Sales
description: Fortune magazine has just issued its list of the nation's 500 biggest corporations, and never in the 20 years that it has tracked their performance have the rankings been so changed. The reason, the May issue of the magazine reports, is oil.

title: No. Amer. Soccer League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Northeastern in Sweep
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May (AP)Northeastern crews swept all events in a heavyweight dual regatta with Massachusetts on the Charles River today.

title: State G.0.P. Is Told That Hope For Recovery Hinges on Youth
description: If the Republican party is to recover from the effects of Watergate, regain control of the Assembly in 1976 and dump Gov. Hugh Carey in 1978, the young Republicans must be visible and attractive to the youth of New York State, the president of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs told the association:s 44th annual convention here this weekend.

title: School Supervisors Ask 8Day Cut in Work Year
description: DOWNINGTOWN, Pa., May 4 The head of the New York City school supervisors union today threatened job actions that would turn the city school system into an administrative nightmare if the Board of Education did not shorten the work year of supervisors.

title: Wallace, Critics and Statistics Differ On Alabama Achievements Since 1963
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.,When Gov. George C. Wallace is asked these days whether he is a Presidential candidate, he often replies with a laugh that he is far too busy running Alabama to worry about running for President.

title: Tesoro and Corco Agree on $14.25 Bid
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation has apparently won its takeover bid for the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company (Corco) of Puerto Rico after increasing its tender offer price to $14.25 a share from $11.50.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A 17yearold Asbury Park youth was to be arraigned today on charges that he threatened to kill Helen Reddy, the pop singer, unless he received $30,000, according to the Fedeal Bureau of Investigation. A spokesman for the bureau said that the defendant, Gerald E. Hall, was charged with violating the Federal extortion laws after his arrest Friday. The suspect was confined to the Monmouth County Youth Detention Center in Freehold pending his arraignment.

title: Carey Held More Concerned About Albany Than a National Future for Now
description: ALBANY, May 4Aside from the usual mendicant's missions to Washington for ??? Federal aid, Governor Carey has a schedule that is atrictly rooted in state affairs for the next several months. There are none of the nation hopping speeches and visits that used to be a kind of Presidential fever chart for Rockefeller watchers.

title: Islanders Lose, 10, and Trail by 30
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., May 4 The Cinderella team that has survived against the greatest of odds finds itself in another perilous situation. The New York Islanders were shut out today for the second time in their semifinal Stanley Cup series with the Philadelphia Flyers, this time by 10, and were only one less away from elimination.

title: Temple Golf Victor
description: NEW HAVEN, May 4Walter Brown, a junior, sank a 35foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today and gave Temple first place in the 41st annual Eastern Intercollegiate golf championship. Brown also captured the medal with a sevenoverpar 147. Delaware was second.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Saigon radio said yesterday that the Military Management Committee administering the city had freed former President Duong Van Minh of South Vietnam, who surrendered the country to the Revolutionary Government, and that 18 other high officials of the former South Vietnamese Government had also been released. Among the officials were former Vice President Nguyen Van Huyen and former Premier Vu Van Mau, the broadcasts said. The decision to release them reportedly was made by the 11member North Vietnamese military committee. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: FordBrezhnev Summit
description: Postponement of the FordBrezhnev summit conference until the autumn is due primarily to technical difficulties in completing the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty (SALT II) outlined in Vladivostok last November. The technical obstacles themselves can only be overcome by political compromises at the highest level, and these compromises have become difficult to tackle when dtente and the broader SovietAmerican relationship are under increasing strain.

title: 42d St. Post Office Robbed by Gunmen; Guards Guns Stolen
description: Four gunmen invaded the Times Square Post Office at 340 West 42d Street yesterday morning and, after overpowering and disarming two security guards, fled in a panel truck with 11 sacks of registered mail.

title: Phils Trade Montanez To Giants for Maddox
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP)The Philadelphia Phillies traded Willie Montnez, a first baseman, to the San Francisco Giants toddy for Garry Maddox an outfielder.

title: Plan to Integrate Detroit Schools To Be Proposed by U.S. Judge
description: DETROIT, May 4A Federal judge has begun the process of deciding what kind of desegregation plan to order for the city's schools.

description: Rabbis have needed ingenuity and memory in their responsa, sampled here:

title: Sihanouk's Mother Mourned at Rites In Chinese Capital
description: PEKING, May 4(Agence FrancePresse)Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the Cambodian Chief of State, lit the funeral pyre today to cremate the body of his mother, Queen Sisowath Kossamak, at a Buddhist ceremony attended by highranking Chinese, Vietnamese and North Koreans.

title: A.C.L.U. Asserts Many Veterans Could Get Discharges Upgraded
description: WASHINGTON, May 4At least 40 to 50 per cent of veterans who received less than honorable discharges over the last 15 years and some who received them earlier could get their discharges upgraded they had strong legal representation, a new book by the American Civil Liberties Union contends.

title: Television
description: Morning

description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing FIRST$6,500, trot, h'cap., mile.

description: Incoming

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: GRACE HARRINGTON GIVES PIANO RECITAL
description: Grace Harrington, a teacher of piano at Marymount College, came to Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night for her first recital here since 1968. She played Beethoven's Sonata in E (Op. 109), Book II of Debussy's Preludes, Brahms's Waltzes (Op. 39) and Prokofiev's Sonata No. 8.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Overture to The School of Scandal, Barber; Piano Concerto, Ward; Skyscrapers, Carpenter.

title: Astros Watson Scores Millionth Run
description: By a margin of approximately four seconds, Bob Watson of the Houston Astros yesterday scored major league baseball's heavily publicized and eagerly anticipated one millionth run. It came 99 years and 12 days after Wes Fisler of the National League's Philadelphia team was the first to circle the bases successfully.

title: DUBLIN OFFICIAL SEES NO ACCORD IN ULSTER
description: DUBLIN, May 4  Conor Cruise O'Brien, Ireland's Minister for Posts and Telegraphs, said today there was no possibility of a government in Northern Ireland in which Protestants and Roman Catholics would share power. Nor would there he any allIreland institutions in which the north and the south share power, he Predicted.

title: A 30Year Reappraisal: Nazis Fall, Bonn's Rise
description: BONN, May 4Thirty years ago Germany, defeated after the most terrible war in history, lay in disgrace and ruin. Today West Germany, the strongest economic power in Europe, is more prosperous than those who won the war in 1945.

title: REFUGEES SETTLE IN CONNECTICUT
description: NEW HARTFORD, Conn., May 3Almost everyone who has taken notice has tried to help make life comfortable for two families of Vietnamese refugees here.

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: (Week ended May 2, 1975)

title: U.S. IS FOUND LAX ON EQUALITY RULE IN CONTRACT JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Government was charged today with being so lax in enforcing its orders requiring Government contractors to follow ondiscriminatory employment practices that it does not even have a list of all the contractors.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Royal Copenhagen Porcelain is celebrating its 200th anniversary, and in honor of the occasion, the Danish firm's shop at 573 Madison Avenue is having a birthday party of its own.

title: Lawrence Robinson Dies; Headed Golf Writers Here
description: Lawrence Robinson, a wellknown golf writer and former president of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association, died yesterday at Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing Queens. He was 73 years Old.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. OrioIcs, at Baltimore. (TelevisionChannel 11, game In progress, 8 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 7:30 P.M.)

title: We Have No Choice
description: The antagonistic response of some Americans in and out of Congress to the prospect of granting refuge in the United States to 150,000 Vietnamese seeking asylum here recalls the worst days of McCarranism a quarter century ago. At that time, the late Senator McCarran of Nevada became the odious symbol for all that was ungenerous In the American attitude toward the admission of political and other refugees after World War II. A recrudescent McCarranism is the last thing Americans should want to see today.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores
description: FIRST GAME

title: Flameproof Clothes Gain Favor
description: The textile and apparel industry appears to be on the threshold of an era in which only flameproof apparel will be produced.

title: A 30Year Reappraisal: Nazis Fall, Bonn's Rise
description: BONN, May 4Thirty years ago Germany, defeated after the most terrible war in history, lay in disgrace and ruin. Today West Germany, the strongest economic power in Europe, is more prosperous than those who won the war in 1945.

title: Report From Elba
description: SAN CLEMENTE You and I haven't had a cup of coffee together in a long time, said Richard Nixon. He had fixed this pot himself, and hastened to assure a frowning secretary that it was the first cup he had tasted all afternoon. Evidently he has been forced to cut back on his Navy coffeeguzling habit.

title: Young Republicans Chief Says Byrne is a Good Issue
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 4 The new chairman of the Young Republicans of New Jersey said today that Governor Byrne's failure to maintain state government financial stability would be the Republican party's best weapon in an Assembly comeback election in November.

title: Motorcycle Racer Dies
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, May 4 (Reuters)  Tommaso Piccirilli, an Italian motorcycle racer who fractured his skull In a crash during a race last Sunday at Imola, died in hospital here today.

title: LANDLORDS PUSHED BY CITY ON REPAIRS
description: Landlords of 900,000 rentcontrolled apartments here were warned by the city yesterday that if they did not repair all major violations in their buildings within the next two months they would not receive rent rises of up to 7.5 per cent due most of them next Jan. 1.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that he would make certain that the state's Public Service Commission carefully examines the impact of a Federal waiver that entitles the oil company owned by his brother, Edward M. Carey, to about $5million a month in cost benefits for four months. The Governor, commenting during an appearance in midtown, said he had been told the ruling was aimed at cutting oil prices to consumers by spurring competition of independent and major companies. If it has that effect, course I'm for it, he said.

title: ABANDONED ARMS PILED AROUND HUE
description: HUE, South Vietnam, May 3American military equipment estimated to be worth $100million is strewn like a gigantic junkpile along the Hue estuary w'ere Saigon's defeated armored and infantry forces tried to escape by sea in late March.

title: The Ballet: Grigorovich s Swan Lake
description: For many, many years the Bolshoi Ballet's production of Swan Lake, as staged by Asaf Messerer, after (many years after) Petipa, Ivanov and Gorsky, had been widely regarded, at the most charitable view, as obsolescent. In 1969 it was finally declared obsolete in Moscow, and the current new staging by Yuri Grigorovich had its first performance at the Boishoi Theater on Dec. 25 of that year.

title: Moroccans Cheer Giscard
description: FEZ, Morocco, May 4(Reuters)  A crowd estimated at one million people wildly cheered President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France today as he drove with King Hassan II from Rabat to Fez. The French President arrived in Rabat yesterday for a threday official visit the first by a French head of state since Morocco became independent 19 years ago.

title: KY SAYS THAT U.S. HELPED TOO MUCH
description: AGANA, Guam, Monday, May 5The United States is not to blame for the fall of South Vietnam, according to Nguyen Cao Ky, former Premier and Vice President of the country.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: Persons who carefully compare before they buy a motorcycle should take the same pains when purchasing insurance for their new vehicle, state insurance officials advice.

title: Bonn Coalition Gains
description: The parties of the governing West German coalition headed by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt halted a recent losing trend and made clear gains in state elections yesterday in North RhineWestphalia and the Saar. Details are on Page 9.

title: French to Be Flown Home
description: PARIS, May 4(Reuters) Four hundred and fifty French nationals evacuated from Cambodia to Thailand will be flown home from Bangkok tomorrow in an Air France Boeing 747, French officials said today.

title: Miss Astrolbges Wins First Golf Tournament
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 4 (UPI)Maria Astrologes sank an eightfoot birdie putt Op the first hole of a suddendeath playoff today to win the Birmingham Classic golf tournament, defeating Joanne Carner and Judy Rankin. Miss Astrologes won the $5,700 first prize in her first tournament victory.

title: Personal Finance: Collecting Claims
description: The cleaner ruined a dress. I took him to Small Claims Court. The owner did not appear for trial nor did he have anyone represent him. Deputy Sheriff H. advised me that there were at least a half dozen ahead of me trying to collect hundreds of dollars from this man. What good are Small Claims Courts if people are permitted to ruin other people's property and get away with it?

title: Going out Guide
description: CELEBRATION Common Ground is the title of the first annual culture festival being staged by Fordham University today through Saturday, with performances in jazz, poetry, dance and theater from 4 P.M. until midnight and a noontomidnight finale. The public is being welcomed to the series of free events on the school's Lincoln Center campus, as students, professional artists and amateurs project a spirit of friendship and common cultural interesthence the title.

title: JOBLESS RATE DROP FORESEEN BY SIMON
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today that unemployment had about reached its peak and should begin to level off soon.

title: Racial Issues Muted in District 1 Vote
description: This year's campaign for control of the Lower East Side's District 1 Community School Board has been waged amid some familiar themes, but racial and ethnic issues have been more restrained than in recent elections.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Bonnie Cashin and her unstudied casualness. Stephen Burrows and his offbeat originality. Oscar de la Renta and his pretty clothes for beautiful people.

title: Hussein Warns of Eruption Without Mideast Move Soon
description: WASHINGTON, May 4(Reuters)King Hussein of Jordan said in an interview broadcast today that an eruption could occur in the Middle East if there were no new moves toward peace within a matter of months.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: MANLEYKirtland, of South Orange, N. J. on January 14, 1975, husband of the late Ruth Rooney King, father of Mrs. Sara Lord Norris Munsen of South Orange and Sutton Island, Me., nephew of Mrs. Marlon Manley Winser of Summit. A memorla service will be held at the St. Andrew Church of the Holy Communion, W. So. Orange Ave and So. Ridgewood Rd., Soutn Orange, on Saturday, May 10, 1975 at 3:30 PM.

title: Vacations for the Aging
description: The elderly are having a particularly tough time in these days of recession and inflation. As their standard of living declines, their isolation from the main currents of society grows.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLUMENTHAL Lenoremay 5, 1974. My beloved wife entered into heaven one year ago today. Your sacrifices, devotion & Iovin kindness are not forgotten. In you God gave an Angel. No one shall take your place in my heart. You did not go away alone, part of me went with you. Your sweet voice & gentle smile endeared you with everyone. They seem to say carry on my darling I'm only sleeping. Till we meet again your beloved husband, Welter.

title: CAMBODIAN OFFICERS REPORTED EXECUTED
description: WASHINGTON, May 4Administration sources said today that intelligence reports indicated some Cambodian military officrsless than 100had been executed by the new Government.

title: ITALY TO DONATE MILLIONS TO PRESS
description: ROME, May 4  Italy is about to make a $70million annual gift to her ??? dened press, but the newspapers do not write much about the proposed largesse.

title: HOME IS ACCUSED IN DEATH OF AGED
description: A former employe or a large South Jersey nursing home has reportedly complained to state authorities that 30 of the 60 elderly patients in the home's intensivecare wing died last winter after the home's administrators ignored the recommendations of its own medical consultant to protect the patients from an influenza epidemic.

title: Powell Breaks Discus Record
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 4 (AP)John Powell, a San Jose, Calif., policeman, smashed the world record in the discus throw by two feet today with a toss of 226 feet 8 inches.

title: Princeton Goes Colonial for Day
description: PRINCETON, May 4 Bright spring weather helped to attract 10,000 people here yesterday to celebrate the nation's Bicentennial in daylong fete called Nassau StreetA Living Museum.

title: Oil Lands Money Reserves Stabilizing
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The monetary reserves of oilproducing countries as a group have apparently stopped rising since the end of last year, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

title: State Altering Its Policies On School Desegregation
description: TRENTON, May 4Conceding that racial imbalance in urban school districts is a political reality that cannot be substantially altered now, high state education officials reported here this weekend that the State Department of Education would not attempt to implement largescale desegregation of the state's public schools this year.

title: Latin Salsa Music Gains Popularity and Recognition
description: At a gala ceremony yesterday evening at the Beacon Theater on Broadway, Latin NY magazine presented awards to Latin musicians based on its poll of readers. And yesterday morning, at the semiannual meeting in it Chicago of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, the academy's national board decided to give one of its Grammy awards in a Latin music category for the first time next year.

title: The Foolish Pleasure of John Greer
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4When John L. Greer got back home to Knoxville last winter with the Eclipse Award saluting his unbeaten colt, Foolish Pleasure, as the 2yearold champion of 1974, he was the proudest bakery tycoon Tennessee. For three days he had been snowed with congratulations and he knew the home folk would come crowding around to share his pleasure. Driving to business on the first day back, he parked where he usually does and started the sixblock walk to his office prepared to stop and shake hands every few steps. He walked one block, two, three, tour. Nobody had glanced his way. A block farther on, a man approached. Well, he thought, finally, and although he didn't recognize the man right off he gave him a receptive smile. Say, Mac, the man said, which way to the nearest pool room?

title: Nancy Schutte Wed to Dr. Howard
description: Nancy Colean Schutte of Hastings, N.Y., and Dr. Geoge Marshall Howard, a New York ophthalmologist, were married yesterday afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church in Salisbury, Conn., by the Rev. Donald R. Cutler.

title: Soviet Seems to Falter on Mideast Talks
description: MOSCOW, Monday, May 5 The S'viet Union's recently accelerated efforts toward resumption of the Geneva conference on the Middle East appeared to falter today, after three weeks of intermittent consultations here between Kremlin leaders and Arab officials.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENCharles H. Services Tuesday, 11AM at Universal Funeral Chapel, 52 St & Lexington Ave.

title: Jury Questions Rights Board Members
description: Members of the state's Human Rights Appeals Board are being called before a Queens grand jury investigating a doctor's charges that he had been asked to pay $30,000 to influence a board decision and that the decision had gone against him after he refused.

title: Dr. McGill is Honored By Police Group Here
description: An Irish Catholic educator yesterday was honored by the St. George Association, the Protestant organization of the city's police officers.

title: U.S. Lawyers to Handle School Vote Violations
description: The Department of Justice announced yesterday that it had assigned a staff of lawyers to receive complaints of Federal violations relating to racial discrimination in the school board elections.

title: Refugee Sighs, I Am Happy, I Am Sad
description: EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., May 4Less than two weeks ago Hong Van Hoanh was one of South Vietnam's elite, a dapper man of prominence, prestige and privilege.

title: Pimlico Next For Winner Of Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4Asked about Foolish Pleasure before yesterday's confusionstrewn Kentucky Derby, Jimmy Jones rubbed his chin and offered a fourword appraisal.

title: Moynihan Bids U.S. Retain World Role
description: Daniel P. Moynihan warned yesterday that the ability of third world nations to retain their independence and nonCommunist character depended on a power balance between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Mailing of Tax Rebates Will Begin This Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI)Income tax rebates, the antirecession bonus to lure consumers into the market place once again, will start flowing to the public this week.

title: KY SAYS THAT U.S. HELPED TOO MUCH
description: AGANA, Guam, Monday, May 5The United States is not to blame for the fall of South Vietnam, according to Nguyen Cao Ky, former Premier and Vice President of the country.

title: Credit Markets Recover; Postponed Offerings Due
description: The bond markets have proved once again that a little good news from Washington can work wonders in Wall Street. One week ago, the markets wallowed in despair. The unknown dimensions of the May refunding operation of the United States Treasury had sent prices lower and despair higher. But all that changed quickly late Thursday when the Treasury announced plans to raise less money this week than expected. As a bonus, the Treasury also disclosed that its borrowing needs in the first half of 1975 would be $5billion below the previous estimate, thanks to surge in tax receipts.

title: The Ghost of U.D.C.
description: Nothing could have defined the tragedy of the Urban Development Corporation better than the recently announced results of the architectural competition for housing on Roosevelt Island, a project started in better days. For one thing, it refocused attention on the U.D.C.'s basic purpose, which has been too quickly forgotten in the fiscal crisis it is now going through. The raison d'etre of U.D.C. and similar housing and development programs is to provide places for people to live inpeople who would not otherwise have decent housing in the urban environment. It is shelter, not tax shelter, that is at stake.

title: A.B.A. Playoffs
description: Denver vs. Indiana

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Saigon radio said yesterday that the Military Management Committee administering the city had freed former President Duong Van Minh of South Vietnam, who surrendered the country to the Revolutionary Government, and that 18 other high officials of the former South Vietnamese Government had also been released. Among the officials were former Vice President Nguyen Van Huyen and former Premier Vu Van Mau, the broadcasts said. The decision to release them reportedly was made by the 11member North Vietnamese military committee. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: A Responsum Sampler
description: Q. Is it permitted to sway while praying? A. Yes. A psalm speaks of addressing God with all one's bones.

title: Refugee Sighs, I Am Happy, I Am Sad
description: EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., May 4Less than two weeks ago Hong Van Hoanh was one of South Vietnam's elite, a dapper man of prominence, prestige and privilege.

description: Aggression in Man, by Charles Burke.(Lyle Stuart, Secaucus, N. J., $7.95). The effects of childraising.

title: Church in Chile is Criticized as Weak on Human Rights
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 4A breach has opened between human rights advocates and the Roman Catholic hierarchy in Chile.

title: NEW WORLD PLAYERS CELEBRATE 10 YEARS
description: The Symphony of the New World celebrated its 10th birthday in the best of all possible ways: It gave a jubilee concert at Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon, conducted by its regular music director, Everett Lee, paying homage to Howard Swanson, one of America's greatly underrated composers, and presenting the violinist Erick Friedman in one of his alltoorare concerto appearances here.

title: Events Today

title: California Seeks Way to Satisfy Motorists Who Got Smog Units
description: LOS ANGELES, May 4California officials are grappling with the problem of appeasing around a million irate motorists who spent $35 or more for auto smog control devices under a state law that has just been renealed.

description: Partial list of scheduled ??? for week follows:

title: Thousands o Greeks Here Mark Easter
description: The goldenrobed priest intoned Christos anesti (Christ is risen) from the altar at midnight yesterday, marking the climax of the Greek Orthodox drama of Holy Weeka combination of religious fervor, family love and the renewal of ties of Greek community life.

title: Reminders
description: SALT LAKE CITYIn the distance the new church office building, characterless white shaft, loomed over the pioneer baroque of the Mormon Temple. We were talking about the Mormon values of thrift and selfrelianceessentially unchanged since Brigham Young saw the great valley and said This is the placewhen the waitress came to take the orders for lunch.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: How difficult it is under the distracting pressures of the nation's present confusions and divisions for us to look at ourselves from a broader perspective, a historical perspective. And how valuablefor the widened scope of such a broad outlook would put us back in touch with our priorities, our actual progress in relation to our ideal goals, and our relation to the experiences of history and the principles of human nature. Such a perspective would be invaluable not only in furthering the cause of freedom and wellbeing in the nation as a whole, but in aiding each individual to determine with greater rationality and conviction what course to follow in his her role.

title: Brewers Defeat Yanks Again
description: MILWAUKEE, May 4The Milwaukee Brewers completed a threegame sweep of the Yankees today by amassing 16 hits for an 114 victory. So the New Yorkers left for Baltimore wondering what went wrong after they finally had begun resembling the pennant contender they were supposed to be.

title: SAIGON REPORTS FREEING OF MINH AND 18 OFFICIALS
description: The Saigon radio said yesterday that the Military Management Committee administering the South Vietnamese capital had freed former President Duong Van Minh, who surrendered the country to the Revolutionary Government five days ago.

title: James Captures Eastern Tennis
description: SYOSSET, L. I., May 4Firstseeded John James defeated Tony Dawson, an Australian countryman, 63, 64, 62 today and won the Eastern men's hardcourt tennis title. The match was moved from the raindrenched Woodbury Country Club courts to the Syosset Racquet Club indoor courts.

description: GERMANAMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Responsa: The Law as Seen By Rabbis for 1,000 Years
description: Tradition has it that young rabbis completing their training are given an ordination certificate and the telephone number of Rabbi Moshe Feinstein. He is the closest that Orthodox Jewry comes to a court of last resort.

title: Rumanian, 13. Tons Women Gymnasts
description: SKIEN, Norway, May 4 (AP)Rumania's 13yearold Nadia Comaneci became the 1975 European women's gymnastics queen today, capturing four of five gold medals the twoday 10th European championships. Miss Comaneci had won the overall fourevent competition yesterday with 38:85 points, and today she added gold medals in the long horse vaulting, the nonparallel bars and balance beam. the final floor exercises, she took the silver medal behind 15yearold, Koreanborn Nelly Kim of the Soviet Union.

title: College Results
description: BASEBALL

title: ENERGY CHIEF SAYS CRISIS IS WORSENING
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI) The energy crisis in this country is worse now than it was before the 1973 Arab embargo, and any new cutoff of foreign oil could bring gas. oline rationing within 90 days the head of the Federal Energy Administration, Rank G. Zarb said today.

title: Lakeland Takes Best In jersey
description: WASHINGTON CROSSING, N. J., May 4The Lakeland terrier comes from the lake district in England, so it was no great surprise that a representative of the breed., Ch. Tarnbreck Cassius, owned by Countess Ercilia LeNy of Milford. N. J., was best in a field of 3,657 dogs at the Trenton Kennel Club show today. An allday rain made a lake of the Washington Crossing State Park grounds and Cassius, handled by Guenter Behr, proved the best mudder.

title: WORLD BANK PUTS STRESS ON HEALTH
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The World Bank is moving toward much greater emphasis on improving the health of the world's poor, according to a new policy statement released today that emphasized the links between illness and poverty in the developing world.

title: Jipcho and U.C.L.A. Savor Track Victories COasts Apart
description: There were symbols and chants of No. 1 from coast to coast in track and field last weekend, from Ben Jipcho to the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: Bulls Triumph for 21 Lead
description: CHICAGO, May 4 (AP)Norm Van Lier's 35 points led Chicago to a 108101 victory over the Golden State Warriors today, giving the Bulls a 21 lead in their National Basketball Association Western Conference playoff series.

description: AT RIVERSIDE Y.C.

title: DEATHS
description: COLT3. Stoan, ?? died May 2 at his horne in Westhampton Beacn. Mr. Colt leaves his wife, the former Anne K. Weld, three children, a son, Richard, and two daughters, Marion Williamson and Catherine yandell and a stepson, Niel McLane. Services will be at his home in Westhampton Beach at 12 o'clock, Tuesday, May 6. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American ked cross would be apprecciated.

title: 25 Refugee Ships Anchor Off Singapore
description: SINGAPORE, ray 4 (Reuters)  Twentyfive vessels crammed with more than 3,000 South Vietnamese refugees are anchored off Singapore awaiting supplies of food, maps and medicines, a senior government official said today.

title: Foss Gives ModernMusic Fans A 5Hour Workout in Brooklyn
description: Lukas Foss clearly loves the marathon format in his Brooklyn Philharmonia programs. wherein a multitude of music is laid out for an audience's delectation over an hourslong period. Saturday night, for his second annual Festival of Modern Combos, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Mr. Foss applied the format once again to contemporary music, and the result for this listener proved a little unsettling.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min from Sandy Hook time. For high tide al Atlantic City (Steel Pier), deduct 26 min from Sandy Hook time. For Mgt tide at Jones Inlet (Pt. Lookout), deduct 19 min from Sandy Hook time.

title: 28 CLINICS SERVE CUBANS IN MIAMI
description: MIAMI, May 3Ten weeks ago, the 4yearold son of Armando Correa, a Cubanborn Miami bus driver, suffered serious head cut.

title: SAIGON REPORTS FREEING OF MINH AND 18 OFFICIALS
description: The Saigon radio said yesterday that the Military Management Committee administering the South Vietnamese capital had freed former President Duong Van Minh, who surrendered the country to the Revolutionary Government five days ago.

title: Fifth Avenue Parade Honors Dr. King
description: A corps of young baton twirlers that marched down Fifth Avenue in the eighth annual Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Parade yesterday wore small plastic bags over the bright yellow plumes on their hats to keep off the rain.

title: Crash Kills Four TeenAgers
description: MOUNT HOLLY SPRINGS, Pa., May 4 (UPI) Four teenagers were killed and six other persons were injured in a twocar collision near here early today. The state police identified the dead as Michael Smith, 17, of Gardners RD 1, Greg Howers and Vicki Kinger, both 16, of Mount Holly Springs, and Kay Myers, 16, of Carlisle, RD 5.

title: Harvard Oarsmen Goldthwait Victors
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 4Princeton won the first Goldthwait Cup in lightweight crew competition in 1922 but had to settle for second place today as Harvard's lights posted a twolength victory in the 50th regatta on the Charles River.

title: About the Mets
description: Yesterday's rainpostponed game between the Mets and the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium tame as bad news to Manager Yogi Berra because he felt it might cause members of his starting pitching rotation to lose some of their sharpness. Tom Seaver, who was slated to face the Expos, will oppose Pittsburgh at Shea tomorrow night the start of a threegame series. Jon Matlack and Jerry Koosman, in that order, will be New York's starters in the other two games with the Pirates. The Mets are scheduled to make their annual trip to West Point today to play against the Cadets. George Stone, who has been suffering with a bad shoulder and who is on the disabled list, scheduled to pitch against the Army nine.

title: Celtic Team Wins Cup
description: LONDON, May 4 (AP)Celtic defeated Airdriel, 31, today and won the Scottish Football Association Cup.

title: Knifton Takes 10Mile Walk
description: SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N. J., May 4 (AP)Dr. John Knifton of the New York Athletic Club won the 12th annual Olympic development 10mile walk today with a time of hour 17 minutes 29 seconds on the rainswept boardwalk. The 35yearold chemist from Poughquag, N. Y., finished with a quartermile margin over John Fredericks of the Shore Athletic Club, who was timed in 1:19:23. Third place in the 30member field went to Bob Falciola of the Shore A.C.

title: U.S. TO CUT TROOPS IN THAILAND BY 28%
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Monday, May 5 (AP)  The United States will cut its troop strength in Thailand by 28 per cent in the next two months in the first step toward total withdra'al by year's end from the last American military foothold in Southeast Asia, Thailand American authorities said today.

title: Masked Invaders Torture Child at Soviet Residence
description: Three men and an armed, Russianspeaking woman wearing ski masks reportedly invaded the grounds of the new Soviet diplomatic residence in Riverdale Saturday evening, and briefly abducted and tortured a 9yearold girl after terrorizing a group of children at play.

title: U.S. Company Payoffs Way of Life Overseas
description: American companies doing business abroad are spending hundreds of millions of dollars each year for agents fees, missions and outright payoffs to foreign officials.

title: Barnes Wins French Open at 281
description: VERSAILLES, France, May 4 (Reuters)Brian Barnes of Britain won the French open golf championship today La Boulie by two strokes after narrowly escaping a twostroke penalty for being late on the first tee. He shot a twooverpar 73 for a total of 281. Tied for second were Neil Coles of Britain and South Africa's Dale Hayes, both whom had final 73's and two Irishmen John O'Leary and Eamon Darcy, with 71 apiece.

title: Pittsburgh Mayor Talks Dailyon Radio
description: PITTSBURGH, May 4The voice announcing the baseball scores and weather and occasionally introducing a pop recording is familiar to Pittsburgh. It belongs to Peter F. Flahert', the city's secondterm Mayor, who appears from 7:30 to 8:30 five mornings a week on radio station KOV.

title: U.S. IS FOUND LAX ON EQUALITY RULE IN CONTRACT JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, May 4The Government was charged today with being so lax in enforcing its orders requiring Government contractors to follow nondiscriminatory employment practices that it does not even have a list of all the contractors.

title: Inmate Frees 3 Hostages
description: NORFOLK, Va., May 4 (AP) Donnie Jackson, an armed inmate at the city jail, surrendered to the police early today and released three guards he was holding hostage, the police; said. No injuries were reported.

title: Music: Ravel Discovery
description: If the newsiest item on the Buffalo Philharmonic progrom yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall was the United States premiere of Ravel's Sheherazade, Ouverture de Fderie, the centerpiece was the performance of Mahler's Symphony No. 6.

description: ROHDTBeatrice. SisterhoodTemple of the Covenant mourns the loss of a near, devoted member.

title: TV Review
description: The stripe of irony is worthy of public TV's Theater in America series. Tonight the Public Broadcasting Service is offering its stations an investigative report called The World's Worst Air Crash: The Avoidable Accident? It is a good documentary, raising tough and pertinent questions about the Federal Aviation Administration and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's DC10 jumbo jets. Yet, the very presence of the program raises at least an equal number of questions about the uneasy relationship between public TV and investigative documentaries.

description: PARAMUS, May 4A doctor and his wife from Franklin Lakes are delighted over their coming weekend at New York's Plaza Hotel. A business executive is equally elated over his new Lincoln Continental. And a college student from Carnegie Mellon University is looking forward to taking his girl friend to sit with Richard Neer, WNEW's disc jockey, during a progressive rock broadcast.

title: 3 Killed as Car is Rammed On Garden State Parkway
description: WOODBRIDGE, May 4 (UPI) Three persons were killed today when a car was struck from the rear on the Garden State Parkway and burst into flames.

description: In, the face of growing corn. petition between people and grainfed animals for an ever tightening world food supply agricultural scientists are developing a variety of alternative feeds for animals that could al low more grain to be released for hungry people without cutback in meat consumption by the well fed.

description: The Shubert Foundation has given $125.000 for the continued operation of Town Hall as a cultural center.

title: Mushrooms for Dinner
description: WASHINGTONOn April 2, the news media reported that an Argentine legislator had introduced a bill calling for his Government to develop nuclear weapons. This was a clear indication of the pressures on a growing number of governments to go nuclear.

description: JERUSALEM, May 4 (UPI)A timebomb explosion ripped through an apartment building in Jerusalem today in the second Arab guerrilla attack in the city in two days, Israeli authorities said.

description: PARIS, May 4 (AP)Michel Laurent, whose photographs of Bangladesh soldiers executing turncoats after the 1971 IndiaPakistan war won the Pulitzer Prize, was killed April 28 covering one of the last battles in South Vietnam, the Gamma photo agency announced today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Landlords of 900,000 rentcontrolled apartments in New York City were warned by the city yesterday to repair all major violations in their buildings within the next two months, or they would not receive rent rises up to 7.5 per cent due most of them next Jan. 1.

description: ABOARD U.S.S. BLUE RIDGE in the South China Sea, May 4The last day began precisely at 4 A.M. On April 29, Saigon awoke to the heaviest rocket attack of the war. First six rockets, then 22, then dozens more slammed into Tan Son Nhut airport.

title: INQUIRY IS ENDING WITH DIG AT I.R.S.
description: The United States Attorney for the Eastern District here said yesterday that his investigation of the finances of a metropolitanarea political figure was nearing completion but had been delayed because of what he called a lack of full cooperation by the Internal Revenue Service.

description: WASHINGTON, May 4 There is growing evidence on the public record that Howard Hughes's Summa Corporation and not the Federal Government, may be the owner of the Hughes Glomar Explorer, a secret ship designed to recover a sunken Soviet submarine from the midPacific.

title: Of Pockets and Rubber Stamps
description: ALBANYIt is now part of conventional wisdom that publicutility regulators are In the pocket of the utility companies, and that they do nothing but rubberstamp company proposals to raise rates.

title: Advertising
description: The nation, despite Its buffeting by the economy and foreign events, does indeed have something to be grateful for is it approaches its 200th birthday. Neither Playboy, Penthouse, Playgirl, Players nor Oui is planning any editorial features marking the Bicentennial. Count your blessings.

title: Crampton Takes Houston Golf
description: HOUSTON, May 4 (AP)Bruce Crampton, the pokerfaced Australian turned back repeated challenges by Dr. Gil Morgan with a carefully constructed 69 and scored a twostroke victory today in the Houston open golf tournament.

description: Caron Marie Giebel, daughter of Mr and Mrs. John C. Giebel of West Hempstead, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to John P. Gibbons, son of Justice David T. Gibbons of the State Supreme Court and Mrs. Gibbons of West Hempstead.

description: The United States, according to senior Defense Department officials, has begun a review of its military position in the world after the defeat of South Vietnam's government forces.

description: Gertrude Evelyn Bell, daughter of the Rev and Mrs. R. Kenneth Bell of San Jose, Calif., was married here yesterday evening to Dr. Mark R. Chartrand 3d of New York, son of Mrs. Chartrand Jr of Miami and the late Mr. Chartrand.

title: Ramirez, Gottfried Win Doubles
description: MEXICO CITY, May 4 (UPI) Raul Ramirez of Mexico and Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., won the World Championship Tennis doubles tournament today, beating Cliff Drysdale, formerly of South Africa and Mark Cox of Britain, 76, 67, 62. 76.

title: Second Heart is Implanted In South African Patient
description: CAPE TOWN, May 5 (UPI) A second heart was implanted today in a South African man in an allnight operation performed by a young Belgian surgeon at Groote Schuur Hospital.

title: N.H.L.Playoffs
description: Islanders vs. Philadelphia

title: CAUTION REPLACES CREDIT EUPHORIA
description: The euphoria that swept the bond markets late last week gave way to caution yesterday. As a result, prices of fixedinterest securities showed only modest gains on the day, if they Rained at all.

title: RULING SUPPORTS 6 NURSING HOMES
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled in Brooklyn yesterday that the refusal by nursing homes officials to admit state safety inspectors was not so serious an offense as to warrant the lifting of their licenses.

title: What Career Should She Choose? Counseling Group Helps
description: Deirdre Garton, 24 years old, a Vassar graduate with two young daughters, had known for some time that she wanted to be more than housewife and mother. But she felt she couldn't do anything about it until the children were older; one child not yet 3 and the other was only 10 months.

title: House Votes Spending Curb For Presidential Homes
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI)  The House passed by a unanimous 352to0 vote and sent to the Senate today measure that would place limitations on the amount of money that can be spent on security for Presidential homes.

title: Litco Corp. Reaches Agreement To Acquire Long Island Trust
description: The Litco Corporation 61 New York, a onebank holding company owning all the shares of the Long Island Trust Company, reached yesterday a tentative agreement to acquire the Long Island National Bank of Hicksville. T h e acquisition price was $18.8million, or $37 a share for each of the 509,374 shares of the Long Island National bank. Part of the purchase price is to be paid in cash and the rest through issuance by Litco of per cent subordinated convertible debentures payable in five equal annual installments beginning one year after completion of the transaction.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: 3 ON RESERVE UNIT SOUGHT MONEY SPUR
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee sought at its meeting on March 18 to speed up the growth of the nation's money supply, but not fast enough to suit three dissenters on the committee, it was disclosed today.

title: Appellate Division Upholds Conviction Of Alice Crimmins
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn confirmed yesterday in a 3to2 decision the manslaughter conviction of Alice Crimmins in the 1965 death of her 4yearolddaughter, Alice Marie.

title: Notes on People
description: Overruled on the choice of a new Marine Corps commandant, Gen. Robert E. Cushman Jr., the present commandant, and Gen. Earl E. Anderson, assistant commandant, have applied for retirement July 1, Pentagon sources said yesterday.

title: School Vote Today
description: The quality of the city's schools depends in large measure on the effectiveness of the 32 Community School Boards. Today, all permanently registered voters as well as all registered parents of children in their districts public schools are eligible to cast their votes for the men and women who will make school policy for the next two years.

title: Stocks Continue Climb; Dow Up by 7.12 to 855.60
description: The stock market registered its fourth consecutive advance yesterday in lighter trading after prices eased on profit taking earlier in the day.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press dispatch that appeared in The New York Times March 9 contained erroneous information about the views of Dr. James D. Watson, biologist and Nobel laureate, on cancer research. A corrective article appears on Page 10.

title: The Islander Who's Shooting 0 for 41
description: When the New York Islanders were returning from Philadelphia last week on their chartered bus, Bob Nystrom suddenly put down the copy of Jaws that he had been reading. Into his consciousness, as haunting as a great white shark, floated the memory of having failed to score again, this time on a breakaway in overtime of the Stanley Cup game that night that the Flyers had won. If I'd scored, I would've been a hero, he said to himself, staring into the darkness beyond the bus window. If, if, if. He's still staring. During the National Hockey League season, Thore Robert Nystrom, born in Sweden, raised in Kamloops, British Columbia, lionized in the Nassau Coliseum, with flowing blond hair, black eyebrows and a scarred square jaw, led the Islanders with 27 goals. But in 13 playoff games against the New York Rangers, the Pittsburgh Penguins and the Flyers, the 22yearold right wing has taken 41 shots without scoring. That might or might not be a Stanley Cup record. But thankfully, the N.H.L. hasn't yet turned a computer loose in its dusty archives. Thankfully for all those people who really don't care. And thankfully for Bob Nystrom who really doesn't want to know.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Ford asked Congress yesterday for $507million to pay for the resettlement of 150,000 refugees from South Vietnam over the next 28 months. The Administration has already committed $98million, taken from other Federal funds, for the evacuation of refugees who fled the Communist takeover in South Vietnam. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Yanks Lose, 31, As Hunter Fails
description: BALTIMORE, May 5 The baseball season is still young, but so far it has not been Catfish Hunter's season.

title: Market Averages
description: Monday, May 5, 1975 THE NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE

title: French Major Reported Killed by Rebels in Chad
description: PARIS, May 5 Moslem rebels in northern Chad recently executed a French army major, one of three hostages they were holding for ransom, according to a reporter for the Paris newspaper Le Figaro.

title: $250,000 in Political Gifts by Northrop Detailed in Documents Filed With S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) The Northrop Corporation made contributions totaling $250,000 over 10 years to a variety of Democratic and Republican political figures, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Schedule of New Tolls Charged by Port Agency
description: Following is the toll schedule that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey put into effect yesterday for its six bridges and tunnels the George Wash ingtcn Bridge, Lincoln and Holland Tunnels, Bayonne and Goethals Bridges and the Outerbridge Crossing: Basic roundtrip cashtoll $ 1.50 Commuter monthly 20trip ticket $20 Commuter monthly 60trip carpool ticket (three to car, good weekdays only) $30 Truck toll $ 1.50 and up (depending on size) Bus toll (unchanged) $ 1.80

title: City Ballet is Having Fun With Ravel
description: The keeper of Sesame Street's Big Bird is hard at work on the animal costumes for a production of the New York City Ballet's Ravel festival next week. And in Daphnis and Chloe, the French composer's most famous ballet, the onceGreek heroine will be surrounded bygirls in hot pants.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Roone Arledge, president of ABC Sports, defended yesterday his decision not to have his network announcers give an immediate explanation of Chick Anderson's wrong call of the Kentucky Derby. Anderson, the regular Churchill Downs track announcer, had Prince Thou Art in the lead for the last part of Saturday's race before realizing his mistake and correcting it to Foolish Pleasure for the Derby crowd and millions of television viewers.

title: HOMEOWNERS ASK REDLINING CURB
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 More than 150 representatives of homeowners in 20 cities and older suburbs that are threatened by redlining voiced strong support today for a Senate bill requiring public disclosure of the savings and investment patterns of banks and savings and loan associations throughout the country.

title: N L to Shut Jersey Plant
description: N L Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it was temporarily discontinuing production at its titanium pigment plant at Sayreville, N.J., to adjust inventories. The company said approximately 690 employes would be laid off and shipments to customers would he made from present stocks. Production will continue at the compery's other plant at St. Louis.

title: Nigerian Visitor Reports Loss of $148,058 in Case
description: A Nigerian businessman told the police here yesterday that a chance woman acquaintance he had invited to his WaldorfAstoria Hotel room left before he woke and that his attache case containing $148.058 was also gone.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Public Advocate filed suit yesterday to halt construction at an American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation office complex in Basking Ridge, because, he asserted, it would harm the environment. Stanley C. Van Ness, the public Advocate, said it was the first legal action taken under a fivemonthold Environmental Rights Act.

title: Pakistanis Fate in Doubt
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 5 A group of Pakistani refugees, released Saturday by the Cambodian Communists, have been refused entry into Thailand and may be returned to Cambodia, according to diplomatic and relief officials.

title: Alvarez del Vayo Dead; Spanish Republican Aide
description: Julio Alvarez del Vayo, Foreign Minister of Republican Spain from 1936 to 1939, died Friday in Geneva, where he was living in exile, according to word received here yesterday. He was 84 years old.

title: Assemblyman's Close Reading Defeats Rise in 25c Insurance
description: ALBANY, May 5 The life insurance that the poor buy from a doortodoor salesman, at 25 or 50 cents a week, would have cost more under an unobtrusive bill on a crowded Assembly calendar today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Levitz's April Sales Down
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporation, Miami, reported yesterday that its April sales declined 17.8 per cent to $24.6million from $30million in April, 1974. Sales for the first quarter ended April 30 were down 20.4 per cent to $71.3million from $89.6million the year before. The warehouse furniture chain had 60 units in operation on April 30 compared with 55 the year before.

title: D. BRUCE BURNS OF GUARD AGENCY
description: D. Bruce Burns, chairman of the executive committee of Burns International Security Services, Inc., died in his sleep Sunday night at his home in Briarcliff Manor, N. Y. He was 53 years old.

title: Fireman Saves Man On Edge of Bridge Over Belt Parkway
description: A Brooklyn fireman yesterday rescued a 19yearold, 200pound man who threatened to jump from a bridge over the Belt Parkway, but he suffered leg injuries when the rope lowering him and the wouldbe jumper broke and spilled them on to the roadway below, the Fire Department reported.

title: FUTURES PRICES IN GRAINS DECLINE
description: Grain and soybean futures contracts were weak yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: BARBARA K. CARY
description: Barbara Knapp Cary, an associate editor of Reader's Digest, died Sunday in University Hospital. She was 63 years old and lived in Wilton, Conn.

title: Theater: Two Contrasts
description: In Richard Wesley's The Past is the Past a son tries to come to terms with an absent father. In Oyamo's The Breakout, two young black convicts challenge the repressiveness of society (in and out of prison). These contrasting plays  the first, naturalistic, the second, more suggestive and symbolic are on a double bill at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: Article 4  No Title
U.S. Is Recovering Planes That Got Out to Thailand
description: WASINGTON, May 5  The Defense Department disclosed today that the United States had started removing from Thailand many of the 120 planes flown there by fleeing South Vietnamese pilots last week before the Communists took control in Saigon.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY UNDER SCRUTINY
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) Concerned with largerthanexpected deficits in the Social Security system, the Administration is drafting legislation to restore the shortrange soundness of the program, the Social Security commissioner, James B. Cardwell, said today social Security payments in the 1975 calendar year will exceed income from payroll taxes by $3billion, Mr. Cardwell said. This is cause for concern but not, alarm, he observed at a news briefing.

title: Mills, Back at Post, Makes a Sobriety Vow
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Tanned and seemingly fit, Representative Wilbur D. Mills returned to Congress today, preaching the evils of alcohol as zealously as he once guided tax legislation through the House.

title: Brooklyn College Gets Berkshire Arts Center
