description: Indian Hill, a center in the southern Berkshires for summer study in the performing arts, has been donated to the Brooklyn College Foundation by Irma and Mordecai Bauman.

title: Homosexual Rally Pressures Council For a Rights Law
description: The Gay Activists Alliance rallied in City Hall Park yesterday for passage by the City Council of a civil rights bill for homosexuals in housing, employment and public accommodations.

title: Events Today ;Theater
description: SUGAR MOUTH SAM DON'T DANCE NO MORE and ORPIN by Don ??? the Negro Ensemble Company's A Season. Wilhin.a Season production at the St. Marks Playhouse, 133 Second Avenue, B. through May 11.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: CHIEFS IN SAIGON EXTEND DEADLINE
description: The military committee governing Saigon announced yesterday that it had extended until the end of the month the deadline for all officials and soldiers of the former South Vietnamese Government to turn themselves in.

title: Abduction Unproven
description: The police investigating the holdup and abduction story of a 9yearold Russian girl at the Soviet diplomatic residence in Riverdale said they were unable to find corroboration of her account. Page 35.

title: Governor Signs Repeal Of the Fair Trade Law
description: ALBANY, May 5 Declaring that there could not be more important bipartisan effort against inflation, Governor Carey today signed into law a bill repealing the state's 35  year  old Fair Trade Law.

title: SPEER SEES A LAG IN ECONOMIC GAIN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said today he believed the nation's economic recovery would be slower than some business leaders have predicted and he forecast that total steel industry shipments this year would lag 15 to 20 per cent below the levels of 1973 and 1974.

title: Nation's Wheat Crop Heading for a Record
description: LIBERAL, Kan. Farmers all across the flat vastness of the Great Plains are looking at what may well be the largest wheat crop ever grown in this country, possibly more than two billion bushels.

title: Soviet Delegate in Peking For Border Talks Leaves
description: PEKING, May 5 Leonid F. Ilyichev, head of the Soviet delegation to the deadlocked ChineseSoviet border talks, left Peking today for Moscow, diplomatic sources said.

title: SOME IN CONGRESS WARY ON ARMS CUT
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Congressional liberals and moderates, having held their ground against the Ford Administration on the issue of aid to Indochina, are backing away from their earlier intention of challenging the Administration anew with attempts to make record cuts in defense spending and to reduce overseas forces.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Tenderness, Hatred and Grief Mark Saigon s Last Days
description: ABOARD the U.S.S. MOBILE, in the South China Sea, May 3 Like a failed marriage, the VietnameseAmerican relationship of the last generation has ended in mixture of hatred and suspicion, coupled with a strong remnant of tenderness and compassion on both sides.

title: Story of Russian Girl, 9, Uncorroborated by Police
description: The police investigating a 9yearold Russian girl's story of a holdup and abduction by skimasked bandits at the Soviet diplomatic residence in Riverdale said yesterday that they had been unable to find corroboration for the child's account.

title: Cards Trounce Phils, 113, For Gibson's First Victory
description: The St. Louis Cardinals provided Bob Gibson with his first victory of the campaign last night in Busch Stadium as they routed the Philadelphia Phils. 113. Gibson increased his career victory total to 249, most by an active pitcher.

title: Chile Tries Shock Treatment for Lagging EconOmY
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 5. After 20 months in power, the military junta has been unable to brake Chile's inflation, the world's worst, or control the highest unemployment in a generation.

title: Dividends
description: Pe Slk of Pay riod Pale Record abl

title: Dance for 3 Mortals and 2 Gods Is Presented by Meredith Monk
description: The fabulist choreographer Meredith Monk has tackled ultimate meaning in her new Small Scroll, a work involving three mortals and two gods. The results were uncharacteristically meager for so large an undertaking, but the accompanying work, Anthology, had a lean force that showed Miss Monk actively involved with movement design again rather than space blocking. Both were given at St. Mark'sin  theBouwerie on Sunday.

title: John Smith Back On Right Track
description: Three years after he thought he had an Olympic gold medal wrapped up, John Smith is stepping back into the starting blocks as the world's finect quartermiler, amateur or professional.

title: Agencies Offering Aid To Refugees Are Listed
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) L. Dean Brown, director of the Interagency Task Force for Vietnamese Refugee Relief, listed today the following voluntary agencies accepting private contributions or offers of resettlement for the refugees:

title: H.E.W. Official to Join Thompson
description: The word around the healthcare advertising field was that J. Walter Thompson was bringing in a heavyweight to take over that facet of its operation. Yesterday the agency announced the name Dr. Henry E. Simmons, deputy assistant Secretary of Health in the Department Health, Education and Welfare.

title: A.B.A. Championship
description: Indiana vs. Kentucky

title: Big Oil Companies to Lose Tax Break in California
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 5 An end is near for a California law that for 45 years allowed major oil companies to deduct 22 per cent of their profits before they calculated state income taxes.

title: Ovation on Seventh Avenue, for a SelfEffacing Designer
description: Seventh Avenue had its first big roaring success of the fall season. It happened at the Geoffrey Beene show yesterday, which ended with one of those rarities an ovation. It took a lot of applause until Mr. Beene, one of those rare, retiring designing gentlemen, was persuaded to take a bow.

title: Blast at ProPalestinian Paper In Beirut Injures 4 Employes
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 5 Four men were injured in an explosion today at the offices of the daily newspaper Al Moharrer, which supports the Palestinian guerrilla movement.

title: Spring Upturn Not Evident Imports Up
description: DETROIT, May 5  The United States auto industry, with no spring sales upturn in sight, sold only 517,637 new cars last month, a 26.3 per cent decline from the 702,338 sold a year earlier.

title: Miss Carillo Gains Eastern Net Final
description: SYOSSET, L.I., May 5 Mary Carillo, 18yearold defending champion, reached the final of the Eastern women's hardcourt tennis championship at the Syosset Racquet Club today. Rain forced the match indoors after it had been scheduled at the Woodbury Country Club.

title: Feuds and Bad Planning In Saigon Exit Recalled
description: MANILA, May 5  Although more than 100,000 Vietnamese successfully escaped from Saigon, the evacuation was marred by what diplomats and newsmen now recall as bad planning, bitter feuding between sections of the United States Mission and often an everymanforhimself attitude.

title: Aviation Thefts on Rise
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 5 (UPI)  The advisory board chairma nof the newly formed National Aviation Theft Bureau says aviation is providing a fertile new field for thieves. R. S. Hirsch, also a partner in a local insurance company that specializes in aviation insurance, says about $63million year is lost in stolen aircraft and aviation equipment.

title: RCA and Sylvania Will Raise TV Prices
description: The new lines or television sets, soon to be shown to distributors, will apparently cost more than this year's models.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press dispatch that appeared in The New York Times March 9 contained erroneous information about the views of Dr. James D. Watson, biologist and Nobel laureate, on cancer research. A corrective article appears on Page 10.

title: Biographical Sketches of Those Selected by jurors for Pulitzer Prizes for 1975
description: Has worked on a halfdozen major investigations with James R. Steele, his fellow Philadelphia Inquirer reporter and cowinner, in the last four years and received a dozen national reporting awards, including two George Polks and a Sidney Hillman, for them. Investigations have included Philadelphia criminal courts, oil industry, Federal Housing Administration, United States foreign aid program and Internal Revenue Service, for which the Pulitzer was given. Born July 17, 1936, in DuBois, Pa., grew up in Johnstown, Pa., attended Pennsylvania State University and wanted to be a newspaperman since he was a teenager. Worked on The Reading (Pa.) Times and The Akron Beacon Journal aa generalassignment reporter and The Cleveland Plain Dealer and The Chicago Daily News as investigative reporter before being recruitmnt.

title: Olympic Bill Introduced
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) Senator John V. Tunney, Democrat of California, introduced legislation today calling for creation of a ninemember commission to review United States participation in the Olympic Games. Tunney said the review was necessary because of administrative bungling, inflexibility and petty nationalism at the Munich Games of 1972.

title: Religious Thinkers Feel Christian Theology Demands Changes
description: Christian theology as it has evolved in the West is largely untenable and requires radical transformation to restore its verve and potency, according to several respondants in al symposium featured in the current issue of the nondenominational biweekly, Christianity & Crisis.

title: 10 Hurt in L. I. Bus Crash
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I., May 5 (UPI) Ten persons including four plainview, L. I., Junior High School students were injured this afternoon when a school bus struck three cars and a truck at Old Country Road and Park Avenue. The Nassau County police said only the driver remained hospitalized. He was Andrew Poggioli. 30 years old, of West Hempstead.

title: Bills on Environment Debated at Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 The issue of whether the states or the Federal Government should be given the paramount role in overseeing environmental protection was debated inconclusively today before a joint meeting of two Senate groups.

title: Plan for Castration of 2 Child Molesters Is Opposed by Coast Medical Societies
description: SAN DIEGO. May 6 A judge's approval of requests by two convicted child molesters that they be castrated, as an alternative to spending perhaps the rest of their lives in prison, has run into almost solid opposition from San Diego's medical societies.

title: Level of Credit to Consumers Fell in March
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 The decline in consumer credit resumed in March after a brief upturn in February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Malpractice Fever
description: ALBANY, May 5 Assemblyman Leonard a Silverman tried to spend yesterday at home in bed, enervated, he said, from an advanced case of searching fruitlessly for a compromise on the medical malpractice issue. As it happened, physicians telephoned Mr. Silverman, who is chairman of the insurance committee, throughout the day, but this morning the issue still haunted the Brooklyn Democrat, the rest of the Legislature, Governor Carey and most of the state's physicians, who face loss of malpractice insurance coverage as of July 1.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS REFUNDS ON RENT
description: The State Court of Appeals has affirmed that tenants of an estimated total of 80,000 rentcontrolled apartments here are entitled to refunds of more than $1million in rent increases they paid last year.

title: YEW SAIGON REGIME CALLS FOR HEALING
description: PARIS, Tuesday, May 6 (Reuters) A spokesman for South Vietnam's Provisional Revolutionary Government said today that hatred and divisions still persist within South Vietnamese families and these are the first postwar wounds which must be healed.

title: Jeremy McGeary Weds Alison S. Busby
description: St. Paul's Anglican Church in Falmouth, Antigua, was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Alison Sears Busby to Jeremy McGreary. The ceremony was performed by Canon Frederick E. Charman.

title: Kissinger Denies Involvement In Domestic Spying by C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he and the National Security Council had had no involvement in any domestic operations of the Central Intelligence Agency and that he had never transmitted to the agency any feeling of concern about domestic security on the part of President Nixon.

title: 16 Months in Steak Theft
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, May 5 (UPI) The State Court of Criminal Appeals ruled today that 16 months in prison was enough for a man convicted of stealing two steaks. The court upheld the larceny conviction of Lloyd Sedric New ton, and said his fiveyear sentence should be modified to the time he had served in prison. 16 months.

title: Feuds and Bad Planning In Saigon Exit Recalled
description: MANILA, May 5  Although more than 100,000 Vietnamese successfully escaped from Sail gon, the evacuation was marred by what diplomats and newsmen now recall as bad planning, bitter feuding between sections of the United States Mission and often an everymanforhimself attitude.

title: WESTCHESTER JURY CLEARS OFFICIALS
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 5  A Westchester County grand jury today cleared a former Greenburgh supervisor, Nicholas Russo, and other town officials of allegations of corruption.

title: 74 Gifts to U.S. Charities Set Record, But Rise is Less Than Cost Increases
description: Despite the troubled economy, Americans gave more than $25billion to charitable organizations last year a record amount, according to the American Association of FundRaising Counsel, Inc.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Horses listed in order of past positions Letter desigr ates OTB listing

title: Pulitzer Prizes Awarded 2 Biographers and Albee
description: Two contrasting biographies carried off 1975 Pulitzer prizes yesterday Robert A. Caro's controversial and current The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York, and the first five volumes of Jefferson and His Time by Dumas Malone. At 83 years of age, Mr. Malone, who was honored for history, is the oldest person to win Pulitzer Prize.

title: Miss Heldman Gives U.S. Lead in Federation Cup
description: AIX EN PROVENCE, France, May 5 (AP) Julie Heldman, captain of the United States team, defeated Eva Emmenagger of Switzerland, 62, 60, in the opening round of the Federation Cup. the women's international team tennis championship.

title: CINCINNATI ENQUIRER BRINGS $30MILLION
description: CINCINNATI, May 5 (AP) The Cincinnati Enquirer has been sold by the American Financial Corporation to the Combined Communications Corporation for $30million in cash and a large amount of stock.

title: Higher Tolls Jam Hudson Crossings
description: Continued From Page 1, Col. 1

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: American League

title: FRANK L. WALTON
description: Frank L. Walton, retired executive vice president of Catlin Farish Company, textiles, a division of Burlington Industries, who was chief of the textile, clothing and leather division of the War Production Board in World War II, died Sunday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 84 years old and lived at 18 Dellwood Road, Bronxville.

title: Abduction Unproven
description: The police investigating the holdup and abduction story of a 9yearold Russian girl at the Soviet diplomatic residence in Riverdale said they were unable to find corroboration of her account. Page 35.

title: H.U.D TOLD BY POOR OF HOUSING FAULTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 A new breed of slumlord, who often works with the unintentional assistance of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, is victimizing many poor and modest income city dwellers, according to testimony here today by spokesmen for tenants.

title: CON ED IS REFUSED INTERIM RATE RISE
description: The State Public Service Commission yesterday turned down, without a hearing, a request by the Consolidated Edison Company for a temporary rate increase of 8.8 pet cent.

title: City Inspectors Find Health Law Violated In 17 Food Places
description: The Health Department has citd 17 more food businesses for failing their second Health Code Inspection and warned that they face closing orders if the violations persisted upon a third and final inspection. The names of the establishments and the dispositions follow:

title: CocaCola Profits Rise 14.7%; Higher Costs Lift Sales 31.5%
description: The CocaCola Company reported yesterday that its firstquarter net increased by 14.7 per cent to a record total of $46.8million, equal to 78 cents a share. A year ago the world's largest softdrink producer reported earnings of $40.6million, or 68 cents a share, in the initial three months.

title: Steel Production Fell 2.1% in Week To a Low for Year
description: Steel production for the week ended May 3 fell to its lowest weekly level of 1975, according to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: State Denies Charges On Flu Deaths in Home
description: TRENTON, May 5 A high state health official denied today that 30 of 60 elderly intensive care patientshad died of influenza at a large South Jersey nursing home last winter.

title: Offshore Drilling Backed in Coast Poll
description: LOS ANGELES, May 5 In spite of widespread controversy over offshore oil development, a statewide public opinion survey indicates that a majority of Californians are in favor of it.

title: Books of The Times
description: I was so taken by Peter Mathiessen's last novel, At Play in the Fields of the Lord, that I read it three times with undiminished pleasure. I must have bought a dozen copies for friends, because it is book for all occasions illness, traveling, divorce, or just reading for its own sake. Though I was never enthusiastic about any of Mr. Mathiessen's other books, I felt that, with At Play in the Fields of the Lord, he had found himself as a writer. I could not imagine his turning out an uninteresting book after it, and I have been looking forward to Far Tortuga for six months.

title: NATHAN HELLER
description: Nathan Heller, deputy state rent administrator and chief counsel for the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission in the nineteenfifties, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived here.

title: Antiwar Suit is Lost
description: A jury in Charlotte, N. C., found H. R. Haldeman and eight others not guilty in $1million civil suit of illegally barring antiwar demonstrators from a Billy Graham Day rally attended by President Nixon in 1971. Page 11.

title: President Says Martin Did Well in Evacuation
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (Reuters) President Ford today stood behind Ambassador Graham A. Martin, who supervized the evacuation of Americans and thousands of South Vietnamese hours before Saigon fell to the Communists.

title: Carol Simkin, Lawyer, Wed to Daniel Berke
description: Carol Faye Simkin, a lawyer with Cowan, Liebowitz & Latman, and Daniel Edwards Berke, who is in the realestate business, were married here at noon yester day. Rabbi Bruce Cole performed the ceremony in his study at the East End Temple.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, May 5, 1975

title: HUMPHREY DENIES HE KNEW OF GIFT
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey testified yesterday at the trial of his former campaign manager that as a candidate for the Senate in 1970 he sought the support of the Associated Milk Producers, Inc. But he said he had no personal knowledge of the illegal contribution that Jack L. Chestnut, the former aide, is accused of taking from the dairy cooperative.

title: BLIND BOY, 5, FALLS TO DEATH OFF ROOF
description: A 5yearold blind boy plunged to his death yesterday afternoon from the roof of the Brooklyn apartment house where he lived, the police said.

title: Cipher Debunked But Not Decoded
description: A mysterious cryptogram, long thought to contain medieval alchemist's secret to eternal life, has been determined by a Yale professor to be most likely the work of a 16thcentury forger.

title: SKIRTSONLY EDICT CALLED JUDICIAL
description: HACKENSACK, May 5 An attorney for Gill C. Job argued that Mr. Job, the Bergen County Surrogate, was exercising judicial discretion when he sent two female employes home to change into dresses after they had reported to the office wearing pants.

title: WAR PROTEST SUIT LOST IN CAROLINA
description: CHARLOTTE N. C., May 5A jury took just under two hours today to conclude that no constitutional rights had been violated by any of nine defendants accused in a $1million civil suit of systematically and illegally barring antiwar demonstrators from a Billy Graham Day rally attended by President Nixon in 1971.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city's Finance Administration started a computer service for public access to realestatetax records. The monthly charge will be $100 and an individual request $2. The service is expected to bring in $250,000 a year. The administration also increased other fees to bring in an additional $20,450, for a total of $39,650 from fees. The charge for a replacement of a tax receipt was increased from 50 cents to $3; for certification of a tax lien purchase, 50 cents to $10, and for a certified duplicate of transfer of a tax lien, $2 to $10.

title: Electricians Training is Decertified
description: State Industrial Commissioner Louis L. Levine has deregistered a training program for electricians that failed over 13 years to qualify as journeymen any of 500 participating apprentices.

title: City Marshaling Its Statistics to Lure the Democratic Convention
description: While visions of freespending Democrats dance in the heads of New York City officials and merchants, teams of professionals are quietly compiling the blueprints, hotel inventories and other information needed to persuade the party to hold its national convention here next year.

title: Article 1  No Title
COURTS INTENSIFY ROLES IN ZONING
description: PISCATAWAY TOWNSHIP, N.J., May 5A fivevolume study of American landplanning law, released here today, concludes that judicial activism In zoning and planning is increasng because the courts are suspcious of local boards that grant too many variances in negation of local zoning ordinances.

title: TENSE ANGOLA CITY GETS FOOD SUPPLIES
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 4 (Reuters) The Portuguese Air Force today began flying food from provincial centers to the Angolan capital of Luanda, where over 500 people have been reported killed in five days of fighting.

title: L.I. Building Chief Indicted Over a House Gratuity
description: RIVERHEAD, May 5 Suffolk County's Buildings and Grounds Commissioner, who makes final recommendations for the acquisition of all property for the county, was indicted here today on charges of soliciting and receiving as a gratuity rentfree occupancy of a $50,000 house from a real  estate developer for whom he had obtained multimilliondollar contracts.

title: V.S.WillProvide Jordan With Defensive Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The United States has reached final agreement with Jordan on the the disclosure of the Hawk defense system, a State Department official said today.

title: SOME IN CONGRESS WARY ON ARMS CUT
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Congressional liberals and moderates, having held their ground against the Ford Administration on the issue of aid to Indochina, are backing away from their earlier intention of challenging the Administration anew with attempts to make record cuts in defense spending and to reduce overseas forces.

title: FORD WILL OPPOSE NOFAULT STANDARD
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr told Congress today that the Administration would oppose efforts to set Federal standards for nationwide enactment of nofault auto insurance.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Saving Water
description: Taking a shower in New York City could scarcely qualify as an unusual experience, but while doing just that a short time ago, I had what might be described as a vision.

title: Schedule of New Tolls Charged by Port Agency
description: Following is the toll schedule that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey put into effect yesterday for its six bridges and tunnels the George Washington Bridge. Lincoln and Holland Tunnels, Bayonne and Goethels Bridges and the Outerbridge Crossing:

title: HUMPHREY DENIES HE KNEW OF GIFT
description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey testified yesterday at the trial of his former campaign manager that as a candidate for the Senate in 1970 he sought the support of the Associated Milk Producers, Inc. But he said he had no personal knowledge of the illegal contribution that Jack L. Chestnut, the former aide, is accused of taking from the dairy cooperative.

title: Workers Save Boy, 2 Trapped in Florida Well
description: MIAMI. May 5 (AP) Rescue ??? using mechanized shovels burrowed into a well tonight and extricated a 2yearold boy who had been trapped 10feet down for five hours.

title: BERNARD EDER, PUBLISHER, DEAD
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., May 5 (AP) Bernard H. Ridder, chairman emeritus of Ridder, chairman emeritus of Ridclay 't St. Mary's Hospital here. He was 92 years old.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
description: BOSTON (A.)

title: Joint Venture Planned
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 5 In a joint venture with Iranian businessmen, the General Motors Corporation is to build one of the world's largest truck manufacturing plants in Iran, with an eventual capacity of 335,000 vehicles a year, the Government news agency reported today.

title: Ky Lands in California; Seeks Leadership Role
description: EL TORO MARINE AIR STATION, Calif., May 5 Nguyen Cao Ky, the former Premier and Vice President of South Vietnam, joined thousands of other South Vietnamese in California tonight and indicated he would seek a leadership role among them.

title: A Neutral Diplomat In France Expects Sternness in Saigon
description: PARIS, May 5  A neutral diplomat with long involvement in Indochinese affairs said today that the speed and extent of the Communist military victory in Vietnam appeared to have dealt a grave blow to hopes for a moderate approach to the unification of the country and a political role for nonCommunist elements in the South.

title: TOCKS DAM STUDY POINTS TO OPTIONS
description: TRENTON, May 5 A reevaluation for Congress of the proposed Tocks Island dam has found there are practical, less expensive alternatives for providing flood control, water supply and recreation for the Delaware River region.

title: Hathaway Says Statement of Record Was Not Always Accurate
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Stanley K. Hathaway, Secretary of the Interiordesignate, acknowledged today that a statement circulated to members of the Senate Interior Committee about his environmental record as Governor of Wyoming was not always balanced or completely accurate.

title: A Hero's Welcome Given To Vasquez at Aqueduct
description: Jacinto Vasquez was a hero to his own colleagues, as well as to many of the 18,977 fans, at Aqueduct yesterday. On arriving at the jockey quarters, the 30yearold Vasquez received a spontaneous ovation from the other riders. Among the greeters were several rivals who finished back of Vasquez Saturday, when he rode John Greer's Foolish Pleasure to success in the 101st Kentucky Derby.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Serenade No. I for Strings, Antheil; Rhasody in Blue, Gershwin; Western Suite, Siegmeister.

title: The Dance: City Ballet Does Balanchine's jewels
description: It was downright fascinating Sunday afternoon to see the New York City Ballet dancing George Balanchine's Jewels at the New York State Theater, after a number of evenings spent across the plaza where the Bolshoi Ballet is holding court at the Metropolitan Opera House. The background of both companies can be traced to a common dance tradition and even more, a similar major stylistic influence the Imperial Ballet of St. Petersburg, However, what each company, the New Yorkers and the Muscovites, has done with that heritage could form the text for an essay on artistic polarity.

title: Green Haven Inmates Ask Action In Death of TearGassed Convict
description: A group of inmates at the Green Haven Correctional Facility in Stormville, N. Y. has proposed to prison officials work stoppage by inmates pending full disclosure of circumstances surrounding the death on April 29 of a 47yearold inmate.

title: Sports Today ;BASEBALL
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow,. Queens, 8:05 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8 P.M.) (Radio WNEW, P.M.) Yankees vs. Orioles, at Baltimore. (Radio  WMCA, 7:30 P.M.)

title: REV. DR. SCHWEITZER
description: The Rev. Dr. Frederick Schweitzer, president emeritus of Bloomfield College and Seminary in Bloomfield, Ni, died yesterday at his home, 217 Hale Street, Pennington, N.J. He was 84 years old.

title: Confronted Nazi Spokesman
description: In 1933, a few months after the Nazi regime came to power in Germany, one Heinz Spanknoebel appeared in The StaatsHerold office here and showed Victor Ridder letters from the German Labor Front and the chief of the foreign division of the Nazi party, which, he told Mr. Ridder, gave the newcomer authority to assume power over the Germanlanguage press in the United States. His first order, Mr. Bidder testified in 1943 proceeding to void the citizenship of Nazis in this country, was to stop publishing your proJewish articles.

title: The Major Events of the Day
description: President Ford asked Congress yesterday for $507million to pay for the resettlement of 150,000 refugees from South Vietnam over the next 28 months, The Administration has already committed $98million, taken from other Federal funds, for the evacuation of refugees who fled the Communist takeover in South Vietnam. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Action on Decontrol in Domestic Supply Sought in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Senate Democratic sources said today that Democrats on the Commerce Committee had reached a compromise among themselves on partial decontrol of natural gas prices and that a bill could be reported to the floor as early as tomorrow.

title: CRAMEL EVIDENCE ORDERED SEALED
description: NEWARK, May 5 A State Superior Court judge said today that he would sign an order enjoining prosecution and defense lawyers from making public any material pertaining to the bidrigging case against J. Edward Crabiel, the New Jersey Secretary of State.

title: 2 Rare Fish Crows Killed in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (AP)  Two rare birds, discovered nesting last week in a downtown tree, were killed, apparently by someone using a shotgun.

title: Roosevelt Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax) FIRST$6,000, trot, mile.

title: MISS WOOD WARD, NEWMAN FETED
description: There was a large blue and white banner outside Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center last night Welcome Joanne Woodward and Paul Newman but evidently Tennessee Williams, the playwright, didn't see it.

title: Chess:
description: The first prize in the fifth annual Louis D. Statham tournament in Lone Pine, Calif., was won by Vladimir Liberzon, a 38yearold grandmaster who has emigrated to Israel from the Soviet Union. He scored 72 in the 10round Swiss system event.

title: M Ginnis Streaks, Stirs Dollar Talks
description: Every time George McGinnis comes down with a rebound, scores a basket, passes off for an assist, his asking price goes up. The powerfully built forward, whom the Indiana Pacers would like to keep and the Knicks and Philadelphia 76ers would like to sign, has suddenly become pro basketball's hottest property. He has almost singlehandedly taken the Pacers to the American Basketball Association championship final against the Kentucky Colonels.

title: BRANIFF DEFENDS PROMOTION FARES
description: DALLAS, May 5 Harding L. Lawrence, chairman and chief executive officer of Braniff Airways, said today that there was no intent to violate any Federal law when between 1969 and 1973 Braniff provided discounted fares and free transportation to travel agents n an effort to increase its share of the market for air travel to Latin America.

title: Lomenzo and Queens D A. Are Accused By Target of BriberyCharge Inquiry
description: A state official who described himself as the prime target of a Queens grand jury investigation charged yesterday that District Attorney Nicholas Ferraro of Queens and John P. Lomenzo, former New York Secretary of State, acted improperly and perhaps illegally  during the inquiry.

title: Kickback Figure is Freed
description: ALLENWOOD, Pa., May 5 (AP) Allen I. Green, an engineer who admitted paying kickbacks to former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, was released today after serving four months in prison for a Federal tax violation. Mr. Green said he had made the payments in return for state and county contracts in Maryland.

title: A Newspaper Venture In Glasgow is a Sellout
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, May 5 (AP)A workers cooperative was born in Glasgow when The Scottish Daily News appeared today. Its first printing of 300,000 copies sold out in a few hours.

title: United Fund Opens Annual Campaign Here
description: The United Fund of Greater New York opened its annual campaign for the benefit of hundreds of community agencies, including the Red Cross and the Salvation Army, at a luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

title: Divorce Around the World: Even When Easy, It Carries a Stigma
description: PARIS Last May's referendum on divorce. Italian style, reached heights of passion topped by the absurd. In Sicily, Amintore Fanfani, a former Premier who dominates the powerful Christian Democratic party, warned darkly that unless the divorce legislation were repealed, Italian wives would desert their men en masse to flee with lesbians.

title: OffHour Betting Gains in Trenton
description: TRENTON, May 5 The State Assembly voted 5210 today to expand parimutuel betting hours in the state, permitting their start at 8 A.M. Existing law restricts wagering between noon and 1 A.M.

title: District School Races to Be Decided Today
description: Amid a flurry of lastminute campaigning by candidates and maneuvers by opposing factions, preparations have been completed for today's schoolboard election in the city.

title: T.W.A. SEEKS HELP AND 5% FARE RISE
description: Trans World Airlines, whose January  through March loss was the largest quarterly loss in airline history, applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday for a domestic subsidy and a 5 per cent rise in domestic fares.

title: Cipher Debunked But Not Decoded
description: A mysterious cryptogram, long thought to contain medieval alchemist's secret to eternal life, has been determined by a Yale professor to be most likely the work of a 16thcentury forger.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HERITAGE Many Americans tend to think of the subject in terms of war catastrophe, but Jane HamiltonMerritt's new photography exhibition depicts Youth of Southeast Asia as basic products of an ancient civilitation rich in art and history. The accent is on traditional culture in the display starting today from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the Chemical Bank Building, 277 Park Avenue (at 48th Street). It shifts on. June 4 to the Chemical. branch at 1251 Avenue of the Americas (the Exxon Building); the hours are 9 A.M. toi 3 P.M.

title: Torre Connects at Army
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., May 5 When the New York Mets acquired Joe Torre from the St. Louis Cardinals last October, they knew they had acquired a proven major league hitter for the heart of their lineup. Over 14 National League seasons, the Brooklyn native had a 300 batting average and 240 home runs.

title: MSGR. FRANCIS CAGNINA
description: Msgr. Francis Cagnina, founder and pastor emeritus of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Clare of Assisi in the Bronx, died Sunday in the Mary Manning Walsh Home. He was 90 years old.

title: PRESIDENT ASKING FOR $507MILLION TO HELP REFUGEES
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 President Ford asked Congress today for $507million to pay for the resettlement of 150,000 refugees from Vietnam over the next 28 months.

title: A Grieving Refugee Says Her American Husband Rejects Her
description: EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., May 5  The pretty young woman slumped on the edge of her cot in the Vietnamese refugee compound here today, twisting the tiny gold band on the fourth finger of her left hand.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 President Ford's latest maneuver in his running power struggle with Congress over energy policy has thrust the issue of controls on oil prices to the center of the political stage.

title: Pulitzer Prizes Awarded 2 Biographers and Albee
description: Two contrasting biographies carried off 1975 Pulitzer prizes yesterday Robert A. Caro's controversial and current The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York, and the first five volumes of Jefferson and His Time by Dumas Malone. At 83 years of age, Mr. Malone, who was honored for history, is the oldest person ever to win a Pulitzer Prize.

title: Big Profit Drop Hurts Charity a Little
description: The drop in corporate profits has, quite predictably, had dampening effect on corporate philanthropy but, so far, not so bad as expected.

title: People in Sports
description: The loss of Catfish Hunter actually precipitated it, said Charles O. Finley, Oakland A's owner. He was talking about the A's decision to put Herb Washington, the major league's only fulltime pinchrunner on waivers yesterday in order to give the former Michigan State and pro track sprinter his unconditional release.

title: Transit Authority Names Its Counsel to No. 2 Post
description: John G. de Roos, 48yearold Dutchborn lawyer and transportation specialist, was named senior executive officer of the Transit Authority yesterday.

title: NorthSouth Golf Marked By Upsets
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May 5 (AP) George Burns, the defending champion, and Curtis Strange, both Walker Cup players, survived a wave of upsets in the opening round of the annual North and South amateur golf tournament today at the Pinehurst Country Club.

title: 36 Refugee Vessels At Singapore Await Food, Fuel, Water
description: SINGAGPORE, Tuesday, May 6 (Reuters) A total of 36 vessels with more than 6,500 South Vietnamese refugees aboard are in the port of Singagpore awaiting supplies of food, water and fuel, the Defense Ministry said last night. It, also said more refugee vessels were known to be heading here, but gave no details.

title: Bvrne's New Proposals: Income Tax or Increased Sales Levies
description: TRENTON, May 5The Byrne administration formally proposed two rival tax plans to the State Senate today.

title: Observatory to Devote All Its Time To a Study of XRay Emissions in Sky
description: What is believed to be the first observatory devoting full time to features associated with black holes and other sources of intense Xray emission has been established.

title: In memoriam
description: KROLL Danny. Memories of your gentle love grow more precious. Love YOU always.

title: VICTORS EMPTYING CAMBODIAN CITIES, U.S. NOW BELIEVES
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 State Department officials said today that they believed that the Cambodian Communists had forcibly evacuated virtually the entire population of Phnom Penh soon after they took power in the capital early last month.

title: Coors Will Offer Stock to Public
description: DENVER, May 5 Coors, the fourth largest, brewery in the country, today announced plans for the first sale of its stock to the public since the familyowned business was founded in 1873.

title: State Senate Panel Sets A Hearing on Arts Chief
description: Responding to expressed fears of political pressure on the New York State Council on the Arts, the Senate Finance Committee will hold a public hearing in Albany May 19 on the nomination of Joan K. Davidson, recently appointed by Governor Carey as chairman of the state agency.

title: SENATE APPROVES STRIP MINING BILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) The Senate approved today compromise bill to regulate coal strip mining similar to legislation President Ford vetoed last year.

title: Harvard TopSeeded In Rowing
description: If the college rowing coaches are correct then Harvard crews are going to dominate the Eastern sprint championships at Princeton on Sunday. Of the six Crimson crews, varsity, second varsity and freshman in both heavyweight and lightweight categories, all but the freshman heavyweights were seeded first yesterday by the Eastern coaches.

title: The Press and S.1
description: There is now under active consideration in the Senate Judiciary Committee a bill that constitutes a grave danger to freedom of the press and to the right of every citizen to know how his Government conducts foreign and military policy. Known in the Senate as S.1, it is sponsored by Senator McClellan, Arkansas Democrat, and has several bipartisan cosponsors including Senate Majority Leader Mansfield and Senate Minority Leader Scott. is questionable whether these members are aware the ominous implications of the measure to which they have attached their names.

title: Food Fund Gets U.S. and Saudi Pledges
description: GENEVA, May 5The United States and Saudi Arabia today promised substantial contributions to a new international fund to promote a big increase in food production in the developing countries, according to United Nations sources.

title: SENATORS OPPOSE FAIR TRADE LAWS
description: WASHINGTON May 5 The Senate Antitrust subcommittee approved today legislation that would have the effect of wiping out state fair trade laws.

title: PRESIDENT ASKING FOR $507MILLION TO HELP REFUGEES
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 President Ford asked Congress today for $507million to pay for the resettlement of 150,000 refugees from Vietnam over the next 28 months.

title: People and Business
description: The president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco; Maurice Mann, has taken a more hopeful view of the possible impact of substantial United States Treasury borrowing this year on interest rates generally than others who have spoken on the subject recently. Mr. Mann said yesterday at the annual meeting of the Society of American Business Writers in Washington that in view of the widespread slack in the economy, as well as diminished demand by private borrowers, the Treasury's financing needs need not necessarily adversely affect interest rates or the availability of credit.

title: J. DANA TASKER, 71, EXEDITOR OF TIME
description: J. Dana Tasker, who rose to executive editor of Time magazine in 1952 and was executive editor of Look and Quick magazines in 195354, died Sunday in a nursing home in his native Gardiner, Me. He was 71 years old.

title: Port Authority's Toll Increases Create Record Jams at Its Hudson Crossings
description: Record five mile tie ups snarled New Yorkbound traffic through eastern New Jersey for much of the day yesterday as angry motorists dug into their pockets for extra change to pay 50 per cent higher tolls on Hudson River crossings.

title: Moe Howard, 78, Last Survivor Of The Three Stooges, Is Dead
description: Moe Howard, the surviving member of the original knockaboutstyle comedy team of the Three Stooges, which has amused movie and television fans since 1930, died Sunday night of lung cancer in Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Woman Sues U.S. Over Raid On Tip About Patricia Hearst
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) A woman who said she had been frightened by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who forced their way into her apartment after getting a false tip on the whereabouts of Patricia Hearst filed a $500,000 damage claim against the Government today.

title: Dr. Feelgood
description: Henry Kissinger has told James Reston of The New York Times that he will not resign as Secretary of State. This is good news, if true, but can we rely on it?

title: BIOLOGIST ASSAYS CANCER RESEARCH
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, N.Y., May 5 (AP) All that can truthfully be said about cancer research right now is that at long last it can be very good science indeed.

title: Christmas in July
description: Some people might argue that lobbying groups that spend the majority of their time trying to rearrange the calendar might well seek more productive work. Not so.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WAITING TILL NEXT YEAR

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Choice for Portugal
description: Portugal's chances for peaceful progress toward political democracy, social reform and economic development now depend critically on the answer to one question:

title: Coors Going Public
description: The Adolph Coors Company, the nation's fourth largest brewer, plans the first sale of its stock to the public since its founding in 1873. Page 59.

title: Keating Dies at 74; Envoy, ExSenator
description: Kenneth B. Keating, Ambassador to Israel, former United States Senator from New York and Ambassador to India, died here yesterday at the Harkness Pavillion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 74 years old.

title: Rescuing the Wetlands
description: Among the many excellent environmental recommendations Governor Carey has just made to the Legislature, one of the most important and urgent is the proposal to preserve this state's remaining freshwater wetlands. The 4 per cent or so of New York that is marshland, bog or swamp may hold a low priority in the mind the average urban dweller, but without it he would be in real trouble.

title: Islanders Baffled By Flyers
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., May 5 For the New York Islanders it's like facing four match points in tennis with the other guy serving and he's John Newcombe.

title: Sets Meet Nets In Nassau Opener
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., May 5  The New York Sets, led by Billie Jean King, will open their home season in World Team Tennis tomorrow night against the Cleveland Nets in the second match of a doubleheader at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Increase by 60% Is to Be Implemented in Two Stages
description: OTTAWA, May 5 For the second time within eight months Canada has ordered a sharp increase in the price of natural gas sold to United States consumers, who take about 45 per cent of the Canadian output of the fuel.

title: TV Review
description: Anyone anxious to get a glimpse of this fall's new television season, the one supposedly devoted to family solidarity and social maturity, can tune into the NBCTV network this evening. Each of the madeforTV movies on the prime time double feature is being used as the basis for a new weekly series.

title: Congress's Inaction On War
description: WASHINGTON On Jan. 5,  1957, President Dwight D. Eisenhower, concerned about possible Communist advances in the Middle East, addressed joint session of Congress to request authority to use military force, needed, in the region.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: About the Yankees
description: In a roster change, Dave Pagan, a young relief pitcher, was recalled from Syracuse and waivers were asked on Eddie Leon, a reserve infielder. Thurman Munson, who had two singles in the loss to the Orioles, has hit safely in eight straight games and his average is 414. But Bobby Bonds has failed to hit in 16 times at bat and Jim Mason in 21. Mason's error, which cost a run against Baltimore, was his sixth. Graig Nettles, batting 207, has made seven errors. For the second of the threegame series at Baltimore tonight, the pitchers will be George Medich and Mike Cuellar.

title: England Bank Involved
description: LONDON, May 5 A signincant share of the British Petroleum Company may be acquired by West German and Iranian interests as a result of preliminary negotiations that apparently have taken place through intermediaries in the financial community.

title: Demand That Editors Join Union Stirs Press Conflict in Britain
description: LONDON, May 5 A controversy involving the press, Parliament and some of Britain's most famous writers has erupted over demands that newspaper editors be required to join the National Union of Journalists.

title: Appellate Division Upholds Conviction Of Alice Crimmins
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn confirmed yesterday in a 3to2 decision the manslaughter conviction of Alice Crimmins in the 1965 death of her 4yearolddaughter, Alice Marie.

title: Will Korea Be Next?
description: SEOUL, South Korea. May 2 With the fall of antiCommunist governments in South Vietnam and Cambodia, the question that has already raced through the capitals of Northeast Asia, and most notably this one. is Will South Korea be next? President Park Chung Hee clearly thinks that South Korea may be the next trouble spot in a speech just before Saigon fell, he said: I have repeatedly emphasized that the Communists in North Korea appear to have set 1975 as the year of aggression against the South.

title: Money
description: DOMESTIC RATES RATES IN PER CENT FEDERAL FUND

title: DAWSON C. GLOVER
description: Dawson C. Glover 2d, for 20 years a director of Deere & Co., farm machinery makers, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 56 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: G.M. Quarter Dividend Is Set at 60c a Share
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday a quarterly dividend of 60 cents a share payable June 10 to shareholders of record May 15.

title: 8 Stolen Mail Bags Found Minus $100,000 in Gems
description: Eight mail bags that were believed to have contained gems valued at more than $100,000 and other registered, mail, taken by five armed robbers Sunday in a midtown holdup, were found floating yesterday in the Hudson River off. Duane Street.

title: Most Futures Markets Get Added Clearance
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) The Government's new Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced today that provisional designation of most contract markets made last month would be extended for an additional 75 days.

title: Big Board Seats Sold
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported two seat sales yesterday at $99,000 and $100,000. The preceding seat sale occurred April 23 at $100,000.

title: AMEX PRICES UP AS TRADING RISES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market rose yesterday in slightly heavier trading.

title: Music: Barenboirn Plays Beethoven
description: Daniel Barenboim, who will be conducting the New York Philharmonic later this week, preceded his interpretations on the podium with a Carnegie Hall recital last night. He played a program of three Beethoven piano sonatas in D (Op. 10, No. 3), A flat (Op. 110) and C (Op. 53). And he played better than this listener has ever heard from him.

title: U.S. Is Recovering Planes That Got Out to Thailand
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 The Defense Department disclosed today that the United States had started removing from Thailand many of the 120 planes flown there by fleeing South Vietnamese pilots last week before the Communists took control in Saigon.

title: Facts on SchoolBoard Election
description: WHO WILL BE ELECTED: Ninemember boards in each of the city's 32 community school districts Those elected will serve twoyear terms, without salary, starting July 1

title: Advertising
description: More and mote industries are netting into consumer premiums and sales incentives, said William C. Battle, president of the Premium Advertising Association of America, as he watched exhibitors at the 37th annual Premium Show stream into the New York Coliseum yesterday morning.

title: VICTORS EMPTYING CAMBODIAN CITIES, U.S. NOW BELIEVES
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 State Department officials said today that they believed that the Cambodian Communists had forcibly evacuated virtually the entire population of Phnom Penh soon after they took power in the capital early last month.

title: Deficits, Jobs and Democrats
description: WASHINGTON A comprehensive poll taken for the Republican National Committee confirms the finding of other surveys that the American people, remarkably enough, still regard inflation as the No. I problem of the nation, with unemployment rated second. Yet, unemployment rose to 8.9 per cent of the work force in April, a postWorld War II record, while the rate of inflation has been declining In recent months.

title: City Found Liable for Damages To Stores in 1968 Harlem Riot
description: A jury in State Supreme Court held the City of New York liable yesterday for property damages sustained by a Harlem grocery store owner in the rioting that followed the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr in 1968.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Monday, May S. 61st day. Weather cloudy, track sloppy.

title: Bunche Pavilion Ceremony
description: The Ralph Bunche Memorial Pavilion, a selfcontained unit for the treatment of kidney disease, is to be dedicated this afternoon at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center on East G8th Street.

title: Two Paterson Policemen Are Accused by Grand Jury
description: PATERSON, May 5  Two Paterson patrolmen were charged with misconduct in office today by the Passaic County grand jury on the basis of a photograph of them taken by a camera operated by a burglaralarm system.

title: City Marshaling Its Statistics to Lure the Democratic Convention
description: While visions of freespending Democrats dance in the heads of New York City officials and merchants, teams of professionals are quietly compiling the blueprints, hotel inventories and other information needed to persuade the party to hold its national convention here next year.

title: House Panel Approves Tax on Autos To Be Based on Mileage Per Gallon
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI) 1 The House Ways and Means Committee approved today tax on automobiles based on how Many miles they get per gallon of gasoline.

title: Developing Nations Warned By U.N. on Mining Cartels
description: GENEVA May 5 The International Labor Organization, a United Nations specialized agency, warned the developing countries today that attempts to force up the prices of their raw materials through cartels can be as harmful to the developing nations as to the industrial powers.

title: Cleon Jones Is Arrested In Florida
description: Clean Jones returned to New York last night following his arrest in St. Petersburg, Fla., where the police said he was found sleeping nude in a station wagon on the main street in town.

title: Keating Dies at 74; Envoy, ExSenator
description: Kenneth B. Keating, Ambassador to Israel, former United States Senator from New York and Ambassador to India, died here yesterday at the Harkness Pavillion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 74 years old.

title: Ford News Conference On Television Tonight
description: The three networks ABC, CBS and NBC and the public Broadcasting Service will telecast live tonight President Ford's news conference in Washington.

title: Kivie Kaplan,N.A.A.C.P.Head And Jewish Leader, 71, Dies
description: Kivie Kaplan, president since 1966 of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and vice chairman of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, was pronounced dead of a heart attack yesterday in Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens. The 71yearold Mr. Kaplan, whose home was in Newton, Mass., had just arrived at La Guardia Airport for a meeting today of the Israel Commission of the Reform Judaism union.

title: Kissinger Denies Involvement In Domestic Spying by C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he and the National Security Council had had no involvement in any domestic operations of the Central Intelligence Agency and that he had never transmitted to the agency any feeling of concern about domestic security on the Dart of President Nixon.

title: Please Ignore This Story
description: The Police Department yesterday transmitted the following alert on its press teletype machine: This is a test message for L.I. Press only. If you do not receive this message you need a repair.

title: President is Requesting Funds For Food Stamps, School Milk
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 President Ford, responding to continuing high unemployment, asked Congress today to appropriate nearly $1billion more this year for Federal food stamp and school nutrition programs.

title: McGovern Arrives in Cuba At Start of FourDay Visit
description: HAVANA, May 5 (Reuters) Senator George McGovern arrived here today at the start of a fourday visit to Cuba.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Washington April 27 Wash. 100, Boston 95. April 30 Wash. 117, Boston 92. May 3 Boston 101, Wash. 90. May 7 At Washington, 8 P.M. May 9 At Boston, 7:30 P.M. May 11  At Washington, 3:10 P.M. May 14 At Boston, 9 P.M.

title: Antiwar Suit is Lost
description: A jury in Charlotte, N. C., found H. R. Haldeman and eight others not guilty in $1million civil suit of illegally barring antiwar demonstrators from a Billy Graham Day rally attended by President Nixon in 1971. Page 11.

title: Market Place
description: The small investor seldom experiences windfall profits in Wall Street these days. But exceptions occur when two or more groups fight for the control of a company.

title: A COMPROMISE ENDS BRANDEIS PROTEST
description: WALTHAM, Mass., May 5 The occupation of the Sociology Building at Brandeis University ended early this morning, following what administrative officials termed the clarification of university policy on the demands of the 28 students who seized the building last Tuesday.

title: TYPHOID EPIDEMIC IN MEXICO ABATES
description: An epidemic of typhoid fever that affected thousands of Mexicans and that was described icans and that was described as the largest in the world in several decades has abated, Mexican and United States Public Health Service doctors said in a report received yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: A young New York foursome raced to victory Sunday in the Grand National Teams zonal final at Tarrytown, N. Y.

title: Senate Rejects New Obscenity Law
description: TRENTON, May 5 The State. Senate rejected tonight a bill that would have allowed Prosecutors in the state's 21 counties to establish individual obscenity standards based on detailed guidelines set forth in the propose statute.

title: U.S. Trustworthiness
description: LONDON The postVietnam questioning in Europe on whether American security assurances can still be trusted is scheduled to produce ringing reaffirmation of confidence on May 2930 at the NATO summit conference in Brussels. But that is unlikely to end the questioning.

title: No. 2 Rating Satisfies Cornell in Lacrosse
description: Cornell's lacrosse power house was ranked second in the nation again this week, but that does not seem to bother many in Ithaca.

title: SUBPOENA DROPPED IN HEARST INQUIRY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 (AP) A subpoena for Phillip Shinnick, a former track star, to appear before the Federal grand jury investigating the Patricia Hearst case has been dropped, James Larson, his attorney, said today.

title: Business Briefs
description: DALLAS, May 5 (AP) Supermarket profits last year were at their highest level since 1971, an industry survey showed today. But the store owners complained their earnings were still below those of other industries and said they needed more money.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, May 6. 1975

title: Futures Decline In Wheat and Corn For May Delivery
description: May futures in wheat, corn and soybeans declined yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, while the new crop, or distant months, showed gains or held steady.

title: Mets: No Comment on Jones
description: Cleon Jones, arrested in St. Petersburg, Fla., early Sunday morning for indecent exposure in a parked automobile, had his scheduled conference last night with the New York Mets' management. The decision was that the outfielder go into seclusion until further notice.

title: 2 Political Scions Pick Their Rungs
description: Somewhat like heirs to the family business starting out in the stockroom, Robert F. Wagner Jr. and Robert S. Steingut have been cautiously charting their political careers in the City Council.

title: TV: Who's Happy?
description: Who's Happy Now?, written by Oliver Hailey, concludes this season's run of contemporary stage productions on public television's Theater in America series. This one, which can be seen tonight at 9 on Channel 13, is offered as an example of the kind of work that can be found at the Mark Taper Forum of Los Angeles. The example, however, carries several qualifications.

title: Alice Cooper Blends Rock With Theatrics
description: Alice Cooper's latest rocktheatrical extravaganza, which he brought into Madison Square Garden Monday night for a single, soldout performance, is based on his recent television special, Welcome to My Nightmare, but it is a lot tougher.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Arabian American Oil Company reported yesterday that output of petroleum fell sharply in April, to its lowest level since July, 1972.

title: STATE BILL SEEKS NEW PRISON PANEL
description: ALBANY, May 6The chairman of the Senate Committee on Crime and Correction today proposed that the State Commission of Correction be made a fulltime commission with increased powers to rectify conditions in prisons.

title: Bankruptcy Step Is Taken
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (UPI)The Valley Forge Corporation, a real estate development concern, filed a petition today for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal bankruptcy laws. The Certainteed Products Corporation, also of nearby Valley Forge, manufacturer of diversified building products, owns 72 per cent of the concern.

title: About Education
description: Now that the community school board elections have been held, the winners are going to have to begin thinking about how to make good on some of the promises they made during their campaigns.

title: United Brands Seen Naming an Outsider Its Chief on Monday
description: The United Brands Company, the scandalridden banana producer that has been seeking a new chief executive to pull the company out of its difficulties, was reported yesterday to have passed over the heirapparent, Edward Gelsthorpe, executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Stocks Down by 20.88

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES ARMS FUND SLASH
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The House Armed Services Committee cut 7 per cent today from the Pentagon's proposed weapons procurement and research program in approving la $26.5billion military authorization bill for the 1976 fiscal year, beginning July 1.

title: People in Sports
Turnout Light as Voters Elect 32 School Boards
description: A Tight turnout was reported in most school districts yesterday as voters throughout the city went to the polls to elect the members of their community school boards.

title: Promisin' Bowie, Franchise Peddler
description: BALTIMORE, May 6The commissioner and I can get along fine, Jerry Hoffberger said today, as long as he sticks to being commissioner and doesn't take over as peddler of my ball club. Jerry Hoffberger is chairman of the Baltimore Orioles and for almost two years he has been talking to Bill Veeck about selling the team to a group put together by Veeck. Last November they agreed on a $12million deal, but before the sale was formally closed the price went up. Now they are trying to settle for $12.5million, but the other day Bowie Kuhn barged in with a $12.6million offer from Edward Cole, former president of General Motors. I am still talking seriously with Bill Veeck, Hoffberger said today. The extra $100,000 isn't going to make all that much difference.

title: 2State Roundup Nets 17 Linked to LoanSharking
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., May 6The top two reputed organizedcrime figures in New Jersey were among 17 persons arrested by the state and local police before dawn today in suburban Bergen County, and in Rockland and Westchester Counties in New York.

title: ALGERIA, AT U.N., SPURS BID FOR AID
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 6Algeria led a move today to secure assistance for the people of Indochina but insisted that the help be given in ways acceptable to the new governments and without interfering in their internal affairs.

title: Warriors Down Bulls, 111 to 106
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 6 (AP)  Led by Rick Barry who scored 36 points, the Golden State Warriors stormed back from a poor first period tonight and beat the Chicano Bulls. 111106.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Jersey Central Power and Light Company has applied to the Federal Power Commission for permission build the nations first underground power plant. A spokesman for the utility said yesterday that the proposed $290million hydroelectric station, beneath Mount Hope Lake Rockaway Township, could be the first of its kind in the world.

title: Neighbors Opposing St. Luke's On Plan for Alcoholics Center
description: St. Luke's Hospital plans to open an alcoholictreatment center in two townhouses on West 108th Street between Broadway and Riverside Drive, and residents there and on neighboring blocks have reacted to the plan with fear, distrust and anger.

title: Unemployment in State 11.1 Per Cent In March, Highest Since World War II
description: TRENTON, May 6New Jersey's unemployment rate rose to 11.1 per cent in March, the highest unemployment in the state since World War II, Commissioner Joseph A. Hoffman of the State Department of Labor and Industry reported today.

title: Sales at W. T. Grant Fall In April by 23.3 Per Cent
description: The W. T. Grant Company announced yesterday that its sales in April dropped 23.3 per cent to $102.2million from $133.3million in the 1974 month.

title: U.S. Will Avoid an Active Role On Malpractice Coverage Issue
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Federal Government is not planning to take an active role in trying to solve the medical malpractice insurance situation whose impact is being felt in New York and California, a review of Health, Education and Welfare Department policy shows.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Wednesday, May 7, 1975

title: Labelle Not Out to Sell Its Soul Short
description: Labelle, the avantgarde soul trio, may have been a classic New York cult group until very recently. But now Patti LaBelle, Nona Hendryx and Sarah Dash can very definitely be said to have made it, what with a recent No. 1 single in Lady Marmalade and a sixnight, soldout run at the Harkness Theater that began last night.

title: U.F.T., Fuentes Backers Campaign Hard
description: In one of the most sharply contested school board elections in the city, the United Federation of Teachers and supporters of Luis Fuentes, the suspended Superintendent of School District 1, poured money and manpower into their campaigns.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: 7 NAMED TO RECEIVE LA GUARDIA AWARDS
description: Seven Americans distinguished for having made outstanding contributions to the country's cities during the last decade have been chosen to receive the annual Fiorello H. La Guardia Awards of the New School's Center for New York City Affairs.

title: U.S. SHIP WITH 200 REACHES SUBIC BAY
description: SUBIC BAY NAVAL STATION, The Philippines, May 6 (Reuters)The Stoddert, last of 46 American Evacuation ships to leave South Vietnamese costal waters, reached the Subic Bay Naval Base today with 200 South Vietnamese refugees, 19 of whom had been rescued from a sinking boat.

title: First Five Prizes in City High SchoolPoetry Contest Are Won by Young Women
description: High on Mount Olympus, the shades of Sappho, Emily Dickinson and Marianne Moore must have smiled in benign pleasure when the word came through that this year's winners in the five top spots in the New York City High School Poetry Contest were all young women.

title: The Market Basket
description: The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City went up again last week, but on a much smaller scale than in the week before, 0.2 per cent over the level of the week ending April 25. In the latter week the price change had been substantial, 1.0 per cent.

title: Youth, 15, Held in Slaying Of South Bronx Widow, 71
description: A 15yearold Bronx youth was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder last Friday of a 71yearold widow in her eighthfloor apartment at 1569 Bruckner Boulevard.

title: RCA Sees Color TV Sales Rise
description: The RCA Corporation believes that the greatest drop in sales of color television sets has already taken place and the trend from here on should be upward, Anthony L. Conrad, president of the company, told 812 stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

title: Omaha Tornadoes Kill 3; Damage Is Put in Millions
description: OMAHA, Neb., May 6 (AP)Three persons were killed. more than 100 were injured and thousands were left homeless when tornadoes struck, Omaha today. Officials estimated damages in the millions of dollars.

title: North Vietnamese Airline In Accord With Air France
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, May 6 (Agence FrancePresse)  An agreement under which the North Vietnamese airline will represent Air France, the French airline, in North Vietnam was signed here today by representatives of the two companies.

title: About New York
description: The men, and the couple of women, who drive cabs on the night line for the Chase Maintenance Corporation are a very mixed lot, Anthony Tuttle was saying the other day.

title: BRITISH TO MOVE ON HOSPITAL CARE
description: LONDON, May 6  The Government, prodded by the left wing of the Labor party, has decided to begin closing down private wings In public hospitals.

title: Signs Indicate Namath Will Remain With Jets
description: Joe Namath apparently isn't convinced the $4million offered to him by the World Football League really exists, his attorney implied yesterday.

title: U.S. Foresees Arab Drive To Sway Stand on Israel
description: WASHINGTON, May 6State Department officials said today that they expected the Arab countries to make a concerted effort in coming weeks and months to convince the United States and other countries of their readiness to make peace with Israel in return for the territory occupied by Israel since the war of 1967.

title: Ford Admits Getting Very Upset Internally
description: WASHINGTON, May 6President Ford said tonight that he sometimes became very upset internally but that he had learned that if you keep your cool, you can make a better decision. I have learned to control my temper, the President said.

title: BEAME AND CAREY AND BANKERS SEE SIMON AND BURNS
description: Mayor Beame, Governor Carey and three of the city's leading bankers met in Washington yesterday with the Ford Administration's top economic officials to seek ways the Federal Government might help the city to come up with $1.5billion it says it must borrow to pay expenses this month and next.

title: Rescued Boy Is Recovering
description: MIAMI, May 6 (AP)Michael Smith, 2 years old, apparently all right after spending almost five hours in chesthigh water in a narrow well, was reported today in satisfactory condition.

title: U.S., at Thai Behest, Suspends Removing of Disputed Aircraft
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 6 (AP)  The United States agreed today at Thailand's request to suspend its removal of American made aircraft flown by South Vietnamese refugee pilots to a Thai air base, officials here said.

title: Vigil Begins Again at Frontier For Arrivals From Cambodia
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, May 6Diplomats and relief officials again took up their, vigili at the ThaiCambodian frontier today, awaiting the arrival of the second and perhaps finall group of refugees being evacuated from the French Embassy; compound in Phnom Penh.

title: Pressure and Popularity Spur Variety In College Women's Studies Courses
description: Women's studies courses have become the vogue on colleges around the country, rapidly increasing not only in the number of camruses on which they are offered, but also in the depth and variety of courses given.

title: Commonwealth to Press Rhodesia Ban
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 6 The Commonwealth conference agreed today to intensify economic sanctions against the white minority Government of Rhodesia.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 7, 1975

title: Music
description: Mahler's Ninth Symphony, like Beethoven's, is so epical in proportion and conception that conductors are always hard up to know what other music to place before it on their programs. (No one. probably, has ever considered putting any piece after either Ninth.) Rafael Kubelik solved the problem at Carnegie Hall last night by letting the Mahler, which runs about an hour and 20 minutes, occupy the whole program. That might have sent one or two bargainoriented music consumers home feeling disgruntled but could not have annoyed anyone who cared about Mahler.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: McGovern, in Cuba, Opposes Embargo
description: HAVANA, May 6 (UPI)Senator George McGovern toured Havana today, dining on black beans and rice with Cuban intellectuals and calling for an end to the United States trade boycott against Cuba.

title: Judge's Wife Arson Suspect
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) Carol Sugerman, 32 years old, wife of Judge Leonard Sugerman of Chester County, faces grand jury action on arson charges involving a blaze that destroyed a dress shop she and another woman owned. Doris Jeanne Morris, 33, of Drexil Hill faces similar charges. She and Mrs. Sugerman had been partners in the dress shop, which was destroyed in a $500,000 fire in May, 1974.

title: Arrival in Paris
description: PARIS, May 6 (UPI)  A group of 357 French and forleign refugees from Phnom Penh arrived here today and pleaded with reporters not to publish anything they might have said inadvertently about the capture of the Cambodian capital by Communistled forces.

title: In darkness, and with dangers compass'd round
description: This is the story of John K, one of thousands of children under 16 years of age declared juvenile delinquents by the Family Court of the State of New York. John is known as a recidivist. He will probably commit crimes as a juvenile delinquent and almost certainly end up in the felony part of the New York State Supreme Court as a repeating adult criminal.

title: 11,851 Refugees Processed At Three Centers So Far
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The Pentagon said today that 11,851 of the 120,000 or so refugees who fled Indochina had been processed at three relocation centers and sent on to their new homes.

title: U.S Accused of Trying to Thwart Congress in Pressing for Offshore Oil Leasing
description: LOS ANGELES, May 5 California state and local officials asserted today that the U.S. Department of the Interior was trying to thwart the will of Congress in pressing for early offshore oil leasing while changes in Federal regulatory laws were pending.

title: Howe's 2 Goals Help Aeros Gain
description: HOUSTON, May 6 (UPI)Gordie Howe scored two goals and a rookie, Terry Ruskowski, connected for the gamewinner to lead the Houston Aeros to a 53 victory over the Quebec Norliqques tonight in the second game of the World Hockey Association playoff finals. Houston leads the fourofseven game series, 20.

title: Handling of Cases Defended by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) Ray Garrett Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, declared today that Government disclosure of corporate slush funds had seriously damaged several business leaders.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Goaded mainly by higher prices, the residential customers of Consolidated Edison cut back their usage of electricity by 10.8 per cent during the first nine months of 1974, according to a Public Service Commission staff report.

title: News Blackout May End
description: PARIS, May 6 (UPI)Officials of the Revolutionary Government's mission here said today that foreign newsmen would soon be permitted to file dispatches from Saigon again.

title: WILLIAM WHEELWRIGHT
description: FREEPORT, Me., May 6 William Bond Wheelwright. owner of the Bond Weelwright Publishing Company, died at his home here yesterday. He was 62 years old.

title: Saudi Arabia Imposes Ban on Contraceptives
description: MECCA, Saudi Arabia, May 6 (AP)Saudi Arabia has banned contraceptives on the basis of a ruling by the World Moslem League that birth control was invented by the enemies of Islam.

title: Bentsen Bill Would Split Kissinger's Two Key Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 Senator Lloyd Bentsen, who has been waging a oneman campaign to strip Secretary of State Kissinger of his other job as the President's advisor on national security, introduced a bill today to bar anyone from holding both positions in the future.

title: Fans' Faith In Islanders Going Fast
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., May 6The New York Islanders' season isn't over yet, but their fans are already talking sadly as if it were.

title: A Cook Who Was Born in the Breadbasket of Russia
description: EAST HAMPTON. L.I.You can't have a Russian meal without herring, Maria Robbins told us as she lifted a fine, fat schmaltz herring from its milk bath, boned it and garnished with chopped scallions and a touch of vinegar and oil. It goes particularly well with fau, which a lot of my Russian friends say they've never heard of, she went on. Fau is a puree of white beans, and it is a specialty of the small Bulgarian village where my father was born. The beans are topped with soft onions fried brown and a little or a lot of cayenne pepper is sprinkled on top, depending on your taste and conscience.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Washington

title: British Group Adds Rothschild Stake
description: PARIS, May 6 (Reuters)The James Goldsmith Group of Britain will hold a potential stake of around 7 per cent in the Banque Rothschild through convertible bonds to be issued in part payment for the bank's recent acquisition of Discount Bank S.A., Banque Rothschild's chairman, Francois Caries, said today.

title: Brooklyn SelfDefense School Called NarcoticsRing Front
description: A major South American narcotics smuggling ring using as a front a Brooklyn school teaching selfdefense was believed smashed yesterday with the seizure of cocaine and highly refined marijuana with a street sale value estimated at $3.6million, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Schools Here Said to Rank Well In Reading Among Large Cities
description: The Board of Education said yesterday that New York City ranked third in pupil achievement on standardized reading tests among the 10 largest cities for which comparable scores were available.

title: College to Appeal Ruling On Teacher's Reinstatement
description: LINCROFT, May 6 (AP)The Brookdale Community College board of trustees has voted to appeal a court order to reinstate Patricia Endress, who was dismissed last year from her job as a journalism profess sor.
