title: STRIKE PACT SET AT PLANE CONCERN
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)A tentative agreement was reached today to end an 85day strike by machinists against plants of the McDonnel Douglas Corporation in St. Louis. currently the target of the largest work stoppage in the nation.

title: BURDETTE S. SWEZEY
description: Burdette S. Swezey, who held 12 patents for changes on teletypewriters, died Monday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 57 Hawxhurst Road, Huntington.

title: VERA VOLKOVA, 71, OF DANISH BALLET
description: Vera Volkova of the Royal Danish Ballet, one of the great ballet teachers in the Western world, died Monday at her home in Copenhagen. She was 71 years old.

title: Doubles Is Finding New Popularity As Prize Money Continues to Grow
description: It's a confounding, exasperating, frustrating and tantalizing game, but more people are playing doubles than ever before. Many pros used to shun the game. Too aggravating, they would say. Now, however, they are scratching and fighting for the greatly increased prize money in doubles tournaments.

title: Standing by Commitments, Ford Assures U.S. Allies
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 President Ford, declaring that the United States had learned the lessons of Vietnam, said tonight that he would pursue a vigorous leadership on a worldwide basis.

title: BEAME AND CAREY AND BANKERS SEE SIMON AND BURK
description: Mayor Beame, Governor Carey and three of the city's leading bankers met in Washington yesterday with the Ford Administration's top economic officials to seek ways the Federal Government might help the city to come up with $1.5billion it says it must borrow to pay expenses this month and next.

title: AIRINES SEEK END TO BASING RATES ABROAD ON DOLLAR
description: PARIS, May 6 International airlines announced tentative plans today to abandon the fluctuating United States dollar and British pound as bases for calculating passenger fares and cargo rates.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 6 (AP)Gordon Johncock, the 1973 winner of the Indianapolis 500, posted the fastest lap of the day as practice for this year's race continued at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Meanwhile, A. J. Foyt, the 40yearold Texan trying for a record fourth victory, arrived from Houston to begin practice for the 500mile auto race, May 25. He had been detained at home over the weekend when his teenage daughter was taken to the hospital with severe asthma attack.

title: North Carolina Coed Slain
description: RALEIGH, N.C., May 6 (UPI) The body of a 24yearold coed who apparently had been beaten to death was found today near the campus of North Carolina State University. The victim was identified as Elizabeth P. Rosenberg, a junior originally from Asheville. Her husband, Edwin, who is employed as an economist for the State Utilities Commission, also attends the school.

title: West 96th Street Project Approved by Local Board
description: Community Planning Board No. 7 voted overwhelmingly last night to endorse a zoning change that would allow Christopher Boomis, the developer, to include a twostory department store at the bottom of an apartment tower planned for 96th Street and Broadway. In exchange for the rezoning, Mr. Boomis has scaled down his plans from a 31story tower with 588 onebedroom apartments to 26 stories with 408 units 23 floors.

title: J.D.L. INMATES LOSE KOSHERFOOD PLEA
description: A move to obtain kosher food in prison for two members of the Jewish Defense League was rejected in Federal District Court here Monday night by Judge Thomas P. Griesa.

title: Venezuela Seeking Data From Gulf Oil
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 6 (AP)  Venezuela ordered the Gulf Oil Corporation to declare within 48 hours whether Venezuelan officials or politicians were involved in charges that the company paid some $4million in bribes to operate in a foreign country.

title: Standing by Commitments, Ford Assures U.S. Allies
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 President Ford, declaring that the United States had learned the lessons of Vietnam, said tonight that he would pursue a vigorous leadership on a worldwide basis.

title: Market Place
description: The CocaCola Company announced on Monday that profits rose 14.7 per cent in the first quarter of 1975, a result reminiscent of its many years as a premier growth company.

title: Cotton Markets
description: Sales: 1,450.

title: No Cash, No Credit
description: The meeting of top city and state officials with the Secretary of the Treasury and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in Washington yesterday underscores the gravity and immediacy of New York City's financial crisis.

title: The Malpractice Tangle
description: The doctors' slowdown protesting the rise in malpractice insurance premiums in California serves as ominous backdrop for the present debate in Albany over legislative efforts to avert a similar emergency in New York. In its customary lastminute scramble, the Legislature is trying to reach a compromise between proposals for pooled malpractice coverage by insurance companies, a doctors' insurance cooperative, and Governor Carey's plan for an emergency State Insurance Fund to step in when commercial carriers are unavailable. The public is left with the distinct impression that, amid the rush to meet a deadline, the treatment to he finally agreed on will deal with the symptoms but ignore the causes of the disease.

title: Heart Recipient Called Well
description: CAPE TOWN, May 6 (UPI)South Africa's third doubleheart recipient is doing well and the heart implanted in his chest Sunday is beating strongly, a spokesman for Groote Schuur Hospital said today. The 40yearold patient, a white Cape Town businessman, has not been identified at his own request. He received the heart of a colored, or mixed blood, man, Arthur Jacobs, who died Sunday.

title: PATHET LAO TROOPS ATTACK AT JUNCTION
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 6 (Reuters)Pathet Lao forces, supported by North Vietnamese troops, have driven rightist troops out of the Sala Phou Khoun region, military sources said today.

title: HONEYWELL TO ALTER STOCKOPTION PLAN
description: Honeywell, Inc., at its annual meeting in Minneapolis yesterday, said negotiations were continuing with the view of combining its French computer affiliate, Compagnie Honeywell Bull, with the Frenchowned Compagnie International Pour I'Informatique.

title: Scott Assails McGovern Bill To Repatriate Vietnamese
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The Senate Republican leader. Hugh Scott of Pensylvania. criticized Senator George McGovern's proposal today to provide American planes and ships to allow South Vietnamese refugees to return to their homeland if they wish.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Sets Victors With Mrs. King
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., May 6 To the adoring screeches of preteens that echoed those for Judy Garland and Olga Korbut in other years, Billie Jean King made her first appearance at the Nassau Coliseum in a New York Sets uniform tonight.

title: ACTION IS PRESSED ON NURSING HOMES
description: ALBANY, May 6Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, who headed the now defunct state commission that investigated abuses in the nursinghome industry, pleaded with members of the Assembly Health Committee today for early consideration of his proposals for relvamping nursinghome operations in the state.

title: Judge Rules F.B.I. Did Not Interfere In Attica Defense
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that there was no evidence of governmental interference with the Attica legal defense team.

title: Under Cover, He's No Rogue Cop
description: HACKENSACK, May 6Joseph J. Delaney drew his first peaceful breath in more than 11 months today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Coast Woman Succeeds Late Husband in House
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (Reuters)Shirley N. Pettis was sworn in today to succeed her late husband as Representative of Californa's 37th District.

title: President Assures Congress on Curbs For Nuclear Arms
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)President Ford assured Congress today that his Administration was giving priority concern to preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons or the acquisition of nuclear explosive material for possible nonpeaceful uses.

title: BURNS STRESSES BUDGET CONTROL
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Success or failure of the new Congressional procedures for controlling the total size of the budget holds the key to whether the nation will restore stable prosperity or sink into galloping inflation and social upheaval, Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today.

title: Soviet Five Triumphs
description: NASHVILLE, May 6 (UPI)  A team of Soviet juniors defeated Tennesee high school allstars 9076 in a basketball game last night at Vanderbilt University.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: In Memoriam
description: BRUNO, HENRY and ANNIE. In loving memory of my father and mother, last in the sinking of the Lusitania, May 7th, 1917. HARRY.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Affairs
description: Following is a transcript of President Ford's news conference in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: SAIGON SAYS CITY IS NORMAL AGAIN
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, May 7 (Agence FrancePresse) The Saigon radio said yesterday that life had returned, to normal in the South Vietnamese capital, with telephone lines functioning as before and wellstocked markets crowded with shoopers.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES ARMS FUND SLASH
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The House Armed Services Committee cut 7 per cent today from the Pentagon's proposed weapons procurement and research program in approving a $26.5billion military authorization bill for the 1976 fiscal year, beginning July 1.

title: Advertising
description: For the airlines, the summer vacation months can be makeorbreak time.

title: Not Guilty Plea Filed
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6 (UPI) Jerry Dean Michael, a transsexual known for the last eight years as Elizabeth Carmichael, pleaded not guilty yesterday to a charge of bailjumping in connection with a counterfeiting operation. United States District Court Judge Malcolm Lucas set trial for May 27.

title: Military Burial for Keating At Arlington Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The funeral of Ambassador Kenneth B. Keating who died cif a heart attack in New York yesterday will take place here Thursday, the State Department announced today.

title: Mets' Records
description: BATTING

title: HARRIS IS DRIVING FOR PRESIDENCY
description: Former Senator Fred R. Harris disclosed yesterday that he had started largescale organizing for his Presidential campaign in New Yorkthe first Democratic Presidential hopeful to begin a major organizing effort here.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: RANDOM HARVEST Plantminded New Yorkers should have a field day today from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. and tomorrow until 4 P.M. as the Brooklyn Botanic Garden spreads its annual Plant Sale over the grounds and into the main building at 1000 Washington Avenue. As visitors stroll through the Garden to inspect the largescale display of earth  grown merchandise, films on gardening will be screened in the auditoriun during the afternoon, starting at 1:30 o'clock. For those who want to make a tour of several hours, a sandwich lunch and checking facilities are available in Room 320.

title: Columbia Honors Schapiro As the Model Art Historian
description: Meyer Schapiro  art historian and polymath, a legendary teacher and lecturer who for several generations has held both academic and popular audiences spellbound with his learning and his eloquence  is one of the great intellectuals of the present age. Unlike other figures of comparable stature, however, Professor Schapiro's fame rests on no single published work or specific discovery  his widely scattered writings are only now, when their author has reached the age of 70, being collected in book form  but on a career that for many admirers in and out of the academic world has served, in the words of the literary critic Irving Howe, as a model of what an intellectual should be.

title: WINE TALK
description: The economic troubles of the wine business in Europe could have some longterm unfortunate effects on the American consumer.

title: RISING TAXES TIED TO A SERVICE LOSS
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI)  A Congressional survey showed today that state and local governments were being forced to cut services and raise taxes this year, removing $8billion from the economy and eliminating about 140,000 jobs.

title: CHANGES OFFERED IN LAW ON FOOD AID
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Senator Hubert H. Humphrey proposed today a revision of United States foodaid legislation that he termed the most comprehensive restructuring of our Food for Peace Program since its enactment 20 years ago.

title: Stocks Down by 20.88
description: The stock market suffered its biggest loss in more than five months yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 20.88 points to 834.72. The main casualties were many of the bluechip issues that made large gains in recent sessions. Page 59.

title: $700Million Railrocl Bill Approved by Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 6The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee approved today and sent to the floor a bill authorizing $700million for an emergency job program aimed at making capital improvements in railroads.

title: Guerrillas In the Soviet Reminisce
description: MINSK, U.S.S.R., April 30 Yelena Mazanik killed a German official in his bed With a bomb. Viktor Liventsev commanded a guerrilla brigade when he was 23 years old. Roman Machulsky walks about with nine German shrapnel fragments in his body.

title: A Black Citizens Group Drops WCBSTV Action
description: Black Citizens for Fair Media, a local organization concerned with broadcast policies toward the black community, has filed with the Federal Communications Commission to withdraw its threeyear old petition to deny the license renewal for WCBSTV.

title: A CONVICTED KILLER OVERCOME BY DRUGS
description: PETERSBURG, Va., May 6 (AP)Lee Roy Hargrave Jr., a former nursing aide convicted of administering a lethal dose of medication to an elderly heart patient, took an overdose of amphetamines shortly after he was sentenced to life imprisonment today, the police said.

title: The Beneficial More Considered and Upheld
description: At Beneficial you're good for more. the lyric of one of the more enduring radio jingles, has last gotten a seal of approval from a panel of the National Advertising Review Board.

title: Judge's Wife Arson Suspect
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) Carol Sugerman, 32 years old, wife of Judge Leonard Sugerman of Chester County, faces grand jury action on arson charges involving a blaze that destroyed a dress shop she and another woman owned. Doris Jeanne Morris, 33, of Drexel Hill faces similar charges. She and Mrs. Sugerman had been partners in the dress shop, which was destroyed in a $500,000 fire in May, 1974.

title: A Place To Hang Your Hat
description: After you design a chair in the shape of a baseball glove, what do you do next? The encore chosen by Jonathan De Pas, Donato d'Urbino and Paolo Lomazzi, the Italian designers who scored earlier with their loveseatsized catcher's mitt called Joe, demonstrates that they can be every bit as witty lifting design from the world of photography as from sports.

title: Black and Chicano Students Occupy Building on Coast
description: CLAREMONT, Calif., May 6 (AP)  About 30 black and MexicanAmerican students took over the central business office building of the Claremont Colleges today to protest policies affecting them, a school spkesman said.

title: POLYSTYRENE PRICES CUT BY 2 SUPPLIER
description: Prices of polystyrene, a major ingredient in plastics fabrication, were reduced yesterday by two leading suppliers.

title: 2State Roundup Nets 17 Linked to LoanSharking
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., May 6The top two reputed organizedcrime figures in New Jersey were among 17 persons arrested by the state and local police before dawn today in suburban Bergen County, and in Rockland and Westchester Counties in New York.

title: ArmyI.B.M. Computer, Pact Criticized on Cost, Is Ended
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) The Army and the International Business Machines Corporation have agreed to end a contract under which computers were being purchased at a cost of $1million a computer higher than open market prices. Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas, said today.

title: Hathaway Differs From 3 Ford Views
description: WASHINGTON, May 6Under intense questioning by some Democrats on the Senate Interior Committee, Stanley K. Hathaway, Secretary of interior designate, took positions today that diverged from those of the Ford Administration on at least three environmental issues. The issues were strip mining, land use and clean air.

title: Burns, Other Favorites Gain in NorthSouth Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May 6 (AP)The defending champion, George Burns, shot oneunderpar golf today and heat the qualifying medalist, Henri deLozier, 2 and 1, in the second round of the North and South amateur tournament.

title: Bridge:
description: If a list were made of Americans who have contributed most to the game of bridge in all its facets during the last half century, Charles Solomon, who died last week in Philadelphia, would have a very high place.

title: Books of The Times
description: George Steiner begins his latest study of language and literature with a series of detailed textual glosseson Posthumus's monologue indicting womankind, which ends Act II of Cymbeline; on Elinor Dashwood's reaction to the news of Edward Ferrars's engagement to Lucy Steele, in Chapter 1, Volume II of Jane Austen's

title: Dow Is Off by 20.88 to 834.72
description: The stock market incurred its largest loss yesterday in more than five months. Some prices fell sharply after four consecutive sessions of gains in accelerated trading.

title: Iran Assuming Britain's Former Role As Guardian of Persian Gulf States
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 6In 1903 Lord Curzon, then the British Viceroy of India, grandly exhorted the Arab rulers of Persian Gulf states, whom he met in the Sheikdom of Sharia.

title: Amax Planning Acquisition Of the Central Oil Company
description: Amax, Inc., which is engaged in the operation of mines and refineries producing zinc, copper, lead, molybednum, coal and iron ore, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Central Oil Company of Laurel, Miss. Central Oil is a closely held, independent oil and gas producer with properties in Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Dakota and Oklahoma.

title: People and Business
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, secondlargest aluminum producer in the United Statesafter the Aluminum Company of Americais diluting the Reynolds component in top management.

title: Mayor Hatcher Renominated in Gary
description: GARY, Ind. May 6Richard G. Hatcher scored an impressive victory in the Democratic primary here today to win nomination for a third term as mayor.

title: Arabs Strive for Unity
description: KUWAIT, May 6Arab leaders are trying to resolve the disputes dividing their governments by exhorting the brothers to set aside their quarrels in the interest of unity to achieve a common stand toward Israel.

title: Italian Airports Paralyzed By a Walkout of Firemer
description: ROME, May 6Italian airports were paralyzed for hours today by a sudden walkout of firemen. All flights will he canceled all day tomorrow because of a nationwide stoppage by ground personnel.

title: W.H.A. Championship
description: Houston vs. Quebec

title: Moscow, After Talks, Stresses a Need for Arab Unity
description: MOSCOW, May 5The soviet Union's intensified effort toward a Middle East settlement has ended as it began three weeks agowith a firm's call for Arab unity.

title: Control Power Is Voted
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (Reuters)The Senate voted, 49 to 39, today to give the Council on Wage and Price Stability power to issue subpoenas in its investigations of wage and price Increases. The vote was on an amendment to the bill extending the life of the council from Aug. 15, 1975, to Sept. 30, 1976. The original bill would have given the council authority to delay wage and price increases for up to 60 days, but this authority was removed by the Senate Banking Committee.

title: Florida Claims Reefs
description: TALLAHASEE, Fla., May 6 (UPI)Secretary of State Bruce A. Smathers said today that Florida owned the endangered coral reefs on the Atlantic side of the Florida Keys and warned fishermen and treasure hunters to stay out.

title: Kuwaiti TakeOver Set
description: KUWAIT, May 6 (Reuters)Kuwait's Parliament ratified today a Government bill providing for the complete state takeover of the Kuwait National Petroleum Company.

title: U.S. Steel Sets Layoffs, Citing Auto Industry Slump
description: GARY, Ind., May 6 (AP)The slump in the auto industry will force the United States Steel Corporation to trim hundreds of employes from its big Gary works beginning next week, a spokesman said today.

title: Philippine Suppression
description: Of all the Asian strongman rulers with whom the United States has found itself strategically engaged, the Philippines' President Marcos is emerging as one of the most cynically skillful in defusing potential domestic opposition to his authoritarian rule.

title: ExLafayette High Pitcher Is Makin.d Giant Strides
description: If he pitched in the Polo Grounds, Pete Falcone would give Horace Stoneham and former New York Giant fans dreams of past glories.

title: FORD ASKS NATION TO OPEN ITS DOORS TO THE REFUGEES
description: WASHINGTON, May 6President Ford, described today as damned mad about widespread opposition to resettlement of 130,000 Vietnamese and Cambodians in this country, appealed tonight to the nation to welcome these people.

title: Ky Settles Into Tent Camp With Ordinary Refugees
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 6In a dusty field in Cali. fornia, far from the palaces of power and gardens of Saigon, Nguyen Cao Ky settled today in the refugee camp that has become his temporary home.

title: Levitt Reports Big Note Sale; Calls Rates Very, Very Good

title: Indicator Up Again On Home Loan Rates

title: NEW BONDS GIVEN STRONG RECEPTION

description: WASHINGTON, May 6For the first time since 1956, a Congressional committee voted today to send to floor debate a bill to scale back Federal regulations of natural gas prices.

title: Smiles Replace Snarls As Motorists Pay More
description: Linda Rockwell, toll collector in lane four of the Holland Tunnel plaza in Jersey City, said, Thank you several thousand times yesterday, as expected. Less predictable, however, was the fact that the vast majority of the motorists, most of whom were prepared for the 50 per cent increase in Hudson River crossing tolls, seemed to have resigned themselves to it and said, Thank you in return.

title: Ford Defends Martin In Evacuation of Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)President Ford called the evacuation of South Vietnam very successful and said in his press conference that critics of the evacuation and of Ambassador Graham A. Martin were Monday morning quarterbacks.

title: Much Confusion and Wave of Protests Mark Beginning of 1976 Olympic Ticket Sales in Canada
description: OTTAWA, May 6Ticket sales for next year's Olympic Games in Montreal opened yesterday and made confused scenes that caused a torrent of criticism of the official arrangements.

title: Episcopal Church's Top Bishop Challenges Contempt Charges

description: BRUSSELS, May 6 (UPI)The Common Market has accused the United Brands Company of antitrust violations in the European banana market, Common Market sources said today.

title: Sabres Win In Overtime, Lead by 32
description: BUFFALO, May 6After looking like a George Foreman who threw most of the punches but lost his fight with Muhammad Ali, the weary Buffalo Sabres revived tonight to tie the score late in the third period and then delivered a knockout in overtime in defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 54. The victory gave Buffalo a 32 lead in the National Hockey League's fourofsevengame semifinal playoff series.

description: GENERAL

title: Moon's Church Buys Former Columbia Club
description: The Rev Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church has purchased the former Columbia University Club building at 4 West 43d Street for use as its American headquarters, a church official said last night.

title: Tax Revenues in the State Showed No April Increase
description: ALBANY, May 6State tax collections for the first month of the new fiscal year showed virtually no increase over April of last year, according to figures released today by the State Department of Taxation and Finance.

title: Medicare Terms 988 Overpayments Bad Debts
description: Alleged overpayments of Medicare totaling $52million, mostly made to nursing homes five to eight years ago, have been referred to the General Accounting Office and the Justice Department as uncollectible by administrative means.

title: AIRLINES SEEK END TO BASING RATES ABROAD ON DOLLAR
description: PARIS, May 6 International airlines announced tentative plans today to abandon the fluctuating United States dollar and British pound as bases for calculating passenger fares and cargo rates.

title: Prosecution Rests in Trial of Humphrey's ExCampaign Chief
description: The prosecution in the trial of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's 1970 senatorial campaign manager rested its case yesterday after the campaign manager's secretary testified she was not sure he destroyed some campaign financial records for fear of discovery by the Senate Watergate committee.

title: Conversion of Hoboken Factory Into Housing Starts
description: HOBOKEN, May 6Groundbreaking ceremonies at the old Keuffel & Esser factory, built in 1906 and vacant for the last four years, marked the beginning today of its conversion to moderateincome housing.

title: A Crowded Place
description: At a meeting last week between some people involved in governing Tokyo and others who have been involved in governing New York, the Tokyo people disclosed a remarkable program for combatting air pollution. Basically, they employed embarrassment. Some of that city's business establishments were persuaded that it was preferable to upgrade their plants rather than to be listed publicly as major polluters. Currently the Tokyo government is engaged in an effort unimaginable by American standardsto persuade the owners of some of the city's most expensive property to accept a garbage disposal plant as a neighbor.

title: U.S. Scores Canada Decision To Raise Natural Gas Prices
description: WASHINGTON. May 6 (Reuters)The State Department estimated that the increase, announced in Ottawa yesterday, would cost United States consumers, the only importers of Canadian natural gas, an additional $583million a year.

description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that there was no evidence of governmental interference with the Attica legal defense team.

description: CHICAGO, May 6 (UPI) Colin Stuart Gordon, a civic leader and a director of the national food price division of the Office of Price Administration under President Truman, died yesterday at Woodstock, Ill., Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)The Ford Administration is considering liquidating the Penn Central and other financially ailing Northeastern railroads and selling their properties to other solvent carriers, the Secretary of Transportation, William T. Coleman Jr., said today.

title: Dance: Vasiliev Is Supreme as Ivan the Terrible
description: Vladimir Vasiliev is unquestionably one of the supreme dance artists of our time. To the many people who have seen him dance this will doubtless come as a statement of no particular shock value, yet his supremacy was so effortlessly demonstrated on Monday night, at the Metropolitan Opera House, where with the Bolshoi Ballet he danced the title role in Yuri Grigorovich's ballet Ivan the Terrible, that it seems inevitable to reemphasize the point.

description: ALBANY, May 6 In one of the touchier political problems of his administration, Governor Carey today vetoed a bill to create a separate agency to care for the mentally retarded, risking a rare threat of override by the Legislature.

title: Denying Our Heritage
description: President Ford was fully justified in his press conference last night to express his concern at the querulous and uncharitable reaction of too many Americans to the plight of the Vietnamese refugees. His statement on the desirability of admitting them to the United States ought to be read by every American. Mr. Ford's request for $507 million to assist the resettlement of approximately 130,000 Vietnamese over the next two years is a reasonable and honorable response to a tragic human situation. The United States can do nothing less.

description: Julius G. Underwood, president of the Harsco Corporation, formerly the Harrisburg Steel Company, died Monday at Polyclinic Hospital in Harrisburg, Pa. He was 60 years old and lived in Harrisburg.

title: U.S. Energy Planners Stress Electricity in Transportation of Future
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 6Federal planning for energy research between now and the year 2000 is giving additional emphasis to an economy and a transportation system that will be increasingly dependent on electricity, a meeting of engineers was told here today.

Mr. Carroll, who has been receiving $95 a week in unemployment benefits since February, estimated that he saved $3,000 by taking his winnings all at once instead of in 10 yearly payments as suggested by lottery officials.

description: TAMPA, Fla., May 6 (AP)Larry Williams testified today that as a fundraiser for Senator Edward J. Gurney he collected $500,000 from Florida builders for influence on Federal housing projects.

Manager Bill Virdon's outfit had that proposition to consider for another 24 hours following the postponement of tonight's game against the Orioles because of rain and wet grounds. The turn of events last night had a lingering quality.

For a group, born and reared in this country but nurtured in England, America sounds nicely soft and rock. It pierces no ear, blows no mind and is as safe as milk.

description: SAN JOSE, May 6 (AP)One of Costa Rica's two largest multinational fruit companies announced today it had accepted that nation's new banana export tax.

description: NEWARK, May 6JohnsManville Products Corporation and Metropolitan Life Insurance Company were named as defendants in a $326million damage suit filed here today by 163 former employes of RaybestosManhattan of Passaic, who contend that they have suffered irreparable physical harm because of long exposure to asbestos compounds.

description: Monir Farmanfarmaian, an Iranian artist and a collector of Iranian art, was inspired by her bedroom ceiling.

description: HARBORSIDE, Me., May 4Life proceeds quietly and firmly at Forest Farm. Helen and Scott Nearing are in good health, which is hardly news. Neither has been to a doctor in several decades.

title: Miss Gerulaitis Victor
description: WOODBURY, L.I., May 6Ruta Gerulaitis got revenge today as she defeated Mary Carillo, 64, 63, in the final of the Eastern women's hardcourt tennis championship at the Woodbury Country Club.

title: U.S. Debt Management
description: The United States Treasury will sell tomorrow a $750million issue of bonds due in 30 yearsnormally the sort of event guaranteed to interest a small band of professional money managers and to produce yawns on Capitol Hill. But these days, with the national unemployment rate nudging 9 per cent and with the economy tiptoeing from recession to recovery, Congressmen have become mightily concerned with such arcane arts as debt management and monetary policy.

title: Percy Wants Embargo Ended

Percy, ReRepublican of Illinois, said today that the United States should end its economic embargo against Cuba regardless of whether the Organization of American States lifts the hemispheric sanctions. He made the proposal in a speech prepared for delivery from the Senate floor.

title: Shinn, Merrill President, Will Head First Boston

Shinn, 52yearold president of Merrill Lynch & Co., the country's lorgest securities firm, resigned yesterday to become chairman of the First Boston Corporation, a leading investmentbanking firm that recently has, had some difficulty on setting up line of succession in top management.

title: Army Engineers Seek Control Of All Waters, Down to Ponds
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)The Army Corps of Engineers, seeking to expand its jurisdiction over United States waters, has proposed a regulation that would give it authority over every lake, stream, stock pond, irrigation ditch and marsh in the nation.

title: CAREY ASKS AID FROM CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 Governor Carey asked Congress today to approve a bill providing $4billion in aid to states and local governments, with New York State getting an estimated total of $337million.

title: Books Of The Times
description: The wrinkles for which W. H. Auden's face was famous remind me of the striations in the surface of the brain. His face looked like a naked brain. It brings to mind also his passion for crossword puzzles. The lines of his forehead, especially, suggest the vertical transfixed by the horizontal man, the Puzzling intersecsection of the mind and the senses. There is something Byzantine, too, in that mosaic of a face, co perfectly caught by Jill Krementz in her cover photograph, something precise, formal and encyclopedic imposed on an embarrassment of riches, like a net thrown over a tiger. Igor Stravinsky, a close friend of Auden, said of his face that soon we'll have to smooth it out to see who he is. This is what Stephen Spender has tried to do in W. H. Auden: A Tribute. He has collected 36 essays by people who knew Auden, beginning with Rosamira Bulley, one of the poet's first teachers. These are characterizations, not evaluations. Auden's friends are speaking and his death is too recentless than two years agoto allow for more than the slightest hint of detachment.

title: Federal Aides Reviewing Ways City Might Be Aided
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Federal Government began an urgent review today of possible options for emergency financial aid to New York City, but made no decisions.

description: LONDON, May 7The closing of the Suez Canal in the ArabIsraeli war of 1967 dealt a serious blow to world shipping, but there will be little celebration outside Egypt when the waterway is completely reopened next month

The average yield of ?? per cent was in line with estimates made earlier in the day by various dealers.

title: U.S. Five in Final
description: CAMPINAS, Brazil, May 7 (UPI)Bob Miller scored 23 points last night to lead a United States junior college allstar team to an 8779 victory over favored Brazil in the semifinals of the Governors Cup basketball championship. Puerto Rico beat Canada, 5956, in the other semifinal.

title: 1.3% RISE RECORDED IN WELFARE ROLLS
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)The Government announced today that rising unemployment pushed the nation's welfare rolls up 1.3 per cent in January, the largest monthly increase in more than three years.

title: Montanez Clicks For His New Club
description: For the second time, Willie Montanez has in effect been involved in a Dick Allen trade. And wherever it takes him Montanez responds.

title: Film: Vapid Mandingo
description: The illustrated ads for Mandingo, which opened at two theaters yesterday, sort of remind you of the ones for Gone. With the Wind, what with the old plantation house in the background, the suggestion of crowds caught up to great events, flames, lovers pictured in tempestuous emprace.

title: Islander Goalie Stops Rare Penalty Shot
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., May 7Please, Glenn Resch said to himself as he faced his first overtime period tonight. If you're gonna give up a bad goal, make sure it's a good one.

title: C. ARNHOLT SMITH SUED BY F. D. I. C.
description: SAN DIEGO, May 7 (AP)The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has filed a $3million suit against C. Arnholt Smith, the financier, accusing him of misappropriating $1.5million in loans from European lenders.

title: Market Place
description: Shareholders and creditors of DHJ Industries, Inc., have faced uncertainty for some time, but there are indications that it may soon be over.

title: Marcos Locked in Risky Test of Wills With HungerStriking Political Foe
description: MANILA, May 7The leading rival and most important political prisoner of President Ferdinand E. Marcos went through the 34th day of his hunger strike today without any sign that the President was prepared to make a gesture that would enable him to call it off.

title: Nursing Homes Fight Subpoena By State's Special Prosecutor
description: Charles J. Hynes, who was named four months ago as special state prosecutor for nursing homes, has not yet filed his first indictment but has at least eight court actions on his hands.

title: HEARST CASE HAS AN ECHO IN JERSEY
description: Phillip K. Shinnick, the former Olympic athlete who was called before a Federal grand jury investigating the Patricia Hearst case, said yesterday he might sue Livingston College in Piscataway. N. J., from which he was dismissed as athletic director on March 3.

title: MOSCOW COURTS PARIS SOCIALIST
description: PARIS, May 7The Soviet leadership considers the present Western crisis the greatest the capitalist world has known, but feels that common action of Communists and Socialists is needed to advance the interests of the Left.

title: Condemned To Repeat It
description: WASHINGTON, May 7When John Hersey spent a week with President Ford and wrote his remarkable account of it in The New York Times Magazine, he found one central puzzle. How could a man so open in manner, so considerate in personal relations, seemingly lack a deeper social compassion and be so insensitive to the currents of change in the world?

title: Studies to Focus on Sea Cucumber's Ability to Snythesize Iron
description: The sea cucumber, which has existed for an estimated 50 million years on a diet of mud, has become an object of scientific curiosity, not because of its digestive tract but because of its peculiar ability to synthesize tiny beads of iron under its skin.

title: U.S. STARTS PLAN TO MAKE UTILITIES SHIFT TO COAL USE
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Government announced today the start of a program of man. datory conversion of electric, power plants to coal, a program that ranks high on the Administration's list of actions to save oil.

title: Benton Plans a Branch in Chicago
description: The 45yearold Benton & Bowles ad agency, which opened its first fullservice branch office in Los Angeles last year, is now preparing to match that trick in Chicago. And they're going to do it with indigenous personnel.

title: Wake Forest Fills Post
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., May 7 (UPI)Win Headley, a former Wake Forest football star, has been named the school's defensive line coach.

title: Dog Shows Paying Off For Bank
description: Interest has reached peak levels at the home office of the Manhattan Savings Bank. In the institution's lounge at Madison Avenue and 47th Street, a dog exhibition started last Monday and will continue through tomorrow, from noon until 1:30 P.M.

title: End of Vietnam Era
description: President Ford issued a proclamation declaring yesterday the end of the Vietnam era for which members or the armed forces could receive wartime veterans' benefits. Details and text of the proclamation, Page 14.

title: JUSTICE AGENCY BACKS TRUST BILL
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Justice Department endorsed today, with some reservations, most of the provisions of a bill that would strengthen the Government's powers to enforce antitrust laws.

title: Honorable Miss Wins
description: Honorable Miss of the PenFBryn Farm scored an expected victory in the $27,250 Toboggan Handicap, the sixfurlong test that had its 82d running Wednesday at Aqueduct. Although she was the only one of her sex in the race, the 5yearold daughter of Damascus was so heavily backed that she returned $4.60 for $2 to win.

title: FORD SETS CLOSING WITHOUT A LAYOFF
description: DETROIT, May 7The For Motor Company announced today that all of its 17 assembly plants and most of its 47 manufacturing plants would be closed two to three weeks in July during which time workers would take their vacations. The move was interpreted here by observers as a way to reduce Ford's growing inventory of cars without further layoffs.

title: Motions Delay Attica Killers' Sentencing
description: BUFFALO, May 7The sentencing of two convicted defendants in the Attica murder trrial was delayed for at least a day today as defense lawyers made motion after motion to set aside the verdicts.

title: ELIZABETH'S VISIT STIRS HONG KONG
description: HONG KONG, May 7The first visit by a British monarch to this crown colony ended today when Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip left for Japan.

title: Malcolm Toon, a Career Diplomat, Is Chosen as Envoy to Israel
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Ford Administration has chosen Malcolm Toon a veteran Foreign Service officer, as the new United States Ambassador to Israel. He replaces Kenneth B. Keating, who died on Monday.

title: Music: Glass's Newest
description: The first two sections of Philip Glass's new piece, Another Look at Harmony, which received their first performance on Tuesday night at Town Hall, will eventually feed into the music that Mr. Glass is providing for Robert Wilson's next major work. The finished WilsonGlass collaboration will tentatively be seen and heard in Shiraz, Iran; Paris, Berlin and New York in the second half of 1976.

title: Clark Oil TakeOver Set by Esmark, Inc.
description: Esmark, Inc., the Chicago holding company that owns Swift & Co., reached an agreement in principle yesterday to acquire the Clark Oil and Refining Company for an exchange of stock worth $106.5million. At the same time, Esmark disclosed the specific terms of an agreement to acquire the International Playtex Company, a subsidiary of the RapidAmerican Corporation, for $210million, a transaction that was first announced on March 3, 1975.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MAY 8, 1975

title: College President to Retire
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. May 7 (AP)Beaumont A. Herman, 66 years old, announced yesterday that he would serve one more year as president of Western New England College and then retire.

title: Cyprus Reopening
description: The results of the first round of Cyprus talks under United Nations auspices have been but modest: an agreement in principle of the Greek and Turkish Cypriote representatives to reopen the Nicosia airport, which has been closed since the fighting last summer, and a decision to set up a committee of expertsthree from each communityto study the powers and functions of a new federal government for the island.

title: BOTH SIDES CLAIM SCHOOL VICTORY
description: Both sides proclaimed victoryeven before any votes have been countedin Tuesday's hardfought school board election in District 1 on the Lower East Side.

title: Notes on People
description: I'm very much opposed to using French words. said W. Averell Harriman in Moscow, where he told American journalists that many of their countrymen were either cynical about or oversold on dtente because they do not understand it.

title: WORLD TEAM TENNIS
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME Golden Caters 29, Cleveland 18.

title: DOW INDEX SHOWS SMALL ADVANCE
description: The stock market staged a small technical recovery yesterday following Tuesday's sharp decline and finished slightly higher in slower trading.

title: About the Yankees ....
description: The Yankees wound up the first segment of their schedule last night25 games against their five foes in the Eastern Divisionand the results were not impressive: 10 victories, 15 defeats. New York flew to Oakland for a threegame series against the A's starting tomorrow night. Catfish Hunter will pitch against his former team Saturday. ... Sign of the Times in Baltimore: The Orioles were advertising the giveaway of 100 boxes of groceries, worth $40 each, to 100 mothers on Mothers Day between games of a doubleheader against Minnesota Sunday.

title: Steinbrenner Will Repay Company for Illegal Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, May 7A special review committee recommended today that George M. Steinbrenner 3d be required to reimburse the American Ship Building Company $42,325.17 for illegal political campaign contributions that he authorized or permitted in 1972 for the Nixon reelection campaign.

title: Gulf Says Neither Ecuador Nor Venezuela Got Bribes
description: Bob R. Dorsey, chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation, said yesterday that neither Venezuela nor Ecuador was the country to which his company had made $4million in payoffs in order to be allowed to continue operations.

title: COURT BACKS SALE OF HOMESTAKE UNIT
description: TULSA, Okla., May 7 (UPI)The sale of an Arizonabased subsidiary of the HomeStake Production Company, which was involved in an alleged $100 million swindle, was approved today by United States District Court Judge Allen E. Barrow.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MAY 8, 1975

title: Leftovers of War
description: In the final disengagement from South Vietnam and Cambodia, billions of dollars in Americanbuilt air, ground and sea facilities and equipment were abandoned by our former allies and captured by their enemies. There was no scorchedearth policy in the last days of the war to exacerbate the bitterness and terror of the departure. The booty of war exceeds by far what was captured from the French in the last shootout at Dien Bien Phu.

title: Bonn Establishes New Policy Agency To Curb Terrorists
description: BONN, May 7The West German government today created a terrorism branch in the national police, the Federal Criminal Office, to try to track down terriorists like those who blew up the embassy in Stockholm last month.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, May 7, 1975

title: ELIZABETH'S VISIT STIRS HONG KONG
description: HONG KONG, May 7The first visit by a British monarch to this crown colony ended today when Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip left for Japan.

title: SIMON FORECASTS LOWER '75 DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)Secretary of the Treasury Wilam E. Simon told Congress today that a surge in income tax receipts meant the budget deficit for this fiscal year would be $4billion to $5billion lower than expected. Mr. Simon estimated the deficit for the fiscal year ending June 30 would be somewhere in the $40billion to $41billion area.

title: NEW RULERS HOLD BIG SAIGON RALLY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 7 (Reuters)The military committee ruling Saigon made its first public appearance today as its members addressed 30,000 people at a rally marking the surrender of the city a week ago.

title: Senate Debates Consumer Bill; Agency Supporters Optimistic
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Senate began today its perennial debate on legislation creating a Federal consumer protection agency amid indications that this year the bill might pass.

title: Hatcher Faces ExPolice Chief In Gary, Ind., Mayoral Contest
description: GARY, Ind., May 7Democratic voters here gave their endorsement yesterday to Mayor Richard G. Hatcher for another fouryear term.

title: CNA Earnings Recover After Recent Big Losses
Newark Budget Concerns East Side High's Students
description: NEWARK, May 7The posters hanging in the faded pink hallways of East Side High School today advertised the school's second annual Soc Hop, promising those who attended both good tunes and good times.

title: House Subcommittee Backs Emergency Job Measure
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)A House subcommittee, declaring that a national unemployment emergency exists, aproved today a $5billion emergency, job bill that would guarantee Federal payment or at least $25million to each state for public works projects. appprovedemtaoin hrd dddd

title: BURMAH MAY SELL OILFIELD SHARES
description: LONDON, May 7 (Reuters)The Burmah Oil Company, Ltd., is holding talks with its bankers as well as potential buyers for its interests in the Ninian and Thistle fields in Britain's sector of the North Sea, the company's chairman and managing director, Alastair Down, said today.

title: CONGRESS PASSES STRIP MINE CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Congress approved a strong strip mining bill today but backers predicted that President Ford would veto the measure.

title: Honeywell Holders Vote for Amending StockOption Plan
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 7 (AP)Honeywell, Inc., stockholders voted overwhelmingly yesterday to amend the company's executive stockoption plan despite one stockholder's contention that the action amounted to giving the boys who ran the engine downhill a second chance.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: SWISS COURT SETS FINANCE'S BAIL
description: GENEVA, May 7  A threejudge court set bail of $2million today for Tibor Rosenbaum, a Swiss financier who is accused of having mishandled $10.6million deposited in his bank by a corporation established to aid the economic development of Israel.

title: Senate Approves 2 Envoys
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (Reuters)The Senate today approved the nomination of Laurence H. Silberman, who has been Deputy Attorney General, to he Ambassador to Yugoslavia. It also approved Charles S. Whitehouse, a career Foreign Service officer, as Ambassador to Thailand.

title: Stamps for ApolloSoyuz
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) The United States and the Soviet. Union will mark their first joint space venture by issuing a twin pair of postage stamps, the United States Postal Service said yesterday. The stamps will be issued on launching day for the ApolloSoyuz mission, now scheduled for July 15.

title: Hart Attacks Hathaway's Coal Lease Policies
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Senator Giry Hart, Democrat of Colorado, said today that he would oppose the nomination of Stanley K. Hathaway to be Secretary of Interior because of what Mr. Hirt called the poor energy development policies followed by Mr. Hathaway as Governor of Wyoming.

title: Places to Take the City Youngster
description: Yonu don't have to take the children to Washington, to see the cherry blossoms. The week's rains have just catapulted the local trees into their fragrant pink flowering. One location is the half mile alongside the boat basin bordering the Hudson River from about 72d Street to 84th Street, which is solidly paved with them. There are various other outcroppings in that area, notably along the approaches to the lower walk, Playgrounds and soft drink vendors are handy, and it's a pleasant way to spend the day before the shortlived blossoms wilt.

title: Yale Reduces Price For Football Tickets
description: NEW HAVEN, May 7 (UPI) Yale University has reduced ??ices for the 1975 footballer ??eason and will offer a $6 general admission season pass to all six home games.

title: DEROSE REJECTS A PLEA TO RESIGN
description: TRENTON, May 7Governor Byrne asked Ralph C. DeRose today to resign his $30.500 a year post as the New Jersey member of the bistate Waterfront Commission because of an alleged conflict of interest and in an unusual transoceanic exchange, he was rebuffed.

title: Pentagon Says 2 Dead Marines Were Left in Saigon by Mistake
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The bodies of two of the last marines killed in the Vietnam war were left behind in the confusion of the final American evacuation from Saigon, the Defense Department said.

title: LEGISLATIVE PLAN FOR NASSAU GAINS
description: MINEOLA, L.I., May 7A controversial plan offered by the Republicancontrolled Nassau County Board of Supervisors for a 15member county Legislature was approved today in State Supreme Court here.

title: 9 Held in Operation of Huge Policy Ring
description: James Vincent Napoli, the reputed boss of the late Vito Genovese's Mafia family, was arrested yesterday and charged with operating the country's largest policy gambling operation with a yearly handle put at hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: 'Day of Locust' Turns Dross Into Gold
description: Detail: A middle-aged man, coatless, sits in a canvas deck chair in a small, untended garden. It is hot and sunny but not really bright. The man stares at a large lizard, which stares back. When an orange falls from a tree, the noise it makes as it hits the ground suggests that the earth deep within is hollow.Detail: A young woman, whose blonde prettiness is drugstore chic, watches the movie screen with the rapt attention of someone expecting a miracle. Suddenly she sees herself on the screen, transformed, as one of a group of harem girls in old Baghdad. For a brief moment she is the center of everything. Then it's over. Says the young woman to her escorts as she leaves, the movie theater: "They ruined it."Detail: A cockfight in a suburban garage late at night. One of the handlers, a middle-aged dwarf, picks up his bleeding, dazed bird. He strokes it. He licks the blood from its neck. Tenderly. Then he sends it back into the ring to be butchered.Detail: An androgynous child of, perhaps, 12, with peroxide hair, dressed in short, Buster Brown pants and shirt, knocks on a window to get the attention of the man within. The man turns. The child does a grotesque imitation of Mae West's "Come up and see me sometime."The place is Los Angeles in the late nineteen-thirties, when the Hollywood movie studios were booming and when California was still the promised land, filling up daily with more and more young hopefuls, with aging con arttists, with Okies, the old and the ill who wanted to die in the sun. It is the setting for the huge, in many ways remarkable film that John Schlesinger has made from Nathanael West's small, classic novel, "The Day of the Locust.""The Day of the Locust," which opened yesterday at the Cinema 1, is less a conventional film than it is a gargantuan panorama, a spectacle that illustrates West's dispassionate prose with a fidelity to detail more often found in a gimcracky Biblical epic than in something that so relentlessly ridicules American civilization.In its scope, in its fascination with second-rateness as a way of life, in the boldness with which it dwells on shabby details, the film reminds me of murals that used to turn up from time to time in early Franklin D. Roosevelt-era post offices. Having been commissioned by the Works Progress Administration, furious, politically committed artists would produce views of American life that seemed to eat away at the walls of the buildings meant to contain them."The Day of the Locust" is like this. It is a Hollywood epic that uses Hollywood sleaziness as a metaphor for nothing less than the Decline of the West. The movie is far from subtle, but it doesn't matter. It seems that much more material was shot than could be easily fitted into the movie, even at 144 minutes.Its narrative focus is uncertain. Are we seeing the story through the eyes of Mr. Schlesinger, the film's director, or of Tod Hackett (William Atherton), the young Yale graduate and apprentice scenic designer who moves through the film participating in events but not doing much about them? What Tod doesn't see, Mr. Schlesinger doesn't hesitate to show us. The film's pivot, Homer Smith (Donald Sutherland), a creepy, sexually repressed accountant from the Middle West, remains a mysterious cartoon of a character throughout.Yet the film works without wasting time on these usual psychological underpinnings, in the way that mural art can. It is reality projected as fantasy. Its grossnessits bigger-than-life quality  is so much a part of its style (and what West was writing about) that one respects the extravagances, the almost lunatic scale on which Mr. Schlesinger has filmed its key sequences: a soundstage disaster (when a set representing the Waterloo battlefiefd collapses during the filming of the film within), and the climactic riot, when a Hollywood premiere turns into an event on the order of the Crucifixion.In such a panoramic movie the performers have a way of being reduced to being the functions of the director and the screenwriter (Waldo Salt). The characters don't change. They don't become something else during the course of the film. They already are what they always will be. This is tough on actors, but Mr. Schlesinger has used this beautifully, with one possible exception.This is a movie that has been ideally cast as much as it is actedby Mr. Sutherland, Mr. Atherton, Burgess Meredith (as a rummy old vaudeville hoofer), Geraldine Page (though her sequence is superfluous), Jackie Haley (as the androgynous child) and Billy Barty (as a mean-tempered dwarf). Only the figure of Karen Black, playing the bit-player, the tough, doomed to-fail aspirant to stardom, softens the film with something like pathos."The Day of the Locust" doesn't need it.

title: CITY HELD BETTER AT AIDING ADDICTS
description: Health Commissioner Lowell E. Bellin said yesterday that the city could do a better job of caring for the patients now in the private profitmaking methadone clinics, but that there was not enough money or personnel to do the job.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 7 (AP)The commissioners of the National Hockey League and National Basketball Association said today that their sports could not continue to pay astronomical player salaries and expect to remain business. Walter Kennedy of the N.B.A. and Clarence Campbell of the N.H.L. joined Commissioner Bowie Kuhn of baseball, National Football League Commissioner Pete Rozelle and the head of the Professional Golfers' Association, Deane Beman, at a national sports and marketing seminar.

title: Pirates Defeat Mets, 61
description: Occasionally during a season, baseball players hit for the cyclesingle, double, triple, home run. The Mets' infield fielded for the cycle last nighterror for the first baseman, error for the second baseman, error for the shortstop, error for the third baseman.

title: D'ANGELO DROPPED AS BOARD NOMINEE
description: Governor Carey has withdrawn the nomination of Armand D'Angelo, the former City Water Commissioner, to the Board of Higher Education.

title: COMPANY PROFITS OFF 15% IN PERIOD
description: Corporate net profits in the first quarter averaged 15 per cent lower than a year earlier and 21 per cent lower than in the final quarter of 1974, the First National City Bank reported yesterday. Only 10 of the 31 industries surveyed showed higher earnings than in the 1974 period.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Tanaka Is Termed Innocent Of Any Serious Tax Evasion
description: TOKYO, May 7 (Reuters)Finance Minister Masayoshi Ohira reported to Parliament today that former Premier Kakuei Tanaka had not been guilty of any serious tax evasion.

title: 30,000 REFUGEES LEFT IN VIETNAM
description: AGANA, Guam, May 7 (AP) An evacuation captain whose ship reached here after more than a week at sea says thousands of South Vietnamese hhowling and crying, Come back! were left behind on the beaches.

title: Results of School Elections in Suburban Counties
description: Following are the results of local school elections in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties. Winners in contested elections for schoolboard seats are indicated by capital letters. Asterisks indicate incumbents. Uncontested elections are not included.

title: Fink Gets Three Goals In 51 Cosmos Victory
description: Joey Fink, a young man from Queens, did what Pete and George Best could have done for the CosMos last night. Fink, who grew up in Brooklyn and went to New York University, scored three goals and led the Cosmos to a 51 victory over the Baltimore Comets.

title: HEARST CASE HAS AN ECHO IN JERSEY
description: Phillip K. Shinnick, the former Olympic athlete who was called before a Federal grand jury investigating the Patricia Hearst case, said yesterday he might sue Livingston College in Piscataway. N. J., from which he was dismissed as athletic director on March 3.

title: A Closer Look at Karl Lagerfeld
description: The significance of Christian Dior's New Look, launched in 1947, turned out not to be the tong, wide skirts and wasp waistlines that changed the shape of clothes for a decade, but the way those clothes were made. An intensive inner structure of linings, interfacings and reinforcement was introduced to give the clothes a shape that, demonstrably, could stand alone, without any body inside it.

title: Ex Humphrey Aide Testifies He Saw No Evidence of Illegal Contribution by Milk Coop in '70 Race
description: Jack L. Chestnut told a jury In Federal District Court here yesterday that he could not recall ever seeing any of the documents or making any arrangements for an illegal corporate campaign contribution from a milk cooperative. But he stater under crossexamination that he had been paid $5,000 during the time of the contribution for legal work done for the co?? operative.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Thursday, May 8, 1975

title: New Corridor Is Opened To Improve Grand Central
description: A 90footlong, 15footwide passageway designed to improves access and circulation in Grand Central Terminal for rail commuters and subway riders was officially opened yesterday morning by David L. Yu nick, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: MARGARET H. EWELL OF BROKERAGE FIRMS
description: Margaret Hannum Ewell, long a member of the business and finance communities, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. Mrs. Ewell, who was 70 years old, underwent an operation for a brain tumor in March.

title: DR. JOHN C. WALKER JR.
description: Dr. John Childress Walker Jr., chief of the departments of plastic surgery and rehabilitation at St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston, N.J., died yesterday at the center. He was 58 years old and lived in Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: A.M.C. Lost $47.8Million in Quarter
description: DETROIT, May 7  The American Motors Corporation reported today a loss of $47.8million for the first three months of 1975, the largest quarterly deficit in the company's history.

title: Chase Plans Jordan Branch
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it had received approval from the Federal Reserve Board to establish a branch in Amman, Jordan. In the Middle East, Chase also has branch offices in Beirut, Lebanon, and Manama, Bahrain.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Almost all the teachers in the Man alapanEnglishtown school district who took part in what the Board of Education contended was a thinly disguised sickin returned to their classrooms. Edward Barrett, assistant superintendent of the Monmouth County School District, said teacher absenteeism had returned to normal after the oneday demonstration on Tuesday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Buildings Aide Among 11 Indicted on Bribe Charges
description: Eleven persons, including a high official of the Buildings Department and the executive vice president of a major construction company, were indicted by a Brooklyn grand jury yesterday on charges of bribery.

title: OLD DANIELS MAGIC TURNS SONGS TO FUN
description: Billy Daniels's old black magic has simniered down to a powder gray. In his current appearance at the Rainbow Grill, the once overt sexuality of his singing has taken on a selfmocking tone. But even his September songs, delivered with a surface air of hokum, have an underlying sensuality that can still strike provocative sparks.

title: FOOD STAMP SHIFT BARRED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Senator Robert Dole, a Kansas Republican, tried unsuccessfully today to get the Senate Agriculture Committee to adopt immediately a more liberal certification procedure for the food stamp program.

title: Advertising
description: McCann  Erickson, which has handled the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation's advertising in overseas markets for some time, has just been assigned a sizable, portion of its domestic business.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Jean Muir of London and Holly Harp of Los Angeles were among the 500 or so viewers of the Chloe American collection shown in the glassedover courtyard of the Galleria, the new building on East 57th Street. Naturally, they applauded the Paris avantgardist, Karl Lagerfeld, who designs the Chlo collection.

title: LEGISLATIVE PLAN FOR NASSAU GAINS
description: MINEOLA, L.I., May 7A controversial plan offered by the Republicancontrolled Nassau County Board of Supervisors for a 15member county Legislature was approved today in State Supreme Court here.
