title: Wednesday's Fights
description: MONTE CARLO, MonacoMiguel de Oliveire, 145 pounds, Brazil, outpointed Jos Duran, 145, Spain, 15 rounds; won vacant World Boxing Council junior middleweight title; Gratien Tonna, 159, France, outpointed Kevin Finnegan, 159, England, 15, won European middleweight championship.

title: Newark Pupils Stay Out, Citing Teacher Dismissals
description: NEWARK, May 8At least 25 per cent of this city's public school students boycotted classes today to dramatize their orposition to planned dismissal of 927 teachers by the Board of Education.

title: F.D.A. Announces Warning On Contact Lens Sterilizer
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration announced today that the owners of 500,000 sterilizers for soft contact lenses were being warned about potential electric shock hazards from the units.

title: Article 1  No Title
Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: BEAM REQUESTS 2D BUDGET DELAY
description: Mayor Beame asked the Legislature yesterday to postpone for one week the submittal of what would be his record $12.8billion expense budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. The delay was sought, the Mayor said, to permit more meetings on our requests for aid.

title: Screen: 'Secret' Dabbles in Suspense
description: David (Jean-Louis Trintignant) is in a fix. He has learned something "no one is allowed to know." When we first see him, in and behind the opening credits of the French film "The Secret." David is strapped to an operating table and water is dripping onto his forehead with maddening regularity. David is being tortured. By whom? What for?The suspense is terrific for approximately seven and a half minutes. After that you may want to make a rude noise or ask for your money back."The Secret," which opened yesterday at the Paris Theater, proves that anybody, including Robert Enrico, who directed this film, can come up with a promising beginning for a suspense melodrama. It's the middles and the ends that cause all the problems."The Secret" is the sort of movie that arbitrarily withholds information. It also depends on its characters to make unlikely, possibly lunatic decisions to string out the running time.Furthermore, it leaves its actors high and dry, looking totally foolish. In addition to Mr. Trintignant, these include Philippe Noiret and Marlene Jobert, who play a married couple that befriend the possibly crazy David. They hide him in their country house near Carcassonne. They give him a gun with which he can better terrorize them, in between those moments when his pathetic story of conspiracy prompts them to attain new heights of idiotic charity.Like most people who go to movies, I'm as willing as the next person to suspend belief. Not this time.

title: House Votes to Bar Variable Home Loan
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) The House voted 291 to 104 today to forbid Federal savings and loan institutions from offering variable interest rate mortgage loans.

title: F16 Lands Wheels Up
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (Reuters)An F16 air combat fighter prototype made an emergency wheels up landing today because of a locked landing gear, the Air Force announced.

title: ARMY ENGINEERS SCORED ON TACTICS
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)Environmental organizations accused the Army Corps of Engineers today of stirring up a nationwide scare campaign by asserting that a proposed regulation would force some farmers to get Federal permis. sion to plow fields.

title: Trade Talks in Accord On Agricultural Products
description: GENEVA, May 8The first major snag in the new round of trade liberalization talks was overcome here today with an accord between the United States and the European Common Market on how to deal with agriculture.

title: HOSPITALS AGENCY TO SHUT DELAFIELD
description: The board of directors of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation voted late yesterday to close Francis Delafield Hospital, the smallest of its 19 municipal hospitals, in response to Mayor Beame's demands for economies.

title: N.C. State Picks Woman
description: RALEIGH, N. C., May 8 (AP)North Carolina State University hired Kay Yow of Elon College today as women's sports coordinator and basketball coach. Miss Yow succeeds R. R. (Peanut) Doak, who held the job on an interim basis during the last year.

title: Castro's Overture Welcomed by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The White House today welcomed the conciliatory remarks made by Premier Fidel Castro last night but said that any dramatic ?? in relation would have to await a formal lifting of diplomatic and trade curbs against Cuba by the Organization of American States.

title: Cambodia Reds Are Uprooting Millions As Theu Impose a Peasant Revolution
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 8  The victorious Cambodian Communists, who marched into Phnom Penh on April 17 and ended five years of war in Cambodia, are carrying out a peasant revolution that has thrown the entire country into upheaval.

title: Flyers No Longer Invincible
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 8Suddenly, there were frowns in the Flyers' dressing room tonight, which happens as often as, say, a team winning the Stanley Cup series after trailing by 3 games to 0.

title: 2 Jockeys Injured
description: ALBANY, Calif., May 8 (AP)Roy Yaka and Anthony Baze, two of the leading jockeys at Golden Gate Fields, suffered broken collarbones in a mishap today.

title: UTILITIES COUNTER T.V.A. PEABODY BID
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)A consortium of power companies in 10 states today challenged the Tennessee Valley Authority's bid to acquire the Peabody Coal Company and said it wanted to buy the company itself.

title: Byrne Scores Sentence Given Weekly Publisher
description: Citing a potential infringement of the freedom of the press, Governor Byrne of New Jersey yesterday criticized a State Superior Court judge who paroled a newspaper publisher on a weapons charge on Wednesday after the publisher agreed to wage an editorial campaign for gun control in his New York City Spanishlanguage weekly.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ON A RED RUG A new Persian night spot, Club Shiraz, happens to be situated in a rather unfestive area, off southwest Union Square and around the bend from Mays store. The club turned out to he a friendly place with exotic background music, a male Persian singerwithguitar named Faromas, and Dalai, a belly dancer who actually seems to he enjoying herself. Between the two specialists, a trio of singing instrumentalists make apt Middle Eastern sounds, now and then dipping into rhythmic American rock.

title: Bettors Will Pick Own Numbers In New Daily Lottery in Jersey
description: NEWARK, May 8Governor Byrne announced today that a new, daily pickyourowndigits lottery, which state officials said was the first of its kind in the country, would begin operations in New Jersey on May 22 for a sixmonth est period.

title: Chipping at Apartheid
description: South Africa's white Government has recently taken several modest but hopeful steps in the direction of dismantling one of the most draconian systems of racial discrimination ever devised; It has restored the rights of Africans to own their homes  though not the ground on which they are builtin the townships outside South African cities, where more than half the country's 18 million blacks live.

title: Norton Simon and India Reach an Accord on Idol
description: A suit filed by India against the Norton Simon Foundation for the rturn of the Nataraja, the bronze Hindu idol acquired for SImillion in 1973, has been suspended by a tentative agreement.

title: GULF CITES STUDY OF BOLIVIAN ROLE
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, under an ultimatum from the Bolivian Government for clarification of a reported $4.2million in payoffs by Gulf to a still unidentified foreign government, issued a statement yesterday saying the question was under investigation.

title: NAME REQUESTS 2D BUDGET DELAY
description: Mayor Beame asked the Legislature yesterday to postpone for one week the submittal of what would be his record $12.8billion expense budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. The delay was sought, the Mayor said, to permit more meetings on our requests for aid.

title: Police Chief of Netcong Indicted With 2 Others on Arson Counts
description: TRENTON, May 8 (AP)The police chief of Netcong Borough in Morris County and two other men were indicted today on charges they burned down the police chief's home and two other buildings to collect insurance.

title: 11 RESTAURANTS ACCUSED OF BIAS
description: The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday filed discrimination charges against a number of leading New York restaurants, accusing them of hiring only waiters rather than waitresses.

title: Treasury Auctions Bonds At Average 8.30% Yield
description: The Treasury auctioned $750million of 30year bonds yesterday at an average yield of 8.30 per cent. That return on the longterm issue bearing an 8 Per cent coupon was right in line with investment community estimates made prior to the announcement. Yesterday's sale, which wound up a threestage sale totaling $5billion, took place against the backdrop of a buoyant credit market.

title: Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Port Authority Terminal Expansion to Start Next Fall
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday that construction would begin in September on the longdelayed expansion and improvement of its midtown bus terminal on Eighth Avenue.

title: 2 % Rise in Food Prices At Retail Level Is Seen
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (Reuters)Retail food prices in the United States will rise about 2 per cent in coming months, mostly due to higher prices for meat, poultry, fish and dairy products, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Ford Assures Asian Visitors on U.S. Ties
description: WASHINGTON, May 8President Ford gave fresh assurances today to officials from South Korea and Singapore that the United States would maintain its presence in Asia.

title: On 12 5th St., the Recession Is Either a Boom or a Bust
description: The recession, which has sounded the death knell for small businesses throughout the country, is being felt on 125th StreetHarlem's major business arteryin peculiar and sometimes conflicting ways.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Joint Commission on Nursing Homes took secret testimony in Trenton from an unidentified nurse who charged that poor care at a South Jersey nursing institution had contributed to the deaths of patients during a flu outbreak last winter. Senator John Fay, Democrat of Middlesex, the commission chairman, said he could not identify the nurse or the nursing home, but he said the home was the object of investigations by the State Departments of the Public Advocate and Institutions and Agencies.

title: Bridge:
description: Almost all competitive activities generate some jealousies and personal animosities at the top levels, and bridge in New York City is no exception. But there are a few experts whose warm and cheerful personalities leave them immune from all feuding: they collect scores of friends and no enemies.

title: SUB FUND AT G.M. STOPS PAYMENTS
description: DETROIT, May 8The General Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers announced today that the supplemental unemployment benefits (SUBS) fund for laidoff G.M. workers was exhausted.

title: U.S Panel Delays for 3 Years Decision on Using Plutonium as Fuel for Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that it would postpone for at least three years a final decision on whether plutonium, the raw material of the atomic bomb, should be used to help power America's nuclear reartors.

title: Kits Flow From a Cubbyhole To Mother's and Father's Days
description: The National Committee on the Observance of Mother's Day, and the Father's Day Council, have one thing in common  a cubbyhole on the 10th floor of 393 Seventh Avenue.

title: Louis Slobodkin, Sculptor, Is Dead at 72
description: Louis Slobodkin, sculptor, illustrator, author of children's books and winner of the 1943 Caldecott Medal for his illustrations of James Thurber's Many Moons, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Bay Harbor Islands, Miami Beach. He was 72 years old.

title: Market Place
description: Since the Chicago Board Options Exchange began trading options two years ago, this market, in which investors pay for the right to purchase 100 shares of a given stock at a set price, has shown phenomenal growth.

title: Fetal Brain Said to Live at 28 Weeks
description: A New York scientist reported evidence here yesterday that brain life in humans begins between the 28th and 32d week of pregnancy, raising questions about just when a human fetus becomes viable and when it first develops the capacity for human intelligence.

title: Costantino Is Exonerated Of Charges of Bribery
description: A Federal grand jury and a special judicial panel have exonerated Judge Mark A. Costantino of allegations that the fix was in when he suspended sentence in a 1973 taxevasion case.

title: AVERY BRUNDAGE OF OLYMPICS DIES
description: GARMISCH  PARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, May 8Avery Brundage, the American multimillionaire who for 20 years as president of the International Olympic Committee fought for what he considered purity in sports and amateurism in world athletic competition, died today in this Bavarian village. He was 87 years old.

title: Kits Flow From a Cubbyhole To Mother's and Father's Days
description: The National Committee on the Observance of Mother's Day, and the Father's Day Council, have one thing in common  a cubbyhole on the 10th floor of 393 Seventh Avenue.

title: GAF Seeking to Acquire Station WQIV
description: The GAF Corporation is negotiating to buy radio station WQIVFM and change its format from rock music to classical. Officials of GAF and the station's owner, the Starr Broadcasting Group, said an agreement was imminent.

title: Nystrom Tallies His First Goal Resch Stars
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 8As mystified as their followers about why they hold so much in reserve until the knife is at their throats, the New York Islanders burst out tonight with a 51 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Energy Conservation Bill Drafted by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The House Ways and Means Connmittee completed drafting tonight a comprehensive energy conservation bill that would raise the Federal gasoline tax, put a quota on oil imports and ??evy an excise tax on automobiles that fail to meet gasoline mileage standards.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly identified the Union Club as the site of a holdup. The holdup actually took place at the Union League Club, which was incorrectly described as the oldest club in the city. The Union Club is believed to be the oldest.

title: CORRECTION AIDE QUITS STATE POST
description: Morton G. Van Hoesen, administrative head of the State Commission of Correction, resigned yesterday in the aftermath of charges that the watchdog agency had concealed irregularities and possible crimes by prison authorities.

title: Data Show Northrop Slush Fund Lasted 2 Years After Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI) The Northrop Corporation continued an illegal political slush fund for nearly two years after it was disclosed, Securities and Exchange Commission documents show.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: State Employes Threaten Strike in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, May 8 (AP)State employe union leaders said today that their members should strike unless Gov. Michael S. Dukakis agreed to bargain over planned layoffs.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A judge of the State Court of Claims was arrested by an offduty patrolman and charged with driving while intoxicated. The police said the incident took place at 12:35 A.M. at the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge toll plaza on Staten Island. The judge, Edward J. Amann Jr., 49 years old, of Staten Island, a former member of the State Assembly who was appointed two years ago to his $48,998ayear judicial post, was arrested by Officer Eugene Wasielewski.

title: Ford Economic Plans
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The Ford Administration, which had been expending much of its energies since it took power last August fighting the adverse economic tides sweeping the country, is now resting on its oars, confident that the crisis is ebbing.

title: Carey, in Bronx, Declares State A Haven for Vietnam Refugees
description: Governor Carey declared last night that New York would provide a safe haven for Vietnamese refugees, but he taxed Pressident Ford for not extending the same degree of compassion to economic refugees in our country and to the poor in the City of New York.

title: To Aid the Colleges
description: The effectiveness of the Basic Opportunity Grants, an imaginative approach to student aid enacted three years ago, has been undercut by a running feud between White House and Congress. The grants are intended to subsidize any qualified student's college education. They begin with total coverage of tuition costs for those at the poverty level and taper off in proportion to rising family income.

title: Big Board Stock Quotations Offered to Other Exchanges
description: The New York Stock Exchange began offering yesterday its bidasked quotations on listed stocks to other exchanges, nonmember brokerdealers and institutional and individual investors.

title: BYRNE CRITICIZES ACTION BY JUDGE
description: Citing a potential infringement of the freedom of the press, Governor Byrne of New Jersey yesterday criticized a State Superior Court judge who paroled a newspaper publisher on a weapons charge on Wednesday after the publisher agreed to wage an editorial campaign for gun control in his New York City Spanishlanguage weekly.

title: BIRMINGHAM PLEA WON BY U.S. STEEL
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 8The United States Steel Corporation was granted today permission to operate five ancient. polluting open hearth furnaces for another year at its Ensley works here after the company had failed to meet a 1972 commitment to clean up or close down the furnaces by May 15 this year.

title: Red Smith
description: Phil Iselin, who worries about Joe Namath, Monmouth Park and the textile business in that order, went to see The Happy Hooker night before last to get his thoughts traveling along other channels. Afterward he dropped into the Russian Tea Room. What's Joe Namath eoine to do? the waitress asked. The president of the New York Jets fished a card from his pocket and handed it over. In large block letters it read simply: I'll be damned if I know. He has them printed by the gross. As Chris Hemmeter and several other people know, Namath is a free agent who has been offered $4million to play quarterback in the World Football League, of which Hemmeter is president. The money, if it exists, would be paid in installmentsa cash bonus of $500,000, a salary of $500,000 a year for three seasons and a 20year annuity of $100,000.

title: Jews in Berlin Mark End of World War II
description: BERLIN, May 8  In the presence of Mayor Klaus Schtz, Jewish survivors of the Nazi period today honored ?? ??ldiers in a ceremony marking the 30th anniversary of the end of World War II.

title: Grief and Animosity In an Embassy Haven
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 8 For the 800 foreigners, including this correspondent, who spent two weeks in the French Embassy in Phnom Penh after the Communists took over, the time seemed like a chaotically compressed generation of life.

title: SAUDI ARABIA PLANS NEW BANK IN LONDON
description: LONDON, May 8Saudi Arabia announced plans today for a merchant bank in London as pact of a longrange program to develop broader economic and financial ties with other countries and gain expertise in financial markets.

title: Crampton Up by Shot With a 66
description: DALLAS, May 8 (AP)Bruce Crampton, picking up where he left off last week, carded a solid, fiveunderpar 66 today and took the firstround lead in the $175,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: BUSSHELTER PLANAPPROVED BY CITY
description: The Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday a plan to finance construction of shelters at bus stops with paid advertising, but it stipulated that none of the shelters be erected on the crowded streets of midtown Manhattan.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Some clothes are snooty, some snappy. Many are conservative classics. But even at the extremes, there's little to upset those who view with alarm any drastic changes in clothing design.

title: Possibility of War Over Stock Fees Worrying Brokers
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 8Less than a week after the start of full price competition on brokerage fees, Wall Street stockbrokers voiced concern at an industry conference here today that a price war might vet develop.

title: Amherst Votes to Welcome Kennedy LibraryMuseum
description: AMHERST, Mass., May 9 (AP)The Amherst town meeting has voted to endorse construction of a John F. Kennedy librarymuseum complex on the campus of the University of Masachusetts here.

title: 5 IN LAOS CABINET REPORTEDLY QUIT
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 9Five proAmerican Cabinet ministers were reported to have resigned from Laos's coalition Government today.

title: CBS Reports K.G.B. Held Oswald Unstable
description: NEW YORK, May 9 (UPI) A former officer in the Soviet secret police, the K.G.B., had told United States officials that while in Moscow Lee Harvey Oswald had been considered mentally abnormal by the K.B.G. and possibly a United States agent, CBS news reported today.

title: ChinaCommon Market Link
description: PEKING, May 9China will ??ablish official relations with ?? European Economic Cornunity and accredit an ambasdor to it, Sir Christopher ??ames, vice president of the ??mmunity Commission in ??arge of external relations, ?? here yesterday. He has had ?? days of talks with sen??r Chinese officials.

title: Brundage Burial Next Week
description: GARMISCHPARTENKIRCHEN, West Germany, May 9 (UPI) The body of Avery Brundage, former president of the International Olympic Committee, will be flown to Chicago next week for burial, his widow said today. Doctors said the 87yearold Mr. Brundage suffered a virus infection two weeks ago and was hospitalized in this Bavarian Alps resort town, where he made his summer home.

title: Music: Naughty Marietta Is Revived
description: The era of American operetta that was dominated by Victor Herbert, Sigmund Romberg and Rudolf Friml pretty much came to an end during the nineteenthirties. The impetus that kept tacky productions of Blossom Time, The Student Prince and Naughty Marietta rolling around the country finally ran down. Postwar revivals of Herbert's The Red Mill and Sweethearts succeeded because of infusions of modern comedyBobby Clark turned Sweethearts into one of the funniest shows of all time.

title: 120 Children Compete Here in Special Olympics for the Handicapped
description: Michael Harris sat still on the wooden floor of the gymnasium at Public School 11 in Brooklyn yesterday, trying to hit a light, blue volleyball over the net. He was one of 120 children on crutches or in wheel chairs, warming up for the fourth annual Dorothy Murray Special Olympic Games for handicapped children.

title: Hanoi Says New Bridge Links North and South
description: HONG KONG, May 9 (Reuters)North Vietnam reported today the completion of a bridge across the Ben Hai Riverthe boundary between North and South Vietnam.

title: 125 DEATHS A YEAR LAID TO AEROSOLS
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)Aerosol products kill an estimated total of 125 Americans. every year, most of them young people who deliberately inhale everything from spray paint to deodorant to experience a high, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today. The estimate was prepared for a hearing with industry leaders to determine whether Federal action was needed.

title: A Radical Columbia Dropout Who Went On to Make It Big
description: On the night of May 10, 1775, the spirit of revolution erupted on the campus of King's College (later renamed Columbia) and a group of students and townspeople decided to oust the college's president, the Rev. Myles Cooper, an Oxford scholar and a militant Tory.

title: Ruffian Class of Filly Field In Acorn at Aqueduct Today
description: Ruffian goes today. Locust Hill Farm's allconquering filly will oppose a surprisingly large group of eight distaff rivals in the Acorn Stakes at Aqueduct, and despite that heavy opposition she will probably he sent off at 1 in 10. With a record of seven victories in her twoyear career, Ruffia.n so dominates the field that her newest rival on the overnight line, William Haggin Perry's Sarsar, is quoted at 6 to 1. And the chance exists that this filly may compete only if, in the words of Sarsar's trainer, David Whiteley, something happens to Ruffian.

title: Urban Congressman Takes On Farm Post
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Six years ago, Representative Shirley Chisholm caused a stir in Congress when she successfully fought against her assignment to the House Committee on Agriculture. As a new member, she was expected to accept docilely the post allotted her by her fellow Democrats.

title: 2 Favorite Bands Of Savoy Ballroom Revived for a Night
description: The music that made the Savoy Ballroom the Home Of Happy Feet in the nineteenthirties, and forties was revived on Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall, and on hand were a few of the happyfooted dancers who once flung themselves through the Lindy hop there. The New York Jazz Repertory Company recreated two bands that were favorites at the Savoythe Savoy Sultans, a ninepiece jump band that kept an endless series of riffs going in an insistently swinging groove, and Lucky Millinder's Blue Rhythm Band, a big group that also built on riffs but with more variety.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court ordered a judicial inquiry yesterday to determine whether a lower court violated the First Amendment guarantee freedom of the press in requiring a newspaper publisher editorialize against handguns as a condition of his parole on a weapons charge.

title: FAYE R. AXELROD
description: Faye Rosenthal Axelrod, dietitian at Knickerbocker Hospital and president of the Visiting Homemakers Service of Bergen County, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 53 years old and lived at 243 Speer Avenue, Englewood, N.J.

title: Shareholders Liquidate Security National Bank
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 9 In a threehour meeting that was raucous at times, shareholders of the Security National Bank voted here today to liquidate the remaining assets of the bank and pay colt $7.40 a share.

title: Theater Festival For Bicentennial Has Been Canceled
description: The projected $5million World Theater Festival, which would have brought foreign theater companies to the United states and sent acting companies from this country abroad in observance of the Bicentennial, has been scrapped.

title: Film: AvantGarde Bill
description: The trio of short subjects by members of California's film making avantgarde that opened Thursday at the Film Forum as successors to a similar Western collection displayed there last month focuses on aspects of the human condition in occasionally satiric but ofen uneven style.

title: 187 STATE JOBS ARE CUT BY CAREY
description: ALBANY, May 9Governor Carey's office announced today that 187 permanently filled positions were dropped from the state's work force last month, bringing to 503 the number of filled jobs eliminated since the Governor's hiring freeze took effect Jan. 8.

title: Borg and Ashe Gain Dallas Final
description: DALLAS, Ma. 9In a 4hour5minute struggle that will ha remembered as one of the great tennis matches, Bjorn. Borg defeated Rod Laver tonight, 76, 36, 57, 76, 62, in the semifinals of the World Championship Tennis final.

title: Kissinger Said to Tell Saudis U.S. Favors New Effort for Oil Talks
description: JIDDA, Sr udi Arabia, May 9 Saudi Arabia has received a message from Secretary of State Kissinger indicating United States readiness to revive efforts to bring about a conference between oil consumers and oil producingers, according to Government sources here.

title: Article 2  No Title
Music: A Mozart Night
description: The scene was Alice Tully Hall and the event was the annual Lincoln Center concert by the 18yearold Long Island chamber group, the Orchestra da Camera. But one might have thought on Thursday night that he had strayed into party headquarters at election time. The lobby was filled with people passing around petitions, sporting lapel buttons and soliciting money for the cause.

title: Four Performances Put Off By the New World Consort
description: Because of the illness of Bill Mount, its director, ehe New World Consort has had to postone its performance at the Clositers tomorrow and the following Sunday and at St. Stephen's Church on Monday and Tuesday.

title: Marijuana Illegal in Plastic
description: SALT LAKE CITY (UPI) Marijuana is illegal in Utaheven if it's imbedded in plastic. The state attorney general's office has issued that opinion after a Salt Lake City service station started selling legal marijuana souvenirsseeds and leaves encased in plastic medallions.

title: Reds Win by 43 on 4Run 5th As Mets Drop 5th Game in Row
News Summary and Index
description: Five proAmerican Cabinet ministers, including the Ministers of Defense and Finance, reportedly resigned from Laos's coalition Government yesterday, in the midst of mounting protests against United States policies and following a demonstration by several thousand Laotian students and teachers against rising prices and foreign economic influences. Some demonstrators threw stones at the United States Embassy in Vientiane. There was no official confirmation of the resignations, which were reported by highly placed sources. [Page 1, Col. 1.]

title: WHEAT CROP SEEN AT A RECORD LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)Farmers are expected to harvest a record winter wheat crop of 1.62 billion bushels, up 16 per cent from the 1974 harvest and 1 per cent more than estimated initially last December, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Two Airlines Face Fines for Bringing Refugees Into U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)Despite the Ford Administration's policy of welcoming Indochina refugees and a Government  sponsored airlift, two commercial airlines have been notified that they face stiff fines for transporting unauthorlized aliens to the United States.

title: SUBPOENA POWER VOTED FOR CHURCH
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence has empowered its chairman, Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, to issue subpoenas that would command the testimony of employes of the Central Intelligence Agency and other agencies of the Federal intelligence community.

title: Controller Limits Bank Use Of FundTransfer Terminals
description: The Controller of the Currency limited yesterday the potential expansion of national banks through the use of electronic terminals used for transferring funds.

title: Schoolboy Runs 100 in 9.0
description: WINTER PARK, Fla., May 9 (AP)A high school student, Houston McTear, equaled the world record in the 100yard dash today with a 9second clocking in a preliminary heat of the state Class AA championship meet.

title: DONALD C. WAGNER
description: Donald C. Wagner, Philadelphia's managing director for seven years under Mayors Richardson Dilworth and James H. J. Tate, died Thursday after suffering a heart attack while driving. He was 73 years old.

title: Burns Gains Final in Golf At Pinehurst
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May 9 (AP)Curtis Strange, the National Collegiate champion, shooting fiveunderpar golf, and George Burns, the 1974 winner, gained the final round today of the North and South amateur tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: AMEX STOCKS UP AS TRADING GAINS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market increased yesterday as trading increased.

title: O.A.S. Postponing Action on Lifting Embargo Against Cuba Until September
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  A majority of the 23 members of the Organization of American States has decided to postpone action on lifting its politicaleconomic embargo against Cuba until next September, diplomats at the annual O.A.S. general assembly reported today.

title: Silverio Breaks Hammer Mark
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 9Manny Silverio made up his mind earlier this week he would not shave until he exceeded 200 feet in the schoolboy hammer throw.

title: Spain to Legalize Strikes by Labor After 36Year Ban
description: MADRID, May 9 (AP)The Spanish Government today approved a bill that will legalize labor strikes for the first time since the end of the civil war in 1939.

title: BOYCOTT PRESSED BY NEWARK PUPILS
description: NEWARK. May 9 (AP)About 40 per cent of this city's public school students stayed home from class today on the second day of a boycott to protest plans to lay off more than 900 teachers and cut back extracurricular programs.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Arlen Realty & Development Corporation is negotiating'with New York City planning officials to build the garMent center's first tower that incorporates residences and offices. Even though the city abounds in new and vacant office space, the building company has decided, on the basis of tenant interest in the area, to proceed immediately on the site, now a parking lot on the east side of the Avenue of the Americas between 36th and 37th Streets. The company will definitely build at least an office building on the site. The zoning change it is seeking would permit a 35story building with 25 floors of apartments and 140,000 square feet of offic'e space, more than a third of which it says is already committed.

title: Drop in March Inventories A Record, but Sales Fell
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The nation's businesses sold far greater quantities of goods than they bought in March, resulting in a record monthly decline of $1.9billion in business inventories, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Seoul Government Backed By 30,000 at School Rallies
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 9 (Reuters)About 30,000 students, with many of their schools still closed following antiGovernment riots on April 4, today pledged their support for their Government and burnt effigies of the North Korean President, Kim Il Sung.

title: Unilever Profit Slumps; Other Companies Report
The Ballet: Bolshoi's Controversial Swan Lake
description: Yuri Grigorovich's classically inclined restaging of the Bolshoi Ballet's Swan Lake has proved predictably controversial, although a man would have to be stoneblind not to recognize its evident superiority over the ramshackle production it has superseded. However, controversy apart, there can be no conceivable doubts about the beauties and excellences of two remarkable New York debuts as Odette/Odile during the last weekLudmila Semenyaka on Tuesday and Natalya Bessmertnova on Thursday. Partnering both ballerinas was the Estonianborn dancer Aleksandr Bogatyrev, making his New York debut in a leading role.

title: Film: AvantGarde Bill
description: The trio of short subjects by members of California's film making avantgarde that opened Thursday at the Film Forum ass successors to a similar Western collection displayed there last month focuses on aspects of the human condition in occasionally satiric but often uneven style.

title: JAIL REBELS IN ITALY SAID TO HOLD JUDGE
description: ROME, May 9Prisoners in a penitentiary in Viterbo, 50 miles northwest of Rome, staged a revolt tonight and threatened to kill a high judge whom they said they were holding hostage.

title: Irish Catholic Bishops Assail Violence Campaign
description: DUBLIN, May 10 (UPI)The Irish Roman Catholic hierarchy said today that the campaign of killings and bombings in Northern Ireland could never be justified in the name of patriotism.

title: Grounding the Texas Air Force
description: WASHINGTON  President Ford signed into law on April 8 a bill that rescinds appropriations passed last year totaling $243 million, of which $123 million would have been spent to buy 12 F111 fighters from General Dynamics of Fort Worth, Tex.

title: Drika Agnew Has Nuptials
description: Drika Nan Agnew and Alexander Purves, both of New York, were married here yesterday afternoon in the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony.

title: WALTER W. MEAD
description: Walter W. Mead, who had been an advertising agency executive here, died Thursday at his home in Portarlington, a town partly in County Laoighis and partly in County Offaly, Ireland. He was 58 years old and formerly had lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Discard Ending of VE Day Stirs a Wide Controversy
description: PARIS, May 9  European leaders solemnly marked the 25th anniversary of the first step toward Western Europe's unity here today while the streets of Paris were still brightened with flags and flowers to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the end of World War II yesterday.

title: Heidelberg Police Search the Offices Of U. S. Lawyers
description: BONN, May 9The West German police today searched the offices and files of a group of American lawyers in Heidelberg who defend United States soldiers. They said later that they were looking for a German lawyer they suspected of providing weapons to a terrorist organization.

title: Better Than Pesticides
description: The busy birds, as some call them, are at work in the garden now, cramming their crops with insect fare, doing a better job of protecting plants from insect pests than any pesticide ever invented. You can see and hear them in almost any grassy dooryard, working at the job.

title: Nations Urged to Hold Back on Sea Exploitation
description: GENEVA, May 9The President of the United Nations Law of the Sea Conference addressed today a fervent appeal to all coastal nations to refrain from grabbing a greater share of the oceans' resources before a new international treaty governing man's use of the seas can be completed.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Moses Malone decided not to go to college a year ago so he could begin collecting $3million for stuffing basketballs through a hoop for the next 12 years. He was reported to be the first basketball player in nearly 30 years to go directly from high school into the professional ranks.

title: . . . But Plants Are Sold All Over Town
description: Live green plants seem to have become more of a necessity than a luxury for city dwellers and, as their popularity has increased, so have the sources of supply. Apart from the myriad shops all over town devoted exclusively to plants and gardening supplies, there's hardly a florist that doesn't carry potted plants in addition to cut flowers and there's hardly a dime or department store that doesn't deal in the commodity.

title: TwoPhase Overhaul Plan Is TentativeEarnings Increases Noted
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and its 24 lending banks announced tentative agreement yesterday on a twophase plan to overhaul the financial structure of the debtladen aerospace giant.

title: COCOA FUTURES SHOW AN INCREASE
description: British traders actively bought cocoa and sugar futures in London yesterday as a hedge against a sharp decline in the value of the pound. In New York, cocoa futures held their gains through the session on the New York Cocoa Exchange, with the July delivery closing at 47.43 up from 46 cents A pound.

title: A's Defeat Yankees by 43 On Lyle's Wild Pitch in 8th
description: OAKLAND. Calif., May 9 Catfish Hunter was finally reunited withhis old teammates on the Oakland A's tonight and reflected: I miss the fights. But the A's supplied him with some reminders of the good old days by sending the New York Yankees to their sixth straight defeat in their debut on the West Coast.

title: POUND IS LOWER DESPITE SUPPORT
description: LONDON, May 9 (AP)The British pound fell sharply today, to a record low on a tradeweighted basis, despite some halfhearted support by the Bank of England, dealers said.

title: Seton Hall Prep Seniors Told to Trim and Comb
description: SOUTH ORANGEA group of seniors at Seton Hall preparatory school here will trim and comb their long hair or wait for the postman to bring their diplomas according to school authorities.

title: Saigon Is Said to Demand Refugee Children Return
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9An American group seeking to block temporarily, at least, the adoption of South Vietnamese refugee children said here today that it had received word from the new Government of South Vietnam that it wanted the youngsters back in Vietnam.

title: In Wilton, a Footlight Flea Mart
description: WILTON, Conn., May 9I can always remember the flops, said Armina Marshall, moving through clusters of friends, picking her way through parts of costumes and stage sets, past the autographed scripts, albums, posters and other bits of theater memorabilia piled high in her huge, rustic living room.

title: Ford Social Receptions OffLimits to the Press
description: WUNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 9  President Ford has laid down a new law at the White Houseno press coverage of social receptions in which he is the host.

title: Elderly in River Edge Acquiring New Skills
description: RIVER EDGE, May 9Elderly residents make up 10 per cent of the population of this threesquaremile municipality, and an innovative program is proving that it is never too late for them to learn new skills and attitudes.

title: State Rights Unit Hints At Bias by Macmillan
description: The State Division of Human Rights said yesterday that it had found probable cause to believe that Macmillan, Inc., had used unlawful discrimination in dismissing nine women employes.

title: Cambodia Calls for Drive To Rebuild Her Industry
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 9 The new Cambodian Government has announced a major program to rebuild shattered industry as well as agriculture.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, May 9, 1975

title: KILLER OF OFFICER GETS 15YEAR TERM
description: Julio Vasquez, a 31yearold former convict, was sentenced to a minimum of 15 years and a maximum of life imprisonment yesterday for killing an offduty police officer whose dismembered body was found in a plastic bag outside a Chinese laundry on West 79th Street last September.

title: The Karate King Wants Ali for Kicks
description: As always, the words had more rhyme than poetry as Muhammad All glared across the ring at his blackbelted, whiterobed opponent. I'll make a mess of Joe Hass, the heavyweight boxing champion announced. In the ring with Ali, he'll think I'm Bruce Lee.

title: Manila Asks Area Amity Pact, Acts to Open Alliance to Reds
description: The executive committee of the Philippines' National Security Council, chaired by President Ferdinand E. Marcos, worked out the new policy moves in a threeandahalf hour conference.

title: Council Asks Legislature To Extend Budget Deadline
description: As expected, the City Council yesterday approved a homerule message asking the Legislature to give Mayor Beame a week's grace, until May 22, to submit a balanced $12.8billion expense budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: Article 1  No Title
WILLIAM PRETTYMAN
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., May 9 (AP)  William M. Prettyman, an insurance broker here who survived 33 bombing missions in World War II. died today of cancer. He was 56 years old and lived at 330 Carlton Terrace.

title: 101 Is Age of the Student, Not Number of the Course
description: I can never get enough to learn, Joseph Schoenberger said yesterday, and I learn more with the passing years.

title: New F15 Fighter Grounded Because of Engine Problem
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) The Air Force has temporarily grounded the F15 Eagle fighter because a part of the $1.7million engine may crack at high speeds, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Union President Reelected
description: WASHINGTON. May 9 (A) C. L. Dennis won reelection yesterday as president of th Brotherhood of Railway an Airline Clerks in a bitter co?? test after which his oppone?? vowed to challenge the resul in court. Mr. Dennis, who will be 67 years old next month, defeated the union's vice president, Jack Fletcher, by a vo?? of 878 to 632.

title: U.S. Companies Aid Evacuated Vietnamese Employes
description: American companies have reported that they managed to get varying numbers of Vietnamese employes out of South Vietnam and have kept them on their payrolls or plan to help them find other jobs.

title: Army Accused of Cruelty In Tests Involving Animals
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) Senator William V. Roth said today that Army crowdcontrol experiments, using hard rubber balls fired at high velocity, have killed or maimed 500 test animals.

title: Conferees Tentatively Set 367Billion Budget Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, May 9A SenateHouse conference committee agreed today to set a tentative ceiling of $367billion on Government spending for the next fiscal year, which begins July 1. The committee estimates that this ceiling, if not breached, would mean a deficit of $68.8billion.

title: Canada to Lend 500Million To Soviet to Buy Machinery
description: OTTAWA, May 9  Canada and the Soviet Union signed a trade agreement today under which Canada will lend up to $500million in the next two years to finance Soviet purchases of Canadian machinery, equipment and services.

title: Music: Naughty Marietta Is Revived
description: Tile era of American operetta that was dominated by Victor Herbert, Sigmund Romberg and Rudolf Friml pretty much came to an end during the nineteenthirties. The impetus that kept tacky productions of Blossom Time, The Student Prince and Naughty Marietta rolling around the country finally ran down. Postwar revivals of Herbert's The Red Mill and Sweethearts succeeded because of infusions of modern comedyBobby Clark turned Sweethearts into one of the funniest shows of all time.

title: NEW UNESCO BAN ON ISRAEL VOTED
description: PARIS, May 9The executive board of UNESCO voted twice today to exclude Israel from conferences on education in the Mediterranean area.

title: Inquiry Said to Focus On Mt. Laurel Home
description: TRENTON, May 9 (UPI)A nursing home in which a nurse contends that 30 elderly residents died during an outbreak of influenza last winter has been identified by informants as the Convalescent Center of Mount Laurel.

title: GLOMAR EXPLORER BACK AFTER TRIALS
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 9 (AP)The Glomar Explorer, the ship reportedly used by the Central Intelligence Agency to raise part of a sunken Soviet submarine, returned to port today after sea maneuvers.

title: 1Up Victory Puts Ragaini in Semifinals
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 9A member of the chorus that sings an airline commercial ending with You Gotta Believe ... became a believer today.

title: Notes on People
description: When the Supreme Court resumes sessions Monday, after a twoweek recess, Associate Justice William O. Douglas will still be here in New York University's Institute for Rehabiltation Medicine, where he was admitted April 22. Preliminary evaluation of his condition following a stroke on Dec. 31 has been completed a spokesman said, but he is expected to remain for three or more weeks.

title: Drop in March Inventories A Record, but Sales Fell
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The nation's businesses sold far greater quantities of goods than they bought in March, resulting in a record monthly decline of $1.9billion in business inventories, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Imaging System Utilized In Laser Beam Scanner
description: WASHINGTON, May 9A scientist at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N. J., has invented an imaging system that can be used in a laser beam scanner, both to take pictures and project images. The invention is part of an experimental method of using lasers to produce text, sketches and photographs for long distance facsimile transmission. RCA regards it as suitable for inspection equipment such as the automated checkout systems that are being introduced in supermarkets.

title: Peak Wheat Crop Seen
description: Farmers are expected to harvest a record winter wheat crop of 1.62 billion bushels, up 16 per cent from the 1974 harvest and 1 per cent higher than estimated initially last December, the Agriculture Department reported yesterday. Page 41.

title: COURT BACKS REVIEW OF U.S. HEALTH BILLS
description: CHICAGO, May 9 (UPI)Federal legislation setting up professional standards review organizations to watch over bills submitted to Federal health agencies has been ruled constitutional by a threejudge Federal panel.

title: FARM GROUP LOSES TAXFREE STATUS
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service said today that the National Farmers Organization, one of the largest farm groups in the nation, had lost its taxexempt status.

title: Spooks In an Open Society
description: PARISThe Central Intelligence Agency has been so traduced in recent months and so unfairly given the public image of an American equivalent of the Soviet secret security apparatus with its enormous political power in Russia and its own private military organization that I would like to tell the following story.

title: Parkway Inquiry Focuses on One Vender
description: WOODBRIDGE, May 9John P. Gallagher, executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority, said today that a state grand jury investigation into purchasing and bidgranting activities by the Garden State Parkway, to date, has centered on one particular vender that has been dealing with the authority.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: CRUNCH ON CREDIT CALLED UNLIKELY
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 9 (AP)A credit crunch probably will not result from heavy Federal borrowing, a group of business economists said today.

title: Down and Out in Revolutionary Boston
description: LEXINGTON, Mass.The standard histories of the American Revolution provide scant detail on the life of the colonial worker, especially in the city. We read of the merchants and editors, politicians and martyrs, but very little of the common menthe laborers, sailors, artisans, criminals, debtors and poor who built the roads, peopled the mobs, cast the cannon, served in the ragtag army. What drove them to such an arrogant war? What was their life like, particularly in Boston, where the rebellion began?

title: Protecting Farmworkers
description: Through a herculean effort of legislative leadership, California's Governor, Edmund G. Brown Jr., seems to have constructed a legislative package which will bring civilization to California's grape and lettuce fields and a large measure of discomfort to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: CharterRevision Proposals Are Praised
description: Several civic groups praised the State Charter Revision Commission yesterday for its proposals for strengthening the role of local communities and the City Council in the budget process as hearings began on the proposed new City Charter.

title: CAR LAYOFFS WIDEN DESPITE CALLBACKS
description: DETROIT, May 9The number of jobless auto workers will climb by 2,088 to 180,101 next week even though more workers are being recalled from the rolls of those furloughed indefinitely.

title: JOE E. ANDERSON
description: COVINGTON, Ky., May 9 (AP)Joe E. Anderson, considered the No. 1 middleweight boxing contender during the nineteentwenties, died here yesterday. He was 69 years old.

title: CHINESE SAY SOVIET SURPASSES HITLER
description: TOKYO, May 9 (AP)China delivered a blistering attack on the Soviet Union today, charging the Kremlin is trying to embark en Hitler's beaten track of world domination.

title: Israeli Aide Pleads Guilty to 14 Counts In Corruption Case
description: TEL AVIV, May 9Michael Tzur, the highest Israeli official ever charged with corruption, pleaded guilty here today to 14 counts of larceny, bribery and corruption.

title: Braniff Concedes Giving $40,000 to Nixon Drive
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) Braniff Airlines admitted today that it contributed $40,000 to Richard M. Nixon's election campaign, using a complicated procedure involving a ticket sales system that circumvented the airline's normal accounting practice.

title: Singaporean Bids Ford and Congress Close Rift Over Asia
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore said in Washington last night that the loss of American allies in Indochina to Communism was an unmitigated disaster and that unless the Ford Administration and Congress spoke with one voice in the future, further aggression could not be deterred.

title: People in Sports
description: John Shumate, whose rookie year in pro basketball was wiped out because of blood clots in his left lung. will return to the Phoenix Suns' training camp in August and hopes to play well enough to make the roster of the National Basketball Association club.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: A Real American Welcome
description: When the English got to America, they found many people who were not fit to be Americans. There were the Indians, and the English put them in their place, which was underground or out in the lowrent district away from the seashore.

title: Students Show Their Performance Energy in ModernDance Competition
description: If anyone had asked Maritza Silva two years ago if she would like to be a dancer, chances are the question would have drawn a blank stare or a polite giggle. But last night she was on the program for Modern Dance Showcase 1975. a concert of dance performed and primarily choreographed by students of the city's public high schools, and won a scholarship to the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater.

title: Now, It's Brandy Versus Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, May 9It is a matter of opinion whether brandy goes well with turkey, but the two may be linked in the latest trade dispute between the United States and the European Economic Community.

title: The Great Convene To Forge a Nation
description: Loyal to their king, but steadfast in their challenge, the delegates slowly made their way  often through prematurely celebrating crowds roused by the news of British defeatto the State House in Philadelphia.

title: M.T.A. Weighs Cut In Night Subways
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is planning A sharp cutback in subway trains operating between 11 P.M. and 5 A.M., and also longer waits between daytime trains running in offpeak hours.

title: F.D.I.C. Announces Failure Of Chicopee Bank & Trust
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation tonight announced the failure of the Chicopee Bank & Trust Company in Massachusetts.

title: Slate Opposed to U.F.T. Wins In District 16 School Election
description: A slate opposed to the teacher's union, which included three writein candidates, retained a majority of the seats in Community School District 16 in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn in last Tuesday's citywide school election.

title: MARY FRASCA, 84, SOCIAL WORKER
description: Mary A. Frasca, whose 50year career in social work included service as a member of the City Parole Commission and the Board of Child Welfare, died Thursday at her home, 45 Fifth Avenue. She was 84 years old.

title: Conflicting Views on the Virgin Islands Presented to Colonialism Unit of U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 9  The Virgin Islands needs more tourists and new industry, according to Cyril E. King, the elected Governor, but progress is being made economically and politically.

title: Waiting Rider Slain On the East Side IRT Just After Midnight
description: A man waiting for a train on a deserted subway station in East Harlem early yesterday was attacked and fatally stabbed, apparently by two youths.

title: F. E. Houston Weds Vondamae E. Nary
description: Vondamae Elizabeth Nary of Arlington, Mass., a senior compensation administrator with the Polaroid Corporation in Waltham, Mass., was married yesterday to Forrest Enos Houston of Cambridge, Mass., an electrical engineer and department head at the Charles Stark Draper Laboratory in Cambridge. The Rev. Ralph N. Helverson, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge.

title: Bank Holdup Is a Holdup To the Police in Buffalo
description: There was something furtive and menacing about the man who stepped into a Marine Midland Bank in Buffalo just before closing time. His hat was pulled down over his eyes and he carried a brown paper bag as he moved up to a teller and handed her a note.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MAY 10, 1975

title: Study Warns of Peril in Mideast War
description: LONDON, May 9 (UPI)A new Middle East war is a real possibility and most likely would trigger a second Arab oil embargo that could lead to international anarchy and economic ruin, the Institute of Strategic Services warned to day.

title: Khmer Upheaval
description: First the King and the surviving notables, and then the people, fled from the great and glorious capital to Khmer civilization as if it were ridden with plague. So writes Lawrence P. Briggs, historian of ancient Cambodia, of the fall of Angkor Wat in the fifteenth century.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Hugh Smith, 79, Times Reporter In Dublin for 24 Years, Is Dead
description: DUBLIN, May 9Hugh Smith, who helped report Ireland's history for almost 60 years, died in a hospital here today. He was 79 years old. Mr. Smith was The New York Times Dublin correspondent from 1948 to 1972.

title: People and Business
description: John E. Sheehan, 45, who announced last month that he was resigning effective June 1 as a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve, will become president and chief operating officer on that date of the White Motor Corporation, Cleveland.

title: Dawns Are Quiet' Added To Bolshoi Opera Schedule
description: Kiril Molchanov's new opera, the Dawns Are Quiet Here, ?? been added to the repertory ?? be performed by the Bolshoi pera at the Metropolitan peraHouse this summer.

title: Two Gorillas Get a Taste of Painting in Apes' Art Program at Bronx Zoo
description: Two young lowland gorillas painted at the Bronx Zoo yesterday, experimenting with an action technique that involved finger painting, foot Painting and nose painting.

title: Council Votes to Let Landlords Pass FuelCost Rise to Tenants
description: The City Council last night approved rent increases of up to $9 a month to help compensate landlords of many of the 900,000 rentcontrolled apartments here who were hurt by higher fuel costs.

title: JOSEPH R. HUXLEY
description: Joseph R. Huxley, president and chief executive officer of the Thomas Publishing Company, died of leukemia Monday at the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. He was 63 years old and lived in Beechurst, Queens.

title: FATHER MEYER DIES A CHINA MISSIONARY
description: The Rev. Bernard F. Meyer, one of the first group of Maryknoll Fathers assigned to missionary work in China in 1918, died Thursday at Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 84 years old and lived at the Maryknoll headquarters in Ossining. N.Y.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was erroneously stated in The New York Times of May 1 that a Frenchbuilt turbotrain on the way to Boston developed trouble and had to be towed back to Penn Station. Actually, the locomotive was built by an American concern, United Aircraft Corporation, now United Technologies Corporation.

title: Philip Dorn, Film Actor, Dies; CoStar in I Remember Mama
description: LOS ANGELES, May 9 (AP) Philip Dorn, handsome, deepvoiced leading man in films from 1939 to 1953, died today at the Motion Picture Country House and Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: France to Rejoin Europe Currency Bloc
description: PARIS, May 9  President Valery Giscard d'Estaing announced today that France would rejoin a European currency bloc led by the West German mark in a bid to revive European monetary and political union.

title: POLICE TO DISBAND SPECIAL DURK UNIT
description: A special police investigating unit headed by Lieut. David Durk, which had taken part in an unusual Federalcity undercover investigation of organized crime in the garment district, is being disbanded.

title: 9% CUT IN BUYING OF ARMS IS ASKED BY SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, May 9The Senate Armed Services Committee, setting the stage for the annual defense debate in the Senate, proposed today a reduction of about 9 per cent in the Defense Department's weapons procurement and research programs in the coming fiscal year.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Council Votes RentIncrease Measure
description: The City Council last night approved rent increases of up to $9 a month to help compensate landlords In many of the 900,000 rentcontrolled apartments here who were hurt by higher fuel costs.

title: At First Blush, There Seem to Be an Awful Lot of Shy People
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.The first systematic study of why people are shyand how it affects their livesis now underway at Stanford University.

title: A SHIFT ON TAIWAN BY U.S. IS OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, May 9Arguments are being strongly advanced within the Administration that no new concessions should be made to China on the status of Taiwan, according to sources familiar with these discussions.

title: CONNECTICUT GETS 1.6BILION BUDGET AND TAX INCREASE
description: HARTFORD, May 9The Connecticut General Assembly approved tonight a 61.68billion budget for 197576, with an accompanying $125million tax increase.

title: Islander Comeback Strategy Gets 2d Chance With Flyers
description: After the Islanders had lost the first three games of their National Hockey League semifinal series with the Philadelphia Flyers, Bill Torrey, the islanders' general manager, clenched his fist and said jokingly, Now we've got 'em where we want 'em. At this point in the series that statement probably would not strike the funnybone of the Flyers.

title: Dividends Announced
ITALY SAID TO LINK BANKS TO RANSOM
description: ROME, May 9Major Italian newspapers have reported during the last few days that judiciary authorities are investigating two banks on suspicion of having laundered ransom money from kidnappings.

title: The Great Convene To Forge a Nation
description: Loyal to their king, but steadfast in their challenge, the delegates slowly made their way  often through prematurely celebrating crowds roused by the news of British defeatto the State House in Philadelphia.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OPEN SEASON Fair weather spells fair time. There's a County Fair today inside and out at the Cathedral School (adjacent to the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine) on Amsterdam Avenue and 111th Street. Outside, the accent is rustic, with scheduled haywagon rides, pieeating contests, a judging of homebaked food by comedians, Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara, dancing exhibitions, a display of Mother's Day merchandise and conducted tours of the school's Bible Gardens (featuring flowers, trees and herbs mentioned in the Scripture).

title: Art: 3 Centuries of the American Nude
description: Three Centuries of the American Nude at the New York Cultural Center on Columbus Circle derives its theme, and derives many of its attractions, from a book by William H. Gerdts, The Great American Nude (Praeger Publishers, $25).

title: Champions Tourney Out Of Golf Tour
description: DALLAS, May 9 (AP)Golf's touring pros expressed surprise, disbelief and disappointment today on learning of the cancellation of the Tournament of Champions.

title: CONNECTICUT GETS 1.6BILLION BUDGET AND TAX INCREASE
description: HARTFORD, May 9The Connecticut General Assembly approved tonight a $1.68billion budget for 197576, with an accompanying $125million tax increase.

title: Cannes Site Bombed
description: CANNES, France, May 9 (AP) A predawn explosion badly damaged the building where the Cannes Film Festival is scheduled to open tonight. No injuries were reported and the cause of the blast was not immediately known. The festival will open as planned, a festival official said.

title: Mrs. Abzug Assails Dominance Of Men in Executive Press Jobs
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug predicted yesterday that women journalists would achieve equal advancement, recognition and opportunity only when they crash into the top management of newspapers, radio and television.

title: CONVERTER TESTING FOR POLLUTION SET
description: DETROIT, May 9 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation and the Environmental Protection Agency are embarking on joint experiments to determine the extent and hazards of sulphuric acid emissions from automobiles equipped with catalytic converters.

title: New Rector Chosen By Grace Episcopal
description: The Rev. Dr. Christopher FitzSimons Allison, professor of church history at the Virginia Theological Seminary in Alexandria since 1967, has accepted a call to be the 11th rector of the historic Grace Episcopal Church at Broadway and 10th Street.

title: Saigon Prohibits Checks And All Foreign Currency
description: HONG KONG, May 9The military administrative committee running the Saigon area unveiled a cashonly economy for South Vietnam today and issued a series of orders to foreigners including diplomats, the Saigon radio reported.

title: April Retail Sales Up 1.4% as Result Of March Revision
description: Total retail sales in the country in April rose 1.4 per cent from the preceding month, but the increase was mainly the result of a downward revision of the March total, the Commerce Department reported yesterday in Washington.

title: L.I. Shop Owner Is Slain by Intruder
description: NORTH AMITYVILLE, LI., May 9The proprietor of a small neighborhood delicatessen in this residential community on Long Island's South Shore was shot and killed here late last night when she apparently surprised a burglar.

title: Judicial Amendments
description: Unless the State Legislature approves second passage of two constitutional amendments affecting New York's judicial system, court reform will continue to be talked to death in Albany. Next week the Senate judiciary committee will vote on the previously approved amendments the first guiding step before the full Legislature permits the voters to decide in November.

title: Two Killed on West Coast As Plane Hits Mountain
description: VAN NUTS Calif., May 9 (UPI)The bodies of a cousin of Otis Chandler, publisher of the Los Angeles Times and a flight instructor were found today in a light plane that crashed in the Tehachapi Mountains.

title: WBAI to Cover Peace Rally
description: Radio station WBAIFM will preempt its normal programing Sunday afternoon to provide live coverage of a peace rally scheduled to take place in Central Park's Sheep Meadow beginning at approximately 12:30 P.M. The rally is expected to include appearances by Joan Baez, Odetta, Phil Ochs David Dellinger, Pete Seeger, Peter Yarrow and Tom Paxton.

title: Stocks Are Buoyed By Inventory Decline
description: The stock market, buoyed by news of a record drop in inventory levels in March, registered a broad advance yesterday in much heavier trading.

title: Music: A Mozart Night
description: The scene was Alice Tully Hall and the event was the annual Lincoln Center concert by the 18yearold Long Island chamber group, the Orchestra da Camera. But one might have thought on Thursday night that he had strayed into party headquarters at election time. The lobby was filled with people passing around petitions, sporting lapel buttons and soliciting money for the cause.

title: Nelson's 134 Gains Dallas Golf Lead
description: DALLAS, May 9(AP)Larry Nelson, a littleknown sophomore on the pro golf tour, shot a sixunderpar 65 in oppressive, muggy heat today and took the secondround lead in the $175,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: OFFICIAL HOCKEY SCORE SHEET
Kaat of White Sox Takes 12th in Row
description: A Minnesota castoff two years ago. Jim Kast of the White Sox is the first pitcher in Chicago history to win 12 straight games. The veteran southpaw accomplished that feat last night in Cleveland when he shut out the Indians, 20, on a sixhit effort.

title: Diamond Polisher Is Arrested Here In $637,000 Theft
description: A diamond polisher was arrested yesterday and charged with robbing $637,000 worth of diamonds from the midtown jewelry concern where he worked, the police said.

title: 48,000 REFUGEES JAMMED ON GUAM
description: OROTE POINT, Guam, Saturday, May 10The South Vietnamese refugee population on Guam continued to grow rapidly today as more than 8,000 new refugees arrived here on three merchant ships, including one vessel that left Saigon after the capital fell to the Communists.

title: Wilson Home, Burden Is Heavier
description: LONDON, May 9  After nearly two weeks abroad, Prime Minister Harold Wilson flew back to London last night to find a mood of rising bitterness and dismay over the state of the nation.

title: Celtics Stay Alive On 10399 Victory
description: BOSTON, May 9In a game that both teams tried to turn into a street brawl, the Boston Celtics staved off elimination from the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference final tonight by defeating the Washington Bullets. 10399.

title: Private Flying Gaining Favor
description: MANHASSET BAY, L.I., May 9Ted Bergmann hates to drive, so whenever his wife asks him to go shopping for fresh lobsters, he takes the family plane.

title: In California's Lettuce Valley, a Harvest of Turmoil
description: SALINAS, Calif., May 7These mornings, mists shroud the Gabilan Mountains looming over the Salinas Valley and then disappear as the warm spring sun rises and warms the darkskinned field workers who toil to fill the Salad bowls of New York, Los Angeles and Milwaukee.

title: For a House Term of 8 Years. Count 'em. 8.
description: WASHINGTON  Spurred by the Democratic freshmen class, the House of Representatives is reforming itself to the point of revolution. In most quarters the news is welcome and long overdue. But by their success the reformers have demonstrated the need for one more reform: limiting the length of time a member may serve in the House.

title: KENNETH M. LANGMUIR
description: Kenneth M. Langmuir, a retired investment counselor, died May 2, apparently of emphysema, at his home in Los Angeles. He was 58 years old and until 1967 had lived here.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: F.C.C. Expands '68 Policy On Using Own Phone Parts
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission vastly expanded today its 1968 policy requiring telephone companies to allow customers to use their own phone equipment.

title: PRIMARY FOR 1976 IS VOTED IN TEXAS
description: AUSTIN, May 9The Texas Senate and House passed a bill today setting up a 1976 Presidential primary that Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas thinks will bolster his chances for the Democratic party's nomination for President.

title: DUALUSE TOWER PLANNED ON 36 ST.
description: Arlen Realty & Development Corporation is negotiating with city planning officials to build the garment center's first tower that incorporates residences and offices.

title: Conferees Tentatively Set 367Billion Budget Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, May 9A SenateHouse conference committee agreed today to set a tentative ceiling of $367billion on Government spending for the next fiscal year, which begins July 1. The committee estimates that this ceiling, if not breached, would mean a deficit of $68.8billion.

title: Canada Cites Gains In Accord With U.S. On Defence System
description: OTTAWA, May 9Canada and the United States have renewed the 1958 North American Air Defense (NORAD) agreement for another five years with few changes, Allan J. MacEachen, the Secretary of State for External Affairs, announced today.

title: Stage: Gorky's Difficult Our Father
description: Maxim Gorky's Our Father (also known as The Last Ones) was published in 1908 but was not performed in Russia until 1918. The Repertory Company of the Virginia Museum Theater has had the perspicacity to give the play its American premiere of the English adaptation by William Marion Smith. The play was first presented in February in the company's home in Richmond and it opened Thursday at Stage 73. Regrettably the New York run is scant; the production is scheduled to close tomorrow night.

title: Spring Rites Kill S.I. Girl Attending William and Mary
description: The daughter of a Staten Island army officer drowned accidentally early yesterday during spring rites held annually by the students of the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va., where she was a freshman, the Williamsburg police reported last night.

title: No Credit Crunch Seen
description: Heavy Government borrowing probably will not result in a credit crunch, according to an assessment by a group of business economists. Page 37.

title: Saigon Prohibits Checks And All Foreign Currency
description: HONG KONG, May 9The military administrative committee running the Saigon area unveiled a cashonly economy for South Vietnam today and issued a series of orders to foreigners including diplomats, the Saigon radio reported.

title: CANADA SETS POLICY ON NUCLEAR EXPORT
description: OTTAWA, May 9The Canadian Government, still smarting over India's use of Canadian materials to produce a nuclear explosion last year, set guidelines today for assisting other countries in developing nuclear power plants. The new policy immediately started a controversy.

title: Bridge:
description: The democratic tradition in American bridge organization has one considerable drawback: a pair contest in which there is no weak pair is Virtually nonexistent. If the standard for inclusion is a purely objective onesuch as master points, or a certain degree of tournament successthere will always be at least a few sheep among the wolves.

title: 20 Children Compete Here in Special Olympics for the Handicapped
description: Michael Harris sat still on the wooden floor of the gymnasium at Public School 11 in Brooklyn yesterday, trying to hit a light, blue volleyball over the net. He was one of 120 children on crutches or in wheel chairs, warming up for the fourth annual Dorothy Murray Special Olympic Games for handicapped children.

title: Acquisitions at the Guggenheim
description: Museums generally function on two fronts. They lavish immense energy and expense on mounting temporary loan exhibitions, and these bring large rewards in terms of publicity, attendance and serious critical attention. At the same time, though with usually less fanfare (unless a great sum of money is involved), they perservere in the task of adding works of art to their permanent collections. This is a process that normally interests the publicand often even the criticsmuch less. Except in the case of objects boasting a significant and wellestablished place in art history, new acquisitions do not count as important news to anyone outside the circle of artists, curators, dealers and collectors immediately involved.

title: Hiss Appeals to Court in Boston To Reinstate Him as a Lawyer
description: BOSTON, May 9The highest court in Massachusetts heard an appeal today for Alger Hiss, 70 years old, to be readmitted as a lawyer here on grounds of good character and a good record since his release from prison in 1954.

title: Opposition Grows to Bill Splitting Off Bronx Courts
description: With the strong backing of Bronx political leaders, a bill that would drastically alter the judicial map of the city has been quietly moving through the State Legislature. The bill, which would split the Bronx and Manhattan into separate judicial districts, is expected to be debated in the State Senate next week.

title: Brokers Confront the City Over Proposed Tax Rises
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 9A new confrontation between New York City and the brokerage industry emerged here today over the Issue of proposed increases in taxes on securities trading.

title: Antiques: Asian Pottery
description: Does the pottery of Southeast Asia predate that of ancient China? What cultures shaped the export wares that traveled from Thailand and Annam (Vietnam) to Indonesia and the Philippines 600 years ago? Why and how did craftsmen of the Middle East meticulously carve pictures depicting complex legends into stones no bigger than postage stamps or lipsticks?

title: Inquiry Set on Editor Sentenced To Editorialize Against Guns
description: TRENTON, May 9  Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes said, today that he had ordered a judicial inquiry to determine whether a lowercourt ruling violated the First Amendment guarantee of freedom of the press in requiring a New York newspaper publisher to editorialize against handguns as a condition of parole on a weapons charge.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A General Accounting Office investigation of alleged improprieties by the Army Corps of Engineers in acquiring land for the Tocks Island Dam project has been called incomplete, inadequate and inadmissible by a conservation group.

title: Market Place
description: Two weeks ago, American Telephone and Telegraph Company stock was trading at 48 and a $1.6billion financing that hinges on A.T.&T.'s reaching 52 by May 15 seemed out of the question.

title: Grace Episcopal Church Chooses Its 11th Rector
description: The Rev. Dr. Christopher FitzSimons Allison, professor of church history at the Virginia Theological Seminary in Alexandria since 1967, has accepted a call to be the 11th rector of the historic Grace Episcopal Church at Broadway and 10th Street.

title: CAMBODIA URGING INDUSTRIAL DRIVE
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 9 The new Cambodian Government has announced a major program to rebuild shattered industry as well as agriculture.

title: MORE AID SOUGHT ON ZONNING LIMITS
description: PRINCETON, May 9About 20 state and national housing and landuse specialists agreed today that little could be done to overcome local housing restrictions against poor and moderate income families until more state and Federal construction aid became available.

title: Eight Hurt in Racial Clashes At High School in Boston
description: BOSTON, May 9 (AP)Eight students were injured in racial scuffles on their way to class at the Rogers annex of the Hyde Park High School today.

title: '74 Conventions Brought City $405.3Million
description: A total of $405.3million was spent in New York City last year as a direct result of conventions, according to a report issued yesterday by Preston Robert Tisch, chairman of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.

title: Clay Pots Have Become Harder to Find . . .
description: Remember those terra cotta clay pots that plants and flowers used to come in? Florists used to sell them for pennies and they were used for growing, not showing, potted plants.

title: Chief of C.I.A.'s Latin Operations Quits To Defend Agency Before the Public
