description: The Jefferson Starship wil appear in a free rock concert tomorrow noon on the Great Lawn in Central Park The concert, being presented by WNEWFM, the progressive rock radio station, and the parks department, is reachable from the West 81st Street and the East 84th Street park entrances.

title: June Bridal Set By Dectora Coe
description: Dectora Coe, a teacher at the Chapin School, and W. Christopher Jeffers, who is on the Xerox research staff in Palo Alto, Calif., plan to be married neat month in Columbus, Ohio.

title: A Jersey Builder Turns Back to the Basic House
description: Squeezed between high costs on the one hand and consumer resistance to high prices on the other, builders are turning to smaller houses with fewer frills in an effort to lure buyers back to their models.

title: Maria Terry Delavan Is Jersey Bride
description: Maria Terry Delay an and William H. DeJavan Jr. were married yesterday afternoon in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Harrington Park, N.J., by the key, Paul C. Deckenbach.

title: Village Development Plan Stirs Clash
description: A 26yearold novice realestate developer and a number of Greenwich Village residents are locked in a dispute over plot of land at Jane Street and Eighth Avenue, and the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission is to begin hearing the matter Tuesday.

title: Music: Thomas at Piano
description: Michael Tilson Thomas is appearing as guest pianist and conductor with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center this weekend in its final pair of 197475 subscription concerts at Alice Tully Hall. The first of the two was given on Friday night; the second is taking place this afterncon.

title: Cuban Exiles Protest
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) After the Organization of American states meeting this afternoon, a crowd of Cuban exile demonstrators estimated by the police at 1,100 gathered near the headquarters of the organization. Many carried signs calling on nations not to renew relations with Cuba and to retain the trade embargo.

title: Festival Comes to Morristown Green
description: MORRISTOWN  A communityinvolvement project with an accent on youth is providing Morristown with a weeklong outdoor arts festival on the Town Green.

title: Janet Volker Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Volker Jr. of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Florence Volker, to William J. Sweeney, of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Sweeney of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.

title: An Opera Mouse With a Roar
description: Thirteenyearold Paul Offenkrantz is just a mite, but his voice is a mighty one that projects to the last row of the Metropolitan Opera House. Last December in the company's new production of Boris Godunov young Paul rose from the ranks of the Met's children's chorus to sing Fyodor, son of the tormented czar, looking more diminutive than ever opposite the Boris of that Finnish colossus Martti Talvela. He was a great success with both his colleagues and the critics. Paul had it all, says Thomas Schippers who conducted the opera; the voice, the incredible diction, the musicianship.

title: Vatican Disavows the Selling of Fake Holy Bricks
description: ROME, May 10The Vatican has disavowed traffic in a Holy Year souvenir  bricks that supposedly were used to block the Holy Door of St. Peter's Basilica and that are on sale for $40 to $80.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The trilogy of 25th Amendment inaugural medals is now complete. An official medal commemorating the Dec. 19, 1974, inauguration of Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller has been authorized by the Special Inaugural Medal Committee under thechairmanship of Sen. Mark 0. Hatfield of Oregon. Senator Hatfield, a rented medal collector in his own right, also made the announcements of the first two 25th Amendment medals  for Gerald R. Ford when he came the first man appointed Vice  President under that Amendment and for Mr. Ford when he assumed the Presidency.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Ever since the late1950's and the goldenoldies days of Chuck Berry, Bo Diddley and Bill Haley, the electric guitar has been the instrument of rock and roll. Beginning in the mid1960's, when a number of English musicians decided to utilize their electrified instruments to play the blues, rock has produced an unending line of guitarplaying heros. The guitarsuperstar is, in fact, rock music's most durable feature. Each of the tarmwing nrsxs, some among the most successful recordings of the year, features a guitarist who has achieved, is attempting to achieve or attempting to vary his own distinctive style with an instrument that has proven to he flexible enough to produce highvoltage gashes of sound as well as intricate and intriguing harmonic variations.

title: Those Who Remained in Oklahoma Dust Bowl Are Thriving
description: HOOKER, Okla.  Forty years ago Glenn and Margaret Teel, with scores of their neighbors, were out in what was left of a wheat field, rounding up jack rabbits.

title: Family Subsidies Aid Workers in Europe
description: PARIS, May 10All the nonCommunist industrial countries provide subsidies for the family man, and in two countries, France and Spain, the subsidies, in compensation for taxes, lift the income or the average worker with two children to a level greater than his gross factory earnings.

title: U.F.T. TO CONTROL FUENTES DISTRICT
description: The United Federation of Teachers won control of the Lower East Side's School District 1 in last Tuesday's citywide school election, defeating the forces supporting Luis Fuentes, the suspended superintendent, unofficial returns indicated yesterday.

title: A Blurred Picture Of a Decade
description: The recent past is really getting it in the eye these nights, though with inconclusive results. Ed Bullins's The Taking of Miss Janie, which has been transplanted to the Mitzi E. Newhouse at Lincoln Center from its original base at the Henry Street Settlement House, devotes itself principally to blackwhite relations in the 1960's (This tale is about the spirit of those times), Symbolizedor at least given some sort of framing device by the ultimate rape of a naive white girl by the black poet she wants simply as a friend.

title: BUSING PLAN ENDS IN COAST SUBURB
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10 (AP) The school district of Inglewood, a Los Angeles suburb whose enrollment is now 80 per cent minority children, has been allowed to discard a fiveyearold desegregation busing plan.

title: Bullets and Bulls Feeling at Home
description: The Washington Bullets and the Chicago Bulls get their final chances to make use of the homecourt advantage today as they seek to advance to the National Basketball Association championship series.

title: Proposed: that the best government is the least government
description: Justice, Aristotle remarked, is peculiar virtue in that its possessor benefits his fellow members of society rather than himself. Over the centuries Western political thought developed a variety of notions testifying to its belief that sharing constitutes the fundamental element of political association. Thus citizenship stood for a common status which enabled the member to claim rights, immunities and advantages. Participation came to mean sharing in common deliberation about matters of general concern. The very word republic derives from the Latin which translates into public thing.

title: H. L. Schwartz 3d Weds Sara Cavanagh
description: Sara Burns Cavanagh, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James F. Cavanagh of Glen Head, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to H. Livingston Schwartz 3d, managing editor of The Daily Dispatch in Moline, Ill.

title: Movies Win the Heart or Wall Street
description: HOLLYWOODThe capriciousness of public taste, the demonstrated ability of producers with impeccable track records to suddenly come up with a turkey, these are the things that give the movie industry about the same kind of predictability and stability that goes with a roll of the dice.

title: U.S. Keeps Mortgages In Rural Areas Rolling
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.Mary and Mike Gabrell moved into a threebedroom ranch house in Mastic, on the South Shore of Suffolk County, in March. Until then, they had spent their three years of married life in furnished rooms, a trailer and an inlaw's spare room. Now they have a house of their own, and Uncle Sam holds the mortgage.

title: GANG SHOWS OFF HOUSING PROJECT
description: Leaders of the Renigades youth gang yesterday showed off a renovated sixstory tenement in East Harlem, which for more than two years was a battered, abandoned building at 251 East 119th Street, at the northwest corner of Second Avenue.

title: Peking Official Off to Paris
description: PEKING, May 10 (Reuters)Deputy Premier Teng Hsiaoping, China's most important official after Chairman Mao Tsetung and Premier Chou Enlai, leaves for a state visit to France this weekend to seek to improve political relations.

title: Winning, Losing and Chinese
description: A United States track and field team leaves tomorrow for two weeks in China, a onceinalifetime experience for each athlete lucky enough to be going. But the odds may be stacked against the Americans even before the first starting blocks are hammered into Place.

title: Hale Chestnut Tree Sought
description: NEW BRUNSWICK A hunt is under way in New Jersey to locate large specimens of the American chestnut tree and, hopefully, to inbreed them Into a variety, that will withstand blight.

title: LETTERS
Vandals Disrupt S.I. Train Service
description: Vandals placed a metal bar across the third rail and a track of the Staten Island Rapid Transit system causing delays in service between Great Kills and New Dorp. The incident occurred at 12:11 P.M. About 90 minutes later, the system began using single track service for the affected 2.4 miles of the 14mile railway. The rail suffered a burn of 10 inches.

title: All Boys Aren't Athletes, and Some Survive
description: Many of us males should be rooting for the acceptance of women in sports forjust as you suspectedour own personal chauvinistic selfish concerns, as well as the genuine desire to see females have the opportunity to participate in any sport they wish, from basketball to boxing.

title: HANCOCK BUILDING
description: BOSTON, May 10 (AP)After three years of shattering glass, the last window in New England's tallest building is scheduled to go into place next week.

title: TERKEL IS WINNER OF LIEBLING AWARD
description: Studs Terkel, author and reporter, last night was named as the winner of the annual A. J. Liebling Award, given by More, the monthly devoted to appraisal of newsgathering organizations.

title: Lavender Becomes Song for the Girls, Too
description: Since it was written in 1919, Lavender, My Lavender, has been the only song, other than The Star Spangled Banner, deemed worthy to he sung at City College commencement exercises. For more than 50 years the Sturdy sons of City College, with trusty hearts and mighty hands, would he admonished to show prowess while on fields of sports contending.

title: MARY S. BROWN, 79, LED JUNIOR LEAGUES
description: Mary Schieffelin Brown, a former president of the Associated Junior Leagues of America and the New York Junior League, died Friday in Katonah, N. Y., where she lived. Her age was 79.

title: Egypt Insists Palestinians Be Invited to Geneva Talks
description: CAIRO, May 10 (AP)Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy said today that Egypt believed it was essential that the Palestine Liberation Organization be invited to take part in Middle East peace talks at Geneva.

title: Rita Gardner Bride of Vincent Murray
description: Mary Rita Gardner and Vincent Paul Murray were married yesterday in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church. Msgr. Joseph P. Murphy, Chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: About the Yankees...
description: Lou Piniella will fly back to Now York today for medical checkup. The 31yearold outfielder has been suffering occasional dizziness for two weeks, cause, unknown. He was examined by an ear specialist in Oakland, who advised further tests. No headaches, Piniella reported, but my eyes were sort of dancing pretty good at times. ... Elliott Maddox almost made the sick list, too. He was struck on the right hand by Rollie Fingers's fastball Friday night and wore a wrapping on it overnight. XRays showed no broken bones Sparky Lyle, explaining why the second ball he threw Friday bounced past the plate for a wild pitch and the game: I was trying to throw low, but not below the plate. Frank Crosetti, a player and coach for the Yankees for 37 years, visited the team from his home in nearby Stockton. He denied he had been drawn from his retirement retreat by curiosity over the man called Catfish.

title: Pamela Poor Is Wedon L.I.
description: Pamela Mason Poor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barton Poor of Garden City and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday noon to John Michael Mallory, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Mallory of West Hempstead, L.I. The Rev. Peter Garry performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City.

title: GUNMAN GETS $4,000 AT OLYMPIC AIRWAYS
description: A welldressed man approached a ticket clerk at 1:30 P.M. yesterday in the Fifth Avenue office of Olympic Airways to inquire about a cruise in Greece, held up the employe for $4,000, then shot and wounded him and escaped into the heavy pedestrian traffic outside.

title: Refugees And Guilt
description: HONOLULUWhen President Ford, addressing the student body of Tulane University on April 25, called Vietnam a war that is finishedas far as America is concerned, the applause was thunderous. His advice to the. country to put Vietnam behind us, regain our pride, and look forward, was enthusiastically echoed by the news media. Not since the British people went wild with joy over Arthur Neville Chamberlain's return from Munich had a nation been so euphoric over the news of peace in our time.

title: Revisions Expected In Wiretap Rules
description: TRENTON  The Senate Judiciary Committee is expected to approve this week a number of major revisions in the state's wiretapping law, including tighter restrictions on the power of the police to eavesdrop on telephone conversations.

title: The Nation
description: There is a serious discrepancy between Governor George C. Wallace's politically successful, selfdescription as the defender of the little man and his performance in office, according to an account by B. Drummond Ayres Jr. in The New York Times last week. He reports that as Governor of Alabama during eight of the last 12 years, Mr. Wallace apparently has favored large corporations and the state's wealthier citizens at the expense of Alabama's poor.

title: Prison Revolt Ends in Italy
description: ROME, May 10Three convicts who last night staged a rebellion with leftist political overtones in a penitentiary at Viterbo, 50 miles northwest of Rome, gave themselves up today, freeing a prison guard they had been holding as a hostage.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: More than two years have gone by since the free world's major currencies were set loose from their moorings to float on what clearly were uncharted seas. While it apparent Mat none or the snips or state have run aground because of floating rates, neither Is it certain that such a development will not occur.

title: Lombardi Memorial Center Under Way
description: Groundbreaking ceremonies for the Vincent T. Lombardi Memorial Athletic Center, a sports enclave for the use of 14,000 students at Fordham University, were held yesterday at the Fordham campus in the Bronx.

title: The Gentlemanly Serpent
description: When Jonathan Daniels's A Southerner Discovers the South was published in 1938, a critic observed on the front page of the Book Review that through the sharply contrasting chapters one gets a feel of the contemporary region, some of its charm, its beauty,

title: Deadline for A.T.&T. Warrants
description: It's the biggest poker game in town now and, oddly enough, it involves the country's most staid investment, American Telephone and Telegraph, a Wall Streeter said last week.

title: Iran and Iraq Weigh a Persian Gulf Defense Pact
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 10Po??nts for inclusion in an eventual Persian Gulf collective security pact have been under study in recent days here and in Iraq, the main centers of power in the upper gulf region, wellplaced foreign sources reported this week.

title: Profits Plummet in Textile Industry
description: The latest reports from textile companies across the nation have been uniformall bad.

title: Profit: The Great Equalizer for Women
description: I wish I could announce that there no sexism in business. I cannot. But what I can say with assurance is that there less sexism in business than in any field I know, and what's left is dwindling fast.

title: Pilot Project Aids Gifted Children in City Schools
description: Thirty pupils In a class at one Manhattan public school, whose ages range from 4 to 6 years, not only know what a runcible spoon is but also have somehow managed to work the phrase into their everyday conversation.

title: Breach of Faith
description: Theodore H. White, friend of Presidents, was vouchsafed three interviews with Richard M. Nixon for the preparation of The Making of the President 1972. At the last of them, March 17, 1973, Nixon was feeling particularly serene. His feet that Saturday were up on the table in the Executive Office Building hideaway, White writes today. He was at ease, his mind roving, sorting out problems and priorities of national affairs; and mostly he talked the shop talk of power.... The President, he felt, must single out a few problems of the thousands and thousands of immensely complicated affairs that clamor for his attention, and must concentrate on those. He must wall himself off from detail.

title: 2 Suffolk Democrats Seek to Face Klein
description: HOLBROOKDr. Martin J. Feldman's onagain, offagain candidacy for Suffolk County Executive was on again last week, but there were growing indications that the Democratic Legislator from Deer Park would be involved in a convention floor fight for the nomination because of the apparent reluctance of the party's leadership to support him.

title: Only Growing Pains Matter To a Gifted Black Tennis Pro
description: At some point in their careers, Arthur Ashe and Althea Gibson probably said what Margot Tiff, the Cleveland Nets' 22yearold rookie, was saying earlier last week as she prepared for her team's season opener against the New York Sets: I want to be thought of as a tennis player first, not as a black person who happens to play tennis. My aim is to be a good tennis player, not a good black tennis player.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE WHOLESALE PRICE INDEX rose to 172.1 in April [1967100], an increase of 1.5 per cent over the March level. Agricultural price increases presage a rise in retail food prices, but advances in industrial prices were small ... First National City Bank reported that corporate profits 1,289 companies totaled $9.69billion in the first quarter, down 21 per cent from the fourth quarter of 1974 and down 15 per cent from the first quarter of 1974.

title: Ideas&Trends
description: Universal History, the history of what man has accomplished in this world, is at bottom the history of Great Men who have worked here, wrote Thomas Carlyle, the Scottish essayist.

title: D. M. Turner to Marry Sigrid McAfee
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Edward McAfee Jr. of the Bronx iave announced the engagement of their daughter, Sigrid Renee McAfee, a candidate for a Ph.D. degree in physics at the Polytechnic Institute of New York, to Dwight Morgan Turner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Caleb W. Turner of Chester, Pa.

title: Beirut Sentences Americans
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 10 (UPI)Residents of Long Island, N. Y., and Washington, D. C., were sentenced today to three years in prison for attempting to smuggle mor than 20 pounds of hashish out of Lebanon, judicial sources said. The sources identified the Americans as Raymond Mandrola, 28 years old, of Dix Hills, L. I., and Ronny Alvin Rowan of Washington. The two were ar?? Aug. 6 at Beirut Airport.

title: Food: West Side hunting ground
description: Whether it's Indian rice, smoked sturgeon, pecan pie, homemade candies or organically grown vegetables, the upper West Side has it. The area is such a rich food hunting ground that many East Siders and suburbanites make shopping expeditions there, much as they do to Chinatown or Little Italy.

title: Joanna Simon, Diva, Diverts
description: It might seem odd that Joanna Simon, who made her debut with the New York. City Opera 13 years ago, would bill her program Friday night in the Divas and Diversions series at the Hunter College Playhouse as her first New York recital. But that's what she did, and it was a most pleasing occasion.

title: Johncke 4and3 Victor In Richardson Golf Final
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., May 10Clas Johncke, who rarely got to play golf in his native Sweden as early as midMay because snow usually covered the fairways and greens, became today the first foreigner to win the William D. Richardson Memorial tournament.

title: Teachers College Leases Hotel
description: Columbia University's Teachers College has taken shortterm lease on the East End Hotel, at 78th Street and the Franklin Roosevelt Drive, as a temporary student's residence. The college will use it to house about 400 students while it renovates its Whittier Hall dormitory on Amsterdam Avenue, between 120th and 121st Streets.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Mets and Yankees will play at Shea Stadium this week, with the Mets playing host to the San Francisco Giants in three night games starting tomorrow and the Yankees meeting the Oakland A's Friday and Saturday nights and Sunday afternoon at 2 o'clock. Sandwiched between these threegame series will be the annual Mayor's Trophy Game Thursday night. All of the night games will start at 8.

title: Iran Soccer Victor
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 10 (UPI)Iran topped South Korea, 10, and Japan defeated Burma, 41, on penalty kicks in overtime today in the opening games of the fifth President Cup soccer tournament. The result placed Iran and Burma in Group A and Japan and South Korea in Group B for a main series starting Tuesday. The scores did not affect their team standing.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: The Minamata photographs of W. Eugene Smith and his wife Aileen, on view at the International Center of Photography, first received widespread attention in 1972 as a picture essay in Life magazine. The essay did not make Life's cover, which featured a fourcolor picture of Raquel we??ch in a clinging athletic jersey; but Life gave it eight pages inside and rushed copies off to Stockholm in time for the opening of the United Nations Environmental Conference, where it created a sensation.

title: Preparing Returns: Pinch on the LowIncome Side
description: We were hurt in lowincome areas, said the man whose company prepares 10.5 per cent of all United States income tax returns. Business started off like a house afireand got worse and worse and worse.

title: U.N. PASSPORT ASKED FOR WAR REPORTERS
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 10 (UPI)Editors from 40 nations have adopted a resolution asking the United Nations to issue special passports for journalists on assignment in danger zones.

title: Richard T. Radsch, a Lawyer, Fiance of Jennifer C. Johnston
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Murray Johnston of New Vernon, N.J., and Southwest Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Clark Johnston, to Richard Thackeray Radsch, son of Mrs. P. Livingstone Armstrong of Fechy, Switzerland, and the late Robert H. Radsch of Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: Native Intelligence
description: In his first novel, Native Intelligence, Raymond Sokolov draws on diaries, letters, secret memos and telegrams to reconstruct the academic and Peace Corps career of Alan Casper, a linguistics genius who graduates from Harvard

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Bibb Company and the DowBadische Company have sired 10year leases for full floors of office space at 111 West 40th Street. The two floors total 46,000 square feet.

title: Ellen Phelps Is Bride of Chaplain
description: Ellen Sheffield Phelps and the Rev. Donald Joseph Schell, associate Episcopal chaplain at Yale, were married yesterday afternoon in the Dwight Memorial Chapel at Yale University by the 2Rev. David Bolton, rector of Christ Episcopal Church in New Haven.

title: Women some women made
description: Patricia Beer has written so perceptive and useful a book, has written it, moreover, in a style at the same time so graceful and lapidary, that one need not resist the necessity of rapping her sharply across the knuckles about her preface before going on to praise and elucidate her stunning text.

title: Senator A Scholar Of Budgets For Schools
description: ALBANY  A delegation from the East Islip school board, looking unhappy, filed into State Senator Leon E. Giuffreda's office the other day. They left and another school board group entered. Those waiting in the reception area riffled through newspaper pages showing the results of local elections.

title: Wendy Ellen Horstman Is Fiancee of Cadet William S. Vogel
description: Mrs. Joanne W. Robinson of Southport, Conn., and Stanley B. Horstman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Ellen Horstman, to Cadet William S. Vogel, a first classman at the United States Military Academy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Vogel of Roswell, N.M.

title: A Corner of Brittany In Canadian Waters
description: IN The Lily of St. Pierre by Damon Runyon a flashy Broadway type named Jack O'Hearts sits in a Times Square chophouse and fondly recalls his visits to the French island territory of St. Pierre and Miquelon: It is the quietest place I am ever in in my life, and the only place I ever know any real peace.

title: An 8x15 Miniplan to Grow The Family's Vegetables All Summer Long
description: As glorious as it would be to have acres and acres to grow vegetables, many of us have to make do with what sunny space we have. There are rewards to be gleaned from the miniplot: the satisfaction of carrying out a careful plan; a smaller expenditure of money for plants, seeds, fertilizer; no wasteful overproduction of a bountiful crop like zucchini; and last, but hardly least, less work.

title: The Chicanos of Texas May Get Help
description: AUSTIN, Tex.Texans generally are proud of the size, the wealth and the political Importance their state, three fairly accurate reflections of Texas' importance nationally. They are somewhat more reticent about discussing the plight of their Spanishspeaking population, which consists largely of 2million Mexican Americans, or about that population's long history of discrimination and disenfranchisement by the state. Mexican Americans constitute 20 per cent of Texas' population and most of them are clustered in South Texas and in the state's urban centers.

title: Miss Hamilton Is Betrothed
description: Mildred Ewen Hamilton, whose father, Charles F. Hamilton, is a former headmaster of the Belmont Hill School, will be married to George, 12, K. Stuempfig of Philadelphia, a sculptor and etcher.

title: U.S. to Orbit 2 Satellites For Its Defense Network
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 10 (AP)Two twin satellites designed to provide secret worldwide communications for United States defense forces are scheduled to he launched into space next Tuesday, officials announced yesterday.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: TodayWindham County K.C. allbreed and obedience, Recreation Park, junction of Routes and 14, Willimantic, Conn.; 1,465 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: It's action, but is it affirmative?
description: BERKELEY, The University of California's Berkeley campushome of the Free Speech Movement, alma mater of Patty Hearsthas just earned another dubious distinction. On Feb. 18, it signed with the Department of Health, Education and Welfare an affirmativeaction plan that Peter E. Holmes, director of H.E.W.'s Office for Civil Rights, hailed as the most farreaching plan his office has yet achieved with a university. Under the plan, Berkeley has agreed, on pain of losing some $13million in Federal contracts, to eliminate discriminatory hiring practices during the next 30 years by filling at least 100 faculty positions with women and members of minorities.

title: STAMPS
description: Hearkening back to a bygone, simpler day, Canada is putting out this Thursday two commemoratives for the authors of two vintage classics from the early years of the century.

title: Miss Lettis Captures 6Mile Run
description: If you're trying to kick the cigarette habit, without success, try the tactics of Charlotte Lettis, who took up running and wound up as the champion of the fourth annual women's MiniMarathon yesterday in Central Park.

title: Singh, 110, Wins Prep At Pimlico
description: Singh, 110, Wins Prep At Pimlico

title: Senghor to Visit U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May ?? (AP President Lopold S. Senghor of Senegal will meet President Ford at the White House on May 22, it was announced today. He will make a tour of United States cities following a state visit to Mexico.

title: U.S. Rent Subsidies May Add 7,800 Dwellings to State Rolls
description: NEWARK  Firstyear funding under a new Federal housing program may result in the construction or substantial rehabilitation of 7,800 apartments and homes for New Jersey families of low and moderate incomes, Government officials estimate.

title: Yankees Set Aug. 2 As OldTimers' Day
description: The decade of the nineteenfifties will be saluted on Saturday afternoon, Aug. 2, as a preliminary to a meeting between the Yankees and the Cleveland Indians at Shea Stadium. On the agenda is an OldTimers' Day pegged around the decade in which the Yankees won eight pennants.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, MAY 11, 1975

title: The Saga of the
description: Judging from my experience, the way to promote flowers on last year's poinsettia is treat 'em rough. My plant has been shot at, knocked about and generally abused for the past year, and now (in spring?) what remains of a threestemmed, plant has five gorgeous blossoms.

title: Donna D. Carnegie Wed to R. T. Maina
description: Donna Dale Carnegie. whose father, the late Dale Carnegie, wrote How to Win Friends and Influence People, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Theodore Maina of Minnea polis.

title: BRIDGE
description: The game devised by Harold Vanderbilt, which we call contact bridge, celebrates its 50th birthday later this year and has virtually supplanted all its ancestors: whist, bridge and auction bridge. Exactly where and when the simple, traditional AngloSaxon game of whist became bridge, with a dummy, a bid by the dealer or his partner naming the trump suit, and doubles and redoubles ad infinitum is obscure, but it was probably in the Near East about a century ago.

title: The Official Directory Of the City of New York
description: Just about as we were getting to thinking that we'd have to wait for our book as long as Joe Heller fans had to wait for theirs, up popped the new 197475 Official Directory of the City of New York, aka

title: Former Aide Says Thieu, Profiting by Control of Corrupt Regime, Left Vietnam a Billionaire
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 10Charges that eight years of corrupt control of South Vietnam made former President Nguyen Van Thieu one of the richest men in the world have provoked shay controversy among Saigon of ficials arriving in this country and have prompted a denial the charges by another former aide of Mr. Thieu.

title: In Monaco Grand Prix Circles, Donohue, Andretti Are Tangents
description: MONTE CARLO, May 10The kings of the road in the United States are not considered royalty in Europe.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: After Foreman, a Deluge
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: When Married Writers Work Together, What Happens to Marriage?
description: Having a good marriage isn't exactly easy. Neither is writing a book or a play or a movie. When a husband and wife attempt to combine the two, what happens?

title: Ideas &Trends
description: New observatories, one classically placed on a mountain top, the other in orbit above the Equator, may help those scientists who are searching for black holes in space.

title: Matching Funds for Tax Rebates
description: George C. Byrnes, president of New York's Flushing Savings Bank, is doing his part to stimulate the nation's economyand at the same time becoming the bestliked man at the bank. Mr. Byrnes has instituted a $250 bonus for most of his employes.

title: Headliners
description: Rep. Wilbur Mills was hack at work last week after almost five months of hospitalization for alcoholism. Mr. Mills looked tanned and healthy, and spoke candidly of his difficulties. I feel too good to give this up for a drink, he said. He refused to com ment on incidents, just before his hospitalization, Involving striptease dancer Anabella Battistella. He was more anxious to discuss his return to House Ways and Means Committee work, I'm taking it one day at a time, he said.

title: Oldfield Puts Shot 75 Feet, World Best
description: EL PASO, Tex., May 10Brian Oldfield of Cupertino, Calif., put the 16pound shot 75, feet today. It is the farthest the weight had ever been propelled.

title: KINKS'S RAY DAVIS EXPLORES THEMES
description: Rock is over 20 years old now, and more and more thoughtful rock composers are turning inward to the themes of what the music means, what rock careers are all about and what they themselves can hope to say in a musical culture ultimately geared to an adolescent audience.

title: Democrats Predict State Fiscal Crisis; Democrats Predicting Fiscal Crisis for State
description: TRENTONThe continuing failure of the Legislature to agree on a new tax program is threatening the Byrne administration with an imminent fiscal crisis, Demo cratic leaders in both the State Senate and Assembly warned last week.

title: Coast Guard Crew Victor In Dad Vail
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 10With crews from as far away as Ontario and Minnesota entered, the Dad Vail Regattathe culmination of the racing season for the socalled smallcollege crewstook place on the Schuylkill River today under ideal rowing conditions.

title: From the Police Blotter:
description: The police reported four homicides in the Bronx, two by shooting and two by stabbing. Pierce Johnson, 34 years old, of 940 Grand Concourse, had just left a subway station and was walking on 163d Street and the Grand Concourse with a relative. They were accosted by two men, one of whom shot Mr. Johnson for no apparent reason. The attackers escaped. James Scott, 27, of 2267 Seventh Avenue, was shot fatally in the head during a fight with an unidentified man at a social club at 841 Trinity Avenue. Carlos Burgos, 35, of 690 Bryant Avenue, was stabbed fatally in the abdomen in front of 890 Bryant Avenue during a dispute with Sixto Carrillo, 46, of 650 Bryant Avenue, who was arrested. Richard Turner, 40, was stabbed fatally in the chest by an unknown assailant in his apartment at 1366 Lyman Place.... Henry Callier, 54, was found strangled to death in his home at 407 Barbados Drive, in the Arverne section of the Rockaways, Queens. The police said they believed robbery was the motive.

title: Islander Pride on Ice Again
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., May 10 The New York Islanders play the Philadelphia Flyers tomorrow for pride, honor and the respect of New York. In the distance, looms the eventual goal of the Stanley Cup.

title: BorgAshe Final Today;; Will It Be Anticlimax?; Meiler Upsets Nastase
description: DALLAS, May 10Bjorn Borg, who defeated Rod Laver last night in a fourhour match that will become tennis legend, faces Arthur Ashe tomorrow for the World Championship Tennis title and a $50,000 first prize. The match, ending a worldwide fourmonth competition, will he televised nationally (1 P.M. New York time, Channel 4) and to Sweden,. Borg's native land.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Every Wednesday morning, two groups of Christian laymen meet for breakfast, Bible reading and prayer at the Holiday Inn in High Point, N.C. The meetings are typical of the increasing religious activity among businessmen. Leaders attribute the trend to the work of the Holy Spirit but say Watergate and the recession may have added impetus to the search for religious values.

title: Leisure Activities Thrive Across Nation in Recession
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The country may be in the depths of the worst recession since World War II, but, despite the lean times, a lot of Americans are still having fun.

title: Design: West Side coop
description: Letty and Michael Tanchum bought their West Side coop apartment in a late nineteentwenties building a year and a half ago for onefifth its asking price of $100,000. The previous owner of the cavernous, 2,600squarefoot duplex, a sculptor in Rome, accepted their bid after the apartment had been on the market two years.

title: Redistricting Plan in Nassau Is Approved by State Court
description: MINEOLA  After seven years of court action, public hearings and discussion, plan for the reapportionment of Nassau County into 15 districts of relatively equal population to form a county legislature was approved by the State Supreme Court here last week. The court also rejected an attempt by minoritygroup representatives to block the plan on the ground that it would split an area with a large minority population among several districts.

title: Tips From the Schools
description: The vertical lines on the face of an iron should be used in lining up a shot. Bracket the lines on an intermediate target six or eight feet away, such as a divot, patch of grass, brown spot, etc.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Continued from Page 14 way, and the decision was shared by the leaders of all the major parties, in and out of government.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Though holography practically a stepchild of photographyis still considered to be in its infancy, it has already shown very definite indications that its growth may well reach gargantuan proportions in the nottoodistant future. Until recently, holography had unfortunately been confined to scientific laboratories because of the need for expensive, specialized equipment, but startling new breakthroughs in the making and viewing of holograms have finally made it possible to bring these mystifying threedimensional creations out into public view. In fact, not only are there several places around New York City currently displaying holograms, but there is even a school where interested individuals can actually learn how to make their own holograms.

title: Suffolk Civil Service Employes Switch to A.F.L.C.I.O. Croup
description: COMMACK, L. I., May 10The executive board of the Civil Service Employes Association's largest unit in Suffolk County has resigned to join the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes, a rival Union it sees as being more aggressive in its bargaining practices.

title: ... Or Lightweight Featherock
description: Miniature alpine gardens are easily fashioned out of Featherock. This unusual volcanic material can be carved, sawed, or tooled easily. A neutral medium, plants grow well in it and tend to retain a dwarf habit. Featherock was formed when volcanoes were active in this country. Some of the molten lava was infused with bubbles of gas. As it cooled and solidified, the gas escaped leaving a lava foam rock. This porous silica weighs about one fifth that of common stone.

title: Stony Brook to Get Two New Buildings
description: STONY BROOKApproval for construction of two buildings for the state university center here has been granted. The skate Division of the Budget approved the $8million performing arts phase of the Fine Arts Building on Friday, and Governor Carey, in reversing the recommendation of the budget division, approved the $11million Social and Behavioral Sciences Building earlier in the week.

title: The World
description: At least 500, and perhaps as many as 1,000 people have been killed in the last 10 days in fighting between rival liberation groups in the Angolan capital of Luanda. Angola's great wealth in natural resources and the competition among external forces to retain influence there is one of the main reasons that her transition to independence has been more violent than in Portugal's other poorer, former African territories, Mozambique and GuineauBissau.

title: Cookbook Offers Favorites of Old Long Island
description: HUNTINGTONEarly last summer the Huntington League of Women Voters decided to act on the suggestion made by one of its members to publish a cookbook to raise funds. At a meeting in September, Chris Baird, a relative newcomer to the organization, mentioned, almost as an afterthought. that she had a collection of old recipes. These were rejected on the ground that the recipes were of Midwestern and New England origin, having nothing to do with Huntington.

title: Elizabeth Cant To Wedin June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry Russell Cant of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Fishers Island, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Cant, to Jansen Noyes 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Noyes Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Fishers Island. The wedding is planned for late next month.

title: Elizabeth Campbell Engaged to Gerald Johnson 2d
description: Mrs. Walbridge S. Taft of New York and Watch Hill, R. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Taft Campbell, to Gerald Justin Johnson 2d, son of Mrs. Walter D. Johnson of Albuquerque, N. M., formerly of Pomfret, Conn., and the late Mr. Johnson.

title: The Man Who Gave an X Rating to Violence
description: The theater marquee on Manhattan's Upper East Side announced the news in big bold letters: First Xrated fight scenes in screen history. For moviegoers accustomed to thinking of X as synonymous with sex, the sign was worth a doubletake. But it meant just what it said; the movie, called The Street Fighter, was the first ever to get an X rating for extreme violence rather than for nudity or explicit sex scenes.

title: Notes: Suggestions For Recession Trips
description: MANY forecasters are predicting a slow upturn in the United States economy beginning in the second half of the year. Others see the recession continuing. Whatever the case, money is still prime consideration in planning a trip. Herewith some ideas for tough economic times:

title: Subway Ridership Dropsin Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn, once the borough of trolley dodgers when streetcars jammed its streets, has a new breed of dodger, the resident who passes up the subway and is no longer a rider.

title: Calculating for Oil Money
description: Japanese businessmen, having found a market in the Middle East for 200,000 standard desk top calculators last year, have apparently decided that so much new wealth deserves special servicesymbols and numerals in Arabic.

title: Dance: Miss Evanitsky
description: The Multigravitational Aerodance Group, formerly the Multigravitational Experiment Group, continues on its imaginative and original path.

title: 2 Killed, 14 Hurt in Bus Crash on Queensboro Bridge
description: Two women were killed and at least 14 other persons were injured, two seriously, when bus crashed into a steel pillar on the Queensboro Bridge yesterday.

title: Crime in Town of 78
description: MOUNT WASHINGTON, Mass., May 10  Residents of this town, which has the smallest population any in Massachusetts, 78, have decided that something has to be done to hold down the increasing crime rate here.

title: Brazil Opens Vaccination Drive to Curb Growing Epidemic of Meningitis, Which Killed 4,000 in 1974
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 10 (Reuters)Brazil has opened one of the most extensive vaccination campaigns in history amid warnings that a meningitis epidemic now sweeping the country could reach catastrophic proportions.

title: Church to Fete Thousands
description: ORANGE  Guess who's coming to dinner next weekend at St. Constantine and St. Helen, a Greek Orthodox church at 510 Linden Place? About 5,000 peoplegive or take a fewthat's all.

title: Dominican Chiefs Quit in Rift
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 10, (Reuters) President Joaquin Balaguer of the Dominican Republic took direct control of the armed forces today after the country's top military leaders resigned.

title: Housing for the Poor: Crisis Is Too Mild a Word
description: Most housing officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will tell you the regional housing situation for poor and lowermiddleclass families has reached a crisis stage. A conservative assessment is that better than 10 per cent of the total number of households in the three states are living in substandard or badly deteriorating housing.

title: Women Face Battle At Power Squadron
description: The New York Squadron has voted, 95 to 9, to recommend the United States Power Squadrons admit women, either on a national or local option basis. The vote, the first on this issue by a local squadron, lends moral support to three New York women suing for admittance to the allmale organization. But the odds are slim it will alter national policy.

title: GANG SHOWS OFF
description: Leaders of the Renigades youth gang yesterday showed of a renovated sixstory tenement in EastHarlem, which for more than two years was battered, abandoned building at 251 East 119th Street, at the northwest corner of Second Avenue.

title: Yankee Hurler in a Dramatic Return Home
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 10 Catfish Hunter, the prodigal son, returned home with his $3.75million contract today and dazzled the folks by pitching the New York Yankees to a twohit, 3.0 victory over the threetime, worldchampion Oakland A's.

title: PAY ACCORD ENDS JAPAN RAIL STRIKE
description: TOKYO, May 10Employes of Japan National Railways and other public corporations agreed to a 14.1 per cent wage increase today to settle the most critical dispute in the annual spring offensive of the Japanese labor movement.

title: PRAVDA ATTACKS FINLAND'S PRESS
description: MOSCOW, May 10For the second time in two months, the party newspaper Pravda has lashed back at reports in the Finnish press alleging Soviet involvement in the activities of the Finnish Communist party.

title: The Freezin' Season
description: Spring is the time for baseball, flowers, lovers and ... Italian ices, the dixiecups full of the sweet, sticky, colorful concoction of sugar, water and artificial flavoring that New Yorkers slurp by the millions.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Elleston Trevor's NIGHT STOP (Doubleday, $6.95) is written with a curious sympathy for the underdog. The book concerns a wretcnea little man, a hustler who sells cheap jewelry. He sees a car go out of control an a Las Vegas high way, investigates and finds two people. One turns out to be an injured judge with a bright political future. The other is the body of his girlfriend.

title: Jersey Facilities Set Port Agency Pace
description: NEWARKThe amount of general  cargo tonnage handled by New Jersey marine terminals of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in 1974 was more than five times greater than that processed by the agen cy's New York facilities, according to the latest official figures.

title: Shealy Gives Harvard Crew Upper Hand in Sprints Today
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 10 In its 300 years and three decades of history, the Harvard Yard has felt the feet of the famous almost without interruption. During this springtime one Could say that in his fashion Alan Shealy, a 21yearold senior from Woodbury, Conn., ranks tight up there with Ralph Waldo Emerson, Franklin Delano Roosevelt or Jack Lemmon.

title: Saudi Arabia Stalls M.I.T. Aid Contract in a Rift on Visas for Jews
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, May 10Negotiations toward a technical assistance contract between the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Saudi Arabia have broken down in ?? disagreement over a guarantee for the entry of Jews to work on the project.

title: Article 4  No Title
On the Card for French Turfistes: Horse d'Oeuvres Varis
description: FEW guide books or travel agents attempt to enlighten American tourists about French racing. Even the most famous tracks get only passing mention in the Michelin Guides. Rut anyone with the slightest interest in the sport is likely to be delighted with an afternoon at one of the major tracks in the Paris area.

title: 22 Budgets For Schools Voted Down In 55 Areas
description: MINEOLA  Long Island voters rejected 22 of the, 55 school budgets presented to them last week.

title: Crime Up in Big Business Too, S.E.C. Discovers
description: Not since the 1930'swhen former New York Stock Exchange President Richard Whitney went jail for stock fraudhave so many of the country's leading corporations and businessmen borne the taint of illegality.

title: Abramowitz Opponents To Seek Reelection
description: Both Nina Taft, the president, and Lawrence Rose, the previous president, announced this week they would seek reelection for threeyear terms on June 4.

title: Yankee was a Chinese saying English
description: Here we have a revisionist philologistwhich is a mouthful, even for linguiststaking issue with most other recent historians of the English language on the question of how American English evolved from the mother tongue.

title: Saigon Declares a 3Day Holiday for Victory Celebration and Curbs Foreign Flights Over Country
description: The new Government of South Vietnam yesterday declared a threeday holiday starting next Thursday for victory celebrations, the Saigon radio reported.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: So when (to pick up the end of last week's column) was the very first concert in history sent out over a broadcast system? 1924? 1917? Wrong. The answer is April 2, 1877. In the archives of Broadcast Music Inc. reposes the actual Steinway Hall program. James Roy, the BMI archivist, was so intrigued that he did a little further work and actually dug out newspaper reports of the day on the phenomenon in general and the actual concert in particular.

title: Danish Dancers Defect Too
description: When people think of ballet defectors, the names of the highly acclaimed Russians leap to mindNureyev, Makarova, Baryshnikov. But the Danes have their defectors, too. Like their Russian counterparts who left the protective environment of the Kirov Ballet for artistic reasons, Peter Martins and Peter Schaufuss, two of Denmark's most promising dancers in recent years, gave up careers with the Royal Danish Ballet to work with George Balanchine at the New York City Ballet. Martins joined the company six years ago, and Schaufuss arrived six months ago.

title: Volunteers Needed By Bergen Hospital
description: PARAMUSBergen Pines County Hospital needs volunteers to assist in patient feeding, to transport wheelchair patients to diversional activities in the hospital's Occupational Therapy Room and to serve as reporters for Whispering Pines, the monthly magazine for patients.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: A New City Hall Complex Dedicated by Hackensack
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., May 10Mayor Michael J. D'Arminio officiated at ceremonies today as Hackensack dedicated its $3.1million City Hall Complex. The facility on State Street allowed for a consolidation of offices and services that were formerly housed at three different sites.

title: Energy Plan Ires Shore Area
description: TOMS RIVERThe Office of Technology Assessment, the research branch of Congress, has predicted in a report that South Jersey, particularly Ocean County, will be the site of several vast energy projects, including offshore oil drilling and the construction of a deepwater port.

title: Letters: Bicentennial Efforts Applauded
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shift to Preventive Aid Urged In State's ChildWelfare Policy
description: The Temporary State Commission on Child Welfare has recommended that the state redirect its efforts toward an intensive program of preventive services for potentially delinquent children and their familiesservices that would be provided as soon as it is known that the need is there.

title: DemocraticStudy Center Cutting Back
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 10The Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions will dismiss most of its fulltime employes and set up a smaller operation in Chicago, the board of directors decided today.

title: Symposium to Air Urban Development
description: NEW BRUNSWICKThe question of how New Jersey can improve the quality of new and existing urban development will be explored at a daylong symposium to be held at Livingston College on Friday.

title: Miss Skakel Fiancee Of Dr. Curtis Williams
description: The engagement of Kathleen Larkin Skakel to Dr. Curtis Michael Williams has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Corroon of Wilmington, Del., uncle and aunt of the future bride. Her fianc is a son of Mrs. Joseph P. Williams of Caldwell, N.J., and the late Joe Williams, sports columnist for The New York WorldTelegram and The Sun and its predecessors.

title: Fashion: West Side boutiques
description: Fashion may just as easily be found on upper Broadway as Madison Avenue. True, the West Side has no boutiques with the names of famous French designers on the windows. And it has no shops that sell status for $500 a handbag. But it does have its own trendy boutiques, some with resident designers and their own seamstresses (but with prices that don't take the breath away). And it does have stores that sell much the same American and European sportswear that's on the East Side. As long as a shopper doesn't insist on a Sonia Rykiel or Yves Saint Laurent label, she need never cross the great divide of Central Park.

title: Putting the hit on mob leaders
description: In American popular culture police melodramas have replaced Westerns as the newest last refuge of frontier individualism. While almost every recent horse opera from The

title: BITTERSWEET
description: Mother's Day, bittersweet. My mother's mother lived with us, with my parents and my brother and me, from the time she was widowed until her death a quartercentury later.

title: Cooling a Superheated Attic
description: Heat that builds up in the attic of most houses during a hot summer day can cause air temperatures inside the enclosed attic space to climb to as high as 140 degrees or more, and this superheated air will add considerably to the cost of cooling the downstairs rooms in the houseregardless of whether the house is centrally air conditioned or merely has one or two room units in the bedrooms. In addition, the high heat can pose a fire hazard and can lead to early deterioration of structural members.

title: Now Is the Time to Talk
description: PARISTime and space are respectively the keys to peace or another war in the Middle East. The United Nation's force intervening between the Egyptians and the Israelis in Sinai has had its mandate, extended only to the end of July. It is obvious the similar torce policing the Golan area between Syria and Israel will be linked to the same terminal date.

title: Teen Arts Week a Big Hit
description: TRENTONAt a rate of 3,000 to 4,000 a day, New Jersey youngsters are converging on the Teen Arts Festival, an annual event held in front of the State Museum.

title: Gulf Denies Giving Bribes to Bolivians
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 10The Gulf Oil Corporation, through its representative here, has informed the Bolivian Government that it has not paid a $4million bribe to protect its investments in Bolivia.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Two weeks ago Robert H. Anderson closed a successful 36year career with Sears, Roebuck & Co., the country's largest retailer, to become president of the W. T. Grant Company, a company fighting for survival that lost $173.3million in its latest fiscal year.

title: A Certain Dignity For the Figure
description: Isabel Bishop was born in Cincinnati, Ohio, in 1902, came to New York to study painting in 1918, and won early prominence in the 1930's along with Reginald Marsh and Kenneth Hayes Miller as a practitioner of a form of regionalism that celebrated New York City while Grant Wood and Thomas Hart Benton were celebrating the Middle West. Since then she has painted unceasingly and exhibited regularly. Her work has been reproduced in books, magazines and newspapers without recess even during the years when other prominent figurative painters of her generation vanished beneath the tide of American abstraction. Critics who have found their greatest pleasure in mutilating the corpse of the American tradition Isabel Bishop stands for, have given her their respect not because longevity has placed her in the position of grande dame of American painting but because the seriousness of her art could not be dismissed even when figurative painting seemed most demod.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONThe economic slump has had an adverse effect on Governor Byrne and his top administration officials. In financialdisclosure statements filed with the Secretary of State, all but four Cabinet members reported heavy losses.

title: Grande Defeats 8 in Jumpoff
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., May 10  Mike Matz piloted Grande into a tie for the lead in the race for the open jumper championship today by winning the Professional Horsemen's Association class today at the Children's Services horse show.

title: Town, Swamped With Applicants, Picks Architect
description: When the township of Cortlandt in northern Westchester advertised last fall for an architect to design a town hall, officials had no idea that more than 140 architectural firms across the nation would respond.

title: DR. NORMA ARONSON, CITY HEALTH AIDE
description: Dr. Norma Aronson, director of the Comprehensive Health Planning Agency for New York City, died Thursday at ColumbiaPresbyterian Hospital. She was in her fifties and lived at 1370 St. Nicholas Avenue.

title: Weddings
description: ElwellStuckey

title: Something good for a change
description: Here at last is a book that says something good about government for a change. John Fischer, the former editor of Harper's describes what's being done in some cities and states to make government work more effectively for people. At

title: BESSIE S. DRUCKER
description: Bessie Sussman Drucker, proprietor of the Melbourne Hotel in Ellenville, N. Y., died yesterday in Ellenville at the age of 84. She was the widow of Hyman Drucker, with whom she founded the Melbourne in 1933.

title: The Female Imagination
description: As a 17thcentury bishop pointed out when he threw a stone at a dog and hit his mother  in  law by mistake, though the intention was imperfectly fulfilled the effort was not wasted. Patricia Meyer Spacks does not seem to me to hit the target indicated by her title The Female Imagination. One infers from it that her book will examine the creative work of women, and define what it is that makes their poems, their novels, their paintings recognizably female quite apart from any clues offered by the subject matter. Such recognition we know can take place. Dickens spotted instantly that George Eliot's Scenes of Clerical Life was the work not of the pottering old clergyman suggested by George Henry Lewes but of a woman. He supported his opinion with a few reasons, but clearly what heand only he for some considerable time  had spotted was the female imagination. Today certain readers can say unerringly whether a poem is by a man or a woman when there is absolutely nothing in the theme to give the game away.

title: Airlift of Refugees From Guam Halted
description: AGANA, Guam, Sunday, May 11The military authorities here have been ordered to halt until further notice all transportation of South Vietnamese refugees to the continental United States.

title: Miss Wiener Bride Of Barry A. Bryer
description: The marriage of Meryl Elaine Wiener, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Wiener of Brooklyn, to Barry Alan Bryer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bryer of Bellerose, Queens, took place here yesterday afternoon.

title: Laotians Told by Premier Of Major Changes Soon
description: I VIENTIANE, Laos, May 11The Laotian capital, braced for disturbances after a week of political and military upheavals, passed a quiet but tense Constitution Day today.

title: LEGISLATURE HOLDS DRUGCOST INQUIRY
description: Soaring costs of drugs and medical supplies are under investigation by the State Legislature, government officials said yesterday.

title: Kindness Day Stabbing To Cost Butz Aide an Eye
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) Doctors have told an Agricultural Department aide that he will lose the eve injured when he was stabbed while walking through crowds at Human Kidness Day near the Washington Monument.

title: SIMON'S REJECTION OF CITY'S AID PLAN SCORED BY BEAME
description: Mayor Beame yesterday termed as specious and legal double talk the arguments given by Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon for the Federal Government's refusal to grant the city $1.5billion in special assistance.

title: Whitlam Returns From U.S.
description: CANBERRA. Australia, May 11 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Gough Whitlam returned home today from a visit to Washington and said that Australia's relations with the United States have never been healthier.

title: Old Supreme Court Chamber, Restored, to Be Opened to Public
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The British tried to burn it down. Later generations of Americans turned it into a dusty storeroom.

title: Innovative Slide Techniques Lighting Up Operas
description: NEWARK, May 11Frank Corsaro's use of film and slide projections in operatic production is only the latest and newestindication of the increasing interest being shown in this country in these techniques. And in a symposium held this morning at Newark's Symphony Hall, some 225 designers, lighting technicians and opera and theater administrators from around the country got together to discuss innovation in the field of scenic projection and to talk up the use of such devices in general.

title: Bonn's Tolerance Is Growing for Thousands Who Refuse Military Service
description: BONN, May 11At the end of World War II there were powerful historical currents to make certain that the Germans would never again bear arms. The cold war froze those currents and West Germany, in the words of a leading air force officer, is now the strongest military power in Western Europe.

title: Jane Weston Bride on L.I.
description: Jane Leslie Weston, daughter of Mrs. Emanuel Halperin of Lawrence, L. I., and Lawrence G. Weston of South Amboy, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Barry Roy Linsky. He is the son of John Linsky of Miami Beach and the late Mrs. Linsky. Rabbi Mark N. Goldman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: JOHN LEWIS
description: John Lewis, a lawyer in Suffern, N.Y. who served with the Judge Advocate General's office in World War II and was a prosecutor of Nazi war criminals in the Nuremberg trials, died yesterday in Suffern. His age was 68.

title: ILLS LINKED TO JOB IN WORKERS STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, May. 11Diseases suffered by three of every 10 factory and farm workers examined by a federally financed medical research team appear to have been caused by work conditions.

title: Art Dealer Stabbed to Death; Suspect Seized in Hotel Lobby
description: A 57yearold art dealer was stabbed to death in his suite at a fashionable hotel on the Upper East Side early yesterday, and a young man with blood on his chest was taken into custody by policemen in the lobby and charged with the murder.

title: Dodgers Beat Pirates, 70, As Sutton Gets 7th Victory
description: In nine years of pitching for the Los Angeles Dodgers, Don Sutton has never been able to reach the goal that signifies stardom, a 20victory season. He has come close in the last three campaigns, winning 19 in 1972, 18 in 1973 and 19 last year.

title: Hatfield Woman, Widow Of a McCoy, Dies at 98
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., May 11 (UPI) Ella Hatfield, whose marriage to Charles McCoy in 1898 sent shock waves through the feuding families of Hatfields and McCoys in the mountains of West Virginia and Kentucky, died Friday at her home here. She was 98 years old.

title: New Head of Alcohol Center
description: CAMDEN, May 11 (UPI)John A. Carpenter, a longtime faculty member of the Rutgers Center of Alcohol Studies, has been named director of the been named director of the center. Mr. Carpenter lives in Piscataway and has been a professor in the center's psychology department since 1968. He joined Rutgers from Yale in 1957 when the center moved to the Rutgers New Brunswick campus from Yale.

title: Man Held in 4 Deaths
description: UPPER DARBY, Pa., May 11 (UPI)A man was arrested at a motel early today and jailed without bond on charges of stabbing to death his wife and their three children. The police said that the children had been killed in their sleep. They said that George Powell, 41 years old, had offered no resistance when he was arrested in nearby Clifton Heights. The bodies were found last night in the Powell home.

title: CAMBODIA RULERS STRESS CHINA TIES
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 11 (AP)  The new Government of Cambodia today stressed its strong ties with China and thanked North Vietnam and North Korea for their support in defeating the U.S. imperialists.

title: Oldfield's New Style Makes Its Mark
Auto Engineers Are Told That the External Combustion Engine Has Little Future
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 9Engineers who have been workling for years to develop alternatives to the internal combustion engine reported progress !here this week, but went away doubting that many people ever would drive cars powered by their radically different engines.

title: Puzzle, Bulldog, Gains 21st Top Award
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn., May 11The topwinning bulldog hitch in the history of the breed in America, Ch. Westfield Cunomorus Stone, added another victory to her list today. She was named best of 1,461 dogs at Windham County's 31st show on Recreation Field. It was an exceptionally strong final, with all six dogs having been bestinshow performers.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: State energy officials want consumers to look for the energy efficiency rating when buying an airconditioner for the summer months.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: VATICAN'S OFFICES PICKETED IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI)  Hundreds of demonstrators, most of them women and members of the National Organization for Women, picketed the offices of the Apostolic Delegation to the United Stales today in a Mother's Day of Outrage against the Roman Catholic Church's support of antiabortion legislation.

title: 3 Men Studied in Kennedy Assassination Photos
description: DALLAS. May 11  Photographs of three shabbily dressed men being led by the police from the scene of the assassination of President Kennedy are being reexamined by a photographic expert for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: New Jersey Briefs; Former Patrolman Fined $500
description: Roger K. Strickland, 30 years old, a former Freehold patrolman, has been fined $500 and placed on probation for two years for altering a drunken driving summons and the results of two breathalizer tests he administered before left the police force. But Superior Court Judge M. Raymond McGowan suspended a oneyear to threeyear' state prison sentence, saying that he did not think it would benefit anyone by incarcerating the patrolman.

title: Norman Thomas Lauded As a Princeton Rebel
description: Legend has it that the British referred to Princeton University as a seedbed of revolution after its sixth president, John Witherspoon, signed the Declaration of Independence.

title: French Add Club Car
description: PARIS, May 10 (Reuters)The staterun French railroad system is hitching a nightclub to overnight trains between Paris and the South of France this summer. The car will be teamed with a new movie car on weekends on the ParisNice run from June to September, the company said.

title: America's Best Self
description: The victors in Cambodia have emptied the cities, driven huge numbers of people on a forced march into the countryside, and recognized no distinctions of age or sex or circumstance in their ruthless zeal to create new society. The Communist rulers in neighboring South Vietnam, more accustomed to power and more sophisticated in creating images for the outside world, have adopted a more urbane style. But no one doubts that there, too, coercion and reeducation will produce the gray conformity of totalitarianism.

title: Brooklyn's Culver Shuttle Makes Festive Final Run
description: Dominic Barone, the motorman on the last run of Brooklyn's Culver Station saluted its demise at midnight Saturday by blaring the elevated fourcar train's shrill horn all along its short trip above 38th Street in Borough Park.

title: SAIGON ANNOUNCES INTENTION TO HOLD NATIONWIDE VOTE
description: The new rulers of South Vietnam intend to hold nationwide elections and eventually to unify North and South Vietnam, according to delayed news dispatches from Saigon.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Donna Young, With 214, Wins by Shot
Wagner Discounts Interest in a Senate Race
description: Though many Democrats expect former Mayor Robert Wagner to parlay his close ties with Governor Carey into an attempt for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate next year, Mr. Wagner said last week that he wasn't interested  and he sounded as though he meant it.

title: Colloquium on Language a Wordy Affair
description: CHICAGO, May 10Philology leads to chaos, remarks a character in Eugene lonesco's The Lesson. This observation about linguistics seems tailormade to Language Celebration, a twoday coloquium at the University of Chicago that ended yesterday and that included, fittingly, a performance of the Ionesco play, a comedy that satirizes professors as teachers of knowledge.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TREASURE The Public Library labels its new exhibition, Swiss Horizon, one of its largest and most unusual in some time. The threepart display of Swiss art, history and culture is on view in the Library's central building, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, Monday through Saturday from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. through June 15.

title: Islanders In Familiar Territory
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., May 11  The New York Islanders were wearing the biggest smile this side of Montauk following their 21 victory over the Stanley Cup champions, Philadelphia Flyers, today.

title: How Referrals to Nursing Homes Are Made
description: The Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes will devote a hearing today to a mystery of the trade: how patients are directed to specific facilities. Medicaid grants freedom of choice. But when overbuilding produced a sub stantial surplus of beds two years ago, it was observed that many of the worst homes continued to operate at capacity. Why?

title: Philip Kayatt, 82, a Deviser Of Broadway's Neon Lights
description: Philip J. Kayatt, president of the Aerolux Light Company, Inc., a division of the DuroTest Corporation, who was involved in the first installation of neon lights for advertising on Broadway, died Saturday at his home, 496 Summit Avenue, Hackensack, N.J. His age was 82.

title: Harvard Oarsmen Take Five Sprints
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 11 Harvard crews won five of six final events today at the Eastern sprint championships on Lake Carnegie and the varsity eight broke a record in the process. This undefeated crew beat five rivals in the heavyweight final, leading all the way through the 2,000meter (1.23 miles) course, and finished in the remarkable time of 5 minutes 43.6 seconds.

title: PRIEST, RABBI TALK TO PROTESTANTS
description: A Roman Catholic priest, a rabbi and a Protestant minister yesterday shared the pulpit for the first time at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at 55th Street.

title: Cultural Arrogance
description: BOSTON, May 11Journalism is by nature episodic and ephemeral. Most of what appears in newspapers fades as quickly as the context of events. But there was a piece of work the other day that I think will live, as writing and something more: the set of stories filed by Sydney Schanberg of The New York Times on his emergence from Cambodia.

title: New Leftist Group Stirs Debate in Italy
description: ROME, May 11Italy is uneasily questioning the nature of a new leftist terrorist organization, the Armed Proletarian Units, that engineered the kidnapping of a high judge and a prison revolt last week amid increasing tension in the country.

title: Books of The Times
description: So now we know everything about the Watergate affair except why it happened. And we may never know that because is doubtful whether even Richard M. Nixon does. All historians can do is to speculate about his reasons for making the choices that he did. They can turn psychoanalysts and try to arrive at these reasons by getting inside the man or they can fall back on sociology and talk about the climates of feeling that made up Mr. Nixon's personal weather. Theodore H. White does some of both in Breach of Faith. He analyzes the lust for power of a President who had experienced poverty as a humiliation. He cites the bitterness of a man who had not one iota of charisma in an imageoriented age. He postulates the notion that the American counterculture made Mr. Nixon feel that he was fighting a civil war for the country he loved and that all was fair in love and war. He very nearly suggestsand I wish he hadthat in the extremity of his loneliness, Richard Nixon's behavior bordered on the autistic.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: EndofWar Rally Brings Out 50,000
description: About 50.000 people, including many veterans of 10 years of antiwar marches and rallies in the city, filled the Sheep Meadow in Central Park yesterday for an afternoon's celebration of peace in Vietnam and Cambodia.

title: Moriarty to Quit Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, May 11 (AP) Phil Moriarty, who guided Yale swimming teams to .908 winning percentage during 16 years as coach, will retire at the end of the 1975 76 season.

title: Monaco Grand Prix To Lauda's Ferrari
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 11Nilti Lauda, wet from rain and sweat, somewhat dazed and slightly exhausted, gave Ferrari its first victory in the Monaco Grand Prix in 20 years today. The wealthy Austrian easily finished ahead of Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, the world driving champion.

title: Advertising
description: A new sincere voice has just joined the other sincere voices currently trying to sell drip coffee makers on television.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Young Executives Adjust to Their First Big Recession
Red Smith
description: Ambrose Bierce defines epitaph as an inscription on a tomb showing that virtues acquired by death have a retroactive effect. And Dr. Samuel Johnson, musing on the discrepancies that sometimes occur between a person's standing with his fellows and the sentiments graven on his tombstone, observed that in lapidary inscriptions a man is not upon oath. Perhaps it is not impertinent to suggest a line for Avery Brundage's headstone: For once, he gave in. It is difficult to believe he went meekly, though, even at 87. One pictures him still haughtily erect at the end, shoulders squared, staring coldly down his nose at an apologetic angel of death. So he passed over and all the trumpets sounded for him on the other side. As president of the Amateur Athletic Union, president of the United States Olympic Committee and for 20 years president of the International Olympic Committee, Avery Brundage stood as a monument to Avery Brundage's concept of sport. It did not trouble him that what he stood for existed mainly in his own mind.

title: EDWARD J. BEACH
description: Edward J. Beach, vice president of the Abbe Engineering Company and an officer of the Beach Russ Company, both of Brooklyn, who held a number of patents relating to vacuum pumps, died Saturday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N. Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Walter T. Bonney Dead at 65, Was NASA Public Affairs Chief
description: FREDERICK, Md., May 11Walter T. Bonney, director of public affairs for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration from its formation in 1958 until 1960, died here last night of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: Monday, May 12, 1975

title: BIG U.F.T. VICTORY INDICATED IN VOTE
description: The United Federation of Teachers appeared yesterday to have won a substantial victory in the third citywide election of community school boards. Candidates backed by the union gained a working majority of seats on at least 21 of the 32 local hoards, as the tally of Tuesday's vote continued.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
CARRIER ARRIVES IN GUAM BRINGING SAIGON AIRCRAFT
description: APRA HARBOR, Guam, Monday, May 12The aircraft carrier Midway arrived today to unload a controversial cargo of 99 repossessed South Vietnamese military aircraft. Meanwhile, the curtailment of refugee flights to the United States continued.

title: Troubled Center for Children Reports Progress, but Basic Problems Remain
description: More than eight months after news articles disclosed that the Children's Center, at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, was being terrorized by adolescent girl residents and by young hoodlums who gathered outside, there has been considerable improvement at the is stitution.

title: 2 Britons Killed in Nepal
description: LONDON, May 11 (AP)Two British Army oficers, training to climb Mount Everest, were killed by falling rocks as they tested equipment on the slopes of Mount Nuptse in Nepal, the Defense Ministry said.

title: Bel Canto Opera Offers the Australian Garni Sands
description: One of the most ambitious productions attempted by the enterprising Bel Canto Opera during its six seasons is Garni Sands, written 10 years ago by the Australian George Dreyfus after a radio drama (and, subsequently, to a libretto) by Frank Kellaway. Mr. Dreyfus came to the United States about a month ago to prepare the gifted young singers for the American premiere, and the composer stayed to conduct the four performances that ended yesterday afternoon at the Bel Canto's tiny home in the Madison Avenue Baptist Church.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Boston vs. Washington

title: Nigeria Cutting Oil Production Sharply
