description: Architecturally, at least, there has been no attempt made to deny the fact that the Robert Lehman Collection is the centerpiece of the Metropolitan Museum's $50million expansion. The new wing has been placed directly on the axis of the museum's main entrance, and will also serve as the focal point of the vast additions now under construction along the west side of the museum building. The wing is not smallits glasscovered central garden court, while nowhere near the museum's Great Hall in size, is nonetheless more than twothirds the height of the central space of the Guggenheim Museum.

title: Laotian Left Says It Wants Coalition Rule to Continue
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 13The fragile coalition that has ruled Laos for 13 months appeared to be holding together today as various elements expressed their support for the Government on the eve of a crucial cabinet meeting.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Northeastern U. Elects Head
description: BOSTON, May 13 (AP)Dr. Kenneth G. Ryder was elected today the fourth president of Northeastern University, the largest private university in the country. He has been executive vice president for four years and will succeed Dr. Ma S. Knowles, 66 years old.

title: Judge Quits Over Salary
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 13United States District Judge James A. Comiskey announced his resignation yesterday, citing the sixyear freeze imposed on the salaries of Federal judges. The 48yearold Democrat, who was appointed to the $40,000ayear post in 1967, said he would become president of the Bank of Louisiana.

title: Jacksonville Schools Give SciFi Film Passting Grade as an Aid to Reading
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 13A 1934 sciencefiction film serial involving a robot, a vanishing machine and mysterious rays has been used here in a threeweek experiment to determine how commercial television can be used to teach reading.

title: Businessman Guilty in Hired Killing
description: The man who hired a killer to murder Robert Newmark, hardware importer who ran for the Assembly on the West Side three years ago, was found guilty late last night of murder. However, the jury acquitted a 29yearold drifter accused of carrying out Mr. Newmark's murder for $5,000.

title: 3M SAYS REPUTATION IS STILL STRONG ONE
description: ST. PAUL, May 13 (AP)Illegal political contributions made by the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company were a mistake but the company's reputation in the marketplace does not seem to have suffered, Raymond H. Herzog, president and chief executive officer, said today.

title: Harvard Plans to Admit More Women
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13 Harvard University's Board of Overseers approved yesterday a plan to give equal consideration for admission and financial aid to men and women applying to Harvard and Radcliffe Colleges, beginning in 1976

title: Olympic Problem For Israeli Star
description: Three years after he escaped the tragedy of the Olympics at Munich, Dr. Shaul Ladany has a new problem on the road to Montreal, but it is athletic, not political.

title: People in Sports
description: The first man to put the 16pound shot 60 feet, Parry O'Brien, thinks that perhaps the man who just tossed it 75 feet might be doing something illegal.

title: Bridgeton Shot Marking 200th Year Seconds Early
description: BRIDGETON, May 13A block of Broad Street here was cordoned off today and began a year of Bicentennial celebrations with a ceremony at the historic tavern where The Plain Dealer, said to be New Jersey's first newsletter, was published 200 years ago.

title: An Ohio Priest Pleads Not Guilty In Giving 2 Women Church Role
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 13The Rev. L. Peter Beebe pleaded not guilty today to charges that he broke Episcopal Church canons in permitting two women to celebrate communion at his Oberlin church last December.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Sales of new singlefamily homes picked up in March and the backlog of unsold homes declined slightly, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Minority Legislators in Albany Offer Hiring Plan for Construction Industry
description: ALBANY, May 13Charging that the state was moving tool slowly in developing an affirmative action plan for hiring minority group members on stateaided construction projects, members of the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus today offered their own proposal for increasing such hiring.

title: Veteran Who Sought More Disability Pay Loses a Long Battle
description: The long fight of Edward N. Evans, a Bronx veteran of World War II who has been seeking Government compensation for paralysis that he contends was serviceconnected, appeared lost yesterday.

title: RIFLE GROUP SPURS FIGHT ON CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, May 13The National Rifle Association of America, the country's leading opponent. of gun control,  is soliciting monetary and political support in a letter that says, In New York City, important city officials have publicly advocated that all firearms he taken away from the city's patrolmen.

title: Electrical Workers Strike
description: VERNON, Vt., May 14 (AP)Half the staff at the Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant walked off the job today after rejecting on Monday a proposed contract, a company spokesman said. The 55 members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers rejected a twoyear contract offer that would have increased their salaries and fringe benefits by more than 18 per cent over two years.

title: Nuclear Moratorium Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)  An organization called Women Strike for Peace demanded today a moratorium on the production and distribution of nuclear weapons and for international nuclear parity created by disarmament instead of by increasing weaponry. The group is sending petitions to Congressmen and other Government representatives.

title: F.T.C. TO EMPHASIZE ANTITRUST PROBLEM
description: WASHINGTON. May 14 (Reuters)The Federal Trade Commission said it would concentrate on antitrust investigations in the food, health and energy industries in the coming year.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs
description: STANLEY CUP FINALS

title: I.R.S. In Its Use of Informers
description: WASHINGTON May 14The Internal Revenue Service is conducting a sweeping internal investigation of how its ants used paid informers in 22 selected tax distriets, Commissioner Donald C. Alexander said today.

title: Senators Seeking Raw Data From F.B.I
description: WASHINGTON. May 14The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activity voted today to ask the Federal Bureau of Investigation for documents contained in the bureau's raw intelligence files.

title: DeBusschere to Head A.B.A.
description: The fastblooming career of Dave DeBusschere has landed him the commissionership of the American Basketball Association two years after his retirement as player with the Knicks.

title: A Glittery Times Sq. Tower Due
description: Times Square's Allied Chemical Tower will be sheathed from top to bottom in oneway mirrors, grow four stories taller and take on new prismlike shape under $10million renovation plan announced yesterday by Alex M. Parker its latest owner.

title: Meadowland Golf Course Is Part of Garbage Proposal
description: LYNDHURST, May 14 (UPI)A plan to end garbage dumping in the Hackensack Meadowlands by recycling trash and building a 2,000acre nature park and golf course on top of present landfills was unveiled today by state officials.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Seizures by Ecuadorians, Barbary States Recalled
description: Although the seizures of the American merchant vessel Mayagez by Cambodian Communists led many Americans yesterday to remember international incidents involving United States ships from the Maine to the Pueblo, the latest case appears to have few parallels in the country's history.

title: 2 in South Win Awards For Reporting on Reading
description: Nita Fran Hutcheson, education reporter for KSLATV News in Shreveport, La., and Robert B. Holland, an editorial writer for The Richmond (Va.) Times Dispatch, were cited yesterday by the International Reading Association as winners of its top awards for excellence in reporting in the field of reading

title: POUND DECLINES; TRADE DEFICIT UP
description: LONDON. May 19 (UPI)The British pound slumped further today and the Treasury announced trade figures shoving a $665million deficit for April. Sterling dropped to record lows against a number of European currencies and lost ground slightly against the dollar.

title: Seoul Aide Says Curbs May Be Kept for Years
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 19The national security decree issued by President Park Chung Hee yesterday may remain in force for at least several years, according to a senior member of the governing Democratic Republican party.

title: Pros Are Cool to Schoolboy Demands
description: With the fanfare now quieting, the two schoolboys who applied recently for the National Basketball Association's Hardship Draft are confronted with a harsh reality: There is little money for the pro teams to be tossing around trying to sign untested 18  year  olds. Moses Malone's success with the Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association sent the pro scouts to high school gymnasiums last winter hoping to find another talent capable of moving from high school competition into the pros.

title: Marijuana Bill Considered
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) A drug agency official said today that the Ford Administration was considering whether to push for reduction of penalties for the possession of marijuana. In questioning at a Senate judiciary subcommittee hearing, Donald Miller, general counsel for the Drug Enforcement Administration, said that the Department of Justice was reevaluating its position on marijuana penalties.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Timmy Lobell on Rail for Realization
description: WESTBURY, L.I., May 14 Ben Webster was delighted this morning to learn the preferred No. 1 post position had been drawn for Timmy Lobell for Saturday night's $101,550 Realization Pace. Timmy Lobell immediately was made the early 31 choice by Roosevelt Raceway's oddsmaker.That's good news, said the 35yearold driver, who will receive the first opportunity in his 18year career to compete for a purse carrying six figures when he guides the 4yearold stallion in the 1 1/16 mile contest.

title: Nilsson to Miss Met Season
description: Birgit Nilsson, the dramatic soprano, will not be appearing with the Metropolitan Opera next season. Schuyler G. Chapin, general manager of the company, said that Miss Nilsson would not return because of her own personal reasons. The soprano, who is in Europe, could not he reached for comment. Danica Mastilovic will replace Miss Nilsson in the title role of Strauss's Elektra, which is to be given its first performance of the 197576 season Nov. 25.

title: Threat to Relations
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Thursday, May 15Premier Kukrit Pramoj said yesterday that the United States had until this morning to remove the 1,100 marines it had flown to Thailand without his permission.

title: BERME PROJECTS BUDGET INCREASES
description: Mayor Beame's contemplated 19756 budget is estimating increases of $205.1million, or 34.3 per cent, for social services, including rising welfare case loads, and $147.2million, or 10.8 per cent, for education. The school rise apparently reflects increased teacher costs.

title: Greenhaven Psychologist Calls For Inquiry on Inmate's Death
description: A consulting psychologist at the Greenhaven state prison called yesterday for an independent investigation into the death of Oliver Robinson, an inmate who died April 29 after he was subdued by guards following his apparent psychotic outburst in the prison hospital.

title: McGill Hints That Calm Is Deceptive at Columbia
description: Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University, said at commencement exercises yesterday that the calm that had settled over the campus, which was in an uproar of violence, strikes and near chaos in 1968, might be deceptive.

title: Andr Previn to Direct Pittsburgh Symphony
description: Andr Previn was named Music director of the Pittsburgh Symphony yesterday, it was announced by press representatives here.

title: Jerusalem Murder Reflects IsraeliArab Tension
description: JERUSALEM, May 12Three Arab brothers from the former Jordanian sector of Jerusalem were convicted of the murder of an Israeli taxi driver early this month and sentenced to life imprisonment. Showing neither contrition nor remorse, the three young men defiantly chanted the Palestinian slogan Palestine is Arabas they were led away.

title: Chrysler Is Offering a ProfitSharing Plan in Britain
description: LONDON, May 14Chrysler U.K., a wholly owned subsidiary of the United States automobile manufacturer, has surprised the Government, its own employes and other big companies with proposals to give workers a chance to share in any profits and to he represented on the board of directors.

title: Seized Vessel Insured At $3Million by Lloyd's
description: LONDON, May 14 (AP) Lloyd's of London said today that it had insured the American merchant ship Mayagez, seized by Cambodia, for over $3million under warrisk policies.

title: Ashland Is Talking to S.E.C. About Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) Ashland Oil, Inc., disclosed today that it was in an advanced stage of negotiations with the Securities and Exchange Commission on terms of a settlement of a proposed lawsuit over political contributions and other cash payments made by Ashland.

title: Washington Silent on the Thai Protest
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 The United States Government maintained silence through the day today about Thailand's protest against the dispatch of 1,100 marines to U Taphao air base.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MAY 15, 1975

title: U.S. GROUP TO ASSIST REFUGEE NEWSMEN
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) A group of Washingtonbased journalists, concerned about economic conditions facing Vietnamese newsmen who have left their country for the United States, have formed a committee to assist them with jobs, money and reeducation.

title: Bankers Not Surprised By City Aid Rejection
description: Investment bankers and commercial bankers who deal in New York City notes and bonds were disappointed but not surprised that President Ford denied Mayor Beame's plea for financial help. Several saw little chance that Congress would pass legislation in time to be of any help to the city in solving its present cash shortage.

title: Food Stamps as the Key to Welfare Reform
description: WASHINGTONEven though welfare reform is not in the news these days, there are important steps that could be taken to improve and rationalize programs to aid the needy. Three events this year, seemingly unrelated, deserve attention.

title: Nixon Owes $148.000 In Back Taxes for '69
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (Reuters)  Former President Richard M. Nixon has not paid $148,000 in back taxes for 1969, Internal Revenue Service Commissioner Donald Alexander said today.

title: METHADONE UNITS FOUND DEFICIENT
description: A wide range of deficiencies, including charging for services that were not provided, was found in 17 of the city's 21 privately run methadone maintenance clinics inspected so far by the Health Department, according to reports released yesterday.

title: Oil From a Shrub Found in Desert May Save the Sperm Whale
description: There grows in the desert of North America a lowly shrub that scientists say may save the sperm whale from extinction.

title: Israel Force Said to Raid Southern Lebanon Again
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. May 14 (Reuters)Israeli troops struck into southern Leabnon again today and the Lebanese Government sai dit would complain to the United Nations Security Council.

title: House Panel Drafts a Bill To End Oil Price Control
description: WASHINGTON, May 14In postmidnight session punctuated by angry shouting between Democrats, a House Commerce subcommittee early today completed drafting of an energy bill that would end price controls on crude oil by 1979.

title: Says State Is Place for Any Requests
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 President Ford, asserting that a federally guaranteed loan to New York City would provide no real solution, tonight turned down the city's plea for the $1.5billion in cash it says it needs for its expenses through June 30.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Princeton Vows Change In Hiring of Minorities
description: PRINCETON, May 14PrinceHon University has submitted to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare a revision of its Affirmative Action Plan, which calls for the school to reach out more broadly for candidates for faculty and staff positions. The report also estimates that 36 women and 16 members of minority groups will be added to the nontenured faculty staff over the next six years.

title: I.M.F. HEAD FINDS A MONETARY GAP
description: WASHINGTON, May 14A serious gap in the world's antiInflationary defenses has emerged from the capacity of the present international mone tary system to create both international liquidity and international credit. the managing director of the International Monetary Fund warned today.

title: LOCKHEED IS BACKED BY CONTRACT BOARD
description: A multimilliondollar shipbuilding claim against the Navy by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, a claim that figured in the collapse of the company's $100million deal with Textron, Inc., has been decided in Lockheed's favor.

title: Hunger Grows in Big Area of East India
description: NEW DELHI, May 14Peasants in a wide belt of eastern India are facing hunger because of drought and rising food prices. They and the urban poor are also suffering because wheat and rice are increasingly scarce in the Government's rationing system.

title: Stability in Bonn
description: The gains accorded Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's federal coalition by a third of West Germany's voters in two crucial state elections, despite recession and million unemployed, were more important for what they avoided than for what they achieved. Loss of North RhineWestphalia, the country's largest state, could have set off more than a year of dangerous instability in the federal government, pending national elections, at a time when Europe and the West need strength and steadiness in Bonn.

title: AN ANNUAL REPORT ON COURTS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The Chief Justice of the United States would deliver an annual report to a joint session of Congress on the state of the Federal judiciary, under a proposal made today by two Democratic members of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Time Is Running Out in Wage Talks for 600,000 Postal Workers
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Time is running out on the negotiations between the postal unions and the United States Postal Service as they try to reach agreement on the third twoyear contract in the history of the reorganized Federal agency.

title: HOUSE APPROVES REFUGEE AID BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 The House of Representatives approved tonight legislation to aid South Vietnamese and Cambodian refugees by authorizing their transportation, temporary maintenance and resettlement.

title: Thais Report Withdrawal Of Marines After Protest
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Thursday, May 15All 1,100 United States marines flown to U Taphao air base in Thailand yesterday were withdrawn early today. the Thai Government announced.

title: Tass Reports Attack Without Any Comment
description: MOSCOW, May 14 (UPI)The Soviet Tass press agency today swiftly announced that the United States had attacked Cambodian naval vessels but made no comment.

title: Stans Fined $5,000 in Campaign Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Former Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans was fined a total of $5,000 by a Federal district judge today for five admitted misdemeanor violations of Federal campaign laws in Richard M. Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: Feminist Shareholders Challenge the Corporate Structure
description: Women wanting to improve their status and increase their numbers within a corporation have used a variety of methods over the years: Long working hours. Picket lines. Affirmative action programs. Lawsuits. And even tears and sex.

title: Chessie Studies Bid for ErieLackawanna
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The Chessie System, Inc., indicated here today for the first time its interest in acquiring 1,200 miles of the bankrupt ErieLackawanna Railroad to gain access to the New York areas. In addition, the Norfolk & Western Railway, Chessie's only solvent competitor in the East, and which owned the ErieLachawanna until it went into bankruptcy in 1972, said that the ErieLackawanna's lines east of Buffalo could never be made economical and that it has no further interest in them.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Republic Steel Corporation announced yesterday a major expansion program at its Gadsden. Ala., plant that would add about 1 million tons of raw steel capacity to the plant.

title: Chess:
description: Never make a move without looking to see what the opponent is doinghe may be doing you in. That advice is ordinarily given to beginners, who, struggling to form a clear plan of their own, exhibit a wild disregard for what the enemy is up to. But they are not the only ones who could benefit by it, for even experienced players at times forget such elementary precepts.

title: French Red Chief Assails Chinese During Peking Aide's Visit
description: PARIS, May 14The leader of the French Communist party lashed out at the Chinese Cornmunists today for what he called their abandonment of MarxismLeninism, their indefensible support for an aggressive Europe of monopolies and their continued praise of Stalin.

title: State Board Favors Panel With More Effectiveness
description: The State Consumer Protection Board, made up of the heads of various state executive departments, yesterday proposed to dissolve itself in favor of a new and more effective consumer division.

title: HOUSE APPROVES REFUGEE AID BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 The House of Representatives approved tonight legislation to aid South Vietnamese and Cambodian refugees by authorizing their transportation, temporary maintenance and resettlement.

title: Dr. Ernst Alexanderson, Radio Pioneer, Dies at 97
description: Dr. Ernst F. W. Alexanderson, the engineer whose highfrequency alternator made possible the first voice radio broadcast in 1906, and who later contributed to the development of television technology, died yesterday at the age of 97 at his home in Schenectady, N. Y.

title: Nieporte Beats Sutter in Playoff, Wins Long Island Golf 5th Time
FORD IS BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The White House said today that President Ford had consulted with Congressional leaders before ordering the miiltary operations off Cambodia.

title: Sadat Says He'll Ask U.S. For Aid on Debt to Soviet
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 14President Anwar elSadat said in an interview published today that he would seek financial aid from the United States to settle. Egypt's large debts to, the Soviet Union.

title: COMPROMISE SET ON SNICK REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, May 14A SenateHouse conference committee reached full agreement today on legislation overhauling Federal regulation of the securities industry and providing for a national market system.

title: Books of The Times
description: Although he Is best known as a playwrightpossibly this country's most distinguished playwright, if productivity and sheer survival are criteria for weighing a playwright's worthTennessee Williams has also published a considerable body of prose fiction. And in his sixth book and first fulllength novel, Moise and the World of Reason (his earlier prose was either short stories or novels, or combina bons of both), he has done something new, not only for his fiction but also in terms his dramaturgy. For the first time, he has dealt at length, overtly and even graphically with the subject of homosexuality. And it makes a difference, whatever the book is finally worth as art.

title: Finding by Safety Agency May Spur Firestone Recall
description: The Federal Transportation Department announced yesterday a finding that could compel the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company to recall almost one million steel belted bias ply tires, according to United Press international.

title: Shell's Gasoline Price Up; St. Joe's Lead Price Cut
description: The Shell Oil Company yesterday increased wholesale prices on all classes of its gasoline by 1 cent a gallon.

title: Kennecott Says F.T.C. Amended Peabody Order
description: The Kennecott Copper Corp. said yesterday the Federal Trade Commission deleted the conditions in the company's extension order to sell the Peabody Coal Company.

title: Perdicaris Alive, or...
description: WASHINGTON, May 14On the eve of the Republican convention of 1909, a Moroccan bandit named Ahmed Raisuli kidnapped an American citizen, Jon Perdicaris, who had been living near Tangier. American and British warships were rushed to the Moroccan capital, three Marines went ashore to assert our serious intent, and President Theodore Roosevelt demanded that the Sultan force the bandit to release the American.

title: Amnesty Group Wages Drive To Free Queens War Resister
description: Groups seeking unconditional amnesty for war resisters are mounting a campaign in behalf of a 32yearold Queens man who is one of a handful of Americans still in jail for refusing to serve in Vietnam.

title: The New York Times Appoints Consumer Marketing Director
description: Donald A. Nizen, who worked in The New York Times circulation department from 1956 to 1964, is rejoining the newspaper on June 2 as director of consumer marketing, a new post. He will he in charge of circulation sales and promotion. Frank Adams, circulation director, and Warren Abrams, promotion manager, will report to Mr. Nizen.

title: CONGRESS AGREES ON A BUDGET GOAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Congress completed work today on the first Congressional resolution on the budget in historythe start of a new process aimed at giving Congress fuller and more rational control over Government spending.

title: Means, Indian Leader, Held For Trial in Dakota Killing
description: RAPID CITY, S.D., May 14 (AP)Circuit Judge Marshall Young ruled today that there were sufficient grounds to continue the murder case against Russell Means, leader of the American Indian Movement, and Richard Marshall.

title: Unemployment in France Up
description: PARIS, May 14 (Reuters)Unemployment in France rose to 797,100 at the end of April on a seasonally adjusted basis,: from 765,700 in March, the Labor Ministry said today.

title: A New City
description: We are, in fact, building a different kind of city from that of ten years ago, using the same set of developers but a different set of rules. In some ways, it is distinctly better city. New York has transformed conventional restrictive zoning into some of the most progressive and provocative zoning policies in the world. The result is a kind of preventive planning, or the setting of objectives and standards in advance of development, based on the ability to see trends and potential consequences and to guide them constructively.

title: Ford Rejects a Plea By Beame for Help
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 President Ford, asserting that a federally guaranteed loan to New York City would provide no real solution, tonight turned down the city's plea for the $1.5billion in cash it says it, needs for its expenses through June 30.

title: FOUR IN DRUG UNIT INDICTED IN THEFT
description: Four detectives once assigned to an elite narcotics unit in the Police Department were accused yesterday of stealing $8,000 from a suspected narcotics trafficker and then lying at his trial.

title: Stage: Haunting Shakespeare Dream
description: NEW HAVEN Two contrasting, but theatrically compatible, versions of A Midsimmer Night's Dream are being performed simultaneously at the Yale Repertory Theater  Henry Purcell's The Fairy Queen, excerpts of which act as background score, and a staged Dream that is in some, entirely laudatory, respects a nightmare.

title: Erie Canal Given 5 Birthday Cakes As It Reaches 150
description: WATERFORD, N. Y., May 15The Erie Canal got five birthday cakes here todayone for every 30 years of century and a half of colorful historyas state officials and Albany area residents commemorated the sesquicentennial of the shallow ditch that opened up the West and made New York its preeminent gateway.

title: Diplomatic Step in Paris
description: PARIS, May 14  France announced today that she was raising her official contacts with the Provisional Revolutionary Government of South Vietnam to ambassadorial level.

title: Text of President's Letter
description: Foilowing is the text of President's Ford's letter Mayor Beame:

title: Security Check and Need for Sponsors Delaying Refugee Flow
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Fewer than 10,000 Vietnamese refugees have been processed and released from the reception centers; the rest await sponsors and completion of security checks before they will be admitted into the United States.

title: 4 Killed in Spain As Basque Rebels Clash With Police
description: MADRID, May 14Four persons were killed today in gun battles between the police and Basque activists in the ancient Bascule capital of Guernica.

title: COVENANT REPEAL ON BONDS UPHELD
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., May 14State Superior Court Judge: George B. Gelman upheld today New Jersey's right to appeal a bond covenant that had limited the Port of New York and New Jersey's involvement in mass transit.

title: 5 JERSEY CITY AIDES SUBPOENAED BY JURY
description: JERSEY CITY, May 24 (UPI) At least five members of the administration of Mayor Paul T. Jordan have been subpoenaed to testify about alleged hidrigging in the award of a computer contract, officials said today.

title: WESTCHESTER HOLDS 3 SCHOOL ELECTIONS
description: Following are the results from three Westchester school district elections yesterday. Incumbents in the school board voting are denoted by asterisks. The winners are capitalized.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, May 14, 1975

title: CBS Reports Sharp Dip in Saturday Morning Ads
description: Partly because of changes prompted by groups working for reforms in children's programing and advertising, the Saturday morning children's shows on the networks are no longer hugely profitable, John A. Schneider, president of the CBS Broadcast Group, said yesterday. In fact, he said, children's television has become a marginal undertaking for CBS.

title: Article 2  No Title
FORD IS BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The White House said tonight that President Ford had consulted with Congressional leaders both before ordering the recapture of the merchant vessel Mayagez and before ordering the sinking earlier today of Cambodian patrol boats.

title: Israel's Inflexible Stand
description: A stubborn war of eighty years between the Arab world and the movement for the return to Zion, today embodied by the State of Israel, is on the brink of ending. It would be pity and a crime if it took another war to convince the parties involved to come to peaceful resolution.

title: Judge Orders Busing Foes To Tell of Demonstration
description: BOSTON, May 14 (AP)  A Federal judge ordered two antibusing leaders today to answer questions about their alleged involvement in organizing a demonstration outside South Boston High School last week.

title: ELDERLY SUE U.S. ON FOOD AID CURB
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Elderly citizens and groups representing them filed a suit in Federal District Court today charging the Ford Administration with impounding more than $40million earmarked by Congress for food programs.

title: Washington Silent
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The United States Government maintained silence today about a Thai protest against the dispatch of 1,100 marines to Thailand.

title: WOMAN IS CHARGED AS ROBBERY DECOY
description: Detectives yesterday arrested a young woman who they believed acted as a decoy for two men who attacked and robbed more than 15 elderly men and women in their apartments in the Bronx earlier, this year.

title: House Leaders to Press for U.S Aid to Bail Out City
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Despite President Ford's rejection of financial help for New York City, Congressional leaders said tonight they would push a fourpoint program that includes Federal assistance to the city so it could solve its immediate cash problems.

title: Women's Complaint of Blas By Law Firm Is Dismissed
description: The City Commission on Human Rights has dismissed complaints against the law firm of Gilbert, Segall & Young brought by two women law students in 1971 who had charged that the firm discriminated against women in its hiring.

title: VIOLENCE IN LAOS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 14AntiAmerican demonstrators ransacked United States mission buildings in the cities of Luang Prabang and Savannakhet today, and embassy officials here said that as a result, the evacuation of Americans scheduled to leave later in the year would begin at once.

title: Smith Upset, Riessen Also Eliminated
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 14 (AP)Two seeded players were upset today in the $150,000 Alan King tennis tournament. Marty Riessen lost to Ross Case of Australia and Stan Smith was beaten by Vijay Amritraj of India.

title: Fragile Ulster Truce Sustained As Slain Policeman Is Buried
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 14The 52d regular police officer to die in Ulster's six years of violence was buried here today.

title: Slowdown in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (UPI)Several hospitals in the Philadelphia area reported work slowdowns today as physicians began taking part in a protest over the big increase in costs for malpractice insurance.

title: New Role for Mrs. Giscard: Husband's Unofficial Envoy
description: Shortly before AnneAymone Giscard d'Estaing set out on her current, semiprivate, semiofficial visit to the United States without her husband, the French newspaper Le Monde analyzed to its usual faretheewell the role of Presidential wife.

title: Municipal Unions Warn They Won't Yield Gains
description: Leaders of municipal unions reacted angrily yesterday to what they regard as a continuing effort by the Beame administration and banking interests to place the greatest burden for solution of the city's fiscal crisis on the backs of its employes.

title: Dr. Marguerite Percy, 65; Discoverer of an Element
description: Dr. Marguerite Perey, a coworker of Marie Curie in research with radioactive materials and the discoverer of a radioactive clement that she named Francium, died Tuesday in Paris. She was 65 years old. Her death ended a 15year struggle against cancer, believed to have resulted from her work with radioactive materials.

title: Chicago Jailbreak Is Said to Involve At Least 17 Inmates
description: CHICAGO May 15 (UPI)At least 17 prisoners escaped through a window at the Cook County Jail last night, but the authorities said that two of them had been recaptured.

title: DR. WU NANJU
description: Dr. Wu Nanju, a diplomat in the Chinese Nationalist Foreign Service from 1926 until his retirement in 1972, died Monday of a heart attack at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 76 years old.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES FAIRTRADE ACT END
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Thee House Antitrust subcommittee unanimously approved today legislation that would have the effect of repealing state fair trade laws under which manufacturers could dictate the prices at which retailers sell their products.

title: ASIANS MAY INITIAL AMITY PACT TODAY
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 14 (UPI)Reliable sources at the Southeast Asian foreign ministers meeting here said today that the ministers from Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia and Singapore would initial a friendship treaty here tomorrow as a first step in a blueprint for a regional peace zone that could include Communist nations. peace zone that could include Communist nations.

title: ASSETS OF VIDAR SOLD TO TRW, INC.
description: The Continental Telephone Corporation announced yesterday that it had sold the assets of the Vidar Corporation, subsidiary that makes telecommunications equipment in Mountain View, Calif., for about $14million to TRW, Inc. The details of the deal were not announced.

title: LTV Arranges a New Line 1 Of Credit With Bank Group
description: DALLAS, May 14 (UPI)The LTV Corporation said today i thad arranged a new $120million sevenyear line of credit with a banking group led by the Bank of America.

title: Cosmos' 4 Penalty Kicks Missed in Overtime Loss
description: It is very difficult for a goalkeeper in soccer to save a penalty shot. But Arnie Mausser saved three last night against the New York Cosmos to lead the Hartford Bicentennials to a 21 victory in the North American Soccer League game.

title: LISBON ABSORBS MORE INDUSTRIES
description: LISBON, May 14 (UPI)Portugal's military Government today nationalized the cement, cellulose and tobacco industries and instituted wage controls.

title: Is Cash Flow Crisis Real Or Only Budget Jargon?
description: Does the city have a cash flow problem, or are those words jargon to mask an unacknowledged budget deficit?

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
RECEIVER SOUGHT FOR NURSING HOME
description: The state, for the first time, asked a court yesterday to name a receiver to operate nursing home that it said had been sold without approval of the Public Health Council.

title: Some Old Problems
description: If there are planning successes, however, there are also dismal failures. For the renascence of downtown Brooklyn, there is the horror of the South Bronx, proving again that physical renewal cannot cure the deeper, unresolved problems of urban pathology. These are subjects for continuing concern and effort.

title: Article 3  No Title
Weaving and Other Fun for Children
Stocks Climb in Heavy Trading
description: The stock market advanced, then eased yesterday in heavier trading despite the report of the sinking of three Cambodian patrol vessels by American planes.

title: Weekly Paper Sold
description: BOSTON, May 14 (AP)A group headed by Ralph I. Fine of Boston anounced yesterday the purchase of The Real Paper, a Cambridgebased weekly. The announcement said Mr. Fine had acquired controlling interest and would be chairman of the board of directors.

title: PAROLE BOARD SET TO ACT ON BACKLOG
description: TRENTON, May 14State officials expressed relief today that the way had been cleared for the start of parole hearings on Friday, thereby relieving tension that had been building in the state's prisons.

title: Construction Jobs Spark Racial Fight
description: Minority and white workers threw bricks, stones and bottles at each other yesterday in a battle over jobs that led the State Dormitory Authority to suspend work on the construction of a $70million academic center on the north campus of City College.

title: 2 Retired Bishops Present Testimony In Priest's Defense
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 14Ordination of 11 women as Episcopal priests last summer in Philadelphia was described at an ecclesiastical trial here today as irregular but valid by three witnesses, including one of the Bishops who ordained the woman.

title: Music: 50 Singing Years
description: Fifty years ago this month, an ensemble called the Adesdi Chorus gave its first concert here. With additions, it soon developed into a large amateur chorus called the Dessoff Choirs. Margarete Dessoff, a native of Germany, was the founder, and she continued as director for 11 years.

title: State Senate Extends Exemption on Tax Limitation
description: ALBANY, May 14The city of Yonkers and 57 school districts around the state could continue to circumvent a constitutional limit on property taxes under a package of bills passed today, amid some grumbling, by the Senate.

title: ExMerrill Lynch Head Uses Option to Buy 30,000 Shares
description: George L. Shinn, who resigned last week as president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., to become chairman of the First Boston Corporation, exercised an option to buy 30,000 shares of Merrill Lynch stock last month, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday.

title: Marcos Foe Ends 40Day Fast; Military Court Puts Off Trial
description: MANILA, May 14  Former Senator Benigno S. Aquino Jr., an outspoken critic of the martiallaw Philippine Government, ended a 40day protest fast today.

title: Notes on People
description: Frank Sinatra won libel damages of $2,400 and another $2,400 in costs and an apology from the British Broadcasting Corporation for a 1972 news program that suggested the singer had connections with the Mafia. The program discussed the possibility that Mr. Sinatra had done favors for organized crime figures in return for influence that got him his Oscarwinning 1953 role in From Here to Eternity. Mr. Sinatra, in London for two concerts May 2829, was not in court.

title: Music
description: This has been a spring for operetta. A few weeks ago the Viennese school was represented by Lehar's The Merry Widow, staged by the Village Light Opera Group. Last week the Light Opera of Manhattan opened a fourweek run of Victor Herbert's Naughty Marietta. On Tuesday night, the Parisian genre had its turn when the New York Lyric Opera presented Offenbach's The Grand Duchess of Gerolstein at the Universalist Center for the Arts.

title: Senate Resists Consumer Bill Changes
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) The Senate decisively rejected two attempts today to make major changes in a bill to create an independent agency to give consumers a voice in Federal policy making.

title: CHARLES VAURIE, BIRD EXPERT, DIES
description: Dr. Charles Vaurie, curator emeritus of the department of ornithology at the American Museum of Natural History, died yesterday at his home. He was 68 years old and lived in Readine. Pa.

title: TwoYear Notes Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The Treasury sold today $2billion of twoyear notes for an average return of 6.86 per cent. The Treasury received lenders for lion and awarded $100million of noncompetitive tenders at the average price of 99.794.

title: Morgenthau Will Investigate Children's Center
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday that he planned to investigate conditions at the Children's Center that prompted the suspension of an employe there for allegedly having sexual relations with an adolescent Girl resident.

title: Stans Fined $5,000 in Campaign Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Former Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans was fined total of $5,000 by a Federal district judge today for five admitted misdemeanor violations of Federal campaign laws in Richard M. Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: WHEAT AND CORN DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Wheat and corn prices declined yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, following sonic supply fundamentals, rather than news of the Cambodian crisis. Commodity prices often rise on news of a possible war.

title: COUNCIL TO HOLD POLICE HEARINGS
description: Disturbed by reports of breakdowns in police administration and poor morale, the chairman of the City Council's Committee on Public Safety announced yesterday that hearings would be held soon on the operations of New York's 30,000member Police Department.

title: Advertising
description: The stockholders of the J. Walter Thompson Company found out yesterday just how busy Don Johnston has been since he took over as president and chief executive last August.

title: Bell Testing a HighDensity Phone System
description: In the hills of western New Jersey, the Bell System is conducting largescale tests of a new, underground, long  distance transmission system that may become a major means of carrying highdensity telephone traffic among the cities of the East Coast megalopolis in the ninetieseighties.

title: EDITOR HIT BY A ROD IN POOR CONDITION
description: Kenneth Douglas, a 64yearold freelance writer, editor and translator, was reported yesterday as still in critical condition at Lenox Hill Hospital after having been struck in the head by a falling curtain rod while walking past a building at 419 East 73d Street Tuesday afternoon.

title: Hunter Of Yanks Wins, 43
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 14 Catfish Hunter, the only pitcher who has won a game for the New York Yankees in two weeks, won another one tonight when he stopped the California Angels in 10 untidy innings, 43.

title: Ali's Show Is a Treat for the People
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 14In the neon dazzle of The Strip, the garish marquees testify to this fortress of show business. Paul Anka is here now. So are Debbie Reynolds, the Smothers Brothers, Phyllis Diller, Olivia NewtonJohn and Charley Rich, and between the pink velvet drapes that frame the stage of the Tropicana Hotel showroom where the girls of the Folies Bergere strut their stuff in the evening, Muhammad All has been putting together his act. He will defend his world heavyweight championship against Ron Lyle on Friday night in a presentation that appears to he choreographed more for act than action. The oddsmakers agree.

title: Land Use and Landmarks
description: Other actions are needed. Revision of the present complex methods of making landuse decisions, a matter basic to intelligent planning, should be part of City Charter reform. There is an equal need for sweeping changes in the city's building bureaucracies, where the best plans are frustrated by gelatinous delays and persistent payoffs.

title: STATE POLICE HEAD RESIGNING JUNE 25
description: ALBANY, May 14The Superintendent of the State Police, William E. Kirwan, sent notice to his 3,000 troopers today that he would resign June 25 after 39 years of service.

title: The Pragmatic Jagger: Planning Stones' Onslaught
description: Upon stage, Mick Jagger has perfected a dynamic, mercurial image that has proved almost irresistible to rock fans for more than a decade.

title: U.S. Loan Guarantee to Enable Rehiring at Navy Yard
description: The Ford Administration announced yesterday a $40million Federal loan guarantee that will enable work to resume and most of 3,000 laidoff workers to be rehired, in the construction of two supertankers at the old Brcoklyn Navy Yard.

title: Gov. Brown, as Predicted, Is Taking Political Risks
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 14After five months as Governor of California, Edmund G. Brown Jr. has begun to focus the power of his office to take political risks in directions that he forecast in campaign speeches last year.

title: HOSPITALS TERM PATIENTS SPOILED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 (UPI)Spokesmen for hospitals halfemptied during the twoweekold doctors' strike here conceded today that the absence of potential patients indicated that Americans were spoiled by unnecessary hospitalization in the past.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Superior Court Judge George V. Schock in Trenton ordered the Byrne administration to explain in court why a permanent director of the State Division on Women had not been appointed. He set May 28 for a hearing. The judge was acting on a suit filed by the National Organization for Women seeking to force Governor Byrne to make the appointment.

title: Warriors Advance To Final
People and Business
description: The deficit in the United States balance of payments registered for the second half of 1974 is expected to be replaced in the first half of this year by a modest surplus, measured at an annual rate, Jack F. Bennett, Under Secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs, said yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: Frank Sinatra won libel damages of $2,400 and another $2,400 in costs and an apology from the British Broadcasting Corporation for a 1972 news program that suggested the singer had connections with the Mafia. The program discusied the possibility that Mr. Sinatra had done favors for organized crime figures in return for influence that got him his Oscarwinning 1953 role in From Here to Eternity. Mr. Sinatra, in London for two concerts May 2829, was not in court.

title: Gwen Davis Wemple Has Nuptials
description: Owen Davis Wemple and William David Robertson, both of Short Hills, N. J., were married there yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Reynolds, friends of the couple. Judge Richard B. McGlynn of the Essex County Court performed the ceremony.

title: WarCrossed Lovers Reunite on Guam as Refugee Weds ExG.I.
description: ASAN, Guam, May 14The massive South Vietnamese refugee effort here has had its first wedding.

title: People in Sports
description: Babe Parilli, head coach of the Charlotte Hornet team that started the first World Football League season last year as the New York Stars, apparently couldn't agree on contract terms with Upton Bell, the club owner. So yesterday; Bell signed Bob Gibson, a former assistant with the Memphis Southmen, to a multiyear pact as head coach.

title: SWIMMING POOL ORDERED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) Over strong opposition from his advisers, President Ford has ordered construction of a swimming pool at the edge of the White House South Lawn near the Oval Office.

title: State of the City: Planning the Future
description: With New York's immediate problems, the long view may seem like a luxury. But the quality of the city's future depends greatly on the quality of its planning. Today planning means hard decisions about policy and goals; it is a determination of the city's optimum destiny based on its assets and liabilities.

title: Albany Accord Sought on Malpractice
description: ALBANY, May 14After two weeks of languishing over the medical malpractice problem to let pressure build for a settlement, the Legislature and Governor Carey's office held private negotiations today in search of a compromise.

title: NO CREW ABOARD
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 15The White House announced last night that United States marines had freed by force the American merchant vessel seized by Cambodian gunboats on Monday and had landed on a nearby island in attempt to find the American crew.

title: Islanders' Disappointment: Roar of Crowd Too Faint
description: After a long, rainy drive up the New Jersey Turnpike, at about 3 o'clock yesterday morning a chartered bus deposited 20 tired and slightly tipsy hockey players in the empty parking lot outside the Nassau Coliseum. Only the muggy and silent spring night greeted them.

title: Corporate Profile
description: As the nation's largest independent refiner and marketer of petroleum products, Ashland Oil, Inc., has long had to tread gingerly amid the industry giants who have vast sources of crude oil.

title: Mirrors Will Sheathe Times Square Tower
description: Times Square's Allied Chemical Tower will be sheathed from top to bottom in oneway mirrors, grow four stories taller and take on a new primslike shape under a $10million renovation plan announced yesterday by Alex M. Parker, its latest owner.

title: Martin Goes to Bangkok After 8 Days in Philippines
description: MANILA, May 14 (UPI)Graham A. Martin, the former United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, left for Bangkok late yesterday after an eightday stay in the Philippines, American Embassy sources reported today.

title: Senate Votes to Outlaw Pyramid Sales Frauds
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)The Senate today passed a bill to outlaw fraudulent pyramid sales schemes.

title: Beame Finds the State an Uncertain Financial Ally
description: ALBANY, May 14Trouble is supposed to come in threes, and Mayor Beame, already plagued first by a budget gap and then by a massive cash flow drought, this week came face to face with a third problemthe state's own financial picture is extremely unsettled, with no prospect of early resolution.

title: Carey and Mayor Express Anger
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame reacted angrily last night to President Ford's rejection of Federal assistance to New York City, with the Governor declaring that we didn't even get 30 nieces of silver.

title: With Allen Back, Phils Win
description: Dick Allen, back with the Philadelphia Phillies, played his first baseball game of the season last night. He played it in the city where it all began for him 12 years and five trades ago and of which he once said, I'm so glad to he out of heresix years in this town is enough for anybody.

title: Music
description: A music reviewer who has been at his trade for any considerable length of time comes to live in hopes of being surprised. Routine, even routine excellence wears flat spots in the brain, like water dripping on a stone. One of the season's pleasanter surprises then, came at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night when Berenice LipsonGruzen, a comparatively unknown New Yorkborn pianist, played a recital of such musical authority, poise and grace that one could only wonder where she has been hiding and why.

title: Amex Prices Show Mixed Tone; OTC Gains in Active Trading
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday in slightly decreasing trading as those in the overthecounter market rose in steppedup activity.

title: World Team Tennis
description: TUESDAY NIGHT'S MATCH

title: 80% of 369 Fire Violations Cured in the Public Schools
description: City Councilman Howard Golden said yesterday that 80 per cent of the 369 fire violations that existed five months ago in the city's 976 public schools had been cured.

title: $2Million in Heroin Seized MAROUETTE, Mich., May 14
description: (AP)  Two million minus worth of heroin was confiscated early today and two men were arrested in an Upper Peninsula raid that ended four months of investigation, the State Police report. The two who were arrested were identified as Myron Matczyszyn, a maintenance crew chief at K.I., Sawyer Air Force Base, and Bruce Scrughold, 22, of Marquette, a student at the Marquette skill center.

title: Ford Waited 11 Hours to Give News of Attack on Patrol Boats
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) President Ford waited at least 11 hours before informing the American people today that United States warplhanes had attacked Cambodian boats.

title: Saigon Terms Unemployment Its Major Challenge
description: How to deal with unemployment in South Vietnam was described by the Saigon radio yesterday as the most difficult task facing the Provisional Revolutionary Government.

title: W.F.L. Club Talks With Namath Aide
description: CHICAGO, May 15 (UPI)Joe Namath's agent, Jimmy Walsh, conferred today with Gene Pulland major stockholder of the new Chicago franchise in the World Football League, presumably negotiating for the star quarterback of the New York Jets to join the W.F.L. team.

title: BIG NUCLEAR TEST IS HELD IN NEVADA
description: MERCURY, Nev., May 14 (AP)The largest underground nuclear test announced in nearly two years was conducted today at the Nevada Test Site, jarring the desert over a radius of 100 miles.

title: New Post for Executive Set
description: Blake T. Newton Jr., president of the Institute of Iife Insurance, was elected yesterday president also of the American Life Insurance Association, effective June 1, when the current president of A.L.I.A., W. Lee Shield, retires. Member companies of the two associations have voted to consolidate into a single new association to be known as the American Council of Life Insurance.

title: Market Place
description: Wall Street's rising costs have led to higher commissions, fewer stock analysts and fewer research reports for the small customer.

title: The Screen: Crime and Punishment
Poverty Aide Charged With Larceny
description: A Lower East Side poverty agency official, a current member of the District 1 school Iboard, was arrested yesterday and charged with misappropriating a $15,000 foundation grant that had been given to the board. The money, according to authorities, was believed to have been used to pay his gambling debts.

title: Former Miss New Jersey Is Hired by the Governor
description: TRENTON, May 14 (AP). A former Miss New Jersey has been hired by Governor Byrne to help arrange his schedule.

title: Democratic Party Telethon Is Set for ABCTV July 26
description: The Democratic party's fourth annual fundraising telethon has been scheduled for the weekend of July 26 as a 20 hour presentation on ABCTV. Entitled Tune In America, it will originate in Los Angeles and will be produced by Eric Lieber, who also produced the party's 1973 and 1974 telethons.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MASTER HAND Private and professional papers of D. W. Griffith go on display today through June 29 as complement to the second, major portion of the retrospective screening of the director's movies now at the Museum of Modern Art. The artifacts, selected from the museum's vast store of Griffith memorabilia, are being shown publicly for the first time because of their fragility.

title: A Narcotics Kingpin Gets 2dYear Term In Drugs Theft Case
description: A 20year prison sentence was imposed yesterday on Vincent Papa, a major narcotics dealer who had been arrested in a car with almost $1million in cash and who had been convicted of possessing 160 pounds of heroin.

title: Hearings on Nursing Homes Resume in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, May 14Samuel Jacobs, administrator of the Royal Crest. Nursing Home in Meriden, said today he thought it unnecessary to inform the police last December when patient at the home died three days after he was beaten by another patient.

title: VIOLENCE IN LAOS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 14AntiAmerican demonstrators ransacked United States mission buildings in the cities of Luang Prabang and Savannakhet today, and embassy officials here said that as a result, the evacuation of Americans scheduled to leave later in the year would begin at once.

title: RALLY CONTINUES FOR MOST BONDS
description: Government securities and corporate bonds, still basking in the glow of an apparent easing of credit conditions by the Federal Reserve, extended their price rally yesterday despite the rising tensions in Cambodia. But it was a different story for New York City's securities, where yields continued to climb amid the deepening financial crisis facing the city.

title: The Recession Increases Racial Tensions in Detroit
description: DETROIT, May 14 Flowers, nice flowers, called the vendor near downtown Detroit's Kennedy Square, where a young man was singing Amazing Grace for an appreciative crowd of lunchbreak loungers relaxing in the warm May sun. At a nearby bus stop, a young black women holding a baby exchanged smiling pleasantries with a young white woman holding a baby.

title: PBW Stock Options Set
description: The PBW Stock Exchange said in Philadelphia yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had approved its plan for stock options trading, which is scheduled to begin at the end of June.

title: Johnson Homers in Japan
description: TOKYO, May 14 (AP)Dave Johnson, former Atlanta Braves infielder, belted a ninthinning home run today to five the Yomiuri Giants a 10 victory over the Yakult Swallows in a Central League game. It was Johnson's third home run since joining the Japanese club recently.

title: City Council Plans Inquiry On Effectiveness of Police
description: Disturbed by reports of breakdowns in police administration and poor morale, the chairman of the City Council's Committee on Public Safety announced yesterday that hearings would be held soon on the operations of New York's 30,000member Police Department.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Jersey Court Backs Repeal Of Port Agency Covenant
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., May 14State Superior Court Judge George B. Gelman upheld today New Jersey's right to repeal a bond covenant that had limited the involvement of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in mass transit.

title: :Stage: Richard III as Manic Gangster
description: NEW HAVENIt is an essential risk for resident theaters across the country to attempt Shakespeare on occasion. It is essential in providing balanced theatrical fare for their audiences, for Shakespeare is the great classic voice of the Englishspeaking theater. It is also risky, because often neither the company nor the theater itself is up to the actual challenge. The Long Wharf Theater has been very successful with Shakespeare in the pastI recall with particular pleasure Stacy Keach's first Hamlet hereand now it has taken on one of Shakespeare's histories, Richard III.

title: Florida Aides Report Widespread Land Fraud Swindle
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 14 (AP)State officials said today that they had uncovered what might be the largest land fraud swindle in the history of the nation, involving thousands of victims and up to $1billion in lost investments.

title: City Will Offer $280Million in Notes
description: After a twomonth absence from a market unreceptive to city securities, the city, through Controller Harrison J. Goldin, announced yesterday a note sale of $280million for Monday.

title: City Breaks Ground for Red Hook Sewage Plant
description: With Mayor Reame presiding. New York officially broke ground yesterday on a $370million sewage treatment project in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, one of the final steps in the city's effort to eliminate all raw sewage discharges from its waterways.

title: Human's Brightest Relative May Be the Pygmy Chimp
description: Deep in the forests of Zaire there lives a littleknown species of 3foottall ape that some scientists believe may displace the chimpanzee as the animal believed to be man's closest living relative.

title: Car Hits Restaurant, Kills 1 and Injures 4
description: A car mounted a sidewalk in Washington Heights yeserday and crashed into rowded Chock Full o' Nuts restaurant, killing a man and njuring four women. The driver said his brakes failed.

title: Repression in South Korea Is Said to Erode Support for President Park
description: SEOUL, South KoreaEvidence from disparate sources here indicates that popular support for President Park Chung Hee has been steadily eroded by his repressive political measures.

title: LYNN KOTTLER
description: Lynn Kottler, director of the Lynn Kottler Art Galleries at 3 Last 65th Street, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 66 years old.

title: Right of Rescue
description: Once established diplomatic procedures had failed to achieve prompt recovery of the seized American merchant ship Mayagez and its crew from Cambodian naval forces, President Ford had no alternative but to employ direct military means to protect American lives and property. This he did with exemplary speed and, according to late reports, with great success though not without casualties. As the President announced last night, all of the crew members as well as the ship itself have now been handed over to American authorities by the Cambodians; and there can be no doubt that the American people as a whole will endorse the limited but effective military action that has led to this welcome result. There will be time and occasion later to examine the many unanswered questions about the whole incident; the immediate point is that no responsible government can tolerate capricious interference with its shipping international waters.

title: O.A.S. DEADLOCKED IN ELECTING CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 The Organization of American States failed in five attempts to elect a new secretary general today.

title: East German Won't Accept Bonn's Protest Over Child
description: BONN, May 14 (Reuters)The West German government protested to East Germany to day over the death of a Turkish child who drowned Sunday in the River Spree in Berlin.

title: Personal Finance
description: When the time comes to pay the annual premium on a homeowner's insurance policy, hundreds of dollars are frequently due in a single payment. Individuals who buy separate fire, theft and liability policies are also likely to he overwhelmed by a large premium payment.

title: JUSTICE POST LIKELY FOR EXBUCKLEY AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Justice Department and Conge Congressional sources said today that Michael M. Uhlmann, a former legislative aide to Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, is expected to be named soon as Assistant Attorney General for legislative affairs, the Justice Department's Congressional liaison.

title: U.S. AND U.N. SAID TO HINDER WOMEN
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) The United Nations, the United States Government, and Congress were called hypocritical today for espousing women's rights but not clearing blockages that prevent those rights from being enjoyed.

title: The Real Victory
description: French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing's decision to turn France toward the future instead of the past by abandoning further celebrations of the World War II victory over Germanyand commemorating the first tangible step toward postwar European union insteadhas aroused angry criticism from political right and left. But history is likely to vindicate him.

title: Barbarous Piracy
description: The diplomacy of violence: That is still, then, to be our trademark. Once again an American Government shows that the only way it knows how to deal with frustration is by force. And the world is presumably meant to be impressed.

title: U.S. FREES CAMBODIANHELD SHIP AND CREW; MARINES STORM ISLAND, SUFFER CASUALTIES; PLANES HIT AIRFIELD, SINK 3 PATROL BOATS
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 15U.S. forces have recaptured the American merchant vessel Mayagez, which the Cambodian Communists seized Monday, President Ford announced early today.

title: Gromyko Chides Kissinger on Large Defense Budget
description: MOSCOW, May 14Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today rebuked Secretary of State Kissinger for having defended an increased American military budget while at the same time advocating the relaxation of tension between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Sadat to Ask U.S. Aid to Pay Soviet Debt
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. May 14President Anwar elSadat said in an interview published today that he would seek financial aid from the United States to settle Egypt's large debts to the Soviet Union.

title: NOMINEE RESIGNS FROM LEGAL POST
description: WASHINGTON, May 14One of President Ford's choices for the Legal Services Corporation withdrew under fire today, and a second came under criticism as Senate confirmation hearings on the longdelayed nominations opened.

title: Anaconda to Discontinue PaperInsulated Cable Unit
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 14 (UPI)  The Anaconda Company's wire and cable division is discontinuing its paperinsulated power cable business and permanently closing its HastingsonHudson, N.Y., manufacturing plant, which has produced cable since the early 1890's.

title: Both Vietnams in W.H.O.
description: GENEVA, May 14The Communist Governments of both North and South Vietnam were represented today as member states of a specialized United Nations agency.

title: Article 4  No Title
Human's Brightest Relative May Be the Pygmy Chimp
description: Deep in the forests of Zaire there lives a littleknown species of 3foottall ape that some scientists believe may displace the chimpanzee as the animal believed to be man's closest living relative.

title: Brazil Quintet Routs U.S.
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 14 (UPI)  Brazil defeated a team of American junior college allstars, 8564, last night and won the International Basketball Tournament of Rio de Janeiro The United States trailed, 4331, at intermission as it completed the final segment of the roundrobin tournament without a victory.

title: Tomahawks Down Arrows, 23 to 12
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., May 14 Charlie Henderson scored five goals and registered three assists to lead the Long Island Tomahawks to a 2312 victory over the Maryland Arrows in a National Lacrosse League game tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Boulez to Leave Philharmonic in '77
description: Pierre Boulez will not return as music director of the New York Philharmonic afier his contract expirer at the end of the 197677 season. He is leaving on his own volition. Recently he was appointed director of the Institut de Recherche et de Coordination Acoustique/Mesique in Paris. The institute will concern itself with avantgarde phenomena, including electronic music, and that is a field close to the conductor's heart.

title: CAMBODIAN DRIVE ON VICE REPORTED
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 14 (Reuters)  Cambodia's new rulers are destroying nightclubs and gambling dens in Battambang, the nation's second largest city, as part of a campaign to assert authentic Cambodian culture, the Phnom Penh radio said today.

title: Article 1  No Title
Contract Awards
description: Gould, Inc., received a $75.5million Navy contract for Mark 48 torpedoes.

title: Bridge:
description: In certain crucial areas of play, mathematics and psychology may become confused, and thereby confusing. A practical player may follow a line of reasoning that is clearly fallacious by mathematical standards, but difficult to refute, especially when it succeeds.

title: SCHOOL PROTEST EBBS IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, May 14 (UPI)A fiveday class boycott to protest the layoff of 900 teachers appeared to be winding down today, although student absence rates remained high in the industrialized Ironbound section of Newark.

title: Schmidt's Beer Chosen Over Coors by Newsmen
description: Schmidt's Beer, brewed in Philadelphia and marketed in the Northeast, has found a way of edging in on the mystique of Coors Beer, which is brewed in Golden, Colo., and marketed in the West. It seems that six intrepid Philadelphia journalists did a blindfold taste test to help a food editor write a Sunday supplement article in March. Schmidt's beat Coors 51 to 30.

title: Marcia Abad Wed To Thomas M. Lee
description: Marcia T. Abad and Thomas M. Lee, students at Tulane University, were married yesterday morning by the Rev. Jack White of the Dutch Reform Church of St. Thomas, Virgin Islands. The ceremony was performed at the Secret Harbour Beach Hotel in St. Thomas.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Indochina

title: Carey and Mayor Express Anger
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame reacted angrily last night to President Ford's rejection of Federal assistance to New York City, with the Governor declaring that we didn't even get 30 pieces of silver.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Alice Crimmins, who was found guilty of manslaughter in the death of her 4yearold daughter, Alice Marie, won the right yesterday to challenge in the Court of Appeals court order that had denied her a hearing on a new trial.

title: May 110 Car Sales Show 20.8% Drop
description: DETROIT, May 14Newcar sales for May 110 were off 20.8 per cent from last year ands were also slightly below the same period in April. There was still no sign of a spring upturn and the May performance was the worst for the period in 17 years, industry statistics showed today.

title: Gloucester Code of Ethics Held Popular With Public
description: McAFEE, May 14Gloucester County's new code of ethics for Freeholders has helped restore public confidence in government, Donald H. Wagner, director of the Gloucester County Board of Freeholders, said today.

title: Article 2  No Title
Governor Gets a Bill Allowing Police to Take Part in Politics
description: ALBANY, May 15Police officers and commissioners could become active in politics under a bill that received final passage in the Assembly today and was sent to the Governor for his signature.

title: Accord to Resolve Malpractice Issue Reached in Albany
description: ALBANY, May 15Governor Carey and legislative leaders of both parties announced today that they had reached agreement on legislation designed to resolve the medical malpractice crisis facing physicians and hospitals in the state as a result of a decision by the major insurer to stop offering such coverage after June 30.

title: People in Sports
description: Deacon Jones, called by George Allen, who coached him in Los Angeles and Washington, the greatest defensive end in modern football, officially announced his retirement from the Redskins yesterday. Jones, acquired from Sana Diego last season but used only sparingly, said he would devote full time to a chain of hospitals in southern California where he is working in community and public affairs. In his 14year National Football League career, Jones, onefourth of the Rams' fearsome foursome, played in the Pro Bowl eight times and was named N.F.L. player of the year in 1967 and 1968. Allen said he would make an

title: COPTERS EVACUATE U.S. MARINES AND SHIPRESCUE MISSION ENDS; TOLL INCLUDES ONE KNOWN DEAD
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 Under the cover of aerial and naval gunfire, 200 marines were lifted by helicopters today off an island in the Gulf of Siam, completing the military rescue of an American merchant ship and crew that had been seized by Cambodian forces.

title: Ford Note to Gov. Thomson Hails Day in New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N.H., May 15 (AP) Gov. Meldrim Thomson has released a letter he received from President Ford thanking the Governor for his welcome in New Hampshire on April 18.

title: Officer Linked to Narcotics Ring Is Indicted on 4 Drug Counts
description: A policeman who allegedly helped a major drug ring distribute large quantities of heroin and cocaine by offering protection was indicted yesterday on charges of possessing, selling and distributing drugs from 1969 to 1972.

title: Recipients of Social Security Will Get 8% Rise in July Checks
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) An 8 per cent increase in benefits for 35 million Social Security and Supplemental Income recipients was announced today by Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: Advertising
description: There was a reason, of course, that Peter G. Diamandis, the 43yearold former publisher of Mademoiselle, was sitting in the office of Martin H. Landey, chairman and president of Martin Landey, Arlow Advertising, yesterday morning. But it didn't come out for a while.

title: Beame and Carey
description: Following is the text of the joint statement issued by Governor Carey and Mayor Beame:

title: Final Attempt to Enact Jersey Income Tax Fails
description: TRENTON, May 15A final attempt to enact a modest state income tax for New Jersey was abandoned in the State Senate this evening, raising the prospect of a major fiscal crisis for the Byrne administration.

title: New Museum in Tucson Focuses on Photography
description: TUCSON, Ariz., May 15A major national museum devoted to the professional work and personal papers of prominent photographers opened today at the University of Arizona here.

title: Article 4  No Title
Two in Helicopter Are Killed Monitoring Student Clash
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, May 15 (UPI)A helicopter circling an area containing feuding students from different schools crashed yesterday on a residential street killing a policeman and a wildlife official.

title: Barenboim Is Fervent in Elgar's First
description: One or two works aside, Edward Elgar has never stood high with American concertgoers. During the 192050 period, the high water of antiromanticism, he was considered, at best, a derivative composer who reflected Edward and Empire. But musicians exposed to his music are apt to take it with more respect. When William Steinberg was working in England, he heard and studied the Elgar orchestral works and was impressed enough to bring them back to Pittsburgh. Much the same thing happened to Georg Solti in Chicago.

title: PRIEST'S TRIAL ENDS; VERDICT DUE LATER
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 15An ecclesiastical court of the Episcopal Church today finished hearing evidence against the Rev. L. Peter Beebe, who was accused of permitting women whose, ordination violated church regulations to celebrate communion in his church.

title: Hearst Book Held Likely
description: SAN ANGELO, Tex., May 15 (AP)The Rev. Cecil Williams, the pastor of a San Francisco church, said here today that he thought Patricia Hearst is writing a book and will come back from the underground when she has it complete. Mr. Williams, who was here to address the Lions Club, acted as a gobetween for the police in their investigation of the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army, a terrorist group that the daughter of Randolph Hearst, editor and publisher of The San Francisco Examiner, has allegedly joined.

title: 2 Nickel Companies In Consent to Stop Tiein Sales Deals
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI) The Justice Department filed today proposed consent judgments that would require two of the nations' largest distributors of nickel to the electroplating industry to stop their alleged tiein sales practices.

title: 3 Added to List of Those Honored at Columbia Rites
description: Honorary degrees of Doctor of Letters were awarded at Columbia University Wednesday to three men whose names were not included in yesterday's story about the commencement exercises.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: BLOSSBURG, Pa.In the Northeast, turkey and trout country often blend together, and this happy coincidence adds a dimension to the hunter's endeavors.

title: Royals Set Back Red Sox, 30; 2d Straight Shutout for Busby
description: Steve Busby was lucky; Luis Tiant wasn't. The result was a 30 victory for the Kansas City Royals over the Red Sox in Boston's Fenway Park last night before 10,200 fans.

title: SOVIET WITHHOLDS COMMENT ON RAID
description: MOSCOW, May 15The Soviet Union withheld comment today on the American military operation that freed the freighter Mayagez and 39 crewmen seized by the Cambodians.

title: 14 SCHOULS LISTED FOR FALL CLOSING
description: The Board of Education has earmarked 14 underutilized or unneeded city schools for closing next fall in line with its current effort to cut operating costs and improve school utilization.

title: DOLLAR MAKES GAIN IN EUROPE TRADING
description: BRUSSELS, May 15 (UPI)The dollar made considerable gains and closed at its best rates in a week on most European money markets today.

title: College, School Results
description: BASEBALL

title: Twas A Famous Victory
description: WASHINGTON, May 15This town hasn't had anything to cheer about since the Washington Bullets won the Eastern pro basketball championship, so it is cheering President Ford and the rescue of the Mayagez and her crew as if this were a famous victory.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Fast Appeal Sought on Voiding of Pact Limiting Port Unit's MassTransit Aid
description: MORRISTOWN, May 15The United States Trust Company filed today a request for an immediate appeal to the Supreme Court of a lowercourt ruling upholding the state's repeal of a Port Authority bond covenant.

title: Kennedy, at the U.N., Asserts U.S. Policy On Third World Lags
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 15Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the United States was lagging far behind European industrial countries and Japan in appreciating the new demands and the new promise of the developing countries.

title: A Field of 10 for Preakness
