title: Ramapo Schedules a Poetry Festival
description: MAHWAHMany of America's leading poets are expected to attend the first Ramapo Poetry Festival, which will be held at Ramapo College for three days, beginning June 12.

title: Ombudsman, Of Nassau Wears Many Hats
description: IVIINEOLAThe Commissioner of Accounts in Nassau County. Benedict P. Ciaravino, and his small, busy staff wear a lot of different bureaucratic hats, but they are never certain which ones each day will require.

title: W. Germany Leads, 21, In Davis Cup
description: BERLIN, May 17 (AP) Jurgen Fassbender and HansJurgen Pohmann defeated Rolf Norberg and Ove Bengtson in doubles, 61, 63, 62, giving West Germany a 21 lead over Sweden in the European Zone A Davis Cup tennis quarterfinals today.

title: Nebraska City Papers Sold
description: NEBRASKA CITY, Neb., May 17 (AP)The Nebraska City NewsPress, oldest daily newspaper in the state, was purchased Thursday by Roy H. Park of Ithaca. N. Y., the owner of five other newspapers, seven television stations, seven AM radio stations and five FM stations.

title: Book Ends
description: Pop Psy. The Best Seller List has had a psychological selfhelp bool in residency for fourh weeks now, so all's right with the world again, The book is When I Say No, I Feel Guilty by Manuel J. Smith Ph.D., and people who coddle their psyches will know what we're talking about when we say it concerns Assertiveness Trainingor Systematic Assertiveness Training as Dr. Smith distinguishes his school. Assertiveness Training has been around for years, but is currently enjoying an upsurge. In a nutshell, Assertiveness Training teaches how to keep people from manipulating you into doing what you don't want to door is it not doing what you do want to do?

title: Claudia Neale Has Nuptials
description: Claudia Neale, daughter or Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Neale of Mount Kisco, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Jeffrey Brodlieb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Brodlieb of Hewlett Neck, L. I.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: It is exactly 10 years since Bridget Riley had her first show in New York Op Art was the hot thing in 1965 with the Responsive Eye exhibition twisting all our eyeballs at the Museum of Modern Art and the auxiliary effects of it to be seen all over the placein advertising, in upholstery, in dress design. Bridget Rileys connection with Op Art was no more than coincidental; inherent in Op Art was an element of vacuous teasing that was the exact opposite of what she aimed to achieve. But there were superficial points of likeness, and those points of likeness got seized upon, and altogether the experience was not a happy one for her. She showed a second time (again with Richard Feigen) in 1967; but when that particular association came to an end she was in no hurry to show again. Nearly a decade went by in fact before she took up an invitation from Sidney Janis and brought over the show of paintings and drawings that is now on view (through May 31) at 6 West 57th Street.

title: Edward VIII
description: Edward VIII, Duke of Windsor, had a lifetime that consisted of one event. He Abdicated. It was the only tning of importance that ever happened to him. Up to the Ahd:cation, he led a Prince Charming existence of endless adolescence. After it, he began an immensely protracted retirement. But for one instant he was caught in the lens of history, in a posture of romantic folly. This brief climacteric has been written about to the point of satiety. Does anything remain to be said? Surprisingly, quite a lot. Indeed, Frances Donaldson has done much more than cast new light on Edward's brief reign. She has written a proper biography.

title: The World
description: Egyptian President Anwar elSadat has been touring Arab capitals, apparently to establish Arab unity in support of the positions he will take in his meeting with President Ford next month.

title: Letters: Sharing Schwindelheimiana
description: To the Editor:

title: Museum Built by Teacher
description: LEVITTOWN  At first school, officials were prepared to burn the building down. Later they predicted that vandals would tear it down. But Casimir Cetna?? kept building.

title: Johnny May
description: If it weren't for that abortive session with Blue Beardher oldmaid aunts, aged 19 and 22, confiscated the hook before she could finishJohnny May would never have suspected Mr. Berry of being a wifekiller. (His four wives have all died or vanished mysteriously ) Now that he's fixing to make Aunt Irene number five, Johnny May has no choice but to unmask him for the murdering varmint he is Trouble is, Aunt Irene is resisting salvation, and Mr. Berry himself keeps confusing the issue by such sneaky redherring tactics as warning Johnny May to watch out for a certain treacherous high place and snatching her, halfdrowned, out of rampaging Big Creek.

title: Catholic School Chief Quits
description: MANCHESTER, N. H, May 17 (AP)The Rev. Joseph Duffy. Superintendent of New Hampshire's Roman Catholics parochial schools, has resigned effective July 1, the state din?? said today Father Duffy said he had resigned for personal and professional reasons.

title: A New Display Garden For Rhododendrons
description: A recently announced agreement between industry and a foundation sets an historic precedent for industrial support of horticulture in America. The Weyerhaeuser Company, a nationallyknown producer of lumber and related products, and the Rhododendron Species Foundation of Salem, Ore., have agreed to dedicate 24 acres of valuable wooded land adjoining the lumber company's offices near Tacoma, Wash. to a display garden for rhododendron species and to provide facilities for its support.

title: Dietz Lowers Rowing Record
description: PLLHAM MANOR, N Y May 17Jim Dietz of the New York A C broke the course record by five seconds today on the Orchard Beach Lagoon in the elite singles. Dr Larry Klecatcky also was under the record, three and one half seconds slower than Dietz and finished second

title: Offshore Recession
description: WASHINGTONMayor Abe Beame of New York will take little comfort in it, but he's not the only government leader who's strapped for cash and getting little help from Washington. Gov. Rafael Hernandes Colon of Puerto Rico was here this week, describing conditions in the island commonwealth that in some ways make New York look welloff.

title: Five Nations Listed For Ledyard Trials
description: Riders from five countries, including members of the United States Equestrian Team's world championship squad, are expected to enter the Ledyard horse trials June 26 through 29. The trials became an international event only two years ago and in that short span have developed into the most important threeday competition in the United States. They will be held at the Myopia Hunt Club in Hamilton, Mass.

title: U.S. Suit Charges $4.3Million Fraud In Mission in Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) The Federal Government has filed suit in Hong Kong in an effort to recover $4.3million in United States military aid allegedly taken out of Saigon in an embezzlement scheme.

title: I.L.G.W.U. MARKING UNION'S 75TH YEAR
description: The International Ladies Garment Workers Union is celebrating the 75th anniversary of its founding with a series of events spread over several weeks.

title: Year of the United States
description: PARISIn vanished days when we were given to proclaiming basic policy intentions, 1973 was dubbed by Washington as its Year of Europe, meaning that American diplomacy intended to focus on that vital area. This idea was never more than a propaganda blast. The year wound up in the silence of an energy famine and intraallied throatcutting.

title: Bolivians View Gulf Oil as Maligning a Dead Hero
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 17Popular resentment against the Gulf Oil Corporation has mushroomed in Bolivia after the company listed a dead national hero as the main recipient of political contributions to protect its investments here.

title: SOUL CITY PAYMENT IS CALLED EXCESSIVE
description: RALEIGH, N.C., May 17 (AP) Federal auditors have found that the United States Comtierce Department paid a nowdefunct New York advertising concern more than to times what it should have been paid under a contract to promote. Soul City, N.C., The News and Observer of Raleigh reports in its Sunday editions.

title: Pimlico Scene a Swirling Blend of Revelry
description: BALTIMORE, May 17From Willie Graves and Mary Pat Dignan to the National Guard, the people were as ready as the horses today for the 100th running of the Preakness.

title: Bergenfield Is Planning A Friendly Celebration
description: BERGENFIELDThis 81yearold Bergen County borough has taken the lead from its motto, The Friendly Town, to launch Operation Friendly, a Bicentennial project in which Bergenfield residents are being asked to reestablish links with relatives in the lands that contributed to the building of America.

title: Master Derby, $48.80, Wins Preakness, With Foolish Pleasure 2d
description: BALTIMORE, May 17Fighting off a closing bid by the heavily backed favorite, Mrs. Robert Lehmann's Master Derby scored an upset victory today in the $216,600 Preakness Stakes.

title: Baker Led Senate In Speaking Fees With $49,150 in '74
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, earned $49,150 last year in speaking fees from private organizations, more than any other Senator, Senate reports have shown.

title: G.O.P. Bill Will Offer City A Loan Tied to Budget Cut
description: ALBANY, May 17The Republican leadership of the State Senate, which Thursday rejected Mayor Beame's plea for new taxing powers and direct state aid, will introduce a bill Monday to authorize a $1billion, 90day state loan to the city conditioned on $640million in cuts from the Mayor's proposed budget.

title: The prisoner's confession was a verboballistic invention
description: On June 3, 1835, a 20yearold Normandy peasant named Pierre Rivire went to his mother's house and murdered her with a pruning book; he then killed his sister and a little brother with the same weapon. Leaving the house, he told a neighbor, I have just delivered my father from all his tribulations. I know that they will put me to death, but no matter.

title: A Cheap East Side Coop
description: Mention the word coop in New York City and most people see visions of some fancy $100,000plus pad on Park Avenue that they'll never be able to afford. As they see it, coops are for bankers, doctors, nursinghome operators, oil company presidents and Walt Frazier.

title: Al Helfer, Announcer, Is Dead; Covered the Dodgers and Giants
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 17 (AP)Al Helfer, for decades one of the country's bestknown baseball broadcasters, died here yesterday of cancer in a hospital. His age was 63.

title: BECKWITH GUILTY ON BOMB CHARGE
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 17 (UPI)A jury convicted Byron De La Beckwith last night of transporting a dynamite bomb to New Orleans without a permit two years ago.

title: Books: Options, the Hottest Game in Town
description: The growing herd of option traders may still sound somewhat less than thundering, but early rumbles are being heard from the financial publishers, bookstores and advisory services which sense a stampede.

title: Middleburg Wins In Jersey Show
description: READINGTON, N. J., May 17Mr. and Mrs King Harris's Middleburg scored all his points in the first two classes and coasted to the noviceopen jumper championship today at the Four Seasons horse show

title: Florence Frederick Macy Wed To John Thomas Stickney Jr.
description: Florence Frederick Macy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Macy of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., and Marbella, Spain, was married in Oyster Bay, L.I., yesterday afternoon to John Thomas Stickney Jr. He is the son of Mr. Stickney of Summit, N.J., and Mrs. Douglas Thayer of Columbus, Ohio.

title: Mayaguez Captain Tells Story of Rescue
description: SINGAPORE, May 17The captain of the Mayagez, the American freighter that was released by the Cambodians Thursday in the midst of a United States air, sea and land assault, said today that he and his crew were aboard a fishing boat that was strafed and teargassed by American planes.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: In the immensely popular and widely diversified field of nature photography, one of the most accessible and rewarding areas is the photographing of flowers in spring bloom.

title: SOVIET WARSHIPS END BOSTON VISIT
description: BOSTON, May 17 (AP)Hundreds of Bostonians jammed Commonwealth Pier to wave goodbye as two Soviet warships pulled away at noon today, ending a fiveday goodwill visit.

title: Correction
description: A story on nuclear wastes in the Week in Review of May 11 erroneously stated that the radioactive elements of cesium and strontium remain lethal for ten of thousands of years. In fact, the correct figure is 700 years; it is rather the presence of longerlived elements such as curium and americium that make the waste dangerous for many thousands of years.

title: F. A. Shea 3d Weds Barbara Krussman
description: Barbara Marie Therese Krussman, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Louis F Krussman of Harrison was married last evening to Frank A. Shea 3d. son of Mr. and Mrs Shea Jr. of Rye, N Y Msgr. Vincent J Lonegran performed the ceremony in the chapel of Manhattanville College in Purchase, N Y. He was assisted by Msgr Charles D. Fitzgerald.

title: The Region
description: One of the ways in which elderly indigent persons have been put away in New York nursing homes was described at Moreland Commission hearings last week: A headhunter was paid by 12 private, or profitmaking, nursing homes to recruit patients front hospitals.

title: WHO OWNS 1776?
description: BOSTON. Who controls the past controls the future; who controls the present controls the past, O'Brien tells Winston in George Orwell's 1984. A new battle for control of the American past has begun here in Boston.

title: Goodman Offers a 4Point Plan To Help City With Its Finances
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., May 17A combined program of new taxes, increased state revenue sharing, city economies and expanded sports betting was proposed today by State Senator Roy M. Goodman of Manhattan as the way the city could meet an anticipated $641million deficit in its 197576 fiscal budget.

title: The Nation
description: The decision of the United States Supreme Court forcing Richard Nixon to release his Watergate tapes was limited, in effect decreeing that the courts' access to evidence in a criminal case was more important than his claim to the primacy of confidentiality in Presidential transactions.

title: Koles Have a Daughter
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kole of New York on April 29 in the Klingenstein Pavilion of Mount Sinai Hospital. The child whose father is a member of the singing and dancing duo of Kole and Parham, is named Hilary Meliza.

title: ART VIEW
description: It is a delicate moment in the history of any artist's reputation when the first of his posthumous exhibitions is presented to the public. During an artist's lifetime, we see his work more or less as he intends us to see it. The conditions of exhibitionthe size and location of the gallery or museum space, the tastes and strategies of dealers and museum curatorsinevitably impose certain realities and limitations on the artist's intentions, but the artist nonetheless has his say. Having shaped his work, he also shanes the way we perceive it. History has not vet intervened to revise our understanding, and estate executors are not yet invested with the authority to determine what is to be deemed a finished or an unfinished work. The depredations of posterity are held at bay while the artist governs our experience of what he has wrought

title: Judith McD. Kinnard, a Writer, Is Bride of Christopher Cabot
description: St. Paul's Episcopal Church In Franklin, Tenn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Judith McDowell Kinnard, daughter of Mrs. Claiborne Holmes Kinnard 4th of Franklin and the late Mr. Kinnard, to Christopher Cabot son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Cabot of Beverly Farms, Mass. The Rev. Charles N Fulton performed the ceremony.

title: HONDURAS CHARGES A U.S. SUBSIDIARY
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras. May 17 (AP)Honduras filed criminal charges today against a United Brands Company subsidiary, the Tela Railroad Company, for allegedly bribing a former economy minister with $1 2million to hate a banana export tax reduced An official announcement said that Abraham Bennaton Ramos, the execonomy minister, is also being prosecuted.

title: Fish, Game Agency Assayed
description: TRENTON  Alarmed by the dwindling supplies of fish, shellfish and some species of wildlife in New Jersey, a prominent conservation organization has recommended broad revision and strengthening of the state's fish and gamemanagement programs.

title: The Nation
description: It has now become evident that the secret political slush funds of some major American corporations, disclosed during the Watergate inquiry, were used by them all over the world in a variety of guises but, essentially, in the same way for the same purposes. They were used for bribes, in the common if not legal use of the term, and they were given to public officials and their political parties.

title: Nancy Harrison Bride Of Malcolm D. Bliss
description: The Cochran Chapel at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Nancy Jean Harrison to Malcolm Donald Bliss, both of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George E. Andrews 2d, an Episcopal priest.

title: Quarterhorse Racing Bill Introduced
description: ALBANY, May 17 (UPI)Assemblyman William F. Passannante, Democrat of Manhattan, said today he had introduced a hill that would authorize quarterhorse racing at existing throughhred tracks in the state Although the Legislature has approved quarterhorse racing in the state, no tracks have vet been built. On Thursday, the Assembly gave first approval to a proposal to use state bonds to help finance the construction of such a track in the Albany suburb of Bethlehem. The sport is caught in the starting gate waiting for tracks to he built, Passannante said. Meanwhile, throuoghbred facilities such as Saratoga and Belmont he dormant for most of the sear.

title: Master Derby Wins
description: Master Derby won the 100th running of the Preakness at Pimlico and paid $48.80 for $2. Foolish Pleasure, the 6to5 favorite, ran second and Diabolo third. Details in Section 5.

title: The Hornblower Saga
description: Christopher Morley's only drug was a good long slug of Tincture of Conan Doyle; and a fine drug that is, but there is one other compound of Doylean potency, and one only; it is Elixir of Hornblower. Like Holmes at the opening of The Sign of Four, take it down: lean back; savor it in anticipation; plunge the piston home:

title: The Election Shows a Special Union Strength
description: The strong showing by candidates backed by the teachers' union in New York City's community schoolboard elections has underscored a question basic to the running of the schools: Is there a managementlabor conflict of Interest when the union deals with people it helped put on the boards?

title: Saving Simplified
description: United States Savings Bonds are tailormade for people who find it difficult to save money, especially those who vow to take a little out of each paycheck and save it, but never do. Savings Bonds are easy to buy and are indestruct??ble. Even though the original punched card Savings Bonds, or the earlier paper certificates may have disappeared, the bonds continue to earn interest. Replacement Savings Bonds, which are available, carry the same issue dates as the originals.

title: Best Sellers
description: Mass market paperbacks are sold on ??tands in supermarkets and vari?? stares, as well as bookstores. This analysis is based on reports from rerepsentative ?? and chains with more than 9.000 outlets in the United States.

title: Miss Reburn Wed to Edward Whiting
description: The Kennett Square (Pa.) Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Barbara Jane Reburn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Story Reburn of Kennett Square, to Edward Cox Whiting, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawson M. Whiting of Darien, Conn.

title: TV VIEW
description: Before it even went on the air a few Sundays ago, A Shooting Gallery Called America? had brought several letters of either praise or condemnation to the offices of NBC News. Produced by Lucy Jarvis, the documentary about handguns had been scheduled for early March but was abruptly postponed to April 27. Apparently the letter writers had seen the early advertisements but didn't bother to check their television sets. The ads were enough to trigger automatic res?? to what they were sure the program would say. Providing an insight into the narrowness of lobbying or the limited usefulness of letter counting, the incident has its amusing side.

title: Bayi: Frontrunner's Triumph
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 17Filbert Bayi finally made his point tonight during the International Freedom Games: he could run from the front, win and set a world record in the onemile rice.

title: Margaret Buglass Is Bride in Jersey
description: Margaret Stainton Buglass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie J. Buglass of Tenafly, N. J., was married yesterday to John Powers Sandercock, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert Sandercock of Easton, Pa.

title: Bromley and Finn Reach Tennis Final
description: ARMONK, N. Y., May 17 Peter Bromley toppled Bob Finn defeated Kerth But??field, 62, 67, 61, in the semfinals of the 42d annual Weschester tennis ??ampionships today

title: Intent on Suicide, Man Dies In Fall After Changing Plan
description: PALMYRA, N. Y., May 17 (UPI)A man who had climbed to the top of a 100foot flagpole here today in an apparent suicide attempt fell to his death after he had changed his mind and was being rescued by firemen, sheriff's deputies said.

title: Robin Lazare Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Lazare of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Lazare, to James Lowell, son of Mr. and Mrs Frank Lowell, also of Scarsdale The wedding is planned for next month. The future bridegroom is an associate director with WCVBTV Channel 5 in Needham, Mass.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruges La Mort Is Reborn as Belgium's Living Museum City
description: As the whiterobed priest moved solemnly toward the altar a woman sitting beside me suddenly broke into sobs. Somewhere in the back of the small chapel another woman began wailing, and all around me I could feel the heightened emotion. It was as if the narrow cylindrical capsule the priest held in front of him on a small cushion was the blood of Someone who had died a violent death just this weeknot 2,000 years ago.

title: Refinery Fire in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA May 17 (UPI)  Hundreds of firemen fought a fire at a Gulf Oil Company refinery for more than two hours early today before bringing it under control. Officials said that the fire was triggered by an explosion of undetermined origin shortly before 12:30 A.M. The blaze closed the Penrose Avenue Bridge that spans the Schuylkill River.

title: Mulches Control Weeds And Conserve Moisture
description: Good gardeners should form the habit of using mulches which save labor and conserve water. Emerging weeds perish under these soil coverings. Mulches also slow evaporation of moisture and prevent formation of impervious crusts. Water seeps in more readily.

title: LETTER
description: To the Editor:

title: CHESS
description: If you're trying to avoid passive defense, how far can you go? Loose pawn formations were accepted by Tarrasch half a century ago if he could thereby obtain open lines for his pieces. His younger American contemporary, Frank Marshall, went him one better, habitually offering a pawn for the sake of the initiative; his famous gambit defense to the Ruy Lopez still stands as the model of his approach to strategy.

title: The dance they do to make a movie
description: More than any other art. film making is about power. In the rites of final cut, the dance the moguls and the artists do to determine the way a film will be presented to the world, is where the true power in, commercial moviemaking is sought and found. Understanding that deceptively simple notion is central to understanding Hollywood. The final cut in Daniel Stern's fine resonant novel about power and Hollywood is nominally the ultimate form that Festival a Woodstockian documentary will take. It is also the last blow and cut absorbed by Ezra Marks, a former Kennedy aide who has come to Hollywood armed with demographic skills and what he and Robbie Robinson, his former teacher and current pal, like to call the art of psychoeconomics: a blend of Keynes and Freud.

title: Robinson Ejected; Team Behind, 100
description: CHICAGO, May 17 (AP)Manager Frank Robinson of the Cleveland Indians was elected from tonight's game with the Chicago White Sox for the first time in his 31game managerial career. His team was trailing, 100, at the time.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The nostalgia business is getting biggerand more up to date. Psychedelic rock music from 1965, for example, now qualifies as the real thing in the eyes of buffs, with classics bringing skyhigh prices at record shops.

title: Doctors at Pendleton Act To Bar Refugee Epidemic
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 17Public health and military doctors, satisfied that the sudden influx of Vietnamese refugees posed no public health threat to Americans, are intensifying efforts to treat the personal medical needs of the Vietnamese and to protect them from infections that often become epidemic among people living in crowded, drab conditions.

title: Food
description: Cantonese cooking, developed in the south of China and centered in the provincial capital of Canton, is to the Chinese what French cooking is to the Europeanthe crme de la crme. A Chinese adage even says, If you like to eat good food, go to Canton. The cuisine is a subtle one. It is characterized by an extravagant variety of vegetables, meats and seafoods cooked to retain as much of their natural flavor as possible. (Cantonese chefs excel in stirfrying.) Hot spices are generally forgone, although herbs are used for their nutritive and medicinal values. On this page are recipes for soy sauce chicken, steamed fish with ginger sauce and stirfried beef with broccoli.

title: ORNETTE COLEMAN PLAYS AT FIVE SPOT
description: Ornette Coleman, notable for his harmonic innovations and investigations of freeform jazz in the nineteensixties, is being innovative in a much less controversial fashion during his quintet's current appearance at the Five Spot. Printed programs are distributed before each of the evening's two sets, a welcome step forward in jazzclub procedure.

title: Catholic School Chief Quits
description: MANCHESTER, N. H, May 17 (AP)The Rev. Joseph Duffy, Superintendent of New Hampshire's Roman Catholic parochial schools, has tesigned effective July 1, the stale diocese said today. Father Duffy said he had resigned for personal and professional reasons.

title: We have from the first been singers
description: What we suffer, what we endure, what we muff, what we kill, what we miss, what we are guilty of is done by us, as individuals, in private.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the DaySection 1

title: Are Little Chimps More Interesting Than Big Ones?
description: The chimpanzee, scientists have gen. erally thought, is man's closest living relative. As such, the animal has been studied and studied. But now some of those who specialize in primates suspect that a rarer species of ape, popularly called the pygmy chimp, may be a closer relative still. Systematic investigation of its attributes has just begun.

title: South Korea's Ruling Party Utilizes a Vast Apparatus
description: TOKYO, May 17  Bob R. Dorsey, chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation, may have been technically correct yesterday when he testified before a Congressional committee that the $3million his company gave to South Korea's governing party in 1971 might have won the election for President Park Chung Hee. But politically it is impossible to single out one contribution and say that it made the difference.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: May 21Datsun Owners Clubmeeting at Bob Sharp Motors. Danbury Road. Wilton, Conn., 8 P.M. Information: Peter Slater, phone (203) 5448375 or (203) 4380222 (home).

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on admendment to bill that would establish a consumeradvocacy agency. Amendment would have deleted a section prohibiting intervention by the agency in labor disputes. Rejected, 52 to 36, May 12.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: MAYOR BEAME has raised a provocative question. Rebuffed in his efforts to persuade the Federal Government to bail out New York City, he asks angrily why he is denied equal treatment with the private businesses which have turned to Washington for help In recent yearsand gotten it. The Mayor cites the banks, which the Government has kept afloat, the Penn Central Railroad and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. Why, he asks, should the private sector get help, but not the impoverished masses of the nation's most important city? Does the Ford Administration care more for private profit than it does for the public welfare?

title: Keep Them Running Smoothly
description: Although modern power lawn mowers are more efficient and more dependable than ever before, they still need periodic maintenance and ?? checkups in order to keep them operating properly and cutting smoothly. Failure to maintain the mower's engine and working parts with a regular maintenance program will not only shorten the life of any machine, it will almost certainly also lead to frequent and annoying breakdownsusually just as a weekend is starting, or during the height of the season when service shops are jammed with mowers that won't start, or mowers that are suffering limn carious other ailments brought on by neglect.

title: Navy Yard Rebirth Brings Joy to Area
description: Merchants and restaurant owners on the fringe of the old Brooklyn Navy Yard reacted happily last week to the news that most of the 3.000 workers who had been laid off by the yard's Seatrain Shipbuilding Corporation several months ago would soon be back on the job.

title: Design: The national A.I.A. awards
description: Once again, the American Institute of Architects has bestowed its blessing upon a selected group of buildings, and once again it has indicated that, if it has the caution one generally expects from such professional organizations, it at least also has a pretty good eye. The nine buildings cited by the A.I.A. as its 1975 Honor Awards do not move out in radically new directions, but refine concepts and approaches that have been with us for some years now. They are all visually pleasing; some go deeper than that.

title: Sunday Observer
description: I am sitting here 93 million miles from the sun on a rounded rock which is spinning at the rate of 1,000 miles an hour.

title: What's Doing in the CATSKILLS
description: FOR THE RECORD  For those who think of the Catskills only as large, splashy hotels or teeming bungalow colonies, the record should be set straight. The Catskill Mountains cover about 4,280 square miles in four New York State counties  Sullivan, Ulster, Greene and Delaware. Included in the region is the 232,423acre Catskill Forest Preserve with its magnificent scenery. Because of the Catskills' abundance of hiking and horseback trails, creeks and rivers for fishing, historic sites and campgrounds, small inns and guesthouses, a visitor need never even go near the de luxe resorts that have for so long helped make these mountains one of the most popular recreation areas in the East. On the other hand, no guest at the big resorts ever has to leave them for want of something to do, for on the grounds of these selfcontained enclaves are such enticements as 24houraday tennis, outdoor and indoor swimming pools, badminton courts, walking trails, pitchandputt greens and golf courses. They lavish on their guests three sizable meals a day and lots of entertainment, with TV and movie stars performing in onthepremises nightclubs. At one time the large resorts in the southern Catskills catered almost entirely to the Jewish trade, but this has changed. Americans of all ethnic and religious backgrounds now flock to the large hotels, one reason being that their extensive facilities attract conventions and the conventioneers come back to vacation with their families. Many of these resorts offer free camp activities for children, who are kept busy while their parents play elsewhere.

title: Below the Equator With Admiral Morison
description: THE offwhite liner slides smoothly through the calm, icy waters of the Strait of Magellan. Stark, graniteribbed mountains soar in the near distance. On the horizon the sun's rays glitter off the snowy peaks of the Andes. To one side of the ship's bridge a tall, patrician figure stands, cane in hand. Now and again he turns to converse with the helmsman, then resumes his solitary contemplation of the sea life about himpetrels floating in the wind behind the liner, an occasional penguin, tiny steamboat ducks whirring their wings comically in the water in a futile race with the ship.

title: Where Is Tennis? In Confused State
description: One of these days the W.C.T. will stop fighting with the A.T.P. and the U.S.T.A. will embrace the I.L.T.F. and everybody in tennis can get on with more important matters, like keeping a 24hour surveillance on Jimmy Connors's accountant.

title: UTILITIES HERE SET FOR SUMMER LOAD
description: Electric utilities in the metropolitan area released estimates and projections last week indicating that they will be able to meet the peak summer loads with ample margins to offset unforeseen mishaps.

title: Section In Brooklyn To Renovate Housing
description: Saint Nicholas, a neighborhood in Brooklyn's Italian Williamsburg, has obtained a $160,000 Federal grant to staff a local housing and development corporation, which last week began work on a program to revitalize the neighborhood's rapidly deteriorating housing stock.

title: Phoebe Craven Becomes Bride
description: In Christ ??copal Church, Christiana Hundred. Greensville, Del., yesterday afternoon, Phoebe Craven, daughter of Mrs. David Craven of Windmar, Wilmington, Del., and the late Mr. Craven, became the bride of Peter Shepard Strange. He is the son of Mrs. A B. C. Strange of Greenville and Dr. Theodore B. Strange of Wilmington.

title: Package Tour to Aruba: 8 Days That Won't Break the Bank
description: BEFORE the 707 even lifts off the runway, euphoria has set in. At the J.F.K. checkin counter, a Manhattan couple has informed me that they're making their sixth visit to Aruba. to the same hotel (my hotel) and they're ecstatic. In the seat beside me on the plane, a New Jersey woman has announced that this is her 12th time in as many years. She and her husband are at my hotel, too. Both couples have the air of sophisticated travelers: Substantial middleaged people who know what they like, and get it; quiet, dignified folk. Or so it seems to me as the jet sets forth on the 4hour 20minute flight.

title: Yonkers Mayor, Rebutting Political Charge, Assails School Head
description: YONKERS, May 16Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli, stung by charges that he is seeking political control of the city's Board of Education, says that School Superintendent Robert F. Alioto is conducting a reign of terror in the school system.

title: Xenophobic Albania Is Not Likely to Change
description: LONDONAlbania Is the only state in the world, with what presumably will be the temporary exception of Cambodia, that has no diplomatic relations with either the United States or the Soviet Union.

title: As Bicycling's Popularity Rises Across U.S., So Do Accidents and Fatalities
description: HEAD OF THE HARBOR, L. I., May 17Patty Reilly would rather have been at the beach the other day, but she wound up instead at the local hospital with a broken arm because on her way to the beach by bicycle, she was hit by a car.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: A 75 per cent interest in the Newsweek Building at 444 Madison Avenue, between 49th and 50th Streets, has been acquired by P. & E. Properties, Inc., from Oestrelcher Properties.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The nearlegendary, radical modern house that Walter Gropius built for himself in Lincoln, Mass., in 1937the revolutionary architectural shot heard across the countryis about to be acquired by the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities. The Society has just inaugurated a fundraising campaign to create a $500,000 endowment for maintenance and other expenses, preparatory to accepting the property from Ise Gropius, the architect's widow, who is giving it complete with original Bauhaus art and furnishings, views of hills and apple orchards, and an incredible complement of birds.

title: Washington Crew Wins In Western
description: LONG BEACH, Calif. May 17The University of Washington Junior varsity and varsity heavyweight eights won the feature races of the Western sprint championships here today. The University of California at Berkeley prevented a Washington sweep when its freshman crew nipped Washington in the last stroke.

title: Letters to the Editor

title: Blue Collar Aristocrats

They epitomized for him The Great American Center, honest, funloving men who work hard with their hands, join craft unions with a bread and butter ideology and who, above all, hate those youths and blacks whose outrage threatened, for a while, the vestedness of the American empire.

description: MOUNTAINVILLE  Back in the eighteen  hundreds, Potter's Old Mountainville Hotel was the place where traveling salesmen met at midday to eat an enormous meal and discuss the territory.

title: Odyssey From River Bend
description: After finishing this book I had the uncomfortable feeling that a great many people are going to like itwhile I did not like it at all. And this, indeed, is the dilemma of the book reviewer. He is watching the world through his own personal window. Like any other mortal, he is prejudiced.

title: Endpaper
description: It's that time of year again: termpaper time. Term papers cause sinusitis, temporary blindness, headache, heartache and severe insomnia. But that's just what they do to the professors. The students have it easier. They just don't write them anymore.

title: Is Rape a Symbol of Race Relations?
description: Ed Bullins, whose play The Taking of Miss Janie is now at the Newhouse Theater in Lincoln Center, was among the most talented and strident of the militant black playwrights to emerge in the sixties. Today, he is still among the most talented and prolifiche estimates he has written more than 30 playsbut the stridency and militancy are gone. He speaks of the old issues with the cynical tongue of a man burned by his own past rhetoric.

description: With the unemployment rate approaching 9 per cent and inflation at a similar level Americans are very critical of the way in which national economic decisions are being made.

The World
description: The new rulers of Saigon are continuing their methodical approach to normalizing South Vietnamese society and have begun to turn their attention outward as well. They are opening relations with other nations, and have proposed doing so with the United States.

description: Before time trials for the Indianapolis 500 began last weekend, 20 drivers participated in a poll on what would be the fastest qualifying speed and what would be the slowest to make next Sunday's race.

description: Scientists have discovered that a desert shrub called the jojoba may have a grander future as the source of a badly needed industrial lubricant, the savior of the sperm whale and the creator of jobs for Indians in the American Southwest.

description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne has finally entered the legislative controversy over Congressional redistricting. At a meeting with the state's Representatives in Washington last week, be offered a compromise to a plan pro?? by State Senator James P. Dugan, Democrat of Hudson County and his party's state chairman.

title: Consumer Pointers
description: With the emphasis on vegetable gardening this year, consumers will be developing keen tastes for appealing vegetables to buy and harvest. I have learned some tips on how to buy and select vegetables and melons at their prime or perfection. Here are some ideas.

title: Musical Plants to Sing In a London Art Gallery
description: LONDON, May 17 (Reuters)A collection of musical plants will debut at an art gallery here this month Green Music", at the Whitechapel Gallery, is the work of John Litton, who puts probes into the stems of plants to pick up the electricity passing through them and feeds this into a synthesizer.

title: SADAT ENDS TALKS WITH KING HUSSEIN
description: AMMAN, Jordan, May 17 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat ended his visit to Jordan today, the first visit by an Egyptian head of state, declaring that there was no substitute tor a reconvened Geneva summit conference for Middle East peacemaking and that the Palestinian cause should have prionty.

title: Metropolitan Imperative
description: Although New York's mayors enjoy powers equal to those of the chief executive in any other city and stronger than most, they are increasingly frustrated by their inability to deal with a growing number of problems that transcend the present city limits, such as the problem of funding essential services for commuters who earn their livelihood in the city but pay taxes in the suburbs.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Silver Lake Inn, White Horse Pike (Route 30), Clementon. (609) 7833300.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: WASHINGTON  The United States Supreme Court, over which Chief Justice Warren E. Burger now presides, is, like all its predecessors and the legal system itself, in its habitual state. That state is continuous transition, however imperceptible its speed and direction.

title: Ford Now Is a President In the Recent Tradition
description: WASHINGTONLast Aug. 8, hours after Richard M. Nixon announced he would resign the Presidency. Gerald R. Ford stood in a light rain outside his home in Alexandria, Va , and, speaking without notes, pledged his best efforts to achieve what's good for America and good for the world. His appearance was unstaged and sincere, almost awkward. His manner seemed to cut through the cynicism and gimmickry that had been associated with the White House, and, by extension the Washington scene of recent years.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Croton's Charm
description: BREWSTER, N.Y.In a dark glide on the righthand shore facing down stream of the fishingforfun section of the East Branch of the Croton River, there is a trout of about three pounds that still may have my Mickey Finn streamer fly in its jaw.

This group is spending more time than ever before in caring for the annexed parcels. Far from resenting the extra chores, most of the tenants are delighted with their real estate bonanzas.

description: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 17 A police intelligence cooperative association that exchanges information among its member agencies about organized crime has dropped the Houston Police Department from its rolls in the aftermath of public disclosures about the Houston agency's alleged involvement in illegal wiretapping.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
Music in Review
description: ChunMyung Kim chose a formidable program for her debut in Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night and met its challenge with remarkable authority and insight. The Korean pianist, who now lives here, has been a pupil of Sascha Gorodnitzki at the Juilliard School, where she earned her master's degree. Now she works with Arminda Canteros.

description: TRENTON  The dark, flaunting world of Ralph Albert Blakelock, the 19thcentury landscape painter, is on view at the State Museum.

description: A year ago Rick Barry sat at the television microphone as a commentator and secondguessed the players during the National Basketball Association playoffs. Some of his remarks upset some of the players.

description: MONTCLAIR Now living in a nursing home in Plainfield is 83yearold Dorothy Hutchinson, a former resident of Montclair. But, say some of her exneighbors, she's still picketing, still writing letters to newspapers. She's still doing everything she did as a Montclair member of WIL.

title: Tacks I. Inquiry Is Assailed
description: NEWTONA General Accounting Office investigation into alleged Improprieties by the Army Corps of Engineers in acquiring land for the Tocks Island project has been called incomplete, inadequate and inadmissable by a conservation group opposed to the projected dam.

Marciante, president of the State A.F.L.C.I.O.

title: If You Go ...
description: ... to Bruges, the least complicated way is by train from Brussels.

title: The Abolitionist Of Clark Gable Place
description: Kenneth Ward is a player of games. He creates waves in other people's lives and rides among the wakes, skimming the surface, hoping to avoid something deeperthe southern Californians of Charles Webb's new novel would inevitably call It commitment. In The Abolitionist of Clark Gable Place, Kenneth meets one person worth caring for and another who plays games better than he does.

title: Montclair Churches To Mark Pentecost
description: MONTCLAIRParishioners of nine Montclair churches will worship together today in an ecumenical service marking Pentecost, the day that Christians set aside to memorialize the descent of the Holy Spirit on Christ's disciples.

description: PARIS, May 17The Cambodian Government spokesman charged in a communiqu issued here today that the Mayagtlez incident was a blatant provocation used as a pretext by the United States to execute a preestablished plan to destroy Cambodian ports and economic facilities.

title: Ali Looks 3 Fights Ahead: Bugner, Frazier, Foreman
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 17 Muhammad Ali looked today toward his next world heavyweight title defense, against Joe Bugner on June 30 in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, following his 11thround knockout of Ron Lyle here last night.

title: Chemical Impurities Found in the Water Of Cities in Midwest
description: CHICAGO, May 17 (AP)A study by the Environmental Protection Agency has found organic chemical impurities, particularly chloroform, in drinking water tested in 83 cities in the Middle West.

description: All planting is go except in colder regions, wait another week to set out tender vegetable plants such as tomatoes, eggplants, peppers and tender annuals such as zinnias and impatiens.

title: 20% Rise in Fires Is Adding To Decline of South Bronx
description: Twenty, thirty, forty times a day the cry of fire sirens and clouds of acrid smoke rise above the stretch of decay and poverty that is the southern third of the Bronx.

title: Vocationals Are Now the Schools In Demand
description: Critics of the public schools in the sixties were not always in agreement about what were problems, or about what might be solutions to them. But on one question, there was near unanimity: Vocational high schools, they said, ought to be eliminated. The reasons cited: Vocational schools are socially stigmatizing; educationally, they are no more than dumping grounds for academic misfits.

title: Coast Museum Gets Clyfford Still Art
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 17In a rare move, Clyfford Still, the 72yearold pioneer of abstract expressionism, long renounced for his isolationist stand toward the East Coast, art world, is donating 28 of his major works to the San Francisco Museum of Art, Henry Hopkins, director of the museum, disclosed here yesterday.

title: Seven Chimneys Mirrors Past
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP Seven Chimneys is an 18thcentury house listed in the National Register of Historic Places. For 47 eighthgrade socialstudy students at West Brook Junior High School in Paramus, a recent visit to the home was n trip through the past that instilled pride in the present.

title: U.S. Cool To PATH Plainfield Extension
description: WASHINGTONThe plan of Governor Byrne and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to extend the PATH transit line from Newark to Plainfield has run into heavy opposition here.

title: Death Penalty Ban Rejected
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 17 (UPI)The Illinois House voted 102 to 36 today to kill a bill that would have abolished the death penalty in Illinois.

title: Witness Describes 12 Zebra Slayings At California Trial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 17More testimony about a series of random street killings that occurred in this city in the winter of 197374 was presented to a jury of seven women and five men by prosecutors in the fifth week of the Zebra murder trial here.

title: Portugal's Revolution Began in the Army
description: There have been two revolutions in Portugal over the last year, only one of which has received much attention. While the transformation of Portugal itself has been dramatic, more remarkable still has been the transformation of the Portuguese Army.

title: Belinda Ann Bowling Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Chandler Bowling of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Belinda Ann Bowling, to Eugene Garrett Bewkes 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bewkes Jr., also of Darien.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The Bolshoi Ballet is different. Very different. And it is different for three particular, if related, reasons. It is Russian. It is Soviet. It is under the artistic direction of Yuri Grigorovich, who, apart from his individuality as an artist, is a Leningradtrained choreographer now based in Moscow. From the web of these circumstances, the contemporary Bolshoi, which is reaching the end of its New York season before its crosscountry tour, derives its character. It is a web worth untangling.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Vox pop. Some people view the bestseller lists as barometers of the taste and preoccupations of the great American public. Perhaps For whatever they're worth, here are some conclusions drawn from the paperback lists of the past 17 weeks, since the Book Review began its weekly compilation:

title: Patrice Margerm Is Bride of J. R. Page
description: In the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here yesterday at noon, Patrice Marie Margerm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Richard Margerm of Wilmette, Ill., was married to Jonathan R. Page, son of Mr and Mrs. John F. Page of Mechanics burg, Pa.

title: Forego Scores at Aqueduct For 6th Consecutive Victory
description: Lazy F Ranch's formidable Forego, named the horse of the year, the best sprinter and the best handicap performer of the 1974 campaign, lived up to all the recognition yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE VIEW
description: I'd always felt a little sorry for John Gayfoolishly, I now see. Gay, of course, had written that most successful of all successes, The Beggar's Opera, and had coined money on it. In fact, we forget today exactly what The Beggar's Opera did to our theater. Until its opening night, repertory had been standard practice in the British theater for the simple reason that you couldn't run a play longer than a night or two at a time; the London audience was thought to be too limited to allow for anything more than that. Then The Beggar's Opera opened, spread its wings, and took off for a hundred or so performances, institutinganl, as it happensestablishing the principle of the long run. Idealistically, we've ben trying to get back to repertory u.ver since; go. Gay gave us the rut we pretend to regret, and on which our profit dependeth.

title: The Rock Star Who Plays Franz Liszt
description: LONDON Franz Liszt, now, he was such a randy old bloke. He really was a raver, did you know that? He was like a 19thcentury Mick Jaeger.

title: Amends for College Prank
description: COLLEGE STATION. Tex., May 17 (UPI)A Houston woman who raid her son had taken the clapper from Texas A&M University's liberty hell as a prank almost a decade ago has returned the ??pound castiron piece to the school.

title: It's Where the Containment of Communism Policy Began
description: WASHINGTONShortly after the fall of South Vietnam, Defense Secretary Schlesinger observed that it would be particularly inopportune, in view of shaken confidence in American power and steadfastness, to consider major reductions in United States forces in South Korea, the last American stronghold on the Asian continent.

title: Is This a Time to Celebrate?
description: The most divisive war in our history still divides Americans. A United States Army force has been defeated by illequipped guerrillas. The American elective process has been contravened. The most deadly sort of racism is rampant and the law is oppressive. A Presidential administration has been exposed as corrupt. The econnomy is in a shambles. Crime is rising. Our citizens live in fearfully overcrowded cities and many of their children are denied a basic education.

title: KISSINGER IS MIEN MIDWEST SUPPORT
description: Secretary of State Kissinger, who has been under fire in Washington, was received with a mixture of enthusiasm, respect and curiosity last week during a fourstop visit to the Middle West.

title: Record Heat Hits Moscow This Spring
description: MOSCOW, May 17  The thirsty men in shirtsleeves queued up at 9 AM. outside the small beer bar on SadovoKaretnaya may have long suspectedi what is now of??cially acknowledged: Moscow, like much of Furopean Russia, is enduring its warmest Spring in memory.

title: Mets Get 5 in 7th, Win, 64
description: HOUSTON, May 17  A fiverun uprising in the seventh inning, plus some strong relief pitching by Harry Parker, lifted the New York Mets to their fifth straight victory tonight, a 64 triumph over the bedraggled Houston Astros at the Astrodome,

title: FILM VIEW
description: When I write about had movies, I sometimes hear myself sounding like a Biblethumping moralist, full of indignation that the world should have to put up with this latest piece of valuedistorting, experiencediminishing, timeconsuming junk. No matter how lofty or honorable a subject may be, a movie that is badclumsy, cliched, banaldoes it a disservice.

title: Picking Winners
description: I used to be intrigued by a graffiti warning in the men's room at old Jamaica Race Track in New York City, which, in cautioning visitors to be careful (Stand Close), noted All horseplayers have holes in their shoes. Well, not all.

title: TV Notes: An Ohio Show With 50% of The Viewers
description: The hottest local TV show in America today surpasses anything in the medium's jackpotgiveaway genre for prizemoney and probably, has achieved the ultimate in athome audience participation. The show is the weekly drawing of the Ohio 50cent Lotterycalled, for TV purposes, The Buckeye 300 Showand features as emcee, Gib Stanley, the WEWSTV sportscaster who does the football playbyplay for the Cleveland Browns. The 7:30 Thursday night telecast goes out over an Ohio network that Includes stations in Cincinnati, Columbus, Dayton, Toledo, Lima, Canton and Zanesville, all of which carry it live. Telephone ratings surveys indicate that it is watched in nearly 50 per cent of the homes turned to television in Cleveland where it plays on WEWS.

title: A. HERBERT SANDLER
description: A. Herbert Sandler, a former first vice president of the Rankers Trust Company, died Friday at University Hospital. He was 67 years old and live, at 155 East 38th Street.

Littman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Littman of Hallandale, Fla. The future bride was graduated magna cum laude from Mount Holyoke College and from the Downstate Medical Center at Brooklyn. Her f??anc is an alumnus of the University of Wisconsin and the State University of New York School of Medicine at Buffalo.

description: SEATTLE, May 17Last Dec. 23, two days before Christmas. the Mayor of this city decided to dismiss the fire chief after receiving a severely critical report concerning the operation of the chief's department.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lebanese on Alert To Thwart Clashes After Kidnapping
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 17Tight security measures were in effect here today after tension over the kidnapping yesterday of three members of the Christiandominated right wing Phalangist party.

title: Few Shifts Seen Among Islanders
description: The hockey players who win together stay together. Almost all the 20 young players who combined to form the defenseminded unit that was the 197475 New York Islanders will remain with the franchise next season.

title: Serafina Takes Y.R.A. Opener
WILD MAN SEIZED IN FLORIDA SWAMP
description: BUSHNELL, Fla., May 17 (UPI)  A kicking, ranting Oriental wild man, dragged from the central Florida Green Swamp by sheriff's deputies today may be an escape front a hospital security ward where he was admitted after refusing to board an airplane for his native Taiwan.

title: Toward Decentralization
description: Decentralization of both the political and administrative structures now concentrated in City Hall would, under one proposal, involve rapid transfer of fairly extensive budgetary and operational functions to elected boards in 30 to 35 new districts of from 200,000 to 300,000 population. Or, as the Charter Commission proposes, it could entail a more gradual evolution toward forty to fifty elected district councils. These would have, initially, strictly limited powers, building slowly on experience already gained in the appointed community planning boards established in the 1963 charter and through Mayor Lindsay's experimental district service councils and Office of Neighborhood Government.

title: Answers/Questions
description: GIANT PUMPKIN (May 4)

title: Red Smith
description: BALTIMORE, May 17  They came barreling down past the bulging stands and around the clubhouse turn, and almost the only sound was the crisp voice of Dick Woolley calling their names as they ranNative Guest, Media, Master Derby, Singh. They were halfway down the backstretch when a roar went up, not a thunder, exactly, but several octax es higher than that, somewhere between a shout and a scream. Foolish Pleasure, winner of the 101st Kentucky Derby and 6to5 favorite in the 100th Preakness, was moving up along the rail, brightening the financial prospects of a large, unsilent minority of the biggest crowd that ever bet a horse race in Maryland.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: The paint on my concrete patio peels in about three months, even though I paint it with a top quality latex paint. The patio is in the rear and is surrounded by trees. Prior to each application I thoroughly clean and etch the surface. Can you give me a solution to this problem?B W., E. Windsor, N.J.

title: Lack of Fire Training Seen
description: CHICAGO, May 17 (AP)The executive director of the Smoke, Fire and Burn Foundation of Boston says that children and teachers are not beling taught to get out of buring schools safely. Dr. Anne W. Phillips, speaker at the closing session of the 79th annual meeting of the National Fire Protection Association, said We are teaching our children to die in fires.

title: Bills' Lineman Arrested
description: HAMBURG, N. Y., May 17 (UPI)Jeff Winans, a Buffalo Bills' lineman, was arrested today by Erie County sheriff's deputies and charged with leaving the scene of an accident. The deputies said Winans's van truck collided with a car at a traffic light on Route 5 and Lake Street in the Village of Angola. Winans allegedly sped away after the accident and was arrested in this community.

title: There Is Just So Much the State Can Do for the City
description: ALBANYPerry Duryea, the Assembly's Republican leader, sat quietly taking notes during the meeting at which Warren Anderson, his counterpart in the Republicancontrolled Senate, refused New York City's plea for help to fill a hole of $640million in its new budget. He penciled some figures delineating the limits, political and fiscal, of what the state could do for the city.

title: The Moneychangers
description: Arthur Hailey's novels are such genuine publishing events that to criticize them is like putting the slug on the Rockettes. It's not going to change anything. No sooner is his contract inked than mighty lumberjacks start to make their axes ring. Paperback houses and book clubs fairly whimper to give him money while the work is still in progress, and Ross Hunter calls up the old actors' home to begin casting his next blockbuster. At the publication party itself the last deviled egg is still to be consumed when his book busts through on the bestseller lists. In view of all this hoopla, the fact that Mr. Hailey's books aren't any good seems to be almost beside the point. They are already winners.

title: Constance Sawyer Bride of John Dix
description: Constance Matthews Sawyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Sawyer of Chapel Hill. N C., was married yesterday afternoon to John Adams Dix, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Dix of Bedford, N. Y. The Rev Peter James Lee performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Chapel of the Cross in Chapel Hill.

title: Oglethorpe U. Names Chief
description: ATLANTA, May 17 (AP)Dr. Manning Pattillo Jr., director of special projects at the University of Rochester, was named this week as president of Oglethorpe University.

title: Birmingham Whites Assist Expansion of Black College
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 15 Back in the early nineteensixties, the predominantly black student body at Miles College helped institute a selective buying campaign against Birmingham businesses that practiced racial discrimination.

title: L.I.Bridgeport Ferry Service Opens
description: PORT JEFFERSON  The Bridgeport and Port Jefferson Steamboat Company, which began ferry service last Friday, is accepting, for the first time, reservations for cars and motorcycles.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may he obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: The Other Government
description: Where Washington lawyers are concerned, an important distinction must be made. The Office of Price Administration, with which I was associated in World War II, had a heavy complement of lawyers recruited by David Ginsbergby some it was said to be overlawvered. It was an excellent fault. Few agencies have ever had a higher potential for corruption. A minor decision on the price of oil could mean millions which sundry predators would gladly have shared. The agency went through the war without a scandal. The lawyers, combining professional suspicion with a high sense of rectitude, were a principal reason. (We also ensured that enough people participated in every decision so that any predation would have to be a conspiracy.)

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, May 17 (UPI)Greece and Turkey opened talks today on issues that brought the neighbors and Aalantic alliance members close to war less than a year ago.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FEDERAL RESERVE BOARD cut the discount rate to 6 per cent from 6 per cent, the lowest since June, 1973....Industrial Production at 109.4 in April [1967= 100] was down 0.4 per cent from March.... New car sales in the first 10 days of May fell 20.8 per cent, to 162,046 units, from the yearearlier level....House and Senate conferees have agreed on a housing bill to produce 400,000 new houses and provide 800,000 construction jobs.

title: New fiction from the Fiction Collective
description: The world is pure Invention from one minute to the next. So says character Ronald Sukenick in author Ronald Sukenick's last novel, Out. So suggest these three books from the Fiction Collective. This kind of inventive urgency made Beckett demand of himself an impossible art. Collectivists Sukenick, Russell Banks and Mark Mirsky choose an implaus ible art, a fiction of elaborate lies. Their stories grow out of play, fantasy and myth, where imagination asserts its own amorphous way, creates its own plausibility. The products of the freed imagination are almost necessarily uneven in effect, and some of these stories are contrivances. More often, though, they flux and delight the reader with signifying implausibility. The best locate his privacy among their processes.

title: Radcliffe Crew Sets Back Yale
description: DERBY, Conn.Radcliffe's crew kept its 1975 record unblemished tonight as the women from Cambridge pulled away from Yale to win by over four lengths in a twomile race on the Housatonic River.

title: New Yorkers Subjected to 22 Different Kinds of Taxes
The Raw Materials Issue
description: Secretary Kissinger's offer to the developing countries to go beyond oil and to open discussions of prices and supplies of other raw materials on a casebycase basis could be the beginning of a constructive response to radical demands for a new economic order. But more is needed.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: The Long and Short of It
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: O GOD! O HOLLYWOOD!
description: My wife and I were in Yellowknife, in the Northwest Territories, when Michael Spencer, beleaguered head of the Canadian Film Development Corporation, telephoned from Montreal.

title: Tensions and Violence in Boston Schools Are Rooted in Traditions of White Ethnic Neighborhoods
description: BOSTON, May 17As the end of the school year approaches, the busing plan ordered by the Federal District court to desegregate the schools has left this city with disturbing consequences.

title: College Is Offering Course in Tennis
description: PEMBERTON  The Burlington County College Office of Community Services will offer a noncredit tennis course this summer for interested youngsters who have not played the game previously.

title: 3,000 THAIS MARCH ON U.S. EMBASSY AS PROTEST GROWS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sunday, May 18Thailand formally expressed indignation yesterday that the United States had used a Thai base in the Marine operation three days ago to, recover an American merchant ship from Cambodian forces, and 3,000 demonstrators marched on the American embassy here,

title: Bayi's 3:51 Sets World Mile Mark
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 17Leading from start to finish, in a spectacular display of speed and strength, Filbert Bayi of Tanzania broke the world record in the mile run tonight with the time of 3 minutes 51 seconds during the International Freedom Games.

title: Son Born to Mrs. Schvey
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Henry Schvev of Voorbout, the Netherlands, on April 24 in Diaconessehuis Bronovo Hospital in The Hague. Mrs. Schvey is the former Patricia Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Cohen of St. Louis. The child, whose father is an instructor in comparative literature at Leyden University in the Netherlands, is named Aram Ashley.

title: Colonels 109101 Victors, Lead Pacers' Series, 30
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 (AP)  Arils Gilmore scored 41 points, 13 in the fourth period, as the Kentucky Colonels rallied tonight for a 109101 victory and a 30 lead in the American Basketball Association championship series with the Indiana Pacers.

title: Queen for a Lifetime
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va.In the nineteensixties, the distaste of undergraduates for anything resembling worldly profit was so pervasive that Dean Jack Tate of the Yale Law School consistently maintained that the first applicant who answered the entrance questions Why do you want to be a lawyer and attend Yale Law School? with a frank Because I want to make a bundle of money would automatically be admitted.

title: Bonac Is Prit Near All Taped
description: THE SPRINGSFor over a year now Isabel Spink has been going through this East Hampton Village with a tape recorder, attempting to capture for posterity a language that is fast disappearing.

title: School Is Sold in Commack
description: COMMACK  With the signing of in agreement recently to dispose of a school building here, the Commack school district became the first on Long Island to sell a school to a private institution since the current wave of school building closings began about two years ago.

title: Beame's Time Is Beginning To Run Out
description: The possibility that New York City may default in the payment of salaries, bills and bank notes, unthinkable only two weeks ago, has considerably increased as a result of the Federal Goverment's refusal to guarantee a loan because it might set a dangerous precedent.

title: Anthony CaroPushing The Limits of Sculpture
description: At first glance, the brightly colored industrial forms strewn around the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture garden seem to be waiting for the hand of a giant child to arrange them into some fantasy of building. Of course, the green and yellow girders, red steel sheets and pipes, and tall, rusted pilings have already been arranged. They are the work of Antho ny Caro, who has been acclaimed by a number of critics as the most important sculptor of his generation, the heir to the modernist tradition begun by Picasso and passed on to the late David Smith. The Museum of Modern Art's current rettrospective of the last 15 years of his work is the museum's first major exhibition of a British sculptor since the Henry Moore show in 1947.

title: Local Lives
description: They who have been accustomed to the gaudiness and inane phraseology of many modern writers, if they persist in reading this book to its conclusion, will no doubt frequently have to struggle with feelings of strangeness and awkwardness: they will look round for poetry, and will be induced to inquire by what species of courtesy these attempts can be permitted to assume that title.

title: Richard Webel Fiance Of Sandra D. Lawrance
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Lawrance of Southport, Conn., and New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Dix Lawrance, to Richard C. Webel, son of Richard K. Webel of Glen Head, L. I., and the late Mrs. Webel, who was the former Janet Darling.

title: Paperbacks
description: THE CRITICAL POINT, by Irving Howe. (Dell/Delta, $2 75) Fourteen recent essays, some of which rank among the best literary criticism now being written in America; among the subjects are Zola, Solzhenitsyn. Philip Roth, suicide, psychoanalysis and poetry

title: Scott Joplin's Operatic Vision Comes to Life
description: gerly pick out his rags at the keyboard; recordings of his music are available in a myriad of instrumental arrangements; the background music to the recent film The Sting has helped spread the Joplin fever throughout the country. Few people are aware, however, that in addition to his many piano rags Joplin also composed at least one opera  Treemonisha, which will receive its first full professional production on May 23 in Texas by the Houston Grand Opera.

title: More Park Space Is Urged for Nassau
description: MINEOLA  The Nassau County Planning Commission urged last week that the county use parking lots, sand pits, building plazas, unused warehouses and other park substitutes to meet the growing recreational needs of its residents.

title: Bicentennial BlastOff: 10 Days That Will Shake New York
description: TWO hundred years ago Thursday a group of confused New York citizens met to try to figure out the news from Boston about the fracas with the British at Lexington and Concord. Before ending their deliberations as a Provisional Congress, the Few Yorkers decided to join their Massachusetts brethren in the field, and the Revolution had come a step closer.

title: Japanese Woman Overcame Injury To Climb Everest
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 17 (UPI)Details became availstole today about the successful ascent of Mount Everest, the world's highest mountain, by a 35yearold Japanese, the first woman to reach the summit.

title: U.S. LOSES TOUCH WITH MEN IN LAOS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 17 The United States Embassy here lost contact today with American officials and their dependents who are being detained by students in the southcentral Laotian city of Savannakhet.

title: KENNEDY '74 INCOME IS PUT AT $490,822
description: BOSTON, May 17 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy made public his 1974 income tax return today showing income totaling $490,822, most of it from trust funds created by his father.

title: State of the City: Is It Governable?
description: Lincoln Steffens described New York City as the leading exponent of the Great American antibad government movement.

title: Farmers' Market Back in Bridgeton
description: BRIDGETON  A weekly Farmers' Market, which proved a success last summer, is returning to Bridgeton next Saturday.

title: College Experiment Offered for Women
description: A new model program for intercollegiate athletics, defined in a document called Women's Athletics: A Search for Sanity, will be offered to college administrators at the next national meeting of the As sociation for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women. The three  year experiment would represent a major restructuring by the A.I.A.W., which has more than 600 member colleges.

title: Manufacturer Convicted in Associate's Slaying Is Suspect in Unsolved '67 Killing
description: Irving Ohlstein, a Manhattan manufacturer of nuts and bolts, convicted last week of hiring killer to murder a business associate, is one of the suspects in yet another murder of Manhattan businessman whose body reportedly was dumped into the waters off Key West, Fla., eight years ago and never recovered.

title: Summer Workshop Is Planned by EVE
description: UNION  A special workshop entitled the Vocational Development Group will be offered this summer by EVE, a women's vocational guidance center at Kean College.

title: CITY BAR OPPOSES A BRONX DISTRICT
description: The city bar association expressed its official disapproval yesterday of a bill that would make the Bronx a separate judicial district, terming the bill unconstitutional, coun terproductive and a political maneuver.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1SUE COE

title: 9 YONKERS FIREMEN INJURED IN GAS LEAK
description: A gas leak from a chlorine lank at New York City's Hill View water reservoir in Yonkers yesterday injured nine Yonkers firemen, three of whom were hospitalized for burns and gas inhalation.

title: Jon Gurkoff Fiance of Stefani Taub
description: Stefani Taub, a pilot, and Jon Buch Gurkoff, graduates of Bradley University, will be married July 3.

title: Rizzo in Tight Race Despite Enormous Liabilities
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 17If he were another candidate in another city, Frank L. Rizzo, the only Mayor in America who once failed a public polygraph examination, probably would not have a chance to be reelected.

title: Dance: Bolshoi Magic
description: For the artistic director of a ballet company, just as with a fly fisherman, casting can he the very devil. And this is all the more true when you are fishing in unfamiliar waters on a foreign tour. This may be the reason why to Western taste, or at least to One Western taste, the Bolshoi casting has seemed a little wayward, even willful, at the Metropolitan Opera House this season. The subsequent casts in quite a few ballets have been rather more successful than the cast presented on the first night. Conventional wisdom suggests that one usually puts out one's strongest cast for premieres. However unconventional wisdom further suggests than in all large ballet companies, bureaucracy and hierarchy have their roles to play and their parts to say. The Bolshoi Ballet is no different from the rest.

title: Sex Bias Settlement
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP)Dr. Phyllis Rackin, a University of Pennsylvania professor who was denied tenure and then filed a sex discrimination suit, will receive 570,000 in cash and her tenure as part of an outofcourt settlement. She will also be promoted from assistant to associate professor.

title: Weaving Proves Popular
description: HEMPSTEAD  At the crafts center of the Long Island Craftsmen's Guild at Hofstra University, dozens of suburban women have traded their canvas patterns, embroidery hoops or crocheting needles for fullsize floor or table looms. Weaving is taking over.

title: Medical School Will Train Midwives
description: NEWARKThe New Jersey Medical School, impressed by the achievements of a nursemidwife program at Martland Hospital, is instituting a course in which registered nurses will be trained as substitutes for obstetricians.

title: Will Wins Two Events
description: FLORAL PARK, L. I., May 17Robert Will of Lynbrook High School posted the best weight double ever by a New York State schoolboy today in the Nassau County divisional track meet at the Floral Park field. Will, an Auburnbound senior, won the shotput with a toss of 64 feet 3 inches and the discus throw with a murk of 1828. Both are among the

title: Curtain Time for the I. B. M. Case
description: Tomorrow, barring some totally unforeseen event, what is perhaps the most important antitrust trial in history, the United States v. the International Business Machines Corporation, will begin in Federal Court for the Southern District of New York in Foley Square.
