description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Chinese Minister Ends Paris Visit; Closer Ties Cited
description: PARIS, May 17  Deputy Premier Teng Hsiaoping of China returned to Peking today. after a sixday state visit here; that he and French officials: said had intensified economic; and political contacts between the two nations.

title: Cycle of Life Is Maintained at Morton Refuge
description: NOYACK  A springtime walk through the Morton National Wildlife Refuge here brings the design of the natural order into greater focus than at any other time of year.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: One of the more amiable subjects of controversy when musicians and musicologists and musiclovers get together is Mozart vs. Haydn. Not that anybody really wants to set one up against the other. Both composers would be on anybody's list of the ten greatest in history. But it is an eternally fascinating topic to look at the oeuvre of those two giants and try to reach certain conclusions.

title: THE SECRET TABLE
description: Two novellas of young men embracing a mystical past. It's a rich combination of blinking insights, satirical commentary and inventive movement conjured up from old ghosts, old graves and a present of sadness and terror... moving, delicately efficient, superb. Kirkus Reviews Of Musky's last novel, The New York Times wrote, Blue Hill Avenue is a joy bringer. This is words magnificently employed, exclaimed Anthony Burgess, and John Hawkes called the author one of the old rude joyous storytellers come to life.

title: Helen B. Stone Married To Desmond Fitz Gerald
description: Helen B. Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Stone Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Desmond G. Fitz Gerald, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. G. Fitz Gerald of Washington.

title: Richard Schuster to Wed Randee Maltz
description: Mr and Mrs William Maltz of South Merrick, L I, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Randee Maltz, to Richard Schuster, con of Mr. and Mrs Robert Schuster of Great Neck, L I.

title: Israeli Kibbutz Home for L.I. Residents
description: KFAR CHARUV, Golan HeightsKibbutz Kfar Charuv sits atop a windswept plain on the Israelioccupied Golan Heights. From a decaying Syrian bunker within its boundaries, there is a dramatic westward view over the Sea of Galilee. To the south and east, only a couple miles away, are the Jordanian and Syrian borders.

title: Black Admissions Aides Advise On Competition for Ivy League
description: One hundred and twentyfive ninth and tenthgraders, most of them black, were exhorted yesterday to maximize their potential if they were to compete successfully for placement in Ivy League colleges.

title: JON GIBSON'S MUSIC PLAYED AT KITCHEN
description: Jon Gibson is a saxophone and flute player who has performed often on the SoHo avantgarde music scene, most prominently as a longtime member of Philip Glass's ensemble. But he is also a composer, and on Friday evening he presented the first of two identical programs of his recent work at the Kitchen.

title: Budget Cuts Peril 2 Byrne Goals
description: TRENTONIn his message to the Legislature last January, Governor Byrne said he regarded the public financing of gubernatorial campaigns and the creation of the Department of Public Advocate as the two major accomplishments of his first year in office.

title: Hoopstick Farm Grooming For Essex Horse Trials
description: BEDMINSTER Hoopstick Farm, which is named for the meandering stream that flows through its fields, is the 65acre estate of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott A. Haller. It also is the setting for a picturesque 2mile crosscountry race course for horses, a course that includes no fewer than 24 jumps.

title: Encounter: Coveting a Plant in Granada
description: I AM a dogged sightseer. Up to point. Take what happened to me in Granada. My second day and second visit to the Alhambra, buying my ticket, turning right and following the signs, treading closely behind an international queue of fellow tourists, I sudaenly began to feel blood brother to a sheep.

title: Garretson House in Fair Lawn Opening to Public
description: FAIR LAWN  The auctioning off of a live goat, plus frogjumping contests, chases after a greased pig and a competitive pull by champion oxen, will be among the events at Kids Day for History here next Saturday. The program, which will mark the opening, for public viewing, of the 267  year  old Garretson House, will run from 10 A.M. to dusk.

title: Andretti Qualifies for Indy10th Row
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 17 (AP)Mario Andretti, who last weekend passed up the first qualifying run for the May 25 Indianpolis 500, qualified for the 33car field today and in the process helped bump Lee Kunzman out of it.

title: Rural Areas' Population Gains Now Outpacing Urban Regions
description: Census Bureau surveys since the 1970 Census show a surprising snift in population movement in the United States. Nonmetropolitan areas are growing faster than metropolitan areas.

description: CHICAGO, May 17 (AP)Sr. Diplomat rallied in the final stride to defeat Recaptured by a nose in the $64,400 Equipoise Handicap before 22,256 at Sportsman's Park today.

description: Candace Marie Young, a research assistant with the Arthur D. Little Company of Cambridge. Mass., and Dennis C. Guittarr, a fine netal services officer with the Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Company, plan to he married Sept. G in Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

description: Executive Director, Citizens Housing and Planning Council

title: Flyers' Coach Expects Punches to Be Flying
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 17Violence The word cropped up, not the act, as Coach Fred Shero of the Philadelphia Flyers looked ahead to tomorrow afternoon's second game here with the Buffalo Sabres in the National Hockey League's championship playoff.

title: She Has an Unpopular Role
description: OAKDALE  When Maria Trivelli speaks, not too many people listen. And that upsets Mrs. Trivelli, for as the special assistant for women in apprenticeship in the State Department of Labor, it is her job to spread the news about opportunities for women in the trades and to interest as many of them as possible in that kind of work.

title: Mrs. Beadle Has Child
description: A daughter, was born to Dr and Mrs. Gordon Beadle of Cortland, N Y, on April 29 in the CrouseIrving Hospital in Syracuse Mrs Beadle, a language specialist, is the former Carnole Corwin of Last Williston ?? ??

title: Oglethorpe U. Names Chief
description: ATLANTA, May 17 (AP)Dr. Manning Pattillo Jr., director of special projects at the University of Rochester, was named this week as president of Oglethorpe University.

title: Calendar of Dog Show Events
description: TodayL I K C allbreed and obedience, New York Institute of Technology, Route 25. Brookville. L. I, 1407 dogs, 830 A M.

title: Hanging on In Paradise
description: Traditionally the screenwriter has been the most neglected and despised figure in the Hollywood dream factory. The cynical screenwriter hero of Sunset Boulevard put it this way: Audiences don't know anyone writes a picture. They think the actors make it up as they go along  Critics, on the other hand, often refer to the director as author of a film, even when he did not write the story or a single line of dialogue. It is true that several powerful directorsAlfred Hitchcock, John Ford. Frank Capra, Howard Hawksput their personal stamp on their films, but it was the writers who contributed the vivid characterizations, the witty dialogue and the sheer narrative drive that kept the general level of American movies so high throughout the thirties and forties.

title: Dena Kirkbride, C. C. Bellows 3d Wed in Suburbs
description: The Rev. Gutherie Speers performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David B. Kirkbride of New Canaan and Keene Valley, N.Y.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Donald E. Westlake has carved out for himself a pretty unassailable position as the funny man of the American crimp novel. A good smooth sophisticated writer with a feel for the ridiculous and a fine ear for colloquial speech patterns, Westlake can often be terribly amusing. And he is in his latest book, TWO MUCH (Evans, $6.95). Yet is it nowhere near as good a book as some of its predecessors. It is true that the Westlakean flashes are there to enliven it. It is also true that he belabors a situation that is impossible to begin with, ends up with too pat a solution and turns farce into tragedy. The author of the book is the deus ex machina, and that is always a copout.

title: Miss Christenson Wed To James Greene Jr.
description: Karen Jean Christenson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul J. Christenson of Spring Lake, Mich., and James Edward Greene Jr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Greene of Summit, N.J., were married yesterday evening in Nashville, in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Edward by the Rev. John N. Cain.

title: SAIGON LEADERS MEET AT PALACE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 17 (Reuters) Leaders of the Provisional Revolutionary Government met privately in the presidential palace here today after a week of presenting themselves to the people at victory celebrations.

title: Rotelle Rule Is Seen Undisturbed for 1975
description: The trial in Minneapolis concerning the Rozelle Rule, which has droned on for some weeks, adjourned on Thursday for 12 days without an end in sight. The trial has pitted the Players Association, the plaintiff, against the National Football League and the league's strategy, in defending the compensation rule for freeagent players traded to another team, was disclosed last week.

title: Cosmos Haunted By Rejected Goalie
description: Allowing only eight goals in 18 games is impressive for a goalkeeper in anybody's league. That's what BrookIynborn Arnold Mausser achieved in the American Soccer League last season when he led the Rhode Island Oceaneers Soccer to the title.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: WASHINGTONRepresentative Thomas S. Foley, who is 6 feet 3 inches tall, stands higher than ever in the House these days despite leading a losing fight for a 1975 farm bill that both producers and consumers, whatever their alignment, saw as one of the major issues of the 94th Congress.

title: New Sculpture in Newark
description: NEWARK  Quietly and unobtrusively, a new sculpture was recently placed in the Newark Museum's sculpture garden, thereby making the outdoor area one of the most exciting places of its kind in New Jersey.

title: The Office in Charge of Refugees
description: WASHINGTON  On the seventh floor of the State Department, in windowless rooms painted the sunny primary colors of a kindergarten, an assortment of facilitators and administrators from Government agencies and departments are wrestling with a complicated problem: how to find new lives in this country for some 130,000 Vietnamese refugees who had to leave their country and old lives behind.

title: Intelligence Inquiries in Capitol Focus On Legitimacy of Covert Espionage
description: WASHINGTON, May 17The basic issue emerging from the Congressional investigations of the United States intelligence community is whether to prohibit covert espionage operations entirely or simply to create some mechanism for legislative control, interviews with Congressional sources have disclosed.

title: Medicaid Patients Barred in Florida
description: MIAMI, May 17The majority of Florida's nursing homes have stopped accepting Medicaid patients in an effort to obtain from the State Legislature a substantial increase in welfare payments.

title: CONTRASTS OFFERED BY CHORAL SOCIETY
description: The New York Choral Society wound up its season Friday night in Avery Fisher Hall with a quartet of nicely contrasted works for chorus and orchestra Bach's magnificat, Dvorak's Te Deum, Vaughan Williams's Serenade to Music and a cantata commissioned by the society, William Mayer's Spring and Yes Forever, which received its premiere.

title: Maine Oil Spill Fines Levied
description: BOSTON, May 17 (AP)Two Maine concerns have been fined by the United States ?? tronmental Protection Agency for oil spills in Maine waters The Maine Central Railroad Company was lined $1.500 for an oil spill last tall in Lake M??ee near Belgi?? The Warren Biothers of Benton, a division of Ashland Oil was fined $2,000 for ?? ?? in the ??

title: Even the Unpleasant Rules Must Be Enforced
description: Aldous Huxley, in Ends and Means, wrote on sports: Like every other instrument that man has invented, sport can be used either for good or for evil purposes. Used well, it can teach endurance and courage, a sense of fair play and a respect for rules, coordinated effort and the subordination of personal interests to those of the group. Used badly, it can encourage personal vanity and group vanity, greedy desire for victory and hatred for rivals, an intolerant esprit de corps and contempt for people who are beyond a certain arbitrarily seIected pale.

title: Siderowf Upset in Travis
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 17  Billy Edwards, a 44yearold golfer, upset Dick Siderowf, a member of the United States Walker Cup team, 3 and 2, in the quarterfinal round today of the 65th annual Walter J. Travis Memorial golf tournament.

title: 4,000 Parade on Armed Forces Day
description: The bands blared and the banners flapped yesterday afternoon as some 4,000 men and women of the nation's military services paraded down a sunny Fifth Avenue in the annual observance of Armed Forces Day.

title: THE LAW AT SEA
description: GENEVA. It is the year 2000. The coastal powers have extended their sovereignty to the centers of the oceans. Cargo and military vessels must pay tribute as they pass from one sovereignty zone to another or as they transit straits through which passage once was free. Conflict between the have and havenot countries, as governments jostle over the resources of the seabed, keeps the world in a state of tension. Fish are a rarity; the few species that survive taste rather odd, for they inhabit an element befouled by enormous amounts of pollution. In most coastal areas, swimming in the sea is forbidden by law. The contamination has killed most of the sea's phytoplankton, the primary source of the earth's oxygen. The environment needed to sustain life on earth is wearing away.

title: SEARCHING FOR SURVIVORS
description: A thematically unified collection of prizewinning stories. One of Banks' special talents is his evocation of place, his feel for the Yankee sensibility and New England landscape. He's a refined writer, subtle and precise, well worth discovering. Publishers Weekly Of his novel Family Life, the poet and critic Michael Benedikt wrote, I don't know how Banks performs such magic but the result is wonderfully entertaining. I know of no other contemporary fiction quite like this; I wish I did.

title: Old Tires Make a Playground Swing
description: MAPLEWOODWhat at first glance at least, might appear to be something straight out of The Towering Inferno, Star Trek or Captain Kangaroo is, in reality, a newly installed playground at the Fielding School here.

title: Ford Sends A Signal
description: President Ford took what appears to have been a lowrisk gamble last week, sending marines, jets and the Navy to rescue 39 American seamen and their cargo ship from the Cambodians who had seized them by force.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: A threeinch solid gold medal costing in the neighborhood of $5,000 may be the crowning piece in the gold, silver and bronze editions of the National Bicentennial Commemorative Medal that will be offered under Congressional mandate early next year by the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration. Although no final decision has been announced, a gold medal this large is said to be definitely under consideration.

title: New Spending Law Likely to Jolt Politics
description: WASHINGTON, May 17Postwar American politics is a game in which the rules keep changing.

title: RIZZOLI TO EXPAND ITS U.S. ACTIVITIES
description: Rizzoli Editore of Milan, Italy's giant publisher, plans to expand its American operations to service what it considers two disadvantaged groups in this country, although the two groups are at the opposite ends of the economic spectrum.

title: STAMPS
description: Bunker Hill, the second of the 1775 clashes between Colonials and British that accelerated the movement toward independence, is being commemorated by a new issue in the series marking the Bicentennial of the American Revolution.

title: New & Novel
description: You'll never know because I'm not going to tell you, says Fiona Keene to Christina Moreland. This is Christy's luck tor the first 294 pages of Phyllis A. Whitney's novelnobody wants to tell her anything. Especially about the rum circumstances of her dad's mysterious death. And when Fiona, Christy's exstepmother, is ready to tell all, darned if she isn't liquidated in the same room of the same Newport mansion as her late husband. It's enough to make a person suspicious.

title: TRAFFIC HAZARDS CITED IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, L.I., May 16Thousands of trees and utility poles placed too close to many roads, pose potential hazards for motorists, according to 15 volunteer teams of insurance company and agency employes who inspected 472 miles of Nassau County roads. The survey was made yesterday by 52 vol unteers from four Long Island insurance organizations. It was sponsored by the Insurance Information Institute of New York City and the New York State Traffic Safety Council. The inspectors also found potential dangers posed by unguarded bridge abutments and ditches.

title: William Rockefeller Is Elevated to President as Order Changes at Westminster K.C.
description: William Rockefeller is the new president of the Westminster Kennel Club. At the annual meeting last Tuesday night, Rockefeller, who had been vice president was elected to succeed James A. Farrell Jr., president for the last two years. Farrell retains his post on the board of governors.

title: TV Satellite to Serve Schools in India After Shift East
description: The world's first communications satellite to be used for broadcasting television directly to small, local antennas, after serving schools and medical facilities in isolated regions of the United States for a year, is about to shift its operations to India, in accordance with longstanding agreements.

title: The Sinking Of the Odradek Stadium
description: This single volume, which contains three novels, could be used as a casebook to trace the development of a writer as he progresses from appealing cleverness to genuine literary skill and achievement, Raised in New York, a graduate of Harvard in 1952, Harry Mathews has lived since then in France and Italy; in 1960 he founded the review Locus Solus with John Ashbery, Kenneth Koch and James Schuyler.

title: Seining for Shad Under Way
description: LAMBERTVILLE  The yearly spawning migration of the American shad in the Delaware River is under way.

title: Notes: Summertime In the Snow Country
description: Think Snow was a phrase coined to stimulate interest in skiing, but these days people in the ski business are spending more and more time encouraging tourists to Think Sun. For years, resort towns in the Rockies have attracted summer visitors who want to go hiking, fishing, canoeing and horseback riding. Now the emphasis on summer attractions has spread to the Northeast, where the proliferation of tennis courts, swimming pools and condominiums around many ski areas in recent years is encouraging a lively tourist trade in the warmer months.

title: Carter and Sanford Support President On Mayaguez Step
description: Two former Governors from the South who are seeking the Democratic nomination for President gave their support yesterday to President Ford's use of military force to rescue the crew of the Mayagez.

title: A Ceremony of Swans
description: SWANS have a special status in Britain, one reason being that at least until the end of the Tudor period they were a gourmet dish at royal banquets. The introduction of the turkey ousted the swan as a table bird, but it continues to receive a special kind of reverence. Every July a party of men aboard six skiffs, each craft flying a large silk standard, row up the River Thames from Blackfriars in the center of London to carry out an ancient task: to establish the ownership of new cygnets on the river between London and HenleyonThames, about 40 miles to the west. The ceremony, which this year will take place July 2124, is known as SwanUpping.

title: Ketch Kialoa First Over Line in Edlu Race
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 17John Kihoy's Kialoa III. the 79foot ketch from Los Angeles, was first to finish this morning in the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual Edlu Trophy race, a 125mile overnight event around a triangular course in Long Island Sound.

title: Mayor Offers Hope of Avoiding Budget Cuts in SEEK Program
description: Mayor Beame told members of the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus yesterday that his recommendations for cuts in the City University's SEEK program budget do not have to be followed by the Board of Higher Education as long as the savings he desires in the total higher education budget are achieved.

title: Ship Is Welcomed Here After a Wait of 43 Years
description: Maiden arrival welcomes here come to ships early in life, usually at the end of the first voyage. Not so for the 25,245ton Britanis of Chandris Lines. The twinstacked passenger line?? had to wait 43 vears to make her debut here as a ?? set.

title: N. Ireland, England Tie
description: BELFAST, May 17Northern Ireland and English fought to a 00 draw in the British soccer championship match today.

title: He'll Be Returning to Princeton to Sell A Taste of His Life on French Vineyard
description: ST. EIMILION, FranceThe wine at the 25th anniversary dinner of the class of 1930 at Princeton University next month will be Chateau Belau. Montaiguillon, which is produced at a small viney ard about three miles from this worldfamous wine center.

title: Dave Anderson
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 17The face known throughout the world had a small purple blemish under the left eye. Muhammad Ali had a souvenir today from his 11 thround knockout of Ron Lyle, and in his vanity he was embarrassed. In his dressing room last night, the world heavyweight champion kept peeking into the mirror as he touched his swollen skin. The complexion of his face is miraculous for a boxer. It's as smooth as cocoa butter and he cherishes it. He likes to say, I'm so pretty, and indeed he is. He also is a gladiator. Perhaps some day that face suddenly will testify to the punches it has absorbed, as if he were Dorian Gray in white trunks. But because he is marked so seldom, the small purple blemish is a reminder of Muhammad Ali's glory.

title: Andrea Dobrow Is Bride of Pal Maleter
description: Andrea Faith Dobrow, traffic manager for Trade Media International, overseas advertising representatives, was married yesterday morning to Pal Bela Maleter, an architect. The Rev. R. Stanley Eaton. a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: On Hold: DialaRide
description: Critics of the American system often charge that many of society's problems remain without solution because people are unwilling to spend the money that would make the solutions work. The case of a mass transit system called dialaride seems to prove their point.

title: Norman LearDaring The Sitcom Audience
description: Los ANGELES On a recent morning Norman Lear, a distinguishedlooking man in his early 50's with a neatly trimmed fringe of silvery hair and sad eyes the washedout blue of his jean seats, glanced at the weekly Nielsen ratings list that enumerated TV's mostpopular shows and began circling the numbers beside the ones he producedtwo ... three ... five ... seven ... nine. He looked up over gold halfframe reading glasses perched on the tip of his nose at the visitor in his office and said with mock solemnity: This is an historic moment you're witnessing. The first time we've had five of the top 10 shows. Then he raised a fist in an equally theatrical fit of resolution and said through clenched teeth: Some day, some day five out of five! Lear's routine deliberately played off his least favorite sobriquet, King Lear, as well as a recent Bob Hope quip: We can all be proud of TV and its owner, Norman Lear. popular shows and began circling the numbers beside the ones he producedtwo ... three ... five ... seven ... nine. He looked up over gold halfframe reading glasses perched on the tip of his nose at the visitor in his office and said with mock solemnity: This is an historic moment you're witnessing. The first time we've had five of the top 10 shows. Then he raised a fist in an equally theatrical fit of resolution and said through clenched teeth: Some day, some day five out of five! Lear's routine deliberately played off his least favorite sobriquet, King Lear, as well as a recent Bob Hope quip: We can all be proud of TV and its owner, Norman Lear.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, MAY 18, 1975

title: Andrea Grass Wed to M. J. Mooney
description: Andrea Grass and Michael John Mooney were married yesterday afternoon in the Scarborough (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. William J. Clague, rector of St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough, performed the ceremony.

title: Mimi Garrard Dancers Present A Work of Lights and Shadows
description: The electronic lighting glamour of Mimi Garrard's Dance Theater is the company's chief asset and also its somewhat limiting frame. The presentation has such a look of fine luxury that it scarcely demands choreographic inventiveness Brazen, a Garrard work in progress, was given at the Exchange Theater on Friday evening, and it was glossily elegant, though not specially memorable for its dance design. tion has such a look of fine luxury that it scarcely demands choreographic inventiveness Brazen, a Garrard work in progress, was given at the Exchange Theater on Friday evening, and it was glossily elegant, though not specially memorable for its dance design.

title: Changes Urged in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) The chairmen of Senate committees would change every four years under a measure proposed this week by Senators Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, and Mark Hatfield, Republican of Oregon.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Before they went overseas to fight in World War II, thousands of American soldiers deposited their $25 War Bonds with the Treasury Department for safekeeping.

title: TB RISE SPARKED BY ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: FORT WORTH, May 17Illegal aliens entering the United States from Mexico are increasing the danger of Americans contracting tuberculosis, according to Dr. John A. Wiggins Jr., chairman of the state's Tuberculosis Advisory Committee.

title: Reds' Homers Beat Expos, 53, Ending 6Game Losing Streak
description: MONTREAL, May 17 (AP) Solo home runs by Ken Gaffey and Johnny Bench in the 10th inning powered Cincinnati to a 53 victory over the Montreal Expos today, ending the Reds' sixgame losing streak.

title: Sealyham Named Best In Show at Hempstead
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., May 17 Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl, a Sealyham imported from Wales by Mrs. Dorothy Wimer of Churchtown, Pa., and handled by Peter Green, who came to this country from Wales 12 years ago, won her 18th best in show today.

title: Galveston, Tex., Is Reawakening After a Long Slumber
description: GALVESTON, Tex.For decades she sat in a wilting snooze, rotting away beside palms and oleanders on her precarious Gulf Coast sandbar. Her fabled history and glorious 19thcentury mansions were snubbed by sixpackers cavorting on her beaches and by moneymakers marching their factories, pollution and fastfood culture south, ever closer, from Houston.

title: Assembly's Staff Triples Despite Call for Cutbacks
description: Despite the statebudget squeeze and an Executive Department hiring freeze, Democratic and Republican leaders in the Assembly have been increasing the Assembly staff every twoweek payroll period since last January.

title: Colorful Creations In Stained Glass
description: My earliest appreciation of stained glass was as a glorious escape from boredom during church services. I would sit through dull sermons watching the colors in the stained glass windows dim and brighten as clouds passed the sun, studying the lead lines and counting the different shades of each color. In later years I often thought about those church windows, regretting that all that beautiful glass was locked up inside such a solemn place. But since associated it only with religlous art, it never occurred to me to work in stained glass myself.

title: Rutgers Tightens Law School Rules
description: CAMDENIn a move designed to help students with academic problems handle the work load, the faculty at Rutgers Law School has approved a revamped program of support services. At the same time, however, it has adopted rules making it a little harder for those students who flunk out to be readmitted.

title: The wild men become nation
description: DAMASCUS In the nineteensixties, Syria was an off with his head country. I remember arriving in Damascus in 1963 and seeing workmen in Marjah Square taking apart a scaffolding that had been used that morning for a public hanging. There had been a coup, and those who kept count said it was the 11th since Syrian independence in 1946. The pattern was always the samean officer deployed some armor, occupied the radio station, took power and had himself elected President. He would govern until he was overthrown by another officer.

title: Whatever Else Changes in Brooklyn, the Traditional Ghosts Remain
description: The Brooklyn streets are filled with historical memories, not the least of which are the host stories in Flatbush, the Navy Yard district, South Brooklyn and Brooklyn Heights.

title: 3 Rainouts Fashion 3 Extra Twin Bills
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 (UPI)  Three rainedout games hay a been rescheduled as twilightnight doubleheaders, the National League office has announced.

title: The Jews of Damascus
description: One peculiarity of life in the Syrian capital is that while it is a military and economic headquarters for the struggle against Israel, it also contains its own Jewish quarter, which about 3,000 Sephardic Jews still inhabit. I repeatedly asked the Ministry of Information, through which I was supposed to arrange my schedule, for permission to visit the Jewish quarter. I was told: The Jews are complaining that we have sent too many journalists to see them. They say they are not animals in a zoo.

title: Eugenie M. McKay Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. George L. McKay Jr. of Flushing, Queens, and Candlewood Isle, Conn, have anncunced the engagement, of their daughter, Eugenie Maxine McKay, to Michael Kolwosky son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael Kolivosky of Hillsdale, Mich. The prospective bridegroom's father is clean of continuing education at Hillsdale College.

title: South Africa Easing Apartheid By Allowing Leases by Blacks
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 17 (Reuters)The decision that urban Africans are to be allowed 30year leasing rights to properties in black townships surrounding white cities instead of being forced to rent on a monthtomonth basis is a significant step in the South African Government's softening of its apartheid policy.

title: Opera: Elixir of Love
description: The Bronx Opera Company, which now makes regular visits to the Hunter College Playhouse in Manhattan, showed up this weekend with a sprightly production of Doniietti's The Elixir of Love. It was performed Friday night and last night.

title: 2 Lisbon Aides, Visiting U.S., Say Aim Is Goodwill
description: WASHINGTON, May 17Twice in 10 days, Cabinet ministers of Portugal's ruling Armed Forces Movement have visited Washington with the missions of learning something about the United States and explaining something about their own politics.

title: The Best Gatsby
description: If you seek an antidote to the image of F. Scott Fitzgerald the playboy, Fitzgerald the spoiled brat of American letters, or Fitzgerald the careless genius, you may now go to the source, the facsimile of the handwritten manuscript of The Great Gatsby, recently published by Matthew Bruccoli, editor of the Fitzgerald/Hemingway Annual.

title: Klein Farm Plan in Dispute
description: HAUPPAUGE  Suffolk County's ambitious $60million farmland preservation program apparently is caught in a crossfire over political and economic questions.

title: Rules on Moving Tightened
description: New Federal regulations governing longdistance moves have become effective in time for the peak moving season this summer.

title: Nigeria Says She Won't Dominate Area
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, May 17Expressing a keystone of Nigeria's foreign policy, the federal Commissioner for Economic Development and Reconstruction, Adebayo Adedeji, said that Nigeria has no plans to dominate the economies of our West African neighbors.

Like patting his head, rubbing his stomach and whistling simultaneouslyRonald Sukenick writes fiction that's revolutionary, funny and significant. He gets more mileage out of the experimental novel than just about anyone98.6 may go slowly but it will go far. It's a sort of acidage quest for the Holy Grail... success. Kirkus Reviews The author of a collection of stories. Death of the Novel and Other Stories, and two previous novels, Up and Out, Sukenick is observant, funny, wise, and playful. William Cole, Saturday Re

title: Gas Routs 150 in Michigan
description: MASON, Mich., May 17 (UPI) Some 150 residents were forced from their homes before dawn by deadly, eyesmarting ammonia gas escaping from a mobile tank. Three hours after the evacuation of a 14square block area on the west side of this city of 6,000 the residents were allowed to go home.

title: The Kidnapping of The Coffee Pot
description: There are few publishers whose books are so distinctive that the mention of their name conjures up an immediate picture of a recognizable style of children's books. One such publisher is Harlin Quist, whose latest book, The Kidnapping of the Coffee Pot, bears his hallmark of imaginative and distinguished bookmaking. It is a scary, funny, slapstick tale, reminiscent of Carl Sandburg's Wedding Procession of the Rag Doll and the Broom Handle. And it is set, of all places, in a city garbage dump. (Wonderfully depicted in the illustrations.)

title: Lebanon Reports a Mortar Shell Killed 7 Children at the Border
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 17A military spokesman here said today that seven Lebanese children were killed today and five wounded, three seriously, when a mortar shell left behind by Israeli troops exploded in a field outside the southern village of Aitaroun, where the children were playing.

title: In Cold Print: American Dilemmas
description: No publisher, it seems safe to say, would on its own, advance over one quarter of a million preinflation dollars to study a downbeat subject like race relations in America and purposely import, to conduct the study, a director among whose chief qualifications were that he have no familiarity with the subject (to guarantee that he have a fresh approach) and that he be from a country with no background or traditions of imperialism which might lessen the confidence of Negroes in the United States as to the complete impartiality of the study and the validity of its findings.

title: Mary Loughead Fiancee Of Robert F. Murchison
description: The engagement of Mary Margaret Loughead to Robert Frank Murchison has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Loughead Jr. of Westfield, N. J., and East Hampton, L I.; parents of the future bride. Her fianc is a son of Jane Coleman Murchison of New York and Clinton W. Murchison Jr. of Dallas and a grandson of the late Mr. Murchison, the industrialist who made a fortune in the Texas oil fields.

title: John Matthews, Lawyer, Weds Diane M. White
description: Diane Marie White, daughter of Mrs. Harold Percival White of Brattleboro, Vt., and the late Mr. White, and John Philip Matthews, son of Mrs. John Thomas Matthews of Houston and the late Mr. Matthews, were married yesterday afternoon at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Brattleboro by the Rev. Paul Thompson.

title: L.I.R.R. Tours of Island's Highlights to Start Today
description: The annual Long Island Rail Road tours of Long Island and Connecticut, which are scheduled to start today, Will enable tourists to become acquainted with the rich history of Long Island.

title: Rutgers Trackmen Capture Met Title
description: Rutgers won the Metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championship yesterday after a close, exciting contest. The Scarlet, with 64 points, edged Adelphi by 2 at St. John's University's synthetic track in Jamaica, Queens. Seton Hall, the defender, pointing toward the I.C. 4A meet next week, finished third with 50 points.

title: Sarah L. Bacon Bay State Bride
description: Sarah Livingston Bacon daughter of Katharine Jay Bacon of Cambridge, Mass., and Robert Bacon of Woods Hole, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Christopher Yates Crockett.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: ExSteel Builder Turns to Iron and Cement
description: Tanned and squarejawed, David Kent stood on the bow of the brigantine, brown eyes scanning the unruffled water of Port Jefferson Harbor on Long Island. He had worked seven days a week for three years, and a few days ago he made the final gesture  he bought a bottle of champagne. Today David Kent was expected to launch his graceful Enchantress, believed to be the largest boat built of ferrocement.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: It is ironic that most public companies today, despite the importance of debt financing and the increasingly dynamic nature of the bond market, still regard holders of their debt as secondclass citizens when it comes to giving them information. Relatively few even send them annual reports.

title: Clarice A. Gilchrist Is Married to Patrick E. Nelson
description: In St Paul's Episcopal Chapel in Lewisboro, N.Y. yesterday afternoon, Clarice Aileen Gilchrist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B Gilchrist Jr. of South Salem, N.Y., was married to Patrick Edmund Nelson. He is the son of Maj. Edmund Allen Nelson, U.S.M.C., retired and Mrs. Nelson of Timonium. Md. The Rev. Michael Shaefer performed the ceremony

title: FollowUp on The News
description: For a good two years, Gail Roszhart and her husband, Terry, tried without success to adopt a child in Southern California, until finally Mrs. Roszhart decided to ignore the advice of doctors and have her own baby. When their daughter, Leigh Anna, was born by caesarean section in November 1973, the event made news across the country.

title: Christmas package with a time bomb
description: A declaration that science has discovered has been for Americans a final judgment to which there is no court of appeal. The credibility of scientists and physicians has encouraged advocates of every shade of opinion about personal and governmental conduct to support their appeals with this nearly irrefutable authority. But on such questions as race. poverty, immigration, as well as the roller coaster of drug policy, science has often merely confirmed the consensus of popular opinion, If anything has been learned from more than a century of official response to drug misuse, it is that the latest scientific announcement with policy implications must be examined with the greatest care.

title: DOWNGRADING OF 110 PLANNED BY O'HAGAN
description: In a move to save about $400,000 a year, the Fire Deapartment plans to demote 110 officers one grade, with accompanying pay cuts ranging from $3,500 to $4,000.

title: South Brooklyn Residents Join to Ease the Disruption of City Construction
description: South Brooklyn residents have formed a committee to minimize the disruptive effects of four major construction projects that the city has planned for that area within the next five years.

title: Loughlin Sets 2Mile Relay Mark
description: HARTFORD, May 17Bishop Loughlin's twomile relay team, still smarting from not being picked for the Penn Relays championship event, shattered the Hartford Invitational track meet record today.

title: Calling It Kosher: How to and Why
description: You don't have to be Jewish to call on Rabbi Bernard Levy. In fact, each year many nonJews do call, write or visit with him at his office or theirs.

title: Poor Visibility Held Major Factor in L.I.R.R. Accidents
description: More than half of the 137 accidents in which people were trapped in Long Island Road train door in the last five years occurred at seven of the line's 140 stations, according to investigators for the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: Public Interest Lawyers Shocked by Supreme Court's Denial of Attorneys' Fees to the Winners of Lawsuits
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  A Supreme Court decision barring the award of attorneys fees to citizens' groups that win lawsuits establishing their rights has sent a shock wave through the profession of public interest law.

title: France Again Sets Forth to Conquer Computers
description: PARIS  To the French, computer independence is a ?? like the Holy Grail of Medieval legend  if approached by any but the most pure it gets borne away and vanishes.

title: MILTON SKURKA
description: Milton Skurka, president of Thayer International and seven other appasel companies, died yesterday of a heart attack at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 910 fifth Avenue.

title: Miss Burns Is Wed To S. P. Federman
description: Elizabeth Ann Burns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Burns Jr., of West Hartford. Conn., was married at noon yesterday to Stanley P. Federman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Federman of Brooklyn.

title: Northrop: Fame in Aircraft, Shame in Politics
description: BEVERLY HILLS. Calif.Of all the corporations sullied by the Watergate scandals, none has been as wholly dependent on Government contracts as the Northrop Corporation, an aerospace company which had about $400 million in revenues from the Federal Government last year.

title: Queens Museum Gets Boost
description: When Thomas P.F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was persuaded to take on the added title of acting director of the Queens Museum three months ago the young organization had just fired its second director in three years, several trustees had resigned in protest and the air was filled with accusation and acrimony.

title: New York's Desperation Reflects That of Its Poor
description: If New York City is forced into bankruptcy, it will primarily a casualty of four decades of expansion in the range, depth and cost of municipal services, many of them unique to the city. On a per capita basis, it does more for its people, especially the poor, than any other city.

title: Electric Bills Are Too High in Atom Work, Also
description: The Investigations of experimental physicists into the fundamental properties of the atom are suffering under a particularly ironic handicap. Some of the nuclear accelerators essential to their work are on downtime, in large part because their electric bills are straining their installations' budgets.

title: Seoul Opposition Leaders Shocked at Gulf Oil's Illegal Payments
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 17Opposition political leaders here expressed shock and anger today at the revelation that the Gulf Oil Corporation had contributed $4million to President Park Chung Hee's Democratic Republican party prior to the 1971 elections.

title: Shah of Iran Warms To Owning New York
description: WASHINGTON, May 17The Shah of Iran, asked at a news conference here today if he would be interested in buying New York City, smilingly replied: Owning New York would be a very appealing proposition.

title: Raw Materials: New Effort at Stable Prices
description: Secretary of State Kissinger finally buried last week America's traditional opposition to managed rawmaterial markets. In a speech in Kansas City, he announced that the United States was now ready to consider plans to stabilize world commodity prices, though only as part of a comprehensive effort to reorder world trade and improve relations between rich and poor.

title: BERLIN DROWNING INCREASES TENSION
description: BERLIN, May 17Political tensions between East and West Germany increased this week as the result of the drowning of a 5yearold boy last Sunday in a river along the border dividing Berlin.

title: Cup Ski to Retain Parallel Slalom
description: LECCO, Italy, May 17. (Reuters)The controversial parallel slalom event innovated in World Cup Skiing this year will be retained next reason, the Italian team's trainer. Matin Corelli, said here yesterday.

title: DialaRide System Expanded in Morris
description: MORRISTOWNThe DialaRide transportation system for Morris County's elderly residents is being expanded to provide free portaltoportal rides to nutrition sifts and the offices of social and volunteer services.

title: Losers Make No Excuses
description: BALTIMORE, May 17 Jacinto Vasquez didn't even flinch today at the announcement that his claim of foul against Master Derby in the 100th Preakness had been disallowed.

title: Headliners
description: In the 1960's Michael Abdul Malik, known as Michael X, was prominent in London's blackpower movement. But in 1970, he fled to Trinidad to escape blackmail and robbery charges. He set up a commune where, police investigating a fire in 1972, unearthed two bodies. both murdered with machetes. Mr. Malik fled again to Guyana but he and two associates were convicted of murder and sentenced to death. The associates/ sentences were later reduced to 20 years but last week Michael X was hanged in Port of Spain.

title: The Peppermint Pig
description: A peppermint pig, according to the milkman who took a shilling for it, is a pig that's not worth much, runt, a token of a pig. Nevertheless Nina Bawden's peppermint pig is worth a great deal to the Greenglass family. It becomes a special pet, has the run of the house and is the cause of considerable emotion in 9yearold Poll, who finds out in the end what can happen to a pig, special or not, when a family is in debt to a butcher. So the pig is one of the major elements of this plot. And so is Mr. Greenglass, though he makes only brief appearances. We worry that he won't appear at all. He's off in America seeking his family's fortunes while his family, shunted off to relatives in the country, try to make ends meet.

title: He Was Concerned About the Legal Prohibition on All Indochina Combat
description: As the affair of the Mayagez was played out last week, public and Congressional attention focused largely on questions of war, diplomacy and politics. But the Mayagez affair also raised profound questions of law and constitutionality. They were very much in the minds of White House lawyers and it was said, President Ford.

title: Brooklyn Garden Touches Nassau
description: ALBERTSON  When the late Grenville Clark made a gift of his stately 12acre home here to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden in 1966, the intent of his bequest was to create a horticultural and educational teaching facility, a source of learning and beauty for the entire community.

title: BRIDGE
description: The American record in international bridge competition presents one curious puzzle. Why is it that the United States, which has a wealth of great women players, has never won a world women's team title?

title: $280MILLION SALE OF NOTES PUT OFF BY GOLDIN ORDER
description: Faced with the possibility of no bids or bids with impossibly high interest rates on tornorrow's planned auction of $280million in city notes, Controller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday canceled the bidding and announced he would try to borrow the same sum in a negotiated sale.

title: Nazis Safer in South America Today
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 17Every afternoon businessmen, Government officials and shoppers crowd into the Confiteria La Paz for a drink or coffee under the motionless overhead fans and dim neon lights.

title: Manhattan College Graduates 800
description: To the music of an organ, more than 800 graduates wearing cap and gown filed into the Felt Forum yesterday for the 124th commencement exercise of Manhattan College. But the music changed when Mary Lou Williams, jazz pianist, composer and arranger, received an honorary degree of Doctor of Fine Arts and played the premiere of her Manhattan Degree.

title: Consecration Held At New Synagogue On East Side Site
description: Consecration ceremonies for the new Sutton Place Synagogue and Jewish Center for the United Nations at 223 East ?? at the site where the old temple had stood for 74 years before, its demolition.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York City's Environmental Protection Administration has approved con,struction of the longplanned Convention and Exhibition Center along the Hudson River. provided that the controversial center prohibits public parking in its garage and meets various other conditions. Under the stipulations, parking would be limited to 500 vehicles and would be authorized only for exhibitors, special center employes, handicapped people, public transit vehicles and trucks servicing the center. Original plans had called for 2,000 parking spaces, which had been a major complaint environmentalists.

title: Robinson Is Suspended 3 Days and Fined $250
description: CHICAGO, May 18 (AP)Frank Robinson of the Cleveland Indians, major league baseball's first black manager, has been suspended for three days and fined $250 for an altercation with an umpire, Jerry Neudecker, in last night's 101 loss to the Chicago White Sox.

title: Rangers Pick Coach
description: Ron Stewart, who played 21 seasons in the National Hockey League, is expected to be named the New York Ranger coach today. Stewart, who wound up his playing career with the New York Islanders in the 197273 season, will replace Emile Francis, who will remain the general manager. Page 37.

title: Met Streak Endedin 127 Astro Rout
description: HOUSTON, May 18After losing nine of their last 11 games, including the last two to the Mets, the Houston Astros took out their frustration today by pounding the New Yorkers, 127, in a ragged exhibition of baseball at the Astrodome.

title: Ford Urges Rededication to Ideals of the Revolution
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 18 President Ford declared here today that the United States would surmount rough times domestically and diplomatically by rededicating itself to the principles of the American Revolution.

title: U.S. Regrets Using Base in Note to Thais
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Monday, May 19 (AP)The United States Government sent a note to the Thai Government today expressing regret for the unauthorized use of Thai bases in the military action taken to rescue the freighter Mayagez and her crew. But the note stopped short of the apology demanded by the Bankok Government.

title: LEROY ANDERSON, WROTE POP MUSIC
description: WOODBURY, Conn., May 18 (UPI)Leroy Anderson, composer of popular music who wrote the wintertime standard Sleigh Ride during an August heat wave, as well as Blue Tango, died today of lung cancer at his home. He was 66 years old.

title: Plunging Into Bankruptcy; Or, How to Get New York Back Into The Swim
description: In his news conference Friday, Mayor Beame insisted that the refusal of the Republicans to accept his taxandaid package would force the elimination of 38,000 additional jobs from the budget he must present this week, closing hospitals and schools, and reducing police, fire and sanitation services. The cuts were both a response to New York City's desperate financial situation and a theatrical gesture to create an uproar and to put pressure on Albany and Washington.

title: Huong, President for Week, Pursues Quiet Life in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 18 (AP)Tran Van Huong, who was president of South Vietnam for a week after Nguyen Van Thieu stepped aside, now stays at home reading and tending his flower garden.

title: Europeans Outpace U.S. On Fast Breeder Reactor
description: This article was written for The New York Times by Chris FitzGerald, editorial director of Nuclear News, monthly publication of the American Nuclear Society, following a tour of nuclear facilities in France, Britain and West Germany.

title: 2 BOSTON RUES AT ODDS ON BUSING
description: BOSTON, May 18  A large stuffed lion with a toy school bus between its paws stood at the side of the podium as City Councilor Louise Day Hicks announced a national drive against busing for school desegregation.

title: Poker Match Won By Texan Holding Jacks in the Hole
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 18 (UPI)On the last deal of the world series of poker yesterday, Brian Roberts flipped over his hole cardsboth jacks  and cleaned up $210,000.

title: Screen: Popeye Doyle
description: Popeye Doyle is not dead. He's alive and treacherously hooked on heroin and pursuing drug dealers (on foot, pantingly) through Marseilles in French Connection II, John Frankenheimer's fairly stylish spinoff from Billy Friedkin's enormously successful 1971 original, The French Connection.

title: GIRL SHOT IN HEAD; BOY, 15, IS ARRESTED
description: A 15yearold boy who told the police he had paid $50 for a pistol to protect himself was arrested yesterday and accused of shooting and critically wounding a 16yearold girl during an earlymorning dispute in a Harlem hallway.

title: ADDISON W. PARRIS
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Addison W. Parris, a senior economist with the Small Business Administration, died here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 51 years old.

title: Curbs on Americans Relaxed in Lao City
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Monday, May 19United States Embassy officials here disclosed this morning that student demonstrators in the southern Laotian city of Savannakhet had relaxed restrictions on American officials and their families who have been held under house arrest since Wednesday.

title: SCHOOL AIDE FINDS HOME VANDALIZED
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, May 18 The home and automobile of the New Brunswick Superintendent of Schools were defaced last night with huge signs scrawled in iridescent paint warning Get out nigger, The KKK was here, and other racial slurs.

title: Carey Changes Stand on Primary Dates
description: ALBANY, May 18Governor Carey, who has been on record for months as favoring a return to a June statewide primary election, has now concluded that a separate primary in April for party officials and delegates to the national Presidential conventions would be advantageous.

title: Russians Are Stepping Up Exports of Tractors to U.S.
description: MINSK, U.S.S.R.  The Soviet Union, which has reaped heavy profits from the escalating demands for oil and gold, is now gearing up to meet what is seen here as a worldwide tractor shortage.

title: City Cash Crisis Linked to Plan to Keep Rents Low
description: The city's attempt to borrow $280million on shortterm notes today has become necessary because of a littlenoticed housing finance strategy, engaged in over the last several years, to keep rents down in cityassisted housing projects.

title: Antonia Brico, at 72, Finds Her Baton in High Demand
description: Everything comes if a man will only wait, wrote Disraeli. That, however, was in 1847. Nowadays his maxim can apply a bit more widely, if you ask Antonia Brico, a woman conductor who waited a long time but whose career is suddenly flowering. She is 72 years old.

title: ANDE MILLER MANNERS
description: Ande Miller Manners, writer best known for Poor Cousins, an account of the Jews who came to the United States from Eastern Europe around the turn of the century, died of cancer Saturday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. She was 51 years old and lived in Norwalk.

title: Hunter Stops A's Again, 91
description: Bill Virdon is no dummy. He wanted to hold a meeting to shake up his players, but he picked his spot  when Catfish Hunter was pitching.

title: Digging for Scandals Questioned by Nessen
description: TIFFIN, Ohio, May 18 (UPI) Reporters who always look for scandal, mistakes and wrongdoing in every news event and Government official are doing a disservice to themselves and their readers, Ron Nessen, the White House press secretary, said here today.

title: President Will Name 15 Winners of Annual White House Fellowships Today
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Tomorrow afternoon, in the rose garden if the weather is fair and inside the White House if it drizzles, President Ford will announce the names of 15 young men and women who have taken all the hurdles in an intellectual steeplechasethe 197576 White House fellows.

title: Screen: Popeye Doyle:'French Connection II' Is Very Different
description: Popeye Doyle is not dead. He's alive and treacherously hooked on heroin and pursuing drug dealers (on foot, pantingly) through Marseilles in "French Connection II," John Frankenheimer's fairly stylish spinoff from Billy Friedkin's enormously successful 1971 original, "The French Connection."Gene Hackman's Popeye Doyle, the hard-nosed, quick-tempered, narrow-minded New York police officer, was just about the only identifiable human amid all the spectacular wreckage in the first film.Popeye hasn't gone soft or genteel in "French Connection II." If anything, he appears to have become a bit more of a magnificent boor as he charges around the Marseilles waterfront, belting a lot of the bad guys (as well as a few of the good ones by mistake), wondering dimly why no one understands good English and behaving, in general, like an upper-class Frenchman's nightmare of an American tourist run amok.Although the producers of "French Connection II" would like to emphasize that this is an entirely new film, with no real connection to the first one, they aren't above associating the two through the title and the use of the central character, whose individuality depends more on Mr. Hackman than it does on the material supplied by the screenwriters.The two films are exceedingly different The Friedkin picture was as much a hallucinogenic portrait of life in that New York half world shared by the police and criminals as it was a superior suspense melodrama. "French Connection II" is nowhere near so complex, though it's still entertaining.In these further adventures of Popeye Doyle, the American detective is the entire subject of the film. Marseilles, its inhabitants and its ways of life provide the exotic backgrounds and raw materials for the movie's various specialty numbers, principally chases in which Popeye and his French counterparts attempt to nab drugdom's Mr. Big, the character played by Fernando Rey, who disappeared at the end of "The French Connection."The concerns of "French Connection II" are not much different from those of old Saturday-afternoon movie serials that used to place their supermen in jeopardy and then figure ways of getting them out. The difference is in the quality of the supermen and in their predicaments.Popeye is a colorful and interesting  though hardly noble  character, and when the Marseilles drug people kidnap him, forcibly create a heroin habit in him, and then release him, you have a very special kind of jeopardy that the film and Mr. Hackman exploit most effectively. The perverse intensity and the anguish in these sequences recall some of Mr. Frankenheimer's best work in "The Manchurian Candidate" and "Seconds."The supporting cast includes Bernard Fresson, as Popeye's worried French associate, and Cathleen Nesbitt, as an ancient charwoman in the hotel where Popeye is held prisoner. In one brief, beautiful scene, the old woman, herself a ravaged addict, tenderly advises the drugged American not to rave and shout, while at the same time she is stealing his watch.

title: Dance: FairyTale Debut
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 Why did Gelsey Kirkland cleave the safe, patriarchal haven of the New York City Ballet? Had she stayed, she would have been dancing in George Balanchine's Ravel Festival. But she decided that she needed something outside the inevitable confines of the Balanchine repertory, and she has thrown in her lot with American Ballet Theater. This afternoon at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the wisdom of her choice became evident.

title: EARL O. MILLER
description: Earl O. Miller, a retired production engineer with the Kaiser Motors Corporation and a longtime resident of Toledo, Ohio, died Saturday in Haven Hubbard House, New Carlisle, Ind. He was 86 years old.

title: Pathet Lao Injecting Austerity Into Easy Texture of Laotian Life
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 18For decades Maurice the money changer sat at the battered desk just inside the crumbling Grecian portico of his aging Constellation Hotel on Samsenthai Street carefully doling out the neatly wrapped stacks of kip he has exchanged for greenbackswhose value is a sensitive barometer of the shifting weather of the Laotian capital.

title: SADAT WILL SPEAK FOR ARAB NATIONS AT FORD MEETING
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 18President Anwar elSadat, winding up a weeklong tour of four Arab nations, declared here today that he had obtained a mandate to speak for the Arab world, not just Egypt, when he meets with President Ford in Salzburg, Austria, on June 1.

title: Portuguese Protest at the U.S. Embassy
description: LISBON, May 18 (UPI) Demonstrators waving red flags and shouting anti  American slogans gathered outside the United States Embassy here Sunday vandalized diplomatic vehicles and splashed the walls with red paint.

title: Recession Kills Black TeenAger Hopes
description: Tens of thousands of black and Puerto Rican teenagers in New York City are piling up at the bottom of the recession. With no jobs and no prospects of jobs, they are abandoning their dreams of education, and their belief in the other institutions of a civilized society, and are slipping back toward the drugs and hustling of the street.

title: State of the City: Welfare and Hospitals
description: Two distinguishing marks of the city's humanitarian spiritits welfare system and its municipal hospitalshave turned into plague areas, wasteful of public funds and destructive of people. In both fields New York has pioneered, out of recognition of governmental responsibility to care for those who cannot care for themselves. In both, the end results have been disastrousfor community and clients alike.

title: Ship Rescue Toll 5 Killed, 16 Missing, 7080 Hurt
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger announced today that the number of American casualties in last week's effort to rescue the freighter Mayagtiez and her crew was larger than initially reported.

title: A Truck Driver From Brooklyn, Left Behind in Saigon Evacuation, Continues Search for His Fiancee
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 18 (AP)The abrupt American evacuation from Saigon left behind about two dozen Americans, 150 South Koreans and 200 Filipinos who wanted to flee on the airlift, according to figures of an international relief official.

title: Beach Nudity Ban on Today
description: WELLFLEET, Mass., May 18 (AP)A ban on nudity at the Cape Cod National Seashore goes into effect tomorrow and (ready rangers say they are ready to arrest any offenders. Lawrence Hadley, seashore superintendent, said only five rangers would be patrolling the beaches until early June, when the force will increase to 42.

title: The Big Apple In a Big Pickle
description: We call New York The Big Apple, a Runyonesque phrase lifted from racetrack lingo, meaning the big time where the high purses could be won. In the early thirties, the phrase was applied to Harlem by jazz buffs, and a nightclub called The Big Apple flourished; a frenetic dance by that name popularized the term nationally.

title: Advertising
description: Last week lain Tennant, chairman of Glenlivet Distillers, Ltd., made a swing around the United States, where 43 per cent of the production of Scotch whisky is consumed. And while Mr. Tennant was singing the praises of Scotch brands in general, he sang particularly loud about his own brand, The Glenlivet.

title: New Voting Law Faces AllOut Legal Challenge
description: WASHINGTON, May 18Dean Burch came out of the first meeting of President Ford's informal campaign planning committee, at which he had presided, and remarked:

title: 2 Drivers Bumped At Indy
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 18 (UPI)Only two drivers, Tom Bigelow and Eldon Rasmussen made successful qualifying runs today to complete the secondfastest lineup in Indianapolis 500 history.

title: DR. L. CABOT BRIGGS, ANTHROPOLOGIST, 65
description: Dr. L. Cabot Briggs, an anthropologist who wrote several books on the peoples of the Sahara, died of cancer Wednesday in Hancock, N.H. He lived there and in Boston. His age was 65.

title: TV: On Abbie Hoffman
description: Tonight, at 9, Abbie Hoffman is interviewed on Channel 13, courtesy of TVTV, a videotape production group, and Ron Rosenbaum, a reporter whose print version of the interview appears in the current issue of New Times magazine. Mr. Hoffman asked $5,000 for the interview and received an $800 video cassette player plus $3,000$2,500 from TVTV (with Channel 13 funds) and $500 front Mr. Rosenbaum, who, aware of certain sensitivities, gave the money to TVTV and  technically at least  not directly to Mr. Hoffman. In several respects, the project represents one of the more bizarre journalistic undertakings of recent times.

title: Jipcho Second In Coast Mile
description: EUGENE, Ore., May 18 (AP)  Australia's Chris Fisher handed Ben Jipcho a rare defeat in the mile at the International Track Association meet today, setting a professional record of 3 minutes 57.3 seconds.

title: Jolley Blames Pimlico Track
Railroad Fined in Oil Spill
description: BOSTON, May 18 (UN) Maine Central Railroad has been fined $750 for an oil spill in St. Johnsbury, Vt., last fall, the United States Environmenal Protection agency said oday. The spill occurred Nov. 12 when a derailment caused a tanker car to rupture and spill between 1,000 and 2,000 gallons of diesel oil into Moose Lake and the Passumpsic River.

title: MILTON SKURKA
description: Milton Skurka, president of Thayer International and seven other apparel companies, died Saturday of a heart attack at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 910 Fifth Avenue.

title: Dance: A Joint Concert
description: Carla Maxwell, a leading member of the Jose Limon Dance Company, and Stanley B. Sussman, a composer who bas conducted for the Martha Dance Company since 1966 as well as other dance troupes, offered a joint concert of dance and music Saturday night at Larry Richardson's Dance Gallery.

title: Down by 16, Warriors Topple Bullets
NURSINGHOME PANEL TO SEND OUT QUERIES
description: Morris B. Abram, chairman of the state's Moreland Commission, said yesterday he would send out questionnaires today in his investigation of the nursinghome industry, and he warned he would make public the names of those who did not reply within a week.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, MAY 19, 1975

title: Panel Will Seek to Improve Supplemental Income Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) A special fivemember panel was announced today to study the problemplagued Supplemental Security Income program and to recommend administrative and legislative improvements.

title: Brick Township Drops the Idea Of Regular YearRound Schools
description: BRICK TOWNSHIP, May 18 The Board of Education here, bowin gto residents' protests, has reluctantly abandoned a plan that could have led to New Jersey's first compulsory yearround school program.

title: KENNEDY TO BEGIN MIDDLE EAST TOUR
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, May 18Senator Edward M. Kennedy will begin a fourday visit to Saudi Arabia Thursday at the start of a Middle East trip.

title: Platinum Fabricators Turning On the Charm
description: The Platinum Information Bureau, which was recently established here to promote the sale of platinum in jewelry, has started a milliondollar magazine ad campaign to tell its story. Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, Inc., the agency telling it, is going after two primary markets: brides and empty nesters.

title: Consciousness Was Raised, Lives Were Changed
description: CROTON  ON  HUDSON, N.Y.  A reunion, complete with Chinese takeout and Sangria, was celebrated here recently in a modest white clapboard house on a suburban street.

title: Article 2  No Title
Card of Thanks
description: HIRSCHORNMorris. ?? pressions of sympathy in their recent bereavement.

title: Uncrowned and Undismayed
description: Darrel McHargue is a beautiful young Okie with golden brown curls that escape in ringlets from under his cap, and soulful brown eyes. Looking back into his level gaze, you know he could never be guilty of dissembling. And you know he couldn't have been talking about the Preakness Stakes when he said: We went for the same hole and got there first. I just had a little better horse under me. He had to be thinking of some other race, because that was no hole he was some for when he and Master Derby veered in front of Foolish Pleasure in the Pimlico home stretch. McHargue and his mount had been as much as three lengths ahead of the field and they were still all alone with at least a length and a half spare when they drifted out into the favorite's path. Jacinto Vasquez said he had to duck inside with Foolish Pleasure, making the horse change course at a crucial point, but the steward said, Sorry 'Cinto, no foul. Fact is, Master Derby kept on drifting out and Vasquez could have gone inside the winner just by maintaining straight course.

title: THOMSON ALLY GETS A KEY POST IN PARTY
description: CONCORD, N. H., May 18New Hampshire's sharply divided Republican State Committee today elected as its chairman, Gerald P. Carmen of Manchester, a key lieutenant to Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr., critic of President Ford.

title: Met Baseball Title Won by Seton Hall
description: TEANECK, N.J., May 18 Seton Hall University won its third straight Metropolitan Conference baseball title by defeating Fordham University, 62, today. It was the second game in the playoffs after the regular season schedule had ended in a threeway tie.

title: Common Market Gains
description: At a time of widespread disillusionment with the idealism that underpinned efforts at international cooperation after World War II, two recent developments the European Community are worth noting:

title: FORD PLANS BILLS TO EASE CONTROL OVER TRANSPORT
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The Ford Administration will send Congress this week the first of three proposals aimed at fundamentally changing the way the Federal Government regulates transportation, a move that may become the principal domestic focus of President Ford's campaign to be elected next year.

title: Hudson Convention Center Approved by City Agency
description: The city's Environmental Protection Administration has approved construction of the long  planned Convention and Exhibition Center along the Hudson River in the West 90's, after sponsors of the controversial center agreed to prohibit public parking in its garage and to meet various other) conditions.

title: LATIN AID LOANS TOP $1BILLION IN A YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The InterAmerican Development Bank reported today that its lending to LatinAmerican and Caribbean countries passed the $1billion mark for the first time last year.

title: Intelligence Adviser Appointed by Rabin In Wake of Inquiry
description: TEL AVIV, May 18Premier Yitzhak Rabin appointed a special adviser for intelligence matters today, in an effort to prevent a recurrence of such blunders as the mistaken evaluations of Arab strategy just before the 1973 war.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An 88foot tugboat that capsized in Rockaway Inlet on Friday, touching off a frantic but successful scubadiver rescue of four crewmen trapped in an air bubble in the overturned craft, was righted, pumped out and refloated yesterday. The Coast Guard announced that a court inquiry would be convened this week to investigate the cause of the accident.

title: Solomon Boneparth Dies; ExJustice of City Court
description: Solomon Boneparth, who retired as a justice of the City Court in the Bronx in 1957, died Friday in Miami, where he lived. He was in his late 80's.

title: Canada Tries to Grapple With a Slipping Economy
description: OTTAWA, May 18An American walked into a Canadian bank the other day and, presenting a $100 check on his New York bank to be cashed, was pleasantly surprised to get back $103 and change in Canadian money. The American had been accustomed to losing on such transactions since the Canadian dollar began to float upward a few years ago.

title: Joel Goldsmith Weds Diane Schwartz Here
description: Diane Schwartz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving L. Schwartz of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., was married here yesterday evening to Joel H. Goldsmith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Goldsmith of New York and Fire Island, L. I.

title: GREEKS AND TURKS HOPEFUL AT TALKS
description: ROME, May 18The Foreign Ministers of Greece and Turkey went into their second day of talks here today, marking the first highlevel contacts between their two Governments in more than six months. Later they voiced cautious optimism that tension between their countries might be eased.

title: Mansfield Asks Recognition Of New Indochina Regimes
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI) Senate Majority Leader Mike Mansfield called today for diplomatic recognition of the new Communist Governments in Southeast Asia to avoid repetition of the Mayagez crisis and its resolution by military force.

title: US. Scores on China Track
description: CANTON, China, May 18 (AP)  Thank God, it's over, Fred Newhouse of Baton Rouge, La., exulted after breaking a rainsoaked tape and becoming the first American ever to win a foot race in the People's Republic of China.

title: U.S. Officials Study Correspondence Schools for Possible Fraud in Federally Guaranteed Student Loans
description: CHICAGO, May 18Federal officials have begun an inyestigation of correspondence schools across the country for possible fraud in connection with a federally guaranteed student loan program.

title: Balkanizing the Bronx
description: Never underestimate the power of Bronx politicians, Democratic or Republican. The boys have got togetherState Democratic and Bronx County chairman, Patrick Cunningham, and Bronx County Republican chairman, Senator John D. Calandraand put a big one over the New York State Senate. They would split off the Bronx from the First Judicial District, which it now shares with Manhattan, and create a separate district.

title: Ryan Wins No. 8, But Misses 3d Shutout in Row
description: Walks have been just as much a trademark of Nolan Ryan as strikeouts, and yesterday a walk cost him a shutout. But the California righthander posted a twohit, 51 decision over the Baltimore Orioles with some relief help, and joined Vida Blue of Oakland as the only eightgame winners in the majors.

title: PARLEY ON ROADS ASKED BY SCHULER
description: State Transportation Commissioner Raymond T. Schuler asked in weekend telegrams to meet with his environmentalist critics to clear up the confusion ... which obviously exists about his views toward the National Environmental Policy Act of 1970.

title: Harry Eisner, ExPrincipal Of Lane High School, Dies
description: Dr. Harry Eisner, principal of Franklin K. Lane High School, Brooklyn, from 1948 to 1962, died Friday in Miami, where he lived. His age was 81.

title: The Morning After
description: CHICAGOThe rule laid down by the United States in the Mayagez affair must go something like this:

title: ALEXANDER BELLER, PSYCHOANALYST, 52
description: Dr. Alexander Beller, clinical associate professor of psychiatry at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died yesterday of cancer in New York Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 118 Riverside Drive.

title: Majority Leader's Comments on Aid Differ From Days When He Said Yes
description: ALBANY, May 18In the midst of saying no to Mayor Beame's request for budget aid last week, the majority leader of the Senate, Warren M. Anderson, included a few interesting words of contrition about the old days when, with Nelson A. Rockefeller as his party leader and Governor, he used to say yes.

title: KATHE SCHOENBERG IN OFFBEAT PROGRAM
description: Kathe Schoenberg brought some refreshingly offbeat programing to her Carnegie Recital Hall concert Saturday night. After a conventional start with songs by Purcell and Schumann, the mezzosoprano turned to the gorgeous Opus 91 Brahms songs, with viola, then went on keto a pair of thematically oriented groupsHungarian vilage airs arranged by Zoltan Kodaly and Laszlo Lajtha, and an engaging set of almost lullabies by CastelnuovoTedesco, Britten and Richard Strauss.

title: DELINQUENCY RATE ON MORTGAGES UP
description: LOS ANGELES  Mortgage bankers say that monthly payment delinquency rates on home mortgages arc climbing in many parts of the country as a byproduct of the nation's worst recession in more than 25 years.

title: Flyers Win and Lead, 20
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 18 Though Buffalo had promised a surprise for game No. 2 today in the National Hockey League championship playoffs, the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Sabres, 21, on what proved to be no surprise at all: A goal and an assist by Bobby Clarke.

title: Photo Shows First Evidence of Electricity in Form of Fluid
description: Scientists at the University of California at Berkeley have taken a photograph that shows for the first time electricity in a fluid droplet form.

title: Dance: FairyTale Debut
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 Why did Gelsey Kirkland leave the safe, patriarchal haven of the New York City Ballet? Had she stayed, she would have been dancing in George Balanchine's Ravel Festival. But she decided that she needed something outside the inevitable confines of the Balanchine repertory, and she has thrown in her lot with American Ballet Theater. This afternoon at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the wisdom of her choice became evident.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supp?? mentary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities cold have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Influx of Retired People to Ozarks a Mixed Blessing
description: HARRISON. Ark.Arkansas thought it wanted more people. It lost 163,000 of them from 1940 to 1960, and it became alarmed.

title: MARCHI SAYS AID TO CITY DEPENDS ON BUDGET LIMIT
description: State Senator John J. Marchi said yesterday that Mayor Beame would have to commit the city to some ceiling on spending in the coming year to get state aid, but added that the ceiling amount would be negotiable and part of the political process.

title: Laura Foreman Does 2 Dances With Imaginative Use of Space
