description: The city municipal unions will announce today plans for a demonstration on June 4 in front of the offices of the First National City Sark to dramatize their assertion that the banks are bleeding the city by imposing high interest rates on city borrowing.

title: North Koreans Report Big Sihanouk Welcome
description: TOKYO, May 19 (AP) Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia arrived in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, today and was warmly greeted by President Kim Il Sung and tens of thousands of workers, a broadcast said.

title: DUNAS KEEPS ADDING WORDS TO HIS DANCE
description: The increasing use of words in William Dunas's works has gone hand in hand with do creasing imaginativeness in devising choreographic structures. to accompany them. Since Mr. Dunas dues both words and movement, it is a case of robbing Terpsichore to pay Tilespis. Storey: An American. Narrative, the latest in the word series, was presented Sunday evening at the Ambrose Arts Foundation, 435 Broome Street.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: The search for fiscal alleviation by appealing to the state and Federal Governments is putting a BandAid on a cancer.

title: AUTHOR URGES LIMIT OF 4 TERMS IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI) House careers should be limited to four terms, but a selfimposed limit will never become a reality without citizen pressure, the author of a new book on Congress says.

title: Italians Shrug at Business Graft They've Heard of It Before
description: ROME, May 19  It isn't taught in business schools yet, but any fledgling executive who wants to get ahead in Italy had better bone up on what is called here the strate gy or lubrication.

title: Zapata Corp. Unit Acquires Doverspike Coal Co.
description: The Zapata Corporation or Houston reported yesterday that a wholly owned subsidiary, Penn West Fuels, Inc., had acquired the Doverspike Brothers Coal Company, a privately held coal mining company in western Pennsylvania. The transaction, which Zapata said involved about $20million in notes and cash, adds about 8,000 acres, near Kittanning, Pa., to Zapata's coal properties. In the fiscal year ended last Sept, 30, Zapata, a diversified natural resources company, indicated that coalmining operations ac counted for about 4 per cent of its revenues and about 2 per cent of its income.

title: Strangers and Natives
description: Some of the furor over the admission of Vietnamese refugees through the golden door symbolized by the Statue of Liberty Seems to have subsided. That is fortunate, as the United States could hardly, in this single Instance for which it bears so much responsibility, have sacrificed a long tradition of hospitality to the homeless, tempesttossed of all nations.

title: Dealers Get Permission To Trade A.T.&T.Stock
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that it had granted deaters permission for 48 hours to trade in American Telephone and Telegraph Company stock in the socalled thirdmarket, away from the floor of the New York exchange.

title: NoName Warrior Wins Sudden Fame
description: Phil Smith failed to make the National Basketball Association allrookie team this year nor did he get a vote for rookieoftheyear honors. Until his 20point performante Sunday against the Washington Bullets in the first game of the championship round, he was a Golden State noname. having averaged 13 minutes of playing time during the regular season and 11 in the playoffs.

title: Sargent May Run in 1976
description: BOSTON, May 19 (UPI) Francis Sargent, the former Republican Governor of Massachusetts, says he may seek Senator Edward M. Kennedy's seat in 1976, but only if Mr. Kennedy is out of the race. Although Mr. Kennedy has said he will not seek the Democratic Presidential nomination. Mr. Sargent said, You can never tell.

title: Channel 13 to Show Hockey Tonight at 8
description: Channel 13 will televise tonight's Stanley Cup hockey playoff game at 8 P.M. from Buffalo between the Sabres and Philadelphia Flyers. The fourth game, Thursday night, at Buffalo, will be covered by Channel 9.

title: Con Ed Chief, at Meeting, Scores Taxes and Ecologists
description: Shareholders of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York were told yesterday at the annual meeting that earnings were expected to improve again this year, but that longterm recovery depended on a number of other factors, including greater use of nuclear energy and relaxation ?? vironmental standards.

title: Dinosaur Prints Halt Work
description: GLEN ROSE, Tex., May 19 (UPI)Construction on a multimillion dollar nuclear power plant has been stopped this week to allow archeologists to chop out limestone footprints of a dinosaur that roamed the region in prehistoric times. Workmen found dinosaur footprints in the limestone. and a Texas Utilities Company representative began making plaster casts of the prints at the site. Dr. S. Alan Skinner, an archeologist at Southern Methodist University, found 10 identifiable prints.

title: Parliament Goes on Air For First Time June 9
description: LONDON, May 19 (Reuters)  The first live radio broadcast from the House of Commons on June 9 will be heard around the world, the British Broadcasting Corporation announced today.

title: MOSCOW STALLED IN FOREIGN POLICY
description: MOSCOW, May 19  The Kremlin's efforts to promote Soviet prestige through a succession of forums abroad appear to have been stalled despite some advantages offered by recent American setbacks.

title: Senate Approves Repeal Of State Fair Trade Law
description: TRENTON, May 19A consumer bill repealing the state's Fair Trade Law prohibiting appliance and clothing stores from selling goods below manufacturers' retail prices received final approval in the Senate today, 33 to 3.

title: SUSPICIOUS FIRES HIT TRADE CENTER
description: A series of seven suspicious fires, including an extensive twoalarm blaze, struck the World Trade Center in quick succession last night, keeping harried firemen scurrying from floor to floor and tower to tower for more than two hours.

title: Ford Sends Congress a Bill to Reduce Federal Control Over Railroad Rates
description: WASHINGTON, April 19President Ford sent Congress today a bill to reduce Federal control of railroad ratesthe first in a series of three transportation proposals the White House says will lead to lower costs and better service for travelers and shippers.

title: Poles Offer 36% on Defaulted Bonds
description: A final offer of settlement to holders of preWorld War II dollar bonds has been made by the Polish Government.

title: Thousands in Chinatown March in Police Protest
description: Thousands of Chinese and ChineseAmericans, chanting in Cantonese, marched through Chinatown to City Hall yesterday to protest an incident of alleged police brutality and to call for an end to discrimination.

title: Cyclops Corp. Won't Reopen 2 Steel Facilities in Ohio
description: PITTSBURGH, May 19 (UPI)  The Cyclops Corporation said today it would not reopen its mills at Portsmouth and Mansfield. Ohio, and that 1,000 furloughed workers at Portsmouth and 250 at Mansfield will be dropped permanently. The two plants were closed this spring.

title: TURKEY AND GREECE TO MEET IN BRUSSELS
description: ROME, May 19Greece and Turkey agreed today that their heads of government would meet in Brussels late this month to discuss the future of Cyprus and other disputes.

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: Dr. David Lewis, 71, Taught Chemistry at City College

title: Fears Over Gas Terminal Voiced at Hearing on S.I.
description: Staten Island residents got chance last night to express their fears and anger over projected liquefiednaturalgas terminal before a Federal agency that is empowered to halt construction of the terminal.

title: Mutiny by Mayaguez Captors Reported
description: WASHINGTON, May 19A report was circulated at high levels of the Defense Department today that the crew on the Cambodian patrol boat that stopped the American merchant ship Mayagez mutinied and set sal for Thailand.

title: State of the City: School and Campus
description: New York City's 950 public schools, staffed by a force of 60,000 teachers and administrators, enroll 1.1million childrenapproximately onethird of the state's school population and more than the schools of all but fourteen states. The City University's network of campusesone graduate center, ten fouryear colleges and nine twoyear community collegesenrolling 266,000 students (including parttime), taught by a faculty of 17,000, constitutes one of the largest institutions of higher education in the world.

title: Election Law Defects
description: In our opinion, the evidence supports a finding that there was a reckless disregard of the limitations contained in section 455 of the law... wherefore it is our considered judgment that there is reasonable cause to believe that a violation of the law warranting criminal prosecution has taken place...

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the Arts and Leisure Guide of The New York Times last Sunday, the Western Wind music concert this Friday at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 120 West 69th Street, was listed incorrectly as beginning at 9 P.M. The concert starts at 8.

title: JULY WHEAT IS UP BY 17C A BUSHEL
description: July wheat, the first of the new crop months, jumped 17 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade to close at $3.25, one of the biggest movements recently.

title: A VORSTER APPEAL TO LIBERIAN CITED
description: LONDON, May 19  Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa has appealed to President William R. Tolbert Jr. of Liberia to arrange a meeting between South African and black African leaders, The Times of London reported today:

title: A T.W.A. FARE RISE OPPOSED IN C.A.B.
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board was urged by its consumer office yesterday to reject Trans World Airlines' request for a new 5 per cent fare increase and instead, to bring about a fare rollback.

title: People in Sports
description: Joe Dey, the retired commissioner of the Tournament Players Division of the Professional Golfer's Association, and Fred Corcoran, who dreamed up the World Cup competition, were named to the World Golf Hall of Fame yesterday. They will be enshrined in the Hall on Sept. 10 during Pinehurst (N. C.) Grand Week of Golf, which culminates in the playing a the $200,000 World open championship. Dey and Corcoran were named on 75 per cent of the golf writers' ballots and beat five others in the distinguished service category. Seven players failed to receive the necessary votes in the modernera category.

title: Files Said to Link Mafia To C.I.A. in Plot on Castro
description: WASHINGTON. May 19The Rockefeller commission has learned of documents supporting the charge that the Central Intelligence Agency contracted with the Mafia in a plot in 1961 to kill Cuban Premier Fidel Castro, authoritative sources reported today.

title: G.S.A. Backs Bill to Preserve And Convert Historic Buildings
description: WASHINGTON, May 19A, bill that would commit the Federal Government to preserving buildings of historical and architectural significance, rather than automatically demolishing and rebuilding, Was endorse today by the General Service Administration, the Govern ment's landlord.

title: All Pupils in the State Will Have to Have Shots
description: TRENTON, May 19 (UPI)The State Health Department announced today that effective Sept. 1 it will require all schoolchildren in New Jersey to be immunized against six diseases. The only exceptions will be pupils who show reactions to shots who refuse on religious principles.

title: M. T. A. RECEIVES $87.5MILLION AID
description: A United States Treasury check for $87.5million was delivered at City Hall yesterday afternoon as the first install ment of the new Federal subsidy to help pay transit operating deficits here.

title: NEW RULES ISSUED ON CRIMINAL FILES
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) The Justice Department announced today art order establishing regulations governing release of federally compiled or federally aided information about criminal records and criminal histories.

title: Chicken Truck Wrecked
description: NASHVILLE, May 19 (AP)A truck loaded with more than 8,000 live chicekens overturned today, forcing thousands of suburban commuters to find an alternate route to work, the police said. The driver of the truck told the police his rear wheels locked, causing the flatbed trailer loaded with caged chickens to overturn on the Silliman Evans bridge.

title: Some Aid to City Coming, G.O.P State Senators Say
description: ALBANY, May 19Some new city taxing authority and some new state aid are likely to be given to New York City, the city's Republican Senators, whose support is crucial to any budgetbalancing package for the financially pressed Beame administration, said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: O.A.S. SESSION ENDS; IT IS CALLED SUCCESS
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The Organization of American States concluded its annual General Assembly today after what diplomats described as the most constructive session in many years.

title: MIXUPS CHARGED IN ORPHAN AIRLIFT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 19Several witnesses testified in Federal District Court here today that during Operation Mrlift at the Presidio Army Base, doctors switched identifications of children, children were lost and not found later, other children were never identified, and come of the children who were brought here from Vietnam last month were not orphans.

title: Detente: Past and Future
description: A French word with a double meaning is the central subject as the American and Russian foreign ministers confer in neutral Austria. Dtente not only means relaxation of tension; Harrap's dictionary also translates it as trigger (of pistol, rifle, etc.). Whether dtente will lead to peace or end by triggering new conflicts is the overwhelming question facing a postVietnam world.

title: 18 CITY FOOD PLACES TERMED VIOLATORS
Head of Lawyers Group Scores Doctors' Strikes
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 19 (UPI)The recent outbreak of doctors strikes are a flagrant violation of physicians fiduciary trust to provide quality medical care. the head of the nation's largest trial bar association said today.

title: Thais Accept U.S. Regrets; Crisis Over Base Is Eased
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 19The Thai Government accepted as a formal apology today an American note expressing regret over the misunderstandings that had arisen over use of a Thai base to recover the Mayagez and her crew.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
3 Quintuplets Doing Well
description: CINCINNATI. May 20 (AP)Univxersity of Cincinnati Medical Center officials report that the three Lvy quintuplets still hospitalized are doing well and gaining weight. Doctors declined to speculate when the babies, born April 22, would be able to leave the hospital. Two of the children went home to Fairfield with their mother, Pamela Levy, earlier this month.

title: Defense in 2d Attica Trial Says State Hid Evidence
description: BUFFALO, May 20The second major Attica trial began today with lawyers for a former inmate contending that the prosecution concealed evidence from the grand jury that would have exonerated their client, who is charged in the killing of two fellow inmates.

title: Bridge:
description: The world's biggest charity bridge event, if one excludes the continentwide games of the American Contract Bridge League, was played here Monday night at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel. Two hundred eighty players, including more than 40 topranked experts, took part in the annual United Jewish Appeal game, and contributed some $27,000 to help enlarge the Teacher's College in Jerusalem.

title: SIRHAN IS GRANTED PAROLE FOR 1986
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 20 (UPI)Sirhan Sirhan, convicted of assassinating Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was granted a parole date of Feb. 23, 1986, by the California Adult Authority, today. Mr. Sirhan, who was originally sentenced to death, would end up serving 16 years and 9 months under the parole date.

title: New Jersey Crewman Home
description: NEWARK May 20Wilbert Bock, radio operator of the Mayaguez arrived here toriight and was greeted by his wife, Marion, and other family, members He will hold a news conference tomorrow at his home in Bogota, in Bergen County.

title: Tomahawks Lose In Lacrosse, 1511
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., May 20 (AP)  John Grant recorded 10 assists for a National Lacrosse League record and the Philadelphia Wings rallied with seven goals in the final period to beat the Long Island Tomahawks, 1511, tonight.

title: CRIME IN PROJECTS ROSE 30% IN YEAR
description: Reported crime rose more than three times as sharply in the city's housing projects as it did for the city as a whole from 1973 to 1974, the New York City Housing Authority reported yesterday.

title: Judge Scores D.A., Clears Man Jailed 14 Months in Homicide
description: An acting Supreme Court justice yesterday castigated the Manhattan District Attorney's office for having concealed evildence that might have exonerated a man who spent 14 months in jail awaiting trial in a double homicide.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article describing hearings on automobile air bags that appeared yesterday in The New York Times, it was reported erroneously that Dr. William Haddon Jr., former head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, opposed air bags. Dr. Haddon is a leading proponent of the devices.

title: MAYOR PROPOSES A FOURDAY WEEK, BUT UNIONS BALK
description: Mayor Beame, seeking to balance next year's budget without wholesale layoffs of city employes, proposed yesterday that city workers go on a fonrday work week or forgo a 6 per cent salary increase due July 1. Both proposals were rejected at once by leaders of the five major municipal unions.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Sixtyseven people over 40 are to share a $10,000 payment from Gino's of New Jersey because the fastfood chain turned them down for managementtrainee jobs. A consent judgment filed in United States District Court in Newark called for the payment and settled a United States Department of Labor suit against the chain for age discrimination.

title: Schools Aide Urges Youth to Keep Faith Despite City's Woes
description: Deputy School Chancellor Bernard R. Gifford called on the city's youth last night not to give up on the city because of its problems, but to join with others in the effort to keep New York great.

title: Scientists Ask Why World Climate Is Changing
description: The world's climate is changing. Of that scientists are firmly convinced. But in what direction and why are subjects of deepening debate.

title: FIVE SEIZED HERE IN POLICE BRIBERY
description: Five men who allegedly paid $5,200 to policemen posing as rogue cops in an effort to buy protection for topless and homosexual bars were arrested yesterday following their indictment by the New York County special anticorruption grand jury.

title: In Memoriam
description: In Memoriam

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AS VOLUME GAINS
description: Prices rose yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as volume climbed, They fell, however, in the overthecouni ter market in somewhat creased trading.

title: More Latin Aid
description: Treasury Secretary William E. Simon says the United States is planning a major contribution to development of Latin America through the InterAmerican Development Bank. Page 69.

title: Music: Knussen Could Be a Corner
description: Oliver Knussen is a 23yearold Scottish composer who already is beginning to make an international career. One of his works was played a few weeks ago at the final concert of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, and last night his short but ambitious Symphony No. 2 had its New York premiere at the Juilliard School. The occasion was the Twentieth Century Music Series conducted by Richard Dufallo.

title: Judge Scores D. A., Clears Man Jailed 14 Months in Homicide
description: An acting Supreme Court justice yesterday castigated the Manhattan District Attorney's office for having concealed evidence that might have exonerated a man who spent 14 months in jail awaiting trial in a double homicide.

title: U.S.SOVIET EFFORT ON MIDEAST IS SET
description: BONN, May 20Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko have agreed to try to cooperate on a framework for reconvening the Geneva conference on the Middle East, reporters aboard Mr. Kissinger's plane were told today.

title: DR. LOUIS H. SUNSHINE
description: Dr. Louis H. Sunshine, a retired plastic surgeon, died at his home Monday. He was. 85 years old and lived At 110 Riverside Drive.

title: CRABIEL IS NAMED IN ANTITRUST SUIT
description: TRENTON, May 20  New Jersey filed a multimilliondollar antitrust suit today against Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel and 26 other individuals and companies, charging them twith rigging highway construction bids and making political kickbacks in Passaic County.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Ingo Williams and Katharine West try to avoid the clichs and poor design to which they feel stained glass as a craft medium has fallen victim. The octagonal tables, geodesic terrariums and other items they turn out at Bedford/Downing, their studioshop in Greenwich Village, are traditional and very Art Nouveau in feeling, with minimal design elements.

title: PET TURTLE SALES BANNED BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) Citing thousands of cases of severe illness and the threat of death, the Food and Drug Administration today banned the sale of pet turtles effective next month.

title: British Petroleum Opposes Government Buying Stock
description: LONDON, May 20 (Reuters) The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., does not wish any of the stake of about 21 per cent currently held by the Bank of England to be acquired by the British Government, Sir Eric Drake, chairman, said in in an interview today.

title: Fame and the Beauty Business
description: Farberge announced yesterday that Margaux Hemingway the much publicized modelgranddaughter of Ernest Hemingway, has signed a $1million exclusive contract to be its spokesman for all products. The contract could run through 1980.

title: In Praise of Congress
description: WASHINGTONI never cease to marvel at the wisdom and prescience of the unique group of men who met in Philadelphia in 1787 to write the Constitution. The system of checks and balances created at that time has once again proved how invaluable it is.

title: Carey Threatens Veto on Aid to City If State Budget Gap Is Not Filled
description: ALBANY, May 20Any aid to New York City that involves new state spending will be vetoed, Governor Carey said today, until a gap of at least $500million in the state budget is filled first.

title: MORE LATIN AID PLANNED BY U.S.
description: SANTO DOMINGO. Dominican Republic, May 20 (AP)Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today the United States was prepared to make what he called a major contribution to development of Latin America through the InterAmerican Development Bank.

title: Passaic County Jail Gets Fund to Aid Rehabilitation
description: PATERSON, May 20Passaic County's overcrowded jail here has received a $76,000 grant from the State Law Enforcement Planning Agency for a pillat inmaterehabilitation program, Sheriff Edwin Englehardt announced today.

title: Sweeping Change in U.N. Is Urged by World Panel
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20A 25member international panel has recommended sweeping changes in the structure of the United Nations to improve its handling of economic issues and increase cooperation between rich and poor countries.

title: FORD PLEDGES U.S. TO STAND BY SEOUL
description: President Ford has committed his Administration to standing its ground in South Korea in the event of attack from the North.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Manuel Orantes of Spain, winner of the British claycourt championship this week, has taken the lead in the Commercial Union Grand Prix of tennis, according to statistics released yesterday: picked up 40 points for his victory at Bournemouth, England, and now has a total of 65. Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, the 1974 Grand Prix champion, is second with 60, followed by John Newcombe of Australia with 40. The Grand Prix links major international tennis tournaments to a point system that leads to $750,000 in prize money at year's end. The top pointwinner receives $100.000.

title: Manila Acts to Achieve Self Reliance in Defense
description: MANILA, May 20 (UPI)The Philippine Government said today that it was stepping up its defense program to achieve selfreliance in the face of a forthcoming review of security arrangements with the United States.

title: SPERRY INTERPRETS LITTLEHEARD SONGS
description: Paul Sperry is a true connoisseur's singerhe may not have the most glamorous tenor voice imaginable, but he does some wonderful things with it, and his programing is always interesting and exploratory. Monday night in the Hunter College Playhouse he addressed himself to some rarely heard German songs and made an absorbing case for them.

title: Concert
description: For the second program of its sixth annual May Festival of Contemporary American Music, the Composers Theater reached back as much as 35 years, digging out Vincent Persichetti's Concertino for Piano and Orchestra (1940). However, a highspirited piece written this year by Roger Hannay, Celebration for Tape and Orchestra, gave the evening an infusion of interest that the older numbers on the program could not match in spite of their solid professionalism.

title: Vorster Refuses to Affirm Or Deny Report on Summit
description: CAPE TOWN, May 20 (Agence FrancePresse)Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa refused today to confirm or deny It report in The Times of London that he had tried to arrange a conference with the heads of state of Kenya, Zaire, Nigeria and Liberia.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 21, 1975

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Many liquor stores in the New York area appear to be waging a price war, with flyers and handbills making such promises as the lowest price in town and every bottle sold at a discount. The campaign seems spirited, but comparison shoppers find that prices usually vary by only a few cents a bottle.

title: U.S. Now Reports 15 Dead In Recapture of Mayaguez
description: WASHINGTON. May 20The Defense Department, in a casualty report that a spokesman called as complete as we can make it. said today that 15 Americans had been killed in last week's operation to rescue, the Mayagez and its crew from the Cambodians.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Stage: Baraka's Caustic Sidnee Poet
description: In its own way, Sidnee Poet Heroical by Imamu Amiri Baraka (LeRoi Jones) is as scandalous as Macbird. This exuberant comedy, written in 1969 but for obvious reasonstoo hot to handlenot produced until now (by the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater), permits the author to express himself simultaneously as artist and activist.

title: Sarsar Shuns Ruffian, Preferring to Go Against the Colts
description: Sarsar worked five furlongs in 58 4/5 seconds at Belmont Park yesterday, but that doesn't mean she's ready for a confrontation with Ruffian. Instead, William Haggin Perry's swift 3yearold filly will oppose colts next Saturday in the Withers Mile at Aqueduct. Apparently, her trainer considers male opposition a softer assignment than going against undefeated Ruffian.

title: Antioch Law School Offers A New Breed of Lawyer
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Antioch Law School has held its first graduation sending forth what its founders hope will be a new breed of lawyer.

title: 10 Injured as Wind Storm Hits Northwest Arkansas
description: FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., May 20 (AP)  A storm system, packing high winds, moved through northwest Arkansas today, injuring 10 persons at Alma and disrupting National Guard training at Fort Chaffee, which is doubling as a Vietnamese refugee relocation.

title: MOSCOW SAYS CHINA FANS THE COLD WAR
description: MOSCOW, May 20 (Reuters) A Soviet commentator charged today that China's support for Western European unity and the Common Market was aimed at setting the continent back on the road to the cold war.

title: ORRECTIONS
description: In an article describing hearings on automobile air bags that appeared yesterday in The New York Times, it was reported erroneously that Dr. William Haddon Jr., former head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, opposed air bags. Dr. Haddon is a leading proponent of the devices.

title: Strip Mining Measure Vetoed; House Override Bid Due Today
description: WASHINGTON, May 20President Ford vetoed the strip mining control bill today, and the Administration and the coal and electric utility industries immediately pressed a major lobbying effort to sustain the veto when the House is expected to attempt to override it tomorrow.

title: Nearby Golf Results
description: AT APAWAMIS CLUB WESTCHESTERFAIRFIELD G.A.

title: New York's E.R.A.
description: New York State's own Equal Rights Amendment the State Constitution was approved by both houses the Legislature last year and already has received the overwhelming endorsement of the Assembly this year. Passage by the Senate in a vote scheduled for this week would mean that the issue would go to the voters for final approval in a referendum in November. But the highly organized opposition threatens to sidetrack state action through a slick parliamentary maneuver.

title: Cambodian Sailors End Training Without Navy
description: NEWPORT, R. I., May 20Twenty Cambocoan sailors who no longer have a navy graduated quietly today from the Officers Candidate School here.

title: President Mixes Politics and History in His North Carolina Speech
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 20President Ford came here today to pay tribute to the past but seemed to have an eye on the future.

title: High School Freshman to Shakespearean Heavy
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y.  The minute 15yearold Peter Miller finished his oneman show, Shakespeare's Old Men, almost everybody at Saint Mary's and Saint John's School wanted his recipe for blood.

title: Sun Cycle Indicates Severe Drought in '76
description: AMES, Iowa, May 16Over the Corn Belt states this summer the weather should be closer to normal than it was last summer, resulting in good to excellent growing conditions and large crops of corn and soybeans.

title: Notes on People
description: The first brothers to hold simultaneously the rank of fourstar admiral in the Navy are both involved in a current shift in highlevel commands. In a ceremony at the American Embassy in London yesterday, command of American naval forces in Europe passed to Adm. David H. Bagley, who is 54 years old. Newly appointed to the rank, he has been in Washington as Chief of Naval Personnel.

title: Open Interest
description: (In contract Monday)

title: Warriors Win and Lead, 20
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 Holding fast through the last 23 desperate seconds after two free throws by Rick Barry had restored a lead they had frittered away, the Golden State Warriors defeated the Washington Bullets, 9291, tonight and took a 20 lead in the fourofsevengame series for the National Basketball Association title.

title: Robinson Hearing On Suspension Set
description: Lee MacPhail, the American League president, will meet with Frank Robinson and Umpire Jerry Neudecker Friday to hear the Cleveland manager's version of the incident that led to his threeday suspension, MacPhail's office announced yesterday.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Teamsters Back Farm Labor Accord
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 20 Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has won the support of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and other unions for his bill to end a long and bitter dispute between the teamsters and Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers.

title: Market Place
description: Half a century ago, the owners of the 45,000acre Waddell ranch in west Texas contracted with the Gulf Oil Corporation for the development of the ranch's extensive oil and gas interests.

title: Rally Lifts Treasury Prices; Corporate Offerings Digested
Memorial Services
Strip Mine Veto
description: In again vetoing a bill to regulate the strip mine industry, President Ford demonstrates a remarkable indifference to the harm that such mining inflicts upon the nation's land and water. Mountain streams choked with silt, underground water tables poisoned by acid runoff, trees and grass uprooted and bulldozed aside, whole hillsides of topsoil and vegetation turned into slag heaps and sent sliding into the adjoining valleythese are some of the deadly scars that uncontrolled strip mining has already made upon West Virginia, Kentucky and southern Ohio.

title: Scots Soccer Victors
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, May 20 (UPI)  Scotland defeated Northern Ireland, 30, tonight and moved into first place in the British soccer championships. The scorers were Ted MacDougall, Ken Daiglish and Derck Parlane.

title: South Street Seaport Gets $1Million
description: The Vincent Astor Founda tion has made a grant of $1million toward the restoration project of the South Street Seaport with the condition that the museum raise an additional $2.5million for the $5million project.

title: I.O.C. Tells Montreal: '76, Not '77
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 20 (UPI)Lord Killanin opened the International Olympic Committee's 76th session with a warning to Montreal today that next year's Summer Games must be held as scheduled.

title: Gurney Trial Is Delayed
description: TAMPA, Fla., May 20 (UPI)United States District Judge Ben Krentzman recessed the Federal briberyconspiracy trial of former Senator Edward Gurney today until May 27 because of the death of the mother of one of the women jurors. The judge said the woman felt she would be able to resume her role as a juroro beginning next week and that he and the attorneys were unanimous in desire not to reshuffle the jury at this point.

title: Marine Concern Weighs Baying Glomar Explorer
description: LOS ANGELES, May 20 (AP)There may soon be a new owner of the Glomar Explorer, the mystery ship the Central Intelligence Agency used to recover part of a sunken Soviet submarine last July.

title: City Center Undertakes a Reorganization
description: The City Center of Music and Drama, which counts among its constituents the New York City Ballet and the New York City Opera, yesterday began a radical reorganization.

title: Oil Price Rise Due
description: A small increase in oil prices is planned by the major oil exporting nations next month to offset the decline in value of the United States dollar, Saudi Arabian sources reported yesterday. Page 61.

title: Yankees, Dobson Win, 60
Saigon Exists Somberly, Many Activities Normal
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 20Nearly three weeks after Communist forces took over Saigon with almost no bloodshed, there is still no sign of a civilian government for the city.

title: GREEKS IN EXILE LONG TO GO HOME
description: BUDAPEST, May 15  For more than 50,000 Greeks exiled from their country for over a quarter of a century, the restoration of democratic government in Athens last year raised hopes that are painfully slow in being realized.

title: Honduras Gets Bribe Telegrams
description: The Honduran Government has obtained copies of three telegrams tracing a $1.25million bribe that it says was paid by the United Brands Company to Abraham Bennaton Ramos, former Honduran Economy Minister, through the Paris branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank to the Zurich office of the Swiss Credit Bank.

title: U.S. Rocket Fails, Losing 2 Satellites In the Defense Net
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 20 (UPI)A United States rocket carrying two satellites was lost in space today, dooming a $57million mission aimed at establishing the final link of a worldwide military communications network.

title: PENSION TAX RISE OPPOSED FOR NOW
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The Ford Administration, citing the recession, asked Congress today not to raise Social Security taxes until 1977, even though there will be a small deficit in the system starting this year.

title: Toll Increase Fails to Cut Port Authority's Traffic
description: The daily stream of traffic between the city and New Jersey has not been turned off by the big increase In tolls May 5traffic has actually increased in the first two weeks since then.

title: Samuel Hesson, 68, Dies; Albany Law School Dean
description: Samuel M. Hesson, dean of the Albany Law School, died Monday evening, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Schenectady, N. Y. He was 68 years old.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BOLIVIA SUMMONS GULF'S CHAIRMAN
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 20 (AP)The Bolivian Government placed the local representative of the Gulf Oil Corporation under house arrest today, ordered Gulf's American chairman to appear in court and said the company would be criminally prosecuted for making illegal political contributions to Bolivian officials.

title: Clashes Erupt Again in Beirut; 2 Are Killed and 20 Wounded
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 20Two persons were killed and 20 wounded today in renewed fighting in a Beirut suburb between Palestinian guerrillas and members of the rightwing Phalangist party.

title: Outlook Gray for the Steel Industry
description: Although 1974 was almost a record year for the steel industry and profits were sharply higher in the first quater of this year, industry leaders are in a sober mood.

title: ADM. KIVETTE, LED WESTERN FRONTIER
description: AUBURN, Calif., May 20 (AP) Vice Admiral Frederick N. Kivette, who retired in 1961 as commander of the Western Sea Frontier, died Saturday. He was 72 years old.

title: Stage: Present Laughter
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Noel Coward was a master of the ordinary  even his commonplace plays have an uncommon touch of craftsmanship to them, and Present Laughter, now at the Eisenhower Theater at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here, is one of his commonplace plays. It was written in 1942 as a light comedy intended to brighten the darker days of World War II, and I remember, with relish, the playwright himself playing the hero at London's Theater Royal at that time.

title: City Schools Face Possible Loss Of Equivalent of 16,000 Jobs
description: The city schools may now have to cut the equivalent of 16.000 teaching jobstwice the number it had feared it would have to eliminatebecause of the deepening budget crisis, Deputy School Chancellor Bernard R. Gifford declared last night.

title: Florida Man Gets 10 Years In Fraud on War Prisoners
description: KINGSVILLE, Tex., May 20 (UPI)Stafe District Judge Vernon Harville gave to Florida man today the maximum sentence of 10 years in the penitentiary and a $5,000 fine on each of two counts of fraud in an alleged $4.5million nationwide scheme to defraud returning prisoners of war.

title: Stocks Lose 7.20 on Dow As Trading Stays Active
description: Stock prices ended lower yesterday in continued active trading after late selling pressure weakened the list.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Federal and city lawenforcement officials have noted that substantial increases in the availability and purity of heroin sold openly on New York City streets suggest cause for alarm.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)The Senate voted today to accept a compromise securities bill that would bring the biggest reforms of the industry in 40 years. The Securities Reform Act of 1975, supported by the White House, was accepted by the Senate on a voice vote with no debate. The House of Representatives is expected to approve the new version soon.

title: HEWLETTPACKARD POSTS PROFIT RISE
description: The HewlettPackard Company, a large maker of electronic measuring instruments: and computer systems, reported yesterday for the second fiscal quarter that It had net income of $24million, equal to 87 cents a share, up 17.1 per cent from last year.

title: Dollar Dips in Europe
description: BRUSSELS, May 20 (UPI)The dollar dipped marginally on European money markets today, in quiet trading. The price of gold was mixed.

title: GIFT SHOP OWNER STABBED TO DEATH
description: A 73yearold man who operated a small gift shop just off Fifth Avenue at 14th Street was stabbed fatally yesterday as two men attempted to rob his store.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 21, 1975

title: Advertising
description: At the annual meeting of Grey Advertising yesterday a stockholder criticized what he called the management's cool relationship with Wall Street.

title: People and Business
description: John T. Omlop, the Secretary of Labor, said here yesterday that he had discerned a decline in the ardor and enthusiasm for public service employment. In rejecting the idea of massive public service employment to solve the nation's unemploymont problem, he called these jobcreating measures a special purpose tool and not a generalized solution.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VOICES New Yorkers will have the opportunity today to hear one of the key figures in Japan's literary avantgarde, when Kobo Abe, who is best known here as the novelist  scenarist of Woman in the Dunes, speaks at Japan House.

title: The Broken Telephone Line
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20  The miniwar in Cambodia, with its sudden attacks in the dark and bizarre misunderstandings, illustrates the need for a more efficient worldwide communication system, and suggests a new and practical peacekeeping role for the United Nations.

title: Costa Rica Cites Corporate Conspiracy
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 20 (AP)Costa Rica accused three United States fruit companies today of conspiring against Central American bananaexporting countries to keep them from raising export taxes.

title: State of the City: The Roots of Crime
description: Crime erodes the viability and the vitality of the city. It affects all manner of decisions ranging from the way people educate their children to whether and what time they will ride the subways or use the parks. It affects the way citizens regard their neighbors, the sections of the city they feel free to enjoy and inhabit, the movement of businessesand peopleout of town.

title: U.S. Orders City to Dismiss Seven Aides
description: The United States Department of Labor yesterday ordered Mayor Beame to dismiss seven city neighborhood workers paid with Federal public service job money on the ground that they had been hired because of their political ties to the Democratic party.

title: Senate Refuses Reinstatement Of Butterfield's Military Status
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The Senate defeated today, 46 to 42, a bill that would have reinstated Alexander P. Butterfield. the former head of the Federal Aviation Administration who first disclosed the existence of the White House tapes, as a retired Air Force colonel.

title: Union Chiefs Call Citibank The City's No. 1 Enemy
description: Leaders of major unions representing city employes accused First National City Bank yesterday of being the No. 1 enemy of the city in the current fiscal crisis, and they called for a boycott of the bank by their members and the city.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
About Education
description: In 1971, when colleges and universities were trying to grapple with the rising costs of private education, the unequal burdens these costs placed on parents and the unequal opportunities the costs presaged for their children, Yale University announced a Tuition Postponement Option. The option, Yale hoped, would equalize things a little.

title: Lisbon's Socialists Threaten to Quit Coalition Over Closing of Paper
description: LISBON, Wednesday, May 21 (Reuters)Portugal's Socialist party has threatened to resign from the Government unless the Communists stop encroaching on the pres, trade unions and local administration, high party sources said today.

title: Namath, W.F.L. Still in Huddle
description: In his time Joe Nemeth has stopped time.

title: Saigon Exists Somberly, Many Activities Normal
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. May 20Nearly three weeks after Communist forces took over Saigon with almost no bloodshed, there is still no sign of a civilian government for the city.

title: Publisher May Sue Author Who Went to Rival House
description: Doris H. Kearns seemed to have everything going for her, but now there may be something against her: a suit in court.

title: People in Sports
description: Bob MacKinnon has resigned as coach of the Spirits of St. Louis of the American Basketball Association and will be named today director of player personnel of the Buffalo Braves of the National Basketball Association. Essentially, the 47yearold MacKinnon will assume many of the duties held by Eddie Donovan, who resigned as the Braves' general manager to accept a similar position with the Knicks.

title: From the Finland Airport
description: PARISNext week's Bonn meeting of the Western European Union Assembly will coincide, one or another way, with a crisis over air defense between the United States and its transAtlantic NATO partners.

title: Violence and How to Control It
description: Deep thinkers such as psychologists, sociologists and cops use terms like marginally compensated people, a lowering of restrictive superego qualities and climate of violence, and what they are saying is that the cus tomers at sports events these days tend to express their enthusiasm by bouncing a bottle off their hero's skull, slugging their neighbors or tearing down the arena. Deep thinking is not a specialty of this department, and if it true that violence in the grandstand is on the increase, no ready explanation will be found here. As a matter of fact, there has been a suspicion here for many years that the typical sports fan is actually two people. One is a nice guy who goes to see Gwen Verdon in Chicago and applauds politely when the star makes her entrance. The other goes out to root for the Mets and boos when Tom Seaver is announced as the pitcher. ready explanation will be found here. As a matter of fact, there has been a suspicion here for many years that the typical sports fan is actually two people. One is a nice guy who goes to see Gwen Verdon in Chicago and applauds politely when the star makes her entrance. The other goes out to root for the Mets and boos when Tom Seaver is announced as the pitcher.

title: Oil Price Rise Due
description: A small increase in oil Prices is planned by the major oil exporting nations next Month to offset the decline in value of the United States dollar, Saudi Arabiart,Spurces reported yesterday. Page 61.

title: CAPTAIN INDICTED IN DEATHS AT SEA
description: NEWARK, May 20 (UPI)The captain of a schooner that sank in the icy waters of the Atlantic Ocean last year was indicted for manslaughter today for refusing to throw his 80pound dog out of a lifeboat land let two men crawl aboard.

title: Rizzo Wins in Primary
description: Mayor Frank L. Rizzo of Philadelphia, piling up big pluralities in white ethnic areas, won the Democratic nomination for Mayor by an overwhelming margin. Page 14.

title: Wyoming Solidly Backs Hathaway
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., May 20When the Senate Interior Committee votes tomorrow, as scheduled, on President Ford's nomination of Stanley K. Hathaway as the new Interior Secretary, it will be judging a man who has widespread, bipartisan and even some environmentalist support in his home state.

title: Suspect, 19, Is Charged With Trade Center Fires
description: A 19yearold cleaning man was charged last night with setting six fires in the twin 110story towers of the World Trade Center Monday night and one in February that caused $2million in damage.

title: Third of Soviet Emigrants Avoid Israel
description: WASHINGTON, May 20More than a third of the Jews permitted to leave the Soviet Union recently have decided to settle in countries other than Israel, primarily the United States.

title: Consumers Battle Food Costs By Cutting on Convenience
description: Rather than radically reducing food buying to cope with rising costs, a study has found that American consumers have adopted other strategies, including using less expensive but equally nutritious alternatives and cutting back on the purchase of expensive cuts of meat, convenience foods and items with large amounts of sugar.

title: Stanley Cup Finals
description: Buffalo vs. Philadelphia

title: NONUNION WORK ON OIL RIGS SEEN
description: CHERRY HILL, May 20Mayor Angelo Errichetti of Camden told an offshore oil drilling forum here today that he had requested President Ford to block what he said was a reported plan to import Southern states' nonunion labor for the proposed coast oil exploration project off New Jersey.

title: Scientis Ask Why World Climate Is Changing
description: The world's climate is changing. Of that scientists are firmly convinced. But in what direction and why are subjects of deepening debate.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: House Rejects 70,000 Cut In Troops Abroad, 31195
description: WASHINGTON; May 20The House, in the first PostVietnam war test of its attitudes on defense policy, voted decisively today against reducing American troops overseas or making substantial cuts in the Military hildget.

title: Housing Agency Fails To Get Bid on Notes
description: The City Housing Authority did not get a bid yesterday when it offered to sell $24.6 million in cityguaranteed shortterm notes.

title: MAYOR PROPOSES A FOURDAY WEEK, BUT UNIONS BALK
description: Mayor Beame, seeking to balance next year's budget without wholesale layoffs of city employes, proposed yesterday that city workers go on a fourday work week or forgo a 6 per cent salary increase due July 1. Both proposals were rejected at once by leaders of the five major municipal unions.

title: A Brezhnev Report
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, is expected to be out of sight for at least three weeks, reportedly for medical treatment. Page 4.

title: Ashe Says Davis Cup Runneth Too Long for Pros to Pass Up Other Tourneys
description: Arthur Ashe bored into the heart of the Davis Cup problems yesterday when he said the country should not expect its leading tennis pros to take 12 weeks off for the international campaign.

title: Retail Food Prices Drop Slightly Here
description: While wholesale prices for meat, fish, poultry and fresh produce were rising on the average about 12 per cent last week, retail food prices, as a whole, dropped slightly. The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City dropped slightly, 0.2 per cent below that of the previous week, according to the City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Article 1  No Title
Coleman Suggests Chessie and N.&W. Take Over Others
description: The Secretary of Transportation, William E. Coleman Jr., summoned yesterday John P. Fishwick, president of the Norfolk & Western Railway, to his office to discuss with him and with Hays T. Watkins, chairman of Chessie System, Inc., the practicability of their railroads' absorbing the properties of the Penn Central and six other major bankrupt railroads in the Northeast.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Dayton Power and Light Company said yesterday it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering of 1.5 million common shares through underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc., and Reynolds Securities, Inc. Net proceeds of the offering, expected to be made on June 10, will be used to repay outstanding shortterm debt, the utility said.

title: Jury Panel Is Still Sought In Kent State Shooting Suit
description: CLEVELAND, May 20 (AP)Lawyers labored today for a second day in efforts to agree on a jury to consider an $11million civil suit arising out of the Kent State University shootings five years ago.

title: WINE TALK
description: Clifton Fadiman once compiled a collection of short stories about wine that he called Dionysius. Alice Tisdale Hobart wrote a novel about a winemaking family in the Napa Valley, The Cup and the Sword, in 1942, But for all the words it has generate among nonfiction writers, wine has never really greatly inspired the novelists.

title: BURGER ASKS HELP IN CUTTING DOCKET
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Chief Justice Warren E. Burgers urged today that the Supreme Court be given a completely) free hand in picking the cases it will hear.

title: Miles College Abandons Plans To Move to a Bigger Campus
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 20 Despite a lastminute fund raising effort by Birmingham's white business community, Miles College, a predominantly black school on the city's southwestern edge, has been forced by a cash shortage to abandon plans to move to new expanded campus.

title: Johnson Takes dh Lead
description: Alex Johnson of the Yankees hit .455 last week and took over the top spot among designated hitters with a .300 average, the American League announced yesterday.

title: DETROIT AVERTS POLICE LAYOFFS
description: DETROIT, May 20Leaders of Detroit's two major police unions and the Police Department said in Federal Coutt here today that they had reached an agreement that would prevent the layoffs of 550 police officers.

title: Penney Net Down 86.8% in Quarter; Kresge's Up 2.1%
description: The J. C. Penney Company, the nation's secondlargest retail chain, told its shareholders yesterday that its net profit in the quarter ended April 26 declined 86.8 per cent from the year before despite a sales rise of 2.7 per cent.

title: MasseyFerguson Obtains White Motor Plant in Ohio
description: CLEVELAND, May 20 (UPI)The White Motor Company announced today it has signed a contract turning over to a new Massey  Ferguson, Ltd., subsidiary a diesel engine plant White built at Canton, Ohio, in 1970.

title: Iran Fights Rising Food Deficit
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 20The people have no lack of wheat, barley and every type of corn, Marco Polo recorded enthusiastically after traveling through Persia.

title: I.B.M. CALLS FIELD MOST COMPETITIVE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation made its opening statement yesterday in the Justice Department's antitrust suit against the company. Lawyers for the computer manuracturer argued that its success in the electronic data processing market was based on better products, greater production efficiency, better service, right judgments at key periods of time and the willingness of management to back these judgments.

title: U.S.SOVIET EFFORT ON MIDEAST IS SET
description: BONN, May 20Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko have agreed to try to cooperate on a framework for reconvening the Geneva conference on the Middle East, reporters aboard Mr. Kissinger's plane were told today.

title: TV: Music, Dance and Funeral Industry on P.B.S.
description: Music, dance and an investigative report on the funeral industry  the mixture on the Public Broadcasting Service this evening is somewhat lumpy but generally satisfying. The music begins at 8:30 as WNET/13's Music Project presents Ancient Voices of Children, a cycle of songs by George Crumb based on texts by Federico Garcia Lorca. Allan Miller, producerdirector, and David Hanser, film editor, go outside the standard music repertory for a contemporary masterpiece. The visualization of the score is frequently superb.

title: MORE CHARGES FACE A SAN DIEGO BANKER
description: Angelo Adams, a former San Diego bank official already scheduled for trial Aug. 19 on various criminal charges in the alleged fraud at U.S. Financial, Inc., was indicted yesterday by a grand jury in San Diego on three additional counts, according to David Curnw, assistant United States Attorney.

title: ExPremier Sato Improves A Bit After Stroke in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, May 20 (AP)Former Premier Eisaku Sato, who suffered a stroke in a restaurant and was reported near death, improved slightly today, doctors said.

title: More Crime Forecast as Idleness Rises
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The nation will face a higher and growing crime rate as long as unemployment is permitted to grow, a broad range of witnesses, including Speaker Carl Albert, told a legislative forum today.

title: A Potpourri of Recipes From Superb Cooks Far and Wide
description: It has long been apparent that people who dote on cooking are among the most generous people on earth. We have found them in Alaska sharing with us a favorite recipe for muktuk, the edible black and white of whale; enjoyed a long conversation in Hong Kong, our host discussing the fine points of making snake soup; relished the details of watching a turtle being readied for the kettle in the flatlands of New Jersey.

title: Not for the Gander, Though
description: HASTINGSONHUDSON, N. Y.In a world not known for fairness, one of the most galling of inequities is a disparity in punishment: when like individuals, committing like offenses, are treated differently. Nowhere is inequity likely to be evident and more infuriating than when there is a disparity in sentencing for committing crime. It suggests a division into privileged and persecuted that is contrary to the fundamental definitions of our democracy.

title: Ford Fund, WHET Decry Hoffman Fee
description: The payment of $3,000 and an $800 video cassette player to Abbie Hoffman, the fugitive formed Yippie, for a taped interview on WNET/13 on Monday night was denounced yesterday both by officials of the station and by Fred W. Friendly, broadcast consultant to the Ford Foundation, which re ceived a donor's credit after the program.

title: Rizzo Wins in Primary
description: Mayor Frank L. Rizzo of Philadelphia, piling up big pluralities in white ethnic areas, won the Democratic nomination for Mayor by an overwhelming margin. Page 14.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Sweeping Change in U.N. Is Urged by World Panel
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20A 25member international panel has recommended sweeping changes in the structure of the United Nations to improve its handling of economic issues and increase cooperation between rich and poor countries.

title: Deere Posts Net Gain
Red Sox Rout Blue; Lee Beats A's, 70
description: The Oakland's A's are baseball's world champions, but the Boston Red Sox seem somewhat less than impressed by that fact. The proper Bostonians walloped the A's at Fenway Park for the second successive night, this time on the twohit pitching of Bill Lee. The score last night was 70, and the individual victim of the Boston bats was Vida Blue, who sought his ninth victory but suffered his second loss. Rollie Fingers, the A's best reliever, didn't fare too well, either. On Monday, the Red Sox beat the A's, 105.

title: Thai Premier Says He Is Hoping To Avoid Hasty Exit by the U.S.
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 20 (Reuters)Premier Kukrit Pramoj said today that a hasty withdrawal of United States forces could create problems for the That Government.

title: CREEL ACCUSED IN ANTITRUST SUIT
description: TRENTON, May 20 New Jersey fired a multimilliondollar antitrust suit today against Secretary of State J. Edward Cyabiel and 26 other individuals and companies, charging them with rigging highway construction bids and making political kickbacks in Passaic County.

title: Challenge for the Very Brighta College for Kids
description: KENTFIELD Calif.A 10yearold college student recently explained to his mother why he liked going to lectures on computers.

title: Article 2  No Title
Music: David Diamond
description: The Hear America First series, which operates in the strongly resonant chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, paid homage on Monday night to David Diamond, who will be 60 years old on July 9. The Rochesterborn composer has been extremely prolific, and his music has been played with some regularity, but the chance to hear it in any degree of concentration has been rare.

title: Improving Criminal Justice
description: Visible shortrange progress in controlling crime will require concurrent efforts to make the criminal justice system at once more rational and responsive, and to amplify, repair and improve the programs for identifying, treating and caring for the community's most damaged, and damaging, childrenwho constitute at once principal source of the problem and its most poignant victims.

title: FLOAT IS JOINED BY FRENCH FRANC
description: BRUSSELS, May 20  The French franc officially will join seven other European currencies in a joint float in a few weeks, and until then it will float with them on a de facto basis, the French Finance Minister, JeanPierre Fourcade, said at a Common Market meeting in Brussels today.

title: Restaurant Restrained From Removing Murals
description: The owners of an apartment cooperative that houses the Cafe Des Artistes at 1 West 67th Street obtained a temporary restraining order in State Supreme Court yesterday barring the cafe's owners from removing the murals painted by Howard Chandler Christy. Justice Thomas J. Hughes signed the order enjoining Romeo Sterlini, the operator, pending hearing Friday.

title: Bucs Hire Larue
description: TAMPA, Fla. May 20 (UPI)  Ken Larue the Oakland Raiders business manager, was hired today by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. The Bucs begin play in the National Football League in 1976. Hugh Culverhouse, the Bucs owner, said Larue would become assistant to vice president of operations Ron Wolf on June 1.

title: Transportation Aide Says U.S. Hinders Road Building in State
description: TRENTON, May 24 (AP)Alan Sagner, the State Transportation Commissioner, said today that new Federal requirements, applied retroactively to previously approve road projects, had seriously crimped highway construction in New Jersey.

title: 2 ENVOYS SOUGHT ASIA NEWS CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The United States ambassadors to South Vietnam and Cambodia asked the Voice of America to play down news of the deteriorating situation in Indochina in early April.

title: State Advisory Unit For Public Policy Named by Steingut
description: ALBANY, May 20Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut today announced the appointment of a 19member advisory committee on public policy to study a broad range of problems confronting the state and to report back to him on proposals for legislation to deal with them.

title: Two Amendments Approved in State Senate to Help Court Reform
description: ALBANY, May 20The Senate today gave overwhelming approval to two proposed constitutional amendments aimed at reforming the court system in the state.

title: Commodity Power
description: PARIS, May 20Commodity power, born a decade and a half ago when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was conceivedappears ready to lead to another round, of oilprice increases this fall.

title: Nichols's 'Fortune' Is Old-Time Farce
description: Though it is set in the nineteen-twenties, Mike Nichols's very funny, manically scatterbrained new movie, "The Fortune," is an epic version of those old two-reel comedies that I associate with Saturday afternoon moviegoing in the thirties, with stars like the Three Stooges, Vera Vague, Ernest Truex and Charlie Chase.It's a marvelous attempt to recreate a kind of farce that, with the notable exceptions of a handful of films by Blake Edwards and Billy Wilder, disappeared after World War II.The characters in "The Fortune" are motivated by greed first and lust second, usually when it's inconvenient. They think big but act small, often the victims of their own short tempers. Nobody is permanently injuredneither physically, by going to sea in a leaky trunk, nor emotionally, by learning that one's lover has been plotting murder all the while."The Fortune," which opened yesterday at the Coronet, has the short focus and the comic self-absorption of two-reelers in which all of the world's problems might be reduced to the difficulties inherent in moving a piano from one room to another.Nicky (Warren Beatty), who uses mounds of Vaseline on his hair and wears a Ramon Novarro mustache, and Oscar (Jack Nicholson), a failed embezzler who often looks like one of the Stooges, are attempting something much more grand than piano-moving, though they are always interrupted by problems as petty as a doorway that's too narrow.In the screenplay by Adrien Joyce, which is less important as a coherent narrative than as the frame for a collection of comedy routines. Nicky and Oscar are out to separate Fredericka Quintessa Bigard (Stockard Channing), known to them as "the mouse-bed heiress, from her family and then from her money. This involves Oscar's marrying her (because Nicky, who is supposed to be her lover, is already married to someone who remains a long distance off-screen) and then transporting her from New York to Los Angeles, where the pair attempts to murder her.Farces about attempted murder can be a little bit nervous-making when the intended victim is as appealing as Miss Channing, a Nichols discovery of major importance. She's a fine-grained, robust, comic talent who keeps the film in proper balance by being just as intently lunatic as her two co-stars.Miss Channing's Freddie, speaking in a horsy, upper-crust accent, delivers lines filched from True Romances with a gravity that's as funny as anything in the film. "The scales have dropped from my eyes," she says primly as she listens to Nicky and Oscar fighting over her future inheritance. Or, with a deep sigh as the two men ignore her to pursue some other minor point: "Je n'existe pas."Mr. Beatty's role is less flamboyant than Mr. Nicholson's, but he plays straight with determined comedy style. Mr. Nicholson is nothing short of superb, being the obligatorily dense member of the con-artist team, the sort of man who, after being arrested for a murder he doesn't realize he hasn't committed, immediately adopts police jargon to oblige his captors. "Then," he says helpfully, "we carried the victim out of the house and put her in the pond," which happens to be a bird bath.Though it's only 95 minutes long, which is virtually a short subject these days, "The Fortune" does have sequences that sag, and there are moments when it's obvious that farce is not exactly the native art of any of the people involved. One occasionally is aware of the tremendous effort that has gone into a particular effect, though that doesn't spoil it for me. The endeavor is nobly conceived in an era that has just about abandoned farce in favor of parody, satire, situation and/or wise-crack comedy, all of which Mr. Nichols already can do withperhapstoo great an ease. "The Fortune" will probably be compared to "The Sting," because of the overlapping of the eras and the con-man theme. Incorrectly, though. "The Sting" is an adventure. "The Fortune" is farce of a rare order.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Until last week, the surest way to provoke the anger of the mildmannered Mayor of New York was to use the word default in connection with the city over which he presides.

title: Spirit of 30's Sculpture
description: In the history of modern sculpture, the art of Barbara Hepworth belongs to the spirit of the nineteenthirties. It belongs to the creative ferment that compelled a small band of British artistspreeminently Henry Moore, Ben Nicholson and Dame Barbara herselfto commit their talents and their energies to the cause of abstract art in the difficult years between the Wall Street crash and the start of World War II. The fame and acclaim of her later yearsthe exhibitions in Venice and So Paulo. the repeated retrospectives in the major London galleries, the rising tide of prizes, publications and commissions, capped in 1964 by the unveiling of the Dag Hammarskjold memorial at the United Nations Secretariat in New Yorkall look back to the quiet and fastidious accomplishments of the thirties, when abstract art was still the passion of the few and a highly unpopular mystery to the many.

title: A.M.A. Urges States to Resolve Malpractice Insurance Dispute
description: The American Medical Association expressed alarm and regret yesterday that the widespread dispute over malpractice insurance was causing doctors to reduce services. It called for prompt remedial action by state legislatures.

title: Company Aides Ponder Women's Rights
description: HOBOKEN, May 20  The masculine mystique in management carries a high price tag, Phoebe Sehama, lawyer who is p esident of the Board of trustes of the Women's Rights lnformation Center, in Bergen Countysaid today.

title: EUROPEANS ASSAIL CHARTER FLIGHTS
description: The Association of European Airlines contended yesterday; that the main cause or excess airline seats and attendant losses on North Atlantic routes was the proliferation of American charter flights.

title: MINORITY LABOR SPLIT ON ISSUES
description: BALTIMORE, May 20A petroteum worker from Houston and a construction worker from Baltimore, both union members, found themselves on opposite sides of basic labor issues during a weekend meetingof minority union workers.

title: Soviet Plans Memorial For Babi Yar Massacre
description: MOSCOW, May 20 (Reuters)Babi Yar, a ravine in Kiev where 200,000 Soviet citizens, half of them Jews, were massacred by German troops in World War II, is to be marked by a large memorial.

title: Energy Action Postponed By Democrats in House
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The House Democratic leadership postponed indefinitely today a House vote on legislation that would raise the Federal gasoline tax and take other steps to conserve energy.

title: Books of The Times
description: Introductory incident: An exhausted young drifter named Gary Cooper White finds himself in a New York City singles hangout called Mr. Goodbar, where he encounters an attractive woman, Theresa Dunn, who is clearly interested in being picked up. Gary, mainly wanting a place to rest for the night, walks Theresa home, allows her to seduce him, and drifts off to sleep. But, to his extreme annoyance, she wakes him up and tells him he must leave, now that she's finished with him. The ensuing disagreement quickly escalates into a physical struggle, which Gary puts to an end by bludgeoning and stabbing Theresa to death. Flashback: Theresa appears as 6yearold, the unhappy child (suffering from postpolio curvature of the spine) of a lowerclass Irish Catholic family from the Bronx.

title: Excerpts From Suggestions for Changes in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 20 Following are excerpts from an unofficial summary of recommendations to the General Assembly by an international panel calling for changes in the structure of the United Nations to improve economic relations between rich and poor nations.

title: Mayor Signs a Bill Permitting Ads on the Outside of Taxicabs
description: Mayor Beame signed into law yesterday a bill permitting exterior advertising atop taxicabs. He acted after having stressed at a City Hall hearing that he had carefully weighed the impact of esthetic pollution in the city against the economic difficulties of the taxicab industry.

title: Labor Urges Jobs Outlay
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI) The A.F.L.C.I.O. urged Congress today to spend $10billion to provide public service jobs for one million of the 8.2 million unemployed Americans. Kenneth Young, a lobbyist for the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations said in testimony prepared for a Senate Labor and Public Welfare Subcommittee that dropping unemployment is the way to cure the deficit problem, not to mention human suffering.

title: Recipe Potpourri (Cont'd)
description: Although fresh trout may not be as common as sole or cod in markets, they are at times available, and they could scarcely be turned into a more toothsome or tempting morsel than in a recipe obtained from Jean Banchet, the owner of a fine French restaurant, Le Franais in Wheeling, Ill., about 30 miles north of Chicago's Loop This is a recipe he had, in turn, from the late and lamented Fernand Point by any odds one of the greatest chefs in French history. The details are a bit elaborate, but the dish is worth the effort and time.

title: Kuhn Names Lang To Panel on Rules
description: Jerome Holtzman of The Chicago Sun Times and Jack Lang of The Long Island Press, both baseball writers, were appointed by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn yesterday to serve on the official Scorine Rules Committee.

title: Market Summary
description: Tuesday, May 20, 1975

title: SAUDIS SAY RISE IN OIL PRICES DUE
description: RYIADH, May 20A small but politically significant increase in oil prices is being planned by the major oil exporting nations next month to offset the decline in value of the United States dollar, according to Saudi Arabian sources.

title: LAOS COMMUNISTS REPORTED TAKING SOUTHERN TOWNS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 20Communistled Pathet Lao forces have reportedly begun moving into virtually every major town in the Laotian panhandle area that previously was under rightist control.

title: Indians Send Jim Perry, Bosman to A's for Odom
description: CLEVELAND, May 20 (AP)  The Cleveland Indians traded Jim Perry and Dick Bosman, righthanded pitchers, to the Oakland A's today for John (Blue Moon) Odom, a righthanded hurler, and an unspecified amount of cash.

title: EXTRAFUNDING BILL IS VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)  The Senate passed by a 76to14 vote today a $15.9billion supplemental appropriations bill after increasing it $4.5billion over the House total and $968million over President Ford's budget.

title: JOB AGENCY CHIEF BACKED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The Senate labor Committee, in the face of complaints from feminist and Hispanic groups that it was acting too hastily, approved today the nomination of Lowell W. Perry to be chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. Mr. Perry is the manager of a Chrysler Corporation plant in Detroit.

title: A Numbers Lottery By OTB Proposed In Assembly Bill
description: A bipartisan bill that would permit the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation to operate a daily numbers lottery with a minimum $1 bet was introduced in the State Assembly yesterday.

title: SIX AWARDS GIVEN BY DEADLINE CLUB
description: Six awards for excellence in various fields of journalism were made last night by the Deadline Club, the New York City chapter of the society of professional journalists, Sigma Delta Chi, at its 50th anniversary dinner at the New York Hilton Hotel

title: Liberalized Depreciation System Urged
description: Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen said here yesterday that the most likely action for Congress to stimulate capital investment would be to liberalize depreciation schedules for corporations.

title: Sabres Outlast Flyers In Overtime, Fog by 54
description: BUFFALO, May 20Bursting out of the fog like an apparition from the moor, Rene Robert sent a 20foot shot past Bernie Parent, the goalie, at 18 minutes 29 seconds of overtime tonight to give the Buffalo Sabres a 54 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: The Child Criminal
description: But even a system operating at peak efficiency would not by itself make significant inroads on the nature and amount of crime in the city. Many of the violent crimes which people fear most are committed by juveniles. Another significant portion of those crimes is committed by graduates of the state's childcaring and juvenile justice institutions, evaluated and consistently found wanting over the last fifteen years.

title: Esmark and Clark Oil Call Off Merger Plan
description: Esmark, Inc., a diversified Chicagobased holding company, announced yesterday that a previously announced merger proposal with the Clark Oil and Refining Corporation, Milwaukee, had been terminated by mutual agreement. No reason was given for the termination.

title: Member of Fetal Research Panel Objects to Some Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, May 20A national commission appraising research involving the human fetus has made recommendations that would sacrifice the interests of innocent human life to a postulated social need, one of the commissioners charged in a dissenting statement made public today.

title: SENATE UNIT DELAYS U.N. GROUPS' FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (Reuters)The Senate Foreign Relations Committee held up approval today of American contributions to two United Nationsaffiliated organizations that are expected to vote soon on measures to oust Israel.

title: Price Fluctuations Marked in Trading Of Grains Futures
description: Grain prices fluctuated widly yesterday as traders seemed unable to decide on the underlying price trend. July wheat futures opened at $3.22 a bushel, off 3 cents, and then suddenly rallied to $3.36 as traders reacted to news, previously only a rumor, that a Soviet buying delegation was to visit the United States. Later. some doubts led to selling, and speculators took profits, pushing prices down to $3.13 al the close on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Rizzo Is Strong Victor in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 20 Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, piling up overwhelming pluralities in this city's white ethnic areas and showing broad strength in most other wards, won the Democratic nomination for Mayor by a substantial margin tonight.

title: Tax and Gambling Charges Dropped Against Colombo
description: Charges of incometax evasion and gambling were dropped yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court against Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed undetworld figure who was shot down at an Italian  American unity rally in 1971 and left paralyzed.

title: Members of Panel on U.N.
description: AbdelHamid AbdelGhany of Egypt, a Foreign Ministry official.

title: Giscard Conquers Alsatian Village
description: PARIS, May 20  Guess who dropped in for dinner tonight? Why, Valdry Giscard d'Estaingagain.

title: Profits Show a Record Drop; Quarter G.N.P. Off by 11.3%
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Reported corporate profits showed a record decline in the first quarter of this year but most of this was a drop in artificial inflation profits, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Oosterhuis Choice in Golf
description: LONDON. May 20 (UPI) Peter Oosterhuis, runnerup in the New.. Orleans open yesterday, is the 61 favorite for the Penfold Professional Golfers Association championship starting at Royal St. George's at Sandwich Friday. Arnolt Palmer, the 45yearold American star, is second choice at 101.

title: Energy Action Postponed By Democrats in House
description: WASHINGTON, May 20they House Democratic leadership postponed indefinitely today a House vote on legislation that would raise the Federal gasoline tax and take other steps to conserve energy.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON LOANS FOR U.D.C.
description: An agreement whereby 11 major New York commercial banks are to lend $140million to the Urban Development Corporation was completed and closed yesterday, making it possible for the agency to pay off the $104.5million in bondanticipation notes on which it defaulted in February.

title: THOMAS J. NOONAN
description: Thomas J. Noonan, a vice president of Carl Byoir & Associates, Inc., the publicrelations company, died Monday at Pascock Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. He was 60 years old and lived in Riverside, Conn.

title: SILBERT QUERIED OVER TWO ISSUES
