description: WASHINGTON, May 20The issue of whether Earl J. Silbert was less than vigorous in his prosecution of the original Watergate defendants was raised yet again today during Senate Judiciary Committee hearings en his nomination as United States Attorney for the District of Columbia.

title: About New York
description: l'ye been on television, the woman said. Several times.

title: Kissinger, in Bonn, Meets Lisbon's Foreign Minister
description: BONN, May 20 (AP)Secretary of State Kissinger held his first meeting today with Ernesto Augusto Antunes, the new Foreign Minister of the leftist Portuguese Government.

title: Escaped Convict Captured
description: LUCASVILLE, Ohio, May 20 (UPI)  The remaining convict who broke out of the Southern Ohio Correctional Facility was recaptured today. Ronald Carter, wounded in the leg, was captured in a wooded area about a mile and a half from the facility.

title: Carpenters Shine in Tarrytown Concert
description: The CarpentersKaren, who sings, and Richard, her brother, who plays keyboards, composes, arranges and conductshave never been very big in Manhattan, at least in concert. Their records sell enormously all over the world, however, and presumably they sell here, too. But apart from a tepidly received Carnegie Hall date in 1971, they have stuck to semiannual visits to the suburbs, most recently at the new West chester Premier Theater in Tarrytown, N. Y., where they opened Monday for a week.

title: Barbara Hepworth Dies in Fire at Cornwall Studio
description: ST. IVES, England, March. 20 (AP)Dame Barbara Hepworth, one of the world's foremost sculptors, died tonight in a fire in her studiohome here. She was 73 years old.

title: LAOS COMMUNISTS REPORTED TAKING SOUTHERN TOWNS
description: VIENTIANE, Labs, Wednesday, May 21  Communist  led Pathet Lao forces have reportedly begun moving into virtually every major town in the Laotian panhandle area that had previously been under rightist control.

title: Health May Briefly Sideline Brezhnev
description: MOSCOW, May 20Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, who was absent from official view for seven weeks last winter, reportedly because of illness, is now expected to be out of sight again for at least three weeks, according to reports circulating here today.

title: A Brezhnev Report
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, is expected to be out of sight for at least three weeks, reportedly for medical treatment. Page 4.

title: 3 Blacks Convicted of Rape to Be Freed on Probation
description: TARBORO, N. C., May 20 (AP)Three young blacks originally sentenced to death after a jury convicted them of raping a white woman entered negotiated pleas to a lesser charge yesterday and were given probationary sentences that will end their confinement Aug. 18.

title: Ominous Slide in Lisbon
description: The shutdown by military order of the Socialist newspaper in Lisbon after its seizure by Communist employes moves Portugal one more substantial step toward Marxist dictatorship and possible civil war. Only a sharp reversal of direction by the ruling Armed Forces Movementin which moderate officers, still believed to be majority, seem to lose every crucial round to a Marxist cabalcan head off catastrophe.

title: Head Shoots 65, Leads in Dodge
description: DENVILLE, N.J., May 20Gasy Hea??, 33yearold pro at Mountain Ridge in West Caldwell, shot a 65, the best round of his competitive Career and held a twostroke lead after the first round of the annual Dodge open golf tournament at the 6,355yard Rockaway River County Cub ??.

title: College, School Results
description: BASEBALL

title: Scenes in Saigon as the Communists Took Over
description: It is finished, an official of the South Vietnamese police said, as Communist forces took over Saigon April 30. As a reporter and photographer watched helplessly, he shot himself fatally, in front of a war memorial in Saigon. This and other scenes of the takeover have just been received from staff and auxiliary photographers of The Associated Press. They were taken to Bangkok, Thailand, by a newsman and transmitted to U.S.

title: URUGUAY LEADERS IN CATTLE DISPUTE
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 20 (AP)The chiefs of Uruguay's armed forces pressed President Juan Maria Bordaberry today to reinstate an official he dismissed yesterday.

title: Goldin and Financiers Meet on City Loan
description: A group of 30 financial leaders from banks, securities firms and lifeinsurance companies met yesterday with the City Controller to consider a request for a, $280million loan, but then deferred a decision until it meets with state officials.

title: House Backs Public Works
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) The House voted today to authorize $5billion for state and local public works projects to spur employment in, construction and related industries. The vote, 313 to 85, sent the measure to the Senate.

title: Methadone Official Decries Bill to Shut Private Clinics Here
description: The director of the city's methadone  maintenance program said yesterday that despite the acknowledged abuses and shortcomings of private methadone clinics, he opposed a City Council resolution that would phase out such profitmaking facilities in three years.

title: SAIGON IS JOLTED BY A GUN BATTLE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 20 (Reuters)A group of men fought a gun battle with policemen in the center of Saigon today.

title: GINZBURG IS SUED BY CITY OVER ADS
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs filed suit today against Ralph Ginzburg, the magazine publisher, charging that he was falsely advertising a dictionary.

title: Noranda Cuts Lead Price
description: The Noranda Sales Corporation, marketing unit for Noranda Mines, Ltd., reduced yesterday its Canadian lead price by threequarters of a cent a pound and the United States quotation by 1 cents. The new American price is 22 cents a pound and the Canadian, 20 cents.

title: Toll Increase Fails to Cut Port Authority's Traffic
description: The daily stream of traffic between the city and New Jersey has not been turned off by the big increase in tolls May 5traffic has actually increased in the first two weeks since then

title: ROBERT E. QUINN, MILITARY JUDGE, 81
description: WARWICK, R.I., May 20 (AP)Formar Gov. Robert E. Quinn, who was the first chief judge of the United States Military Court of Appeals, died here yesterday. He was 81 years old.

title: 55M.P.H. Electric Car Unveiled in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) A prototype electric car with a top speed of 55 miles an hour and a driving range of 70 to 75 miles in urban traffic was unveiled before reporters and onlookers here today.

title: U.S. ORDERS CITY TO DISMISS SEVEN
description: The United States Department of Labor yesterday ordered Mayor Beame to dismiss seven city neighborhood workers paid with Federal public service job money on the ground that they had been hired because of their political ties to the Democratic party.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has been awarded a $100million contract from the Public Service Company of Indiana for two nuclear turbine generators and auxiliary turbines. They will be installed in he utility's Marble Hill nuclear power station near Madison. Ind.

title: Korean Stops Mexican
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 21 (AP)Hong SooHwan of South Korea, a former world bantamweight champion, knocked out Johnny Mesa of Mexico in the second round tonight of a scheduled 12round non title match the South Korean weighed 1193/4 pounds and the Mexican 116.

title: Congressman Profited in Land Deals as a Result of His Own Bill
description: DESTIN, Fla.A little known but enormously powerful Congressman has made thousands of dollars over the last 12 yearsand today stands to profit still furtherfrom land whose value was enhanced by his own legislation.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MAY 22, 1975

title: A Tremendous Chorus Line Arrives
description: The conservative word for A Chorus Line might be tremendous, or perhaps terrific. Michael Bennett's newstyle musical opened at the Newman Theater of the New Shakespeare Festival Public Theater on Lafayette Street last night, and the reception was so shattering that it is surprising if by the time you read this, the New York Shakespeare Festival has got a Newman Theater still standing in in its Public Theater complex on Lafayette Street. It was that kind of reception, and it is that kind of a show.

title: Western Newsmen Complain
description: SAIGON, May 21 (Reuters)Western newsmen today protested to the new Saigon authorities about difficulties in gathering and transmitting news and film reports.

title: 2 Bars and Couple Sued in Car Crash
description: Two taverns, as well as two neighbors who served a man liquor in their home the day his car struck and killed woman while he was intoxicated, were named codefendants yesterday in a $13million damage suit.

title: A.B.A. Championship
description: Indiana vs. Kentucky

title: Books of The Times
description: Her head has an ample cranial structure that dominates her frail body; her figure is flawless and impersonal in the modern manner  her hands she regrets  however, her feet  are beautiful, small and elegant, with classically separated toes. As you can see from this description of Wallis Simpson, Janet Flanner took her reporting seriously. In the mornings around the palace, Queen Mary often whistled when she was alone. Her doll's house was probably the most elaborate in all history, including elegant furnishings  a wine cellar, fishing rods,  a library of postage stamp  sized books handwritten by Milne, Conan Doyle, Maugham, et al., an insurance policy, toilets, baths, towels, and water that runs. The Queen was traditionally entitled to the tail of any whale taken on English coasts, to use in the boning of her corsets.

title: Ship's Safe Reported Looted
description: SINGAPORE, May 21 (UPI)A spokesman for SeaLand Services, owner of the Mayagez, said today that Cambodian Communist soldiers who boarded the vessel last week looted the ship's safe of $5,000 in cash.

title: Bugner Arrives Here
description: Joe Bugner, who will fight the heavyweight champion, Muhammad Ali, June 30 at Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, arrived here yesterday for a few days of workouts and a news conference next Tuesday. Bugner, the European champion, will return to London following the news conference with All and is tentatively set to leave for Malaysia June 6 or June 7.

title: Hanoi Delegation in Bangkok for Talks
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 21 A 13member North Vietnamese Government delegation arrived here today and said that in the present situation, conditions are now favorable for negotiations to normalize relations.

title: DR. BY RON RIEGEL, 68, HELPED DEVELOP PILL
description: Dr. Byron Riegel, who was important in the development of oral contraceptive drugs, died Tuesday at his home in Evanston, Ill. He was 68 years old.

title: Magnavox is Raising Price On Color TV Sets for 76
description: The price of 1976 model Magnavox brand color television sets will be 5 to 6 per cent higher than the prices of last year, the Magnavox Company disclosed here yesterday. The price change is similar to those made earlier by the RCA Corporation and the General Electric Company.

title: Role of the A.S.P.C.A. Here is Discussed
description: The role of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and its relationship to the animal world was the topic for a speech by Encil Rains. the tion' vice the organization's executive vice president, before the Dog Fanciers Club here last week.

title: 100 OTHERS LINKED TO GRAIN SCANDAL
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 21As many as 100 more personsemployes of grain elevators and othersare under investigation and face the threat of indictment in a continuing Federal Inquiry into the handling, inspection and weighing of grain In the Port of New Orleans and elsewhere for shipment overseas, according to sources close to the case.

title: S.E.C. LAYS FRAUD TO REFRACTORIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The General Refractories Company; was charged by the Securities; and Exchange Commission today with fraud and other violations of Federal securities laws in failing to disclose that Hermann Mayer, an Austrian citizen living in Switzerland, is a substantial stockholder in the company.

title: Cosmos 731 Launched
description: MOSCOW, May 21 (Reuters) The Soviet Union launched today a new earth satellite called Cosmos 731, the 30th since the beginning of the year In a predominantly militaryoriented series.

title: OILPRICE RISE URGED BY EMIRATE OFFICIAL
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, May 21Another Middle East oil exporting country has called for increase in oil prices after the price freeze of the 13nation organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries expires Sept. 30.

title: Business Briefs
description: Consumer confidence about the future state of the nation's economy has increased significantly in recent months, the Conference Board reported yesterday. The public's plans to buy various goods and services have also been stepped up, the board said on the basis of its latest surveys among 10,000 households across the country.

title: Women in Ku Klux Klan Move Into the Male Power Structure
description: BATON ROUGEWomen, once confined to auxiliary roles in the Ku Klux Klan, are now becoming more active and vocal in some branches of the secretive white supremacy organization.

title: 75 SENATORS BACK ISRAEL'S AID BIDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 Seventyfive Senators sent a letter to President Ford today saying that they expected the Administration to submit a foreign aid request to Congress that will be responsive to Israel's urgent military and economic needs.

title: State of the City: Delivering Justice
description: The law is a majestic edifice sheltering all of us, wrote John Galsworthy, each stone of which rests on another. The analogy transcends time and jurisdictionand is particularly relevant in a great city of strivers and strife. New York's judicial system does not begin and end at arbitrary borough lines; state and Federal laws and assistance are very much a part of the city's supporting legal structure.

title: New Bond Issues
description: UTILITY BONDS

title: Police Will Press Drive On Arson in South Bronx
description: The Police Department is calling into action more than 200 investigators in a campaign to curtail the epidemic of fires that have been devastating the South Bronx, Chief of Detectives Louis C. Cottell said yesterday.

title: Slaying Suspect Used False Identification
description: The police have confirmed that a prisoner being held in the slaying of Jon Streep, an art dealer, in an East Side hotel on May 10 was actually a 17yearold drifter from New Jersey who used an identification card of an upstate man when he was arrested at the murder scene.

title: Aqueduct jockeys
9 DEAD IN LEBANON IN 3 DAYS OF STRIFE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 21Casualties in a renewal of fighting between Palestinian guerrillas and members of the rightwing Phalangist party have risen to nine dead and about 75 wounded, according to the police.

title: BADILLO URGES U.S. TO STUDY CITY HIRING
description: Representative Herman Badillo, Democrat of the Bronx, yesterday called upon the United States Department of Labor to determine who was responsible for hiring people with political ties for Federal public service jobs in the city, and if the eppointments were arranged by the Mayor's patronage office in City Hall.

title: U.S. May Fine Boston Ed
description: BOSTON, May 21 (UPI)The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission has proposed slapping a $12,000 fine on the Boston Edison Company for alleged infraction of N.R.C. rules, Boston Edison confirmed today.

title: House Democrats Put Off Fight Over Strip Mine Veto
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The Democratic leadership of the House of Representatives decided today to retreat and fight another day rather than face possible failure in attempting to override President Ford's veto of the strip mine control bill.

title: 'Eiger Sanction,' Film of Climbing Spies
description: "The Eiger Sanction" is a long, foolish but never boring suspense melodrama about a college art professor named Jonathan Hemlock (Clint Eastwood), who has a passion for French Impressionists and mountain climbing and an underground reputation as the best assassin in the international spy business.At the start of "The Eiger Sanction," which opened at three theaters yesterday, Jonathan is lured from the campus by his former employer, a man named Dragon, the head of a secret United States Government agency called CII (pronounced "See-Too," not "See-Eye-Eye"), to assassinate a couple of men in Switzerland who earlier had assassinated a CII man. Jonathan agrees so that he can buy a newly "hot" Pissarro and receive Internal Revenue Service approval of all the other stolen masterpieces in his private collection.Jonathan isn't above murder-for-pay or underwriting art thieves but he draws the line when a pretty student offers to sleep with him in order to get a B-minus in his course. Jonathan is that sort of guy: vaguely scrupulous."The Eiger Sanction" is full of people with divided loyalties and peculiar names that recall the somewhat fresher inventions of Ian Fleming. It moves around this country and in Switzerland as if it had a Eurailpass good for the world. I suspect that one shouldn't inspect the plot too closely, but it passes so quickly most of the time you don't notice it.One of the film's two major sequences is set in the American West, where Jonathan goes to freshen up his mountain climbing techniques and where he murders an old enemy by leaving him to starve in the middle of Monument Valley. This is patently silly. Everybody knows you couldn't starve to death in Monument Valley. You'd be rescued before sunset by a Hollywood movie crew.The other major sequenceand it's a stunning one if you've been able to sit through everything elseis an attempt to scale a Swiss mountain peak known as the Eiger. Jonathan has gone on the climb because one of the other members of the expedition is the second assassin he's after. Which one is it? He doesn't know but you can possibly guess by reading the cast list carefully. What is more important than mystery is the spectacle of the climb, which looks difficult and very beautiful.The rest of the movie is the kind of tongue-in-cheek nonsense that Mr. Eastwood, who also directed the film, laboriously intended. Supporting the star are George Kennedy, as an old mountain-climbing buddy who calls Jonathan "old buddy" all the time: Vonetta McGee, as Jonathan's black girlfriend who also hustles as a courier, and Jack Cassidy, as a swishy courier who owns a dog called Faggot.

title: Ben Jipcho Answers the Mile Record
description: The mile is in style again. For nearly eight years, Jim Ryun's world record of 3 minutes 51.1 seconds slowly developed into a tragedy instead of a triumph, a sad reminder of what he didn't achieve after it rather than what he had accomplished with it. Now that glorious burden has been transferred to Filbert Bayi, whose speed is more apparent than his psyche. Filbert Rayi of Tanzania, who learned Sports of The Times run by chasing gazelles with his dogs on the plains not far from Mount Kilimanjaro, holds the mile record with a time 3:51 at the International Freedom Games in Kingston, Jamaica, last Saturday night. of Most of the world was properly impressed with the 21yearold African's performance, but Ben Jipcho wasn't. Ben Jipcho is a 32yearold African from Kenya who dominates the International Track Association tour. Ben Jipcho runs the mile, as he will next Wednesday at Madison Square Garden in an I.T.A. meet. He also runs the twomile and the halfmile.

title: Distraction Stalks Inspector Clouseau
description: In Paris, Inspector Clouseau (Peter Sellers), illustrious hero of "The Pink Panther" and "A Shot in the Dark," pounds the pavement as a common gendarme. Demoted, Kicked downstairs. Stripped of his prerogatives to interfere with the more important affairs of justice. But talent will out.Strolling one day along an avenue on his beat, Clouseau comes upon a blind organ grinder and his monkey outside a bank. Clouseau has a long and profoundly solemn exchange with the organ grinder about the business arrangements the man has with the monkey (or "minkey," as Clouseau pronounces it).All the while, through the bank window, we witness the hold-up that Clouseau, with his usual preoccupation with the nonessential, doesn't see. When the bank manager runs out to the sidewalk calling for help, he's the one that Clouseau clubs, not the organ grinder who was, of course, the lookout.Blake Edwards's "The Return of the Pink Panther" brings back Inspector Clouseau in the superbly awkward figure of Peter Sellersriding, walking, falling, driving, slipping and stumbling to success. His dignity is challenged from time to time, but his faith in his nonexistent deductive powers remains unshaken.Clouseau is the very special slapstick triumph of Mr. Sellers and Mr. Edwards. He's not stupid in any ordinary sense. He simply allows himself to be too easily distracted by details of secondary importance. He's like a child who has just learned to read. No set of instructions on an aspirin botle would be without interest to him.When Clouseau is at hand, innocent objects become potential weapons of destruction, often his own. It has something to do with the intensity of his distraction. You can imagine him getting fatally entangled in a ball of yarn."The Return of the Pink Panther" is not to be muddled with "Inspector Clouseau," the feeble Bud Yorkin spinoff with Alan Arkin in the title role, made in 1968. It is, rather, a glorious throwback to the two 1964 Sellers-Edwards collaborations. "The Pink Panther" and "A Shot in the Dark.""The Return of the Pink Panther," which opened yesterday at three theaters, is again introduced by the marvelous Richard Williams cartoon character who upstages all of the title credits and is, in effect, everything that Clouseau is not  urbane, witty, sly, quick-witted, graceful.When Clouseau suavely salutes a passing lady by raising his billy club, he misses his hat and hits his eye. This time Clouseau is saved from the injuries that can be suffered on the street by the disappearance of the fabled Pink Panther diamond, the national treasure of the emerging, mythical Middle Eastern country of Lugash. They are the same diamond and the same country that Clouseau saved in the first film.Should you want to analyze the screenplay by Frank Waldman and Mr. Edwards, which probably isn't wise, you'd find it bears a distinct likeness to Alfred Hitchcock's "To Catch a Thief." Clouseau is called in to solve the new theft by the grateful government of Lugash, while the prime suspect, Sir Charles Litton (Christopher Plummer), the retired jewel thief, joins the case to clear his name. Sir Charles, known as the notorious Phantom, is repeatedly referred to by Clouseau as Sir Charles Phantom, the notorious Litton.Somewhat complicating matters are the presences of Clouseau's superior, Chief Inspector Dreyfus, hilariously played by Herbert Lom with the fury of the demonically possessed; Sir Charles's wife, Claudine (Catherine Schell), who seems to be enjoying herself no matter how outrageous the circumstances of the slapstick, and Cato (Burt Kwouk). Clouseau's Oriental servant, who sometimes hides in the refrigerator, the better to surprise his employer with an unexpected karate chop.The screenplay is funny but even better are the sight gags that are a kind of inventory of everything Clouseau has been unable to master in his long, irrelevant career  monkeys, magnifying glasses, vacuum cleaners, sauna baths, door bells, dance floors, false mustaches, kneehole desks and four-wheeled vehicles, all kinds and models.When Clouseau takes the wheel, the vehicle is inclined to balk, like a donkey, or to give up, to fall apart, as if suddenly stricken with an acute case of engine fatigue.

The program, which was completed with Kenneth MacMillan's Concerto, might have beenand possibly wasdesigned to show the range and versatility of Mr. Baryshnikov's particular dance genius. Although have been fortunate enough to watch him on and off since his debut in Leningrad in 1967, I think I have never before seen him in quite such exultant form.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Livingston College faculty voted overwhelmingly at its monthly meeting in Piscataway to ask that Rutgers University drop all charges and possible academic disciplinary action against students involved in two recent demonstrations. The protesters were responding to the university's policy requiring students to purchase a meal plan to get first priority for a dormitory room. Fortysix students were arrested an May 1 for occupying the offices of Dean Emmanuel G. Mesthene on the Livingston campus. They have been ordered to appear in Piscataway Municipal Court on Tuesday at 9 A.M. on two charges of disorderly conduct. week earlier, 50 students forcibly entered the Livingston cafeteria. Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, the Rutgers president, and the university board of governors have already taken public stands against amnesty for the students.

title: Political Axioms Seen in Energy Impasse

The first is that Congress cannot normally legislate on a significant issue in the absence of at least a vague national consensus on the issue.

Some railroads are in bankruptcy and others are on the brink of financial collapse. The rail problem has been neglected too long and the desperate condition of the industry is indicative of this neglect. We must begin once a major and massive initiative to restore the vitality of this essential industry.

title: CROWN OIL IS GUILTY IN PRICEFIXING CASE
description: BALTIMORE, May 21 (Reuters)The Crown Central Petroleum Corporation and some of its competitors have been found guilty of combining to fix gasoline prices in the Baltimore area, it was disclosed here today. Crown also has been found guilty of forcing some of its dealers to charge noncompetitive prices.

title: 4 Policemen Arrested
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 21 (AP)The arrest of four Jacksonville policemen has broken up a ring dealing in drugs and stolen building materials, says Chief of Detectives Matt Touchton. He disclosed that a fifth officer, supposedly booked last week on a grand larceny charge, was actually working under cover to help break the ring.

title: Uniforms for Students
description: LIMA, Peru (UPI)A law passed by Peru's military government requires all school children to wear gray uniforms to classes. The uniforms consist of a white shirt of blouse, gray pants or skirts and sweaters. In 1974, the law was expanded to permit slacks for girls.

title: C.W. GOFF, SURGEON, ANTHROPOLOGIST, 77
description: Dr. Charles W. Goff, an orthopedic surgeon and an anthropologist, died Sunday in Hartford. He was 77 years old and lived there.

title: Bugner Arrives Here
description: Joe Bugner, who will fight the heavyweight champion, Muhammad Ali, June 30 at Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, arrived here yesterday for a few days of workouts and a news conference next Tuesday. Bugner, the European champion, will return to London following the news conference with All and is tentatively set to leave for Malaysia June 6 or June 7.

title: EDITH GREENE LINDLEY
description: Edith Greene Lindley, editor of The Junior League Bulletin and chairman of the American Women's Voluntary Services in World War II, died Tuesday at her home, 151 East 83d Street. She was in her 80's.

title: GOLD PRICE SURGES AS DOLLAR WEAKENS
description: BRUSSELS, May 21 (UPI)The dollar weakened on all European money markets today, increasing demand for gold and pushing its price to the psycho.logically important $170anouncelevel in London.

title: House Votes $6Billion Bill To Expand Jobless Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) A $6billion economic emergency bill to extend and expand two temporary programs of federally financed benefits for millions of jobless Americans was passed overwhelmingly by the House tonight.

title: COMPANIES ACCUSED OVER ARAB BOYCOTT
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The Commerce Department; said today that at least 49 American exporters had violated trade laws by failing to disclose they had been asked, to participate in the Arab trade; boycott of Israel.

title: State Will Start Own Numbers Game
description: The threedigit Pick It game scheduled to start operation in New Jersey at 6:30 A.M. today is the first legal numberslike game in the nation, and the first of several steps by which the state hopes to stimulate its lagging lottery sales.

title: Presbyterians Emphasize Role Of Religion in the Bicentennial
description: CINCINNATI, May 21More than 700 representatives of the nation's 2.8 million United Presbyterians ended their eightday General Assembly here this afternoon after committing their church to the proposition that religion must play a significant role in this country's bicentennial. They also urged churchgoers to subscribe to a series of guidelines for religious participation in that event.

title: Market Averages
description: Wednesday, May 21. 1975

title: Iranian Terrorists Slay 2 U.S. Colonels
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 21Three terrorists with submachine guns shot and killed two United States Air Force officers here early today.

title: A NUCLEAR PLANT FOR SUBWAYS DUE
description: CATSKILL, N. Y., May 21The State Power Authority announced today that it intended to build a 1.2millionkilowatt nuclear power plant in Cementon, on the west bank of the Hudson River about four miles south of here, to supply electricity for New York City subways and commuter trains.

title: C.I.A. Role in Coup Denied In Letter to Mrs. Allende
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) The former head of LatinAmerican operations for the Central Intelligence Agency wrote the widow of President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile denying that the C.I.A. was in any way responsible for the Marxist leader's overthrow and death in 1973.

title: Harvester of Canada Layofl
description: CHATHAM, Ontario, May 21 (AP)About 1,600 salaried and hourly rated employes f the International Harvester Company, Ltd., of Canada will be laid offfor six weeks beginning Aug. 11, the company announced today.

title: FIRST LADY VISITS WITH KY ON COAST
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. May 21Betty Ford visited forTier South Vietnamese Premier Nguyen Cao Ky today in what called my humble palace as she toured the Southeast, Asian refugee center here.

title: Liddy Asks Cut in Sentence
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (Washington Star)G. Gordon Liddy, convicted Watergate burglar, has asked Federal District Judge John J. Sirica to reduce his 6 2/3to20year sentence, saying that the term is vastly greater than that imposed upon any other defendant in the Watergate tragedy. In the plea filed yesterday, Mr. Liddy asked that his sentence be reduced to the time he has already served, about two years, and that the $40,000 fire imposed by Judge Sirica be vacated.

title: DOW STOCK INDEX DECLINES BY 11.81
description: Discouraging news sent the stock market into a broad retreat yesterday as trading vol. ume fell.

title: Vorster Sets Aims For Disputed Land; U.N. Goal Not Met
description: WINDHOEK, South  West Africa, May 21 (AP)  Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa has announced major concessions on the future of SouthWest Africa, but they fall short of United Nations requirements for concrete progress toward independence for the territory by May 30.

title: Dividends Announced
description: Wednesday, May 21, 1975

title: CABLE TV LEADERS SEE SUPPRESSION
description: WASHINGTON, May 21A group of cable television executives told the Senate Antitrust Subcommittee today that the three major television networks had mounted an aggressive political and public relations campaign to suppress the transmission of television for a fee over cable.

title: Royals Top Yanks, 41, On 3Run Clout in 10th
description: George Medich did it again. This time, though, it had to hurt more than most of the other times that the Yankee pitcher has given up a costly home run.

title: Toye Off to Brazil for Pel
description: The New York Cosmos will meet the Israeli national team tonight, but Clive Toye, their general manager, will not be at the soccer game at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

title: Nygaard Conducts Youthful Orchestra In 2 Rare Cantatas
description: The Cosmopolitan Symphony Orchestra has played better in its 11year history than it did Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall. But the youth orchestra, which was celebrating, its annual benefit concert, played well enough at its best, and offered a sufficiently unusual program to more than make up for any technical lapses.

title: Ore. State Penalizes Two
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 21 (AP)John Cantlon and Jeffrey Sartz, Oregon State football players who competed while ineligible during the 1974 season, have been penalized one year of eligibility and ordered to the sidelines for the 1975 football season. They were penalized because they continued to play after dropping below the minimum 12 units registration, the Pacific8 Conference executive director, Wiles Hallock, said yesterday.

title: A.B.A. Championship
description: Indiana vs. Kentucky

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, MAY 22, 1975

title: Deaths
description: BAUMTheodore M. Loving brother of Erwin C. and John H. Service Friday, 11:45 A.M. at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: V.A. Studies Case of Patient Apparently Forgotten in an Elevator
description: CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) Veterans Administration officials are investigating the case of a paralyzed former marine who was apparently left in an elevator in which he rode up and down for 27 hours.

title: City's Leverage on Banks is Reduced By Policies on Use of Municipal Funds
description: Only $100million in city deposits are being invested by banks for their own gain at any Oven timeeven though $25billion in city funds passes through their hands each year because of an unusual city policy limiting the compensation due the banks for the servides they perform.

title: Officers' Posts Ide field
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Pentagon said that Colonel Shaffer was director of plans for the Military Assistance Advisory Group. He had been in Teheran for two years and was due to return to the United States this summer. He had 21 years of active service, and was an agriculture graduate of Ohio State University. His wife and two children were with him in Teheran.

title: Saigon Under the Reds: Playboy is Still on Sale
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21 (AP)There are strange sights and sounds in Saigon today for someone who knew the South Vietnamese capital before the Communists took it over.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The exaggerated response of the President, the Congress and the American public to the Mayaguez episode betrays a signal lack of perspective about the seizure of foreign vessels. Based on our use of troops and firepower, one might have imagined that the seizure of a foreign ship was an altogether extraordinary thing, an act of piracy meriting military reprisal.

title: ISAAC GILBERT
description: Isaac Gilbert, retired member of the general accounting department of The New York Times, died Tuesday at La Guardia Hospital in Queens. He was 77 years old and lived at 3993 48th Street, Long Island City, Queens.

title: Market Summary
description: Wednesday, May 21, 1975

title: New Chicago Options Sef
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said yesterday that it would begin trading in 12 new stock options today and tomorrow, all stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading will begin today in stock options for Boeing, Skyline, HewlettPackard, Black & Decker, Honeywell and CocaCola. The exchange will add options tomorrow for Colgate, Baxter, American Electric, Texasgulf, Schlumberger and Jim Walter. This will raise to 58 stocks the number in which the C.B.O.E. trades.

title: FIRST LADY VISITS WITH KY ON COAST
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 21Betty Ford visited forTier South Vietnamese Premier Nguyen Cao Ky today in what called my humble palace as she toured the Southeast, Asian refugee center here.

title: Movie:'Cornbread,' an Urban Tragedy, Arrives
description: "Cornbread, Earl and Me," which opened yesterday at the Penthouse, 59th Street Twin II and 86th Street Twin II theaters, is so much a tract for virtue that a feeling of guilt becomes inescapable in pointing out its shortcomings as a movie.After all, it's not every day that we get films that persist in extolling truth and decency even while making a bloody display of the unfairness of life. And judging by the warm-weather fare of the recent past, it isn't likely that this spring and summer will offer too many films that  like "Cornbread"can appeal to youngsters on a wholesome ethical plane while telling a story that bears some resemblance to life, and death, on real city streets.Part urban tragedy, part courtroom melodrama, "Cornbread" is the story of Cornbread Hamilton a black teenage basketball star about to leave his less-than-ideal neighborhood for college and obviously destined for a big-money professional career. The boy, however, is shot down by the police, who are pursuing an apparent psychopath, who has just left a woman all but dead.It's an all-too-familiar case, one in which the patrolmen involved  one white, one black  speak of something shiny, perhaps a gun, in the running youngster's hand. And it is one in which police superiors bring very real pressures to bear on adults and children in an effort to make certain that no contradictory evidence is offered after Cornbread's parents retain a lawyer to clear their dead son's name.Inasmuch as this is a movie that reinforces one's commitment to truth-telling, it must now be said that what detracts from it is a certain unevenness in the acting and a slapdash air about the climactic inquest that contrasts unfavorably with the careful and occasionally slow-moving construction of the early part of the film.Making his movie debut as Cornbread is Keith Wilkes, a pleasant personality but unlikely to win as an actor the accolade that he has just won for his feats with the Golden State Warriors of the National Basketball Associationrookie of the year.

title: PRICES INCREASED BY 0.6% IN APRIL ON FOOD COST RISE
description: WASHINGTON, May 21A renewed upturn in food prices in April produced the largest increase in three months in the Government's Consumer Price Index, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Kissinger, in Berlin, Affirms U.S. Defense of Allies
description: BERLIN. May 21Secretary of State Kissinger stood at the rostrum of West Berlin's House of Representatives today to confirm the past and to repledge the United States to this city's future.

title: Lack of City Budget Data Called Main Bar to a Loan
description: The lack of city budget fiOres is the chief obstacle to granting New York City the $280million loan it is seeking, according to Wall Street sources who attended the meeting, Tuesday of bankers and financial leaders considering the requests.

title: Bar Will Study WithheldEvidence Case
description: An officer of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York said yesterday that a committee would look into charges of misconduct against two Manhattan assistant district attorneys who had failed to disclose evidence that might have exonerated a man accused of a double homicide. The defendant had remained in jail for 14 months, unable to make bail and awaiting trial.

title: 23 Dead in Copter Crash Related to the Mayaguez
description: WASHINGTON, May 21Administration spokesmen said today that 23 American servicemen killed in a helicopter crash in Thailand last week had embarked for possible use in the military operation to rescue the Mayaguez and her crew.

title: Security and Freedom
description: BOSTON, May 21Even before the Revolution of 1776, Americans rejected the British system of licensing for publicationsthe requirement of official approval before any manuscript could be printed. The First Amendment wrote that disapproval into fundamental law. The Supreme Court has often said that the amendment, at its core, bars the licensing of expression.

title: Theater: Black River
description: In the first play of the monthlong SeasonWithinaSeason at the Negro Ensemble Company, Samm Williams gave a fine performance as a roistering seaman. The final installment of this minifestival, Welcome to Black River (which opened Tuesday), is written by the same Mr. Williams. It is the one play of the series that seems wrenched from the playwright's heart and, one might surmise, from the playwright's experience.

title: Senate Panel Requests Voluminous Intelligence Files From F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The Senate Select Committee investigating Federal intelligence activities has sent the Justice Department a request for intelligence files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and documents that department officials say is unprecedented in scope.

title: 12 Park Police Officers Shot Near Jefferson Memorial
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Two Federal Service police officers, stopped a car on routine traffic charge tonight and were shot and seriously wounded by one of its two occupants, a spokesman for the service said.

title: COLISEUM'S CHIEF FEARS CITY RIVAL
description: Howard G. Sloane, managing director of the New York Coliseum, said yesterday that the Coliseum might be put out of business if the proposed West Side Convention Center was built.

title: PRESIDENT STARTS TO MESH 76 DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, May 21President Ford today began organizing a campaign to the finish for a full term in the White House. He agreed, at a meeting with eight Republican Senators who are expected to seek reelection next year, to wage a coordinated campaign to make a donothing Congress a central theme of the 1976 elections.

title: Sports Today
description: City Game for high school stars. P.S.A.L. vs. C.H.S.A.A. AllStars at Mater Christi High School, Astoria, Queens, P.M.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Orpheus in the Underworld Overture, Offenbach; Piano Concerto in F minor, Hiller, Czech Suite, Dvorak.

title: People in Sports
description: Although batting 441, Gene Locklear was assigned to a minor league team by the San Diego Padres yesterday following his complaints that he has been benched for a 200 hitter.

title: And I Will Be Heard!
description: John Connally, the only certifiably Innocent man on the national political scene, survivor of an assassin's bullet and a wouldbe political assassin's false accusation, came to New York the other day to speak before the World Trade Day luncheon and thereby to take the first step on what could be a long comeback trail.

title: Lambs Club Bought by Church of the Nazarene
description: The Lambs Club, a Times Square landmark and longtime rendezvous for people in the theater, has been bought by a church that hopes to use it as a focal point from which to clean up Times Square according to the church's pastor.

title: LEASE RENEWED FOR HARLEM PREP
description: The Board of Education voted last night to renew the lease for the building occupied by Harlem Prep, despite objections from a board member who said the school should be moved into an empty cityowned school building in the community.

title: Rizzo Aides Planning to Unseat Party Regulars in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 21James J. O'Neill, the tough graying leader of the Plumbers union who led Mayor Frank L. Rizzo's antiorganization Democrats to a broad victory over party regulars in yesterday's mayoral primary lost no time today in mounting a drive to put the powerful party machinery under the complete control of the Mayor.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Arts and Leisure Guide of The New York Times last Sunday, the New York Renaissance Band recital in Carnegie Recital Hall this Saturday was incorrectly listed as beginning at 2:30 P.M. The recital starts at 8:30 P.M.

title: Nyquist Opposes Cut in the School Week
description: State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist said yesterday that it would be unwise and illegal for New York City to shorten its school week to save money.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A public offering of 4 million common shares of the El Paso Company, at $11.875 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by White, Weld & Co., inc. The parent company of the El Paso National Gas Company has said that net proceeds from the sale would be used to reduce outstanding shortterm, debt incurred to meet outlays for construction of liquefied natural gas tankers.

title: Bands and Bells to Help Ring in City's 18Month Bicentennial Celebration
description: Church bells will ring out across the city today. A 50gun salute will be fired in Battery Park. There will be sailing ships on the Hudson River, concerts in parks and plazas, the cutting of a 6footlong Liberty Cake decorated with flags in Rockefeller Center and a spectacular gala of patriotic music, red, white and blue flashing lights and a sky full of fireworks in Central Park tonight.

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 21, 1975

title: Lucille Black, Former Aide Of the N.A.A.C.P., 66, Dies
description: Lucille Black, retired national membership secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died apparently of a heart attack, at St. Luke's Hospital on Sunday. She was 66 years old and lived at 531 East 20th Street.

title: Moment of Truth
description: The wrath Mayor Beame finds it so easy to work up against President Ford and the Republican leadership the State Senate subsides into meek surrender when New York's arrogant civil service unions turn thumbs down on budget economies essential to the city's survival.

title: SENATE UNIT, 94, BACKS HATHAWAY
description: WASHINGTON, May 21By a vote of 9 to 4. the Senate Interior Committee favorably reported to the Senate today President Ford's nomination of Stanley K. Hathaway, former Republican Governor of Wyoming, to be Secretary of the Interior.

title: 3 MORE NOMINEES OF FORD IN PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, May 21Serious doubt arose today over confirmation of three more nominees of President Ford for the Legal Services Corporation. One of them, a state attorney general, left a Senate hearing just before his scheduled apearance for questioning and did not return.

description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: City's Fiscal Crisis Scenario
description: The immediate and initial assumption made on Tuesday when Mayor Beame proposed a fourday work week or wage freeze Zo the city's municipal labor union leaders was News Analysis that the Mayor had raised the ante in his longrunning poker game with the union leaders. With a day and a night to think about what Mr. Beame did, however, the feeling among politicians now is that the Mayor has done nothing of the kind.

title: Attica Judge Criticizes Lawyers for Both Sides
description: BUFFALO, May 21Defense and prosecution lawyers were repeatedly scolded today by a State Supreme Court justice for attempting to go above and beyond the issues relevant to the trial of an inmate leader of the 1971 rebellion at Attica State Correctional Facility.

description: YONKERS, N.Y.

title: LILCO Is Indicted On State Charges Of Air Pollution
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., May 21The Long Island Lighting Company was indicted today on charges of violating state airpollution laws.

title: Beanie Drops Proposal to Impose 4Day Week and Delay Raises
description: Mayor Beame, backing off from his proposal of the dayl before, asserted yesterday that instituting a fourday work week for city employees as a way of cutting the deficit in the next budget would be poor financing.

title: S.E.C. FILES CHARGE ON UNITED BRANDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged the United Brands Company with a continuing effort to conceal the true scope and extent of its payments to foreign government officials, including $1.25million paid in Honduras and at least $750,000 in Italy.

title: Raiders Kidnap 3 U.S. Students at Tanzanian Wildlife Station
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 21 (Reuters)Forty armed Africans have kidnapped three Stanford University students and a Dutch woman from a wildlife research station in western Tanzania, United States officials reported today.

title: Bomb Found in Courthouse
description: ORANGEBURG, S.C., May 21 (UPI)  A 95stick dynamite bomb was found today in the basement of the Orangebury County Courthouse. The building and all other structures within a twoblock radius were evacuated and demolition experts were called in from the nearby Fort Jackson Army Training Center.

title: Opposing Views on S.I. District Expressed at Planning Hearing
description: It was Commissioner Gordon J. Davis who introduced the term infrastructure to last night's City Planning Commission hearing on a proposed special planning district for the South Richmond area of Staten Island.

title: PETER KYROPOULOS
description: Peter Kyropoulos, an executive engineer on the General Motors Corporation's engineering staff and a former associate professor of mechanical engineering at the California Institute of Technology, died yesterday at his home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 60 years old.

title: Fog Clouds N.H.L. Expansion
description: BUFFALO, May 21If the National Hockey League has been wondering why it cannot keep expanding indiscriminately, the final round of the Stanley Cup playoffs between the Buffalo Sabres and the Philadelphia Flyers may have provided one big reason fog.

title: Link With Advertising Is Severed by Cone
description: Yesterday Fairfax Cone, one of the grand old men of the advertising business, severed his last tie witn the advertising agency he ran for so many years He did not stand for reelection to the board of Foote, Cone gt Belding, from which he retired in 1970. He is 72 years old.

description: Horses listed in order of Post Positions Letter deslonates OTB listing FIRST$8,000. cl., 4Y0 and UP, 6f.

title: DAMASCUS AGREES TO 6 MORE MONTHS FOR BUFFER FORCE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 21Syria agreed today to a sixmonth extension of the United Nations peacekeeping force separating Syrian and Israeli troops on the Golan Heights.

title: Screen
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art set a precedent yesterday in presenting its first program of silent, photographic slides and film frames under the general title Genetic Codes. A collection of three studies made by Robert Polidori, dwelling largely on the examination of a succession of stills, it is a tribute to the producer's devotion to his special field but is something less than exciting for, say, standard moviegoer or, perhaps, a film buff.

title: Carla Hubner, Pianist, Offers Recent Music
description: Carla Hbner, a Chileanborn pianist, gave the first of two recitals devoted to 20thcentury piano music Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall. Unlike many performers who specialize in recent music, Miss Hubner is not afraid to look for warmth and lyricism in such works at Schoenberg's Three Pieces for Piano (Op. 11). Moreover, her obvious affection for and involvement in John Cage's The Perilous Night, clothed the simplicities of that suite for prepared piano with an introspective, hypnotic power.

title: Mauritius March Broken Up
description: PORT MAURITIUS, Mauritius, May 21 (Reuters)Policemen used batons to break up a march by 3,000 striking secondary students on the Mauritian capital here yesterday. The march was called to protest against deficiencies in the Indian Ocean island's educational system.

title: Montreal Tells I. O. C. All's Well
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 21The Canadian Cornmission for the 1976 Summer Olympic Games and the Mayor of Montreal, the host city, insisted today that they had convinced the International Olympic Committee that the games would be held on schedule.

title: WALTER ADAMS, EDUCATOR, DEAD
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 21 (Reuters)  Sir Walter Adams, the controversial former director of the London School of Economics and Political Science and the University College of Rhodesia, died here today of a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

title: Ford EnergyPolicy Action Likely Soon
description: WASHINGTON, May 21Administration officials said today that President Ford was virtually certain to announce a major energypolicy action before he leaves for Europe on May 28.

title: Court Curbs Changes In Renewals of Leases
description: Civil Court Judge Bentley Kassal has ruled that a renewal lease under the Rent Stabilization Law must be offered to tenants on the same conditions as the expiring lease.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A new rule intended to protect New Yorkers from the inconvenience caused by noshow repairmen and delivery men was adopted yesterday by the Department of Consumer Affairs to go into effect on June 23. The rule, Consumer Protection Law Regulation 43, requires repairmen and delivery men to give at least one day's notice if they are unable to keep appointments. If the customer questions the merchant's claim that exceptional circumstances prevented him from giving the required notice of delay, the matter will be submitted to a departmental hearmg. If the appointment is postponed three or more days, the merchant must send the customer a written notice within one day of informing him of the delay. Violators face fines of $50 to $350.

title: Surinam is Gripped by Disorders as it Moves Toward Independence
description: PARAMARIBO, Surinam, May 21Devastating fires and angry demonstrations have erupted here daily for the last week as this former Dutch colony painfully works out final plans for independence.

title: Making the Machinery Work
description: The Federal Government also should play an expanded role. On the criminal side of the ledger, the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration now provides some funds for programs and studies in crime prevention, corrections and rehabilitation, and community relations. But there should be far more emphasis on courtoriented programs and somewhat less on upgrading the hardware of police agencies.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF AS TRADING EASES
description: Prices on the American Stuck Exchange and in the overthecounter market fell yesterday in lighter trading.

title: It's AllStar Time For the Dribblers
description: The beat of dribbled basketballs goes on. Tonight at 8 o'clock a team of New York public school allstars plays a squad from Catholic and private schools in the sixth High School Sports annual City Game at Mater Christi in Astoria, Queens. The game benefits the Harlem Junior Olympic program, a citywide summer program that involves competition in 10 sports.

title: Pro Transactions
description: SAN DIEGO (NI) Recalled Larry Hardy, righthanded etcher, from Hawaii of of the ?? Coast League, Optinqed Gene Locklear, outfielder, to Hawail.

title: Chess:
description: Just a few years ago Svetozar Gligoric told me, I don't understand why all these players are so fascinated by the Sicilian Defense. They get wiped out using it and still they come back for more. They must be crazy. Recently, however, none other than the Yugoslav grandmaster himself has joined the ranks of the crazies.

title: Sports Today
description: City Game for high school stars. P.S.A.L. vs. C.H.S.A.A. AllStars at Mater Christi High School, Astoria, Queens. P.M.

title: FIRESTONE PROFIT OFF AS SALES RISE
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's second iargest tire producer (after Goodyear), reported yesterday declines in net income of 8.4 per cent for the second fiscal quarter and 17.3 per cent for the six months ended April 30. Sales in these periods showed gains of 8 per cent and 6 per cent.

title: $200Million Limit Set on State Help to Cover $1Billion Shortage
description: ALBANY, May 21Governor Carey intends to name tomorrow a fourmember blue ribbon panel of nonpoliticians to consider how government and private financing sources might help New York City cover its cash flow interruption a $1billion temporary shortage of cash to pay its regular bills.

title: PUBLIC ORDER BILL APPROVED IN ITALY
description: ROME, May 21Parliament tonight passed a controversial law aimed at curbing crime and political violence by broadening the powers of the police and of magistrates in pretrial proceedings.

title: 100 OTHERS LINKED TO GRAIN SCANDAL
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 21As many as 100 more personsemployes of grain elevators and othersare under investigation and face the threat of indictment in a continuing Federal inquiry into the handling, inspection and weighing of grain in the Port of New Orleans and elsewhepe for shipment overseas, according to sources close to the case.

title: A Flamboyant Peter Pan Is Fun for Children
description: Among the many kinds of children's theater is the spectacular production / superficial plot type, and that's the classification for The Peter Pan Game at the New York City Department of Recreation's Cottage Marionette Theater.

title: DELAWAREPORTUNIT OPPOSES GAS PLANT
description: CAMDEN, May 21The Delaware River Port Authority voted unanimously today to oppose construction of a liquefied natural gas plant in Gloucester County.

title: U.S. CONVICTS 3 MORE IN SECURITIES FRAUD
description: LOS ANGELES, May 21 (UPI) Three former auditors of the Equity Funding Corporation of America, which went bankrupt in one of the largest business frauds in American history, were convicted in Federal court yesterday of securities fraud and filing false statements with the Government.

title: GOVERNOR PRESENTS STATE ARTS AWARDS
description: ALBANY, May 21Governor Carey today presented the 1975 State Council on the Arts awards to II organizations and individuals and named Seymour H. Knox, who was chairman of the council for 15 years, as honorary chairman of the organization.

title: Robinson Shows His Indians How
description: Frank Robinson, the 39yearold manager and designated hitter of the Cleveland Indians, and Jim Kern a rookie righthanded pitcher. combined their talents to give the Indians a 32 victory over the California Angels in Municipal Stadium last night.

title: Police End PieinSky Pizza Plot
description: New Yorkeis have been eating a lot of hot pizza lately.

title: 75 SENATORS BACK ISRAEL'S AID BIDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 Seventyfive Senators sent a letter to President Ford today saying that they expected the Administration to submit a foreign aid request to Congress that will be responsive to Israel's urgent military and economic needs.

title: Davis, First Jet Pick, Signs WF.L. Contract
description: Anthony Davis, the Jets top draft choice who wasn't even slated for fulltime duty, has signed with the Southern California Sun of the World Football League for $300,000 cash as part of a 20year, $2million deal.

title: CLARENCE KILBURN, EXREPRESENTATIVE
description: MALONE, N.Y., May 21 (AP) Clarence E. Kilburn, who represented a fivecounty district in Northem New York in the House of Representatives for seven terms, from 1941 to 1965 died at his home here last evening. He was 82 years old.

title: Plan Would Let City Sell Brooklyn Bridge
description: ALBANY, May 21Want to buy the Brooklyn Bridge?
