description: Morning

title: Court Restructuring Needed
description: A constitutional amendment is up for second passage in Albany that would transfer administrative responsibility now fragmented among the state's four judicial departmentsthe First and Second are within this cityto a chief administrator of the courts. The amendment would enable the state to fund the operation and maintenance of the courts, as in most other states. Central state administration and financing could give flexibility pooling judges and court personnel, thus helping to clear calendars.

title: G.O.P. Governors to Meet
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The National Republican Governors Conference announced today that the 1975 winter meeting will be held Nov. 2022 in Wichita, Kan.

title: Computer Expert Testifies as the First Witness in I.B.M. Antitrust Trial
description: The Justice Department yesterday called Dr. Sidney Fernbach, head of the computation department of the Lawrence Radiation Laboratories of the University of California at Livermore, as its first witness in its civil antitrust suit against the International Business Machines corporation.

title: Aide Cites Guam Typhoons In Urging Refugee Transfer
description: WASHINGTON, May 21, (Reuters)  The chief of the Government's Vietnamese Refugee Task Force called today for a speedup in moving refugees from their tent city in Guam because it could be hit by a typhoon at any time.

title: U.S. Speeds Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (Reuters)The United States has speeded up its pullout of Americans from Laos following an attack by demonstrators on the A.I.D. complex in Vientiane and the detention of Americans in Savannakhet, the State Department said today.

title: Rangers Pursuing Redmond
description: BUFFALO, May 21 Tradewinds circulating today at the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup luncheon blew up some big names: Walt Tkaczuk of the New York Rangers and Mickey Redmond of the Detroit Red Wings.

title: House Approves Proposal To Overhaul Parole System
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) The House approved today a broad plan to overhaul the 45yearold Federal prison parole procedures.

title: Gladys Rousseau, 76, Designer Of Swimsuits for Sennett, Dies
description: FOUNTAIN VALLEY, Calif., May 21 (AP)  Gladys Rousseau Karaskiewicz, the costume designer who revolutionized bathing suits for Mack Sennett's pioneer movie comedies, died today of a stomach cancer at Fountain Valley Community Hospital. She was 76 years old.

title: Social Security Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff. Democrat of Connecticut, proposed today repeal of the rule that Social Security recipients who work can get full benefits only if they earn less than $2.500 a year. He called it a major work disincentive. He said his proposal had broad support.

title: SAIGON IS GETTING SOVIET GASOLINE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21 (AP)Three Soviet tankers have arrived at nearby Nha Be port with badly needed fuel for Saigon, where gasoline is selling for up to $8 a gallon. It was the first call at a South Vietnamese port by Soviet tankers.

title: Park of South Korea Meets Key Opponent On Security Issues
description: SEOUL, South Korea May 21President Park Chung Hee met today with his chief political opponent, Kim Young Sam, to review political and security issues in the light of Communist successes in Indochina.

title: JUNE SILVER IS UP BY 100 AN OUNCE
description: Speculators rushed to buy silver and gold futures yesterday following the announcement on Tuesday of downward revisions in gross national product figures. Gross national product measures the total value of goods and services in the nation and reflects the vigor of economic activity. The value of the dollar was also lower yesterday in foreign exchange markets.

title: SUBWAY EXCAVATION WEAKENS PROJECT
description: Excavation for the Second Avenue subway has partially undermined the foundations of the colonnaded entrance to the Manhattan Bridge on Canal Street and three supporting columns of the Confucius Plaza housing complex under construction just to the south of the bridge in Chinatown, city officials said yesterday.

title: Censorship Not Evident
description: News material from Associated Press correspondents In Saigon as received in New York shows no evidence of censorshipthat is, of words, sentences or paragraphs deleted. But Parts of articles sometimes fail to reach New York.

title: DR. WILLIAM H. MANDREY
description: HENNIKER, N. H., May 21 (AP)Dr. William H. Mandrey, former president of New Eng. land College here, died yester. day when he was stricken while driving his car. He ww. 81 years old.

title: Days May Be Numbered for Forum Restaurant
description: The Forum of the Twelve Caesars, once one of the most opulent and dramatic restaurants in New York, may be on the verge of shutting down. Dining room personnel said yesterday that the restaurant, at 57 West 48th Street, in Rockefeller Center, would shut its doors on June 10. The chef has already left, one captain said, and everyone else is looking.

title: Yeshiva Honors Bank Official
description: John H. Vogel, the president and chief executive officer of the National Bank of North America, was named yesterday the recipient of Yeshiva University's Metropolitan Award for 1975, The award is the university's highest accolade for distinguished leadership in the collaboration of business and the academic community for the advancement of higher education.

title: British Steel Gets Loan
description: LONDON, May 21 (Reuters) A Common Market Commission spokesman here confirmed today a $35.7million loan to the British Steel Corporation to help the company finance $290million improvement to its tinplate works. The terms of the loan have still to be worked out.

title: Fund Raiser Becomes New Kind of Power Broker
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The fundraiser Richard A. Vizuerie is a new kind of power broker for the era of broadbased campaign finance and the rnall contributor. For a number of conservative candidates he is already the indispensable man with the indispensable mailing lists. As such he may have as much control as any individual over the emergence of a new political party in the Presidential election of 1976.

title: SUPPLY OF MONEY ROSE IN THE WEEK
description: The nation's money supply rose again in the week ended May 14 while commercial and industrial loans continued to decline in the latest weekly periods. The statistics were released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the Federal Reserve Board in Washington.

title: The Girl on the Men's Team Casts an Eye Toward Fashion
description: Cyndi Meserve did not go to Pratt Institute last fall to play basketball. She was more interested in fashion.

title: CHURCH SCHOOLS GET RACIAL ORDER
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Internal Revenue Service announced today that taxexempt status would be denied henceforthth to churchaffilated pripary and secondary schools that refuse to accept children from all racial and ethnic groups.

title: Lyle Set for Trial In Shooting Case
description: DENVER, May 22 (AP)Ron Lyle, who lost his heavyweight title bout with the champion, Muhammad Ali, last Friday, was bound over for trial in District Court today on charges of second degree assault and felony menacing.

title: Rate Cut is Cleared
description: WASHINGTON. May 22 (Reuters)The Federal Reserve Board said today its hoard of governors approved today a reduction in the discount rate to 6 per cent from 6.25 per cent for the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. Minneapolis is the final Federal Reserve hank to move to the new lower rate.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.8 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 195.5 from 194.7 last week.

title: Cosmos Play to 11 Tie
description: Save after save after save is a goalkeeper's sweet song in soccer and Sam Nusum of the Cosmos sang it again and again against the Israeli national team last nightuntil the last 45 seconds.

title: Namath Turns Down W.F.L. While Jets Wait in the Wings
description: Joe Namath said no thanks to the World Football League yesterday, spurning the reported $4million offer of the W.F.L.'s Chicago team. But the status of pro football's most famous quarterback remains up in the air. He is a free agent, although the Jets want him back and hope to reopen negotiations soon with Jimmy Walsh, Namath's attorney.

title: Bankers Offer Loan Plan; Goldin Sees a Rejection
description: Leaders of the city's financial community laid down conditions last night for lending the city $280million to ease its current financial crisis. They did so in a letter to Controller Harrison J. Goldin, who said he considered it tantamount to a rejection of the city's request for a loan in that it may constitute requirements that cannot be met.

title: N.B.A. Championship
description: Golden State vs. Washington

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 8%
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Department of Commerce reported today that department. store sales last week were an estimated $1.12billion, up 9 per cent from the yearearlier $1.03billion. Total retail store sales were about $11.10billion, up 8 per cent from last year's $10.24billion.

title: Space Officials Give Approval to LinkUp Of Apollo and Soyaz
description: MOSCOW, May 22 (Reuters) Soviet and United States space officials gave formal approval today to a linkup of an American Apollo and a Russian Soyuz spacecraft in orbit. on July 17 following launching two days earlier.

title: Susanne Brody Wed in Jersey
description: At Temple EmanuEl in Westfield, N.J., last evening Susanne Adrienne Brody, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Brody of Scotch Plains, N.J. and West Palm Beach, Fla., was married to Glen Steven Rosengarten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rosengarten of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Don Decker.

title: Met's Art Shown in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, May 22 (AP)An exhibition of West European and American paintings from New York's Metropolitan Mu. sewn of Art opened today in the Hermitage museum in Leningrad. The paintings, from the 16th to the 19th centuries, are part of a cultural exchange program with the Soviet Union, which sent a collection of Scythian art from the Hermitage that is currently on exhibition at the Metropolitan. United States Ambassador Walter Stoessel read a message from President Ford at the Leningrad opening that said in part, We are pleased to share these paintings with Soviet audiences, and are confident that the exhibit will enhance the cultural ties we already enjoy and lead further.

title: A Gauguin at Auction Sets $950,000 Record
description: A Tahitian portrait by Paul Gauguin has been sold for $950,000, the highest price ever paid at auction for this artist and reportedly the third highest price ever paid for a postimpressionist painting.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Portugal's Socialist party, concerned over what it fears is the erosion of its freedom and power, yesterday made its most open challenge yet to the Armed Forces Movement, which rules the country. At a news conference, the party's leader, Mario Soares, accused the Armed Forces Movement of discriminating in favor of the Communist party and said that if such onesidedness did not end the Socialists would quit the coalition Cabinet. Nearly 50,000 supporters of the Socialists marched through downtown Lisbon in one of the biggest public demonstrations since the revolution last year. Meanwhile, the ruling Council of the Armed Forces Movement held another meeting and made an emergency appeal for unity by all Portugese political parties. It ruled out any form of political dictatorship. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: NEEDHAM CRITICAL OF STOCKTAX RISE
description: The city came under strong attack here yesterday as extremely shortsighted for considering an increase in securities taxes as a means of raising badly needed revenues.

title: Samuelson Cautions Steel Executives
description: Steel industry executives were told here yesterday that your bad time is still ahead of you.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
description: Chicago 100 000 110 J Los Artgeles 000 004 40x8

title: FETAL RESEARCH AVERTS ABORTION
description: Research on fetuses has enabled doctors to prevent an abortion in a case whereit was feared the unborn child was a victim of a debilitating hereditary blood disease known as Coolev's anemia.

title: LISBON SOCIALISTS THREATEN TO QUIT COALITION CABINET
description: LISBON, May 22The Socialist party, concerned over. what it fears is the erosion of its freedom and power, today made its most open challenge to the Armed Forces Movement that rules Portugal.

title: In Memoriam
description: BILDNERPatricia Elman. In memory of my beloved sister, Patsy, who passed awa three years today. Forever remembered, so sadly missed.

title: Banks Own Crisis
description: The city's big banks, which normally concentrate their main, efforts on making loans to the country's major corporations, now find themselves in an unaccustomed glare of publicity, blamed Tor much of the city's financial woe. For many New York bankers a breed caught up in the glamour of expanding overseas, opening offices in the Middle East, building nationwide networks of consumerfinance offices, maximizing profitsthe financial crisis at their home base has been a jolt.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER GAIN
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished slightly higher yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Some Refugees Were Just Swept Along
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 22The appeals of a small number of Vietnamese refugees who want to return to their homeland are not the result of a change of heart about the United States.

title: S. VAN ZANDT SCHREIBER
description: S. Van Zandt Schreiber, vice president and an director of VariVue International and foriner art director of Red Book and Good Housekeeping magazines, died Wednesday in New Rochelle (N.Y.) Medical Cellter. He was 62 years old and lived at 86 Wykagyl Terrace, New Rochelle.

title: Short Interest Climbs by 748,873 Shares to Record
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday reported that in the month ended May 15 the short interest position rose by 748.873 shares to a record total of 26,709,752. This is the second consecutive month for II a record total.

title: TRADING HECTIC IN SILVER FUTURES
description: Speculators seeking refuge in commodities as a hedge against the declining, value of the dollar actively bought silver futures yesterday. Trading was described as hectic on the Commodity Exchange, where 15,653 contracts changed hands, one of silver's busiest days.

title: STOCKS RISE A BIT AS TRADING SLOWS
description: The stock market moved in a narrow range yesterday in slower trading and finished with small gains. Analysts noted that the market was in a consolidation phase following its sharp advance of this year.

title: Dominica Plunge Kills 28
description: ROSEAU, Dominica, May 21 (Reuters)Twentyeight people died when a truckload of men, women and children plunged into a 500foot ravine in this West Indies island last night.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (Millions of dollars)

title: LISBON SOCIALISTS THREATEN TO QUIT COALITION CABINET
description: LISBON, May 22The Socialist party, concerned over what it fears is the erosion of its freedom and power, today made its most open challenge to the Armed Forces Movement that rules Portugal.

title: Colonels Win Title In A.B.A.
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 22 Jim Bradley, a reserve, stood on a locker smoking a big cigar. Artis Gilmore's Afro hairdo was filled with confetti and his body was covered with champagne that his Kentucky Colonel teammates had poured over his huge 7foot2inch frame.

title: PENSIONS STALLED BY LEGAL DISPUTE
description: Pension applications by 194 policemen and firemen or their widows were stalled yesterday when union representatives boycotted two meetings in a dispute with the city over its interpretation of the retirement law.

title: AID TO PALESTINIANS BY U.N. FACING CUT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22The United Nations aid program for Palestinian refugees is facing the worst financial crisis in its quartercentury of activity and may have to cut back soon on essential services, officials here said today.

title: Mansfield Forcing Fight Over Indian Ocean Base
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Administration is facing an open challenge from Senator Mike Mansfield over whether the United Stats in the period after the Vietnam war, should establish a military presence in the Indian Ocean by constructing a naval and air base on the island of Diego Garcia.

title: Lefty Grove, Hall of Fame Pitcher, Dies
description: Robert Moses (Lefty) Grove, a member of Baseball's Hall of Fame who as a star pitcher with Connie Mack's Philadelphia Athletics in the nineteentwenties and thirties won 300 majorleague games, died last night, apparently of a heart attack in Norwalk, Ohio. He was 75 years old.

title: BRONX WIDOW SLAIN AT APARTMENT DOOR
description: An 82yearold widow was found slain Wednesday night just inside the front door of the threeroom Bronx apartment where she had lived for 30 years.

title: Market Place
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, reluctantly bowing to pressure from the Securities and Exchange Commission, has filed an amended prospectus giving details of its loan experience, particularly with regard to the troubled Real Estate Investment Trust industry.

title: Sketches of 4 Named As Carey Fiscal Aides
description: Following are sketches of the four men appointed Governor Carey to be his panel to advise him on New York City's fiscal problems:

title: Corporations Debt Data Show Doubling From the 1968 Figure
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Idebt of the nation's corporations has about doubled since 1968, new figures from the Commerce Department showed Itoday.

title: Liquidation is Approved For Maserati, Car Maker
description: MILAN, Italy, May 22 (Reuters)  Shareholders of the Maserati sports car company, one of the most famous names in Italian motoring history, decided today to place the company in liquidation after a year of massive losses.

title: TANZANIANS PRESS HUNT IN ABDUCTION
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 21 (Reuters)A land, air and water search was under way today in the Lake Tanganyika region for three Stanford University students and a Dutch woman who were abducted from a wildlife research station on Monday by 40 armed ??.

title: The Mayaguez Incident and the Constitution
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Once more Congress has abdicated its constitutional responsibility, carried away by a wave of rally round the flag fever. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee hastened to set its seal on the President's exercise of his constitutional powers in sinking Cambodian patrol boats in order to regain the captured merchant vessel Mayagilez.

title: Penn Central Trustees Report $184Million Loss for 4 Months
description: A $184million deficit reported yesterday by the trustees of the Penn Central Railroad for the first four months of this year brought to $1.4billion the aggregate net loss incurred by the huge system since it filed for bankruptcy reorganization in June, 1970. The net loss for April alone was $56million.

title: HARTFORD ADOPTS MEDITATION PLAN
description: HARTFORD. May 22The Connecticut General Assembly gave final approval today to a bill requiring that time be set aside each day for meditation in the public schools.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday.

title: Sports Today
description: Practice for the Camel G.T. twin 100's to be run Memorial Day at Lime Rock Park, Lime Rock, Conn., 9 A.M.

title: Windfall Indicated for Nursing Homes
description: Financial reports of New York State nursing homes for 1974 disclose that their costs were far lower than the estimates on which their Medicaid reimbursement rates had been based. As a result, they obtained a windfall profit that may come to $70million, and little of it would appear to be recoverable immediately.

title: Feud Between Two Bedouin Clans in Sinai Tests Israelis' Diplomatic Skill
description: FIRAN OASIS, IsraeliOccupied Egypt, May 17The Jarrabahs and the Rawanmas are the Hatfields and McCoys of the southern Sinai Peninsula.

title: Woman Agrees to Change Site of Virgin Mary Vigils
description: Veronica Lueken, the 51yearold housewife whose widely proclaimed visions of the Virgin Mary have drawn thousands of devoted followers to a quiet, residential Queens community, agreed yesterday to hold her controversial vigils somewhere else.

title: Major League Leaders
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Olympics Exclude Rhodesia
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 22The International Olympic Committee, under pressure from black African countries, voted 4126, today to withdraw its recognition of Rhodesia and exclude it from the 1976 Olympic Games.

title: Saigon Tries Persuasion In Restoring Rural Life
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 22 (AP)The direction of the policy of South Vietnam's new leaders is becoming visible, one aspect of it being to persuade some of the people in Overcrowded cities to return to the countryside.

title: Broad Securities Reform Is Approved by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, May 22Legislation to carry out sweeping reforms in the structure and regulation of the securities industry received final Congressional approval today and was sent to the White House for the President's signature.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly identified the American Israel Public Affairs Committee as an official representative of the Israeli Government. The organization, which is financed by American citizens, is registered with Congress as a domestic lobby.

title: Yonkers Entries
description: Horses listed in order of Pbst positions Letter designates 0113 listing

title: Lefty Grove Dies
description: Robert Moses (Lefty) Grove, the lefthanded pitching ace of Connie Mack's great Philadelphia Athletics teams of the 1920's and early 1930's, died last night at his home in Norwalk, Ohio. The Hall of Fame member was 75 years old. Obituary on Page 40.

title: Acid Rain and Snow Regarded by Scientists as a Potential Hazard in Eastern U.S.,
description: Acid rain and snow, an effect of air pollution recognized decades ago in Scandinavia and thought to be among that regton's leading environmental problems, is now regarded by scientists as a potential hazard in the eastern United States as well.

title: Effort to Free Carter and Artis On Bail is Rejected by Judge
description: JERSEY CITY, May 22The New Jersey judge who pre viously denied Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis a new trial on triplemurder charges today refused to free them on bail while they appeal his decision to a higher court.

title: Issue and Debate
description: On May 8 after a sixhour closed meeting the city Health and Hospitals Corporation's 15member board voted with great reluctance to close Francis Deafield Hospital, a 163bed generalCare institution at 99 Fort Washington Avenue in Manhattan's Washington Heights section.

title: REFRACTOR DENIES COMPLAINT BY S.E.C.
description: The General Refractories Company issued yesterday statement through its legal counsel, the firm of Montgomery & McCraken, Walker & Rhodes of Philadelphia, denying all wrong doing alleged by the Securities and Exchange Commission in a complaint filed with the Federal District Court in Washington, D. C.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Bookselling in America and the World7Some Observations and Recouections: In Celebration of the 75th Anniversary of the American Booksellers Association, edited by Charles B. Anderson (Quddrangle/The New York Times Book Company, $9.50).

title: Ford Selects Mortgage Banker For Federal Reserve Vacancy
description: WASHINGTON, May 22President Ford announced today that he would nominate Philip C. Jackson, a mortgage banker from Birmingham, Ala., to fill a vacancy on the Federal Reserve Board.

title: ATTICA DEFENDANT PLACED AT SCENE
description: BUFFALO, May 22A prosecution witness today identified Bernard Stroble as one of the inmates who escorted two fellow inmates from a prison yard during the 1971 Attica uprising. The two inmates were found dead of multiple stab wounds after the rebellion was quelled.

title: Rail Traffic Declines
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Association of American Railroads estimated today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled 15.3 billion tonmiles, 12.3 per cent below a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 457,462 cars, 14.9 per cent below last year.

title: Maserati Failure
description: Stockholders of Maserati, one of the most famous names in motoring history, voted yesterday to place the company in liquidation. Page 48.

title: Reserve Reports
description: In Billions

title: Queens College Students Take Flyer on Sport of Kings
description: Nine students at Queens College have shaped a dream into a syndicate and have bought a 30 per cent interest in a racehorse that is scheduled to run under their colors at Aqueduct next Wednesday.

title: Levine to Be Music Director of the Met
description: James Levine, the 31yearold principal conductor of the Metropolitan Opera, has been appointed music director of the Met beginning with the 197677 season, the company reported yesterday.

title: Connecticut Passes Bill for Meditation In Public Schools
description: HARTFORD, May 22The Connecticut General Assembly gave final approval today to a bill requiring that time be set aside each day for meditation in the public schools.

title: Jury is Selected in Trial Of Kent State Civil Suit
description: CLEVELAND, May 22  A jury of six men and six women has been chosen to delve into the Kent State shootings of 1970 to determine if the rights of those killed and wounded were abridged.

title: People and Business
description: Despite an abundance of reports that oil prices may be increased again this year by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, a Treasury Department official contends that this is not yet definite because such increases are not now justified.

title: Bankers Offer Loan Plan; Goldin Calls it a Rejection
description: Leaders of the city's financial community laid down conditions last night under which it would lend the city $280million to ease its current financial crisis. They did in a letter to Controller Harrison J. Goldin, who said he considered it a rejection of the icity's request for a loan in that it may constitute requirements that cannot be met. Nevertheless, he said, he will continue to explore possible means of finding temporary financing.

title: Ford to Seek ReEstablishment Of White House Science Office
description: WASHINGTON. May 22President Ford pledged today to key members of Congress that he would act to reestablish as a permanent part of the White House organization. the Office of Science and Technology that his predecessor abolished.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Patriotism on Parade as City Bicentennial Gala Begins
description: There were bells, bands and speeches and a daylong burst of patriotism here yesterday as the city opened its official Bicentennial celebration.

title: A Family's TwoState Safari to Game Farms
description: With the determination of Stanley after Livingston, a family of five decided that on successive weekends it would see four jungle safaris and game farms that surround the city.

title: ExHonduran Chief Denies He or Aide Got Banana Bribe
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 22 (AP)Gen. Oswaldo Lopez Arellano, in his first public appearance since he was overthrown as the Honduran chief of state last month, said that neither he nor former Economy Minister Abraham Bennaton Ramos were implicated in a banana bribe scandal.

title: 2 Cars Crash in Indy Drill
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 22The 33 race cars that will compete Sunday in the 59th running of the Indianapolis 500 ran through a sort of dress rehearsal today, a threehour exercise with the anachronistic name Carburetion Day.

title: TURKS THREATEN TO CLOSE BASES
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 22Turkey is threatening to close several American military and intelligence facilities here, possibly within a few weeks, American diplomats said today.

title: Esmark Increases 3Month Net 14.9% As Revenues Drop
description: Esmark, Inc., the holding company that operates Swift & Co., the world's largest meat packers, and other enterprises, had a 14.9 per cent increase in net income in the quarter ended April 26 despite lower revenues, the company said yesterday. Earnings rose 11.6 per cent in the sixthmonth veriod.

title: HandRung Bell at St. Paul's Chapel Starts Others Ringing All Over City
description: At 12:19 yesterday afternoon, a husky blackrobed man standing on the floor, of the oldest church in Manhattan rubbed his hands together, seized the end of a 200foot cable connected to the huge bell at the top of St. Paul's Chapel and pulled with the full weight of his body.

title: Screen
description: It is gratifying but not surprising that Organism and The Nuer, the double bill at the Film Forum that focuses on a feverish New York and comparatively placid, isolated Ethiopian villagers, respectively, brilliantly illustrate Hilary Harris's artistic personal style and technique. As the director of a wide variety of documentaries over the last 25 Years, including the Oscarwinning Seawards the Great Ships, he again proves that documentaries are not synonymous with trite travelogues or dull pedantry.

title: CAREY PUTS CURBS ON AIDES' ACTIVITY
description: ALBANY, May 22Governor Carey today banned outside employment for members of his administration who earn $30,000 a year or more or who hold policymaking positions, and he ordered the same employes to make detailed annual disclosures of their net worth and sources of income.

title: Dorsey Bars Bolivia Trip; 2 Financings for Gulf Near
description: Bob R. Dorsey, chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation, said yesterday that he did not intend to go to Bolivia to reply to a summons calling for his appearance with regard to illegal political contributions in that country.

title: Shanghai Winners
description: MenDon Merrick, Delard, Fla., 250meter run, 20.7 seconds; Jerry Wilson, Los Angeles, 110meter hurdles, 13.6; Mike Manley, Eugene, Ore., steeplechase, 8:36.6; Don Kardong, Spokane, Wash., 5,000 meters, 14:13; Dennis Adama, Newaygo, Mich., high jump, 6 feet 10 inches; Terry Albritton, Newport Beach, Calif., shotput, 67 Tommy Haynes, Nashivell, Tone., long jump, 252 Al HaII, Charlton City, Mass, hammer throw 1822; 400meter relay, U.S., 40.3.

title: City Leads in Per Capita Expenditures
description: To provide services for New Yorkers, the city government spends nearly five times as much for each resident on operations and debt service as does Chicago, the country's next largest city  $1,233.68 compared wtih $267.29.

title: GABRIEL KOHN, 65, SCULPTOR, IS DEAD
description: LOS ANGELES, May 22 (AP) Gabriel Kohn, the sculptor, died yesterday at Sawtelle Veterans Hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: Private Schools Win Star Game
description: For one night at least, a team of Catholic and private school basketball allstars played the City Game better than a squad from New York public schools. The private school team scored the last 10 points of the game last night at Mater Christi High in Queens and won for the second time in the sixyearold series, 8483.

title: Events Today
ExAstronaut Studied for F.A.A. Job
description: The White House decided this week to name a former astronaut, Charles Conrad Jr., to head the Federal Aviation Administration, according to Government sources, but is reconsidering because of issues raised in a Senate vote against reinstating the last F.A.A. chief as a retired colonel.

title: TV: Fascinating Making of the President 1972
description: This Sunday at 9 P. M., Theodore White's The Making of the President 1972 will be shown on WNEW/ Channel 5. Made in 1973, the program was rejected by all three commercial networks, triggering righteous declarations that the major broadcasters were still being cowed be the Nixon Administration. The truth is probably considerably less complicated.

title: About Real Estate
description: All the toilet seats are gone now, and the former Berglas Manufacturing Company building on the Brooklyn waterfront, just south of the Brooklyn Bridge, is an apartment house. A designated landmark, in fact.

title: Lebanon Announces an Accord In Fighting as Deaths Reach 23
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, May 23The Government announced last night that an agreement had been reached to allow Lebanese security forces to be stationed between feuding Palestinian guerrillas and militiamen of the rightwing Phalangist party.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 1,340,000 common shares of W.W. Grainger, Inc., Chicago, at $24 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Kuhn, Loeb & Co.

title: Thursday, May 22, 1975
description: THE NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE

title: Director Who Listened to Chorus Line
description: How a typical Broadway musical comes into being, as described by Michael Bennett: The director sits in a room with the composer and lyricist for a year. The costumes and sets are designed. Orchestrations are done. And then, finally, actors begin rehearsing, with the hours strictly limited. The show goes out of town, where, under pressure, it is rewritten. You cross your fingers, said Mr. Bennett, and hope it comes together.

title: In Tourist Trade, No Sign is a Bad Sign
description: PENN YAN, N.Y.I've been here 38 years in business and all of a sudden the state sends a notice: Get your signs down or we'll take em down', said Clarence Ryal at his small gas station and sevenunit motel on Route 14 near Dresden in the Finger Lakes vacationland.

title: Villanova's I.C.4A Plan Is Built Around Goghlan
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 22  Even after his 3minute53.3second mile and surgery this week for an infected tooth, Eamonn CoghIan has lost none of his enthusiasm for tomorrow's 99th annual Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America outdoor track and field championships.

title: CHRISTOPHER MEYER JR.
description: J. Christopher Meyer Jr., a trial lawyer with the firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan, 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza, died yesterday at his home, Rock Ridge, Greenwich, Conn. He was 60 years old.

title: CARTER MID ARTIS ARE DENIED BAIL
description: JERSEY CITY, May 22The New Jersey judge who previously denied Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis a new trial on triplemurder charges today refused to free them on bail while they appeal his decision to a higher court.

title: PROFIT REPORTED BY BACHE GROUP
description: Responding to a snarp rise in trading volume the Bache Group. Inc., parent company of Bache & Co., Inc., the brokerage house, reported yesterday that profits for the quarter ended April 30 soared to $3.2million, or 45 cents a share, from a loss the year before of $1.4million.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Thuraday, May 22, 1975 CHICAGO GRAINS WHEAT

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A water expert told a public hearing in Trevose, Pa., that if the proposed Tocks Island Dam was built its reservoir would become vastly more polluted than Lake Erie.

title: Salute to the Marines Stirs Debate in Albany
description: ALBANY, May 22Testiness, marked debates in the two houses of the Legislature today, as the Senate engaged in controversy Over a salute to the Marine Corps's handling of the Mayagiiez incident, and an Assemblyman charged that his bill had been plagiarized.

title: HUSSEIN REGAINING ARAB WORLD ROLE
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, May 20King Hussein of Jordan, who lived in virtual isolation in the Arab world for years, now has good relations with Syria and Iraq as well as with Egypt and the conservative Arab countries of the Persian Gulf.

title: Back Bill on Drugs and Eyeglasses Ads Support Ads on Drugs and Eyeglasses
description: NEWARK, May 22In a clash today with trade and professional associations, the Byrne administration and the Federal Trade Commission strongly endorsed legislation that would permit advertising the prices of brandname prescription drugs and eyeglasses and eyecare service in New Jersey.

title: Bunker is Fearful Of Panama Conflict If Canal Talks Fail
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) Ellsworth Bunker, the chief United States negotiator for a new Panama Canal treaty, said tonight that armed conflict in the Canal Zone is a likely possibility unless Panama is given a voice in the canal's operation and defense.

title: A California Democrat Delivers the Votes in House
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 A few weeks ago, as South Vietnam was on the verge of collapse, Secretary of State Kissinger found time for leisurely twohour chat with a Representative he scarcely knew.

title: A Police Chief Says F.B.I. Was Lax in a Tap Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 22(AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation failed to investigate illegal wiretapping by the Houston Police Department thoroughly despite notification by the city's police chief that his telephone had been tapped, the chief said today.

title: Greece Officially Charges Papadopoulos With Treason
description: ATHENS, May 22 (AP)George Papadopoulos, leader of the 1967 coup that brought the military to power in Greece, has been officially charged with high treason and insurrection, the Government announced tonight.

title: Pop Life: Joan Baez On Record
description: Ever since she emerged on the folk scene around 1960, 4oan Baez has inspired mixed reactions. Almost everyone liked the clear, sweet tourity of her soprano, but some felt that her song inrpretations of some of the most impassioned sentiments in folkwere sadly tacking in vitality. And then lider, as her leftist commitments grew more overt, she incurred displeasure for her politics.

title: Thais Report Cambodian Reds Overrun a CliffTop Shrine
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, May 23 (UPI)Cambodian Communist troops have captured a cliff along the Thai border, overrunning a small force of AntiCommunist soldiers holding out since the collapse of the Phnom Penh Government last month, Thai officials said today. They said that the Cambodian forces pounded the top of the cliff with heavy artillery fire, scaled it and drove out the defenders. The Cambodians had previously launched several unsuccessful assaults against the holdouts.

title: Gotbaum Says He Prefers Job Cuts to Erosion
description: Victor Gotbaum, leader of the largest union of city employes, said yesterday that he would recommend acceptance of layoffs, if necessary in the current fiscal crisis, rather than agree to any erosion of present contracts.

title: Finch College Closing For 197576 School Year
description: The president of Finch College said yesterday that the 75yearold women's college on the Upper East Side would not reopen next fall and that its administration would try to raise the money to reopen it the following year.

title: Thousands in the Park Hear Patriotic Tunes
description: Several thousand people last night attended a concert of the American Symphony Orchestra playing a salute to American music at Sheep Meadow in Central Park.

title: Wineries in State Facing Price Dip
description: ROCHESTER (UPI)  A huge surplus of California wines has caused prices in that state to drop sharply. Now, for competitive reasons, New York wine prices may be forced down, too.

title: People in Sports
description: Bill Bradley, the National Basketball Association's Rhodes Scholar, may soon be joined by another of his kind, 23yearold Tone McMillen. Both the Buffalo Braves of the N.B.A. and the Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Association hope to sign McMillen. He resisted the lure of the professional sports dollar in the United States this season to attend Oxford University after graduating from the University of Maryland in 1974.

title: CONGRESS DELAYS HELP FOR RETIRED
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 Congress left today for a 10day Memorial Day recess after postponing until next month legislation that would finance a $50 cash payment to every recipient of Social Security benefits.

title: Closing of Brooklyn EyeEar Hospital Put Off a Week
description: Patients scheduled for surgery at Brooklyn Eye and Ear Hospital were sent home yesterday and 300 employes were told the hospital would close today, but the board of directors late in the day voted a reprieve of one week.

title: Steve Reich Gives Work in Progress At Kitchen Concert
description: Steve Reich is now giving fcur identical concerts of his works at the Kitchen (Wooster and Broome Streets), and the key piece is the last, entitled Work in Progress for 21 musicians and singers. (The final two are tonight and tomorrow night at 9 o'clock.)

title: Patriotism on Parade as City Bicentennial Gala Begins
description: There were bells, bands and speeches and a daylong burst of patriotism here yesterday as the city opened its official Bicenternnial celebration.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A spokesman for the Delaware River Port Authority said in Camden that it planned to appeal a Federal Highway Administration order to lower its bridge tolls from 60 to 55 cents by Aug. 1. The spokesman said that the bistate authority had 20 days to file papers in Federal court on the rollbacks ordered for the Benjamin Franklin, Walt Whitman and Commodore Barry bridges, and the Betsy Ross Bridge, scheduled to open Jan. 1.

title: Advertising
description: Inspiration for advertising campaigns can come from almost any source in the case of the preFathers Day TV effort for Bloomingdale's, the source is a short film that was on the bill with Xrated Emmanuelle at the Paris Theater. It was called Foot Fetish, a stopaction number all about two sneakers that make love and have a baby sneaker.

title: BLUE EYES FOUND MOST SENSITIVE
description: Anophthalmologist in a survey of 156 students in Wales, has found the corneas of those with blue eyes are the most sensitive to touch, and those with dark brown eyes are the least sensitive.

title: Zenith Raises Prices For Color Television
description: CHICAGO, May 22 (AP) Retail prices on 1976 Zenith color television sets will be increased by $10 to $20, the Chicagobased company said today.

title: ExRep. John H. Ray, 88, Dies; A. T. &T T. Aide Served 5 Terms
description: Former Representative John H. Ray, who was first elected to Congress from Staten Island and part of Brooklyn in 1952 after retiring at 65 as vice president and general counsel of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Wednesday at his home. He was 88 years old and lived at 57 St. James Place in the Dongan Hills section of Richmond.

title: Airline Said to Agree To Pay $150,000 Fine
description: WASHINGTON, May 22American Airlines has agreed to pay a Civil penalty of $150,000 as a partial settlement of a case in which it was accused of disbursing nearly twice that amount in illegal political contributions, The Washington Post reported in its Friday editions.

title: State Migrant Agency is Sued For Alleged Inspection Laxity
description: TRENTON, May 22A suit charging the State Bureau of Migrant Labor with failing to make inspections of farm labor camps as required by state law was filed today in State Superior Court in Cumberland County.

title: Music: The Philharmonic Begins Its Promenades Series Richly
description: One of the nice things about the New York Philharmonic Promenades is that they resurrect pieces that were once popular in symphonic programs but are no longer played. Lab's Overture to Le Roi d'Ys. for example, is a beautifully crafted, lovely work that in another day any conductor worth his salt would have been glad to put on a proram. It is ignored now as being too lightweight, as though only masterpieces allowed.

title: Smith Returns to Cards
description: ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP)Reggie Smith, an outfielder, sidelined for 13 games with a recurring back ailment, will rejoin the St. Louis Cardinals tomorrow in Los Angeles. Smith will be limited to pinchhitting or parttime play while treatment continues.

title: Windfall Indicated for Nursing Homes
description: Financial reports of New York State nursing homes for 1974 disclose that their costs were far lower than the estimates on which their Medicaid reimbursement rates had been based. As a result, they obitained a windfall profit that may come to $70million, and little of it would appear to be recoverable immediately.

title: Byrne Jeered by Newark Protesters Seeking State Aid for City's Schools
description: TRENTON, May 22 (AP)The jeers of Newark demonstrators today virtually forced Governor Byrne to retreat to his office after he had tried to deal with their demands for immediate state action to alleviate the city's schoolfinance crisis.

title: HARDWICKE SELLS INTEREST IN PARK
description: The Hardwicke Companies of Atlanta ans contracted to sell its equity in the Great Adventure Theme and Amusement Park in Jackson, N. J., to a trust established for the Pritzker family of Chicago, Charles H. Stein, chairman of Hardwicke, announced yesterday.

title: Big Board Avoids Liability In Member Firm's Failure
description: A jury found yesterday in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York that the New York Stock Exchange was not liable for $2.2million in damages sought by the family of James McDonnell, founder of McDonnell & Co., an exchange member firm that collapsed in 1970.

title: Ford's Condition Reported as Good
description: Whitey Ford, the Yankee pitching coach, who collapsed after pitching batting practice before Wednesday night's game, was reported in good condition at Long Island Jewish Hospital yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: The Lancia touring team, including several Italian world champions, is finding the American opposition tougher than expected. After losing in New York last weekend, they made a disastrous start in Los Angeles Wednesday. After 30 deals, they trailed by 56 international match points against Eddie Kantar, Bill Eisenberg, Larry Cohen and Dr. Richard Katz, all of Los Angeles.

title: IRAN SAYS KILLERS WILL NOT ESCAPE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 22Wellplaced Iranian and foreign sources said today that Iranian security forces were following up several leads in their hunt for the terrorists who shot to death two United States Air Force colonels here yesterday.

title: Television
Father of the Year, With 9Iron
description: Johnny Miller was in New York yesterday to be saluted as father of the year, a distinction he shares with Catfish Hunter (the good provider), Senator Edmund S. Muskie (whose 14yearold beats him at golf) and other sires not including Secretariat. The current leader among professional golf's economic royalists arrived at 1 A.M. with his wife, Linda, and their daughter Kelly, aged 2, one three reasons for his selection by the National Father's Day Committee. The other reasons are their son, John, almost 5, and the baby, Casi, who has not yet Sports reached her first birthday. Following a business meeting at 9 o'clock, Miller visited the of spang new Church of Jesus Christ of LatterThe Times Day Saints at Broadway and 65th Streethe and Linda are Mormons who met as undergraduates at Brigham Young Universityplayed a round of customer golf after the fatheroftheyear luncheon, and was booked to fly to Mexico City last night for an exhibition today.

title: Ford and Senghor Confer
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (Reuters)President Ford met with President Ldopold S. Senghor of Senegal at the White House today for talks on matters conceming he United States and the West African country.

title: County Federal S.&L. Unit Mergers With First Federal
description: A merger of the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Utica, N. Y., with the County Federal Savings and Loan of Rockville Centre, L. I., was announced jointly yesterday by D. A. Winston and Robert H. Thomsen, presidents of the respective organizations. The merger is effective immediately.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ON. ELIZABETH 2, Cunard. Left Cherbourg May 18, due 8 A.M. at W. 50th St. TOMORROW, May 24

title: Dr. George W. F. Hallgarten, Historian, Is Dead at 74
description: WASHINGTON, May 22Dr. George W. F. Hallgarten, a historian, died today of a heart attack in Sibley Hospital here. He was 74 years old.

title: West German Magazine Asserts Mayaguez Carried C.I.A. Data
description: BONN, May 22 (Reuters)The West German weekly magazine Stern said today that the United States had gone to great lengths to rescue the cargo vessel Mayaguez from Cambodian forces because she was carrying containers of topsecret intelligence data and equipment from Saigon.

title: White House Backs Israel, but it Avoids a Reply to 76 Senators
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The White House said today that the United States was committed to the survival of a free and independent Israel, but it declined to respond directly to the urging of 76 Senators that President Ford recommend enough military and economic aid to meet Israel's urgent needs.

title: CONCERN SHOWN IN CREDIT MARKET
description: With only five business days left until New York City's $220million of 6.47 per cent bond anticipation notes come due, signs of growing concern be came more apparent in the credit market yesterday.

title: Carey Says Fiscal Crisis Must Be Depoliticized
description: ALBANY, May 22Governor Carey, saying that his aim was to depoliticize the New York City fiscal crisis, personally involved bankers and business leaders today in the search for a solution.

title: Challenge to Government
description: There are great challenges for government, for universities, for private institutions, for foundations, for entrepreneurs and even for individual creators: To preserve the city's 1,500 cultural organizations, to develop new programs, to make sure that New York and especially Manhattanremains physically and creatively attractive and open to all artistic corners, to see to that the people in the metropolitan region and the fifty states are aware of these cultural resources.

title: W. Donald Maxwell Dies at 74; Chicago Tribune Editor, Trustee
description: CHICAGO, May 22W. Donald Maxwell, former editor of The Chicago Tribune and long a power in the vast Tribune Company communications organization, died here this morning. He was 74 years old.

title: Senate Panel Hears Dispute on Cable TV
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The National Association of Broadcasters told the Senate Antitrust Subcommittee today that it opposed the offering of television programs for a fee over cable only because the system might force the American people to pay for events it nowl sees on conventional, or free, television.

title: Arab Intentions
description: Have the leading Arab governments changed their fundamental attitude toward the State of Israel? Is Arab policy no longer based on the judgment held since the state's formation in 1948 that Israel is an unacceptable intrusion upon the Arab Middle East, an imposition that ultimately must cease to exist?

title: A.B.A. Championship
description: Indiana vs. Kentucky

title: DANCERS WERE ONES WHO LEAPED, LIFTED
description: Viola Farber did not so much give a tight laced, formal dance concert, around the McGrawHill building on Sixth Avenue, as assert a dance presence and a right to occupy the space. The early evening performance Wednesday was done with so much spirit and good humor that her dancers drew the audience behind them like the children of Hamlin to see the conclusion half a block away from the starting site.

title: 3 Indicted Jockeys Appeal Pimlico Ban
description: BALTIMORE, May 22 (UPI) Three jockeys who were disqualified from riding at Pimlico after their indictment on racefixing charges filed a motion today for reinstatement pending a Maryland Racing Commission hearing next week.

title: Antiperspirant Thrust Continues
description: An amateur advertising enthusiast recently expressed surprise that despite special Food and Drug Administration interest and a possible ingredient ban the manufacturers of Sure, Secret and Arrid Double X antiperspirants don't appear to have pulled back on their advertising in any way.

title: Powers ReElected Head Of Printers Union No. 6
description: Bertram A. Powers has been reelected president of Typographical Union No. 6 for his eighth twoyear term, according to an election tally completed yesterday.

title: Oil Discovery for Phillips
description: BARTLESVILLE, Okla., May 22 (UPI)The Phillips Petroletm Company reported that its third oil discovery in partnership with Pertamina, the Indonesian state oil company, on the Teluk Berau contract area in Irian Jaya. The well is on Salawati Island, about four miles southwest of the group's discovery announced in May, 1974, and about 35 miles northwest of an offshore discovery announced in September. 1974.

title: French Train Crash Kills 6
description: TARBES, France, May 22 (Reuters)  Six people were killed and 10 others badly injured when a passenger train caught fire after colliding with a gasoline tank truck near this city in southwest France today, fire officials said.

title: DONALD BORG DIES; PUBLISHER WAS 69
description: Donald G. Borg, who was chiefly responsible for building The Record, a Hackensack newspaper formerly known as The Bergen Evening Record, from a small daily to a major New Jersey afternoon newspaper, died of cancer yesterday at Hackensack Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: Students Here Prepare Picture of Harlem's Past
description: Back in 1776 in old Harlem, hen called Nieuw Haarlem, the tattle of Harlem Heights was ought and won by Washing on's forces in a buckwheat old where Barnard College tow stands.

title: Carey Names Screening Panels For His Judicial Appointments
description: ALBANY, May 22Governor Carey announced today the formation of nominating committees for each of the four judicial departments in the state to screen prospective candidates for subernatorial appointment to the bench.

title: Books of The Times
description: This may be a patchy bookthis testimonial to Ethel and Julius Rosenberg by their children, Robert and Michael Meeropol. It reads more like an anthology of prison letters, autobiographical sketches, and political credos than a coherent statement of any sort. There is a certain arbitrariness in the division of writing labors between the two authors, which makes it look at times as if their purpose were more to put themselves on display than to arrive at any conclusions. The narrative as marrea by occasional patches of cant and by passages tending toward perfunctoriness. In Michael's account of the years between 1950, when his parents were arrested, and 1953, when they were executed, there is a failure to knit together properly the report on what he and his brother were going through at the time, and the various examples he includes of letters his parents were writing from their respective prison cells (although the letters themselves are fascinating for their evidence of growth from selfconsicaus inarticulateness to eventual tragic eloquence). And the authors overreact to what they say was the provocation for their going public in 1973 and for writing the present volumenamely, Louis Nizer's The Implosion Conspiracy, which, while it may have been bumblingly inaccurate and bland in the conclusions it drew, scarcel seemed malicious in its intent, as the Meeropols claim it aws.

title: In Defense of Talkers
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 22President Ford's appointment of Daniel Patrick Moynihan to be his ambassador to the United Nations is being attacked on the ground that Pat is too blunt, too dramatic and combative to represent the United States at so delicate a time in world history.

title: Cultural Treasure House
description: At the crossroads of Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, behind the stone lions that never roar, stands the New York Public Librarythe greatest private library the world open to the public. And the city's own branch libraries in the five boroughs, less renowned, are havens of first literary wisdom for new and old New Yorkers.

title: Credit System Fuels Wallace Fund Drive
description: WASHINGTON, May 22Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is attracting more campaign money as an unannounced candidate for President than five declared Democratic candidates put together.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Tech Trackmen Win Borough Meet
description: Brooklyn Tech, the Public Schools Athletic League indoor champion, scored 62% points and captured the Brooklyn borough outdoor track and field crown yesterday at the South Shore field. South Shore (39) and Wingate (27) were second and third in the 26school meet.

title: School Prayer Bill Is Passed by Senate In New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N.H., May 22 (UPI)The New Hampshire Senate gave final legislative approval today, 18 to 5, to a bill permitting school districts to allow prayer in the schools and recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance.

title: Congress Old Grads in Reunion
description: WASHINGTON, Max 22 Former members of Congress from 39 states trooped back to Capitol Hill today, gladhanding, backslapping and looking around a bit wistfully at the scenes of their bygone days.

title: Singer Stops Red Sox Streak
description: The Boston Red Sox, who faced and defeated three successive Oakland lefthanders in their recent series with the world champion A's ran into the righthanded slants of Bill Singer of the California Angels last night in Fenway Park and saw their fourgame winning streak come to an end.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SOOTHING SANCTUM Fonda Losliililagros, the midtown Spaniel restaurantbar, has just added a secluded, convenient music room as a front, upstairs haven featuring the strings and songs of Falana, a young Chilean who has performed here at other spots for several years.

title: Wind and the Lion Comes to Music Hall
description: The Wind and the Lion, which opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall, is an elaborate, expensivelooking, ludicrously jingoistic historicaladventure that comes out so firmly in favor of Teddy Roosevelt's Big Stick policy, 70 years later, that it could also be a puton.

title: Rep. Sikes Denies a Conflict of Interest on Land Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 22Representative Robert L. F. Sikes told the House of Representatives today that The New York Times had accused him of a conflict of interest, and he said this was untrue.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly identified the American Israel Public Affairs Committee as an official representative of the Israeli Government. The organization, which is financed by American citizens, is registered with Congress as a domestic lobby.

title: Robert E. Hurst is Dead; Weekly Editor on L. I., 59
description: ROSLYN, L. I., May 21 (UPI) Robert E. Hurst, editor of The Port Washington Mail arid Reporter and The Manhasset Mail since 1971, died after a heart attack today in St. Francis Hospital here. He was 59 gears old.

title: CHURCH SCHOOLS GET RACIAL ORDER
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Internal Revenue Service announced today that taxexempt status would be denied henceforth to churchaffiliated primary and secondary schools that refuse to accept children from all racial and ethnic groups.

title: The Dance: School of American Ballet
description: Every year the School of American Ballet stages a special performance to show off its students. At one time these were given in the New York State Theater, but more recently they have found a most appropriate home in the Julliard Theater, which is surely one of the best theaters in New York City, and quite the most attractive auditorium in Lincoln Center.

title: Books of The Times
description: This may be a patchy bookthis testimonial to Ethel and Julius Rosenberg by their children, Robert and Michael Meeropol. It reads more like an anthology of prison letters, autobiographical sketches, and political credos than a coherent statement of any sort. There is a certain arbitrariness in the division of writing labors between the two authors, which makes it look at times as if their purpose were more to put themselves on display than to arrive at any conclusions. The narrative is marred by occasional patches of cant and by passages tending toward perfunctoriness. In Michael's account of the years between 1950, when his parents were arrested, and 1953, when they were executed, there is a failure to knit together properly the report on what he and his brother were going through at the time, and the various examples he includes of letters his parents were writing from their respective prison cells (although the letters themselves are fascinating for their evidence of growth from selfconscious inarticulateness to eventual tragic eloquence). And both authors overreact to what they say was the provocation for their going public in 1973 and for writing the present volumenamely, Louis Nizer's The Implosion Conspiracy, which, while it may have been bumblingly inaccurate and bland in the conclusions it drew, scarcely seemed malicious in its intent, as the Meeropols claim it was.

title: Pearson on Pole
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 22 (AP)David Pearson, his Wood Brothers Mercury running well despite a 130degree track temperature, won the pole position today for Sunday's World 600 stock car race. The Spartanburg, S. C., driver was clocked at 159.353 miles an hour during the opening day of time trials at Charlotte Motor Speedway. Lennie Ponel of Petersburg, Va., was second.

title: NATO Ministers Concentrate On Joint Purchasing of Arms
description: BRUSSELS, May 22The defense ministers of the Atlantic Alliance countries agreed here today that there was a need to increase the joint development and purchasing of arms.

title: Ethyl Raising Its Dividend
description: The Ethyl Corporation direc. tors voted yesterday to in crease the regular quarterly dividend on common stock tc 321, cents a share from 30 cents.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, May 22, 1975

title: Rampant Pollution Of Tocks Reservoir Foreseen at Hearing
description: TREVOSE, Pa., May 22A water expert told a public hearing today that if the proposed Tocks Island Dam was built its reservoir would become vastly more polluted than Lake Erie.

title: U.S. Agrees to Negotiate End of Laos Aid Program
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 22The United States, at the request of the Laotian Government, has agreed to end all activities of the Agency for International Development in Laos outside of Vientiane and to negotiate for the complete termination of the agency's programs.

title: U.S. FORMS GROUP TO OUT AUTO THEFT
description: WASHINGTON. May 22 (AP) Formation of a Federal group designed to cut auto thefts by 50 per cent within five years was announced today by the Departments of Justice and Transportation.

title: Hawley Rides 4 Winners
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 22 (AP)Sandy Hawley, the leading Hollywood Park jockey, won four races today, including a victory aboard favored Kamadora in the $25,000 El Segundo Purse.

title: The City and Red Ink
description: To the Editor: Mayor Beame is revealing an unsuspected side of his personality. He is familiar to me as bookkeeper, accountant, budgeteer, a man with no flights of fancy. He knew (so he said, and I took him at his word) the buck, and where it was hidden, too. We were led to believe that with his election as Mayor we would (finally) be assured of fiscal integrity and a balanced budget.

title: DEMOCRATS DEFEND AWARD OF TV PACT
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) Top Democratic officials yesterday defended the award of a $25,000 advertising contract for the party's July 26 fundraising telethon to a South Carolina concern in which a member of the party's executive committee has a 25 per cent interest.

title: 3 RAILROAD PLANS WILL BE EXPLORED
description: Directors of the United States Railway Association said yesterday that they had ordered studies of three possible plans as a means of restructuring arid reorganizing the Northeast's seven major bankrupt railroads. The studies are to be completed before directors next meeting, May 29.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)  Mutual fund customers bought fewer shares in April and cashed in their shares faster, tumbling net sales in the industry by 92 per cent from the month before, the Investment Company Institute said today.

title: Credit System Fuels Wallace Fund Drive
description: WASHINGTON, May 22Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is attracting more campaign money as an unannounced candidate for President than five declared Democratic candidates put together.

title: 1,000 Vietnamese Refugees Want to Return, House Panel Told
description: WASHINGTON, May 22L. Dean Brown, director of the Administrator's interagency task force on Indochina refugees, said today that about 1,000 Vietnamese who left their country in the last month now wanted to return to South Vietnam.

title: Saigon Bans Publications Issued Before TakeOver
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 22 (UPI)A Government order prohibiting the sale or possession of literature published under the former regime closed down virtually all bookstores and stalls in Saigon today.

title: State of the City: Parnassus, U. S. A.
description: New York is the concentrate of art and commerce and sport and religion and entertainment, bringing to a single compact arena the gladiator, the evangelist, the promoter, the actor, the trader and the merchant.

title: U.S. Sues Detroit Suburb on Rights
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The United States Justice Department introduced today a new weapon against segregated schools when it filed a civil suit in Detroit against suburban Ferndale, Mich., charging that it illegally operates one allblack school and nine that are predominantly white.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, MAY 23, 1975

title: North Korea Strengthens Border Force
description: During the last two weeks of the Vietnamese campaign, the North Korean high command moved elements of two armored divisions into position close to the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea.

title: Yonkers Results
description: (OTB Payotts subject to 5% State tax.)

title: Sato is Moved to Hospital After Surgery in Restaurant
description: TOKYO, Friday, May 23 (AP)  Former Premier Eisaku Sato was moved early today to a hospital from a restaurant where he had been in a coma since he suffered a stroke Monday.

title: U.S. and Poland Sign Accords That Settle 2 Financial Issues
description: WASHINGTON, May 22Poland and the United States have quietly settled a pair of potentially thorny financial problems.

title: DOLLAR BATTERED AS GOLD JUMPS $4
description: PARIS, May 22Fresh turbulence struck European financial markets today as the dollar was battered anew and the price of gold rose sharply.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Baseball fans will begin voting for the starting lineups for the AllStar game Saturday when distribution selection cards will be made in ball parks around the country. The voting will continue through Sunday, July 6, for the game which will be played at Milwaukee's County Stadium Tuesday night, July 15. The computer cards list 128 players, eight at each infield position and 24 outfielders.

title: SITE OF KAWAIDA IS REPOSSESSED
description: NEWARK, May 22 (UPI)The Newark Housing Authority has voted unanimously to repossess an urban renewal site given to the Temple of Kawaida for a housing complex. It cited as its reason the organization's inability to secure a city tax abatement necessary for undertaking the project.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Our two experiences at The Box Tree, a new restaurant at 242 East 50th, were contradictory enough to report separately. During the first, I kept feeling so much like a supernumerary in play (dining room comedy taking over where drawing room comedy left off) that I'll report in that form.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ALBANY, May 22Governor Carey today banned outside employment for members of his administration who earn $30,000 a year or more or who hold policymaking positions, and he ordered the same employes to make detailed annual disclosures of their net worth and sources of income.

title: Dead Aim at the Gun Carriers
description: BOSTON, May 21In April, 1974, Boston police recorded 14 crimes involving the use of firearms in which no firearm was captured. In 114 other gun crimes, a firearmhandgun, rifle Qr shotgunwas taken by the police. In April of this year, 18 crimes involving firearms, but in which none was taken, and 59 in which a firearm was captured, were recorded by the police.

title: SHELEPIN GIVES UP TRADE UNIONS POST
description: MOSCOW, May 22Aleksandr N. Shelepin, who was removed from the ruling Politburo last month, lost his job as head of the national trade union organization today.

title: Reports Cite Three More U.S. Agencies for Job Discrimination
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 Three more reports by the United States Civil Service Commission citing failure by Government agencies in personnel management and inadequate compliance with equal employment opportunity regulations Were made available here yesterday.

title: Sabres Triumph, Gain Tie
description: BUFFALO, May 22The Philadelphia Flyers can't wait to get out of here. The defending Stanley Cup champions lost their second straight game to the Buffalo Sabres tonight at fogbound Memorial Auditorium. The score was 42, and it evened the National Hockey League's four  of seven  game championship series at two games apiece.

title: At Yonkers: Triple is Not Double Fun
description: YONKERS, May 22It was called Old Timers Night at Yonkers Raceway tonight, but the 20cent hot dogs and beer only pointed up the fact that the most hallowed tradition of all, At the the daily double, Race was dead. In fact, it was harness Tracks racing for the nineteen  seventiesa Dixieland band, races named for Ralph Branca and Mrs. Babe Ruth, and a triple in the first race instead of the good old double.

title: 17Month Notes Sold By the 11.5. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Treasury sold today $1.5billion of 17month notes at an average return of 6.54 per cent. The department received $2.6billion of tenders for the notes, which mature Oct. 31, 1976. Accepted tenders included 88 per cent of the bids at the highest yield and the Treasury awarded $200million of noncompetitive tenders at the average price of 99.947.

title: U.S. Oil Reserves
description: Between 1912 and 1924, four tracts of oilrich land and three tracts of oil shale were set aside by a series of Executive Orders for the exclusive use of the United States Navy in the event of a future emergency. The most famous of these naval petroleum reserves is Teapot Dome in Wyoming, the subject of a major scandal in the Harding Administration; but by far the richest are Elk Hills in California and North Slope in Alaska.

title: Pick It Lottery Finds a Lot of Eager Players
description: Nathan? You want Nathan? He's in the lottery booth. He's surrounded by 40, 50 people and they all want lottery tickets, said a clerk, yesterday, at the Silver Rod Drug Store in Journal Square in Jersey City is New Jersey's new threedigit numbers  like Pick It lottery opened for play.

title: Article 2  No Title
Namath Rejects Offer
description: Joe Nemeth rejected yesterday an offer from the World Football League' s Chicago team reported to be $4million. Namath is a free agent, having played out his contract with the New York Jets. Details on Page 45.

title: CAREY PUTS CURBS ON AIDES' ACTIVITY
description: ALBANY, May 22Governor Carey today banned outside employment for members of his administration who earn $30,000 a year or more or who hold policymaking positions, and he ordered the same employes to make detailed annual disclosures of their net worth and sources of income.

title: Notes on People
description: A $500 personal check from President Ford for the White House swimmingpool fund, with a note saying that it was a joint contribution from him and his wife, Betty, was received yesterday by William Schuiling, secretarytreasurer of the pool committee. Like other contributions to the fund, it is taxdeductible. The President's note, Mr. Schuiling said, expressed our appreciation for what is being done to make this available for the White House and future Presidents.

title: Robert O. Sternberger, 80, ExPresident of Hearst Unit
description: Robert O. Sternberger, a longtime Hearst executive, died Tuesday at Montclair (N.J.) Community Hospital. He was SO years old and lived in Glen Ridge. N.J.

title: ACCORD REPORTED Al C.C.N.Y. PROJECT
description: The State Dormitory Authorty reported last night that it nad tentatively reached agreement with a group representing black and Hispanic workers in a constructionjob dispute that in recent days had led to violence and heavy police patrols on the City College campus.

title: In To Trade, No Sign is a Bad Sign
description: PENN YAN, N.Y.I've been here 38 years in business and all of a sudden the state sends a notice: Get your signs down or we'll take em down, said Clarence Ryal at his small gas station and sevenunit motel on Route 14 near Dresden in the Finger Lakes vacationland.

title: U.S. Agrees to Negotiate End of Laos Aid Program
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 22The United States, at the request of the Laotian Government, has agreed to end all activities of the Agency for International Development in Laos outside of Vientiane and to negotiate for the complete termination of the agency's programs.

title: Weiskopf in 3Way Tie at 65
description: MEMPHIS, May 22 (AP)John Mahaffey's string of eight birdies in 10 holes produced a 65 today that tied him with Tom Weiskopf and Andy North for the firstround lead in the $175,000 Danny ThomasMemphis open golf tournament.

title: MillionDollar Lottery Enlists Son of Carey
description: Governor Carey's son Christopher did a brisk business in $2.50 lottery tickets for half an hour yesterday morning on 42d Street near the Avenue of the Americas: to promote New York's newest milliondollar lottery.

title: Chinese Women Victors Over U.S. in Javelin, Discus
description: SHANGHAI, May 22 (AP)A slip of a girl named Li Shin threw the javelin 189 feet 4 inches today and gave the Americans their first surprise in their track and field tour of China.

title: U.S. TOLD TO CHECK VIETNAM CHILDREN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 22Federal District Judge Spencer Williams has ordered the Immigration and Naturalization Service to conduct exhaustive background checks on each Vietnamese child brought into the country as an orphans in Operation Babylift.

title: LIBYA SAID TO SIGN SOVIET ARMS PACT
description: CAIRO, Friday, May 23Cairo's leading newspaper said today that the Soviet Union had promised to supply Libya with $4billion in military equipment in exchange for permission to set up land, sea and air bases on Libyan territory.

title: AIRLINES LOSE BID ON CHARTER RULE
description: A challenge to rules governing charter flights from foreign countries to the United States was rejected yesterday by the Federal Court of Appeals here.

title: Apawamis Wins Women's Golf
description: The Apawamis Country Club, representing Westchester, won the intersectional playoffs of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday at the Sunningdale Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y. Apawamis defeated Piping Rock Lang Island and Somerset Hills of New Jersey. Apawamis won by half a point with 16% points to 16,for,Piping Rock and 12 for Somerset Hills. The victory was the seventh for Apawamis since 1952.

title: Peru Officially Adopting Indian Tongue
description: LIMA, Peru, May 22  The language of the ancient Incas will join Spanish as the official language of Peru, according to President Juan Velasco Alvarado.

title: LOAN BOARD DELAYS VARIABLE RATE RULE
description: WASHINGTON, May 22The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it would postpone indefinitely a proposed regulation that would permit federally chartered savings and loans associations to offer variable rate mortgages.

title: SENATORS' LETTER LIFTS ISRAELI MOOD
description: TEL AVIV, May 22Syria's agreement to extend the mandate of the United Nations peacekeeping force on the Golan Heights for six months and a letter to President Ford by Senators supporting Israel's requests for economic and military aid were hailed here today as shafts of light in a bleak pericd of Israeli history.

title: Namath Rejects Offer
description: Joe Namath rejected yesterday an offer from the World Football League's Chicago team reported to be $4million. Namath is a free agent, having played out his contract with the New York Jets. Details on Page 45.
