description: 67, A.M., WNYCFM: Sunrise Symphony. Serenade in B flat, Mozart.

title: Assembly Leaders Say Payroll Is Not Loaded With NoShows
description: ALBANY, May 22The leaders of the Assembly today issued a bipartisan rebuttal of charges that their payroll is heavy with noshow political appointees.

title: Ziobro Takes Dodge Open by 3 Shots With 277
description: DENVILLE, N.J., May 22Billy Ziobro is so far down the golf tour moneywinning list that the Internal Revenue Service could miss his name. But he is rich in automobiles.

title: 2 CAR PRODUCERS RECALL WORKERS
description: DETROIT, May 22The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation have recalled another 5,900 workers even though overall United States car production was off this week.

title: 2 Economists Split on Recovery Outlook
description: Two leading economists offered contrasting views yesterday about the prospects for economic recovery.

title: About New York
description: Ever since previews began five weeks ago, the word around town has been that A Chorus Line would be a smash hit. On the other hand, there's an old show business saying, Don't send out the laundry until the notices are in.

title: Ottinger Calls on Social Security to Stop a Payment
description: WASHINGTON, May 22Representative Richard L. Ottinger, in a rare move, has urged the Social Security Administration to stop sending checks to one of his constituents. Like Metropolitan many members of Congress, Congressional Mr. Ottinger Notes has a file full of pleas from constituents asking him to help find that Social Security Check or Veterans Administration benefit they were expecting. But the reason for his move was a compelling Onethe woman to whom the checks were made out died 10 years ago. And for 10 years the checks have been coming and coming.

title: WILLIAM MOLITOR
description: William Molitor, a retired member of the photoengraving department of The New York Times, died yesterday at the United Presbyterian Residence in Woodbury, L. I. He was 84 years old and lived at the residence.

title: People and Business
description: Joseph LaSala, a regional administrator for the Federal Energy Administration, yesterday put a price on what he called inability of Congress to work out a national energy policy. He predicted that gasoline prices for drivers would rise 5 to 10 cents a gallon shortly.

title: LIBYANS CONFIRM SOVIET ARMS DEAL
description: CAIRO, May 23The Soviet Union has agreed to sell Libya $800million worth of military equipment including planes and missiles, informed Communistbloc sources here said today.

title: Warriors Win and Lead, 3 to 0
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 Counted out two weeks ago, the Golden State Warriors took a stranglehold on the National Basketball Association championship tonight by beating the Washington Bullets, 109101, for a 30 lead in the fourofsevengame series.

description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Watergate Figure Called Firm on C.I.A. Reference
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Alfred C. Baldwin 3d, the former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who monitored the Watergate wiretaps in 1972 insists that he used and meant the initials C.I.A. in a recorded interview later given to United States District Court, his attorney said today.

title: Robert C. Eunson, 62, Is Dead; Headed A.P. Broadcast Division
description: Robert C. Eunson, a iongtime foreign correspondent and The Associated Press executive who was vice president in charge of broadcast activities for the last 10 years, died Thursday of cancer. He was 62 years old and lived at 1520 York Avenue.

title: Art: A Valentine of a Show for the Whitney
description: For institutions, no less than for individuals, it is often fun to reminisce about the good old days. Distance lends enchantment to bygone events, and memory is allowed a certain license in recreating a sense of the past. Reminiscence is a form of romance, and while not necessarily alien to the tasks of history or criticism, its pleasures are more easily enjoyed when clearly distinguished from the latter's harsher disciplines.

title: Business Briefs
description: Inflationary costs may have jeopardized a proposed $850million coal gasification plant, according to the Western Gasification Company, which last month received approval from the Federal Power Commission to build the facility.

title: City Unions Oppose More Concessions
description: Leaders of some of the unions representing city employes now appear to feel that sizable layoffs may be inevitable in the current fiscal crisis, but they are holding firm to their determination not to make further concessions that would erode their contracts.

title: Mahaffey, on 68133, Leads by 2
description: MEMPHIS, May 23 (AP)John Mahaffey birdied two of the last three holes today for a fourunderpar 68 and pulled away to a twostroke lead after the second round of the $175,000 Danny ThomasMemphis open.

title: Radio

title: Dave Anderson
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 23Joe Namath looked comfortable. He had on a turquoise shirt and blue slacks and he slouched against the cushioned wall at a small table in a dim corner of Bachelors III West, his latest investment. The soft lights glowed in the long mirror behind the bar. Guys in leisure suits held their drinks at their hips when they moved around. Girls with bare midriffs peeked through the cigarette smoke at the quarterback who had just spurned what today developed to have been a $5million offer from the World Football League to join its Chicago franchise. It was an offer he couldn't refuse, but he did. His reasons, he explained, were personal and private but not many people understood what he meant. His image is that of a swinger and rebel, and he can be both. But he is also a conservative. Joe Namath doesn't wear Brooks Brothers suits or buttondown shirts. But as a quarterback with the New York Jets, he learned to settle for a field goal. And in spurning the $5million offer, he also settled for a field goal because it maintained his comfortable lifestyle. Comfortable in the sense of avoiding the possibility of new hassles.

title: State Reduces Facilities And Hours at 37 Parks
description: On the eve of the Memorial Day weekend, the State's Department of Parks and Recreation has imposed sharp cuts in state park facilities open to the public, including some areas of Jones Beach and Bear Mountain.

title: Bridge:
description: The ability of the Italian superstars to produce a storming finish when it is most needed seems suddenly to have deserted them.

title: Ky Rejoins His Family And Tells Farm Plans
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI)  The former South Vietnamese Vice Premier, Nguyer Cao Ky sporting a United States flag pin in his lapel, was reunited with his family tonight for the first time since the fall of the Thieu regime in Saigon.

title: STOCK BID DRAWS 84% OF SANGAMO
description: The Schlumberger Electric Company, a subsidiary of Schlumberger, Ltd., disclosed late Thursday it had been advised that approximately 2,233,000 common shares, or about 84 per cent of the common shares Merger outstanding, Of the News Sangamo Electric, Company. Springfield, Ill., had been tendered in response to its offer to purchase for $23 cash; any and all shares of Sangamo; Electric.

title: DualPurpose Funds ;Weak ended May 16, 1975
description: Following is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value applicable in the capital shares of dualpurpose investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market prices of best overthecounter dollartodollar asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount on Premium) between the net asset value and the asked Prices of the capital shares.

title: Saigon Departures Delayed
description: SAIGON, May 23 (Reuters)The first airlift of foreigners from South Vietnam since the Provisional Revolutionary Government tool over was canceled today becluse of bad weather, officials said. A North Vietnnmese elrcraft due to fly 72 foreign correspondents Vientiane. Laos will leave tomorrow, the officials odded.

title: Cargo of Refugee Ship Reported, To Include Vietnamese Artifacts
description: WASHINGTON, May 23A South Vietnamese ship that arrived at Guam last week with 522 refugees also reportedly carried crates of what may be part of that country's art treasures. But officials here maintain that they do not know the contents of the crates or who owns them.

title: JUDGE STAYS MOVE TO UNSEAT DEROSE
description: NEWARK, May 23Governor Byrne was barred today by an informal but binding ordar by a state superior court judge from taking any further action to unseat Ralph DeRose as New Jersey member of the bistate Waterfront Commission until the court has ruled on the merits of the Governor's case next month.

title: Volkswagen Plans Iraq Plant
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, May 23 (Reuters)Volkswagenwerk, A.G., said today its Brazilian unit, Volkswagen do Brasil, S.A., was negotiating to build an automobile assembly plant in Iraq. The models to be produced and the cost of the plant are still under discussion, but Volkswagen hopes for a decision by the end of the year, a spokesman said.

title: Cubans Suggest That the Vietnamese Persevere in Resettlement
description: MIAMI, May 20Some of the 350,000 Cuban exiles who have resettled here so successfully over the last 16 years are collecting food and clothing for the Vietnamese refugees now headed this way.

title: RUDOLF F. BENECH, CHOREOGRAPHER, 59
description: Rudolf F. Benesh, a choreographer, died in London on May 13, according to the American Institute of Chorealogy, who reported his death in this country. He was 59 years old and lived in London.

title: More Doctors Threaten a MalpracticeLaw Protes
description: A growing number of physicians, especially on Long Island, are threatening to curtail their practices beginning June 1 in opposition to the state's new malpractice law, which they say still leaves doctors uninsurable.

title: Levi Reveals More Harassment by F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that, in the period from 1960 to 1971, the Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted five previously undisclosed counterintelligence programs against domestic political organizations, including one designed to turn organized crime elements against the American Communist party.

title: Yells of Glee Heard in Cradle Economy As New Citizen Arrives to Spark Buying
description: Recession and depression, you're finished. You've beer: floored by the pudgy fist of a new baby girl.

title: 2 Bomb Blasts in San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., May 23 (AP)  Two bombs exploded early today knocking out the front windows of two bank buildings in separate areas of San Juan, the police said. No injuries were reported. A third bomb was found near an Americanowend McDonald's hamburger establishment, but it did not explode.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: LAOS CHIEF ORDERS ARMY NOT TO FIGHT
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 23Laos's Premier said today that, in an effort to prevent a new civil war here, he had ordered rightwing Government troops not to resist when Pathet Lao forces moved into their territory.

title: Bulldog is Best In Jersey Show
description: ROSELLE, N. J., May 23Ch. Westfield Cunomorus Stone, the greatest winning bulldog bitch in the history of the breed, took her 22d bestinshow award today at the Union County Kennel Club's first spring show. There were 1,096 dogs in the competition at the Warinanco Park skating rink.

title: Moms Mabley, 77 Comedienne Of TV, Stage and Radio, Dead
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 23 (AP) Moms Mabley, the rubberfaced comedienne with the toothless grin and baggy clothing, dead here tonight after a long illness. She was 77 years old.

title: Mayaguez Cargo is Inspected And Found Not to Be Weapons
description: HONK KONG, May 23 (AP) The Mayaguez arrived in Hong Kong tonight and her Owners opened six sealed cargo foritainers at the request of rewsmen seeking to learn if the vessel was carrying military equipment when it was seized by a Cambodian patrol boat last week.

title: China Issue Postponed By I.O.C.
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland. May 23The International Olympic Committee has got nowhere by listening to the two China problem and has decided to solve the issue by taking a look for itself.

title: Test Pattern Victor at Devon
description: DEVON, Pa., May 23 (AP) Kathy Anker of Readington, N. J., rode Test Pattern to a class victory in the large junior working hunter event today at the start of the Devon Horse Show.

title: MILITARY CABINET FORMED IN BEIRUT TO RESTORE ORDER
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 23President Suleiman Franjieh tonight appointed the first military cabinet in Lebanon since independence in 1943 in an attempt to restore order here.

title: CAREY AND 4 AIDES WEIGH CITY PLIGHT
description: Governor Carey met privately for several hours yesterday with his four emergency advisers on New York City's twin fiscal crises and said afterward that he thought things are working in the right direction.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your lead editorial of May 8 you stated that an unfinished chapter of the Vietnam war remains to be closed. The subject of that editorial was amnesty, and you asserted, as your opinion, that since the United States wisely refrained from assessing the motives of the thousands of escaping Vietnamese, we should treat American draft evaders and deserters likewise and grant them similar amnesty.

description: Incoming

title: The Dance: Eleo Pomare
description: Eleo Pomare's dances always have a special gutsy quality. Part of this impression stems from the fact that Mr. Pomare, like several other black choreographers, is keeping the fading but necessary tradition of social protest alive.

title: Police Criticized For Using Cameras To Spy on Students
description: READING, Mass., May 23 (AP)Attorney General Francis X. Bellotti stopped the loan of surveillance equipment today to local police departments until tighter controls on their use were worked out.

title: AUSTRIAN TO FIGHT CHARGES OF FRAUD
description: GENEVA, May 23Hermann Mayer, an Austrian business man accused by the United States's Securities and Exchange Commission of concealing substantial holdings in the General Retractories Company, said today he was certain he could defend myself very well.

title: U. S. Judge Orders Florida to Reduce Prisons' Population
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 23 (UPI)Declaring that a democratic society cannot cage inmates like animals in a zoo, a Federal judge yesterday ordered the reduction within a year of the inmate population at state prisons to a total described as an emergency capacity. This emergency capacity is now exceeded by more than 2.600 convicts.

title: Vietnam Holdouts Slain by Villagers, Saigon Radio Says
description: HONG KONG, May 23 (AP)Several supporters of the former South Vietnamese Government were killed by villagers after they failed to surrender their weapons and to register with the new Government, the Saigon radio said today.

title: Refugee Task Force Director
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Julia Vadala Taft is asked from time to time about the genealogy of her husband, William Howard Taft 4th, who is great grandson of the President.

title: Art:'Eraof Exploration, Photos of West, at Met
description: There is something quite special about the first photographs that men brought back from those parts of the United States that had to be seen to be believed: the Yosemites, for instance, or the Grand Canyon, or those vast untenanted areas across which a railroad track had just been laid. The strangeness of the scene was compounded by the strangeness of the medium. Ghosts begat ghosts, on such occasions; the spectral quality of the scene was matched by the spectral quality of the image. Even today, shiver little.

title: Canada Has Trade Surplus
description: OTTAWA, May 23 (Reuters)  Canada's trade balance moved into surplus in April for the first time this year. Exports were up 3.5 per cent to $2.72billion and imports fell 4.5 per cent to $2.67billion, Statistics Canada said today. This gave an April surplus of $55million, compared with a deficit of $170million in March.

title: Welsh of Two Minds on Common Market
description: MERTHYR TYDFIL, Wales, May 22Richard Mackey, the principal of a Roman Catholic school, and William Morgan, a minister of the Church in Wales, are close friends who have worked in the same vineyards of the Labor party for years, backing the same candidates and the same causes.

title: ISRAEL SENTENCES AIDE TO 15 YEARS
description: TEL AVIV, May 23Michael Tzur, until recently a major power in Israel's economy, was sentenced here today to 15 years in prison.

title: SovietIsrael Talks Held By Envoys in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Soviet and Israeli Ambassadors to the United States have held several unpublicized meetings in Washington in recent months to discuss relations between their two countries, broken since 1967.

title: PRESIDENT TO ASK NATO IF PORTUGAL SHOULD BE KEPT IN
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 President Ford said today that he would ask the leaders of the Atlantic alliance next week to consider whether Portugal's leftist Government should remain a member.

description: COMPANY REPORTS

title: Winner in Chicken Contest
description: PARAMUS, May 23 (UPI)Mildred K. Hornicek of Dumont won first prize in the New Jersey State Chicken Cooking Finals today and will represent the state in the national competition in July. She cooked chicken diablo was awarded a $100 check by Mrs. Jean Byrne, the wife of the Governor.

title: New Oil Price Rise?
description: The oilproducing nations, led by Iran, are giving strong hints in advance of another petroleum price increase of 10 to 20 per cent for September on top of the fivefold rise since 1973. A cutback in oil production, now more than a fourth below capacity output, Is relied upon to prevent normal supplydemand factors from undermining this extortionate price. But the United States, which should be leading the consuming nations in an energetic response to this latest cartel threat, is caught with its plans down.

title: Returns to Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday May 24 (AP)Secretary of State Kissinger returned to Washington early today.

description: High Sugar Prices Called A Result of Low Supplies

title: Portugal's Stand Stated
description: LISBON, May 23 (Reuters)Portugal's Foreign Minister, Maj. Ernesto Melo Antunes, said here tonight that his country would not object to Spain joining the NATO alliance. But he said that Portugal, which is a NATO member, was not making special efforts to press for Snain's membership.

title: Ellen Stock is Wed To Peter Stern
description: Ellen Stock, a senior editor with New York magazine, and Peter Stern, production manager of the Broadway musical Goodtime Charley, were married here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Norton Shargel of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N. Y., performed the ceremony at the home of Mr and Mrs. Leonard Harris.

title: March Orders Climbed 8% For Electrical Eqipment
description: The National Electrical Manufacturers Association reported yesterday that new orders or electrical equipment increased by 8 per cent in March over the February level.

Running time: 110 minutes. At the thaw's State 2 Theater, Broadway at 45th Street, and Loew's Cine, Third Avenue near 86th Street. This film has been rated R.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Ford said yesterday that he will ask the leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to consider whether Portugal's leftist government should remain a partner. I don't see how you can have a Communist element significant in an organization that was put together for the purpose of meeting a challenge by Communist elements from the East, he told five foreign news correspondents who interviewed him at the White House. He stopped short, however, of suggesting the removal of Portugal from NATO. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: HighRise Office Buildings Assailed on Fire Hazards
description: The potential for disaster in many highrise office buildings in the state is stupefying beyond description, State Senator Norman J. Levy, Republican of Nassau, charged yesterday.

title: Dow Up by 12.99 to 831.90 As Trading Shows a Rise
description: The stock market, spurred by a cut in the prime interest rate by the First National City Bank, posted a broad advance yesterday in continued active trading.

title: Leningrad: Nicer Than Moscow but Not Unblemished
description: LENINGRAD  Some of the four million people in this beautiful 272yearold city on the Gulf of Finland seem to be getting politely bored by comments favorably comparing it to Moscow. Leningraders are proud of their city's place in Russian and Soviet history, and they are confident that the canals, in the Neva River embankment, the wide avenues and the 18thcentury architecture make it esthetically superior to the relatively drab capital 400 miler to the southeast.

title: DIAMOND SCORED IN A STATE AUDIT
description: ALBANY, May 23  State Controller Arthur Levitt charged today that a state agency created in 1968 primarily to channel Rockefeller family contributions into state conservation work had made a number of questionable expenditures during the three and a half years that Henry L. Diamond, a confidant of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, served as the agency's chairman.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC CLIMB
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose sharply yesterday while volume remained the same. Similar conditions prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: The Distinctive Political Struggle in France
description: PARISFrom July, 1789, to May, 1968, France was the theatrical showcase for, previewing the major trends of modern historyat first, through the liberal revolution against the privileges and injustices of the Old Regime; in our own day, through rebellion against the manylayered and anonymous dictatorship of the profit motive and by movement toward socialist democracy.

title: OFFICIALS WARNED ON ROAD INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, May 23 (AP)Govethor Byrne, in a warning to all department heads and directors of state authorities, charged today that a memo issued by John P. Gallagher, executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority, had the potential of obstructing a state grand jury investigation into contracts for Garden State Parkway supplies and equipment. He cautioned others to avoid making similar mistake.

title: Sihanouk Accuses C.I.A.
description: ALGIERS, May 23 (Reuters) Prince Norodom Sihanouk has said the seizure of the Mayagez was provoked by the landing of C.I.A. agents on Tang Island in the Gulf of Thailand.

title: Elizabeth Walker Valentine Wed
description: Elizabeth Walker Valentine and Robert MacPherson Gardiner, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Reynolds Securities, Inc., were married in New Vernon, N.J., yesterday afternoon.

title: F. E. A. Is Revising Plan on Oil Prices Following Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Responding to criticism by Senator Henry M. Jackson, the Federal Energy Administration has decided to revise its formula for phasing out crude oil price controls over two years, an official said today.

title: Agnew Reported Cited In Maryland Tax Case
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 23 (AP)Louis L. Goldstein, the Maryland Controller, said yesterday that his office had forwarded to the State Attorney General a state income tax case involving former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew.

title: New Amex Stock Options
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that on May 30 it would introduce the, first half of 20 new stock options to be traded on the Amex. They are options for stock of Aetna Life, Beatrice Foods, First Charter Financial, Greyhound, Hercules, Mesa Petroleum, Merrill Lynch, California Standard, WarnerLambert and Westinghouse. The other 10, to be phased in during June, will raise the total options for Big Board stocks traded on the Amex 40.

title: Turks Rebuff Kissinger Bid on Cyprus
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 23Secretary of State Kissinger met with Turkish leaders today but reportedly failed to persuade them to agree to any concessions toward a settlement of the Cyprus conflict.

title: Selassie Reported III
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia May 23 (UPI)Haile Selassie, 82yearold deposed cmperor of Ethiopia is suffering from a painful ailment of the urinary tract that requires surgical operation. Ethiopia's military Government announced today.

title: Justice Agency Reviewing Stand on Election Law
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) In a policy shift, the Justice Department decided today to review its defense of the new Federal election law after a top official questioned the law's constitutionality.

title: Red Sox Trounce Ryan, Angels, 61
description: The nearest thing to a sureshot victory in major league baseball this season seems to be Nolan Ryan, the California Angels righthander who uses his pitching arm like a flamethrower.

title: SALES OF AUTOS HIT 14YEAR LOW
description: DETROIT, May 23  Auto producers reported today that sales of domestic new cars for midMay fell 27.7 per cent below 1974 to a 14year low.

title: State Reduces Facilities And Hours at 37 Parks
description: On the eve of the Memorial Day weekend, the State's Department of Parks and Recreation has imposed sharp cuts in state park facilities open to the public, including some areas of Jones Beach and Bear Mountain.

title: City to Hold Public Links Event
description: A few hundred rounds of golf were played on Van Cortlandt Park Golf Club in the Bronx in 1889, the year the nineholer was opened as the first public links course in the nation. It was run then as now by New York City.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The Government's inflation monitoring agency said today that speculation was not a significant factor in last year's soaring sugar prices.

title: Mrs. Grasso Finds Way to Pay Raises Slated for Rejection
description: HARTFORD, May 23Gov. Ella T. Grasso agreed today, subject to the approval of the General Assembly, to pay Connecticut's state employes the raises they were to have been denied in the coming fiscal year, by diverting $5.3million that the state had earmarked for the State Employes Retirement Fund.

title: Chinatown Protests Bring on Transfer Of Precinct's Head
description: After two major demonstrations at City Hall over alleged police brutality in Chinatown, the commanding officer of the Chinatown precinct was relieved of his post yesterday.

title: In Weakness There is Union
description: ery and while a considerable number of those already here have been extruded, the figure for those still here remains very high. What is more, a poor Turk thrown out of work in Germany or a poor Portuguese unemployed in France, can claim compensation, can thriftily exist on it and can even have something left to send back home in remittances.

title: A Bedroom With a Split Personality
description: Most people don't take advantage of the space they have, Noel Jeffrey, an interior designer, said the other evening as he and his wife, Lynn, waited for dinner guests. In Manhattan there just isn't space to waste.

title: EMMYLOU HARRIS SINGS SPIRITEDLY
description: It's fun to see a pop performer arrive on the scene already a star, and that's what Emmylou Harris did Thursday night at the Bottom Line. She appeared there only one night, but she will be back for the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park on June 28.

title: Article 6  No Title
Sports News Briefs
description: EL PASO, Tex., May 23 (UPI)Paul Gibson, a hurdler in the International Track Association competition and a former professional football player, was killed early today in an automobile crash on Interstate 10. He was to have run in Madison Square Garden next Wednesday night. Police said Gibson's car was traveling at a high speed shortly after midnight when it went out of control within the city limits and crashed. He was 26 years old.

title: Dance: 5 Additions for Ravel Festival
description: Pots were being boiled all over Lincoln Center on Thursday night as New York City Ballet went into Phase Two of its current Ravel Festival at the New York State Theater. In a furious spate of creativity the company presented its faithful audience with five new ballets in one evening. Unfortunately each one of them was a clinker. One would have felt like saying back to the drawing board in hte first place.

title: News Blackout is Imposed In Two Spanish Provinces
description: MADRID, May 23 (UPI)The Spanish Government imposed a news blackout today on two Basque provinces where the authorities are trying to stamp out antiGovernment agitation and terrorism.

title: Fine French Food in Germany? Yes, If You Are Willing to Pay
description: COLOGNE, West GermanySuperb cuisine, contrary to a cherished American belief, is highly appreciated in Germany. Sometimes it can even be found here.

title: PRICES FOR GRAINS SHOW DOWNTURN
description: Heavy marketings of wheat, corn and soybeans by farmers helped to depress prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Ford Picks Thornburgh To Head Criminal Division
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI)  Richard Thornburgh, United States Attorney for western Pennsylvania, will be nominated as assistant Attorney General for the Criminal Division, President Ford said yesterday.

title: SERGEANT GUILTY IN CORRUPTION CASE
description: A Queens police sergeant, suspended since his indictment along with nine fellow members of an alleged sergeants club at the 103d Precinct in Jamaica, was found guilty on a perjury charge yesterday.

title: Market Place
description: Last July Citicorp, the holding company that controls the First National City Bank, introduced a fascinating investment concept floatingrate notes.

title: Long Term Plans of NATO Are Extended
description: BRUSSELS. May 23Stressing the continued danger of growing Soviet military strength despite the encouragement of dtente, the defense ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today on the basis for longterm alliance plans.

title: LEE CURRLIN NAMED CBS PROGRAMS HEAD
description: Lee Currlin, an executive, in the CBSTV sales department, yesterday was appointed vice president in charge of programs for the network. He succeeds Fred Silverman, who last week was hired away from CBS by ABCTV.

title: MORGENTHAU SAYS HIS OFFICE ERRED
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said yesterday his office had erred in failing to disclose eyewitness testimony that might have helped a man awaiting trial in a murder case, but Mr. Morgenthau said the error had been the result of inadvertence, neglect and, in some part, accident.

title: PRESIDENT TO ASK NATO IF PORTUGAL SHOULD BE KEPT IN
description: WASHINGTON, May 23President Ford said today that he would ask the leaders of the Atlantic alliance next week to consider whether Portugal's leftist Government should remain a member.

title: Castle Clinton Opening Again, to Beethoven 9th
description: Castle Clinton, the weathered, darkbrown bagel of a building set in the salad greenery of Battery Park on Manhattan's harborside tip, opens its doors to the public this afternoon for the first time in more than 35 years.

title: Francis C. Thayer, 57, Dies, Made Documentary Films
description: Francis Curtis Thayer, president of United States Productions, Inc., a producer of documentary films for business, industrial and general distribution, died yesterday after surgery in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived at 47 East 88th Street.

title: Sarsar, a Filly, Is Favorite Against 12 Colts in Withers
description: A filly will rave against a dozen colts in the 100th running of the Withers Stakes at Aqueduct today. William Haggin Perry's Sarsar will undertake the task in the onemile test for 3yearolds, and, what's more, she is the morningline 31 favorite.

title: N.B.A. Championship
description: Golden State vs. Washington

title: U.S. Steel Head Urges Tax Law Change
description: The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation called yesterday for legislation to ease, capital shortages.

title: Mrs. Rankin Leads on 66
description: RALEIGH, N.C., May 23 (UPI)Judy Rankin shot a sixunderpar 66 today and took the firstround lead in the $40,000 Raleigh golf classic.

title: BETTY JONES, LUDIN TEAM UP IN DANCES
description: Betty Jones and Fritz Lildin were pioneers in touring as a duet with repertory pieces by a variety of able choreographers. And if their programs have been a shade more exciting at other times, their appearance at Pace College's Schimmel Center on Thursday evening had is special pleasures.

title: PAPP PLANS PLAYS AT BOOTH THEATER
description: Joseph Papp is planning to take over the Booth Theater on Broadway next season to present five new American plays. Discussions have been held between Mr. Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, and representatives of the Shubert organization, owners of the Booth and most other Broadway theaters.

title: Madrid Says it is Ready to Give Freedom to the Spanish Sahara
description: MADRID, May 23 (AP)The Spanish Government, pressured by Arab neighbors and fearful of a guerrilla war, announced today that it was ready to give independence to the Spanish Sahara in the shortest period possible.

title: GOING OUT Guie
description: ROUND AND ROUND Today is the time for all pedalists to test their stamina and flexibility, in the city's fourth 24hour PepsiCola Bicycle Marathon. The event takes place on a fivemile course in Central Park starting at 72d Street and Fifth Avenue at noon and running until noon tomorrow. A large number of contenders are expected to be on hand, from professional wheelers to average weekendinthepark bikers. The event, which is open free to all comers, is being presented in cooperation with the Department of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs. Awards will go to any rider who completes 25 miles.

title: Levi Reveals More Harassment by F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that, in the period from 1960 to 1971, the Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted five previously undisclosed counterintelligence programs against domestic political organizations, including one designed to turn organized crime elements against the American Communist party.

title: Lisbon Leaders Summon Party Chiefs Amid Crisis
description: LISBON, May 23Portugal's military rulers met separately today with leaders of the Socialist and Communist parties in what may be a last effort to maintain civilian political participation in the Government.

title: TWO RAILROAD LINES GET TAKEOVER DATA
description: The United States Railway Association briefed officials yesterday of both the Norfolk & Western Railway and Chessie Systems, Inc., on the specific segments of the properties of the bankrupt railroads of the Northeast, which it wants those solvent carriers to take over.

title: Saigon Permits Telegrams
description: SAIGON, May 22 (Agence FrancePresse) (delayed)Postal authorities in Saigon today began accepting private telegrams for destinations outside Vietnam for the first time since the city was surrendered on April 30 to National Liberation Front forces.

title: Key Vietnamese Negotiator Leaves Paris for Saigon
description: PARIS, May 23 (AP)The last peace negotiator for the Provisional Revolutionary Government in South Vietnam left Paris today, closing the last chapter in seven years of talks on ending the Vietnam war.

title: Italy's Airline Pilots Strike
description: ROME, May 23 (AP)Pilots of the Italian airlines Alitalia and Itavia began a 36hour strike today, forcing the airlines to cancel most of their national and international flights.

title: Holiday Closing Set
description: Securities and commodities markets and banks in major financial centers in the United States will be closed Monday in observance of the Memorial Day holiday.

title: A Reserve General Is Relieved of Duty In Misuse of Funds
description: LOS ANGELES, May 23 (UPI) The Army has announced that a Reserve general commanding 9,000 reservists in three states was relieved of duty on charges of improper conduct involving misuse of authority and funds.

title: Notes on People
description: Dave Beck, the 80yearold former president of the International Brotherhood of teamsters, has received a full and unconditional Presidential pardon, wiping out his conviction in 1959 for incometax evasion. He had paid a $20,000 fine and served nearly one year of a fiveyear sentence, from June, 1962, to May. 1963. The pardon was one of 58 granted by President Ford, the Justice Department said.

title: State's Numbers Game Picks Up on Its 2d Day
description: There were fewer mechanical problems yesterday and an increase in betting volume as New Jersey's new numberslike lottery game moved into its second day of operation.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Kingston, Jamaica, in The New York Times last Friday gave the incorrect equivalent for the Jamaican dollar, which is worth about 90 cents.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Friday.

title: Jersey's High Court Tells State to Alter School Aid Pattern
description: TRENTON, May 23The New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered a redistribution of $300million in state school aid next year unless the Legislature complied with its mandate and approved a new system of financing public schools. The ruling was by a 4to2 vote of the justices.

title: A Commuter Town Marks 2 Centuries
description: DEMAREST, N.J. May 22Just 14 miles from the hubbub of New York City lies this idyllic community where the ducks once had their own bank account and where couples still pose for pictures under the wedding tree alongside Tenakill Brook.

title: Djerassi Sets Hammer Mark
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 23Boris Dov Djerassi may be too heavy for acceptance by some graduate schools but he became No. 1 today in American hammer throwing this year with a meetrecord throw of 222 feet 6 inches during the 99th annual I.C.4A outdoor track and field championships.

title: HighRises Scored On Fire Safety
description: The potential for disaster in many highrise buildings in New York State is stupefying beyond description, State Senator Norman Levy, chairman of the Senate Committee on Labor charged. He and other members of the committee issued a report of their yearlong study of fire safety and said they would introduce legislation in the Senate mandating state fire safety standards for public and private buildings and requiring the World Trade Center in New York City to comply with city regulations.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures ;Friday, May 23, 1975
description: CHICAGO GRAINS WHEAT

title: Buddy, Wanna Buy a Diploma? I Can't Get a Job and Need a Dime.
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill.The Class of 1975 on the nation's campuses is marching out into an indifferent world. Its members face the Worst recession since the 1930's, and to at greater extent than most people realize the burdens of recession fall heavily on the young.

title: SovietIsrael Talks Held By Envoys in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Soviet and Israeli Ambassadors to the United States have held several unpublicized meetings in Washington in recent months to discuss relations between their two countries, broken since 1967.

title: Deaths
description: Benjamin, L. Part

title: London Metal Market
description: (In pounds stoning per metric ton) COPPER

title: Official Denies Saigon Blocks Refugees
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 23  A spokesman for Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, today disputed assertions made in Washington that Vietnamese refugees wishing to return home were being impeded from doing so.

title: Books of The Times
description: In American Building and the Forces That Shaped It, Prof. James Marston Fitch of Columbia wrote that the 19th century saw three great developments in structural theory the enclosure of great areas in the Crystal Palace; the spanning of great voids in the Brooklyn Bridge; and the reaching of great heights in the Eiffel Tower. Nothing which came after them could remain entirely unaffected.

title: Court Backs a Church Planning Jail Services for Homosexuals
description: SAN FRANCISCO. May 23 (AP)  A threejudge Federal court has ruled that a church seeking to hold services for homosexual prison inmates is a bonafide church and must be guaranteed freedom of relieion.

title: State Vows to Regain Nursing Home Excess Profits
description: The State Health Department yesterday pledged to recover, huge windfall profits just disclosed in records filed by nursing homes and to plug the loopholes in the Medicaid system that had made them possible.

title: C.C.N.Y. JOB ACCORD IS NOW IN DOUBT
description: A group representing black and Hispanic construction workers made public yesterday several conditions for accepting a state proposal designed to end a dispute over the number of minority workers on a City College construction project.

title: ExLegislator in Suffolk Indicted on Bribe Charge
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., May 23A former Suffolk County legislator whose recommendations led to the approval of a proposed $20million quarterhorse race track in the county was indicted here today on charges of soliciting and receiving a bribe from a consulting company that eventually received a contract from the track.

title: Citibank Cutting Prime Rate To 7%, the Lowest in 2 Years
description: The First National City Bank announced yesterday that it would lower its prime rate on corporate loans to 7 per cent on Monday. The move reflected continued weak demand for loans and lower interest rates on competing sources of borrowed funds.

title: Marcos Urges Reassessment Of PhilippineU.S. Relations
description: MANILA, May 23  President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the United States and the Philippines must build a new relationship based on a realistic view of whether there is need for either the American instalations here or the mutual defense treaty.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The city's new fire safety code for highrise office buildings, the most stringent such law in the nation, is beset as few other local laws have been by debate over its technical and economic feasibility.

title: G.M. Sees 1975 as Turnaround Year
description: DETROIT, May 23Despite dismal auto sales so far this year, Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, maintained his optimistic view today at the company's annual meeting and predicted that 1975 would be a turnaround year for our economy and our business.

title: U.S. SEEKS INTEREST ON ITS IDLE DEPOSITS
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The Treasury Department today proposed legislation that would permit the Federal Government to earn interest on the billions of dollars of its deposits which sit Idly in bank accounts every year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court, in a 4to2 ruling, yesterday ordered a redistribution of $300million in state school aid next year unless the Legislature complied with its mandate and approved a new system of financing public schools. The order means that of the state's 601 school districts, half that are in the wealthiest communities would lose varying amounts of state aid, and the other half, in poorer and urban districts, would gain corresponding increases.

title: Mayor Seeking New Delay For Submitting of Budget
description: Mayor Beanie said yesterday he would seek still another postponement, beyond next Thursday, for submittal of a balanced 197576 budget. But he added that if he failed to win the delay from the Legislature he would issue a $12.8billion budget next week balanced with the $641million in revenues he has been told he will not receive.

title: U.S. F16 CHOSEN BY NETHERLANDS
description: THE HAGUE, Saturday, May 24The Netherlands Cabinet decided conditionally late last night to buy the American F16 jet fighter instead of the competing Frenchmade Mirage to replace its squadrons of F104 Starfighters. But the purchase will be made only on the stipulation that Denmark, Norway and Belgium, which have formed a consortium with the Netherlands for the purchase, also buy the same aircraft.

title: SMALL CAR STUDY OF AIRBAGS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Council on Wage and Price Stability recommended today that the Federal Government finance a program to install airbags in 100,000 small cars for field testing before American automobile manufacturers are required to make them standard equipment.

title: REFORM PRESSED ON CITY CHARTER
description: The State Charter Revision Commission for New York City was told yesterday that its sweeping recommendations for overhauling a sluggish, overcentralized municipal bureaucracy did not go far enough.

title: Box Scores of Major League Games and Standings
description: American League

title: Treasury Bills Rise At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Friday, May 23. 77th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Kennecott's Move To Sell Peabody Blocked by F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission refused today to approve in principle the Kennecott Corporation's attempt to sell the Peabody Coal Company to one of three bidders.

title: ITALY EXPLORES BANANA BRIBERY
description: ROME, May 23A chief state prosecutor here opened a judicial inquiry this week into allegations that the United Brands Company had been bribing Italian Government officials for years to obtain favored treatment for its banana exports to Italy.

title: Official Says Refugees May Remain in Camps
description: John Eisenhower, chairman of President Ford's advisory committee on refugees, said Friday, that many of the 135,000 Vietnamese refugees in this country may have to spend the rest of their lives in the camps set up for them because of security and literacy problems.

title: State of the City: Linking the Region
description: Promoters of metropolitan area government have traditionally assumed that their goal, for all its soundness, cannot be achieved until conditions in city and suburbs alike approach the intolerable. History has so far borne them out. Half the drinking wells on the fringes Minneapolis and St. Paul had to be contaminated with sewage before those rival cities could be moved to significant collaboration. The Toronto area had to endure similarly acute discomforts before it could become the classic model of municipal federation. Without such pain, politicians appear to be too addicted to the status quo to dare fundamental change.

title: The Program
description: RAVEL FESTIVAL: PROGRAM TWO. Music Maurice Ravel; conductor, Robert Irving; looting, Ronald Bates. Presented by one New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater. INTRODUCTION AND ALLEGRO FOR HARP (Premiere). Choreography, Jerome Robbins; costumes, Arnold Scaasi; solo harp. Cynthia Otis. W to Patricia McBride, Heist Tomasson and Judith Fugate. Dolores Houston, Catherine Morris, Steohen Cares, Jay Jolley and Laurence Matthew.

title: N.H.L. Championship
description: BUFFALO vs. PHILADELPHIA.

title: Effects of Court Ruling On 27 School Districts
description: TRENTON, May 23 (UPI) Here is a list showing how today's State Supreme Court ruling would affect 27 selected school districts, compiled by the New Jersey Education Association, with the figure showing the amount of money they would lose.

title: Article 3  No Title
Three Fiscal Gambits for Beamed
description: The circle of people whose actions and decisions will most immediately determine whether New York continues to slide toward defeault has shrunk to three, and they will be meeting for breakfast Tuesday morning. They are Mayor Beame, Governor Carey and Warren M. Anderson, the Republican majority leader of the State Senate. Mayor Beame will make three requests, one procedural and two substantive.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Kingston, Jamaica, in The New York Times last Friday gave the incorrect equivalent for the Jamaican dollar, which is worth about 90 cents.

title: 681 Temporary Employes Dismissed by the Assembly
description: ALBANY, May 23Speaker Stanley Steingut today dropped 681 employes from the Assembly payroll, citing as a cause for costcutting the uncertainty over when the legislative session would end.

title: 2 Killed in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 23 (Reuters)Hooded gunmen burst into an apartment in North Belfast today and killed two Roman Catholic brothers who were playing cards, the police reported. An organization identifying itself as the Protestant Action Force telephoned newspapers and claimed responsibility.

title: Melissa Carr Leib is the Bride Of Robert Illingworth Veghte
description: Melissa Carr Leib and Robert Illingworth Veghte were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Charles Newberry at St John's Episcopal Church of Lattingtown in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: W. T. Grant Offers Liens on Inventory
description: In an unusual concession to its merchandise creditors, the W. T. Grant Company is offering 1,500 of its largest suppliers a lien on its inventory and prior claim for repayment over its principal lending banks should Grant become bankrupt.

title: THAILAND'S PREMIER SEEKING HANOI TIES
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, May 23 (Reuters)Trailand wants diplomatic relations with North Vietnam as soon as possible, Premier Kukrit Pramoj said today on the second day of talks here between the two countries.

title: Search for Four Students In Tanzania is Fruitless
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 23 (Reuters)Tanzanian policemen and troops combing the eastern shore of Lake Tanganyika have found no trace of four kidnapped American and Dutch students and are certain they are being held in Zaire.

title: MONETARY ACCORD SEEN AS UNLIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 Jack F. Bennett, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today he was pessimistic about chances of agreement on pendin'g international monetary issues when world finance ministers meet early next month in Paris.

title: Mormons Rekindle Their Efforts Here With New Headquarters
description: The first Mormon missionary to New York City, Elder Parley P. Pratt, wrote dolefully of his meagre success at winning converts during the first few months of his efforts in 1837.

title: Yonkers Results
description: (OTB payoffs sublect to 5% State tax) FIRST$6,000, Pace, mile.

title: STANLEY McCUTCHEON
description: ANCHORAGE, May 23 (UPI)Stanley J. McCutcheon, lawyer who was the architect j of the Native Claims Settlement I Act, died in a hospital here yesterday. He was 57 years old. Surviving are his widow, Evelyn; his mother, Mrs.H. H. McCutcheon, two daughters and two brothers, all of An chorage.

title: City Hospitals Unit Votes For Cuts to Avert Closings
description: While protesters outside shouted angrily against further cutbacks, the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to try other economies rather than close another of the municipal hospitals in the face of the current budget, squeeze.

title: Health Agency Offers Some Timely Counsel
description: Worried about the city's budget crisis and layoffs? Does the talk of payless days or a fourday week get you down? A note tucked in with paychecks distributed to city employes yesterday reminded them the Health Department's special counseling unit was there to help them with their troubles.

title: PAN AM WINS TEST IN A BRITISH COURT
description: LONDON, May 23 (Reuters)Pan American World Airways today won a legal battle involving commission rates against the British Government, which had threatened to suspend Pan Am permits to fly into Britain.

title: Mayor Seeking New Delay. For Submitting of Budget
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday he would seek still another postponement, beyond next Thursday, for submittal of a balanced 197576 budget. But he added that if he failed to win the delay from the Legislature he would issue a $12.8billion budget next week balanced with the $641million in revenues he has been told he will not receive.

title: In Memariam
description: HOLLANDERPaul. In everlasting loving and cherished memory.

title: Sail Race Starts in Light Air
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 23A fleet of 124 yachtsor was it 125?ranging in size from the 80foot ketch Tempest down to a trio of 26loot Midget Ocean Racing Division sloops, set sail this evening in the Storm Trysail Club's 30th annual race to Block Island and back. Unless the wind pipes up the voyage for around 700 yachtsmen is going to consume most of this holiday weekend.

title: Lisbon Leaders Summon Party Chiefs Amid Crisis
description: LISBON, May 23Portugal's military rulers met separately today with leaders of the Socialist and Communist parties in what may be a last effort to maintain civilian political participation in the Government.

title: MILITARY CABINET FORMED IN BEIRUT TO RESTORE ORDER
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 23President Suleiman Franjieh tonight appointed the first military cabinet in Lebanon since independence in 1943 in an attempt to restore order here.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: TWO MORE BODIES SOUGHT BY POLICE
description: ONSTED, Mich., May 23 (UPI) The police dug today for more bodies in the yard of a rural home once occupied, by a former mental patient wanted for questioning in the killings of 20 persons in Califomia, Michigan, Texas ondi Washington State.

title: TV Interview Payments
description: The payment made to Abbie Hoffman for a public television interview was not precisely analogous to CBS News's remunerating H. R. Haldeman for a twopart interview, although both are being discussed in journalism circles as patent cases of newsgathering by checkbook from which no hard news emerged. The issue of whether it was right to pay for exclusive access to political personalities, or to anyone in the news, is compounded by the widely held view that the subjects in question were actually manipulating television.

title: Antiques: Radio Rarities
description: Fifty years ago radios flickered and sputtered in very few parlors across the land. Broadcasting was then a fouryearold reality and its programs reached listeners gathered around a rudimentary twopart apparatus that consisted of a receivera bunch of tubes sprouting from a mahogany slab baseand a speakera pedistalbased, wheelshaped metal device with a grill cloth instead of a hubcap, centering one side.

title: Dr. C. E. Hillyer Weds Lydia Geer
description: The Chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Lydia St. John Geer, daughter of Mrs. Howard Earl Geer of Meadow Lakes Village, N.J., formerly of New York, and the late Mr. Geer, to Dr. Charles Ellison Hillyer of Cliffside Park, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John K. Hammon.

title: U.S. Scores Near Sweep In Shanghai
description: SHANGHAI, May 23 (AP)  Another Chinese woman, 18yearold Chu Hsechen, spoiled an American sweep today in the last day of a goodwill track and field meet here between the United States and China.

title: Terry Riley Plays Refined Selections From His Works
description: When Terry Riley first emerged in the early nineteensixties, he was known for In C, a conceptual piece for large chamber ensemble that opened out into an extroverted tapestry of sound. But in the last decade he has concentrated on solo performances, and particularly on introverted solo improvisations using electric organ and tape delay. Some of us have regretted the apparent slowing of his development and his intense devotion to his studies of Indian vocal music, and some of his past performances have seemd both decorative and repetitious of previous work.

title: Job Cuts at Bethlehem
description: BALTIMORE, May 23 (UPI) A spokesman for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation confirmed today that 2,500 persons will remain off the job next week at the Sparrows Point plant. The tin mill, pipe mill, hot mill and cold mill will not operate this coming week, the spokesman said. Of those, only the tin mill was shut down last week.

title: Spinola Gets Passport
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 23, (Reuters)  Former President Antnio de Spinola of Portugal, in political exile here, was given a Brazilian passport today, a member of his staff said. Mr. Spinola was deprived of his Portuguese citizenship after the abortive coup in Lisbon on March 11.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MAY 24, 1975

title: DOLLAR IS MIXED IN EUROPE TRADING
description: BRUSSELS, May 23 (UPI)The dollar fell today to its lowest mark against the French franc in more than 22 months. On other European money markets trading in the dollar was mixed. The price of gold fell.

title: McGinnis Sues To Be a Knick
description: Pro basketball newserupted in the legal courts and on the trading fronts yesterday and involved some of the sport's biggest names:

title: Nettles (2) and Bonds Homer. Before War
description: As soon as it became evident that Catfish Hunter was en route to his sixth victory in his last seven starts, this time by 117, Beanball War II erupted between the Yankees and the Texas Rangers it Shea Stadium last night.

title: CHINATOWN HEAD OF POLICE SHIFTED
description: After two major demonstrations at City Halt over alleged police brutality in Chinatown, the commanding officer of the Chinatown precinct was relieved of his post yesterday.

title: Pro Transactions
description: ST. LOUIS (NL)Acquired Mike Barlow, pitcher from Tucson of the Pacific Coast League as completion of earlier trade that sent Teddy Martinez to Oakland.

title: Kissinger Confers in Spain
description: TORREJON AIR BASE, Spain, May 23 (UPI)Secretary of State Kissinger stopped here today, on his way back to Washington, for talks with Foreign Minister Pedro Cortina Mauri of Spain on such matters as Portugal's swing toward the left.

title: New Safety Rules Urged for Reactors
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today new standards to protect the public from radiation released by nuclear reactors and by the processing of uranium used to power reactors.

title: Box Scores
description: EGarvey, DPSt. Louis 1. LOBSt. Louis 4, Los Angeles 5. HRGarvey (5), Melendez (2), Wynn (7). SBFerguson. SFGuerrero.

title: TRADERS IN GRAIN REACT TO INQUIRY
description: CHICAGO, May 23Disclosures of widespread corruption and bribery in the handling of grain exports at the port of New Orleans came as no surprise to the grain trade.

title: SENATE BARS DATA IN GURNEY TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The Senate rejected a subpoena yesterday for confidential financial records of former Senator Edward I Gurney, Republican of Florida, who is now on trial on bribery, perjury and conspiracy charges.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: LAOS CHIEF ORDERS ARMY NOT TO FIGHT
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 23Laos's Premier said today that, in an effort to prevent a new civil war here, he had ordered rightwing Government troops not to resist when Pathet Lao forces moved into their territory.

title: N. Amer. Soccer Leaguel
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: C.I.A. Plot on Castro Reported After '60's White House Talks
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Central Intelligence Agency prepared contingency plans for the assassination of Cuban Premier Fidel Castro as a result of White House discussions, former agency officials have told the Rockefeller Commission, which is looking into Federal intelligence operations.

title: Screen: Curtis Is Lepke:Sordid Career of Thug Shown Dutifully
description: Louie (Lepke) Buchalter was a bad little boy who stole things and lied. He was bound to come to no good end, as the film called "Lepke" so dutifully shows, but before he arrives at that point, the electric chair, he makes a lot of money, marries a sweet, orthodox Jewish girl named Bernice, and kills a number of men intentionally.There are some people in this world who could imagine worse lives and I suspect, it's for them that this dour, witless movie is intended. "Lepke," which opened yesterday at the Loews State 2 and Cine Theaters, covers most of Lepke's life, from the delinquent years of his adolescence in Brooklyn through the delinquent years of his adulthood in Brooklyn, as the head of the outfit called Murder, Inc.The cast of characters includes such other "name" hoods of the nineteen-thirties as Lucky Luciano, Albert Anastasia and Kid Twist Reles, all of whom have turned up in earlier, better gangster films. This one is different only in that it gives the Jewish side of the underworld story."Lepke" was produced and directed by Menahem Golan, the Israeli film maker ("Kazablan"), mostly in and around Los Angeles. A mature Tony Curtis plays Lepke as well as the limited concerns of the screenplay allow. Vaughn Meader, the impressionist once so closely identified with the Kennedy-era Camelot, appears briefly as the late Walter Winchell, while Milton Berle plays Lepke's father-in-law, a man who apparently puts on old-man make-up in the morning the way some women wear lipstick and eyeshadow. It doesn't make Mr. Berle look convincingly old, just spongy.

title: Mots Score in 4th and Take 7th of Last 9
description: ATLANTA, May 23It still bothers Jon Matlack that he hasn't pitched a complete game this season, but the Mets lefthander wasn't complaining about his 31 victory tonight over the Braves.

title: Trainer Fined $1,000
description: John Cotter, the thoroughbredhorse trainer accused of drug and claiming violations, was given the option of accepting a $1,000 fine or 20day suspension yesterday by the State Racing and Wagering Board. The trainer afterward said he would pay the money.

title: Hungarians Reflect on Transition
description: CLEVELANDSteve Menyhart, an American citizen and confirmed suburbanite, used to be Istvan Menyhart, a Hungarian rebel. He remembers well what it was like in the beginning of his new life in the United States after he fled his homeland in 1956, when Soviet troops crushed the Hungarian revolt, Unable to speak English and largely helpless at that time, Mr. Meynhart says today, You felt like a baby who don't know nothing.

title: Diplomats Skeptical
description: MOSCOW, May 23 (Reuters) Diplomatic observers in Moscow expressed skepticism today over a report that the Soviet Union had concluded a large arms pact to provide Libya with weapons worth $4billion.

title: Memorial Services
description: MARTIIBANEZDr. Felix. A third anniver sary Memorial Mass in loving memory of Dr. Felix MartIbanez will be offered at, St. Patrick's Cathedral at 10 A.M. today.

description: Music

title: Sets Triumph For 11th in Row
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 23 The undefeated New York Sets juggled their lineup in three matches tonight en route to a 2721 victory over the Boston Lobsters, their 11th straight triumph this season. The match was played at the Providence Civic Center before 4,317 neoole.

title: Article 4  No Title
New Jersey Briefs
description: Five teenagers were apprehended by authorities within 30 minutes after they allegedly used a toy handgun and a pluggedup machine gun to rob the Fidelity Union Trust Company in East Orange of $9,700. A police spokesman said the teenagers burst into the bank at 9:40 A.M. Thursday and forced employes and at least eight patron to line up along the wall. The bandits scooped up the money from tellers cages and fled. Within a halfhour, the police rounded up five suspects and about $7,000 of the stolen money. Arrested and held without bail were Vozell Johnson and and James Watson, both 19 years old, and Ken Whitlock, 18. The spokesman said the other suspects, aged 16 and 17, had been held for juvenile authorities.

title: Lunar Eclipse Due at Midnight; Viewers to Need No Precautions
description: At midnight tonight an eclipse of the sun will begin on the moonand, of greater interest to inhabitants of the United States and Canada, an eclipse of the moon will commence on earth.

title: City Starts Exodus for Memorial Day
description: Thousands of travelers took to the highways and jammed airports and train and bus termirtals yesterday to get an early start on the threeday Memorial Day weekend that traditionally opens the summer season:

title: Italy's Airline Pilots Strike
description: ROME, May 23 (AP)Pilots of the Italian airlines Alitalia and Itavia began a 36hour strike today, forcing the airlines to cancel most of their national and international flights.

title: KENNEDY CONFERS WITH KING KHALID
description: RIYADH, May 23  King Khalid of Saudi Arabia has told Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who is visiting here, that the Arab countries cannot relieve energy problems for the United States until there is a just solution to the Middle East conflict with Israel.

description: CHICAGO, May 23After the cocktails were ingested last night in a decidedly unVictorian manner, the 75 guests checked the ornate calligraphy of their place cards.

title: Buckley Asks Inquiry On Hoffman Payment
description: Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative of New York, has called upon the Federal Communications Commission and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting to investigate WNET's payment of $2,500 to Abbie Hoffman, a fugitive charged with selling cocaine, for a television interview.

title: Plastic Book Cover is Made Electronically
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 A chemist who is a specialist in polymer technology believes he has the answer to the problem of bookbinding. Alvin V. Roberts was granted a patent this Patents week for an electronic method of of the making plastic Week book covers. He assigned Patent 3,884,742 to Bookwrights, Inc., Scarsdale, N.Y., of which he is founder and president. The inventor says his patented cover can replace with plastic sheeting the paper, cloth and paperboard in current use. When commercial production begins, Mr. Roberts predicts that the onepiece plastic cover can achieve every graphic effect possible with conventional hardbound and paper books at a cost somewhere between the

title: AfterSchool Classes Boom, but Some Parents Resist Obligation
description: Irma Ellis wanted her 8earold son, Emery, to study art after school. He wanted instead to learn magic tricks. And so he enrolled in the magic class at the Walden School Community Program, where he also takes karate and where he learned woodworking.

title: Music: Boehm Quintette
description: The repertory for woodwind quintet is not short of works that are challenging to the players, but it is by no means awash in masterpieces of the sort that make angrossing listening. So the Boehm Quintette has been busy in recent seasons commissioning works by composers whom the group believes will make a serious contribution to the literature, in the words of a program note for its concert at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night.

title: Hospital Agency Votes for Cuts
description: New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation voted to try other economies rather than close down another hospital to cut its expenses and help close the city's budget gap.

title: O.A.S.: Alive in D.C.
description: Two points remained clear about the Organization of American States after the close of its annual General Assembly the 24 member governments want the organization to survive; most of them want its headquarters to stay in Washington. No action was taken on the statement by Assistant Secretary of State William D. Rogers that the United States would be willing to transfer the O.A.S. to another country if a majority of members so desired.

title: Bonn's NoNonsense Bugle
description: BONN, May 23, (Reuters) West German soldiers in future must leap out of bed the moment the bugle blows reveille. New military regulations that have just come into force abolish the 15 minutes grace previously allowed.

title: Mr. Ford's Doctor Coue
description: The figures. This means, he exulted, that the United States economy has withstood the abolition of slavery remarkably well and has even found jobs for half of a youthful population that would have been tied down in nonwageearning forced labor 110 years ago. In another 110 years, we may very well be able to create jobs for the other 50 Der cent.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe morning after President Ford ordered the attack on Tang Island off Cambodia to retrieve the merchant ship Mayagilez and her crew, one of the first congratulatory telephone calls to the White House came from Carroll Hubbard Jr of Maysfield, Ky.

title: DUTCH MAKE GAINS IN ARAB RELATIONS
description: THE HAGUE, May 24 (Reuters)The Netherlands, Israel's stanchest supporter in Western Europe, is making fast headway in a quest for reconciliation with the Arab nations.

title: Oases of Silence In a Desert of Din
description: LAST summer's announcement that canned music had been installed in the Sistine Chipel can as no surprise to those of us who have spent recent years in an increasingly frenzied pursuit of peace and quiet. Silence has become the traveler's rarest luxury. Ever since behavioral scientists discovered that the sound of saxophones caused chimpanzees to scratch less, the world tourist industry has been hanging loudspeakers in every possible crevice.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U2's at British Base Stir Angry Laborite Protests
description: LONDON, May 24 (AP)Use of a British air base by five American U2 reconnaissance planes drew angry protests today from Labor party lawmakers who demanded the craft be withdrawn.

title: Sewage Plant Limits Hanover Twp.
description: HANOVER TOWNSHIPSewage disposal, a problem that plagues many communities in New Jersey, has prevented this Morris County township from developingmuch of its land and thus incraasing its tax income. Two years ago, the state's Department of Environmental Protection ordered officials here to ban construction until they were able to double the capacity of the sewagetreatment plant. Township leaders are now optimistic that they will be able to move quickly, for they have submitted a plan for expanding the removal of effluents from 1.5 million gallons to 3 million gallons a day.

title: Dr. Edward Kirkland Dies at 81; Economics Historian at Bowdoin
description: HANOVER, N.H., May 24Dr. Edward Chase Kirkland, a member of the Bowdoin College faculty for nearly 30 years and an internationally known economics historian, died in a nursing home here today, his 81st birthday.

title: Delay in Boston integration is Denied
description: BOSTON, May 24The law says it should be done this way, said Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr., peering down at the well of his courtroom filled with attorneys. It will be difficult without question, Lord knows, and it won't be perfect.

title: Design
description: The MulfordBaker house in East Hampton is a fine residence of the sort that whaling families built in the Nth century. Its Federal hallmarks include a wellbalanced facade, 12over12 sash windows (still bearing their handmade panes), high, exposed stone foundations and a doorway flanked by fluted pilasters and topped by transom lights and graceful entablature.

title: Jane Levine is Engaged
description: Mr and Mrs. Irving R. Levine of Miami Beach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Sheila Levine, to Dr. Irwin Lipp, son of Mr and Mrs. Louis Lipp of Fort Lee, N. J. Miss Levine is a nurse on the staff of the New York State Nurses Association. Dr. Lipp practices otolaryngology in Valley Stream, L. I.

title: 81 Western Reporters Leave Saigon for Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos May 24, (Reuters)The first Westerners to leave Saigon since the Communist takeover on April 3081 newsmen leaving at their own request and a retired French general expelled by the new South Vietnamese authoritiesarrived.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Seven tenants have leased more than 116,000 square feet of office space in the 22story building at 460 Park Avenue, on the northwest corner of 57th Street. The leases have terms of 5 to 10 years and a total aggregate rent of more than $11million.

title: The America to Sail Again
description: KINGS POINTA replica of the glamorous 105foot schooner, America, has been acquired by the United States Merchant Marine Academy here.

title: The Bankers: Not in it for the Pay?
description: Bankers are just like anybody else, except richer, wrote Ogden Nash in 1938 in the days before proxy perusing became an annual divertissement among financial analysts. Now, through the grace of the Securities and Exchange Commission, it can be proven that bankers, for all their reputed riches, are not so well paid as the men from I.T.T., Exxon, CBS, I.B.M. or G.E.

title: Prison Diaries
description: There is no reason to believe that Edward Kuznetsov, the 36yearold author of Prison Diaries, has ever met any of the 17 former Soviet citizens interviewed in Irina Kirk's Profiles in Russian Resistance. Yet the books are intricately entwined. Kuznetsov and the others share a total disaffection from the Soviet system, an inability to conform and an overwhelming despair which, ultimately, led each of them to seek personal treedom in the West.

title: Miriam Anna Marecek is a Bride
description: Miriam Anna Marecek, an educational consultant here was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Leos J. Zeman, a research fellow at Harvard Medical School, where he received a grant for research in molecular genetics.
