description: War, beanball variety, did not erupt at Shea Stadium last night. The Yankees did.

title: FIREMEN ASSAULTED IN HYDRANT DISPUTE
description: Three firemen were assaulted by about a dozen youths in Harlem last night when one of them attempted to prevent the youngsters from aiming stream of water from an open hydrant against a ladder truck, authorities said.

title: Race Horse is Stolen In Extortion Attempt
description: LAUREL, Md., May 24 (UPI) The Maryland state police arrested a man today and accused him of trying to extort $20,000 from the owner of a thoroughbred race horse stolen from a stable at the Laurel Race Course.

title: Dave Anderson
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 24Joe Namath sipped blackberry brandy on the rocks and looked up.

title: Trips to Canada With Pets Require Extra Planning
description: People from the United states planning to take a dog with them on a vacation to Canada this summer should have their pet vaccinated against rabies before leaving. Unlike the United States, where a rabies vaccination within the previous three years is sufficient to gain entry, dogs going into Canada must have been vaccinated with 12 months of entering the country north of the border.

title: A Staff of Few Exceptions
description: Morgan Stanley & Co at the professional ??? dominated by white, male Ivy Leaguers. Black faces, Hispanic surnames and skirts are a rarity.

title: Scouts to Explore Israel Crane House
description: MONTCLAIRNext Saturday is Scout Day at the restored Israel Crane House, which was built in 1796. The Montclair Historical Society has invited all Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, Brownies and Cubs in Montclair and West Essex towns to visit the house between 9 A.M. and 4 P.M.

title: Marcia Rickenbacker Married to Douglas Pettibone
description: Marcia Frost Rickenbacker, a granddaughter of the late Capt. Edward (Eddie) V. Rickenbacker, the flying ace, was married yesterday afternoon to Douelas John Pettibone of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Smith Pettibone of Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: If You Go
description: on a houseboat cruise of the Everglades National Park, bear in mind that this is the beginning of the wet, hot, mosquito season. which is also the best time for fishing. The temperate dry season doesn't start until midSeptember.

title: INVESTING
description: Some building material and housing stocks have climbed sharply in the vigorous stock market rally of the last several months, but few in Wall Street are betting that they will continue to make impressive gains.

title: Angola Begins Testing A Television Service
description: LUANDA, Angola, May 24 (Reuters)A television service went on the air here this week with its first experimental program.

title: 50 Crates of Art Objects Seized From Vietnamese Ship in Guam
description: AGANA, Guam, Sunday, May 25About 50 crates of very old, very valuable art objects were taken into custody yesterday by authorities on Guam from a South Vietnamese coastal freighter that arrived here May 15 with 522 war refugees.

title: North Korea Chief Derides Talk of an Attack on South
description: VIENNA, May 24 (Reuters)North Korea's President, Kim I Sung, today described talk about a possible attack on South Korea as foolish, saying that Korea should be reunited by democratic and peaceful means.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: The current favored group among New York's pop music cult followers is The Manhattan Transfer, brought to us by the same people who gave us Bette Midler (same manager, agent and record company). This offshoot group (the first Manhattan Transfer, a countryrock group, began in 1969 and disbanded in 1971) consists of two women and two men who sing and dress in 1940's recherch style. According to their press bio, they first met in a taxi (driven by original MT member, Tim Hauser). When the four performers discovered that they shared a passion for jazz songs and dressing up in 1940's deco drag, they immediately formed a quartet.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: The Federal Government has not paid its Revolutionary War debts. Historians say it owes Haym Salomon upward of $350,000.

title: Egypt Doubles Rate for Canal Passage
description: CAIRO, May 24Egypt announced today that dues for ships going through the Suez Canal will be roughly twice the rates that prevailed before the canal was closed by the ArabIsraeli war of 1967.

title: Children Trying to Lure Bluebirds to L.I.
description: EAST HILLSThe bluebird, once a common sight bean, has been declining greatly in numbers for the last few decades, but a group of determined amateur ecologists in this village are trying to line him back.

title: Lesbian to Keep Children
description: LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP) Two children of a selfadmitted homosexual woman will be allowed to live with her, under a ruling by the suburban Torrance Superior Court. Lynda Mae Chaffin, who lost custody, of her two daughters after she admitted she was a lesbian, was granted a modification Tuesday of the original custody order.

title: Patricia Taylor is Bride
description: Patricia Ann Taylor, daughter of Mrs. Richard Porter Taylor of Cannondale, Conn., and the late Dr. Taylor, was mairied yesterday afternoon to Orton Porter Jackson Jr., son of, Mr and Mrs. Jacksm of St. Davids, Pa., The Rev. Lorin Bradford Young performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Taylor home.

title: Club Life: Still Going Strong
description: Every five years or so, someone writes the obituary of club life in New York. The stories are usually the same younger people are not interested, oldfogey clubmen are dying off, expenses are going up and modern, more casual life styles have made the clubs, with their rigid social barriers, irrelevant.

title: I.R.A. Race Not Going To Harvard
description: Having concluded their final exams, those athletes who divide their time between books and boathouse will face their last rowing tests of the 1975 collegiate season this week.

title: Few Using Vouchers to Pay for School
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.Five years after education vouchers were widely proposed and debated as a device to broaden educational choice and to give parents more control over their children's schooling, the notion is still having difficulty taking root.

title: Foyt Choice Again in Indy 500 Today
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 24A. J. Foyt has something in common with Jack Nicklaus. Both have won everything important two, three or four times. And now, in the same year that Nicklaus became the first golfer to win the Masters a fifth time, Anthony Joseph Foyt Jr will try to make it tomorrow asthe first fourtime winner of the Indianapolis 500.

title: Lead in Gas Guidelines.
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 24 (UPI)Under a new cooperative agreement signed with the Federal Government, Maryland will be the first state to enforce regulatidhs ih limiting lead and phosphorus content in gasoline.

title: Miss Magruder is Bride Of Henry P. U. Harris 3d
description: Eleanor Murray Magruder, daughter of Dr and Mrs. Roger Gregory Magruder of Charlottesville, Va., was married there yesterday afternoon to Henry Pratt Upham Harris 3d, who attends the Darden School of Business Administration at the University of Virginia. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. Harris Jr president of Harris, Upham & Co., Inc., member of the New York Stock Exchange, and Mrs. Harris of Brookville, L.I., and Holderness, N.H., and a greatgrandson of John F. Harris, founder of the concern.

title: Aerial Expenses Spark GoldinKibbee Dogfight
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday accused five City University professors of flying too high and far at taxpayers expense  and then collided with the university's chancellor, Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, who sought to explain to Mr. Goldin the intricacies of academe.

title: Sarsar, $5, Beats 12 Colts In2Length Withers Victory
description: Sarsar elevated herself to the top echelon of the thoroughbred scene at Aqueduct yesterday. The only filly in a field of 13 horses in the $60,600 Withers Mile, William Haggin Perry's representative scored a smashing victory, defeating Laramie Trail by two lengths.

title: With Only Normal Temperatures, Next Winter Could Be a Rough One
description: WASHINGTONIs the United States sliding quietly into an invisible crisis, as Representative Al Ullman, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has suggested?

title: Military Cabinet is Assailed in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, May 24Moslem political and religious leaders demanded today the resignation of the military, cabinet that was appointed yesterday by President Suleiman Franjieh to restore order in the barricaded streets of this Lebanese capital.

title: Diana Common Bride Of Ernest D. Dempsey
description: Diana Melanie Common and Ernest Davis Dempsey were married yesterday afternoon in Montreal in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Cathedral. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William E. Daly of St. Louis, a cousin of the bridegroom, assisted by the Rev. Dr. David L. Common of Toronto, an uncle of the bride, and the Rev. M. D. Dube of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Hope H. Brock, Grant Winthrop Plan Marriage
description: Mr and Mrs. Horace Brock of Oyster Bay, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hope Hartley Brock, to Grant Forbes Winthrop, son of Mr and Mrs. Frederic Winthrop of Groton House. Hamilton, Mass.

title: Tighe Wins Hour Run
description: Mike Tighe, 19 years old, from the Central Park Track Club ran 10 miles 125 yards yesterday to win the Road Runners Club OneHour Run at. Queensboro Community College in Bayside, Queens. Tighe finished 95 yards ahead of Alan Corder of the Milrose A.A.

title: Still an Epidemic
description: WASHINGTONEarly in his 1968 campaign for the Presidency, Richard M. Nixon correctly perceived that the illicit drug epidemic in the United States touched the lives or emotions of a crosssection of Americans from ghetto to suburb.

title: Byrne Seeking Action on Bills
description: TRENTONThe Democratic majorities in the Legislature, deadlocked on a tax program to offset a $413million deficit in Governor Byrne's proposed $2.8billion state budget, have been asked by the Governor to approve a number of other measures before adjourning for the summer.

title: Fire Department and Unions Weigh Cutback Alternatives
description: Fire Department officials and union representatives yesterday discussed without agreement alternative proposals for closing of 50 companies or limiting engine companies to five men.

title: $100,000 Indy Cars: Long On Speed, Short on Comfort
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 24Tomorrow's Indianapolis 500mile auto race is limited to United States Auto Club championship cars, commonly known as Indy cars.

title: Editors Choice
description: General

title: The New Initiatives
description: We New Yorkers must, in short, take effective steps to help ourselves. We must act promptly to reverse the alarming erosion of the city's vital economic base. New initiatives, requiring in some cases drive and imagination more than money, are needed to reduce the high costs of living and doing business here, to raise productivity in both public and private sectors and to improve the quality and attractiveness of urban life, Here are a few, most of which have been touched on in these columns during the past two weeks:

title: Research Facilities of Libraries Shut on Saturdays for Summer
description: Yesterday was the last Saturday that bibliophiles could use the research facilities of the New York Public Library for at least four months, and one teacher with the City University was making the most of it.

title: Submarines of U.S. Stage Spy Missions Inside Soviet Waters
description: WASHINGTON, May 24for nearly 15 years, the Navy has been using specially equipped electronic submarines to spy at times inside the threemile limit of the Soviet Union and other nations.

title: Delaware Toll Rise Near
description: PALMYRAThe few commodities that New Jerseyans buy for a nickel will decline by one this week. The Burlington County Bridge Commission is expected to announce a toll increase on its two Delaware River spans.

title: State Senator Conklin Speaks for the Retarded as Only a Parent Could
description: ALBANY  Twentysix years ago, when his son, Billy, born a Mongoloid, was 5 years old, William Conklin took him by the hand to the nearest Bay Ridge public school. We have no class for him, the principal said.

title: CHESS
description: ROBERT BYRNE

title: The Experimental City
description: As the experimental city, New York has become during the past generation the leader in social services to its citizensin fact, a pioneer among American cities and states in the provision of assistance to the less advantaged among its huge and polyglot population. New York has established benefits for those who work and live here unmatched anywhere else in the countrywhether in hospital treatment or in cheap public transportation or in free higher education for all or in generous welfare payments or in a host of other services which the city can no longer afford but thateven if were desirablecould not be severely reduced, much less eliminated, without socially disastrous results.

title: Word Wrangle
description: There's not much difference to hear or even see between the words several and seven, but these days the Gulf Oil Corporation, and more particularly an unknown stenographer, must wish there were.

title: Inflation and a Cartel War
description: BONNIn the wake of EastWest dtente, which has proved more effective in Europe than the Middle East or Asia, a new kind of cold war shows signs of starting between developed nations and the underdeveloped third world.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Lunch on Nature, Free for the Finding
description: When we bought 40 acres of New England woods and a couple of cabins a few years ago, my first thought was to start a garden. We partially cleared a couple of acres of secondgrowth forest, dug and fertilized a small garden plot, planted, and waited.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, May 25, 1975

title: Literary Magazine Started at Suffolk Community College Seeks L.I. Talent
description: SELDENThere is an incredible creative sense among young and old people on Long Island, and a need to recreate their Long Island experience imaginatively, Prof. Vince Clemente of Suffolk County Community College's English department, said last week.

title: Title Soccer to England
description: WEMBLEY, England, May 24 (AP)  England thrashed Scotland, 51, today to win the annual British international soccer championship. England led, 31, at halftime before a capacity crowd of 100,000 at Wembley Stadium.

title: The World
description: The location and use of governmental power in Portugal has become so confused as to be close to anarchical. Last week one of the country's large independent newspapers was shut down under Communist pressure, but the event was more a symptom of confusion than an indication of the country's political direction.

title: Shop Talk
description: TOTOWA  Yardley, the 105yearold Britishborn cosmetics company that made the scent of lavender famous, is constantly introducing new lines and dropping others. The reason is simple, for in this business, like fashions, consumers tastes change from season to season.

title: Jacobson's Return to Tracks Seen
description: Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, whose career as one of the nation's leading trainers apparently was ended five years ago with a decision to bar stalls for his horses in New York, may soon be in action again.

title: The Lie and the Image
description: BOSTONThe approach of the Bicentennial year is causing a good many Americans to search for the deeper causes underlying the recent collapse of American foreign policy and the economic and social disarray at homeprecisely because, Hannah Arendt said here the other day, people are aware of the fearful distance that separates us from our extraordinary beginnings.

title: J. T. Bryan 3d Weds Carroll Kyser
description: Carroll Amanda Kyser and James T. Bryan 3d were married yesterday afternoon in an Episcopal ceremony in the Chapel of the Cross in Chapel Hill, N.C. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. Robert A. Bryan, executive director of the Quebec Labrador Mission Foundation. He was assisted by the Rev. Peter Lee.

title: Honduran Peasants Yield
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 24 (Reuters)  Some 10,000 peaasants who seized land in various parts of Honduras in the last few days decided last night to abandon the land peacefully, the militarybacked Government said here. The Government said yesterday that if the peasants did not agree to quit the land action would be taken against them.

title: Bridal Planned By Miss Pappas, Donald T. Lewis
description: Mr and Mrs. Philip Miller Pappas of Houston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gwendolzn Pappas, to Donald James Lewis, son of Mr and Mrs. James Gibson Lewis of Temple, Tex.

title: Betty Ford in TipTop Shape After Grueling FourDay Trip
description: WASHINGTON, May 24For four days, Betty Ford had been almost constantly on public display, hugging a 106yearold foster grandmother, cuddling a baby chimp in a zoo, greeting Vietnamese and Cambodian refugees in their dusty campsite, mingling with the rich and the superrich at Los Angeles and San Diego dinParties.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Broadway's Rodgers and Hart has Rodgers and Hart and Yale's A Midsununer Night's Dream has a moon. Rodgers and Hart are made of sugar and spice, and the moon is made of popcorn.

title: How to Have the Neighbors for Dinner
description: It was a simple solution to our annoying problem, but it didn't dawn on us until after several years of fussing aver spilled garbage cans. Since we couldn't beat the marauding raccoons, skunks and opossums who were causing the trouble, why not join them? Or, more accurately, why not let them join us?

title: ARTHUR L. HAGAN
description: Arthur L. Hagan, former president and treasurer of the Hagan Investing Corporation, Utica, N.Y., died Friday at St. Elizabeth Hospital, Utica. He was 77 years old And lived in Utica.

title: Crime Compensation Board, Out of Funds, Still Seeks Victims
description: TRENTONNot too long ago, members of the state's Violent Crimes Compensation Board were looking for eligible persons to whom they could give money.

title: STAMPS
description: Stamps of sailing ships, in colors of the entire spectrum of the rainbow, make up a novel set being issued by Great Britain on June 11.

title: Demands of the Bicentennial Keep a Specialist in Textile Crafts Quite Busy
description: MONTAUK  Betty Alexander is getting ready for the Bicentennial. She has a hefty supply of gray fleece from dwarf sheep being raised experimentally in Ohio, has imported as much flax as she could get from Ireland, and picked and dried enough bay berries, marigolds and dandelions to keep her cauldrons boiling.

title: Navy Is Lacrosse Finalist
description: ITHACA, N.Y., May 24Navy became the first of the three major academies to reach the final of a National Collegiate lacrosse tournament when the Middies upset Cornell, 1512, today, at Schoellkoof Field.

title: Proponents Say Chaos Can Be Averted
description: The tattered state of the American economy has stimulated renewed debate over the role of Government planning in a democratic society. Advocates promise relief from the gyrations that have plagued the economy in the past. Opponents condemn planning as a threat to freedom and efficiency.

title: Indianapolis 500 Field
description: FIRST ROW

title: The Bolshoi's Supers Could Have Danced All Night
description: It was late afternoon, and a knot of fans waited by the stage entrance to the Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center, watching the dancers arrive for the Bolshoi Ballet's production of Sleeping Beauty that evening.

title: Selling, for Some, Keeps the Pink Slip Away
description: In an effort to save their jobs, 75 production workers at a KimberlyClark Corporation mill near Neenah, Wis., voluntarily traded their blue collars for white ones last week and became sales representatives.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Real Owner of the Mets?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Warriors Hoping to End Season Today
description: The basketball season may actually end before Memorial Day if the Golden State Warriors can beat the Washington Bullets one more time at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md., this afternoon. The fourth game of the National Basketball Association championship round, in which the Warriors lead 30, is scheduled for 2:10 P.M. on national television (Channel 2 here).

title: What's Doing in MONTREAL
ExConvict Slays 2 Women, Rapes 2 and Kills Himself
description: DAYTON, Ohio, May 24 (AP)  A 28yearold former convict killed two women, shot lind wounded nine other persons and raped two teenagers before killing himself early today, the police said.

title: Arthur O. Sulzberger jr. And Gail Gregg Married
description: Gail Gregg, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Thomas M. Gregg of Topeka, Kan., was married there yesterday afternoon to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr.

title: Professionally Planned Little Parks Are Sprouting Up in Downtown Brooklyn
description: Where once tree and flower plantings were sufficient for a neighborhood park in downtown Brooklyn, there is now parkleting, a more sophisticated approach to developing vacant community patches.

title: Gen. Paul Legentilhomme Dies; Leader of Free French Forces
description: NICE, France, May 24 (AP)Gen. Paul Legentilhomme, the first French Army general to join the Free French forces of Gen. Charles de Gaulle in Britain following the German occupation of France in 1940, died here yesterday in a clinic.

title: Elbert E. Wortman, 85, Retired Advertising Man
description: Elbert E. Viortman, a retired advertising executive died yesterday at his home, 3427 79th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 85 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will hold three public hearingsJune 3, 4 and 5dealing with its applications to the Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administration for $132.5million in grants. The Federal funds are to be used for subway construction in Queens, for operating assistance for subways and buses and for commuter rail improvements.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Major League Box Scores

title: Britain's Kids Take TV News With Their Tea
description: LONDON More than five million British children, aged around 11, have been settling down on many a recent evening to tea, their television setsand pictures of the upheaval in Vietnam, military preparations in the Middle East or some other grim crisis that the frenzied world of their parents is struggling through.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Like the weather experts who have difficulty trying fathom climatic conditions in the variable days spring, the leading economic forecasters these days are puzzled by the trends they have been examining in business and finance.

title: Athletes Are Asset For Tract Society
description: ORADELL  What do Theodore Roosevelt, Billy Graham, Bill Bradley, Representative John B. Conlan Jr. of Arizona, Manny Sanguillen and Gary Player have in common?

title: In a City of Lobbyists, the Governor's Own Lobbyist Manages to Stand Out
description: ALBANYIn a city of lobbyists, Fabian Palomino runs one of the trickiest lobbying operations around. on a given day he might arrange a softball game between State Senators and the Governor's office, negotiate for the Governor with a group of skeptical legislators, usher a freshman Senator into the Red Room for a picturetaking session, and sit an Assembly Committee chairman down with a state Commissioner to talk about a bill draft.

title: Nancy E. Leighton, a Teacher, Is Bride of Harold Otto Koenig
description: In the Episcopal Cathedral Cnurch of the Incarnation in Baltimore yesterday morning, Nancy Elizabeth Leighton became the bride of Harold Otto Koenig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Purlington Koenig of Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: Kathy E. Ludwig Bride of A. R. Pisciotta
description: Kathy Elizabeth Ludwig, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Henry G. Ludwig of Nutley, N.J., and Anthony R. Pisciotta were married yesterday afternoon by Msgr. Francis Lo Bianco, assisted by the Rev. Peter Brown, at the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in Nutley.

title: Evans Quits Kings Post
description: KANSAS CITY, May 24 (AP)Ray Evans resigned today as chairman of the Kansas CityOmaha Kings of the National Basketball Association. The announcement cited health as the reason. Evasis was fined $15,000 in Federal court yesterday on two criminal charges.

title: Scottish Trade Unionists Try to Halt Rightist Rally
description: LONDON, May 24Scottish trade unionists clashed with the police in Glasgow tonight in an attempt to break up a meeting against Britain's membership in the Common Market called by the extreme rightwing National Front.

title: It Has a Deficit, But it Also Has a Trust Fund
description: WASHINGTON  The nation's Social Security system a drifting into the red this year, but no one in authority is particularly worried and no one's benefits are in danger.

title: A School Within a School
description: GREENLAWN Last fall, 28 students  all potential high school dropoutsand two teachers sat down to design a school.

title: Meet to Honor Brundage
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 24 (UPI)The first National track and field Hall of Fame Classic June 14 will be dedicated to the late Avery Brundage, longtime president of the International Olympic Committee, hall officials said today. The meet will be at Laidley Field in Charleston.

title: Adelphi is Beginning Scholarship Tryouts
description: Beginning this week, women at Adelphi University will have a chance to compete for eight fulltuition athletic scholarships for the next academic year. The scholarships are valued at $2,670 each for a full credit program. Ron Bazil, the athletic director, lists the tryout schedules for incoming women freshmen seeking scholarships in the following sports:

title: Grassroots Lively Arts Will Grow in Brooklyn Park
description: A Haitian poetry and music festival, readings of supernatural poetry by four Brooklyn sorcerers, a performance by John Cage, the modern composerthese are a few of the events planned for summer weekends at the Music Grove in Prospect Park, thanks to the efforts of a couple of Parks Department employes with a belief in Brooklyn's unmined cultural potential.

title: Is Inventory Indigestion Curable?
description: The great inventory surplus may be largely over in the retail business but its effects linger on to confound stores and suppliers alike.

title: Card of Thanks
description: PINCUSLester J. The faintly of the fate Lester J. Pincus acknowledge with deep gratitude the comfort and sympathy of their many friends.

title: Son to Mrs. Friedman
description: A son was born to Mr and Mrs. Michael L. Friedman of New York on May 6 in the Klingenstein Pavilion of Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Friedman, the former Jane Becker of New York, is director of promotion at Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. Her husband is the vice president of DWJ Associates, Inc., a publicrelations concern. The child is named Stefan Clay.

title: Soviet Orbits Crew For Station Linkup
description: MOSCOW, May 24The Soviet Union launched today a manned Soyuz spacecraft for an expected linkup with Salyut 4, a space research station in orbit since last December.

title: Michael Hudner to Wed Hope Freeman
description: Charles Wellman Freeman of Providence, RA I., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Elizabeth Hope Freeman, to Michael Sweeney Hudner, son of Mr and Mrs. Harold Kennedy Hudner of South Swansea. Mass.

title: How to Become a Dirty Fighter
description: The legal battles following the Muhammad AliChuck Wepner freeforall in March are certainly more interesting than their fight was. Referee Tony Perez filed a $20million suit against Ali for  marring his good name and credit  and causing him public scorn and disgrace. Within a week Al Braverman, Wepner's manager, filed a suit against Perez for allowing  deliberate and flagrant fouling by Ali. Braverman further asserted, Any referee with an ounce of courage would have stopped the fight. The BravermanWepner suit raises some interesting questions, such as Are there any rules in boxing? and Does anybody enforce them?

title: Miss Halpin Sets Mark at Two Miles
description: More than 1,600 girls from high schools and clubs throughout the state and from New York City junior high schools competed yesterday in a oneday relay carnival at Queens College.

title: Warrants: Appeal Waning?
description: Earlier this month, the lowly warranta strippeddown security that carries no dividend, voting power or claim on assetsfound itself at center stage on Wall Street.

title: ZZ Top Rock Trio Performs Cliches To Please Crowd
description: Z Z Top, the Texas trio that appeared at the Felt Forum on Friday, offers a series of clever, crowdpleasing clichs from the Rolling Stones to John Lee Hooker, from B. B. King toamazinglyJohnny Cash. And even Elvis Presley (with Jailhouse Rock) is not spared. A whole history lesson of rock n roll is neatly distilled through the group's TexanMexicanNashville experience. But little originality filters through.

title: Toward an Honest Budget
description: The most immediate, most urgent action to be taken within the next few days if New York is to avoid a disastrous slide into bankruptcy and begin a long uphill climb to fiscal integrity lies squarely within the responsibility and power of Mayor Beanie. That is to submit to the City Council and Board of Estimate a budget for the coming fiscal year that is honestly balanced and that will cover a looming deficit that the Mayor himself projects at $641.5 million but that other experts believe may go as high as $1.5 billion and even higher. Only in this way can the city regain the confidence of the financial community and of state and Federal officials on whom it must depend for help in meeting its immediate cash needs.

title: Barbara Wieland Wed To John F. Lehman Jr.
description: The marriage of Barbara Thornton Wieland, daughter of Mr and Mrs. D. Alexander Wieland of Philadelphia, to John Francis Lehman Jr., deputy director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, took place in Philadelphia yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lehman of Glenside, Pa. The Rev. Tom T. Edwards performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Chestnut Hill.

title: Saigon Ceremonies Mark Ho Chi Mirth's Birthday
description: Photographs just received here were made last week during a threeday victory celebration. On the reviewing stand (photo at right) were President Ton Due Thang of North Vietnam, at extreme left, and, next to him. Nguyen Huu Tho, head of National Liberation Front. Le Duc Tho, Hanoi diplomat, is at right, wearing white shirt. To his right, hands raised, is Huynh Tan Phat, who heads new Government. Also present was Lieut. Gen Tran Van Tra, Saigon's new military chief, photo below.

title: Civilians Aid Police In Accidents On Roads
description: Civilians working with the local police precinct in Ozone Park, Queens, have formed a volunteer patrol to assist at traffic road emergencies in the community.

title: Fiscal Threat
description: The New York dream is threatened today as never before in the city's 300year history by a fiscal crisis of unprecedented magnitude, a crisis engendered not only by a prolonged period of profligate municipal mismanagement but by longterm demographic and economic trends for which the cityand the nationhave yet to develop an adequate response. These trends include the flight of more affluent, better educated, mostly white citizens to the suburbs and a heavy influx of poor, uneducated and unskilled blacks and Hispanics whose special needs have severely strained the city's social services and its traditional powers of absorption.

title: South African Navy Takes First Nonwhite Seamen
description: CAPE TOWN, May 24 (Agence FrancePresse)The South African Navy has announced that it is training its first group of seamen of mixed ethnic background on a fighting ship for combat duty.

title: Carey Recommends Politics To Graduates at Canisius
description: BUFFALO. May 24 (AP) Governor Carey asked the graduating class of Canisius College here today to consider seriously careers in government and politics.

title: Fog Hides Sailing Race Leaders
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., May 24No one knew today which yacht was ahead in the Storm Trysail Club's annual 205mile race to Block Island and back. it was known, however, that the leader and the 121 others were not sailing very fast in continued light winds.

title: Food News
description: LYNDHURSTThe month for wedding bells is just around the corner again and, for the nine bakers at Mazur's Bakery, it is music to their ears. Before June is over, this 35yearold establishment will have turned out at least 100 wedding cakes.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Founded in 1969, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has enjoyed six soldout seasons in its home at Alice Tully Hall, effectively disproving the old canard that chamber music is boxoffice poison. Obviously a large segment of New York's concertgoers are eager to savor the kind of intimate musical experiences offered by the CMSLC, which has so imaginatively and Pxpertly explored a rich and often unduly neglected repertory of works for small instrumental combinations.

title: PILOT TAPE TELLS OF SAIGON FLIGHT
description: According to the copilot of a helicopter, the American evacuation of refugees from Saigon was halted because the crews of rescue helicopters were exhausted.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: FASHION TALK
description: Add Steckling is getting quite used to hearing her friends call her another Chanel or another McCardell. Not because her clothes are derivative, but because, like the other two designers who have left their stamp on the clothes people wear, she is a woman who designs primarily for herself.

title: Radio
description: 7:305 A.M., WABCAM: Message of Israel. Address by Rabbi Hyman Judah Schachtel.

title: New Jersey
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East Orange Never Sang for My Father. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through June 21). $3.50$4.90; students and the elderly, $2.5043.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: $70Million Art Collection Homeless
description: LONDON, May 24  Few cities could have had the embarrassing problem of owning an art collection valued at $70million and being unable to house it. Glasgow has been struggling with that problem for 30 years. A solution now seems in sight.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Next Friday, May 30, is the last day for ordering the third pair in the America's First Medals series offered by the U.S. Mint. This 11piece series (five pairs plus a bonus medal) is a major part of the Mint's effort to provide the public with meaningful mementoes of the Bicentennial.

title: City Completing Financial Prospectus
description: The city administration is completing its first prospectus on its finances, a highly detailed compilation that Corporation Counsel W. Bernard Richland says will show the city's magnificent resources, enormous potential and imperishable aualities.

title: The Tower In the Park Becomes An Enclave
description: The cloistered tradition is being revived in the Soundview section of the Bronx, where a housing development for 948 families is scheduled to open this summer.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger, in a news conference in advance of President Ford's trip to Europe this week, said yesterday that if Mr. Ford failed to narrow differences between Egypt and Israel next month the United States would probably put forth its own plan on how to make progress toward a Middle East settlement. He said a continued stalemate could lead only to a catastrophe for all parties concerned, and that the United States was determined that elnlomatic progress be continued. [Page Column 8.]

title: Collector: Portrait of Robert Lehman, by Aaron Shikler, at the entrance to the Metropolitan's new wing.
description: Great art museums, like other institutions dependent upon the support of powerful elites, sizable sums of money, elaborate bureaucracies, and the acquiescence of a broad publie for their prosperity and survival, are a paradigm of the societies that create them. There was a time when such museums derived their collections from the spoils of imperial conquest: The capitals of Europe still abound in the glittering evidence of that bygone era. At other Limes, immense museological enterprises have been the direct resultas they are, evidently, in China todayof the will to sanctify a mystique of nationalist identity. Museums follow where society leads, and thus strive to serve the values certified by established power.

title: Developer Challenging Zoning Curbs and Master Plan in Passaic County Town
description: PATERSONOne of New Jersey's longestrunning zoning disputes is now a bitterly contested court case that could eventually form another link in the chain of State Supreme Court decisions affecting land use.

title: Renaissance Man Lime Rock Choice
description: Jim McXay, the broadcaster, once, described Sam Posey, the racecar driver, as a renaissance man. That was very, kind of him, says the 30yearold Posey, but think it's stretching the point a bit. I think that in this day and age, it's not possible to have a man who truly dips into all the important areas in the manner people did during the Renaissance period. I think a more accurate, if slightly less high faluting description, is that I have many interests and they're not all along the same channels. in addition to racing, which is my primary profession, I've designed a house for myself and a couple of other houses for other people. I've made a couple sets of furniture which are being marketed and I've written a book

title: Yanks Again Overpower Rangers, 95; Mets Defeat Braves, 51
description: ATLANTA, May 24Randy Tate may have pitched himself out of a demotion to Tidewater tonight and into role as the fourth Met starter.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Unlike many of this year's 23,000plus business school graduates, Thomas K. Emmons got the job he wanted.

title: Escaped Michigan Patient Said to Admit Killing Four
description: ADRIAN, Mich., May 24 (UPI)  Gary Addison Taylor, an escaped mental patient, admitted today that he had murdered four women in three states and buried two of them in the yard of his rural Michigan home, the Michigan authorties said.

title: An Odyssey Through The 13 ExColonies
description: Either Mr. Stern ber or a reliable agent seems to have visited every battle scene and to have taken account of even minor topographical changes in 200 years.Alden Whitman, reviewing The Bicentennial Guide to the American Revolution by Sol Stember in The New York Times on Aug. 20, 1974.

title: TV VIEW
description: On Monday evening, April 14, the American Broadcasting Company presented a twohour dramatic production called I Will Fight No More Forever. The original screenplay by Jeb Rosebrook and Theodore Strauss offered the true story of Chief Joseph, a leader, of the Nez Perre tribe. in 1877. the tribe became a target in the American Government's deliberate policy of forced containment against American Indians. Despite a protective treaty signed in 1863, the Nez Perces were ordered to a reservation. Chief Joseph eventually found himself leading a heroic retreat over 1,600 miles of land in the area where the states of Washington, Oregon and Idaho now meet. That event provided the central focus of the television drama.

title: JUSTICE SYSTEM SCORED BY PANEL
description: An extensive revision of the city's criminaljustice system was prescribed yesterday by the State Charter Revision Commission which found the system plagued by a lack of comprehensive planning misplaced priorities, ineffective use of personnel and other re. sources.

title: Sandra E. Ferguson to Be Married
description: The engagement of Sandra Elizabeth Ferguson to Jonathan Trumbull McPhee has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. David Ferguson Jr. of Bethesda, Md., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the on of Clement Spurgeon McPhee Jr of Northbrook, Ill., and Point Judith, R.I., and the late Mrs. McPhee.

title: AUTHOR SUES NAYY FOR DEFAMATION
description: A hearing is set for Friday on a suit by Michael Harrington, the journalist, author and political activist, who contends that top Navy officials have unconstitutionally collected and disseminated information designed to defame him.

title: Abravanel and Utahans
description: Some wag chose to publicize the Utah Symphony's only appearance here this season Friday night at Carnegie Hall by boldly labeling it one of America's 12 best orchestras.

title: Work Continues On Carter's Car
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 24, (UPI)Working against the clock, Gary Bond, the chief mechanic, and his helpers pieced together the car Duane (Pancho) Carter smashed into the wall in Thursday's final carburetion tests for tomorrow's Indiannapolis 500mile race.

title: Dnueilings
description: FINKELSTEINA monument to the memory of the late Joseph Finkelstein will be unveiled at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y., Peter Block Circle, Section H, Block 7, June 1, 11:15 A.M.

title: 12 RECEIVE AWARDS FOR PARKS SERVICE
description: Twelve New Yorkers have received distinguished service medals for outstanding contributions to the city's parks, Edwin L. Weisl Jr., the parks administrator, has announced.

title: Elizabeth G. Strider Bride of Frank Dain
description: Elizabeth Greer Strider, daughter of Dr. Robert E. L. Strider 2d, president of Colby College, and Mrs. Strider of Waterville, Me., was married there yesterday afternoon to Frank Westbrook Dain, son of Dr and Mrs. Frank M. Dain 3d of Nyack, N.Y. The Rev. Roland W. Thorwaldsen, chaplain at Colby, performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: KENNEDY IS FIRST IN GALLUP SURVEY
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, despite his noncandidate status, is easily the top choice of Democrats for the 1976 Presidential nomination, according to a Gallup Poll made public yesterday.

title: A Young Stranger Returns to Vienna
description: VIENNA is a hierarchical, seniority oriented society in which youth amounts almost b an afflictionfor which time is the only cure. There is a curfew (fortunately rarely enforced) forbidding kids to be abroad in the city, even with adult supervision, in nonprivate places after 9 P.M. if under 14 and after 11 P.M. if 14 or 15. Moviegoing is regulated from somewhere to the right of the Legion of Decency you have to be at least 10 to see The Ten Commandments and 14 to see Romeo and Juliet. A nice child would be defined here as a miniature adult at whom a grownup can safely shake a stick. in fact, I know of one Viennese girl who, when asked what she wanted for her ninth birthday, replidd: A caneso I can wave it back at all the people who shake their sticks at me.

title: Jones Beats McTear in 9.3 Sprint
Parent and Child
description: We are the only people we know who have child, or at least the only people we know well.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: TodayPlainfield K.C. allbreed and MidJersey Companion Dog Training Club trial, St. Joseph's High School. Plainfield Avenue, Metuchen, N. J. 2,125 dogs; 8 A.M.

title: Maltese Are Abolishing The Nobility and Titles
description: VALETTA, Malta, May 24 (AP)The Government is abolishing the nobility and establishing its own awards for acts of bravery and distinguished service.

title: The Death Of Stalin
description: The nightmare story of Stalin's last weeks alive in his dacha at Kuntsevo, just outside Moscow, could well be as fascinating as the more familiar tale of Hitler in his bunker. Many of the scenes are the same the dictator about to die, crazed with persecution mania, dispatching his henchmen to kill more and more Jews, friendless, consoling himself with the exercise of power. But while the secrets of the Third Reich have been revealed, those of the Kremlin are closely guarded and dangers lurk for any Western writer who tries to discover the truth and tell it. The information available is almost bound to be meager and unreliable.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor: An article on April 27, told of the passing of a political era in Hudson County a few years back and of how a new era of politicians had abandoned and forgotten the old Hudson County Courthouse. May 1 add that a still new era and new breed of officials have succeeded the latter group and appear to be thwarting a deliberate attempt to raze the courthouse.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne said earlier this year that he and members of his Cabinet would consider taking salary cuts in an effort to reduce state spending and as evidence that his administration was prepared to make personal financial sacrifices as a public demonstration of official belttightening.

title: Democrats Pick Donovan to Run in Oyster Bay
description: HICKSVILLE  Francis J. Donovan, a former Republican District Court judge in Nassau County, was selected last Thursday as the Democratic candidate for Supervisor of the Town of Oyster Bay.

title: No. Am. Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Red Smith
description: Originally it was to be a journalistic firstan interview with Bob Seagren and Steve Smith sidebyside on a sofa, and the inquisitor armed only with whip and kitchen chair. Then Smith reported by phone from California that he had seen this girl with a load on outside this joint in Los Angeles, and when he tried to help her into a car her guide took umbrage and Steve had to flatten him. He said he was wearing his Olympic ring, which put brand of five interlocking circles op the guy's jaw, and now Smith was feeling such machismo he was afraid that if he got in a room with Seagren he would slug him, too.

title: List of Pupil Percentage in Schools
Jazz at Noon Anyone Can Have Lunch With Jam
description: Shortly after noon on a Friday a few years ago, Bucky Thorpe, a truck driver who also plays trumpet, managed to find a place to park his truck near the Roosevelt Hotel. After wedging his vehicle into the space, he grabbed his trumpet and ran into the Roosevelt's Rough Rider Room where a group of musicians were jamming on Take the A Train,

title: Brazilian Elected To Olympics Post
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland May 24 (UPI)The International Olympic Committee elected Sylvio de Magalhaes Padilha of Brazil as vice president, succeeding Herman van Karnebeek of the Netherlands.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: CLIVE BARNES

title: Blind Panic of South Vietnamese Army in Final Hours of the War is Depicted
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 24Survivors of the last two divisions defending Saigon in the hours before its fall last month tell of men fleeing in blalld panic, of officers deserting; of complete resignation to defeat by whole units and of the few who tried to salvage sons honor from the sudden stunning victory by the Communist forces.

title: Playing With Money
description: The main characters dealing with New York City's financial crisis have passed through a week of fiscal foreplay, with everyone saying what was expected and no one doing what was needed. Now, with the options what they always were but less time to negotiate, the officials involved plan a meeting Tuesday that may determine howand ifthe city can avoid defaulting on its obligations.

title: Miss Freed Affianced To Richard E. Brook
description: Mr and Mrs. Morton Freed of Chestnut Hill, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Freed, to Richard Edward Brook, son of Mr and Mrs. Lester Brook of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: The Nation
description: There is substantial evidence to support the expectations of economists that the recession is near or at bottom. The classic telltale signs of a turning point are beginning to emerge.

title: Art League Art is Shown
description: MONTCLAIRThe current exhibition at the Montclair Art Museum celebrates both its permanent collection and the Art Students League of New York City.

title: KENNETH DOUGLAS, WRITER, TRANSLATOR
description: Kenneth Douglas, a freelance writer, editor and translator, died Friday evening in Lenox Hill Hospital. He had been in the hospital since May 13, when he was struck on the head by a falling curtain rod while walking past a building at 149 East 73d Street.

title: Endpaper
description: The OBJECT of the game is simply to plant SEED in the GARDEN so that a player grows enough VEGETABLES to win the VICTORY over inflation. The excitemcnt of the game is that at each toss of the DICE, players court CHANCE and DISASTER as they invest lavish amounts of MONEY, TIME and HARD LABOR.

title: April Traffic Toll 3,436
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI) Preliminary reports from the Department of Transportation have indicated that 3,436 persons were killed in April in traffic accidents across the nationa drop of more than 1,000 since the same month two years ago and a decreease of 9 from last April.

title: Great Adventure: A Visitor's View
description: JACKSONHow's everything going so far today? Tom Price asked. I hope you'll have a good time.

title: Rosamond Bernier is Married To John Russell in Suburbs
description: Rosamond Bernier of New York, art critic and lecturer, and John Russell, an art critic for The New York Times, were married yesterday afternoon by Judge Penfield C. Mead of the New Canaan Probate Court at the home of Philip Johnson, the architect, in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Power Failure in Satellite Cuts Short Indian Project
description: NEW DELHI, May 24 (AP)India said today that a power failure had forced curtailment after only four days of a sixmonth scientific project it had planned to carry out with the satellite launched for it in the Soviet Union on April 19.

title: Associated Press
description: THE EYES HAVE IT: Upper left, Coach Al Attics after Warriors beat Bullets. Upper right, A. Foyt at Indianapolis driver meeting. Lower left, Larry Hinson after sinking putt at Memphis. Lower right, Arnold Palmer en route to 70 in England.

title: L.I. Restaurant Takes Slow but Sure Route
description: SAG HARBOR  in the Hamptons, new restaurants explode on the scene like shooting stars. They blaze brightly for a time and then fade as the crowds are drawn to another source of light.

title: Eye Exams Slated For Sussex Aged
description: FRANKLIN  Meals on Wheels and Operation Outreach are sponsoring free eye examinations for elderly residents of Sussex County.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I am sure all informed investors have been wondering for a long time just what would happen to New York City when it became impossible for the city either to borrow any more money, or to pay any more interest on money borrowed already.

title: In 3 Volumes Weighing 13 Pounds, it Gets Changed About 5,000 Times in a Year
description: The New York City budget is as sprawling and undecipherable as the city it pretends to manage. it is the singular instrument of governmentproducing it and administering it are the two important functions of the Mayor. it is second in size only to the Federal budget. And it is unfathomable.

description: Article 3  No Title

title: Impounded Bon Vivant Soup Will Be Burned
description: ELIZABETHThe fiery destruction of more than a halfmillion cans of Bon Vivant soup is scheduled to begin here this week, nearly four years after the Federal Government impounded the cans following a man's death from botulism.

title: Music in Review
description: The Carnegie HallJeunesse Musicales Series came up with a winner Tuesday night when it presented Dora Schwartzberg in her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall. Miss Schartzberg, a violinist, was born and trained in the Soviet Union and is now a citizen of Israel. She won prizes in the 1969 Paganini and 1971 Munich competitions and on this side of the Atlantic, has performed at the Festival Casals in Puerto Rico and at the Aspen Festival.

title: Alison Haskins Warner Wed to Percy Pyne 4th
description: The marriage of Alison Haskins Warner to Percy Rivington Pyne 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pyne 3d of Far Hills, N.J., took place yesterday afternoon in New Canaan, Conn. The bride is a daughter of Rawleigh Warner Jr., chairman of the Mobil Oil Corporation, and Mrs. Warner of New Canaan. The Rev. Grant A. Morrill performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church. A reception was held at the Warner home.

title: Future of Picatinny Arsenal Clouds Life in Dover
description: DOVERAn ominous cloud of economic uncertainty is hanging over this community.

title: Memorial Seruices
description: SANDBACHWalker, a memorial service wiil be held at Scarsdale Friends Meeting, 133 Popham Road, Scarsdale, Sunday Afternoon June 1 a 3 o'clock. in lieu of flowers the family suggest memorial gifts be sent to the National Association for Mental Health 1800 North Kent St, Arllngton Virginia 22209 or to a local affiliate at that organization.

title: Diana K. LeMaire is Engaged To Stephen Harris Squibb Jr.
description: Mr and Mrs. Farish A. Jenkins of West Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Jenkins's daughter, Diana Knight LeMaire, to Stephen Harris Squibb Jr of Marblehead, Mass. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Squibb of Simsbury, Conn., and Saunderstown, R. I., and a greatgreatgrandson of Dr. Edward Robinson Squibb, founder of E. R. Squibb & Sons, the pharmaceutical company. The wedding is planned for Aug. 23.

title: BUS RIDER IS KILLED IN CHIDING A SMOKER
description: A 66yearold Brooklyn man was fatally injured by two men who attacked him on a Flatbush Avenue 41 line bus near Nostrand Avenue yesterday afternoon after he objected to a woman smoking on the bus.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FIRST NATIONAL CITY BANK lowered its prime rate from 7 per cent to 7 per cent, Its lowest since May 7, 1973. A number of other leading banks reduced their prime rates to 7 per cent from 7 per cent.

title: New Novel
description: You can spend years without coming across a funny novel based on the notion that you can take it with you. Then, in one season you find two: Roy Dolinees For Love or Money and this latest effort of Richard Condon. Each is an oasis of pleasure in a different style. Mr. Dolinees novel has more heart, but Mr. Condon's has more head, with a plot as intricate as the printed circuit of television set.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Fund Will Protect Hunters Rights
description: Earlier this month at a meeting of Game Conservation International in San Antonio, Jack Samson, the editor of Field and Stream, told his listeners that the American hunter might justifiably be regarded as an endangered species.

title: Reader's Block
description: The Guest Wordin September of 1944 I parachuted into a Dutch beetfield with thousands of former grease monkeys, students, corner bums and coal miners who made up the 101st Airborne Division. When Cornelius Ryan's A Bridge Too Far came out last fall, I got a copy right away. it was, after all a book about me.

title: Women Help to Fight Crime
description: JERSEY CITYThis aging and depressed city has been the scene, over the last 10 months, of a number of violent crimes against women.

title: Wings for McDonald's: Will it Fly?
description: The McDonald's Corporation, licenser and operator of a nationwide system of 3,232 fastfood restaurants and home of the Big Mac, has been mulling over the idea of adding fried chicken to its menu.

title: Calendar of Motor Sports Events
description: TodayDrag racing at Madison Township Raceway Park, Pension Road, Englishtown, N.J. Gates open 9 A.M., eliminations at 2 P.M.

title: Aides Soften Ford's Remarks on Lisbon
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 President Ford's statement that he intended to ask leaders of the Atlantic alliance next week to consider whether Portugal should be expelled was blunted today by Administration officials, including Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Beverly Hope Wed To Charles H. Rowe
description: Beverly Hope, daughter of Neva Tatman Hope of White Plains and the late William C. Hope, Was married yesterday afternoon in Scarsdale. N.Y., to Charles Hines Rowe, son of Perce O. Rowe of San Antonio, Tex., and the late Elizabeth H. Rowe. The Rev, David Kendall performed the ceremony, in he chapel of the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church.

title: 2 DUPE BANK OFFICIAL AND RANSACK HOUSE
description: Two armed men made off with $8,000 in valuables yesterday after gaining access to the Brooklyn home of a Chase Manhattan Bank executive posing as representatives of his childrens school.

title: Toy Poodle is Chosen Monmouth Show's Best
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., May 24 The smallest dog in the final of the prestigious Monmouth County Kennel Club fixture today scored the biggest victory of her career. A 9inch toy poodle, Ch. Peeples Sahara, was named best in a field of 1,840 at Wolf Hill Farm, the Monmouth Park Race Track annex.

title: In Memoriam
description: SECKERGladys. Dear, we miss you so very much. Rosale and Helen.

title: Indy Facts and Figures
description: Event200 laps around the 21/2mile track sanctioned by the United States Auto Club but open to NASCAR S.C.C.A. Grand Prix and other drivers through international (F.I.A.) listing; does not count in world driver standing because of car engines up 4.2 litres against Formula One limit of three litres.

title: Emma Benson returns home
description: Pleasant books so often lie that I read them with the same suspicion I have for happy newsmen, cheery psychiatrists and other sure fixers of the simple mind. Diane, Vreuls's first novel, Are We There Yet? is a pleasant book, the engaging story of a woman's journey from city, life to country home, but it doesn't lie. It forgetsforgets the pain it admits and considers  but without dissolving trouble in a warm solution of good feeling. Nicely controlled and cleverly voiced, this novel is for readers who, dues paid by reading Kosinski and Oates, remain unembarrassed by the thought of a charming book.

title: A Stronger New York
description: Out of the trauma of the present, New York City can emerge stronger than ever before; but it is not likely to do so unless its own government is made more responsive, more effective and more responsible. This implies cautious steps toward decentralization, as recommended by the Charter Revision Committee in proposals to be voted on this fall. it also implies at the same time strong steps toward regionalism, the most expansive development and use of intercounty and even interstate authorities for the more efficient handling of functions that transcend the innumerable artificial political boundarics of the city and surrounding communities.

title: Food
description: There are probably more recipes for Hungarian goulash throughout the world than there are for sauerkraut, coq au yin and bouillabaissenot to mention baked beansput together. Actually, both a soup and a meat stew go by the name goulash. George Lang explains in his immensely edifying book, The Cuisine of Hungary (Atheneum, 1971). that originally gulyas was a shepherd's dish made with meat cooked with onions until all the liquid disappeared. The dish was then put in a bag made of sheep's stomach and placed in the sun to dry When the shepherds got hungry, they simply added a little water to make a meat stew (gulyashus), a lot of water to make a soup (gulyasleves). On this page are our versions of these dishes.

title: Environmental Proposal Would Give Suffolk Agency Unprecedented Powers
description: HAUPPAUGEA new proposal in Suffolk would give unprecedented powers to the county's Department of Environmental Control, which would be allowed not only to enforce regulations but also to formulate them.

title: Correction
description: The photograph of Adrienne Rich on Page 5 of the issue of April 27, should have been credited to Thomas Victor.

title: Ulster Officer Killed in Blast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 24 (AP) A police officer was killed today when he investigated a boobytrapped car, and a policeman said the death appeared to be a deliberate terrorist assassination.

title: Miss New Jersey Quits As a Secretary to Byrne
description: TRENTON, May 24 (UPI) Suzanne Plummer, Miss New Jersey 1973, has terminated her job in the office of Governor Byrne.

title: Venezuela's Oil TakeOver Puts Jobs of Foreigners in Jeopardy
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 24 (AP)More than 700 foreign oil engineers, technicians and executives, most of them Americans, face an uncertain future as the time draws closer for the nationalization of Venezuela's huge oil industry.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Sometime in the fairly near future, a movie buff will take from his shelf a flat disk, twin to a phonograph record in size, on which the label reads: Jean Renoir: The Rules of the Game,' He will put the disk on a player connected by a wire to his television set, just as a phonograph player is connected to a radio or stereo set. As the new disk spins on the turntable, Renoir's beautiful film will appear on the screen of the TV set, the image sharp and clear. The viewer will be able to stop and start the film at will, replaying any part of it for study or simply lot enjoyment.

title: Schedule of Meetings By Council This Week
description: The following public hearings by City Council committees will be held this week:

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ITHACA, N. Y., May 24The Madiera Cup regatta came down to the last stroke today as Cornell's varsity heavyweight crew eked out a twofoot victory over Penn, ending the Quakers 10year hold on the trophy. Cornell covered the 2,000meter Ithaca Flood Control Inlet course in 6 minutes 26.8 seconds, onetenth of a second better than Penn.

title: Stoneflight
description: A lone stone griffin crouches on a pedestal atop 658 West 116th Street. Downstairs in the Harris's apartment Janetta Harris is alone too. Summer in the city is difficult when your friends are away and your parents don't seem to like each other anymore. Janie's mother and father are too busy to help her fill her days. And the sculpture class she had set her heart upon is for older children. So one day she wanders upstairs to pass the time with Gruff. in him she finds a friend she couldn't lose.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: An accretion of evidence has prompted new speculation about asyet unanswered questions in the earth sciences: What caused the ice ages? And is a new one due?

title: New Business Watchdog Needed
description: Extremely grave questions are being raised about the moral standards or ethical behavior of the business world today. As a result of Watergate and other recent incidents in our society, a certain number of our institutions have come under scrutiny, if not under attack, far more than ever before. And this kind of public concern has created a skeptical and sometimes hostile atmosphere in which the business community must do its work.

title: Meriane Reifers is Wed to Student
description: In St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan, Conn., at noon yesterday, Meriane Reifers, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Richard Francis Reifers of New Canaan, became the bride of William Lorne Palmason, son of Mr and Mrs. Lome V. Palmason of Summit, N.J., and Wolfbero, N.H.

title: Pratt to Give City Groups Architectural Assistance
description: An architectural service whose clients will be neighborhood organizations will open next week on the Brooklyn campus of Pratt Institute.

title: R. H. Ackerman to Wed Irene Rosenstein
description: Mr and Mrs. Nathan Rosenstein of Brooklyn and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Irene Rosenstein, to Richard Harris Ackerman, son of Mr and Mrs. Milton J. Ackerman of Kings Point. L.I.

title: FRINGE BENEFITS RAISED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON. May 24Members of the House of Representatives have received up to $12million a year more in allowances and perquisites but they have not got a pay rise.

title: Victors in Saigon Abound in U.S. Goods
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, May 24 (UPI)The Americans are gone, hut what they gave South Vietnam's former Government is still very much here.

title: Miss Rost Is Winner At Devon
Idea of Growing Disparity In World Prices Disputed
description: WASHINGTON, May 24A group of experts from industrial and less developed countries has reported unanimously to the United Nations that a widely held belief about the world economythat in the last 25 years the prices of raw materials exported by poor countries have risen less than the prices of the manufactured goods that they importis not true.

title: Wall Street is Just Wild About Options
description: Scratch an options trader, a broker, or an investoreven, it seems, if he's a loser and you'll find an optimist.

title: Walk Through Old Roslyn
description: ROSLYN  Long before Bicentennial fever whipped up a frenzy of preservation projects in other areas, residents of this historic village knew what they had and set about about preserving it.

title: The Region
description: The New York Legislature last week approved a measure that will allow voters to register by mail, a system that is intended to enhance voter participation in general and is aimed especially at potential voters in underregistered urban slums and poor up. state rural areas.

title: In Laos, the Confusion is Expected to Leave a Blend of Communism and Nationalism in Control
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 24Whatever chances this country had even a month ago to maintain a coalition governmentthe last truly neutral one in Indochinahave vanished in a confusing welter of events that is expected to leave a blend of Communism and nationalism in control.

title: Five Men Arrested And Heroin Seized In Raid in Newark
description: A series of raids by Federal, county and local law enforcement officers in Newark yesterday led to the seizure of 10 pounds of heroin with a street sales value of several million dollars, and the arrest of five men.

title: ART VIEW
description: By now it is news to nobody that as of next Tuesday the Lehman Collection will be on view at The Metropolitan Museum of Art. After Robert Lehman died in 1969, it was joyously revealedand here I quote from the museum's official biographer, Calvin Tomkinsthat the 3,000 works of art in the Lehman collection would come to rest at the Metropolitan, in a separate wing of their own, suitably identified, and forever inviolate from contamination by alien objects. No time was lost; other major constructions in New York City might grind to a halt, but the Lehman pavilion was whipped up with no delay at all. And it has been suggestedso far without contradictionthat the Lehman collection as thus reconstituted and set out is one of the best things that has happened to the world since Noah got the animals to step into the ark.

title: 2 CHILDREN'S DEATHS TIED TO PACEMAKERS
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) Physicians axe being advised to monitor closely adult and child patients wearing heart pacemakes equipment recently associated with the deaths of two children, the Food and Drug Administration says.

title: A Confidante of Johnson Sued by Book Publisher
description: Doris H. Kearns, Richard N. Goodwin, the Sterling Lord literary agency and Simon & Schuster have been sued by Basic Books for breach of Dr. Kearns's contract for publication of a book on President Johnson.

title: SHARE OF ARAB OIL IN U.S. IMPORTS UP
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 Arab countries increased their share of United States oil imports in the first three months of 1975, newly compiled Government figures showed today.

title: Mr. Kissinger is Regarded as the Key to Foreign Policy
description: PARISThere is no inclination among responsible Europeans to slight President Ford, whose rectitude and good intentions are not questioned, but his coming visit is not stirring passionate interest.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The Lehman Wing of The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which opens to the public this week after a stormy fiveyear course from concept reality including a trip through the courts, is a fait accompli and a tour de force. Fait accompli because construction is now complete, making all of the heated controversy about the Lehman collection's disposition and housing, including pressures for museum decentralization and a lawsuit to prevent expansion in the park, almostbut not quiteacademic. Tour de force, because it carries out a highly questionable program with consummate ingenuity, artistry and skill.

title: Polish Ship, Seized by U.S., Freed in Court Settlement
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 (AP)The Polish fishing trawler Kalmar, detained here a week after she was seized for allegedly violating United States waters, was back at sea today following an agreement to pay a $350,000 settlement to avoid confiscation.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayStratford Stables, King Street and Lincoln Avenue, Port Chester, N. Y. Regular and junior working hunters, open jumpers, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Rich and Poor Join to Help Each Other
description: GREAT NECXA partnership forged by the two major social agencies serving the nine villages on this peninsula is bridging the extremes of wealth and poverty found here in an effort to provide comprehensive community services.

title: How South Vietnam died by the stab in the front
description: At 8 o'clock on the morning of Saturday, March 15, Tran Van Anh, a shrewd, wiry man of 45 who managed a small icemaking factory in Pleiku, climbed into his old Dodge truck, which he had bought cheaply from the departing American troops in 1973, and drove to work. He did not notice anything out of the ordinary. Groups of offduty South Vietnamese soldiers wandered aimlessly in the potholed streets of the drab, dusty town that served as headquarters for the 20,000 square miles of South Vietnam's Central Highlands. Packs of lean, yellow dogs rooted in piles of uncollected garbage. By the door of the Dong Khanh Hotel, where American G.I.'s on leave had once stayed, the owner, a slight man with a wispy white beard, sat on a chair, as he did every morning, nodding to passersby.

title: LEGISLATIVE SNAG TROUBLING JAPAN
description: TOKYO, May 24The Japanese legislature today extended its current session for 40 days at the insistence of the ruling Liberal Democratic party because little has been accomplished in the four months it has been sitting.

title: Fashion
description: Out of the pits

title: PHYSICIAN STRIKE MAY BE WIDENED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 24As the doctor's strike entered its fourth week here, the California Medical Association threatened yesterday to encourage its 26,000 members to join in the work stoppage if the Legislature does not enact new malpractice relief reform by the end of ??? week.

title: Ballet: Bolshoi Ends Exciting Season
description: Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet ended its fourth visit to New York, and its first for nine years, at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with a performance of Yuri Grigorovich's Ivan the Terrible, with Yuri Vladimirov, Natalya Bessmertnova and Boris Akimov. As comparatively few of the company's principals are featured in Ivan the Terrible, at the end of the performance the rest of the entire company came on stage in mufti, to wave farewell and acknowledge the reception.

title: Vann Wins Marathon
description: ARKADELPHIA, Ark.. May 24 (AP)Roger Vann of John Brown University won the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics 26mile marathon today with a time of 2 hours 29 minutes 14 seconds. The defending champion. Lucian Rosa finished fourth. Vann won by 400 yards from Barrey Hence of College of St. Francis. Ill.

title: AROUND THEx0020;Garden
description: JOAN LEE FAUST

title: Student is Slain by Police At Post in Bilbao Area
description: BILBAO, Spain. May 24 (AP) A Civil Guardsman shot and killed an 18yearold student early today, informed police sources said.

title: Minish Urges Boldness to Protect Fishing Fleets
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Joseph G. Minish says that he wants the United States to take unilateral action on the control of offshore fishing.

title: JACOB LEICHTMAN, BANKER, 79, DEAD
description: Jacob Leichtman, president of the $500million Commercial Bank of North America until his retirement six years ago when it became the National Bank of North America, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 7 West 81st Street.

title: Quirk in U.S. Law Lets School Employes Get Summer Jobless Benefits
description: TRENTONBecause of a loophole in a Federal law, thousands of teachers and other employes of public and private schools in the state are eligible to collect unemployment benefits while on vacation this summer.

title: JUSTICE SYSTEM SCORED BY PANEL
description: An extensive revision of the city's criminaljustice system was prescribed yesterday by the State Charter Revision Commission, which found the system plagued by a lack of comprehensive planning, misplaced priorities, ineffective use of personnel and other resources.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: I.L.O. Finds That Pay Of Women Still Lags
description: GENEVA, May 24 (Reuters) Women are still discriminated against in wages despite energetic measures to promote equality, according to a report by the International Labor Organization.

title: Dancers Charm Adds Dimension To Promenades
description: John Clifford and a small group of dancers from the Los Angeles Ballet were guests of the New York Philharmonic for the Promenades concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night. The program, devised by the conductor, Andre Kostelanetz, was entitled Music for Dance and Drama, and Mr. Clifford had worked up a set of dances to go with a group of Vincent Youmans songs, including Great Day, Without a Song and Tea for Two.

title: DR. JOHN F. WHITE
description: Dr. John F. White, a general practitioner here for more than 60 years, died Friday at St. Patrick's Home in the Bronx. He was 97 years old and lived at 367 West 46th Street.

title: Joan Woodside, Gen. Emerson Plan Marriage
description: William Sheppard Woodside, an investment counselor of Chicago, has announced the engagement of his sister, Joan Woodside, to Maj. Gen. Henry Everett Emerson, U.S.A. He is the son of Mrs. Gouverneur Vincent Emerson, of Milford, Pa., and the late Brig. Gen. Emerson, Medical Corps, U.S.A.

title: B. S. Lemkin Weds Mary F. DeVylder
description: Mary Frances DeVylder, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Arthur F. DeVylder of Cheshire, Conn., and Lieut. Bruce Stuart Lemkin, U.S.N., were married yesterday at noon.

title: Geoffrey HolderThe Whiz Who Rescued The Wiz
description: Weaving gracefully on his extravagant legshe is 6 feet 6 hitches tallGeoffrey Holder seemed to be dancing to a secret inner rhythm as he led the way into his Upper West Fide apartment. He was a dramatic figure in white slacks and apricot shirt, with a hunk of freeform turquoise dangling from a leather thong around his neck and his wrists accented with gold and silver bangles. Darling, he confided, I'm not one of your bluedenim types.

title: PennsylvaniatoMaryland Railroad Gives Way to Bicycle and Hiking Trail
description: OHIOPYLE, Pa., May 21The wild Youghiogheny River plunged down the steep gorge that it has cut through the emerald ridges of the Laurel Highlands here in southwestern Pennsylvania, flinging great rushes of pure, graygreen water against boulder after boulder, exploding in one whitewater crescendo after another.

title: SOVIET ACADEMY: A POLITICAL ROLE
description: MOSCOW, May 24  The 250th anniversary commemoration of the Academy of Sciences, now scheduled for October, is being built up as an event of ideological as well as scientific significance.

title: A Classic Case History in Fish
description: The reputation of the economics profession may be going down the drain, but in the fish industry, at least, the 1974 results should warm Adam Smith's heart.

title: Booksellers Meet Here For 75th Anniversary
description: The American Booksellers Association will begin a four day celebration of its 75th anniversary today at the Americana knd Hilton Hotels with what its officials say will be the largest gathering of booksellers and book people in its history.

title: T. S. Orlin Marries Alison Cushing Dye
description: Alison Cushing Dye and Theodore S. Orlin, both of New York, were married yesterday evening at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue here by Rabbi James Perman of the Free Synagogue of Westchester.

title: 4.2 MILLION YOUTHS JOINING JOB SEARCH
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) With jobs already at a premium, the Labor Department estimated today that 4.2 million youths will enter the labor force this summer.

title: House Geodesic
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP, N. J.A young woman with platinum blond hair, her husband and their two children stopped on Province Line Road here just off the Princeton Pike, where two igloolike structures that will soon be a geodesicdome house were under construction.

title: Copy of 76 Declaration Set for London Auction
description: LONDON, May 24One of the 17 recorded copies of the first printing of the Declaration of Independence, printed by John Dunlap in Philadelphia in 1776, will be put up for sale by Christies, the London auctioneers, on July 2.

title: Chicago Cartoonist Beaten Outside Daley Party
description: CHICAGO, May 24 (UPI)Bill Mauldin, editorial cartoonist for The Chicago SunTimes, had his nose broken yesterday when he tried to photograph some 20 cars illegally double parked near a building where party for the son of Chicago's Mayor, Richard J. Dailey, was in progress.

title: Seton Hall's Trackmen Win I.C.4A
Surtees May Bow Out of Racing With Belgian Grand Prix Today
description: ZOLDER, Belgium, May 24 The trouble with grand prix auto racing, say the poor of the circuit, is that the sport is not very competitive. The same teams, race after race, make it to the finish line first. Team Surtees has not been one of them.

title: PanAmerican Games Trials Scheduled for Next Weekend
description: The Essex Horse trials, one of the events that will help determine the makeup of the United States Equestrian Team's threeday squad for the PanAmerican Games, are scheduled for next Saturday and Sunday. The event will be held at Hoopstick Farm in Far Hills, N. J., and according to Jack LeGoff, coach of the U.S.E.T.'s threeday riders, the course will be of international design.

title: J. ARTHUR LEVE
description: J. Arthur Leve, who been partner of the law firms of Coudert Brothers, and Chadbourne, Stanchfield & Levy, died Thursday at the Harkness Pavilion. He was 86 years old and lived at 970 Park Avenue.

title: Philip Roth accounts for his life as a man and a writer
