description: Either the American approach to breeder reactor design is excessively cautious or the Soviet approach does not provide for adequate safety and reliability features, according to an American power engineer who recently toured the Soviet breeder plants.

title: Books of The Times
description: All over the Western world, there are thousands, perhaps hundreds of thousands, of women who have become disconnected from the mainstream of life. Some of them are divorced, others never even got that far. They are outside of things as a result of circumstances they themselves may not be able to describe. Their lives are private digressions, parentheses in the human comedy. Like outoftune keys on a piano, they give off a distressed sound. Like some of the more experimental composers, Beryl Bainbridge creates an odd sort of music out of such wrong notes. She is the champion of a group of women so dislocated that no one has even labeled them yet. In her last novel, The Secret Glass, the heroine's attempts to get back into life were so pathetic that she attained a kind of lugubrious poetry, what you might call the poetry of minimal expectations.

title: LAWYER IS UPHELD IN SUBPOENA FIGHT
description: A subpoena to compel a lawyer to disclose his client's address has been quashed by a Federal judge who called it an abuse of the grandjury process.

title: N.H.L. Championship
description: May 15Phila. 4, Buffalo 1.

title: Buffalo and Yonkers Join Drive for More State Aid
description: Anxious bids for increased state aid are being pressed by Buffalo, the state's second largest city, which fears the layoff of nearly 1,800 municipal employes, and Yonkers, the fourth largest city, with a looming gap of $30million in a projected $142million budget.

title: A Lifetime in Driver's Seat
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 25When Bobby Unser first won the Indianapolis 500 in 1968, the man who finished second was Dan Gurney. The onetime rivals combined their talents to win to day's rainshortened Indy 500 and after it was over, Gurney cracked, I've never forgiven Bobby for winning in '68, but this will go a long way toward making up for it.

title: Flyers Triumph for 32 Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 25The sign read: He who lives by the Sabre dies by the Hammer.

title: The Diva Stepped Up to the Plate and Belted a High C Into the Tiers
description: WASHINGTONThere was no major league baseball team where I grew up, in Newark, N. J.

title: Sealyham Judged Best In Plainfield K.C. Show
description: METUCHEN, N.J., May 24 A Sealyham terrier, who has been sweeping aside all opposition for the last five weeks, won her 20th top award today. She was Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl, owned by Mrs. Dorothy Wimer of Churchtown, Pa., and handled by Peter Green, and she triumphed in the 33d Plainfield Kennel Club's show, which drew 2,122 dogs to the grounds of St. Joseph's High School.

title: C.I.A. Role in Europe Is Issue In Britain's Vote on Market
description: LONDON, May 25Financial support reportedly provided years ago by the United States Central Intelligence Agency to European groups has emerged as an issue in the present campaign here over British membership in the Common Market.

title: KUWAITIS WEIGH INVESTING IN U.S.
description: KUWAIT  Government financial managers of Kuwait's oil wealth view with favor now a big move toward direct investment in United States corporations that are seeking capital.

title: FRANCIS W. ROUDEBUSH.
description: Francis W. Roudebush, a retired New York architect, died Friday at a reset home in Salisbury, Conn. He was 76 years old and lived in Salisbury and. Greensboro, Vt.

description: Herbert S. Herlands a California Superior Court judge for the last 16 years, died Saturday at Santa Ana, Calif. He was 57 years old.

title: San Francisco Redevelopment Project Is Called Dead
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 25The Yerba Buena Center, a redevelopment project in a once seedy area on the edge of downtown San Francisco, has apparently failed, representing a major defeat for business interests and their political allies and a victory for antidevelopment forces.

title: Orders Down 69% For Machine Tools In First 4 Months
description: The machine tool industry continued to work off its inventories during April as new orders for the first four months trailed the yearearlier level by 69.1 per cent.

title: Seton Hall Wins Regional
description: STAMFORD, Conn., May 25  Dan Morgiello limited Maine to three hits during a sixinning relief stint today to pitch Seton Hall to an 117 victory over Maine in the title game of the National Colegiate Athletic Association University Division Northeast regionals at Cuebta Stadium. The victory, their 14th in a row, qualified the Pirates for the national tournament, which gets under way at Omaha on June 6.

title: Homosexual Is Fighting Military Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 Lenny Matlovich joined the Air Force in May, 1963, when he was 19 years old. He wanted to make a career of it, as his father had, and he wanted to go to Vietnam.

title: GOVERNOR IN LEAD IN KENTUCKY RACE
description: LOUISVILLE Ky.  Kentucky politics, famous for its feuding factionalism, looks something like a onehorse derby this year the closest thing to a walk over that old political railbirds can remember In a Governor's race here.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PAGING PUBLIC The famous old Custom House, dark for the last 16 years, will reopen today to house the second New York Book Fair, running for three days in the historic building at the foot of Broadway and Bowling Green. The occasion is expected to draw a large crowd of bibliophiles, browsers and buyers, as happened last year uptown, with the display from more than 350 small, independent publishers and a free program of special events, including a poetry festival and children's activities.

description: CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico, May 21  A 10yearold international partnership by which United States manufacturers have tapped the cheap labor of Mexico is turning sour under the forces of inflation and recession, and is causing deepening bitterness along the 2,000milelong MexicanAmerican border.

title: LEBANESE CABINET OF MILITARY MEN IS NEAR COLLAPSE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 25Lebanon's military cabinet was near collapse today in the face of solid opposition from, the leadership of the Moslem half of the nation and from parliamentary forces.

description: I had no special ambitions to be a ballerina. Fate happened to make me one, Gallna Ulanova said the other day.

title: Gita Karasik Is the Bride of Lee Caplin
description: Gita Karasik, a concert pianist, and Lee Evan Caplin were married yesterday noon in Washington at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mortimer Caplin, former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and Mrs. Caplin.

Bobby Unser Wins 500 Again; Foyt 3d in RainCurtailed Race
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 25In a motor race that has a history of bizarre finishes, Bobby Unser won the Indianapolis 500 today as a sudden cloudburst cut it off at 435 miles, after 174 of the scheduled 200 laps.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Under a new state policy, New York Telephone Company customers will generally be told when an investigator wants a record of their toll calls, so that they can move to block release of the record if they so desire. The State Public Service Commission ordered that notice be given to customers at least 72 hours before release of records unless the investigatorsuch as the Federal Bureau of Investigation or some legislative unithad obtained a court order to prohibit the disclosure of the request for records.

title: Sharon Shulman Bride Of Arthur Beckerman
description: Sharon Andrea Shulman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Shulman of Brooklyn, was married at the Plaza last evening to Arthur Michael Beckerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Beckerman of Danbury, Conn. Rabbi Jerome Malino performed the ceremony in the Baroque Suite.

description: BATTING

title: Vietnamese Gold Drains Laos Wealth
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 24In the last 10 days before the fall of Saigon, it is estimated, nearly a quarter of the wealth of Laos left the country to buy p, old from the fleeing South Vietnamese.

title: U.S. Strike Force Aide Refuses Tapes To Prosecutors in Garment Area Inquiry
description: The chief of the Federal Joint Strike Force Against Organized Crime in New York has denied the requests of four local prosecutors for access to information and tapes gathered In an undercover investigation of the city's garment district.

title: Harry Albert, Lawyer, 75, Helped Build N.Y.U. Center
description: Harry Albert, a lawyer who was instrumental in raising funds to build the New York University Law Center, died yesterday at the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 75 years old and lived at 1 St. Paul's Court, Brooklyn, and had his office at 225 Broadway.

title: Jane Austen's Fans Hail a Bicentennial
description: When she was alive her books were regarded as mere curiosities, and not one of them ever bore her name. Today no detail of her worknot even the gender of one of her fictional dogsescapes loving scrutiny.

title: For Joshua Logan, Flower Arranging Is Therapy
description: The carnations reach up toward the ceiling, their pink blossoms swaying delicately above branches of quince and small clusters of statice. The man who fashioned the arrangement smiles with delight as his fingers touch the long green stems, seemingly balanced in thin air.

title: Female Crew Enters Raft Race
description: SMITHFIELD BEACH, Pa., May 25For the first time, a raft with an allwomen crew took part today in the annual Delaware River raft race. Their raft finished the race 26th in the field of 80.

title: SelfDestruct Bribes
description: At least ten giant American corporations have now admitted, or been charged with, paying bribes or making political contributionssome of them illegalin return for contracts or other favors awarded by officials of host countries.

title: Israelis Battle in Lebanon With Artillery and Jets
description: TEL. AVIV. May 25Israeli and Lebanese forces battled for about 12 hours today in southern Lebanon after what an Israeli military spokesman described as an accidental and unintentional encounter between Lebanese soldiers and an Israeli patrol.

title: Bilingual Education Here
description: On Aug. 29, 1974 a Manhattan Federal court, in the case Aspira of New York v. Board of Education, ordered, with the consent of the litigants, bilingual education for all Hispanic students unable to effectively participate in the learning process by reason of their Englishlanguage difficulties and who could more effectively participate in Spanish. Aspira is a Puerto Rican educational selfhelp organization.

title: Bridge:
description: The Lancia touring team of European stars bounced back after defeat in New York and Los Angeles by building up a decisive lead in Chicago Saturday. Going into the second day's play yesterday, with 30 deals remaining, they led by 47 international match points.

title: Franco Attends Parade Marking 1939 Victory
description: MADRID, May 25 (AP)Generalissimo Francisco Franco reviewed Spain's military and police forces today to mark the 36th anniversary of his victory in the Civil War.

title: 20th Century Bursts on Sinai's Bedouins
description: ST. CATHARINE'S. Israelioccupied Sinai, May 18 Khader Achmed Salim is a Bedouin success story.

title: Carolinian Appeals Fine for Covering Car Plate Slogan
description: RALEIGH, N.C., May 25 (AP) A Raleigh man has been convicted for putting tape over the First in Freedom slogan on his 1975 North Carolina auto license plate, despite the state Attorney General's advice to drop such cases.

title: RABAT CITES CLAIM TO SPANISH SAHARA
description: RABAT, Morocco, May 26 (Reuters)Morocco announced today that she intended to take over responsibility for the Spanish Sahara, the desert colony rich in minerals that is to be granted independence by Spain.

title: Vandals Smash Windows, Set a Fire in High School
description: Vandals broke into the Samuel J. Tilden High School at Tilden Avenue and East 57th Street yesterday morning, smashed door windows in more than 20 classrooms and set a small fire that destroyed some attendance records, school officials said.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Bridge
description: The Lancia touring team, which consists largely of the Italian stars who have dominated world championship play for two decades, won its first match in Chicago Sunday night and then headed for Miami Beach for more play today and tomorrow.

title: Refugees' Family Life Strained by Weeks of Waiting
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 26A stillness descends on Camp 1 shortly after sunset, a time for the Vietnamese refugees to draw inside the Quonset huts and canvas field tents that have sheltered many of them for nearly a month now.

title: CAMBODIA REPORTED AT WORK ON MEKONG
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 26 (Reuters)Cambodia is trying to clear the lower Mekong River, one of her main supply routes, of about 100 merchant ships sunk during this year's Communist offensive, the Phnom Penh radio said today.

title: LIVANOS APARTMENT ROBBED OF $50,000
description: The Fifth Avenue apartment of George Livanos, the Greek shipowner, was broken into over the Memorial Day weekend, and jewelry worth $50,000 to $100,000, and $1,000 in cash, were reported stolen, the police said last night.

title: Slump's Impact at Retail: Varied

description: OTTAWA, May 26The Secretary of State for External Affairs, Allan J. MacEachen, issued a lengthy statement today, defending the controversial, manner in which the Canadian Embassy staff departed from Saigon, leaving Vietnamese employes behind, just before the city fell to the Communists.

title: Common Market to Help Lisbon, But Ties Aid to Democratic Rule
description: DUBLIN, May 26The foreign ministers of the nine European Common Market countries agreed in Dublin today to intensify their trade and aid relations with Portugal as long as such a step seemed helpful in maintaining democracy in that politically troubled country, high Market officials said.

title: JEWISH CONGRESS TO SUE ON BOYCOTT
description: The American Jewish Congress plans to file a suit next month in Federal Court here against the Department of Commerce to force disclosure, under the Freedom of Information Act, of the names of American companies complying with the Arab boycott against Israel.

description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 26A stillness descends an Camp 1 shortly after sunset, a time for the Vietnamese refugees to draw inside the Quonset huts and canvas field tents that have sheltered many of them far nearly a month now.

title: Ford Will Announce Energy Plan Tonight
description: WASHINGTON, May 26President Ford will go on national television tomorrow night and is expected to announce new executive actions to reduce the nation's dependence on foreign supplies of oil.

title: War on Cancer Stirs A Political Backlash
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Three and half years ago, Congress and President Nixon declared war on cancer. Today some see a backlash emerging, based more on the political than the scientific aspects of the effort.

title: Books of The Times
description: One can imagine Tom Wolfe doing his number on Albert Einstein. The slightly absentminded appearance of the young physicist in Bern. (Doubtless Mr. Wolfe would come up with an absurdly minute catalogue to identify the style and sources of the rumpled clothes.) The thinker in his study, staring off into the middle distance and jotting down strange hieroglyphics on scrap paper. (Doubtless Mr. Wolfe would come up with the precise term of endearment with which Mileva Maric called her husband away from his thoughts to dinner.) And doubtless it would be terrific fun. Except that Mr. Wolfe would never get away with it or even try it in the first place, because Eimstein's thoughts and jottings had verifiable consequences. And the awesomeness of those consequences has cast into insignificance the various mannerisms and idiosyncrasies that Einstein manifested as he worked.

title: TANZANIANS BAR CAPTORS' TERMS
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 26 (Reuters)  The Tanzanian Government today rejected the terms a group of Zaire dissidents set for the release of three kidnapped studentstwo Americans and a Dutch nationala presidential spokesman said.

title: Coast Trial in Ambush Slaying Of Black Educator Nearing End
description: SACRAMENTO. Calif.. May 26 (UPI)Two reputed members of the terrorist group that kidnapped Patricia Hearst are nearing the end of their trial for the ambush slaying in 1973 of Marcus Foster school superintendent of Oakland.

description: NEW ORLEANS, May 26 (AP)Coach Bill van Breda Kolff wants the New Orleans Jazz to pay for his first 20 technical fouls next National Basketball Association season, and that's just one of the contract hangups that may make the fiery coach miss Thursday's college draft.

description: PHOENIX. Ariz., May 26Arizona's Governor has expressed reservations about the offer by John Wayne, the actor, to help Vietnamese refugees obtain 17,000 acres of land in the state.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 26The United States is expected to propose new ideas this week to its industrial allies on how to resume negotiations with oil producers on price and supply in an international conference.

description: There may be a building slump, but things are good for the Ruckus Construction Company. It has just undertaken its most ambitious projecterecting Manhattan all over again, from South Ferry right up to the Cloisters.

title: One in Every Crowd
description: WASHINGTONFifteen years ago, Adlai Stevenson speculated wryly that the Democratic Presidential nomination might well go to the last survivor. That year there were eighteen primaries; as we move toward 1976, we are at thirty and still counting.

ADVERSARY ROLE HIT BY FORD CHIEF
description: DEARBORN. Mich.. May 26 (AP)The president of the Ford Motor Company says that if the Government will end its adversary relationship with the auto industry, American car makers can save consumers $100 on every new car.

title: Israel U.N. Delegate Calls on Jews Here To Stay Steadfast
description: Yosef Tekoah, head of Israel's delegation to the United Nations, called on American Jewish communities for an unremitting display of Jewish strength on the side of Israel even though his country might have to adopt positions which do not find favor with others.

title: Carey Asks Doctors to Give Malpractice Law a Chance
description: Governor Carey urged doctors yesterday not to strike over the states new malpractice law but instead to wait and see how it operates after it takes effect July 1.

title: Paris: Trenet Distills Elan of the Chanson
description: PARISThe farewell appearances of popular singers usually last longer than a ballerina's entire career. In the case of the 62yearold Charles Trenet, who has announced his retirement after the beginning of a current oneman show at L'Olympia that is slated to take him around the world until 1976, no one would think of complaining. For the Singing Madman, as he was nicknamed at the start of his career, has been the most creative force in the French chanson since the nineteenthirties.

title: Royals Topple Yanks in 11 th
description: KANSAS CITY, May 26Frank White dropped a perfect squeeze bunt in the 11th inning to score Jim Wohlford and give the Kansas City Royals a 65 comeback victory over the New York Yankees before a paid Memorial Day crowd of 13,156.

title: CHINATOWN GETS NEW POLICE HEAD
description: The police captain who was relieved of command of the Chinatown precinct after two major demonstrations at City Hall over alleged police brutality was reassigned yesterday as commander of the 20th Precinct on the Upper West Side, replacing a deputy inspector.

title: Gregg, Holbert Cars Triumph
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., May 26From the front lawn of the Trinity Episcopal Church on Main Street in tiny Lime Rock, you can see the doubleS turn on the Lime Rock Park race track. You can hear the noise three miles away on the treeshaded streets of peaceful Salisbury.

title: Warriors' Triumph Indicates Better Balance Among N.B.A. Teams
description: The indiscriminate applicatirm of the word dynasty to any team that wins any championship with fairly young personnel became fashionable some sears ago, but in the National Basketball Association the dynasties have been getting shorter and shorter.

title: Church in Basking Ridge Starts WeekLong Festival
description: BASKING RIDGE, May 26The allgirl Highlanders band from nearby Berkeley Heights played Glen Caladh Castle and Scotland the Brave here today as St. James Roman Catholic Church opened its week long Festival on the Ridee for the second year.

title: Beastly Manhattan
description: After moving to Manhattan I bought a camel. I did not want a camel, but in Manhattan it was absolutely vital to own an animal of some sort, and of all the animal kingdom a camel seemed to me the most sensible sort to own.

title: Gottfried, Solomon Advance
description: ROME, May 26 (UPI)Americans preserved their seedings on a lackluster opening day at the $120,000 Italian international tennis championships today, with Harold Solomon and Brian Gottfried winning their matches. The tournament is one of the world's major claycourt events.

description: PAETElKarl O. Author, foreign correspondent, died on May 4, 1975 after a long illness. A memorial gathering will take place on Thursday, May 29, at 5:30 P.M. at the Goethe House, 1014 Fifth Avenue, New York City, between 82nd and 83rd Street, facing the Metropolitan. Museum Deutschsprachiges Forum (German Speaking Forum for Culture and Politics).

title: Parades Honor War Dead, but Spectators Seem Fewer
description: The jubilant sound of march music and the doleful sound of taps rang out through the metropolitan area yesterday as those who had survived war and those who had never been touched by it joined to celebrate Memorial Day and commemorate the nation's dead.

description: CHICAGO, May 26 (UPI)The Chicago SunTimes today offered a $2,500reward for information leading to the arrest of a man who assaulted Bill Mauldin, a Pulitzer prizewinning cartoonist.

title: Refurbishing of Park At 45th St. Is Snagged
description: The old narrow playground that runs from West 45th Street to West 46th Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues is a sorry little poor Man's haven, With bathrooms that do not work and benches that smell strongly of wine.

description: Three Republican State Seriators from New York City yesterday opposed an expected attempt by Mayor Beame today to postpone for a fourth time the submission of the proposed city budget and renewed their call for extensive spending cuts.

title: Singh, $4, Scores in Jersey Derby
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 26Blocked in the Preakness a week ago, favored Singh found all the racing room he needed today in the $135,600 Jersey Derby at strikethreatened Garden State Park.

title: Barbara Koller Is Bride of John Huston
description: Barbara Lee Koller and John Marthew Huston, who received M.B.A. degrees this month from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, were married last evening in Milburn, N.J.

title: Rumors of Threats Cancel Sinatra Concert in Berlin
description: Frank Sinatra canceled his concert in Berlin yesterday because of attacks in the local press and rumors that he could be in danger there, his American mess agent said Sunday.

title: A Quake in Atlantic Is Felt in Portugal, Spain and Islands
description: LISBON, May 26 (AP)A powerful earthquake was reported today in the Atlantic between Portugal and the Azores.

title: Saving the U.N.
description: The selfdestructive trend of voting futile, propagandistic resolutions in the United Nations General Assembly could be arrested by the reforms recommended a few days ago by an international study group. The 25member panel has focused on restructuring the U.N.'s economic machinery to improve cooperation between rich and poor nations. But one of its principal proposalsnegohated solutions to disputes by small groups of responsible countries instead of the irresponsible voting of resolutions which cannot be implementedshould be applied to political as well as economic debates in the General Assembly.

title: Saigon Expels U.S. Reporter and French Author
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 26 (UPI)The new Government in Saigon expelled an American and a French journalist today, the first to be expelled since the Communists seized Saigon on April 30.

title: TEXAS LAWYERS FORM CLIENT FUND
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., May 24Texas attorneys have established a consumer protection fund with cash from their own pockets that will pay back clients who are bilked by dishonest lawyers.

title: STELLA MARRS SINGS WITH EASY WARMTH
description: Stella Marr's identification as Ms. Soft Soul may sound like another showbusiness bit. But in this case, it has some viable meaning, at least as Miss Marrs exemplifies it at the Seafood Playhouse, 209 West 48th Street. She has an easy, relaxed attitude toward her listeners and, at a time when singers are leaning toward tight mannerisms and overwrought performances, she is a refreshing return to warm, natural human communication.

title: Judgment of Peers
description: To 375,000 lawyers in the United States, just about the most interesting case in the country today appears on no calendar, is conducted with the greatest secrecy, affects the reputation of one of the best known members of the profession and of the profession itself, and can lead to a historymaking judgment. It is the disbarment proceeding conducted by the Association of the Bar of the City. of New York against Richard M. Nixon, Esq.

title: 2 HOSPITALS FEEL IMPACT OF PROTEST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 26A doctors' strike over malpractice insurance that is in its fourth week here has imposed a growing burden and extraordinary demands on the Bay area's few unaffected hospitats.

title: KALLINGER TRIAL TO START TODAY
description: Joseph Kallinger, a Philadelphia shoerepair man accused in three Eastern states as the man who led a young boy on a spree of sexual abuse and felonies that culminated in a murder in northern New Jersey, faces his first trial today in Harrisburg, Pa., on charges of burglary, armed robbery and kidnapping.

title: Ford Will Announce Energy Plan Tonight
description: WASHINGTON, May 26President Ford will go on national television tomorrow night and is expected to announce new executive actions to reduce the nation's dependence on foreign supplies of oil.

title: Prize to Renaissance Band
description: The New York Renaissance Band, an ensemble that has devoted itself chiefly to the performance of early instrumental music, has been selected as the winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation's 197576 chambermusic award. The group will be presented in a concert at Alice Tully Hall next season and will be given $3,000 to commission a new work from an American composer.

title: Aquarium Urges Razing Of Coney Island Cyclone
description: Two unlikely adversariesthe Coney Island Chamber of Commerce and the New York Aquarium  are involved in a dispute over a city  owned roller coaster that could have wide implications for the future of the Coney Island amusement area.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1975

title: Article 4  No Title
Questioning Parole
description: The lawsuit filed by the New York Civil Liberties Union against the New York State Parole Board is going to force the board to face searching questions about its value to society. In common with most bureaucracies, the board has been rocking along on its own momentum in directions which often bear little resemblance to the idea which sparked its creation.

title: Trial of Kallinger In Burglary Case Is Set for Today
description: Joseph Kallinger, a Philedelphia shoerepair man accused in three Eastern states as the man who led a young boy on a spree of sexual abuse and felonies that culminated in a murder in northern New Jersey, faces his first trial today in Harrisburg, Pa.on charges of burglary, armed robbery and kidnapping.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Mayor Beame has asked the Board of Higher Education to cut $69.7million from its budget for the City University for the coming year, as part of his plan to eliminate an expensebudget deficit estimated at $641million.

title: Portugal Military Shunting Parties Aside
description: LISBON, Tuesday, May 27 (UPI)Portugal's military leadership declared early today that it was bypassing the leaders of political parties and establishing an alliance with the people to guarantee a correct sequence of the revolutionary process.

title: SALT II Progress
description: The litmus test of dtente between the United States and the Soviet Union, apart from the absence of war, is progress in the control of nuclear weapons. No other common interest is greater than that in maintaining the stability of mutual deterrence and slowing the dangerous and expensive upward spiral in the nuclear arms race.

title: Gold and Myrrh First in Metropolitan
description: Gold and Myrrh defeated Formidable opposition, including Forego, in the $111,400 Metropolitan Mile at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4yearold horse, owned and trained by William Wilmot and ridden by Walter Blum, scored a threequarterlength victory over the Greentree Stable's Stop the Music before 47.167 fans.

title: Former Boyfriend Is Held in Murder Of Brooklyn Nurse
description: The former boyfriend of a 29yearold nurse found strangled in her Brooklyn apartment early Sunday morning turned, himself into the police yesterday afternoon and was later charged with murder.

title: Sato Has Pneumonia
description: TOKYO, May 26 (UPI)Former Premier Eisaku Sato, unconscious and in critical condition since last Monday, developed pneumonia today. His doctors expressed concern over his condition.

title: Ford, at Arlington, Declares the U.S. Must Stay Strong
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) President Ford paid homage to the nation's war dead on Memorial Day and warned that Americans would risk their freedom unless they maintained the military might to deal with international lawbreakers.

title: Deutsche Bank Sets Limit
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, May 26 (Reuters(  Deutsche Bank, AG, said the annual meeting had approved its proposal to restrict the voting rights of any one shareholder to 5 per cent of capital. The Board spokesman, Franz Ulrich, said last month the measure was only precautionary as the largest known existing stake is one of 3 per cent held by an insurance group.

title: BIG BOARD LIKES SECURITIES BILL
description: New securities legislation, passed by Congress last week and sent to President Ford for his signature, has been greeted warmly by the New York Stock Exchange. But it may not be so well received by banks, other big financial institutions (such as pension funds and mutual funds)or the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Landmark Buildings Also Win Citations For Their Inferiors
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday singled out the interiors of three Landmark buildings in the city and designated them as Interior Landmarks.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO END IMPASSE IN LAOS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 26 (Reuters)  American officials were negotiating here tonight with students occupying they sprawling compound of the United States aid mission on the issue of wages owed to locally hired employes.

title: Common Market to Help Lisbon, But Ties Aid to Democratic Rule
description: DUBLIN, May 26The foreign ministers of the nine European Common Market countries agreed in Dublin today to intensify their trade and aid relations with Portugal as long as such a step seemed helpful in maintaining democracy in that politically troubled country, high Market officials said

title: VIOLATIONS CHARGED TO 25 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The City Health Department yesterday released the names of 25 foodprocessing establishments charged with having violated the health code.

title: How Large a Gap?
description: As politicians maneuver to try to keep New York from falling into bankruptcy, possibly as early as the end of this week, it is essential that the depth of the city's crisis and the need for drastic fundamental reform be kept clearly in mind. Halfway measures, designed as in the past only to stave off disaster temporarily, will not do.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1975

title: Sadat Asks Europe to Join In Geneva Talks on Mideast
description: VIENNA, May 26 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said in a radio interview broadcast today that he supported a broadening of the Geneva conference on the Middle East to include European representatives.

title: First of 5 Grain Inspectors Going on Trial in Houston on Bribery Charges as Shipping Inquiry Spreads
description: HOUSTON, May 26  The United States Attorney here is preparing to go to trial with the first of five men indicted on bribery charges stemming from a broad investigation into alleged corruption in the handling of grain shipments. The inquiry began in New Orleans and has spread to Houston and other ports.

title: ExAgent Says Hoover Barred Left Turns on Car Trip
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) The F.B.I. agent driving J. Edgar Hoover, the late director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, from Dallas to Austin in 1959 was told to make the 200mile trip without turning left, a retired agent has written in a book about the bureau.

title: Advertising
description: The news last week that the desperate city fathers were proposing a four per cent sales tax on advertisingagency commissions and fees sent chills up the spines of agency managements. There was anger as well.

title: Study Finds Reviews by Court Help Release Foster Children
description: A study undertaken by a New York University professor in cooperation with the city administration has concluded that Family Court reviews of the cases of children in foster care can help to free the children for adoption or return to their homes.

title: More Unease Expected in Bond Market
description: An undercurrent of nervousness began eroding prices of fixedinterest securities last Wednesday despite surface signs of easier conditions in the credit markets. Not only did shortterm money rates fall as much as a quarter point during the week, but also the dearth of business borrowers caused the First National City Bank here to lower its prime rate to 7 per cent from 7 last Friday.

title: A Minor Agency Is Now a World Forum
description: PARIS, May 26  For years the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development was considered just another component of the alphabet soup of international bureaucracies.

title: Rehoboth Beach Votes To Annex Ocean Area
description: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del., May 26Voters here have approved annexation of about 60 square miles of ocean in hopes of having some say in offshore oil drilling.

title: Kennedy Says No to A.B.A.
description: Walter Kennedy, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, has turned down a $1million winnertakeall challenge from the rival American Association to have the league champions meet in a threeoffivegame series.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: MANSFIELD SAYS U.S. MUST DEFEND SEOUL
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (Reuters)The United States would have no choice but to go to the defense of South Korea in the event of an attack by North Korea, Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, said today.

title: Let's Keep Steve Garvey Going
description: By himself, as if the curtain of an invisible voting booth had closed around him, a boy about 12 years old jeans and sneakers sat on the pavement outside Shea Stadium and did what he surely considered to be the most important thing he could do yesterdaymark a ballot with his choice of players for the major league AllStar game. But he had no secrets. First base, he announced loudly, Steve Garvey. Told later about that tableau, Steve Garvey of the Los Angeles Dodgers laughed and said, That kid must be Irish. Not necessarily. But the kid was ironic. Last year Steve Garvey's name wasn't even on the printed AllStar ballot. But he received more than a million writein votes and emerged as the National League's starting first baseman. Although benched by an ear infection the previous weekend, he justified the fans' faith by winning a trophy as the AllStar games' most valuable player. He then led the Dodgers to the National League pennant and, to the angry annoyance of Lou Brock, he was voted the league's most valuable player award.

title: Massachusetts Strike Over
description: READING, Mass., May 26 (AP)Workers were to return to their jobs tomorrow at the General Tire and Rubber Company plant here following ratification of a new threeyear contract by 140 striking union members. Local 971 of the United Rubber Workers Union voted yesterday to end its twoweek strike.

title: JOHN B. DOLAN
description: John B. Dolan, a former newspaper photographer, died Sunday in Dublin, where he had lived for the last six years. He was 63 years old.

title: RABBI SAMUEL BASKIN
description: Rabbi Samuel Baskin died Sunday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 91 years old and and lived at 210 West 101st Street.

title: War on Cancer Stirs A Political Backlash
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Three and half years ago, Congress and President Nixon declared war on cancer. Today some see a backlash emerging, based more on the political than the scientific aspects of the effort.

title: 4 Die in Fire
description: RAVENNA, Ohio, May 26 (AP)A fire that started in the electrical system of a house early today resulted in the deaths of four members of one family, including three children. Asphigxiated were Judy Moore, 23 years old, her two daughters, Candis, 4, and Mandis, 3, and her sisterinlaw, Sandy, 13.

title: Article 1  No Title
Sex and Chemistry Join Fight on Apple Moth
description: GENEVA, N. Y.  Redbanded leafroller moths are flying this month through the apple orchards of upstate New York, their antennas tuned for their main task in life. The male moth, which lives for only about two weeks and does not feed, must sniff out a mate to produce the eggs for the next generation of caterpillars that threaten the state's $50millionayear apple crop.

title: The Holiday in Eastport Celebrated With Variety
description: EASTPORT, L.I., May 26In, this small, rural community on Long Island's South Shore, Memorial Day was a time for LeRoy Privett to polish his rifle for a parade, for Lillian Frey to prepare hot dogs for a party and for Ruth Slade to pray for those who died in combatbut for Libby Pascalucci it was just another day to play tennis.

title: Senegal's President Here After Stops in 3 U.S. Cities
description: President Lopold S. Senghor of Senegal arrived here tonight after visits to Atlanta and New Orleans and a meeting in Washington with President Ford.

title: Afghan Is Best at Queensboro
description: A blue brindle Afghan hound, Ch. Sandina Starstream, owned, bred and handled by Mrs. Glorvina Schwartz of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., was best of 1,392 dogs yesterday on the Riis Park Mall at the 50th show of the Queensboro Kennel Club.

title: Soviet Crew Checks Orbiting Research Station
description: MOSCOW, May 26Two Soviet astronauts checked out systems to continue a research program aboard an orbiting Soyiet space station today, after docking with and boarding the craft in pitch darkness.

title: TALKS ON BASES BEGUN IN MANILA
description: MANILA, May 26President Ferdinand E. Marcos and the United States Ambassador, William H. Sullivan, have held talks, described as strained but productive, over the last month on the terms under which American military bases could remain in the Philippines.

title: Campsites Bracing For Record Season
description: PROMISED LAND, Pa., May 26Camping for the first time this weekend at Lake Taghkanic, N. Y., Linda Dias of Rego Park, Queens, awoke in the middle of the night in terror.

title: Article 3  No Title
Marquess of Donegall, 71, London Columnist, Dead
description: The Marquess of Donegall, a former British war correspondent and London newspaper columnist, died Saturday at his home in Switzerland. His age was 71.

title: SUSPICIOUS AUTO FOUND NEAR JAIL
description: An auto believed to be getaway car was found yesterday morning outside the Brook. lyn House of Detention, when one alleged Black Liberation Army member died and a secand was arrested in an escape attempt Sunday night.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Bolivians Discuss Gulf Gifts In Cynicism and Resentment
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia  It was crowded in Georgissimo's, even for a weekend night.

title: Many Cities in Crisis Cut Payrolls and Raise Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Like New York, many large cities across the nation are in financial trouble, but their troubles are generally much less severe.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: No fish introduced to the fresh waters of the United States has caused as much trouble and controversy as the common carp (Cyprinus carpio). Now a distant cousin of that fish, the white amur, or grass carp (Ctenopharyngodon idellus), is regarded by some persons as a threat to sport fishing throughout the country.

title: Many Cities in Crisis Cut Payrolls and Raise Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, May 26Like New York, many large cities across the nation are in financial trouble, but their troubles are generally much less severe.

title: M.T.A. RIDERSHIP SHOWS A DECLINE
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority reported yesterday a continuing substantial slide in subway and bus ridership in the first quarter of 1975 and a drop in commuter rail patronage after last year's big gains.

title: Plane Pilot Killed in Crash
description: COSTA MESA, Calif., May 26 (UPI)  A Phoenix, Ariz., man piloting a light plane apparently lost his sense of direction in the clouds over this Orange County community today and crashed into a house. The crash killed the pilot, Edward Ketchum and seriously injured Norman Harran, who was standing in the front yard of his home.

title: ISRAEL RESISTING U.S. ON SINAI PACT
description: JERUSALEM, May 26Buoyed by recent demonstrations of Congressional support, Israel has decided to ignore the United States' repeated requests that she produce new negotiating proposals before the AmericanEgyptian meeting in Salzburg next Sunday, according to senior Israeli officials.

title: Camp Heeds Complaint By Refugees on Food
description: ANNVILLE, Pa., May 26 (AP)Vietnam refugees lodged at military camps in the United States have voiced a complaint that American servicemen have been voicing for years: They don't like the way their food is prepared.

title: JAMES C. ZEDER, 75, CHRYSLER ENGINEER
description: James C. Zeder, a leading automotive engineer with the Chrysler Corporation for 35 years, died Sunday at his home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 75 years old.

title: Los Angeles Fluoridation Vote Today
description: LOS ANGELES, May 26This city is preparing to settle in a vote tomorrow a longstanding dispute most other major cities in the nation resolved long agowater fluoridation.

title: 2 Boys, 15, Are Injured By HighTension Rail Wire
description: Two 15yearold boys were injured yesterday afternoon when one of them stepped on a hightension wire in a Long Island Rail Road tunnel near 49th Avenue and 21st Street in Long Island City, Queens.

title: U.S. Gains Time but Lacks Optimism on Middle East Accord
description: WASHINGTON, May 26President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger have unexpectedly won additional timeprobably at least until the end of this year  for their effort to achieve a diplomatic breakthrough in the Middle East and forestall another ArabIsraeli war that they fear might otherwise result.

title: More Time Sought for Inquiry Into a Possible Attica CoverUp
description: The independent inquiry into the charge that the chief Attica prosecutor covered up possible crimes by lawenforcement officers is expected to last 45 to 90 days more, the special investigator heading the inquiry said yesterday.

title: M.T.A. RIDERSHIP SHOWS A DECLINE
description: The Metropolitan transportation Authority reported yesterday a continuing substantial slide in subway and bus ridership in the first quarter of 1975 and a drop in commuter rail patronage after last year's big gains.

title: Notes on People
description: After a threeday voyage from Copenhagen on the royal yacht, Queen Margarethe II of Denmark arrived in Leningrad yesterday as the first crowned head from Western Europe to visit the Soviet Union since the 1917 revolution. The 35yearold Queen and her Frenchborn husband, Prince Henrik, cruised into Leningrad aboard her royal yacht, the Danneborg, to salutes fired from the Soviet naval base at Kronstadt. They were met by Mayor Vasily Kazakov and other Soviet officials.

title: EXUBERANCE MARKS RECITAL BY PEERCE
description: Jan Peerce, 71 years old next week and still going strong, gave a recital in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night with Allen Rogers accompanying at the piano. Time and nature have been kind to Mr. Peerce, for he is still recognizably the same tenor that he was 40 years ago.

title: 21 Chinese Artists Open Coop Gallery
description: A group of 21 immigrant Chinese artists have opened a cooperative gallery in Chinatown in an effort to display their native art to the public and to overcome the scarcity of showcases available to them.

title: Indians Rally Behind Robinson, Offer to Boycott
description: Frank Robinson, major league's first black manager. began a threegame suspension yesterday knowing he had unqualified support from his Cleveland Indians.

title: E. G. BURKHALTER, LAWMAKER, DEAD
description: Former Representative Everett Glen Burkhalter of California, who was elected to Congress gress at the age of 65, then resigned after two years because he said he was disgusted, with the seniority system in the House, died yesterday at City of Hope Hospital in Duarte, near Los Angeles. He was 78 years old.

title: When All Else Fails, Tan Tan Steps In
description: There was, Mailan Lee related, the affair of the chocolate bunnies. An importer had taken retail orders for a quartermillion of the rabbits, wrapped in foil. The shipment from Europe was due in plenty of time for Easter selling. The bunnies arrivedsmack in the middle of a dock strikeand the importer was tearing his hair, as delivery dates loomed.

title: ROBERT HUFSTADER, LED JUILLIARD UNIT
description: Robert Hufstader, director of the Julliard School's precollege division, died yesterday at his home. He was 68 years old and lived at 1088 Park Avenue.

title: Cotton Support Rate Set
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) Agriculture Department officials have announced they would not increase the 1975 cottonsupport loan rate beyond the rate of 34.27 cents per pound announced on a tentative basis last October. The preliminary rate has been made final, spokesmen said.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor urged the State Legislature to vote down pending legislation that would take away from the commission the power to balance the size of the work force in the port and terminate the agency's control over hiring of longshoremen longshoremen employment centers. These matters would be controlled jointly by the International Longshoremen's Association, which has sponsored both measures, and the New York Shipping Association.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Peter Witt, the producer, is planning an extensive theatrical schedule both here and abroad. For New York, Mr. Witt is putting together the musical Picasso, covering the 10 years that the artist spent in the Montparnasse section of Paris. Maurice Jarre is composing the music and Daniele Thompson is writing the book. Picasso is planned for Broadway in 1978.

title: TRIBUTE IS PAID TO THE WAR DEAD
description: The jubilant sound of march music and the doleful sound of taps rang out through the metropolitan area yesterday as those who had survived war and those who had never been touched by it joined to celebrats Memorial Day and commemorate the nation's dead.

title: JOB ACTION ENDS IN ASBURY PARK
description: ASBURY PARK, May 26The City Council and the uniformed employes agreed today to reopen salary negotiations, ending the traffic jam and economic crunch that had occurred here throughout most of the Memorial Day weekend because of picketing by firemen and policemen that tied up the main roads.

title: Dance: Two Companies
Papp Sounds Knell for Off Broadway
description: Joseph Papp's move to Broadwayhe will take over the Booth Theater, the 780seat house on West 45th Street, in the fall for a full season of five new American playsis the first formal, extended collaboration between the nonprofit New York Shakespeare Festival and the commercial theater.

title: Market Place
description: A number of oilservice companies appear to have been overlooked in the current stock market rallyor so some analysts say.

title: Steel Marketing Influx
description: CLEVELAND, May 26 (AP)Recession and inflation have caused a near total distortion of normal steel market patterns, Industry Week reports. American shipments of steel in the second quarter probably will be the lowest of the year. Usually, the second quarter shipments are the highest, the Clevelandbased magazine says. Steel users are expected to liquidate 5 million tons of steel inventories this quarter.

title: U.N. Officials. Defer Comment on Report Denying Price Gaps
description: GENEVA, May 26After daylong consultations, United Nations officials said tonight that they needed more time before commenting on a Washington ??ispatch in The New York Times that said experts had found that longterm price trends had not gone against the developing countries that export raw materials.

title: JuneBugs
description: You hear them now, banging at window screens in the evening or fluttering and bumbling at the outdoor lights. They are called cockchafers in England, and Junebugs here in America. Or, more truly, May beetles, since they appear in late May in most areas.

title: Article 5  No Title
Sex and Chemistry Join Fight on Apple Moth
description: GENEVA. N. Y.  Redbanded leafroller moths are flying this month through the apple orchards of upstate New York, their antennas tuned for their main task in life. The male moth, which lives for only about two weeks and does not feed, must sniff out a mate to produce the eggs for the next generation of caterpillars that threaten the state's $50millionayear apple crop.

title: Lisbon Gets a Respite Briefly
description: LISBON, May 26Encouraged by bright sunshine and the perfumed warmth of the late May Saturday and Sunday, the Portuguese took time off from their revolution.

title: SECRET BALLOT PLAN FOR UNIONS BACKED
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 26 (AP)A plan for secret ballot union elections that Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. said would end a decade of farm labor strife in California was approved today by the state Senate.

title: Blast at Mexican Consulate
description: Shortly before midnight, minor explosion, shook the tiasement of the Mexican Consulate at 41st. Street and Fifth Avenue. Investigators said that a device, possibly a weak pipe bomb, of some sort, had detonated near a basement door.

title: 2 Summer Hotels Burn
description: OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., May 26 (AP)  A fire that swept through the Seagate and the Four Flags, two wooden summer hotels in this tourist town today, was brought under control after about three hours, officials said. Several fire fighters were treated at area hospitals and released. There were no reports of serious injuries.

title: Carton Concern Bought By Esquire Executive
description: Perry Jontry, the 64yearold but nimble president of the Publishing Group of Esquire. Inc., has retired nine months early to become a boxer. Well, not boxer really, more of a carton man.

title: 3 STATE SENATORS FROM CITY OPPOSE DELAY ON BUDGET
description: Three Republican State Senators from New York City yesterday opposed an expected attempt by Mayor Beame today to postpone for a fourth time the submission of the proposed city budget and renewed their call for extensive spending cuts.

title: TV: Superbly Acted Moon for the Misbegotten
description: The awardwinning stage production of Eugene O'Neill's A Moon for the Misbegotten has been translated into magnificent television. Again, the director is Jose Quintero, receiving assistance from Gordon Rigsby for TV purposes. And the cast is brilliantly headed by Jason Robards, Colleen Dewhurst and Ed Flanders. It is, in almost every respect, the definitive realization of the play, and it can be seen on ABC tonight from 8:30 to 11.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Ford, at Arlington, Declares the U.S. Must Stay Strong
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (UPI) President Ford paid homage to the nation's war dead on Memorial Day and warned that Americans would risk their freedom unless they maintained the military might to deal with international lawbreakers.

title: Single Sculls Won by Dietz In Fast Time
description: Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club defeated his teammate. Dr. Larry. Klecatsky. in the Elite singles yesterday at the 107th annual Memorial Day regatta on the Orchard Beach lagoon. Dietz triumphed by four lengths in the fast time of 7 minutes 5 seconds which is 32 seconds under the qualifying time for international competition.

title: The Vietnam Disease
description: Memorial Day is supposed to honor ?? dead of the nation's wars but it also is a better time than most to give some thought to war's living wreckage. For example:

title: Susan McCulloch Hill Is Wed To Lionel P. Chalier, Designer
description: In St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in HoHoKus, N.J., last evening, Susan McCulloch Hill, daughter of Robin Merrill Hill of Saddle River, N.J., and John Sprunt Hill 2d of Rougemont, N.C., was married to Lionel Pierre Chalier, son of Mrs. Andr Chalier of St. Jean de Vedas, France, and the late Mr. Chalier. The Rev. Hayward L. Levy Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Service at Goethe House To Honor Karl O. Paetel
description: A memorial gathering in honor of Karl O. Paetel, German author, will be held Thursday at the Goethe House, 1014 Fifth Avenue, between 82d and 83d Streets, at 5:30 P.M.

title: ISRAEL RESISTING U.S. ON SINAI PACT
description: JERUSALEM, May 26 Buoyed by recent demonstrations of Congressional support, Israel has decided to ignore the United States' repeated requests that she produce new negotiating proposals before the AmericanEgyptian meeting in Salzburg next Sunday, according to senior Israeli officials.

title: Landmark Buildings Also Win Citations For Their Interiors
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday singled out the interiors of three Landmark buildings in the city and designated them as Interior Landmarks.

title: Gold Again a Seed of Monetary Discord
description: PARIS, May 26  Although the major Western nations are agreed that gold should play a lesser role in the monetary system, differences on bringing this about have sown new discord between the United States and its European allies, particularly France.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 26 (AP)Ancient Title, with Laffit Pincay riding, withstood a stretch challenge by Big Band today and captured the $118,100 Californian at Hollywood Park by a head before 46,028 fans. Pincay sent Ancient Title, the favorite, to the lead on leaving the gate and then allowed Century's Envoy to set the pace until the turn for home in the 1 1/16mile race over the fast main track. Sandy Hawley, on Big Band, made his move and pulled nearly even before Ancient Title surged again. The time was 1:40 1/5; one second above the race record, and the return $4.60 for $2, with the winner's purse $73,100.

title: Saxbe Follows an OffBeat, Aloof Course as American Ambassador in India
description: NEW DELHI, William B. Saxbe has emerged as one of the most offbeat American Ambassadors to India.

title: Engineer Corps Dealt Setback on Rivers Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 26The Army Corps of Engineers was dealt a rare setback last week when the House insisted and the Senate reluctantly agreed that the corps must have formal Congressional authorization for its plan to expand the upper Mississippi navigation system.

title: Tax Loopholes Found to Favor Those Earning More Than $20,000
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) A new Treasury Department study shows that the 14.6 per cent of United States taxpayers who make more than $20,000 a year receive 53 per cent of the benefits from Federal tax loopholes.

title: Fashion Takes It Easy for the Autumn
description: Casual. Relaxed. Not rambunctious or selfconscious.

title: Lightning Kills 2 Golfers
description: PINE MOUNTAIN, Ga., May 26 (UPI)  A bolt of lightning killed two golfers and injured two others today on the Garden View Golf Course. Killed were Joseph J. Norton 4th, 28 years old, and Dr. Tracy W. Ramsey, 36. The two injured men were identified as James Mac Sams, 31, and James G. Leach, 27. The incident occurred when a bolt of lightning struck a grove of trees under which the golfers had taken shelter during a thunderstorm.

title: National League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Shipping/Mail's
description: Incoming

title: Jobs for Youths a Casualty of Recession
description: ENGLEWOOD, May 26Alice Langer, 18 years old, may transfer from Skidmore, where costs have reached nearly $6,000 a year, to a less expensive school if she fails to get a summer job.

title: Rhodesian Premier Warns Black Group He May Halt Talks
description: INYANGA, Rhodesia, May 26 (Reuters)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said here today that his Government would call off talks with the African National Council if it did not agree to participate in a constitutional conference to decide Rhodesia's political future.

title: Soares Says Reds In Lisbon Threaten EastWest Detente
description: PARIS, May 26The Portugese Socialist party leader, Mario Soares, today accused the Communist party leader in Lisbon, Alvaro Cunnal, of endangering improved relations between East and West.

title: Markets Closed
description: Securities and commodities markets and banks in major financial centers in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of the Memorial Day holiday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey has announced plans to expand an ocean bacteria testing program with 35 additional testing sites in Atlantic and Cape May Counties. The State Department of Environmental Protection already has 61 similar testing sites in operation in Monmouth and Ocean Counties to test bacteria levels in ocean surf.

title: West German Steel Makers Undaunted by Current Lag
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, May 15In this city on the Rhine, where steel is a sort of religion, the faith appears to be burning bright, despite gloomy shortterm prospects.

title: 46 STUDENTS FINED IN SITIN AT RUTGERS
description: PISCATAWAY, May 27The 46 students arrested May 1 for occupying a Rutgers University building were found guilty today of trespassing and fined $25 each.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company has informed its shareowners that it is exploring the possibility of leasing, constructing and operating facilities to generate electricity and steam on the site of the iormer Brooklyn Navy Yard and entering into a contract with the Commerce, Labor, Industry Corporation of Kings (CLICK). CLICK is a nonprofit organization whose board is comprised business leaders from Brooklyn, appointed by the Mayor for the purpose of retaining industry in the Brooklyn area and attracting new industry.

title: 2 Die in Yosemite Fall
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, May 27 (AP)Two men were killed when they fell 150 feet while climbing Columbia Point here on Sunday, park authorities said today. The victims of the accident were identified as John F. Schwab, 22 years old, Monrovia, Calif., and Ronald P. Baum, 21, Hillsdale, N. J.

title: Fiscal Crisis at a Glance
description: The city's fiscal crisis consists of three distinct elements: a budget deficit for the fiscal year ended June 30; an even bigger budget deficit looming for the following year, and a cashflow problem forcing the city to borrow more than a billion dollars in the next five weeks to pay its bills. Here is a look at these elements:

title: A New Imprint
description: WASHINGTON, May 27On the eve of President Ford's weeklong trip to Europe, White House advisers are saying that he is reducing his reliance on Secretary of State Kissinger and assuming increasing command over his own foreign policy.

title: Kentucky Governor Wins a Decisive Victory in Democratic Primary Election
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 27Gov. Julian M. Carroll won a decisive victory today in the Democratic gubernatorial primary election. Mr. Carroll, who became Governor four months ago, led his chief opponent, Todd Hollenbach, in every part of the state except metropolitan Jefferson County, where Mr. Hollenbach is the chief executive officer.

title: LAWYER SURRENDERS IN MAULDIN ATTACK
description: CHICAGO, May 27 (UPI)A lawyer surrendered to the police today and was charged with assaulting Bill Mauldin, the Pulitzer prizewinning editorial cartoonist of The Chicago SunTimes, while Mr. Mauldin was photographing illegally parked cars outside a party for the son of Mayor Richard J. Daley.

title: E.D.A. EASES RULES ON SOME VITAMINS
description: WASHINGTON, May 27The Food and Drug Administration backed away today from its decision of 1973 that superpotent vitamins and minerals should be regulated as drugs.

title: 300 Striking Teachers March in Norwalk
description: NORWALK, Conn., May 27Close to 300 striking school teachers held a rally outside City Hall this afternoon, carrying placards and chanting briefly in the hot sun, hoping to muster public support and persuade the city's Common Council to approve a pay raise the teachers thought they had already won.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 430 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: Concert
description: The concert that the grandly named (or is it so grand these days?) Orchestra of the City of New York gave yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall had its distinct virtues, and it was virtuously intended, besides. But there were enough distractions at times to make it hard to pay attention to the music.

title: News Summary and Index
description: In a significant change in its foreign economic policy, the United States says it is willing to consider arrangements for greater price stability for the raw materials exported by developing countries. At a meeting in Paris of the International Energy Agency, an 18nation grouping of major oil consumers, Secretary of State Kissinger told the ministers, Our interdependence will make us thrive together or decline together. The United States told its Western partners that it hoped the new efforts to deal seriously with the problems of the developing world would break a deadlock between oil producers and consumers and help avoid another energy confrontation. [Page Column 5.]

title: ABORTION DEATHS IN SHARP DECLINE
description: WASHINGTON, May 27A sharp decline in maternal deaths and injuries related to abortion has accompanied liberalized abortion laws, a report from a panel of the National Academy of Sciences laid today.

title: Goldin Given a Lesson On the Buget by Pupils
description: While city and state officials wrestle to solve the city's budget problems, a fifth  grade class from a Brooklyn public school has come up with some solutions.

title: Dodgers Set Back Mets, 104
description: Double trouble stalked the New York Mets last night, when they lost Bud Harrelson for perhaps the rest of the season and then lost some of their recent dash under a 104 barrage by the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: ... and Development
description: The developing countries need huge investment to achieve increasing income, yet want to inhibit private foreign capital. The industrial nations want assured supplies on a steadily increasing scale.

title: She Saves Those Spicy Mexican Dishes for Special Occasions
description: MEXICO CITY  Maria Quijano stirred a dish of cubed cactus leaves and eggs. My son, she said, offered to furnish me with cactus at five pesos a kilo this morning, but I refused. It is cheaper to buy it in the market.

title: New Jersey's Schools
description: Supporters of educational and tax reform in New Jersey have been disappointed by a State Supreme Court order which calls for the redistribution of $300 million in state school aidabout half of the current aid packagebeginning in 1976 unless the Legislature complies with the court's 1973 mandate to produce a new system of public school financing.

title: Westvaco Profits Declined 46% in Second Quarter
description: The Westvaco Corporation, a large producer of pulp, paper and linerboard, reported yesterday profit declines of 46 per cent for the second fiscal quarter, and 23 per cent for the six months ended April 30.

title: Jewish Leaders Critical Of Missile Sale to Jordan
description: American Jewish leaders voiced concern yesterday over the Ford Administration's announced intention to supply Jordan with $100million worth of Hawk antiaircraft missiles while denying Israel new military aid.

title: Egypt Is Said to Uncover A Plot to Depose Sadat
description: CAIRO, Wednesday, May 28 (Reuters)The Egyptian police have uncovered a plot to overthrow President Anwar elSadat's administration by force, the Cairo newspaper Al Akhbar reported today.

title: How an Author's Pen Wins West
description: Louis Dearborn L'Amour high school dropout, former ranch hand, professional boxer, seaman and longshorernan has written 33 stories that have been made into movies and 62 books that have sold 50 million copies. By October he will become Bantam Books' bestselling author, surpassing John Steinbeck.

title: RABBI ISRAEL JACOBSON
description: Rabbi Israel Jacobson, a Lubavitcher educator and cornmunal leader, died yesterday at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 778 Montgomery Street; Brooklyn.

title: A New Imprint
description: WASHINGTON, May 27On the eve of President Ford's weeklong trip to Europe, White House advisers are saying that he is reducing his reliance on Secretary of State Kissinger and assuming increasing command over his own foreign policy.

title: A Critic's Notebook
description: About 10 years ago one was being told that music was dead; that the symphony orchestra and the opera house were museums and relics of the past; that nobody was writing largescale works any more. Most of the noise about the death of music was, it is true, being made by composers whose music was not being played very much, if at all. But it was a fashionable thought, and such celebrities as Leonard Bernstein made equally loud noises in agreement.

title: Lisbon Military Rulers Sharpen Hostility to Socialists
description: LISBON, May 27  Mario Soares, the embattled Portuguese Socialist leader, returned here today from talks with other European Socialists to face sharpened hostility from the ruling arched forces.

title: Reporter's Notebook: The Mayor, in Time of Stress
description: It was after an earlier budget pilgrimage to Albany, like yesterday's unsuccessful one, for Mayor Beame. He was drawn, pale, not angry.

title: Bank Robber Sentenced
description: TORONTO, May 27 (AP)Vernon Lewis Allen, 30 years old, of Columbia, B.C., a former United States Marine who served in Vietnam, was sentenced today to eight years in prison for bank robbery.

title: SHOP TALK
description: For several years now, American manufacturers have doused consumers with the scent of lemons. Supermarket and drug store shelves are crowded with lemonscented hand creams, lemonscented furniture polish, even lemonscented laundry detergent.

title: Monday's Fights
description: Monterrey, Mexico  Miguel Canto, Mexico, outpointed BetuHo Gonzalez, Venezuela, 15 rounds, flyweights; Canto retained his World Boxing Council crown.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON. May 27The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: SUDANESE REPORTS ERITREA PEACE BID
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, May 27 (Reuters)The Sudan's President, Maj. Gen. Gaafar alNimeiry, said here today that the Ethiopian Army and the Eritrean separatist rebels who have been fighting in northern Ethiopia had accepted a Sudanese peace plan.

title: ANTIAEROSOL BILL PASSED IN OREGON
description: SALEM, Ore., May 27  The Oregon House passed today a ban on the sale of aerosol sprays containing chlorofluocarton compounds that are believed to be damaging the ozone layer above the earth's surface.

title: Hard and Soft Sell Blend as Booksellers Meet
description: Some 12,000 people who like books were in New York yesterday for the 75th anniversary of the American Booksellers Association. They talked about books, argued about books, and in various hotel rooms they even drank to books. Mostly, however, they were concerned with selling books, sometimes in ways you would never think of.

title: Five Arrested in Washington In Protest at Bolshoi Ballet
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP)  ?? five per?? Kennedy Cen?? Opera House tonight after ?? used noisemakers ?? try to drown out the play?? of the Soviet, national an?? before the start of a per?? by the Bolshoi Ballet.

title: Stuttgart Ballet Does Cranko's Eugene Onegin Here
GRADUATES FACING 18% HIRING SLASH
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) Eighteen per cent fewer new college graduates are being hired this year than last year and the job market for them may not pick up until next spring, according to a survey released today.

title: Laotians Occupying U.S. Aid Compound Agree to End Siege
description: VIENTAINE, Laos, May 27 (AP)Students occupying the American aid program mission here agreed today to leave the compound where three Americans have been holding out for almost a week, Christian A. Chapman, the United States charge d'affaires, said.

title: Impeachment of Treasurer In Florida Urged by Panel
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 27 (AP)A select committee of the Florida House has recommended that the state TreasurerInsurance Commissioner, Thomas O'Malley, be impeached on charges of profiting by wrongful influence over the industry he regulates.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Public school attendance in Newark dropped sharply as pupils boycotted classes to protest a threatened $14million budget cut and the prospective dismissal of 900 teachers. An estimated total of 60 to 70 pupils, joined by Charles Bell, president of the Newark Board of Education, went to Trenton by bus to demonstrate for more state school aid, which city officials and school authorities say is essental to preserve educational services.

title: Senate Passes a Measure Guaranteeing Thorough, Efficient Public Education
description: TRENTON, May 27  The State Senate gave initial legislative approval tonight to a bill guaranteeing a thorough and efficient free public education for every child in New Jersey and promising the state financing to implement it next year.

title: A.R.F. Confirms Simmons Study
description: The Advertising Research Foundation has completed its fourth and final report on its audit of the 197475 Simmons Study of Selective Markets and the Media Reaching Them, and according to its president it found nothing basically of concern, no substantial problems.

title: 7 G.O.P. SENATORS WITHHOLD BACKING ON A CITY BUDGET
description: ALBANY, May 27The seven Republican State Senators from New York City failed to agree today on a city tax package, and Mayor Beame, who had waited with mounting impatience all day for their answer, left for home.

title: MARGARET MUEHSAM
description: Margaret Edelheim Muehsam, a journalist and editor, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived at 11 Riverside Drive.

title: South Bronx Housing Program in Peril
description: The first project under the country's major new subsidizedhousing programthe rehabilitation of 11 decayed South Bronx buildings into new apartments for nearly 400 lowincome familiesis on the verge of financial collapse because the state cannot come up with its end of the financing.

title: U.S. Cautions Israelis Against Raids Into Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 The State Department said today that, we particularly regret the incursions of Israeli armed forces into Lebanese territory at a time when Lebanon is beset by internal tensions.

title: AIRLINES' AUTHORITY ON EMBARGO DENIED
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled yesterday that only the United States Department of Transporationnot the airlines has the authority to embargo hazardous materials, such as chemicals and radioactive matter from their flights.

title: MISS SOMOGI LEADS NAUMBURG CONCERT
description: Judith Somogi conducted the opening Naumburg concert of the season on Monday night on the Mall in Central Parkthe first time a woman has led the orchestra in the 70year history of this annual free summer series. Miss Somogi chose an appropriately sprightly program that competed bravely with the usual openair racketairplanes, transistors, bongo drumming and loud conversations.

title: HOMER D. KRESGE
description: Homer D. Kresge, publisher of The Ocean Grove (N. J.) Times, a weekly, from 1925 to 1961, died Monday. He was 88 years old and lived in Ocean Grove.

title: BONN WILL OPPOSE NATO TIE TO SPAIN
description: BONN, May 27  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt would oppose any efforts by the United States to press for a closer association between Spain and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at the alliance meeting this week in Brussels, West German officials said today.

title: Bank Liquidation Authorized
description: The Security National Bank, the Long Island bank whose assets were taken over by Chemical Bank last January, reported yesterday that the Controller of the Currency had authorized the bank to proceed with its liquidation. No further shareholder action is expected, and the bank will send out its initial liquidating dividend of $7.40 a share on June 23.

title: VIVIAN BLAINE SINGS WITH A MIXED MOOD
description: Vivian Blaine, who survived a succesion of generally dreadful movies in the nineteenforties to find a place for herself on the stage, starting with Guys and Dolls in 1950, has joined a string of other musicaltheater veterans in the supper club Arena at Brothers and Sisters, 355 West 46th Street. At 53, Miss Blaine still exude Hollywood glamour while she alternately kids her movie career and draws worthwhile material from her past.

title: How an Author's Pen Wins West
description: Louis Dearborn L'Amour high school dropout, former ranch hand, professional boxer, seaman and longshoreman  has written 33 stories that have been made into movies and 62 books that have sold 50 million copies. By October he will become Bantam Books' bestselling author, surpassing John Steinbeck.

title: TAX PREPAYMENT VOTED BY COUNCIL
description: The City Council yesterday unanimously approved a measure proposed by Mayor Beame that would allow the issuance of interestbearing certificates of deposit for the early paymeat of city taxes.

title: A Doctor Is Confounded By the Malpractice Issue
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L. I., May 27These are days of deep anxiety for Dr. Stanley Renner.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 300 Asphalt Truck Drivers Walk Out in a Strike Here
description: A drivers strike that could impede work on many construction projects in the city was started yesterday by members of Local 282 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: About New York
description: Faint as spirit writing are the city's old wall signs. Some are already indecipherable, their messages having flaked away atom by atom over the years, and others are headed inevitably for the same fate.

title: China Says 9 Scale Everest
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, May 28 (Reuters)  A woman was among nine Chinese mountaineers who reached the summit of Mount Everest yesterday, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported today. The agency, in a dispatch monitored here, said the nine climbers, eight of whom were Tibetans, had reached the summit from the northern slope.

title: Where Is Newark Headed?
description: NEWARKThe heralded remark of Kenneth Gibson that wherever the American city is going, Newark will get, there first was made in the aftermath of his first successful campaign for Mayor, not long after the catastrophic riots of 1967. At that time almost any expression of optimism about Newark sounded unrealistic. The Mayor sought to bring to his office not Only political honesty but intellectual honesty. He tried to tell it like it was: No matter how hopeful one felt about its future, Newark still had hard times ahead.

title: A College President To Be Investigated By Committee Here
description: The Board of Higher Education appointed a special committee of board members yesterday to investigate the performance of Dr. Edgar J. Draper, the embattled president of the Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: $1 OIL IMPORT FEE DOUBLED BY FORD; GAS PRICE TO RISE
description: WASHINGTON, May 27President Ford announced tonight that he would impose a second $1abarrel fee on imported oil beginning Sunday and that he would start phasing out price controls on domestic oil supplies later in June.

title: Some Food Can Be Refrozen, Even if Package Says Not To
description: When frozen foods first came on the market, consumers were told that they should never, under any circumstances, refreeze them. No reason was given, but the notion got around that something dire, such as food poisoning, could occur.

title: A DISPUTE CENTER OPENS IN HARLEM
description: A communitybased mediation center for minor disputes that is designed to free policemen for more serious crimes and help unclog the courts was opened yesterday in Harlem.

title: Equus Voted Best Play By Drama Critics Circle
description: The New York Drama Critics Circle yesterday voted Equus, a British import, the best play of the 197475 season. The Taking of Miss Janie was named the best American play and A Chorus Line the best musical.

title: Xerox to Sell 800 System
description: DALLAS. May 27 (UPI)The Xerox Corporation said today it would sell as well as rent its new 800 electronic typing system, which operates at he rate of 350 words a minute. Sale prices of the units, which use magnetic tape or cards. will range from $9,800 to $11,780. The cost of renting the units is between $195 and $310 monthly.

title: Imports of Oil Expected to Rise Despite Ford's Doubling of Fee
description: WASHINGTON, May 27The nation's dependence on imported oil will continue to grow despite the steps announced by President Ford tonight, according to estimates released by the White House.

title: AIRLINE IS FINED $150,000 BY C.A.B.
