description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in overthecounter trading were lower yesterday in slightly steppedup trading.

title: CLOSING OF HOSPITAL RESISTED BY BOARD
description: The medical board of Francis Delafield Hospital in Washinghon Heights, which the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation has voted to close as an economy move, voted last night to continue all health services to the citizens of New York City, a spokesman announced.

title: Medicaid Centers Fighting Reform Move
description: New City Health Department regulations, designed to save taxpayers here tens of millions of dollars a year in Medicaid overpayments, are being challenged in a suit brought in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn by the owners or operators of more than 50 Medicaid centers.

title: Hughes Gets a Bill For $3Million Tax OnGlomar Explorer
description: LOS ANGELES, May 28The refusal of Howard Hughes and the Central Intelligence Agency to disclose who owns the ship Glomar Explorer has brought Mr. Hughes's Summa Corporation a tax bill for $3,119,865.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On Saving Peregrine Falcon
description: Two recovery teams have been formed under the United States Fish and Wildlife Service to save the American peregrine falcon from extinction.

title: Cyprus Suspicion and Rigidity Dimming Prospects for Accord
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, May 28More than four months after the ethnic Greek and Turkish communities started talking about the political future of Cyprus, the two sides seem locked in a cycle of increasing suspicion and intransigence. Accordingly, most Cypriote leaders and foreign diplomats share deep pessimism about prospects for a settlement.

title: City Budget: A Document in Flux
description: The city's $12.8billion 1975 76 expense budget, which Mayor Beame submits today, will contain all the usual budgetary trappings of permanence and certainty  column after column of neatly calculated numbers. row upon row of headings, all of them adding up, with seeming precision, to the second biggest government budget in the nation. Mayor Beame has said that, when all the city's day to day expenditures for next year are totaled, they will exceed all the revenues by $641.5million, a deficit he has been trying to close with new taxes and state aid.

title: Smith Sets World Best Of 185 in Pole Vault
description: Minutes before he cleared 18 feet 5 inches for a world indoor best in the pole vault last night, Steve Smith laid on a rubbing table in a dressing room at Madison Square Garden with an ice pack on his right knee.

title: Rail Net Being Repaired
description: SAIGON, May 28 (AP)Six thousand workers are repairing South Vietnam's rail system to link it with North Vietnam, another step toward reunification of the country.

title: In Monaco, Knickknacks for $4Million
description: MONTE CARLO, May 27The Baron and Baroness Guy de Rothschild and the man who will be their star lodger in one of the most gorgeous mansions in Paris have now disposed of some surplus knickkacks that brought in $4million here in the last two days.

title: Advertising
description: People who like to consider alternatives will love a new firm that has opened its doors at 3 West 35th Street. It's called Byrne Or Schoenfeld and is dedicating itself to marketing problem solving.

title: Katherine Gauss Jackson Dies; Editor of Harper's Book Review
description: Katherine Gauss Jackson, for many years both the book review and the fiction editor of Harper's magazine, died of cancer yesterday in Fairview Hospital, Great Barrington, Mass. She was 71 years old and lived in nearby North Egremont.

title: Start of Kent State Trial Hears Appeals on Conflicting Rights
description: CLEVELAND, May 28  The constitutional rights of freedom of speech and assembly versus the right to put down violent insurrection were the issues drawn by lawyers in the opening statements of the Kent State civil trial today.

title: Personal Finance: On Deferred Annuities
description: Singlepremium deferred annuitiesa type of investment long used by the rich to provide a guaranteed income for lifehave become more widely available recently to the middle class.

title: Article 1  No Title
Pele Says: 60% to 70% Chance I'll Sign
description: All of a sudden, Pel's chances of playing for the Cosmos have increased. How much?

title: Text of the Remarks by Ford in Brussels
description: BRUSSELS, May 28 (AP)Following is the text of President Ford's statement on arrival in Brussels for the meeting of the North Atlantic alliance:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was stated incorrectly in The New York Times yesterday that the New York State Department of Parks and Recreation had discontinued arrangements for campers to reserve campsites in its facilities through Ticketron. Actually, the agency never booked its campsites through Ticketron. Campers can, however, book campsites through Ticketron in the Catskill and Adirondack forest preserves, which are administered by the state's Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Sex, Even at 92 or 100, Called Normal
description: PARAMUS, May 28Sex after 60 is as essential to the quality of life as it is at any other age, Dr. Virginia Stone told an overflow audience at the Bergen Pines County Hospital today.

title: No.Amer.Soccer League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Most of Oil Industry Backing Ford's Plans
description: Most of the nation's oil industry expressed strong support yesterday for President Ford's new energy proposals. Strong reservations, however, were expressed by some analysts and representatives of other industries.

title: Soviet Astronauts Ready to Activate Laboratory in Orbit
description: MOSCOW. May 26 (AP)Two estronauts, in their third day aboard an orbiting space station, completed the basic work to activate the Salyut 4 laboratory the official press agency Tass said.

title: JACK ANDERSON SIGNS WITH ABC
description: ABCTV announced yesterday that Jack Anderson, the syndicated columnist, had been signed for a weekly spot, beginning next month, on the network's twohour morning show, A.M. America.

title: Dallas Sniper Victim Dies
description: DALLAS, May 28 (UPI)A black teenager shot by snipers from a car window died today, and the police said the two persons held in the incident probably would be charged with murder. Johnny Kenner, 15 years old died at Parkland Hospital. The suspects, both white, are Thomas Leon Watson, 22, of suburban Irving, and Patrick Ray Werner, 23, of Dallas.

title: G.O.P. UNIT MEETS TO DRAFT POLICY
description: TRENTON, May 28, (AP)The Republican platform committee heard today from a variety of special interest representatives at a hearing preparatory to drafting the G.O.P. campaign platform for the Assembly election this year.

title: THOMAS RIDDICK, 68, OF ENGINEERING FIRM
description: Thomas M. Riddick, president of Thomas M. Riddick & Associates, consulting engineers and chemist, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Huntington, L.I. He was 68 years old and lived also at 1700 York Avenue here.

title: Bicentennial Issues Will Be Discussed At Monthly Forums
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) A major Bicentennial program to explore the meaning of the American Revolution through a series of monthly forums was disclosed today.A national calendar of topics to be discussed was distributed to 250,000 civic leaders and other persons by the National Endowment for the Humanities and the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The United States Golf Association is being taken to court by a group of amateur golfers who contend that their new tournament is being harmed by the U.S.G.A.

title: The Mayor's Choice
description: Having been rebuffed in Albany on his demand for a fourth postponement, Mayor Beame is scheduled to submit today his long overdue 197576 expense budget, indicating how he plans to deal with what he says is a $641.5million gap between anticipated spending and revenues.

title: Charley to Close Saturday
description: After 104 performances, the musical Goodtime Charley, will end its run at the Palace Theater on Saturday. The closing was atributed to a weak box office. Charles Ohermeyer, the producer said yesterday, The musical, starring Joel Grey and Ann Reinking, was originally capitalized for $800,000. In the course of its run, it lost $300.000 more.

title: Rabin Is Looking To New Sinai Talk With the Egyptians
description: TEL AVIV, May 28  Less than a week before the scheduled Middle East talks in Salzburg between President Ford and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, Premier Yitzhak Rabin today signaled Israel's wish to resume negotiations for a secondstage interim agreement with Egypt.

title: WALTER FRIED, 69, PRODUCER, DEAD
description: Walter Fried, producer and general manager of many memorable Broadway plays over the last 30 years, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 16 West 77th Street.

title: 2 Million Fans Salute Flyers
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 28This old city wasn't closed today.

title: Times Sq. Housing Project Poses a Problem for City
description: A $95million attempt to lure uppermiddleincome apartment dwellers to the western fringe of Times Square appears likely to fail, city officials say, and the two 45story apartment towers being built for them on West 42d Street may have to be rented instead to poor and moderateincome families receiving Federal subsidies.

title: DAVID DUBROW
description: David Dubrow, a linotype operator in the composing room of The New York Times from 1943 until he retired in 1972, died yesterday at his home, 103 Corbin Place, Brooklyn. He was 63 years old.

title: Judge Urges 1Cent Cut In FirstClass Postal Rate
description: WASHINGTON, May 28An administrative law judge recommended today that firstclass postal rates be cut from 10 cents to 8 cents. It was a stunning surprise to the United States Postal Service, which had been planning to meet a deficit by raising the price to 13 cents.

title: Wee Paws on a Vintage Problem
description: WASHINGTONReading the newspaper has become a depressing experience. It is not newspapers' faultit is the fault of a country that still looks to the Federal bureaucracy for leadership and still supports the unnecessary centralization of our service, production and distribution sectors. Nuclearpower plants, metropolitan seweragetreatment systems, huge onecrop agribusinessowned farms, sprawling Federal and city bureaucracies are the problem, not the solutions.

title: Karami Is Named Premier in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 28A powerful Moslem political leader was designated Premier today in a new effort to form a government that could end the bloodshed and anarchy in Lebanon.

title: Lisbon Socialists Suspend the Boycott of Cabinet
description: LISBON, May 28 (AP)The Socialists suspended their boycott of Cabinet meetings today and the military rulers loosened the reins enough to let civilian officials discuss a major national issue.

title: Venezuela Sets a Target For Reducing Oil Output
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 28 (Reuters)Venezuela has set a tentative target for 1976 average oil output of 2 million barrels daily, Finance Minister. Hector Hurtado said today.

title: Productivity Slips
description: Output per manhour throughout the economy slipped twotenths of a per cent in the first quarter, the Labor Department reported yesterday, revising earlier figures, which had shown a small gain. Nonfinancial corporations, however, raised their productivity 3.4 per cent. Page 53.

title: At a Wine Auction Here, Some Prices Are More Than in Neighborhood Stores
description: The seventh annual Heu blein wine auction, held yesterday at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel, was described by the auctioneer, J. Michael Broadbent, as a sober sale.

title: Unveilings
description: ZUCKERMANMurray. Dedication of ?? ment in loving memory will be unveiled at 10 30 A.M., Sunday, June 1, at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City Goes All Out in Bid for Democratic Convention
description: When the elevator doors at 666 Fifth Avenue closed on the arms of a West Coast Congressman yesterday afternoon, he shouted in dismay. I'm voting California! he protested

title: WESTCHESTER VOTES IN SCHOOL ELECTIONS
description: Schoolboard elections were held yesterday in Westchester County.

title: Coast Doctors End Strike, Agree on Malpractice Pact
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 28Leaders of the State Legislature and several medical organizations announced today an end of the monthlong walkout by California doctors protesting great increases in malpractice insurance rates.

title: 15 African Nations Sign Pact Creating An Economic Group
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, May 28 (AP) Fifteen leaders of African nations signed a treaty today creating the largest single economic grouping in Africathe Economic Community of West African States.

title: Man Held as Prostitute
description: BROCKTON, Mass., May 28 (UPI)A 36yearold man was arrested yesterday at his home on charges of prostitution after he allegedly solicited an undercover policewoman. The police said that, Frederick A. Doane, had operated a massage business in his apartment the past several months.

title: S.E.C. Fraud Suit In Oklahoma Lists Commodity Firms
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, May 28 (AP)  Fourteen commodity trading companies and 27 individuals, including former Oklahoma securities officials, have been named in a fraud suit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Midwood Wins Title
description: Midwood defeated Jamaica, 32, yesterday for the Public Schools Athletic League tennis championship at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens. It was the second title in five years for Coach Barry Goldsmith.

title: The Screen:'Children of Rage,' on Conflict in Mideast
description: If a movie could be made by a computer, it might look like "Children of Rage," a fastidiously well-meaning, completely lifeless film that attempts to dramatize the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in what producers call human terms.It's about a selfless Israeli doctor who sneaks off to minister to Palestinian refugees in a camp in Jordan, the young Palestinian woman who loves the doctor, and her younger brother, who becomes a terrorist out of frustration. The movie was directed and written by an American, Arthur Allan Seidelman, whose characters are mouthpieces for the various Palestinian and Israeli, conservative-through-liberal positions."Children of Rage," which opened yesterday at the Fine Arts, is totally lacking in the kind of idiosyncratic detail that forever separates cinema from mere picture-taking.

title: Borg Gains Third Round With a 75, 64 Victory
description: ROME, May 28 (AP)Chris Evert moved into the quarterfinals of the $120,000 Italian open tennis championships today with a 61, 63 triumph over Susan Barker of Britain.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Arriving in Brussels for a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, President Ford told an airport welcoming crowd, Our commitment to this alliance will not falter. The President was greeted by King Baudouin of the Belgians and Joseph M. A. H. Luns, the alliance's secretary general. Mr. Ford said NATO has the support of the American people and Congress. [P. 1, Col. 5.]

title: SUGAR FUTURES CONTINUE TO DROP
description: The downturn in world sugar futures continued yesterday, with the July position closing at 15.89 cents a pound on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The close Tuesday was 16.70 cents a pound.

title: North Sea Oil to Flow To Britain Next Month
description: LONDON, May 28 (Reuters) Britain will bring in its first oil from the North Sea next month, beginning what is hoped to be a flow worth a total of $414billion from the country's offshore fields, it was announced today.

title: Los Angeles Stresses Glamour to Attract Both Parties
description: LOS ANGELES, May 28 Los Angeles is offering the sun and the stars and a chance to return to the birthplace of John F. Kennedy's Camelot in its quest to lure the 1976 Democratic convention.

title: ISRAEL REBUFFS APPEAL ON BOOK
description: JERUSALEM, May 28The Israeli military censor has rejected an appeal by an Israeli journalist for access to the confiscated manuscript of his book on Secretary of State Kissinger's Middle East diplomacy, the lawyer for the journalist said today.

title: Ninth Time in Office
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 28 Rashid Karami was a natural choice to be Premier in Lebanon's current political crisis, and he demonstrated this today by deliberately driving through the Beirut stronghold of the rightwing Phalangist party on his way to the Presidential Palace to accept his appointment.

title: Play: Sherlock Holmes
description: Althoughas the playbill at the Broadhurst Theater makes scrupulously clearit is the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of Sherlock Holmes that is playing there, it is notif you see the distinctionany longer the Royal Shakespeare Company. The Royal Shakespeare has gone home, and the actors now at the Broadhurst are all North American citizens or residents.

title: HUGHES IS NAMED IN ANTITRUST SUIT
description: Victor Kurtz and Ellen Kurtz, two minority stockholderS of the A. W. Liquidating Company, formerly known as Air West, Inc., have brought an antitrust suit in Federal District Court here against Howard Hughes in which they seek, for the cornpany's shareholders as a class, damages of $210million and fees of $21million for their own attorneys, Bader & Bader.

title: KORFF IS RESIGNING FROM NIXON FUND
description: WASHINGTON, May 28Rabbi Baruch Korff announced (today that he was resigning as head of the group that has raised 3190,000 toward the legal gal fees of former President Richard M. Nixonbut not from my friendship with him.

title: Alcoa Trims Operations
description: PITTSBURGH, May 28 (Reuters)The Aluminium Company of America said today it was reducing the operating rate of its domestic smelting system from 85 per cent to about 74 per cent of the rated capacity of 1,575,000 tons a year. Alcoa said the cutback totaled about 180,000 tons on an annual basis. About 500 employes will be affected.

title: Chess:
Philadelphia Stops To Salute Flyers
Ford on Father's Day
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)  President Ford says the nation's observance of Father's Day should include a salute to natural fathers, foster fathers, adoptive fathers and big brothers. It is a fitting American tradition that once a year we pay a well deserved tribute to these fathers of America, he said yesterday as he proclaimed June 15 as Father's Day.

title: Trial Run on Destruction of Soup Is Faulty
description: ELIZABETH, May 28As soup cans threaded through an automatic can opener here in a former barrel factory on their way to an incinerator, drops of vichyssoise, shrimp bisque and onion soup splashed from the rims to the floor.

title: Tokyo and Washington
description: STANFORD, Calif.No one can say for sure how Japan will respond in the long run to the Indochina debacle. Party factionalism, domestic preoccupations, and a disposition not to ponder questions that weigh so heavily on Americans all diffuse Japanese responses on such matters. Though the Vietnam issue has occasionally stirred passions in Japan, most Japanese have tended to view Vietnam as a remote land of peripheral interest to them.

title: ISRAEL WEINSTEIN, CITY'S HEALTH CHIEF
description: Israel Weinstein, the city's Commissioner of Public Health from 1946 to 1947, died Tuesday at his home in the Bossert Hotel, Brooklyn. He was 82 years old.

title: Bayern Munich Victor
description: PARIS, May 28 (UPI) Bayern Munich, the defending champion, broke away to score twice in the closing minutes today and defeat Leeds United, 20, in the final of the European Soccer Champions' Cup. The game was held up for three minutes when Leeds fans ripped out seats in the Parc des Princes Stadium and hurled them onto the field.

title: FIGHTING IN ERITREA IS SAID, TO CONTINUE
description: ROME, May 28 (Reuters) Sporadic fighting between Eritrean rebels and Ethopian Government troops is continuing despite the acceptance by both sides of a Sudanese peace plan, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: Failure of the Moreland Panel's Ethics Bill Is Foreseen
description: ALBANY, May 28A proposal by the Moreland Commission investigating the nursinghome industry that would bar lawyerlegislators from practicing before state agencies will likely expire in the Senate, legislative officials indicated today.

title: DEMOCRATS NAME SLATE IN SUFFOLK
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., May 28 Suffolk County Democrats] tonight nominated their candidates for the Republicandominated County Legislature and the County Executive's office, which is also occupied by a Republican.

title: Business Briefs
description: KUWAIT, May 28 (AP)Abu Dhabi's Oil Minister said today that the Persian Gulf emirate might have to sell buyback oil well below the price decided by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: INVESTIGATION SET OF TOBACCO BUYERS
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (Reuters)The Justice Department is investigating possible price fixing and collusion among major tobacco companies in leaf buying, an Agriculture Department spokesman said today.

title: Gasoline a Prime Target
description: President Ford's new import fee on oil could mean increased costs of living in the New York area that would work out to $10 a year for the average Consolidated Edison electricity customer, $11.25 for the average motorist and $22.50 for the average onefamily home using heating oil.

title: China Appears to Caution North Korea Not to Attack
description: WASHINGTON, May 28Administration officials said today that China had indicated strongly in recent weeks that she had cautioned North Korea against launching a military attack against South Korea.

title: TWO '76 ASPIRANTS PAY A VISIT HERE
description: Taking their cue from the city's fiscal plight, two Democratic aspirants for the Presidency campaigned here yesterday with promises to seek Federal loans or loan guarantees to prevent default of city bonds within the next month.

title: GRANT WILL MEET DEBT OBLIGATIONS
description: Amid mounting concern among merchandise creditors about its ability to meet bank debt and to reverse an unfavorable credit rating, the W. T. Grant Company said yesterday that it planned to make a payment of $56.5million Monday to fully satisfy loans due 116 banks.

title: U.S. Gives Egypt $40Million
description: CAIRO, May 28 (Reuters)The United States and Egypt signed two agreements today under which the United States gave Egypt grants of $40million for reconstruction of electrical systems and road in the Suez Canal area.

title: DoctorOwned Malpractice Insurer in State Puts Rate Rise at 10%15%
description: Malpractice insurance premiums for doctors will go up by only 10 to 15 per cent this year under rates to be announced this week by the new doctorowned insurance company in New York, a representative of the State Medical Society said yesterday.

title: Portugal's Inaction on Aid Offers Frustrates Donors
description: WASHINGTON, May 28A number of Western countries and lending institutions are trying to help Portugal out of her economic difficulties with aid offers.

title: Making Peace in Europe
description: WASHINGTONSix weeks ago, a suggestion was made in this space that the European security conferencea proposed 35nation supersummit to legitimatize that Soviet conquest of Eastern Europebe postponed.

title: OneYear Notes Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, May 28The Treasury auctioned $1.37billion of oneyear bills today at an average yield of 5.803 per cent.

title: Lindsay's Memory on Debt Faulted
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that his predecessor, John V. Lindsay, was trying to rewrite history in his contention last weekend that the spiral of shortterm borrowing was something that began with the Beanie administration.

title: Nets offer Kenon for Nater
description: The Nets, eliminated in the first round of the American Basketball Association playoffs by the Spirits of St. Louis, an expansion team, are in the midst of a deal with the San Antonio Spurs that would bring Swen Nater to New York for Larry Kenon and Mike Gale.

title: Coast Doctors End Strike, Agree on Malpractice Pact
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 28Leaders of the State Legislature and several medical organizations announced today an end of the monthlong walkout by California doctors protesting great increases in malpractice insurance rates.

title: Fiscal Backlash Increases State's Cost of Borrowing
description: ALBANY, May 28In an apparent reflection of New York City's fiscal troubles, New York State today was forced to pay substantially higher rates of interest for major shortterm borrowing than it paid for a similar transaction only three weeks ago.

title: STOCKS RETREAT AS TRADING GAINS
description: The stock market declined yesterday in accelerated trading despite sonic encouraging economic developments.

title: Dance: Legends of Brazil
description: The dancers are quite good, and their commitment and sincerity are beyond question. These are the favorable impressions one carried away from the local debut Tuesday night at Hunter College Playhouse of the Stagium Chamber Ballet of Brazil, a moderndance group from Sao Paulo.

title: PromTime Music By Louis St. Louis And the Lettermen
description: Prom time is here, somewhat varied. There is the squeaky Clean trio called the Lettermen at the WaldorfAstoria's Empire Room, singing the good old songs of the last two decades and some of the softer, more plastic new ones.

title: Times Will Pay Dividends
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it would pay a regular quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share on its common stock. The dividend is payable June 26 to shareholders, of record June 10. The company also said it would pay a dividend of $1.375 a share on its 5 per cent cumulative prior preference stock on July 1 to shareholders of record June 10.

title: Bozell to Buy Minneapolis Agency
description: Bozell & Jacobs International, which has 23 offices here and abroad, will acquire on Sunday Knox Reeves Advertising, a 40yearold Minneapolis agency that has seen better days.

title: LEON R. LEVY DIES; ARCHITECT WAS 75
description: Leon R. Levy, an architect who had worked on the design of the New York Coliseum and other buildings here, died Tuesday on the island of Sanibel, off the west coast of Florida. He had lived there in retirement for the last several years.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Books of The Times
description: Of course one never completely loses interest reading Edmund Wilson's The Twenties: From Notebooks and Diaries of the Period. Alwaysjust as one is beginning to grow restlessthere pops up an interesting portrait of someone familiar from the period, someone like Frank Crowninshield, the editor of Vanity Fair, which Wilson helped to edit for a time. Or Charlie Chaplin, whom Wilson tried to enlist for a dance sequence when he was briefly press agent for the Swedish Ballet.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: SCHMIDT LAMENTS U.S. IMPORT DROP
description: BONN, May 28The value of West Germany's exports to the United States in March sank 46 per cent below the level of last year, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said today, expressing fear about the strategic consequences of the slump in the United States for the Western alliance.

title: STAUFFER SETS RISE ON CARBON DISULFIDE
description: The Stauffer Chemical Cornpany aid yesterday it would raise the price of carbon disulfide by $20 a ton, effective July 1.

title: U.S. Track Team Ends China Tour
description: PEKING, May 28 (UPI)Li Yunpiao a husky, 37yearold coal miner, powered China's track and field team today to its best showing yet against a touring United States team. But his hammerthrow victory wasn't nearly enough to keep the United States from making a clean sweep of the three  city, goodwill series of meets.

title: Lack of Staff Hampers Cancer Unit
description: WASHINGTON, May 28The director of the National Cancer Institute told ?? staff today that the huge cancer program may soon have to curb its spending because of lack of manpower to administer the funds properly.

title: FORD CALLED LAX ON GUN CONTROLS
description: LOS ANGELES, May 28Representative Robert McGlory of Illinois, a senior Republican on the House Judiciary Committee. today said that President Ford had failed to provide leadership in the search for a way to control the level of gun violence in American society.

title: D. W. Griffith Honored By Issue of 10c Stamp
description: LOS ANGELES, May 28The United States Postal Service yesterday dedicated the commemorative 10cent D. W. Griffith stamp in memory of the Hollywood film maker who was born 100 years ago. The ceremonies were held at the American Film Institute in Beverly Hills, in keeping with a Postal Service tradition of holding such events at the subject's birthplace or a locale he made famous.

title: City Goes All Out in Bid for Democratic Convention
description: When the elevator doors at 666 Fifth Avenue closed on the arms of a West Coast Congressman yesterday afternoon, he shouted in dismay. I'm voting California! he protested

title: Gambling Legalization Urged At Hearings in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (AP) All forms of gambling; including sports wagering, should be legalized because of the [general apathy of the police, courts and public in enforcing gaming laws, the National Gambling Commission was told today.

title: Winning 21 for the Skipper
description: Showing the benefits of a winter weight program demanded by Coach Stan Wnek, Irvington High won all its preseason baseball games and followed with victories in its first eight regular  season games. Then Wnek developed a physical problem, which needed exploratory surgery and a long rest. He did not want to leave this team which he felt could be the best in his 21 years of coaching.

title: Marion Smith Is Wed To Harold Weinstock
description: Marion Smith of New York, widow of Sanford J. Smith, was married here at noon yesterday to Harold J. Weinstock, also of New York.

title: Whalers Trade Green
description: HARTFORD, May 28 (AP)  Ted Green, the New England Whalers defenseman and a 13year veteran of professional hockey, has been traded to the Winnipeg Jets. Green signed a multiyear contract with the Manitoba team today.

title: Private Dumps Ease Pressures On Meadowland Disposal Plan
description: LYNDHURST, May 28The erouting of commercial and Industrial wastes into privately owned landfills in the Meadowands has cut substantially into the amount of refuse being deposited at the county dump nere and extended its life by approximately two years, Bennett Mazur, Bergen County Freeholder, said today.

title: FORD, IN BRUSSELS, AFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR NATO NATIONS
description: BRUSSELS, May 28President Ford arrived here today for a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and declared that our commitment to this alliance will not falter.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Eleven autoinsurance companies that provide coverage for nearly half a million motorists in the state asked yesterday for rate increases of up to 16.7 per cent. The State Insurance Department said the request for the largest increase came from Nationwide, which covers 48,408 cars. State Farm Mutual, which insures more than 171,000 cars, asked for a 16.2 per cent increase.

title: White Plains Republicans Pick a Democrat for Mayor
description: The White Plains Republican party, which dominated city government until the Democrats took control last year, nominated a Democratic Councilman, Alfred Del Vecchio, Tuesday night to run for Mayor next November.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was stated incorrectly in The New York Times yesterday that the New York State Department of Parks and Recreation had discontinued arrangements for campers to reserve campsites in its facilities through Ticketron. Actually, the agency never booked its campsites through Ticketron. Campers can, however, book campsites through Ticketron in the Catskill and Adirondack forest preserves, which are administered by the state's Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: People in Sports
description: Ron Reed, the former National Basketball Association player who had been enjoying indifferent success pitching this season for the Atlanta Braves, found himself in new surroundings today.

title: For Children, a Beloved Storyteller Is Celebrated
description: Films

title: United Backs TWA in Seeking 5%
description: Frank Borman, Eastern Air Lines' new president, disclosed yesterday the company's support of American Airlines' bid for a new 6 per cent fare increase, saying the increase was all the more vital in view of the Administration's action raising fuel costs.

title: Carrier's First Black Ink Since August
description: Pan American World Airways reported yesterday a $19.3million profit equal to 47 cents a share, far April.

title: NATO's Summit
description: The third summit conference in 26 years of the West's grand alliance is designed to impress Europe with America's steadfastness, America with Europe's confidence and Moscow with bothlest the Kremlin seek to exploit the West's economic crisis and America's setbacks ranging from Vietnam to the Mediterranean.

title: Track Meet Draws Protest
description: Four winners of events at the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor track meet will not be competing Saturday for an outdoor title.

title: Makeup of an Acid That Causes Gout Is Determined
description: Those who suffer from gout know the meaning of pain, usually an excruciating swelling of the big toe. Doctors know the immediate cause, an excess of uric acid in the blood stream. But only now has a scientist determined the molecular structure of the tiny, needlelike uric acid crystals that collect in the joints and bring on the misery.

title: NAME TO SUBMIT 2 BUDGETS TODAY ONE A CRISIS PLAN
description: Mayor Beanie is expected to submit two budgets to the City Council and the Board of Estimate todayone balanced with new state aid and taxes he is seeking and the other a crisis budget reflecting the drastic economies that he says will have to be made if no aid is forthcoming.

title: Excerpts From Kissinger's Paris Talks
description: PARIS. May 28Following are excerpts from speeches delivered here by Secretary of State Kissinger before a ministerial meeting of the International Energy Agency yesterday and before the ministerial council of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development today:

title: The Way Of The World
description: What part should considerations of law and morality play in the conduct of international politics? Are they mere distractions from reality? Is power the only motive force, the only true guide to policy?

title: SMELTER FIGHTS CURB ON ARSENIC
description: TACOMA, Wash., May 24A smelter that refines 8 per cent of the nation's copper and provides a $12million annual payroll to 1,100 employes here is embroiled in a dispute over its air pollution.

title: STATES AND CITIES HELPING REFUGEES
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI)) States and cities as well as thousands of persons across the country are volunteering to help resettle displaced Indochinese refugees, the chief spokesman for President Ford's refugee task force said today.

title: Chris Evert Gains Semifinal at Rome
description: ROME, May 29 (AP)The defending champion, Chris Evert, scored one for her sister and herself today as she advanced to the semifinals of the $120,000 Italian open tennis championships.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Fernando Sanchez has developed a following in two disparate fields, furs and lingerie. Perhaps it's not as unlikely a combination as it seems, both being part of the luxury trade.

title: Ida Klaus, at Age?, Is Retiring From City Side of Bargaining Table
description: Ida Klaus, who has played a key role in shaping the collective  bargaining rights of the nation's public employes, is retiring as one of the city's top labor negotiators in the midst of a fiscal crisis that she thinks shows the need for reappraising the bargaining system.

title: Motorcycle and Bus On Noise Control List
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI)Motorcycle buses have been picked by the Environmental Protection Agency as candidates for noise control.

title: RATE WAR RAGES AMONG BROKERS
description: A month after the end of fixed commissions, a rate war is raging among stockbrokers, and some of the nation's leading financial institutions warned yesterday that it could lead to the death of one or more Wall Street houses.

title: GRACE E. B. MURPHY, NATURALIST, WRITER
description: Grace E. Barstow Murphy, a wellknown naturalist, conservationist and author, died Wednesday in a nursing home in Seattle. She was 86 years old and had formerly lived in Stony Brook. L. I.

title: Ford's Motorcade Halts As Giscard's Goes By
description: BRUSSELS, May 29 (UPI) President Ford's motorcade was stopped today. It took another president to do it. Mr. Ford was leaving the meeting at NATO headquarters when the police motorcyclists leading the way suddenly signaled a halt.

title: 10 CORRECTION AIDES SUE TO LIMIT HOURS
description: Ten correction officers, contending that forced scheduled overtime violated their civil rights and deprived them of normal relationships with wives and children, petitioned the State Supreme Court yesterday to enjoin the city from assigning them the extra hours.

title: Government Will Study A.T.&T. Private Rates
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission agreed today to investigate recent rate changes by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for its privateline data transmission service.

title: Litton Industries Profit Fell 3.3% in Third Fiscal Quarter; Others Report Earnings Results
Beame Honors Cary Grant For Theater Contributions
description: Mayor Beame took some time off from his budgetary problems yesterday to present a special award to Cary Grant for his contributions to the American theater.

title: 2d Senior Official Haunts Ford Plane
description: BRUSSELS, May 29 (UPI)  Correspondents have been hearing and reporting comments on American foreign policy from three basic sources these nays: Secretary of State Kissinger, his official spokesman. Robert Anderson, and a senior United States official traveling on Mr. Kissinger's plane.

title: F16's Form Much Flashier Than Competitors in Paris
description: PARIS, May 29 (UPI)Three jet fighters competing for the Western European market displayed their form today at the annual Paris air show.

title: City's Final Bid Impresses DemocraticParley Panel
description: Governor Carey promised Fifth Avenue and all it offers to the planners of the 1976 Democratic convention yesterday and generally wooed them so well that some conceded for the first time that they favored New York as the convention site.

title: Sanford Is 6th to Enter Democratic Race
description: WASHINGTON, May 29Terry Sanford, the president of Duke University and onetime Governor of North Carolina, became today the sixth Democrat to enter the 1976 Presidential race. He is the fourth entrant with a Southern accent and the first to make a confrontation with Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama the central test of his candidacy.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HIGH NOON Baby, Won't You Please Come Home, chanted the husky, bassist leader of Balaban and Cats, and most of the customers looked comfortably at home at one of the new jazz lunch sessions, Fridays only, in Eddie Condon's, 144 West 54th Street. The oneday, noonto3 P.M. policy is geared for business people the area, tourists (the Americana and Hilton Hotels are nearby) and general jazz fans, all of whom seemed represented last week. You can perch up front at the bar or drink and eat at the tables of this smugly atmospheric tunnel, decorated with large pictures of jazz celebrities.

title: The Party Faithful Have Own Worries
description: Like most of the party regulars who managed to make to within whispering distance of Mayor Beanie at last night's Queens County Democratic dinner, Wayne McNally congratulated the Mayor on his budget message. But, like many others, Mr. McNally also had a personal concern.

title: Grand Jury Finds Abuses Of Patients at Greystone
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 29 Allegations of patient beatings and other abuses that led a group of student psychologists to resign from Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital last fall were verified today by a Morris County grand jury that described the hospital's appearance to the mentally ill as a prison without exit.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
William H. Hendelson, 70, Of Funk & Wagnalls, Dies
description: William H. Hendelson, former editorial director of Funk & Wagnalls, Inc., book publishers, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 400 East 57th Street.

title: U.S. WILL DEFEND VOTING FUND LAW
description: WASHINGTON, May 29The Justice Department will defend the controversial Federal campaign finance law against a court challenge to its constitutionality, but will urge limitations on the authority of the newly created Federal Election Commission to enforce its provisions, a department spokesman said tonight.

title: A New Economic Order
description: WASHINGTON, May 29In the last three weeks, Secretary of State Kissinger has made three important speeches on America's future world economic policy, which have been the source of the most intense controversy at the highest levels of the Government.

title: Jobless Rate Declines in City and State
description: Unemployment declined in the city and the state last month, but the drop was smaller than usual for April, indicating that the recession still had a strong grip on the New York economy, the State Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCH

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CUNNINGHAM DANCE COMBINES IMAGES
description: Publicity releases infrequently give one the precise texture of a dance event. Surprisingly, Merce Cunningham's Westbeth at Westbeth was just as it was described in a release, a combination of images lessthanlifesize, lifesize (and live) and largerthanlife. It was a test or an exercise in perception, given at the Cunningham studio Wednesday evening by company members and accompanying video monitors.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Superior Court Judge Merritt Lane Jr. refused to open Deal's beaches to the public, saying that the state's Public Advocate had not proved that the residentsonly policy had caused irreparable harm to the public.

title: Met's Tour of Japan Gets a Fine Start
description: TOKYO, May 29The Metropolitan Opera opened here tonight and from the first haunting strains of Japan's national anthem, Kimigayo, to the last dying gasp of Violetta, the Japanese audience seemed enthralled.

title: STOCK PRICES SLIP AS TRADING SLOWS
description: The stock market ended slightly lower yesterday in slower trading despite new indications that the economy was improving.

title: California Farm Workers Law Passed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29The California Legislature completed passage today of the Agricultural Labor Relations Act and sent it to the man who proposed it, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., who will sign it next week.

title: RESIDENCY PLAN GAINS IN COUNCIL
description: The City Council's State Legislation Committee approved yesterday two residency requirement bills for city employes in the form of home rule messages to the Legislature. The full Council is expected to pass both bills today.

title: Golf Religion From Japan Stymied in U.S.
description: MALIBU, Calif., May 29The score is less than perfect these days for the Church of Perfect Liberty, which preaches that living is a lot like playing golf.

title: Butz Expects Farm Export Drop
description: Farm exports, the nation's top source of foreignexchange earnings, are expected to drop 10 per cent to $20billion this year because of recent declines in grain prices, Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said here yesterday.

title: COURT BARS SHIFT IN BEEF GRADING
description: OMAHA, May 29 (AP)Federal District Judge Robert V. Denney today barred the Department of Agriculture from putting new beef grading standards into effect.

title: Advertising
description: The guidelines and proposed guidelines for the use of endorsement and testimonial advertising, as announced last week by the Federal Trade Commission, should not cause too many problems for reputable advertisers and ad agencies.

title: Captive Whooping Cranes Have Chick
description: WASHINTON, May 29The first whooping crane chick ever born to parents hatched and raised in captivity emerged from its shell just before 7:30 A.M. today at the Patuxent Wildlife Research Center raising fresh hope that the huge white birdswho now number 77may wing their way back from the edge of extinction.

title: MAYOR EMOTIONAL
description: Mayor Beame, declaring that in the absence of new money we must move from programed recovery to shock therapy, yesterday submitted what he called an unthinkable twolevel budget that at its worst would require cutting the payroll by 67,347 in the next fiscal year.

title: Gaynor Brennan, 72, Dies; Connecticut Legislator, Aide
description: STAMFORD, Conn., May 29  E. Gaynor Brennan, former chairman of the State Liquor Control Commission, former City Court judge, a member of both houses of the Connecticut State Legislature and an athlete, died here today. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: Station Official Gives Letter Of Radicals to Coast Jury
description: LOS ANGELES, May 29 (AP) Will Lewis, general manager of radio station KPFKFM, has turned over a letter received by the station from a radical group to a Federal grand jury here.

title: SHARP RISE MADE IN MONEY SUPPLY
description: The money supply showed a large increase for the third week in a row, and business loans at major New York City banks continued to decline harply.

title: Iran Air Starts Service Here; Chief Sees Pan Am Pact Near
description: Iran's national airline opened service from Teheran to New York yesterday in a manifestation of that oil country's bold aeronautical expansion program.

title: Neighborhood Change Virtually Unnoticed At Settlement House
description: In the beginning, 82 years ago, the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side was a place for poor immigrants, mostly Jewish, to be assimilated into the New World. For years it served thousands of people whose middleclass children and grandchildren still think fondly of the place.

title: Purification of Uranium by Laser Detailed
description: WASHINGTON, May 29Two independent methods using lasers to extract uranium suitable for bombs or power plants were made public here today after long being kept secret.

title: Neighborhood Change Is Virtually Unnoticed At Settlement House
description: In the beginning, 82 years ago, the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side was a place for poor immigrants, mostly Jewish, to he assimilated into the New World. For years it served thousands of people whose middleclass children and grandchildren still think fondly of the place.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Department of Agriculture announced that effective July 1 it would take over inspection of intrastate meat and poultry plants in New Jersey. A spokesman for the department said the action was being taken at the state's request. New Jersey's inspection program is being phased out as a result of inaction on legislation that would have continued it.

title: Magic Show Star Turns Party Into an Outdoor Treat for 250
description: At high noon yesterday at the Grand Army Plaza, Fifth Avenue and Central Park South, melting ice cream trickled down the sides of some onlookers' cones as about 250 persons watched a magician do all sorts of fantastic tricks, except make the 80degree heat disappear.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article about Joseph Papp's production plans in The New York Times Tuesday erroneously stated that the Mitzi Newhouse Theater in Lincoln Center would be devoted to the production of classics. The Newhouse Theater will become a children's theater. The Vivian Beaumont Theater will he devoted to revivals of classics.

title: New Economic Indicator Signals Imminent Upturn
description: WASHINGTON, May 29The Government's new composite index of leading indicators, which is intended to foretell economic activity, gave off a strong signal today that an upturn in the economy was imminent. The index had declined steeply, with only one shortlived interruption, since the summer of 1973. It nearly leveled off in February. Then, today's report revealed, it turned up by 1 per cent in March and then increased by a record 4.2 per cent in April.

title: Reserve Reports
Major League Baseball
description: Friday, May 30, 1975

title: TEMPORARY PLAN
description: The state yesterday advanced New York City $200million in welfare funds originally scheduled to be delivered next year, staving off a threatened default today by the city but only temporarily easing the city's cashflow problems.

title: U2 Crashes in West Germany on Flight Called New and Advanced Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON, May 29An American U2 reconnaissance aircraft conducting a new and advanced kind of electronic surveillance over Western Europe crashed today near the town of Winterberg, West Germany, a highly placed government source said tonight.

title: Transcript of Mayor Beame's Speech Describing an Austerity Budget for City
description: Members of the Board of Estimate and City Council. and all New Yorkers: Last month I proposed an austerity expense budget for 197576. It contained major cutbacks in personnel and city programs. It also calls for additional state aid and local taxing powers to permit the city to fill the $641million gap in this budget without devastating our services.

title: 3 VYING CARRIERS VOTED IN RAIL PLAN
description: Directors of the United States Railway Association reaffirmed yesterday by a 7to1 vote, with two board members abstaining and one not in attendance, its proposal of Feb. 26 that there be three competitive railroads in the Northeast and directed its staff to pursue plans for this operation.

title: 4 Indicted in New Orleans On Grain Fraud Charges
description: WASHINGTON, May 29A licensed grain inspector, three other men and a Louisiana corporation were indicted today by a Federal grand jury that has been investigating the handling of grain shipments in the port of New Orleans.

title: Urban Homesteading Faltering In Fight Against Blight of Cities
description: BALTIMORE  Urban homesteading, regarded by city plan. ners two years ago as a major solution to urban blight, appears to be losing some of its luster after experience in more than two dozen cities.

title: Rails to Trails
description: Of all forms of transportationexcept for the bicycle the railroad is environmentally the most benevolent. Planes, trucks, and automobiles use much higher ratios of fuel to carry comparable amounts of cargo or passengers and they cause more pollution to boot.

title: New Economic Indicator Signals Imminent Upturn
description: WASHINGTON, May 29The Government's new composite index of leading indicators, which is intended foretell economic activity, gave off a strong signal today that an upturn in the economy was imminent. The index had declined steeply, with only one shortlived interruption, since the summer of 1973. It nearly leveled off in February. Then, today's report revealed, it turned up by 1 per cent in March and then increased by a record 4.2 per cent in April.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, May 29, 1975

title: 2 Share Lead at 68 In L.P.G.A. Event
description: BALTIMORE. May 29 (AP) Debbie Austin and Sandra Spuzich, among the early starters in the record field of 96, shot fiveunderpar 68's today and shared the firstround lead in the $55.000 Ladies Professional Golf Association championship.

title: Bond Prices Appear to Stabilize in Slow Trading
Beame Invokes Fame Of 13 Sons of the City
description: Thirteen famous Americans who grew up or went to school in New York City found their way into Mayor Beame's budget oration last night. All were cited as products of a city which generates greatness.

title: UtilityBill Aid for Elderly Urged by P.U.C. Member
description: McAfee, May 29A New Jersey Public Utilities Commissioner suggested today that federally subsidized utilities stamps, similar to food stamps, be distributed to lowincome elderly citizens to help them pay for the rising cost of their gas, electricity and telephone bills.

title: U.S. Voices Concern Over 9 Americans Held by Vietnamese
description: WASHINGTON, May 29The State Department voiced serious concern today about the fate of nine American citizens who have been held prisoner by Communist authorities in South Vietnam for more than six weeks.

title: Theater:
Physicians Here Drafting Master Plan for Protest
description: Doctors in and around New York City were drawing up rosters of volunteers yesterday to man hospital emergency rooms as early as next Sunday when physicians prepare to cut off all but emergency service in protest over medical malpractice insurance.

title: For a Namibian Solution
description: On the surface there would seem to be little prospect for progress toward a negotiated agreement providing for selfdetermination and independence for Namibia (SouthWest Africa) in the United Nations Security Council deliberations that resume today. Yet, the gap between the U.N. position and that of South Africa, which has controlled Namibia for half a century, has clearly narrowed since the Security Council made its most recent demands on the Pretoria Government last November.

title: 6 Are Killed in Tribal Clashes In Territory of Afars and Issas
description: DJIBOUTI, Territory of Afars and Issas, May 29 (Agence FrancePresse)Six men were killed and 15 wounded in tribal clashes here last night, bringing the official death toll since Sunday to 11, with 250 wounded.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Article 1  No Title
Variety of Fish Taken In Nearby Waterways
description: AREA A  Right now, around Long Beach Island there's a little bit of everything, but not very much of anything, is the description of John Falkiewicz of Surf City, N. J. Among the variety of fish he was describing were bass, weakfish, summer flounder and blues. Blues are in heavier supply off Barnegat Inlet where 5to 15pounders have been taken and at Island Beach State Park where red fin lures have been used to pull in 3pounders. Striped bass in the 30pound class are running two to four miles off Barnegat Inlet.

title: Mexican Orchestra Sets 10Day Tour Of 7 Cities in U.S.
description: MEXICO CITY, May 29The Symphony Orchestra of the State of Mexico is to give concerts in seven United States cities in June as part of Mexico's contribution to Bicentennial celebrations.

title: Text of President Ford's Address to the Leaders of the North Atlantic Alliance
description: BRUSSELS. May 29 (Reuters)Following is the text of President Ford's address today to leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Britain's Common Market Debate Turns to Gimmickry
description: LONDON, May 29The latest news in the heated debate over whether Britain should remain in the Common Market is that campaigners for one side found a Norwegian  speaking housewife and sent her to Oslo, while the other side produced the 7yearold grandniece of a Cabinet minister.

title: James Taylor in Concert: More Tastes of Soft Rock
description: James Taylor returned to Carnegie Hall Wednesday night for the first in a series of three concerts in what will hopefully become an annual event. Mr. Taylor's performing schedule became a little sparse for a while, but now he seems willing to keep rm the road at least some each year, which is as it should be.

title: U.S. Backs Tactical Atom Arms Against a Soviet Push in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, May 29Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger has told Congress that a conventional Sovietled attack against Western Europe may force the United States to use battlefield nuclear weapons to avoid defeat.

title: The Dilemmas of Flexible Containment
description: PARISEurope is not Vietnam. This is the essential message that the Atlantic Alliance summit meeting and President Ford's visit to Madrid and Rome are supposed to convey. This is also what Europeans want to hear. But they are likely to be more worried than reassured if they do not perceive in their American visitors an awareness that the Europe of 1975 is not the Europe of 1948 either, and that in Southern Europe in particular the lessons of American experiences with the Third World are at least as relevant as those of containment in Central Europe.

title: Music: By Vita Brevis
description: A remarkable amount of crossfertilization goes on among this city's thousands of performing groups. The better freelance musicians keep busy on so many different fronts that a computer might be needed to sort out the strands that interconnect the bewildering variety of ensembles. A group calling itself Vita Brevis, for example, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night, and while the performers were all familiar from other settings the mix they prepared was both special and captivating.

title: Du Pont Raises NylonDacron Prices
description: E. T. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., announced yesterday price increases ranging up to 8 per cent on a broad range of nylon and dacron polyester filament yarns. The increases, effective immediately, cover nylon yarns used for texwring, some lightdenier industrial applications and knitted and woven apparel. Also affected are selected nylon yarns used in women's hosiery.

title: FORD SEES DANGER TO NATO INTEGRITY IN SPECIAL PACTS
description: BRUSSELS, May 29President Ford warned today that partial membership or special arrangements could endanger the Atlantic alliance.

title: Neighborhoods: Woodside Distrusts the Politicians
description: Anger, skepticism and distrust of the politicians appear to be widespread among the city's middle and lowerincome classes after months of listening to talk of the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Inman, Casper, Irwin Lead in Golf
description: ATLANTA, May 29The Atlanta Golf Classic, a nineyear fixture that is the showcase for the biggest guns on the professional tour, got its name back today and, with the 1975 renewal, a spate of 66's and an hour of rain.

title: Chile Accused of Killing Labor Leaders
description: GENEVA, May 29A threemember factfinding commission appointed by the International Labor Organization accused Chile's military Government today of having tortured labor leaders to death or executed them because of their trade union activities.

title: Military in Lisbon Split on Parties' Role
description: LISBON, May 20An effort by radical Portuguese officers to deprive the political parties of any share in government appears to have been defeated for the moment.

title: F.T.C. SET TO ACCEPT KAISER SETTLEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission announced today it intended to accept a negotiated settlement under which the Kaiser Steel Corporation of Oakland, Calif., would dispose of three specialty tubesteel mills acquired in 1970 and accept restrictions on its business at the other six mills,

title: I.B.M REALIGNING SEVERAL DIVISIONS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday the realignment of a number of data processing development activities.

title: Sylvania and RCA Raise Color TV Set Prices for 1976
description: Two major television set makers announced yesterday what the higher price tags on their 1976 lines would be. They had earlier said they planned such price moves.

title: Diet Foods: Consumers Usually Pay More to Weigh Less
description: The labels read Calories Reduced  Sugar Free, Fat Removed, Packed in Water. The message to the consumer is clear. Thin is beautiful. The message to the retailer is equally as clear. Diet foods are a bonanza.

title: A Rifkind Professorship: Proposed for Columbia
description: Simon H. Rifkind, the former Federal judge whose legal career spans almost a half century, has been recommended by the board of trustees of the Columbia University School of Law for a professorship to be named in his honor.

title: LEONIA STUDENTS STAGE A PROTEST
description: Fifty students from Leonia's Alternative High School Program held a friendly protest yesterday on the lawn outside the Board of Education, asking for increased student participation in school decisions and a guarantee that their school be made a permanent rather than experimental part of the school system.

title: BROOK HAVEN HEAD OF G.O.P. INDICTED
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., May 29Richard D. Zeidler, Republican chairman of the Town of Brookhaven, was indicted here today on charges of violating state election laws by authorizing the use of party funds to support organizationbacked candidates in a primary.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Now here's a nice little Japanese restaurantTokubai, at 1425 Second Avenue between 74th and 75th Streets. At this stage of the game, with Japanese food no longer a novelty in New York, I hardly know whether to say that Tokubai is slightly Westernized or that New York palates are becoming Orientalized.

title: Sanford Is 6th to Enter Democratic Race
description: WASHINGTON, May 29Terry Sanford, the president of Duke University and onetime Governor of North Carolina, became today the sixth Democrat to enter the 1976 Presidential race. He is the fourth entrant with a Southern accent and the first to make a confrontation with Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama the central test of his candidacy.

title: ROCKLEIGH EXEMPT IN HOUSING RULING
description: TRENTON, May 29 (AP)The Appellate Division of State Superior Court ruled today that the recent landmark court case ordering equal housing opportunity in suburban communities did not apply to Rockleigh Borough in Bergen County.

title: FORD VETOES BILL TO PRODUCE JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 President Ford vetoed today a $5.3billion package designed to fund jobproducing projects across the nation through 1976.

title: Young Fellow Named Ezzard Charles
description: Mike Jacobs was ailing when Joe Louis retired as undefeated heavyweight champion of the world, and Mike's lawyer, Sol Strauss, was running the Twentieth Century Boxing Club for him. WrongWay Sol, they called him, because he removed his glasses to read, took his teeth out to eat and, if he was interested in what you were saying, shut off his hearing aid. Somebody asked Sol how he expected to fill the void created by Louis's departure. There's a young fellow out in Cincinnati, he said, named Ezzard Charles. They tell me he is a high school graduate, loves good music, speaks well, wears a necktie and has nice manners. He seems to have everything you would want in a heavyweight championif he can fight.

title: Lottery Drawing Shifted
description: Beginning next week the New York State lottery will hold its regular weekly drawings on Thursdays between 4 and 4:30 P.M. rather than on Fridays. The change, according to the announcement, is being made to draw greater attention to the winning numbers each week and it is hoped it will reduce the number of unclaimed prizes.

title: F.D.A. Urges Ban On Antiperspirants Having Zirconium
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration proposed today a ban on aerosol antiperspirant sprays containing zirconium, saying their benefits are not worth the risks of lung disease to which millions of consumers are exposed.

title: Tomahawks Top Boston Bolts, 2011
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., May 29 The Long Island Tomahawks took a 61 lead after 11 minutes 4 seconds of the first period and defeated the Boston Bolts, 2011, in a National Lacrosse League game tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Husak, Czech Party Chief, Also Assumes Presidency
description: PRAGUE, May 29 (UPI)The Czechoslovak Parliament unanimously elected Dr. Gustav Husak President of Czechoslovakia today to replace Gen. Ludvik Svoboda, 79, who had been unable to carry out his duties for more than a year because of illness.

title: No Recourse ?
description: At a time demanding the highest statesmanship and candor from the city's elected leader, Mayor Beame has offered demagoguery and dissembling.

title: FORD SEES DANGER TONATO INTEGRITY IN SPECIAL PACTS
description: BRUSSELS, May 29President Ford warned today that partial membership or special arrangements could endanger the Atlantic alliance.

title: Ordinary East European Finds Some Drawbacks in Detente
description: BUDAPESTWhile Eastern European officials and people with an official reason to consort with outsiders are more relaxed in their relations nowadays, in the atmosphere of dtente, those outside the privileged circle feel more isolated than ever.

title: British Petroleum Says Earnings Fell
description: The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., reported yesterday a 62.5 per cent drop in firstquarter net income to $102million, or 26 cents a share, from the yearearlier $272million, or 70 cents a share.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: In their practices, two black psychiatrists find themselves often trying to help black children unable to cope with their blackness. Some of the children are consumed by hatred for whites, others accept the image of blacks as evildoers and so do evil, or they use racial issues to disguise essentially nonracial fears about themselves.

title: Contract Awards
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has received a $36million contract from the General Services Administration for electric typewriters.

title: Palestinians at Geneva
description: One of the major worries about the proposed Geneva Conference on the Middle East may no longer be valid. This was the belief that the gathering would be immobilized from its opening day by demands that Yasir Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization be admitted as a fullfledged participant.

title: Rufus C. Rose, Puppeteer, Dies; Was Creator of Howdy Doody
description: Rufus C. Rose, the puppeteer who was the creator of Howdy Doody, a silly, frecklefaced marionette that enthralled television's first generation of moppets from 1947 to 1960, died yesterday at Lawrence and Memorial Hospital in New London, Conn. His age was 70.

title: CABLETV CONCERN IN NETWORK STEP
description: Teleprompter Corporation, the largest operator of cableTV systems in the country, announced yesterday that had reached an agreement in principle to carry the paytelevision service of Home Box Office on the 82 largest of its 140 systems.

title: View in May: Recovery
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon and Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, with plenty of support from outside the Government, have been saying for months that although halting the recession is the nation's No. 1 shortterm problem curbing inflation remains the big problem for the intermediate and longer term.

title: Multinational Shipping Unit
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 29 (AP)Eight Carribean countries have announced the formation of a $30million multinational shipping company in a joint effort to protect their national freight lines from the traditional big shippers. An agreement forming the company was signed yesterday by delegates from Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Jamaica, Mexico, Panama, Nicaragua and Venezuela.

title: New I.L.G.W.U. Head
description: Sol Chick Chaikin, who was elected yesterday as the ninth president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, represents a new breed of leader at the helm of the union that charted the way out of the sweatshops of an earlier era. I'm neither David Dubinsky nor Louis Stulberg, Mr. Chaikin told the union's executive board in paying tribute to his predecessors, following his election. I'm Sol Chaikin. I was born in this century. I was born and educated in this country. I'm not better for that reason, but I'm different even as the challenges that confront us and our union are different from what they were 43 years ago when Dubinsky became president, or nine years ago when Stulberg became president.

title: PRICES IRREGULAR ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in overthecounter trading finished mixed yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Sadat Leaves Cairo to Meet With Ford
description: CAIRO, May 29Egypt is approaching the Salzburg conference between President Ford and President Anwar elSadat with Egyptian officials saying that the next step in the Middle East is up to the United States.

title: TV: Warble, Attractive for Children
description: In the area of children's programing, the games stations play are endlessly diverting. For present instance, there is Big Blue Marble, a series financed and syndicated as a public service by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. The halfhours offer a nice opportunity to move children's material outside the earlymorning weekend ghetto, to recognize the fact that children watch television at other hours of the day on other days of the week.

title: Raising the Ante in the Budget Poker Game
description: In laying out his $11.9billion crisis budget yesterdayin an unusual speech before the City Council and the Board of Estimate that was pointedly timed for live coverage over the evening news television programs  Mayor Beame abruptly raised the stakes in the pokergame facedown with the Republican State Senators in Albany.

title: Books of The Times
description: Although publication of these memoirs 80 years after their composition will not greatly alter historians' delineation of Ulysses Simpson Grant, it is likely to direct new interest to the woman who also occupies that ponderous tomb on the site of the Revolutionary Battle of Harlem Heights in Manhattan. Apart from Ishbel Ross's The General's Wife, which appeared 16 years ago, Julia Grant has been something of a biographical cypher. Miss Ross was permitted to read the memoirs, but not to draw from the manuscript in any way, so that her book, as good as it is, lacks the flavor of Mrs. Grant's marvelously appealing idiom. Now, however, it is possible to get closer and to realize that Mrs. Grant was a remarkable person in her own right.

title: JEWS' BOYCOTT CALL IS DEPLORED BY GULF
description: PITTSBURGH, May 29The Gulf Oil Corporation has expressed deep concern about a resolution adopted by 300 American Jewish leaders endorsing a boycott against the concern because of its support of what were termed Arab propaganda efforts.

title: Notes on People
description: Savoring the unstructured schedule of her own visit to Europe with the President. Betty Ford explored shops and cobbled medieval areas in Brussels yesterday before lunching at the only restaurant outside France to boast three stars in the Guide Michelin. She wore a bright red dress, a pale blue tweed cape and a redwhiteandblue scarf hearing the Presidential seal. To a shopkeeper who tried to give her a tiny porcelain swan, she said with a smile, That's very sweet but I couldn't accept.

title: H.E.W. to Halt Individual Bias Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON, May 29The Department of Health, Education and Welfare plans to stop investigating discrimination complaints from individuals.

title: Unveilings
description: LEVINHarold. The unveiling of monument in loving memory of Harold Levin will take place at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, N.Y., Plot 407, Section 25, on Sunday, June 1, 1975, at 2 P.M. No postponement.

title: U.N. Assays Geothermal Energy
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29Geothermal energythat vast reservoir of heat bottled up beneath the earth's crustis still (despite past choruses of hope and promise) rather like a great genie yet to be uncorked for the working of wonders.

title: TURKS' NEW STATE IN CYPRUS EVOLVES
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, May 29Almost three months after the Turkish Cypriotes announced that they were forming their own state, that state has become a political and social reality.

title: Levi and Aides Differ on Data Senate Unit Has on F.B.I. Spying
description: WASHINGTON, May 29Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that a great deal of information about the intelligence activities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had already been provided to the Senate select committee that is examining the bureau's operations as part of an overall inquiry into the Federal intelligence community.

title: Pacifists' Property Is Sold
description: CINCINNATI, May 29 (UPI) A pacafist group's property was sold for $25,100 at auction yesterday to satisfy delinquent taxes. The Internal Revenue Service had been batling with Gano Peacemakers, Inc., for three years over a $24,408.12 delinquent tax bill. The service said that Ernest and Marian Bromley, members of the group, who live on the two acres in Butler County near here, refused to pay the taxes. The Bromleys obpected to paying taxes because some of the money was spent on military defense.

title: TOP MENTAL AIDE ANSWERS CRITICS
description: ALBANY, May 29 Nearly five months after he began running the Department of Mental Hygiene as the acting commissioner, Dr. Lawrence C. Kolb went before the Senate Finance Committee today for the start of longdelayed and unusually bitter confirmation hearings.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: ROME, May 29The Government today sent a bill to Parliament that would increase guaranteed state subsidies for Italy's deficitridden opera houses from, at present, $25million to $96million annually.

title: Soviet Forward Picked by Jazz
description: The New Orleans Jazz chose Aleksandr Belov, a 6foot7inch, 220pound forward from the Soviet Union, yesterday on the 10th and final round of the National Basketball Association draft.

title: People and Business
description: Reginald H. Jones, chairman of the General Electric Company, urged tax reform yesterday to ease the shortage of capital needed to energize economic growth and employment.

title: ARLEN WILL DROP ATLANTIC STORES
description: The Arlen Realty and Development Corporation announced yesterday that its Korvette stores division had 60.5 per cent lower net income in the fiscal year ended Feb. 28 and that it would discontinue both the Atlantic Department Stores and importmanufacturing operation by the end of the year.

title: Giscard Supports European Unity Goals
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (Reuters)  President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France said in an interview published today that the European Economic Community needed a push toward political unity.

title: Monmouth Begins Year of Questions
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., May 29 Facing what management calls an experimental year, Monmouth Park began its 30th modern season of thoroughbred racing today with a mixture of pride, apprehension and mild resentment.

title: Gold
description: Selected world gold prices Thursday.

title: Vesuvius Loses Stake, Wins Title
description: DEVON, Pa., May 29Vesuvius won the amateurowner jumper championship at the Devon Horse Show tonight although he did not score in the final class.

title: GORDON A. SKEAN
description: TOKYO, May 29 (AP)Gordon A. Skean, general manager of the Pacific edition of Stars & Stripes, the armedforces newspaper, died today in a Tokyo hospital. He was 61 years old.

title: BEAME PROPOSALS DECRIED BY UNIONS
description: Mayor Beame's crisis budget proposals brought forecasts last night from the head of the firemen's union that a lot more people are going to die and from the sanitation union's chief that the city will be covered by oceans of garbage.

title: Some U.S. Citizens Allowed to Retain Land in Philippines
description: MANILA, May 28 (UPI)President Ferdinand E. Marcos, overriding a Supreme Court decision barring Americans from owning land in the Philippines, has issued a martial law degree allowing certain United States citizens to retain their landholdings.

title: Synagogue Here Marks Closing by British in '76
description: Two British soldiers entered Congregation Shearith Israel in lower Manhattan during the Torah reading almost 200 years ago, reportedly shot at the cantor and threw the scroll out into the street.

title: Trainer Is Fined $6,000
description: A fine of $6,000, the largest in the history of thoroughbred racing in this state, or the alternative of a 60day suspension, was imposed on Frank (Pancho) Martin yesterday by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board, The leading trainer in this state for three of the last four seasons, Martin was handed these choices at the offices of the New York State Racing and Wagering Board for violations of the drugging rules.

title: Fiscal Crisis at a Glance
description: The city's fiscal crisis consists of three distinct elements: a budget deficit for the fiscal year ended June 30: an even bigger budget deficit looming for the following year, and a cashflow problem forcing the city to borrow more than a billion dollars in the next five weeks to pay its bills. Here is a look at these elements:

title: New I.L.G.W.U. Chief
description: The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, born in the sweatshops of the Lower East Side 75 years ago, is moving under dynamic new leadership. No union has contributed more to building dignity and decent economic standards in an industry marked by cruel exploitation of an immigrant work force; no union has done more to expand the horizons of the general labor movement in social responsibility and civilized industrial practice.

title: REAL ESTATE GROUP SUED ON BIAS IN ADS
description: NEWARK. May 29 (UPI)An organization of 45 New Jersey real estate brokers was charged today with violating the Fair Housing Act of 1968 by using only white actors in its television commercials.

title: Thailand and North Vietnam End Talks on Ties
description: BANGKOK, Thailand. May 29 Thailand and North Vietnam today completed a week of talks on normalizing relations and announced that a few problems need further discussion.

title: MAYOR EMOTIONAL
description: Mayor Beame, declaring that in the absence of new money we must move from programed recovery to shock therapy, yesterday submitted what he called an unthinkable twolevel budget that at its worst would require cutting the payroll by 67,347 in the next fiscal year.

title: STALEY IS SOUGHT IN OFFER BY HEINZ
description: The H. J. Heinz Company, the worldwide food concern, has made a proposal to acquire the A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company, the second largest corn processor in the world (topped only by CPC International, Inc.). The proposal, announced yesterday by Staley, calls for the merger of Staley into Heinz on the basis of 0.905 share of Heinz common stock for each share of Staley common, adjusted for the 2for1 Staley stock split that became effective Tuesday. (This is equivalent to 1.81 Heinz shares for each Staley share prior to the split.)

title: P. S. C. Aide Urges $50.4Million Rise For Phone Company
