description: ALBANY, May 20A Public Service Commission examiner today recommended a rate increase totalling $50.4million la year for the New York Telephone Company.

title: Golf Cup Is Kept By U.S.
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 29Craig Stadler, a big broth of a man from La Jolla, Calif., sank a putt of just over a yard on the 16th hole today that assured the United States of victory in the biennial Walker Cup competition amid raw wintry conditions and winds gusting up to 30 knots an hour off the North Sea. The final score was the United States 15, Britain and Ireland 8 as the Americans took their 22d victory in the 25 matches held since 1922.

title: PLAN IS WEIGHED FOR AREA TRANSIT
description: Raymond T. Schuler, New York State's Transportation Commissioner, said yesterday that this fall he would recommend a program of additional revenues to support area mass transit and that the program might include both a regional, tax and higher fares.

title: People in Sports
description: Rod Thorn, who turned down a chance to become head coach of the Spirits of St. Louis during their first season, was named to the job yesterday. Thorn accepted what he called one of the prize coaching jobs in basketball. Thorn, at 34 years of age, becomes the youngest head coach in the American Basketball Association and takes over a youthful team that he says has the nucleus to become a champion. Thorn saw that potential when the Spirits upset the defending champion New York Nets in the first round of this season's playoffs in five games. Thorn was the Nets' assistant coach. He replaced Bob MacKinnon, who resigned to join the Buffalo Braves of the National Basketball Association as director of player perscnnel.

title: Inmate'sButterCups, And Homemade Kit, Add Up to Freedom
description: With the help of a little butter and same improvised tools, a suspected murderer squirmed out of a highsecurity state jail in Bridgeport, Conn., near sunrise yesterday.

title: Abuse of Patients at Greystone Verified by Jersey Grand Jury
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 29 Allegations of patient beatings and other abuses that led a group of student psychologists to resign from Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital last fall were verified today by a Morris County grand jury that described the hospital's appearance to the mentally ill as a prison without exit.

title: Nonpolitical Trust Urged To Direct the City Fiscally
description: ALBANY, May 29An outside group of nonpolitical trustees would direct a new government corporation to take over payment of New York City's multibilliondollar shortterm debt and assume powersas yet unclearover the city's fiscal operations, under a plan proposed by Governor Carey's four emergency advisers on the city's fiscal tribulations.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: U.S. Backs Tactical A torn Arms Against a Soviet Push in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, May 29Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger has told Congress that a conventional Sovietled attack against Western Europe may force the United States to use battlefield nuclear weapons to avoid defeat.

title: Business Briefs
description: MONTREAL, May 28 (AP)Canadian newsprint shipments to all markets in April totaled 747,829 tons, down 5.4 per cent from March and 11.8 per cent below April, 1974, the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association reported today.

title: Adrienne d'Albe Leichtle Is Bride
description: Adrienne d'Albe Leichtle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Adrian Leichtle of Watertown, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to John Courtlandt Maxwell Jr. of Richmond, son of the late Mr. Maxwell and the late Genevieve Mangam Maxwell of New York.

title: 16 INDICTED ON COAST IN FILM PIRACY CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, May 29 (Reuters)A special grand jury indicted 16 persons today in a sweeping investigation of motion picture and television film piracy that was undertaken by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Attorney's office.

title: STATE BILL CURBS CAMPAIGN FUNDS
description: ALBANY, May 29Democratic leaders in the Assembly have drafted a campaignspendling bill that severely restricts the amount of money a candidate can spend in an election land puts stricter limits on campaign contributions.

title: Canisius Hit By N. C.A. A. 2Year Ban
description: KANSAS CITY, May 29 (AP)The National Collegiate Athletic Association placed Canisius College on probation today, banning the Eastern basketball power from postseason playoffs and television appearances for two years.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 7%
description: WASHINGTON, May 29The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.2billion, up 14 per cent from the yearearlier $1.05billion. Total retail store sales were about $11.27billion, up 7 per cent from last year's $10.5billion.

title: Bridge:
description: The Lancia touring team, consisting largely of world champions, found itself battling down to the wire in Miami Beach Wednesday night, and for the third time in two weeks they faltered in the final strides when victory seemed within grasp.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Ford in an address to heads of state at the meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Or:ganization in Brussels, vigorously reconfirmed the United States commitment to the Atlantic alliance yesterday, but warned that partial membership or special arrangements could endanger it. American officials said that the warning was directed in part, at least, at Portugal, which is viewed by the United States as moving toward Communism. Mr. Ford also said that NATO remained the foundation in the relationship between the United States and Europe and that important tasks confronted the alliance. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Booksellers' Chief Shares a Page on How to Succeed
description: Nobody really knows how to sell books, although some people are better at it than others, and the merchandising of books is not so much a business as it is an art. Richard Noyes, president of the American Booksellers Association, is better at it than most.

title: Smith Is Confident He Can Vault 194
description: Even with bad knees, poor crowds and little competition, it is nice to report that Steve Smith has not changed: he is as irrepressible as ever.

title: L. Park Benjamin, 72, Dead; A Hearst Advertising Chief
description: L. Park Benjamin, retired advertising director of Popular Mechanics, a Hearst magazine, died Friday, apparently of a stroke, in Orlando (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Naples, Fla.

title: Toy Manufacturer Hits $250,000 Jersey Jackpot
description: MILLVILLE, N.J., May 29, (AP)A 56yearold industrialist from Cherry Hill won $250,000 in the Jersey Jackpot here today.

title: Default on Jobs
description: The Commerce Department's composite index of leading economic indicators has turned sharply upward, which may mean that the recessionat least the worst of itis just about over. But that does not mean that recession's devastating companion, unemployment, is anywhere near a reasonable level, or that it might not yet get worse before if gets better.

title: Market Place
description: Ever since the conglomerate era of the late nineteensixties, individual shareholders of companies that have fallen under the control of other companies have complained of secondclass citizenship.

title: AirConditioner Workers Will Be Laid Off by G.E.
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 29 (Reuters)The General Electric Company said today its major appliance group will lay off 1,800 airconditioner workers here for the last two weeks in June, because of declining factory shipments.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: RATE WAR RAGES AMONG BROKERS
description: A month after the end of fixed commissions, a rate war is raging among stockbrokers, and some of the nation's leading financial institutions warned yesterday that it could lead to the death of one or more Wall Street houses.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Sometime between a guard's bed check at 5 A.M. and a medic's arrival at 5:30 A.M. with pills, the slightly built inmate picked, pried and wriggled his way from his secondfloor cell window using such things as a broken nail clipper, a stool leg, a bent paper clip and five inchhigh cups of butter apparently pirated from a dining room in the jail.

title: Miss Reyn in Key Role In the Stuttgart's One gin
description: The wrong person remains onstage at the close of Eugene Onegin, John Cranko's ballet for the Stuttgart Ballet, which had a new cast of principals on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Freon Kills 6 on Boat
description: SAPPORO, Japan, May 29 (AP)  Six of 12 crewmen of the 90ton shrimp boat Hokuyo Maru were killed Wednesday by Freon gas leaking from the ship's refrigeration system.

title: Equality in the Military: 25Year Progress Report
description: WASHINGTON, May 29Twentyfive years ago, the President's Committee on Equality of Treatment and Opportunity in the Armed Services submitted its final report to President Truman, who had created the committee in July, 1948.

title: Drug Agency Chief Is Expected to Quit
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 The chief of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration has been asked to resign in the wake of growing criticism of his agency's ability to stem the flow of illicit drugs, authoritative Administration sources reported today.

title: Byrne Signs Bill Repealing The State Fair Trade Law
description: TRENTON, May 29Governor Byrne signed into law today four cons'r bills, including one repealing the 1938 Fair Trade Law, which set minimum retail prices on appliances: clothing and certain other manufactured goods.

title: Jury of Eight Women, Four Men Sequestered in Trial of Kallinger
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 29Joseph Kallinger will he tried here by a predominantly female jury on charges of tying up and robbing four women in nearby Susequehanna Dec. 3.

title: Auto Production Is Seen Continuing Moderate Gains
description: DETROIT, May 29  Auto production in the United States in June is expected to continue the slow increase of recent months but will still trail last year's levels and will also fall short of earlier forecasts. G.M., Chrysler and A.M.C. all said they would again have all their plants operating next week.

title: Students' Questions Never Cease
description: Dear Sir: I have been given an assignment to write a paper on advertising. Would you send me everything you have on the subject.

title: The Pop Life
description: On the eve of the Rolling Stones tour, which begins Sunday in Baton Rouge, La., we have not one but two new Stones albums. Actually, though, neither one is really new.

title: About New York
description: At 8:15 yesterday morning Abe Beame bounced down the steps of Gracie Mansion. The grounds of his official residence were as fresh and quiet as a country glade.

title: Bank of Japan Sets Loan
description: TOKYO, May 29 (AP)The Bank of Japan signed a contract today under which it agreed to lend $142million to the World Bank. The loan, which has an average maturity of 6 years and a floating rate of interest is the second largescale external loan by Japan's central bank in two months. In April, the Bank of Japan agreed to lend the Asian Development Bank $100million disbursable over a twoyear period.

title: Hawks Get Thompson, Webster; Knicks' First Choice Is Short
description: The National Basketball Association held its college draft yesterday, but the Knicks' immediate hopes rested more on a judge making George McGinnis available and on Eddie Donovan's trading touch.

title: Headin' for Stir
description: ALBANYThe disastrous effects that many experts predicted would result from former Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller's harsh drug laws of 1973 are now a grim reality in New York's courts and prisons. Yet, oddly enough, the trouble is not so much due to the narcotics measures as it is to another piece of Rockefeller legislation, enacted at the same time with a lot less ballyhoo.

title: CONTRACTS CLIMB IN CONSTRUCTION
description: A surge in electric power plant construction helped lift April construction contract values by 16 per cent over the year ago level, according to figures released yesterday by the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Aye Leads Dunlop Golf

title: Laos, Cutting Away From U.S., Will Get Chinese and Thai Rice
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 29The Laotian Government announced today that it would for the first time receive aid in the form of rice from both Thailand and China.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates fo?? Thursday:

title: Nonpolitical Trust Urged To Direct the City Fiscally
description: ALBANY, May 29An outside group of nonpolitical trustees would direct a new government corporation to take over payment of New York City's multibilliondollar shortterm debt and assume powersas yet unclearover the city's fiscal operations, under a plan proposed by Governor Carey's four emergency advisers on the city's fiscal tribulations.

title: About Real Estate
description: Until early last year. Ocean and Monmouth Counties in central New Jersey were considered the hot real estate markets of the metropolitan area. It was the heyday of the national builder. Several of them were moving apace with townhouses and gardenapartment communities in the Northeast, as well as other projects across the country.only way to build new suburban housing for moderate or even middle income people in the metropolitan area. And just such housing is what recent New Jersey court decisions have begun to insist upon as a means of ending exclusionary zoning.

title: Drive on Fare Cheaters On Subways Paying Off
description: A new crackdown on subway fare evaders has resulted in the issuing of 2,450 summonses and 400 arrests in the last two weeks, transit officials disclosed yesterday.

title: 4,725 on Police Force, 2,869 Firemen Imperiled
description: Following is a listing, by city agency, of the anticipated impact of the budget proposals made yesterday by Mayor Beame:

title: FirstRound N.B.A. Draft Choices
Letters to the Editor
description: Of Subways, Buses and Coordination

title: BEAME PROPOSALS DECRIED BY UNIONS
description: Mayor Beame's crisis budget proposals brought forecasts last night from the head of the firemen's union that a lot mare people are going to die and from the sanitation union's chief that the city will be covered by oceans of garbage.

title: U.S. Plans a TakeOver Of State Meat Scrutiny
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)The Department of Agriculture announced today that effective July 1 it would take over inspection of intrastate meat and poultry plans in New Jersey.

title: Soybean Futures Show Rise; Beef and Hogs Also Advance
description: Although profit taking trimmed early gains in most other pits, soybean futures prices were as much as 6 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Soy oil futures climbed nearly a half a cent a pound.

title: PLAN IS WEIGHED FOR AREA TRANSIT
description: Raymond T. Schuler, New York State's Transportation Commissioner, said yesterday that this fall he would recommend a program of additional revenues to support area mass transit and that the program might include both a regional tax and higher fares.

title: O.E.C.D. Ministers Express Confidence
description: PARIS, May 29Ministers of the Organization of Economic Development ended three days of meetings today expressing confidence that the policies of member governments would lead to a recovery in demand and employment. They added, in a communiqu, that this would be combined with further reduction in the average rate of inflation.

title: Portugal Insists That She Wants to Remain Loyal Member of NATO Alliance
description: BRUSSELS, May 29Premier Vasco Gonalves of Portugal said today that he had told Atlantic Alliance leaders that his country was a loyal European state and intends to remain a loyal NATO member.

title: '61 MEMO IS CITED ON C.l.A.MAFIA TIE
description: WASHINGTON, May 29Robert F. Kennedy knew as early as May. 1961, that the Central Intelligence Agency was secretly dealing with the Mafia, according to a Federal Bureau of Investigation memorandum now in the hands of the Rockefeller commission and the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: He Says He Intervened To Halt Misinformation
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 As Mayor Beanie and Governor Carey were presenting their case to President Ford earlier this month for Federal aid to New York City, Vice President Rockefeller  by his own account  intervened to tell the President that New York State. had the capacity to help with the city's fiscal problems.

title: CBS Official Leads Fund Drive For Press Freedom Committee
description: The appointment of Arthur R. Taylor, president of CBS, Inc., as chairman of a twoyear drive to raise $2million for a trust fund for the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press was announced yesterday by the committee.

title: Article 2  No Title
TEMPORARY PLAN
description: The state yesterday advanced New York City $200million in welfare funds originally scheduled to be delivered next year, staving off a threatened default today by the city but only temporarily easing the city's cashflow problems.

title: In Memoriam
description: KANSamuel Ralbe. Died May 30, 1963, in his 53d year. Lovingly remembered by hit family.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TORONTO, May 29 (AP)Wayne Dillon, of the World Hockey Association's Toronto Toros, has agreed to jump to the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League in the 197677 season, according to his agent, Gus Badali. Dillon will sign a sevenyear contract for an estimated $1.4million, Badali said today.

title: 12 Indicted Here in Drug Sales Alter YearLong Investigation
description: Twelve men were indicted yesterday on charges of negotiating for the purchase of 50 kilos of heroin, making a payment of $350,000, and being in possession of varying amounts of heroin and cocaine.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article about Joseph Papp's production plans in The New York Times Tuesday erroneously stated that the Mitzi Newhouse Theater in Lincoln Center would be devoted to the production of classics. The Newhouse Theater will become a children's theater. The Vivian Beaumont Theater will be devoted to revivals of classics.

title: About the Mets ...
description: In opening a threegame series with the surprising San Diego Padres at Shea Stadium tonight, the Mets will face the major league's leading shutout pitcher. Randy Jones, a 25yearold lefthander who last year lost 22 games, has recorded four shutouts among his six victories in eight decisions. . . . Jerry Koosman will pitch for the Mets tonight followed by Tom Seaver tomorrow night and Randy Tate Sunday. Joe McIntosh will work against Seaver, and either Alan Foster or Dave Freisleben will pitch against Tate. . . . Bob Apodaca, who started the season on the Mets' disabled list, is tied for the National League save lead with six. His earnedrun average is 0.86 and he has allowed no runs and only six hits and three walks in his last seven relief appearances totaling 1215 innings. . . Jon Matlack, for whom Apodaca has saved three victories, has yet to complete a game in 10 starts. His appearance against the first batter in the ninth inning Wednesday night marked the furthest he has made it this season. . . . When Ed Kranepool batted .300 last season, it was his highest average in 13 major league seasons. Now he's batting .382 with 14 hits in his last 29 times at bat.

title: Former Official Says Gurney Protested Inquiry on His Aide
description: TAMPA, Fla., May 29A former Under Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development testified today that in 1971 Senator Edward J. Gurney angrily complained to him about an investigation of a member of his staff.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, MAY 30, 1975

title: Assembly Passes Carey's Consumer Protection Bill
description: ALBANY, May 29Governor Carey's proposal for a new and stronger consumer protection agency, providing power for individual citizens to initiate lawsuits, passed the Assembly today over Republican objections that it would concentrate too much power with the State Commissioner.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The America Stock Exchange this week issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders. officers and directors of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not make a list available this week.

title: M.I.T. Is Qualifier For Rowing Final
description: SYRACUSE, May 29Varsity crews from Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Northeastern and Wisconsin won their heats and thereby qualified for Saturday's championship final as the National Intercollegiate Rowing championships began here today on flat, still Onondaga Lake. There were 485 oarsmen from 23 colleges in competition in six different events.

title: TOP AIDES IN LAOS FORCED TO RESIGN
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 30Top officials throughout the Laotian administration are resigning under pressure from demonstrators as the Pathet Lao increasingly solidify their control over the Government.

title: Schmidt Says Economic Plight Of World Is a Threat to NATO
description: BRUSSELS, May 30Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany declared today that the Atlantic alliance was threatened more by the world economic situation than in any particular geographical area, and called for more coordination in economic policies.

title: Connecticut AAA Credit Rating Downgraded Because of Deficit
description: One of the nation's leading creditrating agencies dropped Connecticut's rating a notch yesterday, mainly because the state has a projected $74million budget deficit and plans to make it up through shortterm borrowing. The lower rating will mean the state will have to pay higher interest on its bonds.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, MAY 31, 1975

title: U. S. TROOP BUILDUP IN KOREA REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (Reuters)The United States has quietly increased its military presence in South Korea over the last year by an additional 4,000 men to the authorized level of 42,000, United States officials said today.

title: Kenneth Clark Retiring From C.C.N.Y.
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, who has helped prepare generations of City College students for their life's work, has retired from teaching after 35 years at the school and himself starting a new career.

title: Antiques: French Prize
description: Two auction records were broken, a Napoleonic desk remained in France and a Frenchman, $96,000 poorer, strode away with 32 walking canes.

title: Her Own Fan for the Filly in Barn 34
description: In the quiet of Barn 34 at Belmont Park, the stalls were identical except for a small electric aluminum fan humming high above Ruffian's pretty head.

title: JOHN W. LEVINSON
description: CHICAGO, May 30 (AP)The professional golfer John W. Levinson has died of injuries suffered in a sixvehicle crash here. He was 32 years old.

title: Shooting Flares in Beirut; Effort for Cabinet Falters
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 30The Premier designated to resolve Lebanon's political crisis has encountered trouble in forming a cabinet. At the same time, new shooting incidents today closed shops and banks in Beirut after a day of relative order.

title: Kenneth Clark Retiring From C.C.N.Y.
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, who has helped prepare generations of City College students for their life's work, has retired from teaching after 35 years at the school and is himself starting a new career.

title: JERSEY ASKS F.C.C. FOR A TV STATION
description: TRENTON, May 30Contending that a lack of its own commercial television station had undermined and impoverished New Jersey's cultural, social, economic and political life, a legislative commission urged the Federal Communications Commission today to move a New York television station to northern New Jersey.

title: Kostelanetz Leads Concert on Theme Of Imperial Russia
description: The New York Philharmonic's popular Promenades sometimes go scouting along the fringes of the repertory for unusual pieces to mix with the standard lightclassical stuff. At Thursday's concert in Avery Fisher Hall, however, the fare was entirely drawn from the familiar favorites bag.

title: Knicks Sign McGinnis; 76ers Label It Piracy
description: The New York Knicks announced yesterday the signing of George McGinnis in defiance of the National Basketball Association constitution. The surprise move violated the league's bylaws and its draft rules.

title: Heimann Reported Choice Of Carey as Banking Chief
description: John C. Heimann, an investment banker who has been actively involved in solving the problems of the Urban Development Corporation, is Governor Carey's choice to be Superintendent of Banks, sources close to the Carey administration said yesterday.

title: FORMER OFFICIAL HELD IN BRIBERY
description: Albert S. Pacetta, who served as deputy fire commissioner and as Markets Commissioner here in the Wagner administration, was indicted by a Queens County grand jury yesterday on a charge or asking for a bribe to influence his decision as a member of the New York State Human Rights Appeals Board.

title: HUBERT GLENDON, CREW COACH, DIES
description: Hubert A. Glendon, former head rowing coach at Columbia University, died Thursday at Cape Cod Hospital, Hyannis, Mass. He was 72 years old and lived in Harwich Port, Mass.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Amex Seat Price Falls
description: The American Stock Exchange reported a seat sale yesterday at $50,000, down $5,000 from the last sale May 20.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO BLOCK A DEAL IN PRINTING
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) The Justice Department says it will file suit to block the proposed sale of the Miller Printing Machinery Company of Pittsburgh to Gutehoffnugshutte Aktienverein of West Germany.

title: Rail TonMileage Drops
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.5 billion tonmiles, 12.4 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 464,051 cars, 15.0 per cent below last year.

title: New Head of U.S. Drug Agency Named
description: WASHINGTON, May 30Attorney General Edward H. Levi named today Henry S. Dogin, a Deputy Assistant Attorney General and a former assistant district attorney in Manhattan, as acting director of the Drug Enforcement Administration, which is responsible for the Federal campaign against the illicit drug traffic.

title: A Riverdale Commuter Bus Held Up for Second Time
description: On a Friday night, last Dec., 6, holdup men boarded a commuter express bus to Riverdale, the Bronx, as it left Manhattan, and robbed its passengers at gunpoint as the bus traveled along the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx. It happened again last night.

title: Sinatra Coming Home To Garden State Center
description: WOODBRIDGE, May 30 May 30 (UPI)Frank Sinatra is returning to New Jersey to sing at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel on Aug. 22 and 23, the New Jersey Highway Authority announced today.

title: Carter Hawley Announces 18.7% Decline for Profits
GOING OUT Guide
description: CURTAIN UP A monthlong, citysponsored Youth Theater Festival of teenage activities in theater and related arts opens today with a variety program by youth groups in Lincoln Center, following a sidewalk parade of costumed performers and musicians starting at 10 A.M. from 59th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Diamond Reo Trucks Declared Bankrupt; Trustee Is Named
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 30 (UPI)Diamond Reo Trucks Inc., which was founded 70 years ago by auto pioneer Ransom E. Olds and still ranks as the nation's 10thlargest truck manufacturers, was declared bankrupt today.

title: WESTERN EUROPE FORMS OWN NASA
description: LONDON, May 30Western Europe acquired today a single coordinated civilian space agency along the lines of NASA after more than 10 years of confusion.

title: Miss Whitworth Leads Title Golf
Heileman and Schmidt Deal Planned
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company of LaCrosse, Wis., brewers of Blatz and other beers, announced yesterday it expected to purchase C. Schmidt & Sons. Inc., of Philadelphia for an estimated $16million in cash and notes. The acquisition, of the privately held company, which is subject to certain conditions including a definitive purchase agreement, would move Heileman from the nation's ninth largest brewery in terms of barrel sales to No. 6 nationally, according to Russell G. Cleary, Heileman's president.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP) Money rates for Friday.

title: Business Briefs
description: Firstquarter delinquencies on home mortgages held savings banks rose but foreclosures were unchanged, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks has reported.

title: 4 Bethlehem Steel Plants Resume Output Next Week
description: BALTIMORE, May 30 (UPI)  About 4,000 workers who were scheduled not work this week will return to the regular jobs at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Sparrows Point plant next week. A spokesman said today all four mills shut down this weekthe tin, pipe, hot and cold millswould resume normal operation next week.

title: A. M. A. Liberalizes to Draw Young Doctors
description: CHICAGO, May 30  The American Medical Association, faced with declining membership and struggling to emerge from several years of growing financial deficits, is slowly moving to change its image of a conservative, often stodgy champion of the medical establishment.

title: Canadian Posts Upset In ShotPut
description: WICHITA, Kan., May 30Bishop Dolegiewicz of Montreal, Canada, upset an impressive field in the shotput at the United States Track and Field Federation outdoor championships tonight, and also set a Canadian national record.

title: H.U.D. PLANS TEST OF HOMESTEADING
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The Department of Housing and Urban Development, not satisfied that the idea of urban homesteading has been fully tested, will invite about 10 communities across the nation to take part in a $5million demonstration beginning this summer.

title: As Deadline Looms, Rhodesian Talks Snag
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 28With less than a month to go before Rhodesia's maim economic lifeline may be severed, there is no evidence that the black nationalists and the Government, which is controlled by the white minority, are making progress toward settlement of their long constitutional dispute.

title: Bridge:
In Memoriam
description: SAQUIBena. In cherished ever loving meory of our dear, devoted mother, departed May 31, 1933. HER CHILDREN.

title: Margaret Seligman Is Wed to R. A. Cook
description: Margaret Ann Seligman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse A. Seligman of New York and South Salem, N.Y., was married at the Hotel Carlyle yesterday afternoon to Robert Avery Cook, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Cook of High Point, N.C. Dr. Paul Migliore of the Ethical Culture Society performed the ceremony.

title: Some Agencies With Volunteer Programs
description: New York City

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Russians Visit Pasternak's Grave, Read His Poems
description: PEREDELKINO, U.S.S.R., May 30Throughout the balmy spring day, visitors trickled through the village cemetery of this pastoral writers' colony, bearing bouquets of flowers to lay reverently on the grave of Boris Pasternak.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Showed Decline for Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 192.5 from 195.5 last week.

title: A NURSING HOME IS ORDERED SHUT
description: One of the patients had bedsores so deep that muscle, tendon and bone were visible. All were unkempt and unbathed. Few were fully dressed or had personal possessions, or knew their own names. Many were unidentified, and medical records were missing. When one died, nobody knew whom to notify.

title: Saigon Bans the Burning Of Decadent Literature
description: HONG KONG, May 30 (Agence FrancePresse)  The new authorities of South Vietnam have banned the burning of books and publications deemed decadent and reactionary, the Saigon radio reported today.

title: CAMBODIAN FLIERS RETURN FROM EXILE
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, May 30 (AP)Eightytwo Cambodian military men, most of them fliers, returned to their country voluntarily today after six weeks of exile in Thailand. Many who passed through this border village said they were going because they had left their wives and children behind.

title: Jon Hassell Offers Solid State, Touches of Mysticism, Wagner
description: Jon Hassell, a composer who has performed often with La Monte Young, gave the first of three concerts Thursday night at the Dia Art. Foundation, 141 Wooster Street. The third and last is tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: STAVISKY CRITICAL OF CHARTER PANEL
description: After a fivehour behindthescene wrangle with fellow members of the State Charter Revision Commission, Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky made public last night a sheaf of documents he said represented a blatant effort to sell charter revision to the public before final proposals are formulated.

title: Treasury Announces Its Plans to Sell 500,000 Ounces of Stockpiled Gold
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The Treasury announced plans today to sell about 500,000 ounces of gold from its stockpile next month. At the present price of around $167 an ounce, that would be about $83.5million worth.

title: U.S. Says 400,000 More Join Food Stamp Program
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 Fourhundred thousand more persons joined the food stamp program last month, bringing the total enrollment to 19.6 million, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

title: Space Shuttle's Timetable Is Set Back
description: Inflation and budgetary stringency have quietly forced a more gradual increase in the number of flights for the manned shuttle rocket plane being developed by the United States under a $6billion program.

title: Notes on People
description: Already the subject of a publishing controversy, the decision by Doris H. Kearns to rewrite her book on the late President Lyndon B. Johnson  in collaboration with Richard N. Goodwin, his former aideappears to have thrown into some doubt her bid for tenure as a full professor at Harvard University. Basic Books, which made a contract with her in 1970 for the manuscript, completed last fall, has sued Dr. Kearns and Simon & Schuster, with which she and Mr. Goodwin signed this year for an advance of $150,000. Now some members of the department of government, where Dr. Kearns is an associate professor, are raising questions about whether the new book might be more polemical than scholarly.

title: Art: On Discovering Discarded Fancies
description: The season of the country flea market and the backyard tag sale is upon us. From now until the foliage turns fauve, we shall once again have the opportunity to pick our way through other people's discarded enthusiasms in the hope of making an exciting discovery or at least of acquiring something that pleases our fancy at a decent price. The hopeabout a decent price, anywaynowadays proves illusory, but there is often a certain element of fun in the adventure, even if one comes away emptyhanded.

title: A General Links Kennedys To Plan to Depose Castro
description: WASHINGTON, May 30Retired Maj. Gen. Edward G. Lansdale said tonight that in late 1961, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, acting on behalf of President Kennedy, ordered him to prepare contingency plans to depose Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

title: Top Europeans Get First CloseUp of Ford, and His Directness Pleases Most
description: BRUSSELS, May 30Frank. Candid. Blunt. Open. Sincere. These are the words used by European leaders and officials here to characterize President Ford's diplomatic style at this summit meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Coast Jury Deliberating the Fate Of 2 Radicals Accused of Murder
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 30A jury of eight women and four men began deliberations here today in the murder trial of Joseph M. Remiro and Russell J. Little, two members of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army, who have been accused of killing Dr. Marcus A. Foster, the Oakland School Superintendent, with cyanidetipped bullets on Nov. 6, 1973.

title: A Virus to Replace Chemical Pesticides Reported Near MassProduction Stage
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.,  A virus that is considered one of the more promising alternatives to chemical pesticides as a means of combatting insect pests is reported to be nearing the stage of mass production.

title: U.S. Steel and E.P.A. in Accord In Alabama, but State Aide Balks
description: BIRMINGHAM, May 30The United States Steel Corporation and Federal air pollution officials reached a compromise tonight in the running dispute over how to cleana up the big manufacturer's Birmingham operation.

title: Rankers Warned Beame Of a Crisis Early in 1974
description: Underwriting bankers expressed alarm over the city's crisis in the commercial money market as far back as April, 1974, and in several subsequent meetings with Mayor Beame sought to convince him of the gravity of the situation, according to confidential minutes of the meetings of a group of financial advisers to the City Controller.

title: Not Paying Jobs, but at Least They're Jobs
description: College and high school students know that jobs are scarce. They've been warned that the summer job market is tightprobably the tightest in years.

title: Anne Hearst Put on Probation For 4 Months in Drug Case
description: BUFFALO, May 30Anne Randolph Hearst, the 19yearold younger sister of Patricia C. Hearst, pleaded guilty here today to a misdemeanor charge of drug possession and was placed on probation for four months with the understanding that the charge would be dismissed if she completed probation satisfactorily.

title: SHOP TALK
description: When The Craftsman's Gallery in downtown Scarsdale decided to have a show centered around the human face, it invited 27 craftsmen to render faces in a variety of media (clay, metal, fiber, wood, leather and enamel). Visages is the result. The faces are whimsical and grave, folkloric and archly witty, and there seem to be an inordinate number of heads trapped inside containers, faintly straining to get out.

title: Port of Boston Struck In a Contract Dispute
description: BOSTON, May 31, Saturday (AP)  Approximately 600 longshoremen and clerks struck the port of Boston at midnight Friday in a contract dispute with the Boston Shipping Association Inc.

title: Chrysler to Extend Rebate Program
description: DETROIT, May 30  The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would extend its $200 rebates on compact cars into June because of the success of the program during May.

title: DOLLAR SHOWS RISE IN EUROPE DEALINGS
description: BRUSSELS, May 30 (UPI)The dollar ended the week with its best showing in 10 days on most European money markets while the price of gold fell for the eighth consecutive trading day.

title: Ford Says NATO Keeps A Wary Eye on Portugal
description: BRUSSELS, May 30President Ford said today that the Atlantic allies had adopted a watchful attitude toward Portugal.

title: Unidentified Closter Hero May Stir Bicentennial Debate
description: CLOSTER, May 30  An anonymous farmer who won fame for preventing a battle in 1776 may become the center of a dispute during the country's bicentennial celebration.

title: Heimann Reported Choice Of Carey as Banking Chief
description: John C. Heimann, an investment banker who has been actively involved in solving the problems of the Urban Development Corporation, is Governor Carey's choice to be Superintendent of Banks, sources close to the Carey administration said yesterday.

title: Kenneth Clark Retiring From C.C.N.Y.
description: Continued From Page 29 time ago when I went to teach at the University of California at Berkeley for a while.

title: GROWERS ASK END OF GRAPE BOYCOTT
description: California owers of table grapes, who contend that a nationwide boycott has had no effect on their sales, made a plea yesterday for an end to the boycott, which they say has become obsolete.

title: Soviet Planning to Offer Small Car, the Lada, Here
description: DETROIT, May 30Trade officials representing the Soviet Union said today they expected to enter the United States smallcar market next year with a new model, called the Lada.

title: Ballet: Exciting Romeo
description: The Stuttgart Ballet's version of Romeo and Juliet is a production for the tired business man and balletomane alike. At its first performance this season Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the ballet again proved to be an exciting spectacle. This is theater in the best sense.

title: RATING UPGRADED FOR CON ED BONDS
description: The rating on Consolidated Edison's first mortgage bonds a variety of issues totaling $2.3billion in par valuewas upgraded yesterday to BBB from BB by Standard & Poor's.

title: WHEAT FUTURES LOWER AT CLOSE
description: Profit taking sent the prices of wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade down yesterday after they had been higher during the day. They ended the day off as much as 3 cents a bushel.

title: MOBIL TO FINANCE 5 SERIES FOR PBS
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation, one of the leading corporate underwriters of programs for the Public Broadcasting Service, will provide all or part of the financial backing for five series next season, including two new ones and a repeat of the late Dr. Jacob Bronowski's The Ascent of Man.

title: Prices Farmers Received Up 5% in FourWeek Span
description: WASHINGTON, May 30Prices farmers received for raw agricultural products climbed 5 per cent from April 15 to May 15, the second consecutive monthly increase, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: The Man Who Came to Dinner
description: BRUSSELSThe position of France at the current NATO summit is both anomalous and important. It is anomalous because the French have not been members of the NATO military organization since they withdrew from its integrated command structure and expelled its headquarters eight years ago. But it is important because the French still consider themselves signatories to and loyally obligated by the North Atlantic Alliance.

title: FORD AIDES OFFER BRIGHTER OUTLOOK ON ECONOMY IN '76
description: WASHINGTON, May 30The Administration published today revised projections of the nation's economy for 1976 and the rest of the decade that were a little less gloomy than those issued last February.

title: New Dental Treatment Reduces Need to Drill
description: WASHINGTON, May 30Two professors of dental medicine have invented a method of treating decayed teeth that has attracted wide professional interest. It promises a substantial reduction in the amount ex the drilling required. The dental caries decayed matteris entirely removed with a pumped chemical solution, eliminating the grinding done at present for that purpose before the tooth is filled. Tests so far indicate the drug to be harmless.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday on proposals to assassinate Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba said erroneously that The Associated Press had reported that, in August, 1962, Robert S. McNamara, then Secretary of Defense, sent a memorandum to the Central Intelligence Agency directing the C.I.A. to prepare a plan for the elimination of Mr. Castro. Actually, The Associated Press dispatch said an aide to Mr. McNamara had prepared the memorandum, and that the Secretary denied that he had ever ordered it drawn up.

title: Nations Accuse South Africa Of Flouting U. N. Resolution
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 30African countries accused South Africa in the Security Council today of continuing to flout United Nations demands that it give up control over neighboring SouthWest Africa.

title: GUARD IS KILLED AT ST. JOHN'S STORE
description: A 63yearold security guard lin a bookstore on the Jamaica campus of St. John's University was shot and killed yesterday while attempting to foil a robbery, the police reported.

title: Byrne Signs Law on Safety Of State Amusement Rides
description: TRENTON, May 30 (UPI) Governor Byrne has signed bill designed to pro?? children from unsafe amusement rides.

title: GUNNER WINS SUIT ON DEFECTIVE SHELL
description: An Army Artillery gunner whose leg was blown off when a defective shell exploded prematurely after he had loaded it into a Howitzer during the war in Vietnam in 1969, was awarded $600,000 in damages by a Federal jury here yesterday.

title: Michel Simon, Actor, 80, Dead; Acclaimed for Two of Us Film
description: Michel Simon, the French actor with a homely face and a Teddybear body who won acclaim in such films as Port of Shadows and The Two of Us, died yesterday in a hospital near Paris. The Swissborn performer, who appeared in 145 movies and 40 plays, was 80 years old.

title: AMAX AND SOCAL SET STOCK ACCORD
description: Amax, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement by which the Standand Oil Company of California will purchase 5.9 million shares of Amax common stock for $333.4million in cash and preferred shares of a Socal subsidiary.

title: U.S. Failed to Airlift 150 in Saigon Police
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 30The United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, Graham A. Martin, promised helicopter evacuation last month for 150 top South Vietnamese policemen, but the aircraft never arrived, sources directly involved in the operation said today.

title: DECLINE REPORTED FOR APRIL LAYOFFS
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI) Layoffs declined and new hirings and recalls picked up in manufacturing during April, the Labor Department said today.

title: BOSTON MUSEUM MAY OUST HEAD
description: A move to oust the director of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts this week heralded what appears to be that institution's second leadership crisis in little more than two years.

title: Finger Lakes Bid Is Rejected
description: Citing the considerable difference between revenues deriving from the diverse operations, the New York State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday denied the application of the Finger Lakes Racing Association to become, temporarily, a part of the New York City OffTrack Betting Corporation. Finger Lakes, situated in Canandaigua, N. Y., had made its application with the purpose of requiring the OTB to accept bets at the upstate track on Tuesdays during the periods when Belmont or Saratoga would be closed be cause of the experiment with Sunday racing, which will begin on June 8 at Belmont.

title: A General Links Kennedys To Plan to Depose Castro
description: WASHINGTON, May 30Retired Maj. Gen. Edward G. Lansdale said tonight that in late 1961, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, acting on behalf of President Kennedy, ordered him to prepare contingency plans to depose Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

title: Rowdy China Fete Finishes U.S. Tour
description: SEATTLE, May 30 (AP)A 64member American track and field squad returned home today from its historic China tour after a rowdy, drunken display by a few athletes at a dinner given by the Chinese hosts.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Saturday, May 31, 1975

title: GOVERNOR IS FIRM ON MALPRACTICE
description: ALBANY, May 30Governor Carey had no intention of renegotiating the medical malpractice insurance issue next week when he meets with dissatisfied officials of the State Medical Society, his chief medical adviser said today.

title: Minimum Price of Milk Rising 2 Cents a Gallon
description: TRENTON, May 30 (UPI)The minimum price of milk in New Jersey win rise two cents a gallon on Sunday, the State Agriculture Department announced today.

title: People and Business
description: A start of recovery in most industrial countries by the end of the year was forecast yesterday by Leif H. Olsen, senior vice president and economist of the First National City Bank.

title: BlueRibbon Bailout
description: The proposal by Governor Carey's blueribbon panel of fiscal experts for a new state corporation to relieve New York City of its crushing burden of debt offers a ray of light in deepening municipal gloom.

title: ALASKA PIPELINE PLANS HUGE ISSUE
description: Sohio/BP Trans Alaska Pipeline Finance, Inc., a company that was set up to raise almost half the $6billion cost of the transAlaska oil pipeline, is now trying to raise pipeline, or more through a private placement of notes. This would be the largest private placement so far.

title: Article 1  No Title
Jersey Congressional Delegation Says Washington Neglects the State
description: WASHINGTON, May 29The New Jersey Congressional delegation sometimes feels the state is being deprived of facilities common to others and that there are grasping hands trying to snatch away those the state has.

title: Most Nations at Geneva Parley Dissatisfied With Nuclear Pact
description: GENEVA, May 30Sixtyfive nations today ended a fourweek review of how well the fiveyearold treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons has worked. Most of them registered strong dissatisfaction.

title: Socialists and Military Reach Accord in Lisbon
description: LISBON, May 30Portugal's leftist military rulers and the strong Socialist party reached an agreement tonight that could ease tensions threatening the provisional Government.

title: Market Place
description: On May 15 Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., wired this message to its salesmen:

title: Electronic Function In Bank's Operationl Is Curbed by Judge
description: DENVER, May 30 (AP)A Federal district court judge has ruled that only part of an electronic banking operation at the First National Bank of Fort Collins, Colo., can be considered a violation of Federal and state branch banking statutes.

title: Actual JobLoss Total Unknown
description: Of the reams of budgetary numbers issued by City Hall, few pose more confusion than those having to do with layoffs and dismissals.

title: PRICES MOVE UP ON ALEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market made strong gains yesterday in active trading.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: N.&W. BARS TAKING BANKRUPT ROADS
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway has advised the Department of Transportation that it is not prepared to acquire large segments of the Penn Central and other bankrupt lines serving the Northeast and the Midwest.

title: FORD FINDS ALLIES IN NATO CONFIDENT OP U.S. FIRMNESS
description: BRUSSELS, May 30President Ford said today, at the conclusion of NATO's twoday summit meeting here, he had found that the Atlantic allies considered America's commitment firm and vigorous despite what he called recent traumatic experiences in Indochina.

title: New South Vietnam Government Expected to Take Office June
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 30 (UPI)South Vietnam's new government is expected to take office on Friday, June 6, the sixth anniversary of its founding in the Vietnam jungles, officials said today.

title: Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy Sr. Dies; ExAdelphi President Was 80
description: Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy Sr., president emeritus of Adelphi University, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in the Fort Pierce (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Fort Pierce.

title: GEN. OTHO VAN EXEL, CIVIL AIDE IN NASSAU
description: Brig. Gen. Otho C. Van Exel, director of the Nassau County Office of Civil Preparedness since 1971 and a veteran of more than 30 years of Federal and state military service, died Thursday at the Concord Hotel, Kiamesha Lake, N.Y. He was 59 years old and lived at 123 Carlne Avenue, Hempstead, L.I.

title: Doctors in Area Ready to Start Slowdown Tomorrow to Protest New Malpractice Law
description: Protests over malpractice insurance are expected to touch off tomorrow the first widespread slowdown by physicians here. The impact of the action on patients is expected to vary from area to area. With some physicians balking at even volunteering for emergency service and others carrying on their practices as usual.

title: Sets Top Friars, 3011, for 15th
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., May 30 Winning all five events for the first time this year, the New York Sets rolled to their 15th straight victory by beating the San Diego Friars, 3011, in a World Team Tennis match tonight at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: CAREY'S WORK WINS PRAISE OF LIBERALS
description: The Liberal party warmly praised Governor Carey yesterday for his accomplishments during the first five months of his tenure but its state chairman, Dr. Donald S. Harrington, was critical of Mayor Beanie's efforts to solve the city's fiscal problems.

title: Prefontaine, 24, Killed in Crash
description: Steve Prefontaine, America's finest distance runner and an outspoken critic of the track and field establishment, died early yesterday morning in an automobile accident in Eugene, Ore.

title: Ramirez Topples Borg
description: ROME, May 30 (UPI)Raul Ramirez, playing methodical tennis, upset topseeded Bjorn Borg, 64, 63, and gained the semifinals of the $120,000 Italian tennis championships today.

title: Text of NATO Leaders' Communique
description: BRUSSELS, May 30 (Reuters)Following is the text of the communiqu issued at the end of the meeting here of the heads of state and government of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization:

title: The Crimson Tide Takes Devon Jump
Knicks Sign McGinnis; 76ers Label It Piracy
description: The New York Knicks announced yesterday the signing of George McGinnis in defiance of the National Basketball Association constitution. The surprise move violated the league's bylaws and its draft rules.

title: EMILE E. BUGNON
description: Emile E. Bugnon, who served for 39 years as chief of police of WoodRidge, N.J., died Thursday at his home there. He was 79 years old.

title: TOP AIDES IN LAOS FORCED TO RESIGN
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, May 30Top officials throughout the Laotian administration are resigning under pressure from demonstrators as the Pathet Lao increasingly solidify their control over the Government.

title: More on Chilean Terror
description: Chile's military rulers are doubtless correct when they charge that they are targets of a relentless propaganda assault from international Communism and that their violations of human rights are blown out of proportion by governments guilty of far worse offenses. Yet, the most telling disclosures about the continuing terror in Chile have come from international agencies of high reputation, without taint of Communist domination.

title: OPEC CHALLENGED ON OIL PRICE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP)  The Treasury Department has prepared a new study of world commodity prices that is intended to refute any attempted economic justification for another increase in world oil prices.

title: George Simon Weds Lynne Martin
description: The marriage of Lynne Robinson Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Martin Jr. of Darien, Conn., to George Tedesche Simon took place here last evening. Criminal Court Judge Shirley R. Levittan performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. Carol Simon, mother of the bridegroom.

title: Knicks See McGinnis As New Capital Asset
description: Just what, the skeptic may ask, can George McGinnis do for the Knicks?

title: Processing of Refugees Speeded Up
description: FORT INDIANTOWN GAP, Pa., May 30As the third contingent of Indochinese refugees began arriving here today, the civilian machinery to prepare them for eventual status as resident aliens was gathering speed.

title: Rangers Defeat Yanks in 9th
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 30 Two wellplaced hits in the ninth inning tonight gave the Rangers a 65 victory over the Yankees after Texas had rallied three times to tie the game.

title: Dow Stock Index Up 17.29 to 832.29; Gain Is Average's Largest Since May 2
description: The stock market registered an impressive advance yesterday in heavier trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average making its biggest gain in almost a month.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Utility CoWorkers Association said it would strike state's largest utility tomorrow at midnight unless a contract impasse were resolved. A snokesman for Public Service Electric & Gas Company said a strike by the association would have no effect on customer service.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday on proposals to assassinate Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba said erroneously that The Associated Press had reported that, in August, 1962, Robert S. McNamara, then Secretary of Defense, sent a memorandum to the Central Intelligence Agency directing the C.I.A. to prepare a plan for the elimination of Mr. Castro. Actually, The Associated Press dispatch said an aide to Mr. McNamara had prepared the memorandum, and that the Secretary denied that he had ever ordered it drawn up.

title: With Teheran's Oil Profit Come Cars, Crowding and Social Ills
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 30The city fathers want to put new numbers on all the buildings because growth has gotten out of hand. Bus drivers have been quitting, saying they cannot stand the traffic. And Western businessmen, unable to find lodging, have been getting hospital rooms.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Planning by Compromise
description: Compromise is the name of the game in New York; it is also the name of the planning process. Two zoning amendments just adopted by the cityfor the design livelier and more useful open space in midtown and the conservation of natural areas in Riverdaleemerged their final form through careful negotiation of the objections of local institutions and community planning boards. Although at times both situations looked hopeless, the compromises finally became law.

title: Fish Ladder Sets a Record
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., May 30 (AP)A fishlift device at a dam here on the Connecticut River has transported a record 76,000 shad upstream during the current migratory season, officials of the Holyoke Water Power Co. said today. The previous record for the fish ladder was 65.000 in 1970.

title: Cornell Crew Gains Final in Title Rowing
description: SYRACUSE, May 30The Coast Guard Academy, Cornell and Rutgers today placed varsity eights in tomorrow's final of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association national championship. These three crews won repechage, or secondchance heats on widdy Onondaga Lake to jo??n the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Northeastern and Wisconsin in the final fleet of six. M.I.T., Northeastern and Wisconsin qualified yesterday by winning the opening heats at this regatta, which involves 79 crews from 23 colleges in eight different events.

title: Cast of Thousands Is Set For Auction on Channel 13
description: A year's supply of bagels, a MercedesBenz sedan, a finger painting by two Bronx Zoo gorillas and a rare Picasso plate are among the goods viewers may need or crave after New York's first televised auction commences Friday at 8 P.M.

title: Amex Adds 10 New Options
description: The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday that it had added 10 new options to buy New York Stock Exchange issues: Aetna, Beatrice, Greyhound, First Charter, Hercules, Merrill, Meas, California Standard, Westinghouse and WarnerLambert. The Amex said it planned to add 10 more in June, raising the total to 40.

title: CHIPAO CHENG
description: Chipao Cheng, acting chairman of the Institute of Chinese Culture and from 1954 to 1968 associate director of cultural projects for the China Institute in America, died Thursday at La Guardia Hospital in Queens. He was 79 years old and lived at 10232 65th Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: McKendree Spring Heads Club Date At the Bitter End
description: McKendree Spring is headlining a club date in town this weekend, but with all due respect to that pleasantly eclectic American band, it is the club rather than the group that is the real story.

title: Dance: A Fitting Conclusion for Ravel
Grand Slam Beats Mets, 62
Air Pollution Drive Lags, But Some Gains Are Made
description: The arrival of the first major target date in the nation's effort to eradicate air pollution finds the program embroiled in problems and running far behind scheduleyet solidly moving forward on the course set four years ago.

title: Irwin, Barber In Lead
Kallinger Identified by 2 As Man Who Robbed Them
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 30The hostess and a guest at a midday card party identified Joseph Kallinger in court here today as the intruder who bound and robbed them last Dec. 3.

title: U.S. WILL CONTINUE U2RUN IN EUROPE
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (Reuters)The United States plans to continue flights of highaltitude U2 reconnaissance planes over Western Europe despite the crash of one of them in West Germany yesterday.

title: LAWMAKERS FIGHT ARSENALS CLOSING
description: MOUNTAIN LAKES, May 301 United States Representative Milicent H. Fenwick, Republican of Middlesex County and Representative Helen S. Meyner, Democrat of Princeton, today told 150 members and guests of the Morris County Chamber of Commerce here that, rather than close down Picatinny Arsenal, the Army should keep it open and create additional jobs.

title: A Little This, a Little ThatPoof! Jewish Magic
description: A little worried about the Evil Eye? Need a love potion? Protection against the plague?

title: Pirates Win in 9th, Gain Lead
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates pinched themselves twice last night in the ninth inning at Three Rivers Stadium against the Atlanta Braves and wound up in first place in the Eastern Division of the National League.

title: St. Francis Takes Title on OneHitter
description: Jack Murphy hurled a onehitter yesterday as St. Francis Prep scored a 20 victory over Mount St. Michael and won the Catholic High School Athletic Association baseball championship at St. John's University.

title: Air Pollution Drive Lags, But Some Gains Are Made
description: The arrival of the first major target date in the nation's effort to eradicate air pollution finds the program embroiled in problems and running far behind scheduleyet solidly moving forward on the course set four years ago.

title: British Oldsters Look Ahead on the Market
description: HASTINGS, England. May 30This seaside strip on the southeast rim of England is called the Geriatric Coast, for it has the highest percentage of old people in Europe. They remember when the sun never set on the British Empire, the white man's burden, Britannia ruling the waves, Nazi bombing.

title: Beame to Lay Off 16,590 City Workers, Including 1,000 Policemen, by June 30
description: Mayor Beame announced late yesterday that dismissal notices would be sent out next week to 16,590 city workers, including 1,000 policemen, 500 firemen and 500 sanitation workers, ordering them off the city payroll by June 30.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Shubert Foundation has made 108 grants to performing arts organizations totaling more than $1.2million. The New York Shakespeare Festival received the largest amount, $145,000. Other major grants went to the APA Phoenix Theater ($50,000), Roundabout Theater ($37,000), the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts ($35,000) and the Yale University School of Drama and Repertory Theater ($30,000). A grant of $125,000 to Town Hall was announced earlier this season.

title: Ford Delivers the Mail
description: A knock at the door. It was the President. He was beaming. Guess what I have for you, he urged.

title: U.S. Plan to Airlift Saigon Police Failed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 30The United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, Graham A. Martin, promised helicopter evacuation last month for 150 top South Vietnamese policemen, but the aircraft never arrived, sources directly involved in the operation said today.

title: Jobless Benefits to End For 50,000 Next Month
description: Regardless of what Congress does to extend benefits, these workers have exhausted their unemployment insurance, a department spokesman said.

title: Beame Cuts Awe Tourists
description: The scope of the extensive cutbacks proposed by Mayor Beame in his new budget were staggering to some the outoftowners visiting New York yesterday.

title: Fahmy of Egypt Says U.S. Must Define Stand and Act on Mideast
description: VIENNA, May 30  Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt today urged the United States to announce a position of its own on the Middle East, including recognition of the principle that no country must be allowed to acquire territory by armed force.

title: Acquitted Rape Defendant Gets Year on Other Counts
description: A State Supreme Court justice who this month ruled that a cabletelevision moderator had seduced but not raped a college student yesterday sent the man to jail for one year for trespassing in the apartment where the assignation occurred and for escaping from the police after his arrest.

title: Reenter Mr. Sanford
description: On a political visit to New York a few months ago, former Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina shrewdly evaluated his chances in the competition for the Presidency. I'm not testing the water, he said, I already know it's just as cold as can be. Nevertheless, he has now formally declared himself in the race, indicating that whatever the temperature of the water, he does not feel frozen out.

title: BRITAIN ANNOUNCES PLAN FOR ANGUILLA
description: LONDON, May 30 (Reuters) Britain plans to give the Caribbean island of Anguilla large measure of self government without formally cutting its constitutional link with the Associated State of St. KittsNevisAnguilla, the Foreign Office announced today.

title: FORD FINDS ALLIES IN NATO CONFIDENT OF U.S. FIRMNESS
description: BRUSSELS, May 30President Ford said today, at the conclusion of NATO's twoday summit meeting here, he had found that the Atlantic allies considered America's commitment firm and vigorous despite what he called recent traumatic experiences in Indochina.

title: High Rating for Gov. Brown
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 (UPI)Californians think Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. is doing a very good job, a survey by the California Poll said today. The survey said that Mr. Brown's ratio of 43 per cent good job to 7 per cent poor job is the most favorable rating achieved by any Governor when measured by the California Pell.

title: 7 G.O.P. Senators Firm On Austerity Budget Stand
description: ALBANY, May 30Placed by their own leader in a position where they must share some responsibility for city services cut or curbed because of a constricted budget, the seven Republican Senators from New York City have started to feel some pressure. But most of them insist they will stand fast for austerity.

title: Nuptials for Linda B. Crawford And Benjamin R. Fisher Jr.
description: Linda Belle Crawford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Crawford 3d of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to Benjamin Reeves Fisher Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fisher, also of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Dr. Robert Cleveland Holland performed the ceremony in the Shadyside Presbyterian Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Marcus B. Hall, uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900: WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800: CONNECTICUT (203)) 3487767.

title: Citibank's Prime Unchanged
description: The First National City Bank kept unchanged yesterday its prime rate on loans to corpora tions. The rate, the lowest the bank charges on such loans, remains at 7 per cent. Most other large banks now post a 7 per cent rate.

title: POLICE SEEK WAYS TO CURB SPENDING
description: OLD BROOKVILLE, LI., May 30The highest ranking officers of New York's police department today began searching for ways to reduce departmental spending more than 13 per cent though service cutbacks that would be alternatives to the dramatic proposals made by Mayor Beame.

title: Nixon Aides Said to Urge His Return to New York
description: LOS ANGELES, May 30 (AP) Some close advisers to former President Richard M. Nixon have urged him to establish a new base of operations in New York, The Los Angeles Times says.

title: Norway Moves Closer To Purchase of F16
description: OSLO, Norway, May 30 (UPI)  The military committee of the Norwegian Parliament tonight recommended the purchase of 72 American F16 fighter planes to replace the country's F104's. With the recommendation, Norway virtually committed herself to the General Dynamic Fl6 instead of the French Mirage or the Swedish Saab Viggen. The action increased the F16's lead in the competition for a $2billion order for 350 planes to be placed by Norway, Denmark, the Netherlands and Belgium.

title: No Doctors' Strike
description: Reforms in medical malpractice insurance, which ended the monthlong curtailment of services by physicians in California, and creation of a doctoroperated insurance company in New York are only stopgap remedies for a complex set of problems. For the moment, however, these shortterm efforts to halt the threat of skyrocketing insurance premiums should suffice to persuade militant doctors in Brooklyn, Queens, Long Island and several other suburban areas that they ought not persist in plans to halt services to patients.

title: Yankee Records
description: BATTING

title: ROY ROBERTS DIES; CHARACTER ACTOR
description: Roy Roberts, a film actor who was reputed to have appeared in close to 1,000 films in a career lasting more than 40 years, died Wednesday evening in St. Vincent's Hospital, Los Angeles. He was 69 years old.

title: Card of Thanks
description: GILBERTEll English. The family of the late Ell Gilbert wishes to sincerely thank their many friends for their kind expressions of sympathy, during our time of sorrow.

title: GOVERNOR IS FIRM ON MALPRACTICE
description: ALBANY, May 30Governor Carey has no intention of renegotiating the medical malpractice insurance issue next week when he meets with dissatisfied officials of the State Medical Society, his chief medical adviser said today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Patrick J. Buffalino, former Mayor of Westbury, L.I., and former deputy commissioner of the Nassau County Department of Consumer Affairs, was sentenced in County Court to five years' probation for attempted bribereceiving.

title: Study Urges Simplified Program On Financial Aid for Students
description: WASHINGTON. May 30 (AP) A task force representing 25 major educational organizations recommended yesterday simplifying the process that channels billions of dollars in financial aid to millions of college students.

title: People in Sports
description: It was welcome home for Tim Foley and Bob Kuechenberg in Florida yesterday as the pro football players again found themselves members of the Miami Dolphins. Last September the men announced they would play out their options and join the Birmingham Americans of the World Football League.

title: Books of The Times
description: After a pause in Asia, the final quarter of the 20th century moves back relentlessly to the winedark sea of Homer. Clashes of men, arms and oil, in somewhat more sophisticated masks, return to the crossroads of civilization. Looking closely, through the eyes of a brilliant historian, we can envision windpowered galleons crosshaired in the periscopes of prowling nuclear submarines.

title: Flower Smuggler, Drop That Pistil!
description: MORGES, SwitzerlandFlowers are not the sort of contraband your traditional smuggler would be seen dead with, unless they are the ones that are injected, swallowed or smoked. But nowadays, the international traffic in plantsthe kind you simply look at or, if you must bore them, talk tois so intense that it threatens the survival of some of the world's most beautiful and interesting species.

title: McTear Is Victor In 9.4 Dash
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., May 30 Every week is turning into a crosscountry sprint classroom for Houston McTear.

title: DOCTORS HERE SET TO BEGIN PROTEST
description: Protests over malpractice insurance are expected to touch off tomorrow the first widespread slowdown by physicians here. The impact of the action on patients is expected to vary from area to area, with sone physicians balking at even volunteering for emergency service and others carrying on their practices as usual.

title: School Economy Move Will Cut All Headquarters Units by 10%
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker said yesterday that staff reductions of at least 10 per cent would be made in all Board of Education headquarters units as part of the school; system's new budget belttightening.

title: Mary Robinson Bride Of Kent Carter Jewett
description: In St. Paul's Episcopal Cathedral in Buffalo last night Mary Elizabeth Robinson, daughter of the Right Rev. Harold Barrett Robinson, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Western New York, and Mrs. Robinson of Buffalo, was married to Kent Carter Jewett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Holland Jewett, also of Buffalo. Canon Richard J. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: Prices Farmers Received Up 5% in FourWeek Span
description: WASHINGTON, May 30Prices farmers received for raw agricultural products climbed 5 per cent from April 15 to May 15, the second consecutive monthly increase, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Unveilings
description: KERN  J. Herschel ana Mathlida Kitty. Dedication of monument in loving memory of my adored beloved son and wife, Sunday, June 1, 11 A.M. sharp, rain or shine, Mount Lebanon Cemetery, 78.00 Myrtle Ave., Glendale, N.Y. Block Sect. 14

title: British Feminists: Still Mountains to Climb
description: LONDON, May 26When Margaret Thatcher, the new leader of the Conservative Party, walked out from lunch recently, the photographers gathered to record the event as if she had just achieved a miracle.

title: E.P.A HEAD ASSAYS GAINS IN CLEAN AIR
description: WASHINGTON, May 30Russell E. Train, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that significant progress had been made toward cleaning up the nation's air, but that there was still a long way to go before healthrelated primary standards on six pollutants were met in urban and industrial areas.

title: 2 Women Identify Kallinger at Trial As Man Who Bound and Robbed Them
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 30The hostess and a guest at a midday card party identified Joseph Kallinger in court here today as the intruder who bound and robbed them last Dec. 3.

title: Senegal President Tells P.E.N. Culture of U.S. Lacks Feeling
description: Declaring American culture is dominated by the reasoning that has provided great advances and technical achievements in the fields of the physical sciences, Leopold Sedar Senghor, President of Senegal and a distinguished Frenchlanguage poet, said that this culture still lacked a vital element that of feeling.

title: PUBLIC HEARINGS SET ON THE CITY BUDGET
description: Three days of public hearings on Mayor Beame's twolevel crisis budget have been scheduled.

title: Erika Wallace Bride Of Dr. Alan C. Kors
description: Erika Wallace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Justin Wallace of Albertson, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Alan Charles Kors, son of Mrs. Samuel Kors of Jersey City and the late Mr. Kors.

title: Mets' Records
